Not to mention the fantastic architecture of the house.

Calm, cool respite from hot weather and traffic. Would have visited again and again - great environmental and educational foundation. Picturesque and amazed at the array of cactus and palm trees in the grounds.

Hello Yves Saint Laurent. An absolute must while in Marrakech. A truly magical place, It is perfect to visit in may. The weather is perfect for a stroll. Extremely enchanting with all its colours and history. If you are a cactus fan you will love this place, filled with varieties of cactus. A good idea to get here is with a cab, try to get the price fixed on 40 dirham and make a deal the the taxi driver to pick you up on a certain time for the same price. The is a taxi stand next to the garden but they will overcharge you.

Beautiful. Not a massive garden fan myself but you can't escape the beautiful gardens designed by Yves Saint Lauren. Colourful, clean and many varieties of plants. Plenty of photos taken and worth the relatively small entry fee, about £6
Breathtaking. amazing collection of plants some looked hundreds of years old great for photos can get crowded go early
Beautiful oasis. It was a very beautiful place to visit although we expected it to be bigger. We took really nice pictures.

Nice Garden. This is an interesting place to visit while in Marrakech with great use of colour and interesting planting throughout the garden. The Berber museum within the grounds is also a great way to find out about Berber culture and history.

A place not to be missed. What a gorgeous museum and gardens. I am not sure which is most impressive and of course with the stamp of YSL it cannot miss. The Berber Museum is filled with the most amazing finds of the Berbers and both a joy beyond compare

Spirit of Yves Saint Laurent endured!. Very nice to place to chill in the heat of Marrakech. Beware of the yellow taxis on your journey back to the city. We payed 30 dirham on our way there, and on the way back they asked for 150. So better arrange a cab to wait for you.
Amazing. The place is beautiful. A must see in Marrakech! If you're a student, don't forget to ask for lower price.

I liked the garden, it is wonderful and nice with cactus plants from America.. I liked it I got an idea about Yves Sait Laurent, I didn't know he was born in Oran Algeria before. I liked the small water swamps.

Stunningly vibrant blue!. The plantings are attractive and include a wide variety of cacti and succulents. The buildings add another dimension, as they are painted in "Majorelle Blue" with bright yellow accents - very minimalist and attractive. If you can go as soon as they open in the morning, you will avoid the crowds.
Go. Lovely gardens, Tranquil feel especially with an early morning arrival. Interesting bookshop and good quality but expensive items in the shop.

Colourful visit of Jardin Majorelle on very hot day. Only a few minutes walk from the Medina but so peaceful! Perfect place to wander for a couple of hours and take great pictures.
We loved the flashy colours and especially the blue walls.
We also enjoyed watching the turtles, frogs and fish.
Small but well worth a visit.
Beautiful gardens. Gorgeous and very cool gardens slightly outside the main part of Marrakech. Gorgeous vibrant blue colours, exciting plants and gorgeous shop too! Expensive entry fee, but worth it.

Gorgeous . Unbelievable what hides behind the fence! What an incredible garden contrasted against traditional buildings. Cactus are amazing as is bamboo grove. Loved the turtles, frogs on Lilly pads and the koi. A very different side of Morocco

Mr and Mrs Mills. Photos look better than actual place.
Worth a visit but it's not spectacular
It's walkable from centre reasonable price to get in
Coffee cafe inside
Toilets etc

Well worth an hour of your time. You don't have to be a garden lover to enjoy this place. Its a lovely and cool oasis of style and calm. The plants are architecturally stunning, offset by vivid coloured planters. Its very popular with locals and tourists alike. Once done, the area outside has some excellent cafes and designer gift/clothes shops.

absolutely stunning. I could wander around this garden for hours. It is so beautiful, very photogenic the colours are breathtaking. A definite must see in marrakech to get a calmer view of the city's busy ora.
Peaceful Place. I enjoyed a lot visitinng this the Majorelle Garden. I was seduced by its splendid architecture and bright colors!
Amazing Garden . This is a must see, so cool and a feast for the senses. Lose yourself for a couple of hours wandering around this garden and beat the hustle and bustle and heat outside. Amazing.
Well worth a visit.. Really enjoyed the morning strolling around these gardens. Amazing trees plants and water features well worth a trip to

A relief from the mayhem. We visited the garden at lunch time and it was quite warm, but lovely under the shade. The gardens are interesting but nothing extra special, as I was expecting. Lunch is the cafe was 'okay', I had a club sandwich which literally had no chicken inside, so expensive for a salad sandwich!! It is probably worth the visit as a relief from the mayhem of souks but do not expect the quality of a good European city!
Nice gardens. Nice plants and flowers. Nice change from the city. Does get quite busy by lunch time , so go in the morning.

A beautiful oasis. This is a must-see stop when you are here. The gardens are beautiful, and if you have time, enjoy a glass of sweet tea in the lovely cafe. Try to get there when they open, as it can get crowded as the day goes on.

Urban cool. Great place to relax in the heart of the city . Lovely marjorelle blue walls with cactus and plants to wonder at and relaxing water . Lovely cafe at the end of your stroll in the gardens . Belonged to yes st Laurent

A beautiful garden, but expensive entrance fee. We were staying in the medina, and decided to take a small taxi to and back from the Jardin Majorelle (too far to walk). This was a beautiful little oasis - you could find a peaceful spot to sit and relax if you looked hard, but generally it's busy with tourists. However, the entrance fee and taxi rides together made me wonder if it was worth it to enjoy this little oasis for an hour. If you're looking for a break from the madness of the medina, this may be a good option.
Unique and beautiful. I love this garden, it is well worth a visit and the souvenirs are completely unique. The colours are spectatular.

Lovely getaway from the chaos!. Definitely worth a visit. We just roamed around here for a couple of hours. Such nice scenery. Really rejuvenating - just enough to get back to the fun chaos in the Medina!

Jardin Marjorelle/Yves Saint Laurent Garden. What a wonderful oasis in Marakech city. Beautiful greenery amidst cobalt blue highlights. The waterlily pond is gorgeous. A must see here is the Berber museum, the artefacts on show are brilliant. The starry night room holding the most spectacular headdresses and ornaments was my personal favourite.Definitely go there if you're visiting the gardens.

Worth a visit. This is a lovely garden with beautiful plants and trees but it wasn't as big as I thought and unless your a real plant's person you only need an hour and a half, two hours max.
There's a nice little cafe, it was cool the morning we went and they do great hot chocolate.
Beautiful. A delicious surprise, of green and cobalt, an oasis of peaceful tranquilitity, plus great photo opportunities to be had, and a beautiful onsite restaurant. My Moroccan salad was delicious.

Beautiful - and NOT expensive . It is not expensive to visit jardin majorelle AT ALL - it's 70dh which is about £4 and if you have a valid student card it actually goes down to 35dh which is about £2. I wouldn't recommend paying extra to go in the museum - we didn't and didn't feel like we missed out - unless Yves Saint Laurent really interests you, as the gardens, boutiques and cafe are beautiful and interesting enough on their own.The garden itself is gorgeous - people who complain it's 'just blue paint and cacti' are clearly very negative people who maybe visited on a very negative day - it is lots of blue paint and cacti but it's also bright flowers, ponds, fountains, bridges, tunnels of plants, tall palm trees with splashes of yellow and red and blue throughout - all of which together makes this stunning place 100% worth visiting. The little shops aren't that expensive - I bought the jardin majorelle edition of Letters to Yves for only 90dh (about £5). The cafe IS expensive by Marrakech standards - however you don't NEED to go in there, but I would recommend as it was beautiful and the juices and salads were delicious. A Moroccan salad, fruit salad and two homemade juices came to 285dh (£20). This isn't somewhere you should miss, even if you end up not loving it, you only paid £2-4 so hardly a massive loss.

Exquisite gardens - a riot of colour. Even full of tourists, Jardin Majorelle is a special place. The assault of colours and textures is a delight - no wonder Yves Saint Laurent felt that the people of Marrakech needed to hold this treasure for future generations. The gardens are not enormous, but we spent ages ambling slowly along, snapping pictures at every opportunity and taking tea in the lovely salon. Highly recommended.
Beautiful and quiet. A lovely relaxing and interesting visit away from the hustle and bustle. Great cafe on site too. Recommend the Morrocan salad and the chip sticks

Go first thing in the morning!. The gardens are beautiful, there's no denying this. I've been here twice now and best advice I have is to go first thing when they open to avoid the crowds and get some nice shots without people in them. Its a peaceful little sanctuary. There are some cute shops nearby as well.
Very nice garden. Jardin Majorelle is a beautiful garden just outside the Marrakech medina. I would recommend it to anyone wanting a break from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech.

Lovely garden. Much smaller than expected - we should have done more research before going as we had put time aside to look around and it was not needed. So we walked back to the centre of Marrakech instead of taking a taxi to view more sights. The gardens are beautiful though.

Relaxing and wonderful experience. The Majorelle gardens are a really beautiful sight and a must-do in marrakesh. We enjoyed our time there a lot even if it was a bit crowded but it is just so relaxing after a long time in the busy medina. The french word tranquille describes it just perfectly - definately go there to wander around palmtrees, cacte and flowers and search for the frogs and turtles in the garden pool :-)

Beautiful Oasis. The garden is a nice antidote to the chaos of the Medina and the souks, however it too can get busy so it’s best to go in the morning when it is not too hot and there are fewer tourists. Our visit was part of a larger tour of the city so we were only there for half an hour which felt sufficient time to walk around the entire garden but you could quite easily spend longer as there is a café and a small museum to explore too. Jardin Majorelle is worth taking the time to visit as it is beautify and carefully maintained, offering a serene oasis for visitors to explore and appreciate.

Stunning colours . Definitely a place to visit on your trip in Marrakech, you will be impressed from the variety of plants and colours that this garden reserves! Also you cannot miss it if you are a fashion lover ;)
Tired overated. The indigo paint clashes with the plants and is tired . Cost 70 dh for 1/2 walk. Pools dirty. Nice cafe.Shops ridiculous price. Would not go back
Resting place. Escaping to the beauty world of plants and colors . This is and interesting place to spend some hours. Also visit the Berber museum...

Beautiful gardens a haven in Marrakech. We visited the gardens early in the morning which is a good time as they do get very busy around lunch time, people seeking shade. We were mesmerized by the beauty of the plants, mainly cacti, flowering and not, but you would expect that with the dry land that is Morocco, and the time and effort put into this precise garden. The bright colours of the pots only add to the magnificence of this garden. We had tea at the cafe and sat listening to the birds. A little oasis if you're tired of the hustle and bustle outside.

Peaceful and Charming. After roaming through the city under the hot sun, the Jardin Majorelle was a welcome delight to our group with it's coolness and greenery. Although the total area the garden spans through is not too large, but you could take some time wandering around appreciating it's collection of cactus, the overall aesthetics of the garden and building, taking in the burst of colors and strolling through its cool orange pavements. A good stopover in the middle of a day out in Marrakesh, although it might be a bit challenging to find its location on your own.

You should visit this garden when you are in Marrakesh. Yves Saint Laurent designed this garden and you can definitely see the hand of the Master. Visit this garden in the morning when the temperature is still comfortable.

Nice garden in the city, but definitely not the #1 the attraction in Marrakech. Garden was smaller than expected and cost approximately $7 per person (without the museum). The plants weren't very "exotic" and only toke about 30 mins to walk through.
Beautiful place to visit. Such a beautiful garden, well worth a visit and if the heat gets too much, go and have a mint tea in the air conditioned café. Easy to find. Would definitely recommend.

One of the prettiest gardens around!. The blue walls are stunning. Not a fan of cacti and you will see alot of that, but it is peaceful there- and a fantastic place for photos. Worth a trip. Only 5 mins by taxi from the old town.
Wrong choice. Went with 2 little kiddies but not suitable for them as its nature (plants trees to look at). Wish I had known before so could've saved the taxi and entrance fee expense

A pleasant and visually stunning afternoon out. These gardens, created originally by a French artist and renovated and extended by Yves St Laurant, is a calm haven of towering exotic cactus and bamboos, small cannels and bridges, beautifully manicured flower beds and pretty little seating areas, ponds and fountains. The exotic deep blue of Morocco colours the beautiful building that houses a gift shop and Berber museum, where traditional costumes and jewellery can be seen under a thousand stars. The coffee shop is shaded and very pleasant. A lovely afternoon out.

Beautiful in the sunshine.. Great location for some wandering in the early afternoon. We were lucky to have arrived at around 12 before the afternoon rush. The garden is gorgeous with lots to take pictures of, not much else to see inside. Shop with lots of expensive gifts to buy.

Calming. We spent around 1.5hrs, Although slightly overpriced for what it is this garden does give you chance to escape the madness of the Souks which is only a short taxi ride away or a 10-15 min walk from the main square. The Berber museum is good with plenty to see so definitely take a look.

Lovely reprieve from the Medina. The Jardin Majorelle will take about an hour to explore. It is a lovely garden and a nice reprieve from the chaos of the Medina and souks. The museum, though small was really interesting with a good collection of Berber artifacts, dress and jewellery. It is definitely worth a look and the cafe food looked great, even though we didn't eat there.If you are catching a cab fro here, beware of the can drivers out the front. Walk 100m down the road and negotiate with a driver there. They seem to ask for twice as much as what the fare is actually worth. Many cabs have meters but wont use them for tourists, but you can insist that they do so.

Great attraction in Marrakech. We loved our visit. The bamboo canopy offers a nice shady walk around the gardens. I loved the extensive cactus displays. Has YSL memorial in the garden. Nice high-end gift shop inside.
Small but beautiful. We had a nice stroll round this beautiful garden. The garden is well maintained and clean. With a nice gallery of Yves Saint Laurent paintings to view.

Escape from the busy city. Jardin Majorelle is actually a nice place to visit if you have time left over in Marrakech, provided it is not too filled with tourists (we were lucky I think). Do not expect something amazing, but just a nice escape from the medina into a nicely landscaped garden. Costs are around 7 euro each. Note that on the way back you are kind of forced to take an overpriced taxi, which will cost you at least 5 euro for a (short) ride. If you want to avoid that you will need to walk to the main road (around 5 min to get a taxi).

Beautiful and very popular. If you want to visit some garden in Marrakech, choose this. It is beautiful and spacious place. Nice decoration and architecture also. There are lot of pretty plants and flowers! Very popular so lof of crowds. Maybe it's little overpriced, but worth of it.

shady respite. Well worth a visit, though choose your times carefully. It get busy later in the day. Top Tip: Explain to teenagers that it is the garden of 'YSL'. My 14 year old was not interested in the garden until he realized who Yves Saint Laurent was, he then wanted to go round again with renewed interest.

Gorgeous Bamboo. We spent an hour here in May 2016. Breathtaking flowers and the bamboo like I've not seen before. This is a lovely tribute to Yves Saint Laurent and it was donated to the city by he and his partner, There is a museum being built next door to open in 2017.

Wonderful gardens. Well worth the visit. Fantastic collection of cacti, euphorbia and palms. Many were flowering now in May. Beautiful collection of Berber art and culture in the small museum. Yves' intense blue walls citrusy the spiked greenery. A must on any visit to Marrakesh.

Nice but not our favourite. We visited the gardens after a lot of recommendations- they are very beautiful but quite small and they don't take very long to get round. We were expecting a little bit more for our money, obviously quite a tourist attraction, would probably pick different gardens to see if I had the choice again.
Peaceful.... Wonderfully peaceful gardens - definitely worth a visit. I wasn't that impressed with the museum so would give it a miss.

Colorful and great for photos. At about 40dh (4usd) you get to see beautiful gardens comprised primarily of tons of different types of cacti and other dessert trees. It's filled with the most vivid indigo blues and yellows covering pots and toward the back a beautiful house (which you cannot enter). The Yves St. Laurent memorial is here, although it's very small and the least colorful thing there. There's also a few ponds filled with koi, frogs and turtles. It's not very big, but it's worth a nice stroll in the shade. Outside is the Berber museum which has an extra cost. We didn't get to check that out tho. There's a row of fabulous shops (pricey tho) before arriving to the entry. Don't be fooled by the taxi drivers outside! Some will charge you double! Remember what you paid to get there or ask your hotel or riad what a standard price should be. Never forget, like all things in Morocco, even taxi rides are negotiable.

Pretty but not what expected. It is beautiful and serene in here but there was a lot more greenery than flowers, may just be the season I went. It is still beautiful inside, there is a cafe, museum and gift shop

Beautiful gardens - a must to visit!. A 1hr visit to Jardin Majorelle should be a "must" on every visitor's stay in Marrakesh. Coloured concrete paths make strolling around the diversely-planted areas so easy, meandering through the gardens, ever-changing views. (Don't forget to look down at details, or up to the heights of the plants.)The shop has gone up-market since we last visited several years ago, so not much in the way of budget mementos. But the postcards are nice. (Everything's nice in fact, just a bit pricey.)A visit to Majorelle can easily be combined with 2 hours' gentle walking to/from the newer part of the city, where there are plenty of cafes, bars & restaurants, and shops too. Walk the main road in from near the gardens, and return in the direction of Jemaa el fna square by another...2 sides of a long triangular walk - if that makes sense! Enjoy - we did :)

Over crowded and over priced. Maybe okay if it was a sunny day but we went when it was cloudy and not very hot. Very overpriced for what it is. Nice photos can be taken but nothing extraordinary. Long queues and then not a lot to see once you're in. Just a lot of cacti and some benches. You can only walk on the pathways.Total of about an hour can be spent here. Not bad, but not great.

Nice place . JM was my number one place to visit in Marrakech. The garden indeed is nice, beautiful plants, flowers and colours (majorelle blue is a very beautiful, intense colour). There is turtles and thootes and a lot of birds. You can spend some time chilling on a bench in the shade. The boutique was nothing special (overrated in my opinon) and the same goes for the book shop, but the food in the restaurant was very good. The berber museum is nice, but the atmosfeer is a bit strange: no nice welcome but a big set of rules: no pictures, be quiet, wait, not to many people in the museum etc. All this gave our experience a strange negative vibe and we couldn't enjoy the museum that much. If the people working there would loosen up (honour the YSL spirit alive) this museum would be much nicer. JM is worth the visit, an entrance ticket is MAD 70 and MAD 30 for the museum.
Beautiful and scenic. Nice place, very pretty and interesting history. However if you're not into plants and scenery I would avoid, the price is a bit steep for Marrakesh and it's quite crowded.

Jardin Majorelle Peace and Tranquility. Very popular we were there by 10.30 and beat the crowds, how amazing to find this gem in the middle of a crowded noisy city, Yes it is mainly Cacti but nothing like I had seen before an hour is probably all you need to see everything but take longer and rest a while and enjoy the peace.

Calm and relaxing. Once owned by Yves St. Laurent, this spacious garden is teeming with various varieties of cactus and other tropical plants and a small memorial to YSL. Don't miss the Majorelle museum next to the cafe, which houses an incredible collection of Berber artifacts including jewelry, clothing and weapons. Traveler's hint: go early in the day to have the gardens virtually to yourself. Tour buses start arriving about 9:30 - 10:00 am.

Peaceful oasis amidst Medina's madness. Nicely landscaped. The cacti lovers especially will enjoy the variety of species. I would recommend the place for an hour or so of peaceful retreat from the general chaos and turmoil of the old city of Marrakech.
Beautiful . Go early as very busy. Worth seeing 100dh entry with museum. Missed this first time in Marrakech and glad I got to see it. Only around 30dh in taxi from Jemma el-fnna square.
Good. Nice gardens but expected more for the price. Was a good place to chill out for a while though. Other activities were more fun
Beautiful gardens. Lovely gardens but very crowded and quite expensive. Only need about 1 hour in here so if it's well out of your way i wouldn't bother.
A place in history. A little bit of an Oasis in the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. A fabulous arrangement of plants with Yves Saint Laurent's home so beautiful and the museum to wander through

Beautiful gardens. Beautiful gardens where you can see a lot of exotic plants, tons of suculents and birds chasing the others in the bamboo stems. Slightly pricy (70 dh) for Morocco, but one can tell the money go to taking care of the gardens :)

A must to visit. We had a lovely time at the garden. Lovely atmosphere. So peaceful, relaxing and calm. This garden is up there with the best horticulturally and blends morrocan and french styles. Berber museum is wonderful, humbling story amazing artefacts.
Very pretty, worth a stop. If you're a garden lover, then definitely stop here. It's a very pretty, peaceful break from the chaos of the rest of the city.

Yawn. If you like cacti, and blue paint you're in for a real treat, expensive for what it is but very small and disappointing, quite far out so not worth the trip! If you like gardens then you will probably like this.
Worth queueing for!. Better go at lunch time. Shorter queue. Always a bit crowded. Amazing garden full of cacti, bambooes and palms. Grab a seat and contemplate it.

Visit early, indeed!. Do come at the opening hour and you will get a chance to enjoy this beautiful garden. Also, it looks close to the old city center on Google maps, but the road is not that entertaining. I suggest taking a petit taxi or a regular taxi and then making your way to the old city after you have visited the museum.Also, do not skip the museum. It is wonderful indeed!

Perfect peacful place. Perfect place to relax in the middle of chaotic Marrakech. Different plants from all over the world. Nice walk and a place to take beuatiful pics. It takes 10 min walk from Medina.

The Berber Arts Museum inside: Brilliant. The garden is lovely but small. Under the tall palms, the beautifully landscaped plants are mostly cactus (a very wide variety of cactus, to be sure), aloes and agaves. It's cool, breezy, but it was very crowded in the afternoon. What's really brilliant is the small and superbly presented Berber museum, only three rooms, but stunning for us as we had just traveled through the Berber lands on the other side of the High Atlas. The garden entrance was 70 dirhams and the museum a separate 30 dirhams (for non-Moroccans).

Beautiful garden and cool Berber museum. Loved the little escape away from the hustle of the medina. It was nice to see a bit more of how locals live with different styles of apartments nearby, too. The cacti garden was awesome, just unexpected that they weren't local plants. The fact that there's a small art gallery, bookshop and museum add great interest. I didn't try the cafe, but it looked adorable! Use the visit here as a nice break, grab a seat to enjoy the cool breeze.

Gorgeous!!!. The garden was a bit small, but the colors were so vibrant and the landscaping beautiful. It was one of the more expensive attractions we visited, but still very affordable. Definitely worth visiting!

Peaceful . We walked here from the medina and back which was interesting to see some other parts of Marrakesh. It was quite a hot day so it was great to arrive at the shady and peaceful gardens. It is a little expensive for what it is, but we sat around the gardens for quite some time so it was worth the money for us.

Average botanical garden, isolated attraction, expensive. The garden itself is pretty average compared to botanical gardens in larger cities. The ponds and other ornaments are pretty but I don't believe it justifies being one of the main attractions in Marrakesh. I haven't visited the Berber Museum, so I can't give my opinion on that, but it would have been more expensive.Another knock on the jardin is its isolation compared to the rest of Marrakesh: because its far from the Medina, you can't get there on foot so you have to plan accordingly. Also, the garden is quite small so you might end up spending more time to get there and back than inside...The price is a bit steep: 70 dirhams (about 7 euros). The pathways are narrow so it gets cramped pretty easily, especially if groups take turns snappin g pictures in front of cacti and such.I recommend it for people who stay in Marrakech for a long period. it's not worth the detour if you're there for a day or two.

Bue garden. Unbelievably beautiful garden. You can't imagine all those colours of flowers, shrubs, bamboos, trees. The majorelle-blue villa amidst the green flowering garden and a blue sky abouve. Heavenly. A real must-see.

Beautiful!. This is the gardens of what was once the house of Yves Saint Laurant on Marrakech. The gardens are amazing, very well designed with exotic planta from all over the world and beautiful fountains and niches for one to take their time. There's also a museum within the gardens, dedicated to the Berbere's traditions, beautifully curated, very interesting! You can also have a quick lunch or a cup of the at the Cafe, also withing the gardens, not very friendly staff but worth the tea. I would recommend it!
Best tourist site in Marrakech!. The gardens are just SO BEAUTIFUL. Some serious cacti going on. Only downside was that it was super busy.

A green paradise inside a hustling city. The Jardin Majorelle is the best way to relax a bit after having a Long day of Sightseeing in the hustling City of Marrkesch. There are indeed also many tourits but you also find a quiete place between the bamboo, cactus, Little fountains and amzing blue and yellow buildings!
tranqility. this is a very tranquil and quiet place to enjoy , very different to the fast pace of life in marrakesh

Pretty Surroundings . Lovely once we found the entrance which is very near the fitness place
Had a great cup of earl grey tea & staff were super friendly.

Beautiful oasis. Jardin Majorelle is a beautiful oasis of greenery north of the old city. The plant life from around the world is colorful and the vivid colors of both the pottery and buildings add a wonderful dash of color. The Berber museum is also very good and worth the price of admission.
Pretty. I thought this was a nice little stop, it takes maybe a half hour to go through it and I believe it's around $7.00.
Enjoyable . The garden was a brilliant place to visit, with lots of foliage that wouldn't otherwise be found in the UK, exotic and a fantastic Berber museum, with its rich and vast history.
Lovely but busy . Lovely gardens and the museum is worth visiting too, go earlier on in the day if you can as it's much nicer with less people.

Incredibly Beautiful. Purchase tickets on site. Our favorite place in Marrakech. This unusual garden is breath taking; we couldn't stop taking pictures! The plants are so unusual. There are many places to sit and enjoy the beautiful surroundings. The garden is mostly shaded and would be a respite from the summer heat. There are many tourists visiting this site but it did not detract from our experience.

Beautiful gardens!. Visited the gardens on a lovely morning with my brother and I cannot describe how impressed I was! The garden is really beautiful: full of colours and shade! You can tell it is really well kept as soon as you arrive at the ticket office. Queues are very well organised and quick. We only visited the garden itself but it would have been worth visiting the Berber Museum too!Definitely a place to see if you are in Marrakech and if you love taking pictures - like I do!

A tranquil sanctuary .... This is one of the main attractions of marrakech answer I can see why. A true sanctuary of tranquility.
Amazing colours .
the museum is well worth the visit

Amazing garden. This place has not word to describe it. It's such a beautiful garden and the price is only 70dhs unless you wanna go to the museum inside which is an extra 30dh and believe me it's worth every single penny of it.
PS take a nice camera or phone because you will take pictures!

Tranquil Escape. Nice quite place to escape the New Town. Beautiful gardens & water features that were until fairly recently belonged to YSL.
The museum is worth a look too.
Breathtaking. An oasis of peace and beauty in a frenetic city. This garden is completely unique and stunning . Thought the memorial to YSL was a bit bland. Take time to look for the wildlife.

A beautiful urban oasis . I visited in December, but I would bet it's the coolest place in all of Marrakesh in the hot summer months. A stunning work of landscape architecture and the use of color. That shade of blue is somehow so fitting. Check out the Berber museum if you get a chance. It's worth the small price of admission.
Very pretty and calm. Go early in the day otherwise there are queues, we got there late morning and it was busy, but no more than 20/30 minutes in the queue
Well worth A visit. Lovely gardens with huge selection of palms and cacti with terrapins in the pool. Small cafe providing drinks and snacks.
Garden Museum - Fabulous. Whilst I thought it expensive to get into the gardens £7 per person you must visit the museum as it is really interesting.

Oasis of calm. Beautiful gardens, well worth a visit and if the heat gets too much, go and have a mint tea in the air conditioned café.
Easy to find, and not to far to walk from the Souk.

Lovely Garden. A lovely garden and a relaxing place to spend an hour or two. Very well cared for but perhaps a little bit over priced for what you get. The Berber museum in the garden is well worth a visit and excellent value.

Shade in Marrakech. This is a must-stop on your visit to Marrakech. While the rest of the city is busy, bustling, hot and noisy, here is a place of cool and calm. Full of amazing cacti and succulents and a peaceful pond, Jardin Majorelle is a place to sit and be contemplative for an hour or so. A vibrant blue enhances the visual beauty of the place.
Beautiful place to visit. Such a beautiful garden. Well worth a visit. Colours are stunning. Museum interesting and informative. Great cafe even though a bit pricey. Would definitely recommend.

beautiful oasis in the middle of Marrakech. if you want to beat the heat you can definitely do that here in the lush garden of Jardin Majorelle. With the abundance of water features and shade the whole garden felt about 15 degrees cooler than the rest of the city. But enough about the practicality, the place is absolutely beautiful. It is definitely worth the small entrance fee and worth your time if you are in Marrakech.

Garden Jewel - but wait, there's more!. The garden was as beautiful and as full of life - birds, butterflies, turtles, fish - as are most well cared for gardens. However, for my sister and me the best part was the small Berber museum also in the garden. This was the real jewel! We were educated and visually pleasured by the amazing Berber jewelry, costumes, tools and handicrafts. This little museum is a must-see!
Lovely . We visited the gardens on a short trip to Marrakech. The gardens are beautiful and very well maintained. The cafe is very nice and we had lunch there which was nice.
A designers garden. A must to visit. A cool oasis I a hot city. Visually stunning. Use of bold coloured architectural bits.
very pleasant. not as big as i thought it would be but still very nice to walk round try and beat the crowds by going in the morning if you can.Also took some lovely photos there.
Beautiful!. A relaxing escape after a day in the medina. Beautiful and well designed. Well worth a visit and worth the extra money to visit the museum.
beautiful. I'm so glad I found it. Charming gardens, worth getting out and about, to find the ultimate chilling space in the crazy Marrakech.

Beautiful place! . This is a gorgeous garden, beautiful flowers with many colours! Entrance fee was 70dh per person which we thought was slightly expensive due to the garden grounds themselves being quite small, however it was beautiful and worth a visit if you are passing a few hours!

INCREDIBLE ARTISTIC COLLECTION OF RARE PLANTS FROM EVERWHERE.... Taken over by iconic designer Yves Saint Laurent,where he lived with his partner for many years,wonderfully colourful landscaped with the most phenomonally interesting plants&greenery,imported from all over the world,particularly the amazing cacti....His home now houses a Berber museum with awesome treasures,textiles& objects from the nomadic Sahara people,,,magic....

Beautiful gardens. A rare, yet beautiful take on a part of the legend Yves Saint Laurent. It was so nice experiencing his favourite place in the world, and was really nice to escape the hustle and bustle of the souk's. You will get some great photography here, many picture perfect moments :)
Definitely worth a trip. The garden has beautiful colours and shaded on a hot day. Nice cafe for a break too. Berber museum is worth a visit too if you like jewellery.
Good, not great!. Marrakech doesnt have lota of monumentos. This is one of them, too expensive for what it is. It is Nice, but not that great. Not a Place you must go, but nice place anyway.

Relaxing and contemplative. What a great find in the middle of Marrakech. This is a beautiful, shaded and relaxing formal garden with some stunning designs, amazing plants and flowers (the bamboo is awesome) and gives you the ability to wander round at a relaxed pace giving you time to decompress and think, in amongst the madness of the rest of the city.
Relaxing!. This was a lovely garden space. We thoroughly enjoyed walking around and then sitting at the little cafe for a tea! This is definitely worth visiting

The best in Marrakech. As being a truely unique experience to wander through the medina, the Majorelle Garden offers a picturesque area, in which you can feel the breeze and be surrounded with a beautiful garden, water and nicely decorated areas. A must for all visitors to Marrakech.
A beautiful space.. We enjoyed our walk in the gardens and the experience of finding this hidden treasure was well worth the visit.
Best experience . I will definitely come back and bring friends and family. The staffs are amazing, the place is clean and I have experienced only awesome moments there. Can't wait to go back there.

Expected more but nice as an overall. The jardin itself costs 70 DH to enter which is a big price considering it has nothing too special on the inside .. Just a small garden with some plants .
However the musuem inside which cost about 30 DH to enter is totally amazing . It holds ancient clothing and stuff of the sahara people.
Heaven of colours. One of the most important places to see in Marrakesh. It's a heaven of colours. Can not be missed. Don't forget to check the shop 33 just across the garden's entrance.

Beautiful spot. Definitely worth doing if you are in Marrakech. Wouldn't say that I am in any way interested in trees or plants normally but found that the Garden was enjoyable and offered a retreat from the busy souks and medina.

An oasis in Marrakech . Time does not pass in this beautiful and very peaceful artistic corner of Marrakech
Colors, light, peace, freshness, nature, art, history, etc...All together waiting to surprise you in the middle of the city.
A real must... An oasis...

A relaxing garden in a bustling city.. An amazing location to relax and spend half a day. The entry fee is a bit over priced but it is worth visiting at least once. We didn't pay extra fee to view the Berber museum. Would definitely recommend a visit once.
loved the flowers and cactus. its nice to visit to get away from the bustling markets- i bought a lollipop before i went in as there were no shops inside

Jardin Majorelle. a welcome breather from the hustle and bustle of city life, a pretty garden nice and relaxin. a very small place 15/20 minutes your done. when you exit across the road from the taxis is a small snack/juice bar.

Yves Saint Laurents' dream garden, well worth a visit. This beautiful, lush garden has been owned and developed by Yves Saint Laurent. It is easy to see why he liked it so much - it's a peaceful oasis of beauty, with trees, flowers and water plays. Besides the residential house (which can't be visited), there is a very interesting museum on Berber culture, and a nice restaurant.

Ok for a quick tour out of Medina but.... It doesn't get the full rate because:- as a botanic garden, is very small and does not have much variety;- as a memorial, it is pretty simple and does not give full insight on Yves Saint Laurent life and character;- as an attraction, the price of the entrance is way above the moroccan standards;- as a moroccan highlight, it is not a core/ must see, but mostly a 'side dish' to the Medinas' atmosphere.So, if you have spare time you could go; otherwise I'd say there are probably more interesting things to see/do.
If you love Cactuses this is a MUST. World's most amazing breeds of cactuses are here. And the bamboo and deep blue provide a magical backdrop :)
A must!. Simply beautiful - not too busy or big but we aware that it closes quite early. Stunning scenes to take pictures of.
Crowded and uninteresting. The place is advertised as a peaceful place in the city. I found it far from that; the place was very small, crowded and the plants looked dusty and rather miserable.
Peaceful spot. The gardens were a welcome relief in the busy hectic city. The Berber museum was to get a perspective of the culture and history

Bizarre. Possibly the weirdest place I've been. It's ran down, too many people are allowed in at once. The cafe is over priced and not very nice. The Yves Saint Laurent statue is baffling, not worth seeing.The only good thing about this 'attraction' is that no one is pestering you to buy anything or begging or trying to shout you over, unlike the rest of Marrakesh.
Cute spot. A little overpriced but it was a nice garden area. Only tourists here. Saw the whole thing in about 20-30 minutes.
Very beautiful garden. Amazed with variety of plants with a beautiful home. Everyone wish to have a dream home like this. Must visit this place.

Lovely walk!. This is definitely a place to visit a lovely quiet walk round the gardens, the views were fantastic didn't pop in the museum but did visit the little shop can get a little busy as it is small an they have a lovely cafe if you fancy having a break!

not worth it. we went there because of the great review it had here on trip advisor and let me tell you that I couldn't understand what people saw in te place. The garden is nice and quiet (which can be a relief in Marrakesh). However, it is small and nothing out of the ordinary. I wouldn't spend time and money (expensive for Marrakesh standards) going there.
Ok attraction. Felt the gardens didn't live up to their hype. Pleasant hour spent there but not amazing by any means.

Pretty but overpriced. The gardens are certainly beautiful and a nice place to spend an hour.However, the entry price of 70 Dirhams (which doesn't even include the museum) is very high compared to other, more interesting attractions in the city (which generally cost around 10 Dirhams). If you are just looking for place to relax in the shade, I would recommend visiting the Cyber Park instead, which is easier to access, free, bigger, just as pretty, and more peaceful.
Such a beautiful place. We loved it there. The place is so beautiful, all the colors and flowers. It was so quiet and calm. Like an Oase.

very beautiful and great for picture taking. The gardens are very well maintained with so many different species of plants, we had a guided tour that explained to us about the history of the garden and how it was bought by YSL from french painter Majorelle , it is a must visit while in Marrakesh, I was mostly impressed by the cactus collection that I had never seen before. I can not understand the people complaining about the fee being paid to be too expensive, maybe they do not know it is a foundation and all the fees collected go to social works.

beautiful collection of succulents and other endemic moroccan species. don't miss the shop and museum , worth it , there are intersting things to see and buy, try those Liberty caftan ( little expensive though)
Definitely visit this is a total oasis . Beautiful lovely trip. Totally recommend this trip peaceful and beautiful. Highlight of my trip to marrakech

Walking in Peace. What a beautiful garden, well worth the visit. There is a small charge and you get the chance to wander with no time limit. The cacti are amazing, they mainly come from Mexico. There is some wonderful examples and about this time of year many are beginning to flower. There are little areas where you can sit and just contemplate, although there are other visitors, it is surprisingly quiet. There is a memorial to Yves Saint Laurent who bought the garden along with Pierre Berge who saved the garden from destruction. This garden should certainly be opn every ones itenary.
Nice but small and expensive. This was a very nice garden and a good break from the hustle but it's really small for the price that you pay.

Expensive for what's on offer. Gardens were nice but not really worth paying the price for.The museum was good and interesting but you have to pay extra for this.Would not recommend the attraction based on the price.

A small paradise.. An architecturally structured green oasis of palms, shrubs, viewing points, paths, a shop (good for gifts) and cafe. Building are painted a striking deep but with yellow touches. Majorette, a French painter designed the gardens and Yves Saint Laurent restored them. They are a delight.

Colorful!. Nice garden with a very large variety of plants and unique colors. Interesting museum also, the jewelry space is fascinating. The entrance fee seems to have doubled though, and that's too bad.
TINY GARDENS BUT BEAUTIFUL. Worth a trip but surprised how small they are some beautiful art and great photo opportunities take water with you too

Peaceful and Lovely Despite the Attempted Overcharge at the Cafe. Everything said by everyone else about these beautiful gardens is true. They were a delightful respite from the rest of Marrakesh. If you are staying in the Medina, they are not reachable on foot. We took a cab. Our hotelier said 15 dh for the three of us, but we agreed to 30, remembering that that's about $3. The cab stand coming back was a harder negotiation, so we paid 50 dh. We were very happy to see turtles and frogs and to hear an orchestra of birdsong in addition to the fabulous trees and flowers. As stated in my title, we stopped at the cafe for a coffee and banana split at about 2:30 pm. The waiter seemed unhappy that's all we wanted, and we did find an "error" on the bill, which is never endearing.

Lovely walk around a delightful garden. This seems to be a very popular place and it is easy to see why. The back story is fascinating: Yves Saint Laurent renovates the old home of artist Majorelle and makes it a must visit in Marrkech. The garden contains plants from all over the world -- and also a memorial to YSL. Several ponds contain turtles and koi and the local kids were excited by that. The Berber Museum is really interesting too, but can only be entered with a separate ticket (30 dirhams for non-Moroccans). The shop has lovely pieces of jewelry, clothing, leather etc on offer but at very high prices. There is also a book and photography shop which has some interesting offerings. Thei garden is quite popular and there are loads of drivers etc outside waiting for their groups. Perhaps the best time to visit is early in the AM. Quite a relief from the chaos of the medina.

If you like gardens a great place. I Like gardens so this was a great place to visit. If you don't like gardens you will be in and out in no time and it is quite expensive. The Berber museum is not great but the garden is beautiful; particularly if you have any interest in cacti and succulent plants. we had a coffee in the courtyard which was very pleasant indeed. a couple of hours well spent in the city.

Worth a go. You may NOT be into viewing gardens but this one is a must the colour is awesome the paths twist around the plants and trees, water features, there is a caff with table service, toilets are clean and no big hold ups.Now if you decide to go to this garden DO it on your own get a taxi from your hotel and a CALECHE (horse & carriage)back fix the price before you leave and go early in the morning 09.00 am before the coachs arrive later on. All the coach trips take in another garden but all that consists of is a olive grove

OK, but very busy. . This garden is outside the old town, so it's a good walk. The garden was OK, although it was mostly bamboo and cactus. It was. 70 MAD for the garden and 30 MAD for the Berber museum. To be honest, the Berber museum was by far the best bit with some really interesting stuff. The garden was also very busy, so not particularly relaxing.

Little to add- See it.. This was one of the highlights of our trip in Marrakech. The gardens are just beautiful, but don't miss the museum on Berber heritage and culture. One can instantly see why artists off all stripes were drawn to both Marrakech and this particular garden over the course of history.

Lush gardens, but a bit of a let down!. I was really looking forward to visiting these gardens.However, first of all it wasnt as big as I expected. What let it down was how people have been able to disrespect the garden and plants by carving their names into a lot of plants!We took our time wandering round, which, other than some pretty ponds, looked much the same around the walk - just large bamboo.The berber museum was interesting, we were lucky enough to visit a berber village whilst on a day tour to the Atlas Mountains.The garden's cafe was nice though we did get covered in falling greenfly!A nice rest and a lovely oasis from the madness of the souks/Marrakech but felt a bit let down with some areas of the garden which need a bit of love & attention.

Stunning gardens. This was quite unexpected. Part of the gardens restored by Yves St Laurent landscaped with arid plants from all over the world - mainly palms, cacti, agaves and loads of bougainvilleas. The cafe was expensive but the Berber museum was well worth a visit and very revealing about this ancient civilisation.
Overrated . Very expensive not worth the entry fee. We walked through within 15 mins. Better ways to spend your day in Marrakech. :).
Calm oasis in Marrakesh. Great place to see some tremendous cactus and also get really lovely photos with the stark colours of the buildings.

Wonderful. This beautiful garden just outside the walls of the old town of Marrakesh is absolutely gorgeous. It can get very busy, as when we were there, but we were wisely advised to stop and take a seat on a bench and watch the people go by. An inspirational garden and the museum is worth a visit too. There is a reason why there is a shade of blue called Majorelle.....and it will have you mesmerised.Advice: upon entry: people tend to queue in one big line but there are actually two rows for queuing. So don't do what we did and form a long line, create the second line- which others did!

Pretty but disappointing . Very nice scenery
Very nice staff
Garden was smaller than expected
Pretty cacti
Museum inside was not value for money
Disappointed overall with the whole experience
Lovely Morning!. Wonderful garden! Get there early or late to avoid crowds and take your camera...som many good photo ops! Be sure to have tea in the garden!

amaizing. Hard to believe it's only 10 mins from the sweltering heat of Jemma El Fna when you arrive here and would say you needn't have a great knowledge of plants to appreciate the tranquility and beauty.Have no problem recommending this to anyone who'd like a little peace and quiet. Dare I say it's quite spiritualEntrance is only 30 MD but when inside, the prices both in the shop and cafe, are VERY high!Taxis and the little stall outside the entrance seem to see this as a bit of a tourist trap and inflate their prices accordingly. Great way to spend a couple of hours or so.

Cool (if also a bit crazy). We visited this on a weekday morning. There is some dispute with what the website and attraction says (open 8 am?) versus what the local riad owners tell tourists (9 am?)... regardless we lucked out because there was a giant group of school children leaving just about the time we got there (10 am). Other than that there was nothing to raise an eyebrow at with the gardens. It is a beautiful, shady, cool place (so much so that I think it would even be bearable during the heat of the day). We walked around a couple times without looking at the map and found paths we hadn't already taken. There tends to be A LOT of posing by tourists for photos, though, so come prepared to be patient if you're seeking great photos.

Just Lovely!. This was on my definite list for the trip to Marrakech. For some reason we never got there until the last day of our 3-night trip, but it was so worth it.The gardens are absolutely beautiful and an oasis of calm in the hectic city of Marrakech. You are shaded from the sun in the vegetation of the gardens and surrounded by beautiful plants and flowers. The gardens are immaculately maintained. Colourful pots are dotted around and the beautiful blue house makes for stunning photo backdrop. 30 minutes would be a good time to spend in the gardens, although up to an hour if lunching. Also I imagine at peak times there will be a wait for a photo opportunity outside the blue house where everyone seemed to gather.I'd say the entrance fee was on the high side at 70DIR per person compared to any other attractions we visited. The same is to be said about the cafe for lunch (I wouldn't eat there again). We didn't visit the Berber museum.We followed Google maps to find our way to the gardens by foot. This was approximately 35minute walk from the Jema El Fna square through the souks and local markets (part of this route was not so nice to the eye). On our way back we took a much longer route; taking our time walking back through Gueliz neighbourhood (the new town). This was a good walk back and you can find the modern shopping centres with high street stores and starbucks along the way. There are also bars and cafe on the route to stop for a drink (also alcoholic!).
Lovely garden well worth a visit. I am not a garden visitor normally, but enjoyed our trip, the museum is well worth adding to the visit

WANDERFUL. Wonderful gardens to visit and to relax. It is an oasis in the middle of the town. You can find thousandths of plants from all over the world. All are in tact and the clerks are doing the best in order to keep the area clean. It is recommended to visit it during the morning.

Beautiful relaxing gardens. These popular gardens are beautiful and like many of my favourite attractions in Marrakesh an oasis of calm in a crazy city. The famous majorelle blue was striking and made for great photos. It is def worth the trip but I wouldn't recommend getting one of the overpriced taxis at the gate, just walk down to the main road and hail one.

Beautiful gardens. Definitely worth a visit! We recommend going early before the crowds get in - to appreciate the gardens in peace. 30-60 minutes are all you need to walk around the garden. There is a cafe/restaurant inside too but we didn't visit it. At the far end of the garden there are shops for gifts and books, and a museum (additional fee for entry). Yves Saint Laurent's house is in the next block (behind the garden) but obviously out of bounds.
Beautiful gardens. A lovely way to while away an hour or so. Beautifully manicured gardens with vibrant colours and hundreds of different plants. A nice change from the bustling souks.

A piece of beauty in middle of a crazy city. This garden is definately worth the 70DH you pay.
It is absolutely stunning inside, the blues and greens work so well together. Very well designed with plenty of flowers, plants and trees to see. Nice to sit down for a bit and take it all in.
If you are ever in Morocco, this is def something not to miss.
Expensive for what it is. Plays heavily on the ownership by Yves Saint Laurent. We thought it was okay but nothing special and not worth the 70dh entrance fee..

A real oasis. What a beautiful well-kept garden. I saw the best collection of cacti ever. And after all the tagine and the regular desserts in the medina, the garden restaurant was such a treat. I feel that the 7 EUR entry fee was well worth the beauty and the cleanliness of the garden. A must visit to cool down while in Marrakesh :)

Peaceful escape from the busy city. These beautiful gardens are the perfect shady escape from the heat of Marrakech. Amazing cactuses, beautiful shades of blue and birds tweeting overhead. Top tip: Buy an ice cream from the seller outside to enjoy as you explore!
a welcome break from Marrakech madness. beautiful place to visit, great photo ops. lots of plants and colour along with frogs fish and turtles.

Beautiful . A must do while in Marrakech, such a lovely escape from the hustle and bustle of the medina. The Berber museum within the gardens although very small was highlight for me, it is stunning. We also had lunch at the cafe within the gardens which was delicious (overpriced but to be expected at a tourist attraction)

Rain or Shine, It's Beautiful!. We had talked to people who had been there and had read reviews and had seen pictures. Nothing prepared us for our encounter with this island of tranquillity and beauty in the midst of a bustling city. Not unlike the gardens of Suzchou, China, this place with its walkways, pools and planting seeds was so worth the price of admission. The attached Berber Museum was part of the package and it, too, was well worth while. Displays are well presented and the English printed guides are organized and clear. And the history was presented in a manner that accentuated the richness of Berber culture, both Muslim and Jewish.Get there early - it gets crowded as the day goes on, even on the occasional rainy day in Marakkech!
Jardin Marjorelle - very pleasant. A garden with lovely plants and a nice Berber museum, but perhaps overrated.The Bahia Palace costs a tenth the price to get in and is ten times better!
Beautiful!. A must see when you visit Marrakech! The majorelle blue is so unique and the garden is so beautiful. Just make sure you don't get ripped off by taxi to go there.

Noce J Majorelle. Was beautiful, I had a cheese omelette and it was the best omelette I've ever tasted. There is a museum you can pay extra to visit, there is a gift shop and a room with some pictures

Beautiful garden. We really enjoyed this beautiful garden, although it was a bit smaller than expected. The trees, flowers and ponds were calming and were a welcome contrast to the busy streets of the city.
I would also recommend the museum which was very well presented.

Beautiful Garden & Nice Cafe. We only spent a couple of hours here but they were just lovely. The gardens are immaculate and beautiful, the cafe excellent and the nearby shops with modern maroc designers were great
Very pretty gardens. A small garden but well stocked with plants, trees and bird song. We stayed for coffee followed by lunch - very pleasant

A calm relaxing enclave in a busy city. Jardin Majorelle is a beautifully tended, vibrant garden with lots of interesting plants. Even for non gardeners, it is a fascinating place, and for a half day visit provides a bit of respite from the noise and hustle and bustle of the city. It is wonderfully colourful and a photographer's dream. It can get a bit busy, and it's a good idea to take water to drink as you walk around. there are however plenty of places to shade away from the sun.

Beautiful relaxing and inspiring. One of the most wonderful gardens i have visited, beautiful plants, the water is so tranquil and the blues and yellows everywhere are very calming. Ideal visit for couples, very romantic.
Very nice. We had a walk there and it was very nice and peacefull place. Exotic trees, nice decorations everywhere, everything well arranged and very clean. Definitely recommend !!!

Tranquil on a quiet day?. I imagine the gardens would be tranquil if we had visited on a quiet day, our visit was not such an occasion and we were somewhat shuffled around in long lines of people.The museum was worth a look though it is quite small but interesting, I was fascinated by the cacti and the graffiti on the plants, how was this allowed to happen and who on earth thinks it's "cool" to damage plants in thus way
Majorelle Jardin. Very Nice Place to visit , 70 Dhm pp fees for Garden and 30 pp for the Museum. Место очень романтичное , не зря эвсанлоран выбрал его , не пожалеете

Beautiful Garden, interesting Museum, but surprisingly small.. This was one of the place I was most excited about visiting prior to my visit to Marrakesh. I was a little let down as I thought it would be a place you could walk around aimlessly for hours and take in it's beauty, but it's rather small and compact. How compact it was meant that anytime you wished to take a picture there was bound to be someone with a camera or 7 crowding the walkway. I was kitted out with my camera too, but some people to hold up the smooth flow of traffic with photo-taking. The cafe was in a lovely area of the garden. The design, colours and craftsmanship is next to none. I enjoyed it, but would say that there are better parks and gardens in Marrakesh. The Berber museum was very informative, but again because of queues they are happy enough to show you the exit. High star rating because it is beautiful, but wouldn't be high up on my list of to do's in Marrakesh.

Just Magic Jardin Marjorelle. A stunning garden retreat from the heat and madness of Marrakech. Stylish, surprising and worth a visit to soak up the simplistic beauty and vision of Yves Saint Laurent. Contrast of line, shape and texture of the cacti against the brilliant colour of the bougainvillea and that amazing blue colour that draws the whole garden together iOS a real delight.

Didn't disappoint . We weren't expecting that much from it, but it really is beautiful. It's immaculately set out and very well preserved. It's also worth spending that little bit extra to go into the museum as it is very unique and well curated.
All in all a perfect brake from the busy town centre.

Beautiful place to relax and recharge, despite all the tourists.. An amazing place where the architecture and colours of the building and garden elements contrast fantastically the unbelievably green and opulent garden.

Worth a visit. This magnificent place should be visited by absolutely everyone who goes to Marrakesh. Away from the hustle and bustle of Djemma El Fna and the Souks this is a fabulous way to spend an afternoon or morning. Great variety of plants, bamboos, cactus, etc. So relaxing. Try their cafe too , serving delish food!!

Crowds predicted didn't materialise. This was my third visit to Marrakech and my third visit to these beautiful, cooling, calm and relaxed gardens. After the noise and hustle and crush of Marrakech this oasis is a must to recharge your senses. The colours are beautiful with "Majorelle blue", lemon yellow and orange pots contrasting against the lush green vegetation. And such a rush for your senses after the constants faded reds and browns of the rest of the city. Do go. But enjoy the garden with your eyes more that through your phone camera lens. Please!

Visit to the gardens.. The gardens are in the new town of Marrakech so it is about a 20 minute taxi ride from the old town. Very beautiful and the cafe in the centre is lovely for lunch. Its cost 70 dirham to get in.
Worth a visit. Interesting cool and worth a visit. Take a taxi for 40dhs as quite a long way to walk from the Medina.

amazing. beautiful, captivating, with amazing boutique inside ( the jewellery alone is amazing but expensive. it is worth spending some money here ). polite people. wonderful cafe. museum with very interesting exhibits.
Beautiful!. I had a wonderful birthday visiting the gardens. Small place and it's worth paying for the museum. Go and see all the colours of the rainbow.

Beautiful gardens with giant succulents and cacti.. This was a beautiful place to take your time and enjoy all of the mature planting seeds. There were lots of birds singing and frogs making their noises. I highly recommend this garden if you are interested in plants and landscape design.

An Oasis in Marrakesh. The beauty of these gardens is difficult to explain with words. You better visit these gardens and enjoy a walk in the shades of all the trees. There are many benches too so you can sit down and enjoy the views, listen to the birds singing and take pictures of all the nature in these gardens.

Culture and colour. A breathe of fresh air in the bustle of Marrakech. I spent a very pleasant few hours mooching and sitting here, after having arrived in Marrakech the night before and there's no better way to ground and rejuvenate after traveling. Follow the curving paths and there's more beauty to see than you expect - it just keeps going. And the colours! There's also a Berber museum tucked away in one corner that used to be Majorelle's studio, 30 dirham well spent to learn about the Berber culture.

Underwhelming. Crowded and small. Went thinking we would walk through a lush beautiful garden, and while it was pretty, it was not worth waiting in a line and paying to see. The public Cyber Park is a much better way to spend time outdoors.
Fab gardens. A real oasis in Marrakech one not to miss, the gardens are stunning and only a short walk from the old city gates with plenty of affordable taxis to take you to your next destination
Wonerfull place. Wonderfull place for chilling and taking photos, it costs 70 DH and it's really a good value for money. Give it 1 hour in you plan.

Nice to visit, not a highlight of the trip. We took an hour or so and visited the garden before visiting a spa. It was beautiful, but nothing extraordinary. The fee for entrance helps to support internationally studying Moroccan students, so it was worth supporting.
Marrakech tour. Average experience. Good collection of rare plants. Berber museum has very limited collection. Cafe food was below standard.

Welcome break from the city!. We got a taxi from the jeema (4euros) it saved the hassle its a bit of a walk and tucked away in a more modern residential area could be hard to find on foot. Well worth the visit, the highlight for us was the pond, so many cute (and noisy) little frogs and terrapins swimming around kept a nature loving 10 year old entertained for ages.

Lovely space to breathe in the heat of the city. . At first it seems a small place but it continues to open out to one beautiful vista after another. Best of all was the very interesting Berber museum well worth the extra charge - loved it.

A garden of inspiration. Visited this beautiful garden with friends. It is small but has the wow factor. Carefully designed it pleases the eye at every turn. The museum within the garden is great too. The cafe is in a beautiful courtyard.A little gem, not to be missed.
Great vibrant Gardens. Lovely gardens and definitely worth a visit but I wouldnt say they're the #1 attraction of Marrakesh

A beautiful garden well worth the trip . The gardens are quite pricey in comparison to other tourist attractions in Marrakech, but the 70 Dirhams for a ticket are well worth the expense. The plants are so beautiful that it is hard to resist taking pictures continuously! A very different experience in Marrakech, but well worth the trip!

Lovely oasis if a bit overcrowded. I'm in the gardening profession so always keen to visit a garden or two when on holiday. The Jardin Marjorelle is a lovely garden, hidden behind high walls, so a welcome respite from the hubbub of the city surrounding it.Some interesting specimens to be seen although the majority of visitors are here for its famous connection to Yves st Laurent so it was pretty darn crowded. The Berber Museum is worth a visit though, tucked away in the corner.

Serenity in horticultural art. Jardin Majorelle is justifiably popular. The original gardens were restored by Yves Saint Laurent & his partner and serve to display an international collection of plants suited to dry climates with agaves, palms, cacti, bougainvilleas and many more in a beautiful setting. At any point you can pause and lose yourself in the designs of these unique gardens and ponds. The Berber Museum on the site was an eye-opener to the Berber tribes and traditions and was a little gem within this spectacular setting.
Lovely gardens. We had this as part of a Historic tour of Marrakech, this was one of the highlights of our day out. This garden has been restored to a lovely place to visit.

A Oasis In theCity. YSL and his partner bought this garden in 1981 when it was rundown and the spent the next few years restoring it to its former glory. A great place to visit and relax for a hour or two.
Must see. Wonderful small park, with an interesting history, wonderful colorfull architecture. Be prepared to stay in crowds of tourists.

Form not flowers. Originally the garden of a French oriental painter Jacques Majorelle it was acquired by Pierre Berge and Yves St Laurent after his death when it looked as if the real estate developers might acquire the site .It is an interesting garden because it relies far more on plant form than flowers. A wonderful collection of palms from all over the world together with a wonderful collection of mature cacti make for a powerful statement.The plants are well labelled so this is a garden for those who seek to create gardens as well as those who simply want to look at them. Not to be missed.
Beautiful garden and home!. Nice surprise in Marrakech. Tranquil walk among plants, passages. Nice house. Everything painted in bright vivid colors - ideal for photography

Beautiful but small. Jardin Majorelle is a beautiful space and a welcome break from the busy streets of Marrakech. It wasn't as big as I expected so we weren't there very long and the entry fee was far higher than it merited.
Beautiful gardens. Beautiful and quite gardens, really woth visiting, specially after a few days walking around the Medina and getting lost in the souks. Go!

Beautiful. Stunning garden and beautiful rich colours. It is small so will not take long to walk around but plenty of photo opportunities. The Berber museum is within the garden and you pay separately for this, so if its only the garden you wish to see you will not need to pay for something you don't.

Tranquility and peace. What a lovely change compared to the busy streets of Morocco. As soon as you walk in and pay 100 MAD for each person (gardens and museum), which I would say is very good value, you find yourself in a place of tranquility and peace. It smells lovely and looks beautiful, I would highly recommend visiting it. The Berber museum is interesting as well and has some really nice pieces. Beware that the cafe inside the gardens is a bit overpriced and that you're not allowed to take photographs inside the museum, obviously you are allowed in the gardens.

Very relaxing. If your looking to go to somewhere in marrakech for some relax time this is the place to go. It is kept very clean with people cleaning it constantly. Very nice for taking photos and enjoying the sun.

The most beautiful gardens I have visited. You won't believe the graffiti on the cacti, scratched in for the eternity of the plant, a sight in itself. These gardens are magnificent, take time to go slowly through them and really soak it in. I'm not a typical garden visitor, but these gardens are a must see!! So many different forms, colours and creations, you will be wowed when you turn a corner and find yourself in a totally different zone, like night and day. Yves St Laurent memorial garden is also here. Some areas are out of bounds, should you stroll where you are not allowed you will be gently asked to go back, it's hard to pay attention to the signs when you are surrounded by so much beauty. Bamboo groves where you see so many different types! A real experience, not to be missed! There were turtles in a fountain, a cat in the cacti garden, and birds elsewhere. A MUST DO!!!
Should come here on your 1st day.. This is a beautiful garden but the museum is even better in my opinion. Visit here on your first day to get a better understanding of the Moroccan history.

Exotic and cool (literally). This was like an oasis. Beautiful garden and interesting buildings. Plants weren't only moroccan but from all over the wolrd. The grave of Yves Saint-Lauren was surprise for us. Really worth visiting (and good student discounts).

A cool oasis in the heart of Marrakesh. Must see.. Compact and quite small gardens which cool shade from trees and cactus in abundance. The blue and yellow colour on pots and pond edges was great and reflected Yves St Laurant and his taste. Do not miss out on the existing museum.

Pleasant Escape. From the noisy streets outside you step inside the outer wall to tranquility.It costs 70 dh for the garden and an additional 30 dh for the museum which we opted not to go into. Yves Saint Laurent bought the villa and garden to preserve the original form.There are plants and cacti from many places including Mexico, Australia, California and Indonesia here and the colours of the plant pots and walls, doors make for incredible photos !!

Lovely oasis away from hustle & bustle of the medina.. Its a nice 15min walk from the main square in the medina. A lovely, well kept park donated by Yves Saint Laurant, lots of colours and plenty of photo opportunities. Take a minute to sit on a bench & unwind. Lovely quiet sanctuary.

Beautiful oasis in Marrakech. I love this place. I have been back both times I went to Marrakech, and I will be going back next time because apparently the museum is worth a visit and I haven't been in yet! It is a peaceful, beautiful place and a credit to Yves Saint Laurent for saving it from disappearing. The plants create a shield from the sun and the streets and the painted pots and colours have a v relaxing effect. This time I went with my 2 daughters and they were inspired by it too! The cafe is not cheap by Marrakech standards but food is good and there is a good kids menu.

Oasis in the City. Excellent spot for those with an interest in trees and plants and a good visit for the everyone. We went as a family - I enjoyed it and our kids enjoyed the stop more than I expected.

Amazing for photos. Such a pretty garden, perfect background for pictures.
30 mins there is enough to go around. Would definitely recommend going.
wow! Must see. Not a walk distance from Jamaa el Fna but definitely worth a taxi ride (40/50 dh). Extremely well looked after, beautiful gardens!

Beautiful and relaxing. Wonderful colors and plants and trees.
10 dirham. (80 pence)
The blue is magnifient and made naturally with a stone from the region. I spent time on a bench relaxing. It is worth the visit.

Beautiful oasis in marrakech. A bit of a line up in the morning to get in but totally worth the walk there. We had lunch at the cafe. Typical moroccan salads, my husband had the sardines sandwich, he loved it. Worth visiting!

Great historic site. The cost of the fee for the Islamic Art Museum and botanical garden together was $100dhs It's a lot of cactus collection and blue Majorelle. After Yves Saint Laurent died in 2008 his ashes were scattered in Majorelle Garden. The museum has lots of collection includes North African textiles from Saint Laurent's personal collection as well ceramics, jewelry, and paintings by Majorelle. There is gift shop and restaurant.It's a must see.

This was an interesting garden filled with exotic plants.. There were many exotic plants here which were interesting to see. The colors of the buildings and contrasting floral blooms makes for great photo ops. You will be with many other people snapping photos of this unusual place.

Colours and quality of plants - outstanding. A must see for all garden enthusiasts. A wonderful collection of succulents and cacti from around the world. It is so clean here and I think I spotted only one plant that looked a bit sorry for its self. If you are into photography it would be hard not to get a great shot here. The colours of the walkway and pots really zing out.

Must See. After reading reviews saying there would be a long queue and we would pay a lot to get in, I was wary. However, it was relatively cheap we thought, and we queued for less than 10 minutes even though the queue was fairly long (I can imagine in summer there would be a wait).The garden was lovely, well kept and people were cleaning throughout the day. The museum was a lot better than expected, although you can't take pictures inside. The decor is lovely!
Beautiful. A welcome quite retreat from the hustle and bustle of the square. Beautiful gardens with amazing smells and sights. Look for the turtles and frogs in the pond.

beautiful botanical garden. Supposed to be one of marrakech highlights this beautiful garden is a nice hideway in a bustling city, but .....also very popular with tourists. So go there in the early morning or late afternoon

Beautiful YSL gardens. This is a stunning collection of plants in a well manicured garden. The trust that looks after it really keeps it in a beautiful condition. The house is now a studio with a historic Berber collection.To access the gardens, you can walk from Marrakech - it is about 45mins from Jemma el Fna. Or a 30-40dirham taxi (depending on your negotiation skills!)

Unbelievable Color. I once listened to an interview with Oliver Sacks in which he discussed taking a cocktail of hallucinogenic drugs in order to see the color of heaven - which he imagined as an impossibly bright yet saturated hue of blue. That was how I felt taking in the Majorelle blue walls of the Jardin Majorelle one sunny afternoon. The blue was so deep and bright in the sunlight that it almost vibrated. I had to avert my eyes. And I was completely sober! The gardens themselves are mostly a collection of interesting cactuses and local plants, some of which were flowering during our visit. Many of the larger plants had funny and romantic graffiti carved into them in diverse languages, which was actually incredibly charming.
AMAZING. If you're a fashion, nature and plant enthusiast make sure you go. Also great for photographers too.

Calm and Cool. If you have had enough of the hubub of Jemaa el Fna then a trip to the Jardin Majorelle is recommended. We had to queue and paid around £6 to get in but the queue went quite quickly. Inside it is cool and calming and nice to sit on a bench in the shade. The plants are architectural but don't be tempted to vere off the set pathways as you will be told off! Not sure why Yves Saint Laurent has a memorial there - i think he spent a lot of time in the area - but it's cool.
Nothing special. I was expecting more about the jardin Majorelle. It was small and not worth the 70 dhm. Cafe inside the jarding was not worth the money aswell.

A wonder and an oasis of tranquility in a lively city. Yves Saint Laurent and his partner Pierre Bergé saved this site form falling apart and being taken over by developers back in the seventies and rightly so. Now this wonderful garden sits in a nice part of town and showcases Morrocco and Africa's best specimen of cacti, palm and hot weather hardies. Of course the cleanliness and order are outstanding once you step into this YSL world and it makes you appreciate why order is so important to us mortals: it is utterly calming.And yet this god of fashion has shown us how to appreciate the simpler things in life and one that he only came in contact with when he was here, in Marrakesh, to switch off: NATURE. At the end of your reflective and colourful tour of this Majorelle garden, you will be happy to alight in the café there, where the charming staff are totally devoted to your comfort. Woe betide the scantily dressed women though, as generally, in the Muslim world they are considered a joke and what's more, of lose morals and thus fair game.
