Quiet escape within the city. Beautiful gardens. The gardens are nearly completely shaded, making it a great activity for a warm day.

Lovely gardens - worth the walk. Finding the Gardens is easy and it is interesting to walk from the Medina to the gardens and experience the changing environment from the old Medina to the newer Marrakech. Inside the gardens are well laid out and beautifully restored. The Museum is worth paying extra to see. The cafe is a little expensive.
Small, but worth a look. It's small, but it's well looked after and definitely worth a trip. It was quite busy when i went, I'd much rather see it in quieter times.

Bit disappointing. I wanted somewhere green and calm and I certain got this. The gardens were beautiful and well maintained. Unfortunately there were too many other people there to make it a truly relaxing enjoyable visit.

Peaceful and lovely. Nice place to go to get away from busy Marrakech and to relax. Spent over an hour walking around the gardens, taking photos and sitting for a while enjoying the cool air. Definitely recommend to visit however much dearer than all other tourist spots (although still only £10 for two people).

Lush but petite. This is a very nice garden but overall I can't say that we enjoyed it any more than the many other beautiful parks and gardens in the city ( and the others are free and far fewer people). Nice lunch with friendly staff within the garden.
Bleu Majorelle . The gardens are stunning. That blue background with all the foliage and the water features. So tranquil and captivating! I'm definitely painting my bathroom that same blue now!
Must visit. YSL reclaimed little heaven. Great to relax and absorb the little nocks and corners. Flowers and small pathways, including the water channels are beautiful.
Beautiful and peaceful. A nice reprieve from the noise of Marrakesh. Beautiful colours, but seemed oddly placed as it has little, if anything to do with Morocco.
Garden visit . An amazing garden. A jewel. Delightful to visit. A veritable oasis. I loved it. Just outside the city but worth the walk to get the vibe.
Best in Morocco Yet. Loved this place, slightly more expensive than other museums etc but well worth it. Serene, calm, nice history and the best museum we have seen in Morocco.

Jardin Majorelle calm and tranquil. i visited the gardens in October,its best to get there early am as the queues can be long A beautiful calm and tranquil oasis in busy Marrakesh ,bursting with color and amazing plants Definitely worth a visit

Shady spot. Walked here from the Medina and got lost on the way back but worth it. Beautifully designed and got some fantastic pictures. It's small but plenty seating and spots to loiter and take in the views. Toilets clean if you need to use them and staff available but discrete. Shopping beautiful if you fancy a treat and some more expensive gift shops nearby.
A hidden oasis of green. Nice garden with lots of shade and a little quite break from the noisy Marrakech.. Recommend the berber-museum.

Excellent Garden . I visited Jardin Majorelle during a recent trip to Marrakech based on Trip Advisor recommendation. Excellent garden with a variety of cacti and plants & very relaxing. It's a must see.

Not usually my thing.... I'm not one to specifically visit gardens whilst travelling however I'm glad we did visit Jardin Majorelle. Some of the items I bought from the gift store were the best quality gifts I bought in Morocco! There are some lovely shops just outside too. The gardens were lovely.
Lovely gardens; very relaxing. Lovely gardens and a nice temperature out of the sun. You won't be there long - quite small. Restaurant available.

One of the prettiest in the world. Worth every penny and it should be on your list of things to do even if you are not into plants. Beautiful setting, vibrant colors and perfectly planned out. There are great shops and a few restaurants near the gardens too.
Oasis in the centre of town. Beautiful gardens, nice and cool in the heat of the day. Great restaurant for a sandwich and mint tea

An unexpected delight in Marrakech!. The Jardin garden and adjacent Berber museum were an amazing surprise during my time in Marrakech! The garden is simply beautiful and the Berber museum is the most breathtaking display of a culture that I have ever seen. Both were unexpected delights during my time in Marrakech. Don't miss them!

Beauty, like a rose amongst the thorns. The Jardin Marjorelle is a truly beautiful garden likened to a small botanical garden you would expect in any city of the world. The history is such that you admire the tenacity of Yves St. Laurent and Pierre Berge to restore it to this present splendour. The plants and setting are stunningly presented and the Lapis blue colouring throughout the garden takes your eye and makes you sigh. The exhibition inside of the Berber jewellery is a revelation in itself. All up, a breath of fresh air in a teeming area which will restore your spirit and your soul.
nice, if you like this kind of thing. if you like gardens, then this is nice. Museum was interesting. Haggle with the caleche outside if you wana go medina from here. Otherwise get a cab

Stunning Gardens, well worth the visit. A taxi from the square to the gardens should cost only 10-15 MAD, make sure to bargin as we were first quoted 60!!Once there we grabbed a gelato from the café opposite and took the chance to eat it and relax whilst walking around the gardens.The gardens are shaded and offer a lovely reapite from the heat. We particularly enjoyed the turtles and frogs in the large main pond.A taxi back to the square will cost a little more (they have to pay 5 for parking) but it's a lovely little detour and a good chance to unwind.
Lovely garden. Went in January this year and had a nice time exploring the garden, it's really peaceful and is nicely laid out. At times it felt a bit full of people.

Beautiful gardens. Well worth a couple of hours. Gardens are tranquil and extremely well maintained. The museum is worth the extra cost, especially the mirrored Jewel room. Spectacular!December is a good time to visit, not crowded and warm enough to be able to enjoy the gardens without pressure.
Must see oasis in the middle of Marrakech. Marrakech is a bustling city with lots of people and chaos...the gardens are an escape from it all. It is well worth a visit.

Swanky Oasis Among Marrakesh's Circus . The minute you arrive to the Jardin Majorelle you are inspired by the high-class style and influence of the garden's famous investor Yves Saint Laurant. You only need an hour to explore the grounds and the museum, as it's fairly small, or you can extend your stay with lunch or tea at the cafe, which offers a mix of traditional Moroccan and some more international dishes. The Berber Museum, which introduces Berber Culture is also quite small but beautifully done and a stark contrast to the far less curated Dar Sid Said museum (also in Marrakesh) - stick with the Berber museum over the two, for sure - you can see where your $10 entry fees go.
Beautiful Garden. Great break from the hustle of the markets and the motorbikes and mopeds riding down the pavement. Very beautiful a lot smaller than I expected but very nice.
Serene . We spent 45 minutes exploring here, it's chilled and pretty. Very good for getting away from the madness of the markets. Good for photos, everything is very colourful.
Beautiful!. Amazing gardens beautifully restored by Yves Saint Laurent. A must visit! The gardens have plants from every side of the world!

Peaceful haven in a bustling city. This garden is a must if you are visiting Marrakech. You can easily forget that you are in a noisy city once you are in this beautiful serene garden. The planting is interesting, some very large cacti and palms and the colour is mainly brought in by painted pots and walls. We though that the memorial to Yves St Laurent was surprisingly plain given that he was a world famous fashion designer, but the mosaics, bright blue walls and terracotta pots all made up for this.
Something different. The Jardin, is a welcome change from the small bustling and chaotic alleys of the Medina. Well kept, beautiful restaurant, and definitely worth a visit when in Marrakech.

Over designed, smaller than expected. The garden is pleasant but not amazing, the bright orange and yellow pots felt a bit out of place, the the blue water features were good. The museum is very small but perfectly formed - elevating Berber artefacts to the level of art. Its a bit of an Yves San Laurent shrine.

for the artistic and/ or botanically interested. fascinating insight into the life and work of both the original artist owner jaque majorelle and also the subsequent owner yves saint laurant good museum too about the berber people

Lovely gardens. A great visit as the place has not been spoils. Makes sure you go the small museum inside.
The place is very uncommercial and was worth the entrance fee.
Tranquillity. Visited gardens end November. Could not believe that such a tranquil place can exist in the heart of city. Beautiful colours & layout.

Quaint, but small. Very pleasant gardens and a nice relaxing stroll away from the chaos that is Marrakech - however the gardens are a lot smaller than we expected and not that much variety of plant life to see.
Tourist . This garden was so relaxing. Everything was spotless. Not too expensive. The plants were very interesting. The pools of water very calming
so good.. it is the best garden to visit in marachesh, even in morrocco. you pay about 70 dirhems , 25 turkish liras, about 8 dolars but it worths it.

Beautiful oasis in the city. A short trip, but a beatiful stop as I was exploring the city. Well worth a visit - bring a book and spend some time in the garden relaxing.
Don't forget your camera!

Gorgeous but expensive entry. The Jardin Majorelle was one of the best attractions in Marrakesh and it is worth paying the upscale price to see it. Go in the off season or early in the day or else there are a tons of tourists there

Nice place . It's a nice garden with nice colores a decoration, they have a nice little café
It's worth visiting and will not take a very long time to see it all.

Nice reprieve from the city streets . I desperately needed a break from the streets of Marrakech as a solo female traveler a couple of weeks ago. The garden was the perfect spot. It's quiet, beautiful, and has tons of benches for sitting in the silence of this little oasis in the city. The museum inside is very small with an overpriced entry, but is educational & interesting. The gardens are clean, well maintained, & beautiful.

Easy to get too and well worth the visit €10 entry but well worth the price. Visited these gardens which given to the Moroccan government by Ralph Lauren who lived there for a number of years Lovely gardens and well looked after lots of photos and other momento of the period he lived there.The place gets very busy so it's best to go early or late in the evening an hour should be enough there . Coffee and souvenir shop on sight so all your requirements are looked after we visited individuals so no guide but we managed other people in groups were guided but it's not necessary if you want you can tag on with one of the tours if you want.Martin Mayo
Beautiful gardens even in the rain!. A must to see! The gardens and colors are beautiful. A bit of heaven in the bustling city. Enjoyed the museum and the cafe for a spot of tea.

A refreshing island. An oasis in the middle of jungle. When you first get in you say wow, what a small nice garden. When you finish, you say how come this place can be this large. That is because of being exceptionally well organising. In the garden there is a berberi museum. Definitely get in and see some of berberi culture.

Dont expect lying on the grass. ... or sitting in the sun.. this garden is smaller than I hoped and it was full with tourists when I arrived (end of the day). You can see this in 20 minutes or less. If you get a taxi at the taxi stand, the taxi pays 10 dr to the taxistand, so he can ask less if you walk a bit away.20 dirams to Fna/big square in daytime, or 10 dirams more at the taxistand
Gorgeous. A lovely and tranquil place to visit with a spectacular array of succulents and beautiful design. Worth a trip.

Middle Class Escape for Horticulturalists. Lovely antidote to the bustle of Marrakech - cafe/restaurant is full of Royal Horticultural Society members and French bourgeoisie in their Panama hats and air kissing ways. Not to be missed, for its people watching, the place to see and be seen. Garden has been maintained as Yves Saint Laurent left it and is a delight BTW.

Good If You Like Garden and Fashion Fan. I can't remember how much I paid for the entrance, but it wasn't super cheap. It is a good size garden, and sort of an oasis in the desert. It's an OK garden, with a huge variety of plants. It could be a great place to sit down and relax, but there are not many seating options in the garden itself. It can take you 15 mins to an hours to visit, it depends on you.

Nice and relaxing. Nice and relaxing away from the hustle and bustle. Easy to find and kids go free. My son enjoyed this (7 years old). Would recommend this and the museum is worth a visit just for the last room with the stars and mirrors! Jaw dropping room!!!
Lovely excursion. The gardens are lovely and we had an enjoyable time exploring it. We also enjoyed lunch at the local restaurant. It was a little expensive but the food was good.
Nice Gardens. I thought it would have been bigger but is a nice respite from the hustle and bustle of the town. Beautiful blues everywhere. Be sure to take a cab from old town.

Beautiful-well laid out - An Oasis. This Garden, where Yves St. Laurin is buried, is a testament to beauty and good taste. It is well worth the trip. Beautiful tropical flowers adorn the outer edges of the garden while cactus of every variety abound the interior. Pools scattered around keep the serene quiet, and the tiles of all the small buildings again make this a lovely place to visit. A definite must in Marrakech.
An amazing place. Hello everyone , Jardin majorelle is a must do place with all the wild flowers and long cactus trees feels like a wonderland place , so glad I got a chance to visit it .

Sublime! That blue is so wonderful!. An interesting way to get to these gardens is to go by horse and cart (each cart holds 4 people). There is only bamboo and many species of cacti growing but watching the light move from one plant to another, over the lily pond was lovely. Jacques Marjorelle's house was turned into a Berber Museum by Yves St Laurent and his partner, Paul Barre (they saved it from a real estate development. A beautiful way to escape the madness of Marrakesh for a few hours. A good cafe on the premises.
Beautiful gardens - so tranquil. A must if staying in Marrakech, the buildings are stunning and the grounds beautiful, the museum of traditional dress was very interesting.
Wonderful . It's simply wonderful, very cheap and so beautiful.We found a very professional staff, good services and nice shops.I suggest this attraction to couples because it' very romantic
very nice. nice garden, and looking around this place it is close to the city it is something to explore, enjoy
Lovely garden. Our visit to this lovely garden was very peaceful and calming. The garden has a number of areas with trees and plants from all over the planet. Nice place for a afternoon stroll
Disappointing. Visited these gardens but would not return. Lots of bamboo a statue to Yves St Laurent and very little else. Very expensive cafe.
Amazing. Must be the most beautiful and serene place in Marrakesh! Never seen so many plant species, especially cactus, from all over the world. Housing a good in house museum.
Beautiful. Incredibly gorgeous gardens, don't expect retiro/central park size however, I am definitely glad I was able to visit during my time in Marrakesh.

Whats all the fuss about ?. Got there early to avoid the package tour buses... oh how i was wrong. They were already there in their hundreds and in such a small garden. Couldnt take a photo as within seconds there would be a human standing right in front of you [usually taking a selfie ]Crowds are not my idea of a peaceful garden so to me a complete waste of time.

Tranquil oasis amid the hurly-burly of Marrakesh. A must-do in Marrakesh. Created as a work of art, the brilliant blue and yellow of the buildings contrast beautifully with the plants. The giant cactus collection is a particular feature.This is a wonderful experience, especially early in the day before the buses arrive.

Pretty Garden, but not a must-do. We were told on a guided tour of the old city of Marrakesh that we must make a visit to Jardin Majorelle, and so we did on our final day in the city. It is definitely a beautiful place, with vibrant colors and a wide range of palms and cactuses. There is a nice small museum you can visit for a small additional fee, and it houses some lovely old artifacts of the local Berber people.We went as a group of five, and overall we were all a little bit underwhelmed. Don't get me wrong, it is definitely a peaceful oasis in a bustling city and the "majorelle blue" color that adorns the entire garden is one of the most beautiful blues I have ever seen. But if you're limited on time and trying to squeeze this in, I would say take a tour of the Atlas Mountains instead!

Amazing oasis among the hustle and bustle of Marakesh. Spent 3 hours here wandering around this beautiful tranquil place. I sat and read, I wandered and took photos and felt so peaceful in this truly special place. It is the most colourful garden I have ever been in with brightly coloured walls, pots and buildings. It is a must when visiting Marakesh
Lovely gardens. Great gardens, not huge but interesting to visit to see different types of plants and hear about YSL's connection to Marrakesh.

Nice Enough.... This is a nice site to visit if you like this kind of thing. I found it a little too well manicured for my taste. You walk around the pathway and look at the plants. Ho hum. Its about as far removed from nature as you can get. It's also a bit pricey for Moroccan standards.
Jardin Majorelle . A marvellous oasis in the melee that is Marrakesh. Fabulous colours and style abound. Great garden café too.Highly recommended.
Striking oasis. Cacti and striking blue features make this a wonderful shady oasis to wander around. An unexpected highlight of our trip to Marrakech.

Relaxing and colourful. A visit to the jardin is a nice break from the noise of the medina and busy roads. It's a relaxing place to look around some very well kept gardens. Striking contrast of bright painted walls and pots against the plants and flowers makes it a memorable place to visit.It might be good to get there early to avoid crowds and if you want people-free photos.The gift shop is very expensive. We didn't try the cafe so can't comment on that.
Peaceful and tranquil............ Especially loved the 'Love Collage Exhibition' and coffee in the Cafe.....couldn't get over the variety of Cacti to be seen there!
Marmite. You'll either love it or hate it.... Lots of cactus, smooth wide paths and blue. Left me cold. Museum inside however was very interesting focus on Berber life.
Pretty and tranquil. A very lovely garden. It doesn't take long to go round. Perhaps 20 minutes. A bit on the pricey side. Around £5 each.

Great place to gawp - along with everyone else on tour. First queue up for the (comparatively) expensive tickets. Their profits got to maintaining the garden and local charity, I think, so maybe a worth while cause.There is little peace on a Sunday morning as there are so many people, most of whom want to stand in front of you after they check that you have raised your camera to eye level. The place is actually quite sterile in a way with little atmosphere, other than seeming contrived. Dead-eye Gulch with lots of cactus but tidier.There are lots of security personnel to keep you moving, especially in the museum which is rather like walking into a high end boutique with no prices on the items - same feeling.Nice toilets - the staff conveniently stand outside waiting for their tips.Can't say I would recommend it.

Lovely Desert Garden. This was a lovely desert garden. The landscaping and paths were beautiful. I was particularly taken with all of the structures and pots in "Marjorelle Blue" - a distinctly lovely shade of royal blue. The one challenge, is that it gets quite crowded and is a little more expensive than I expected at $7USD for entry (which believe it or not is on the high site for entrance fees in Marrakech!). Still a nice way to spend an hour or so.

A jewel in the dust of the city. Having visited 12 years ago, we were keen to revisit, and the sense of calm, the structure of the place, there peace depute the high number of visitors seem all the greater than they were. In turn this high tens to contrast with the outside which is a daily downbeat commercial area of the new town.The exhibition of Berber history is new since we were there before and is well worth a visit if you are at the garden.

Worth going to see the cacti!. The most expensive tourist attraction in Marrakech at 50 MAD pp, but an interesting stop. I loved the cacti gardens. It really is a 20 minute visit unless you find somewhere to sit and relax.
Simply stunning!. Amazing and well worth a visit, if not a little expensive! I would not necessarily pay to visit the Berber museum again but the garden is stunning.
Serene. A peaceful calm place to wonder. The vibrant colors and water features make a great back drop for some lovely photos.

So so. There are soooo much more beautiful and interesting places to go and things to do in Marrakech. My friends and I did regret we spent our time and money (not as cheap as everything else in Moroccoo haha) on this! :( It's a nice garden but has barely no flowers and it's actually pretty small.

Don't expect tooooooo much. Nice way to spend one hour in the garden. Small garden and not that special. Its nice to visit this place when it's really hot. Since there is a lot of shadow by the trees.

A different and unexpected oasis amid Marrakech madness.. Get here early in the morning before the large tour groups descend on the place! I think whenever you visit you will be quite aware of many others vying for the best spots to take their pictures. But of course there are plenty of photos to take - the contrast of the lush greenery and the Majorelle blue is ever tempting. I particularly enjoyed the Berber museum in the original house. The displays were very well laid out and informative and worth at least 1/2 hour of one's time.

Beautiful . Beautiful place to walk around and see different plants. It's so peaceful especially when you think that behind the gate is a busy road. Place well maintained, all staff is helpful. As a tourists we found it reasonably priced. However we did not purchased additional ticket to berbers museum but it didn't spoil our walk in the garden.
Amazing. This is a great place to visit. Tranquil, interesting and peaceful. Suggest you make time (1 hour) to view the Berber museum as this is outstanding and often missed by vistors.
Colorful treat. The colors in this place are gorgeous. Really enjoyed the walk around and also the museum inside. Great stop on a trip to Marrakesh.

A delightful oasis in the city: try to go early in the day. This garden is stunning - an oasis in the busy city. But try to avoid busy times of day. The Berber museum is fascinating. The gift shop has exquisite gifts. I strongly regretted later not buying a leather bag - the craftsmanship is superb
Beautiful oasis close to the Medina. Very pleasant and artful gardens! Café and Berber Museum were both excellent although the Moroccan crepes were so-so...
Lovely setting to while away some time before lunch.. Beautiful gardens. Very reasonable entrance fee. This is a great place to visit one morning before a nice lunch in this part of town.
Gardens. We took a horse and carriage from the medina. Quite a distance. Beautiful garden though not large. Museum us interesting.
Beautiful . Behind the walls it's a tranquil calm from the hussle of the Medina.Excellent value for money.Beautiful gardens and some very impressive cactus.
Overrated. This place was billed as amazing to us but actually was a pretty unimpressive small garden with some multicoloured pots and a pond. Well done Marrakech on your top tourist destination.
Mehhhh!. I'm sure if you are an Yves Saint Lauren or bamboo fan then this garden is for you. If not.......mehhhh
Beautiful!. Also known as the Yves St Laurent gardens, these are a picturesque and tranquil haven from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Loved the Early Morning Tour. We arrived just after the garden opened and I was so glad that we were there early. The colors and the light peaking through the garden were extraordinary and being in the garden without a crowd made our visit so special. There are a few "musts" in Marrakech and this is one of them.

Beautiful, peaceful gardens in easy reach. Do not miss these gardens if you visit Marrakech. I first visited about 8 years ago, and was delighted that very little has changed, apart from the memorial to Yves Saint Laurent. The gardens are quite small and you can visit for an hour, or sit back and relax for longer.

Find a seat and a friend and enjoy. Expect to spend a few hours to just enjoy it. you can easily walk around the whole venue in half an hour, but go take it easy, take your time and just enjoy it. Take your time and visit the Berber museum too to take in the history, its not too expensive, about £10.00pp for both the garden and the museum.

Interesting. With cacti from around the world,lovely water features,brightly painted pots and walls this little garden was a pleasant interlude to a hectic schedule. The Berber museum inside a converted artist studio was well worth the visit too.
Another. Oasis. Quiet calm beautiful in the middle of all everything. Never seen cactus so large Well worth a visit to sit and relax.

Beautiful nature. Very surprising green place despite all of pink and dusty Marrakech. The house of Yves Saint Laurent is very beautiful. Nothing spectacular but the fact that it is memorial house of someone so important in fashion world is enough to make an impression. Good to see.
Expensive, but beautiful. The gardens are beautiful; a little was out of the centre of town and by Moroccan standards a little expensive, but it is 100% worth a visit!

Wonderful respite. We stopped here as part of a tour, and it was definitely the highlight of the afternoon. Being able to leisurely stroll through the gardens, admiring the plants and colorful accents of pots and railings, was so relaxing. There is also a Berber museum on the grounds, with a bookstore, gift shop, and cafe.
so so beautiful. the most beautiful point in Marrakesh for me - perfect garden, cozy cafe, nice and not too big museum, and of course this color - Majorelle blue
wonderful garden. beatiful this attraction and much Amazing this garden with muh plants and flowers my prefer and water not know other place more beatiful of this

A unique place in Marrakech. The Majorelle gardens are steeped in European color and smell. You can not describe in words. Yves Saint Laurent knew reform the space to turn it into an oasis within the city .

very pretty - like walking in a rainforest. Very very pretty - I liked how at the beginning the trees were tall enough to enclose the area so it was like walking in the rainforest. The birds were whistling so it was all very peaceful.The plants and trees were very beautiful and you can see Yves Saint Laurent's memorial.It wasn't very crowded when we went so it was nice.I don't think it was worth 70 dirhams though (another 30 to enter the museum) but I would recommend people to go and see it.

A true oasis in the desert. The Jardin Majorelle is a soothing oasis of cobalt blue, fountains, and winding paths. This is not a large garden yet it is laid out in a manner that offers many vistas with twists and turns. I would recommend a visit to the Berber Museum which is in the garden yet a separate fee. The garden shop has many beautiful things at a price.

Not worth the time and money. If you are a cactus and bamboo lover then this a 70sqr mtrs of haven for you. Else it is just a garden full of cactus and bamboo for which you have to pay 70mad/person and an additional 30mad/person for the museum inside the garden. We didn't visit the museum so can not comment on what is inside if it is worth the price tag.Personally I would have given it a miss if someone would have informed me about what to expect.
Waste of time and money!. Hardly anything to see...it was a waste of 70 dhms and ofcourse the time we spent there...not worth the money at all.
Lovely day out.... The garden and plants were beautiful & the museum was very informative. We took so many photos and would recommend it as its a super day out.
Absolutely Stunning. This place is a must see - slighly outside of the centre but 7-8 MAD in a taxi should be fine. The garden , pond, tiling and the colour is absolutely unique. We will be back
Short break . Had a lovely day here exploring the garden and enjoying the beautiful plants...the museum was very good as well we found it very informative...we would definitely recommend a visit.

Like!. Beautiful garden in Marrakech. Lots of personnel to keep it in tip top shape but smaller than I expected. You need not be here more than more hour. Yves saint Laurant lovers will enjoy this ;).

Oasis with in the city. We took a taxi from Medina to Jardin Majorelle and paid about 40 Dirham. Entrance fee was 70 Dirham per person which is rather high, but still worth it. The garden is very well maintained and has bamboo trees, cactuses, palm trees and lots of other greenery. The buildings are mainly blue with some parts in yellow and white. It takes about an hour to cover the ground. It is very calm and relaxing inside the garden and a real contrast to busy Medina.

A must visit- beautiful and relaxing place. A must visit of you are in Marrakech. 70dh per person or 100dh if you want to go onto the berber museum. It is approx 15dh to the pound. It takes approx 45mins to 1 hour to take it all the gardens, photo taking and the gift shop. The plants, trees, flowers,cactus, fountains and vibrant colours bring a small plot in the city to life and you are thankful that Yves Saint Laurent saved it from real estate developers.
Romantic park. Small, romantic park in the North Eastern corner of Marrakech. Here you can relax and stress down from the constant traffic noise & street sellers. 70 Dirham entrance fee.
Stunning. Really well worth the visit. The gardens & museum are beautiful & the colours used were indeed stunning.

Worth a visit. Not very big and not at all what I expected but I would say it's worth going to. It was quite busy when we visited so not as peaceful as most reviews have stated and mainly green, not many beautiful colorful flowers on show. We were in and out within 45 mins so it's a nice little visit that won't take all day!

Incredible blues, peaceful and cool gardens.. This garden, sponsored by YSL, is definitely worth a visit. It is glorious....part bamboo grove, part rain forest, part high desert cactus garden, but it all works. There is a lovely little spot perfect for enjoying some mint tea and Moroccan biscuits. A little pricey-er than you'll get on the street, but hey! It's YSL.

A noticable change of pace. To get out of the hustle and bustle of the city this is a perfect trip. Only 5-10 minutes walk from the north walls it is hard to believe the serenity you encounter inside the gardens. If you need a break from the noise this is the place.

Beautiful oasis in the city. Quiet lovely with varieties of plants from around the world which surprisingly to me grow in Marrakesh. Well taken care of. And the Berber museum in the gardens is a must see. So interesting to learn about the Berbers. See their excellent craftsmanship and how they do it.

A must see in Marrakech!!!!. Go early in order to avoid crowds, we did and thoroughly enjoyed the peace and quiet of the gardens. There is a lovely cafe on the premises and the Berber collection of jewelry was exceptional.
Lovely. Not as large and I expected and entrance fee is due as well at the entrance, but a lovely garden nonetheless. Well worth a visit.

Lovely and quiet, but not too much colour. I would recommend going to the gardens, however we went in November and there weren't many colourful plants on show. Maybe I was expecting too much. For a £10 for to people it's a no brainer though.

Beautiful Experience. The gardens are absolutely beautiful and incredibly well-maintained; they were very calming and peaceful, even with all of the other tourists. Strongly recommend an early start, before the tour buses arrive. It's one of those "once in a life-time" experiences.

Oasis of cool in dusty city. Great place to visit to escape from the dust and hustle of the Medina. Amazingly cool under the green canopy. Quite expensive to get in but worth it for the experience. Would not recommend trying to find the gardens by self directed walking through the old city... got very lost and ended up tipping local "guides" more than a taxi ride cost back to base!

Worth a visit. I took my fiancée here and it was a great experience. Definitely worth seeing. it was smaller than I expected but still a good opportunity to capture a good snap! Its quite peaceful which is quite a contrast when you walk outside the gates!
Small but perfectly formed. A quiet, beautiful garden away from the centre of marrakech well worth visiting for a breath of tranquillity

Lazy morning. Took a horse and carriage ride from the main square. It's a little bit out of the way wouldn't be easy to find on your own. Though a little small and didn't really take too long to look around it was spotlessly clean and very well presented

pretty but underwhelming. A nice garden. Not huge. No more than an hour long activity. Pleasant for a diversion but I was surprised it is a major attraction of the city. You'd be better off spending an afternoon heading out into the Atlas Mountains and getting a real feel for local culture.

Unbelieavable. This place incorporates a vast collection of the world's cacti (cactuses?) Sounds dry and dusty,but far from it. Colorful pools, richly painted pottery, beautiful light make this garden a real treat. Do not miss it and bring lots of pixels.

An oasis in the midst of chaos. You cannot miss the Jardin Marjorelle if you have more than one day in Marrakesh. Amidst all the noise that is Marrakesh, one enters the gates here and finds instant calm and serenity. One also finds incredible beauty in the flowers and plants, the many places to sit quietly and savor the meditative atmosphere, the absence of noise and movement that is just outside these gates. I regret that I did not pay for entrance to the museum, Yves St Laurent's home, when I entered as I was so confused as to where I was going and what I was doing. It looked like it would have been worthwhile. Beautiful choice to visit.

Not sure if it's quite the trek. The colours of the building/gallery were stunning, however the garden itself was not very impressive. I'm sure it must've been much more beautiful but maybe it was difficult to maintain because it was far from an actual garden. It is quite far from the Medina, so it may be worth checking everything else off the list first!
Small but lovely . Worth a visit to both the gardens and the museum within as a lovely way to spend a hour or two. There is also a nice cafe for a much needed coffee

Well maintained garden, perfect for photographers. We spent a few hours there in the afternoon as a large group (40+) and had a wonderful time. Great areas, very distinct, and well kept. Would recommend making the trip there!

Worth a visit. Although its a small garden in the hub of new town, this is a tranquil and beautiful place.Beautifully kept too. Although always busy, if you take your time around the gardens and you will find some peace. Nice gift shop too!
Amazing garden. Beautiful garden well worth the visit. It us very small but worth a look we really enjoyed it and too some amazing pictures

Beautiful Historical Garden. This very unusual tranquil garden which is being preserved for posterity was designed by French painter Jacques Marjorelle in the 1920s - 1930s. Lily-filled pools bordered by cobalt blue edges, bamboo groves and cactus gardens are divided by peaceful paths with splashes of blue, yellow and orange pots and colourful plants. The cobalt blue Art Deco pavilion in the centre of the garden provides a focus and now is a museum of Islamic Arts. There are twelve acres in all, seats in corners to sit and reflect. This is a place to return to again and again. It is not to be missed if in Marrakech for a day or two.

Lovely oasis in the city. Went here as part of the usual "top 10" things to do although wasn't expecting much. Totally blown away by the colour, design and layout of the place.We also took in the Berber museum which was well worth the small additional cost. You'd need to get your timing right as many tourist groups can descend at any given moment.Cost was 70Dhs for the gardens and 10Dhs for the museum - about £6.50 at today’s rates.
Bit dull garden. Had expected a larger and a more floral garden. Nothing I would recommend but is happy that I still have been there.
Beautiful garden. The Jardin Majorelle is beautiful and worth a visit. We loved the bamboo and cacti and the colours in the garden are amazing.

Alot behind the walls!. Its a good thing to visit but pricey for what it actually is. Limited amount of plants- was expecting to see more. If trying to pack alot in the day only need about 1hour- 90mins to get around

very breathtaking gardens. The Majorelle Gardens is the perfect place to visit to escape the heat and noise of Marrakech. Serenity and beauty are the only two words to describe this paradise that was restored by Yves St Laurent. There is a tea room where you can have a light lunch but the sorbets are a must - unique traditional Moroccan flavours!
lovely gardens outside the medina. Take a taxi here if you are staying in the medina. The gardens are quite compact but lovely - a real oasis in the city. Very restful on a hot day.
Worth seeing. Not the most interesting gardens I have seen but interesting plants as designed and supported by Yves St Laurent
Pristine garden in Marrakech. A very nice and pristine garden hidden away in the middle of the town. Worth a visit and for a lazy walk in this garden.
Beautiful Landscape. Love the Blue Colour, Very nice designed park, clean and not crowded, located in the middle of the city. It is a great place to spend the afternoon in Marrakech.
Cool walk in a garden. Everyone who visits Marrakech MUST visit this garden, absolute beauty, coolness,interesting plants.... in addition a great museum o the Berbers.
Beautiful. If you visit Marrakesh and look for something different than the Medina, you must visit Jardin Majorelle.
Beautiful, but crowded.. The Gardens were very beautiful, but the crowds of bus tours made it hard to appreciate. Maybe going on a weekday would be better.

Gorgeous Gardens!. I had totally underestimated the beauty of these gardens. My initial reasoning for visiting was just to check off the proverbial box of places to see in Marrakech. Again, totally underestimated this place. The gardens are so well kept and I've not quite seen anything like them. Then of course there's the Berber Museum within the grounds -- it's an extra (small) fee to visit inside there (tickets can be obtained at the ticket booth at the entrance to the gardens) which, if you're interested in history or anthropology, is a must see as well! Can't recommend this place enough.

Quiet beauty in the middle of the city.. This garden is quite lovely and interesting. There are plants from all over the world. It was surprising to see such a beautiful place in the center of a large, busy city.
Beautiful Oasis. After walking around the Medina, this is a haven of quietness and calm. Beautiful gardens, well worth a visit.

Oasis in a bustling city. Get there before 10am to miss the crowds that start to jam this tranquil oasis of gardens and water features collected Yves Saint Laurent and its former owner from around the world. There is also a small memorial to Yves in a quiet section of the gardens to mark his passing at his home here where his ashes are scattered in the gardens.The small Yves art gallery of personalised annual Christmas card drawings is also nice and the Moroccan blue's on the buildings and walls are almost uniquely vivid.
Too crowded. Far too many people and the garden was a little disappointing . The entrance fee is going to a good cause which is the only reason we would suggest including it on your tour

Composed and subtle beauty. I arrived just as it opened c. 9am on day and was pretty much alone for a while. I marvelled at the care that has clearly been spent on the plants, ponds, trees etc in particular they seemed to produce excellent views as you walked round - it seems that the layout and botanics have been carefully considered and every step gave you another nicely balanced view. The deep blue that predominates is an excellent and resonant colour and comes out well even on rubbish cameras. The Berber museum is very good and worth the extra. It has some interesting artefacts and good explanations for its exhibits and I particularly liked the fact that the costume manekins have no faces and are shaded by the overhead lights - wierd when you are alone. I loved the quite good free wi fi in the cafe which meant I could contact my daughters after having been out of town for a few days. So why isn't it five stars?After I had been there some time I noticed that it had become packed with people and the original mellow vistas were now thronged with people taking pictures so either they were in the few I took or I was in theirs. There was nowhere to tuck yourself out of the way and contemplate the subtle beauty of this place anymore. As I left c. lunch time I noted there was a huge queue to get in now along the boundary wall. The other slightly negative element was that (certainly by comparison to other attractions in Marrakech) I found it a bit twee and contrived after a while. It is nevertheless a lovely attraction and has plenty of potential for superbly composed pictures when it is quiet.

Nice garden outside the Medina. Its a nice garden/oasis not that far from the Medina. You can take bus nr 1 from the Grand place. Takes about 10 minutes.Nice place to retreat from the busy life of the streets of Marrakech. Somewhat pricy at 70dh pp though.
Nice little park with amazing collours. Beautiful garden with outstanding Villa in amazing blue collours. Bamboo tall like houses give shadow and peace.
This is a must -. Even if the place is loaded with tourists - here is an extraordinary experiencxe. Take all the colours with you in your mind - and think of Yves st. Laurent, who was inspired here.

Small, crowded and pricey. I really do not understand why everyone in Marrakech advises you to go here. Indeed it is a nice garden with all kinds of palm trees, cacti and more plants like that. Nothing extraordinary though.The garden is very small. We spent an hour or so, including a visit to the Berber museum which is within the garden walls as well. And because of it being such a popular attraction it was very crowded.Entrance fee is 70 MAD for the garden and 30 more for the museum. And to get there you'll probably need a taxi, because it is in the modern part of Marrakech, away from the medina.If you're not a botanist or really into gardens, I suggest to skip this place. If you're interested in the Berber culture go to the Dar Si Said museum in the medina. It's much cheaper, you will see the same things and on top of that you get a peek inside a beautiful old building.

That Majorelle Blue!. Moving through the garden with its blue hues is like diving into the sea...except that you see potted cacti instead of coral. And I'd give it 5 stars, but it was so crowded that it was hard to be still in the beauty and soak it in.

Visually stunning . This is a photographer's paradise full of exotic plants, water features & the signature Majorelle blue. The beauty of the place and the additional attractions - a small museum (which has an additional cost but is probably worth it) & an even smaller gallery of Yves Saint Lauren posters (free to enter once inside the gardens) - fully justify an entrance fee which is relatively high by Moroccan standards. There's also a decent enough cafe inside and plenty of places to sit & be soothed by the long shadows of the cacti. Definitely worth a visit.

Don't miss the Berber Museum (extra fee) while here!. This is probably the top attraction in Marrakech because of the serenity (even when it's crowded) you can find in the shade appreciating the lovely gardens. The admission fee (70MAD) is high compared to most other attractions in Morocco (cheaper, of course, for locals) and does NOT include the fantastic Berber Museum! Make sure you add on admission to the museum (another 30MAD, I believe). It's wonderful and I felt I learned more about the Berber people while appreciating and enjoying the exhibits and accompanying artifacts, clothing, jewelry than I had in 2 weeks touring Morocco.Fantastic!There's also a somewhat pricey cafe, but if you're needing a little bit of class and European dining, you'll like this.

peace. had a lovely walk with my wife around the garden ,a oasis in the middle of the hustle of Marrakech.stopped for coffee in the garden cafe.totol chill out .would save not a chav visit .but not to arty farty.

something different. This is a beautiful place, it could be an oasis but the queue was long when we arrived in the afternoon and the gardens were very busy so it was difficult to take photos or enjoy any sort of uninterrupted view.
Beautiful. Not a huge garden but absolutely beautiful, so tranquil, plenty of seating to enjoy the gardens. 70mad admission. There's someone to eat, shop and museum.
Just ok. kind of small and pricey (70dh at the door), not that much to see inside as you can walk the entirety in 20 minutes or less. Skip it if you're not into gardens.
Outstanding Museum of Berber Culture. The Garden was unusual - no flowers but many many amazing International Cactii - painted Azure and Verte

Well worth a visit. Pricey by Marrakech Standards and very popular the gardens are still well worth a visit. We spent a couple of hours there on our first morning in Marrakech enjoying the peace and tranquility. The Berber museum was small but interesting and also had a good lunch in the cafe.
Beautiful!. Definitely a must see whilst in Marrakech. Relaxing atmosphere and there's a lovely, little museum within the gardens.
Worth a visit. Great little gardens, 70 dnh each but worth the visit, calm in the oasis of the busy streets, just beautiful
YSL. Get there early or go late afternoon before or after the bus tours arrive. Very well managed garden. Quite peaceful

Beautiful and peaceful. I enjoyed walking around this stunning garden, the colours are just amazing. I didn't go into the museum, just the garden so can't talk to much about that. The cafe was a nice place to grab a quick cup of coffee. Downside I'd say, a bit overpriced for such a small garden that you can walk around in 10mins. I still enjoyed the experience
Beautiful . Beautiful place a must visit if in marrakech, and very very cheap! One of the most Amazing gardens I've seen!

Worth a visit. This garden was created by a guy named Jacques Majorelle and opened in 1947 but after he died in 1962 it fell into ruin. In 1980 good old YSL and another guy bought it and restored it. It is now rather nice and includes a memorial to Yves Saint Laurent. You walk along painted concrete paths and brightly coloured pots and urns filled with plants. There are beautiful tall trees, bamboos and a wonderful collection of all kinds of cacti. There are lots of pools and fountains It is a lovely peaceful oasis amongst the madness of Marrakech. It will cost you 70 dirhams to enter the garden, around £5 and a further 30 dirhams to look around the Berber museum. it's not a large place so 1-2 hrs is plenty of time to see it all. The Berber museum is small but houses a small but beautiful collection of Berber jewellery and clothing. You can take photos in the garden but not the museum. There is a small shop selling a variety of clothing, bags etc but in true YSL fashion it is very expensive, as is the nice courtyard cafe.

Unique garden setup. I think I have seen quite a lot of gardens, but this one is special. This includes the plants as well as the colors, and on top there were not too many people. Even our son enjoyed his time and the very special atmosphere. A big recommendation

Beautiful cacti . We absolutely adored all of the cacti in this garden. As cacti connoisseurs, we really were pleasantly surprised at the level of upkeep and attention paid to the flora. It's such a lovely and tranquil place to spend the afternoon in and the museum was small, but definitely worth visiting for the stunning Berber jewels. Excellent gift shop too, although on the pricey side.Must see when in Marrakech!

Not a huge attraction. I think if you are going to really enjoy this place you want to think about it more of a back garden of a nice house then you'll be pleasantly surprised. We went in expecting something a bit bigger and grander. The Museum is quite interesting but again quite small.

Nice peaceful location, but very busy.. The gardens and museum are very well presented, and are an oasis in the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. It was fairly busy when we were there. Difficult to moan about this though when you are adding to the problem ! On reflection I'm not sure it was worth the taxi ride there and back, for what turned out to be a half hour visit. If it weren't for the YSL connection, I doubt it would draw many visitors at all.

Lovely house and gardens. I have read that you need to get tickets the day before to avoid the queues, but I went in the afternoon and there was no queue and were straight in, However I did visit in November. Access the gardens cost 70 MAD and the museum is 30 MAD. Which is approx £6.50 for both. The Musuem is inside the house and is very small and only on one level, it is fully accessible for wheelchairs. You can pay seperately for the musuem on the door, if you only purchased garden tickets and change your mind. I loved the colour of the house, its like nothing I have seen before and the gardens are beautiful. There is a small art gallery and shop aswell as a restuarant.I would recommend getting a taxi here from the medina, it cost 40 MAD (approx £2.50) and dropped me right outside. You can walk, but it is a far distance and the surrounding area didn't feel very safe for me. It is also not sign posted until you are almost there. Do bring a camera! Fantastic pictures because of the brightness of the house.

Nice but busy. I enjoyed our visit the the garden but it was incredibly busy. The gardens were smaller than I imagined which meant there were not many places to escape the crowds. The Berber museum is definitely worth paying extra for very interesting.

Majestic Gardan. There really isn't much here to do but, if you're a keen gardener, love the outdoors or simply enjoy all things beautiful, then this is a place to visit as a couple or with family. I spent a few hours at the garden with my wife - much of which was spent sitting on a bench and soaking up the winter sun, and we enjoyed every bit of our time. Everything you see and everything you can take in is so serene and tranquil. It is definitely worth visiting, but be sure to give yourself a few hours for your visit.

Hot. This is certainly one of those places that your film like you have to go and see. I am not in Tiley convinced that this is a must do activity when visiting Marrakesh. Yes there are elements of beauty all around you but I think that goes for the whole of the city. I found it a little too hot and my interest in botany is fairly low so perhaps I should've chosen to do something else

Lovely gardens. First you need to get your tickets the day before as to not wait in line. The garden are beautiful and even thou there is a lot of people walking around, you feel you got to see the place on your own. A must see...

Exceptionally beatiful garden with great Berber museum. The Berber museum in the garden is very worth seeing. The garden is a must. Unique and suprisingly rich for anyone who loves nature. Stay there at least 2 hours, the longer the better.

OK but small. We visited in November, don't get me wrong it is lovely but £8 was expensive for what is a small but succulent garden. Compared to the other free parks and attractions I think you pay for the YSL connection.Lovely to see once but not a place I would go back. The Berber museum was very interesting but small. Loved the YSL yearly Love prints.
lovely garden. did nto know about this place until another guest told us, well wortyh a visit, an oasis of tranquility in the middle of Marakesh
Peaceful, beautiful gardens. Really Lovely gardens, they are quite small though so you don't need huge amount of time to visit them.
Beautiful . Beautiful gardens with lots of plants and different types, really nice to just look Around and have a calm walk after being in lots of heat
A small oasis. A great place to visit an exotic garden and a very good Berber museum.Lunch or tea in the courtyard restaurant is a nice way to cap off your visit.

Lovely Oasis. I can't tell you how nice it was to get out out the heat. The garden is gorgeous and is literally a couple of degrees cooler. Lots of tropical looking trees and of course cactuses, plus it has nice water features where you can spot the frogs and turtles. Spent a good 2 hours here, well worth it.

Pleasant . I visited this garden during my city tour to Marrakech and it was pleasant due to nice plants and good colours of the buildings with nice photos to take and arrival by horse car carriage which is good experience. I think most people should do.
Beautiful garden.. Museum in the garden is must see place. To avoid waiting in line to get ticket, it is probably a good idea to get there early in the morning,

Ok if you like cactuses.. Hmmm...everyone told me how great this atttaymction was, but we felt really let down by it. Firstly its out of the Medina, so 50d cab ride there and 80d back (they have a taxi service you have to use which takes a cut). Next up its pricey - 70d per person. Finally its not especially interesting, unless you have a penchant for cacti. We've seen similar gardens (parks) in cities in SE Asia for free.Spend the money on a Hamman or a nice roof terrace lunch instead!
Beautiful gardens. Make sure you take a couple of hours to go and visit these wonderful gardens. Even if you aren't in to gardening it will blow you away.

Lovely garden . It's a lovely garden The Jardin Majorelle are some lovely and unusual gardens located in the Gueliz area (new town) of Marrakech. The gardens were originally created by Jacques Majorelle, a French painter who moved to Marrakech in 1919 with an interest in plants.
Interesting "garden". Not what a lot of people would call a garden in that it is not full of flowering plants. But it is well worth a visit as it is beautiful and peaceful.
A peaceful courtyard. The Moroccan salad was delicious there was enough for two to share after a morning walking it was a pleasant escape
Lovely haven within a bustling city!. Such a lovely colourful and well kept garden. Definitely worth a visit and pretty cheap to. great place to get some good pics.

Just beautiful. Visited as part of guided tour, and was very enjoyable. Interesting details given of the life of Yves Saint Laurent, a major benefactor of the gardens. Includes major cactus collection that's amazing of itself. Berber museum within the grounds is well worth the (additional) price of entry

Something different to do. Two of us went along to Jardin Majorelle as it had been recommended by a friend.The gardens were very pretty, and it's something to do to get away from the hustle and bustle of the souks. We walked from the main square which took us about 30mins, the gardens are located just outside of the old town. Not sure if it's worth the admission fee, but something different to do when you're sick of the haggling.

Amazing oasis in Marrakesh. The painter Jacques Majorelle purchased the property in 1923 and spent the 39 years developing the garden. He died in 1962. The property was rescued by Yves Saint Laurent in 1980. The grounds have his memorial. There are fountains and pools. The garden is very popular and it seems every tour bus that comes to Marrakesh stops here. ...But still it is an amazing space But not too calm.

Arrive early!. If visiting this attraction it is really important to arrive before 10.30 as the attraction becomes very crowed after this time - when the tour groups arrive!!!If arriving late you will be very disappointed as you will have to jostle with crowds.
Garden colors and freshness. This garden makes you forget that you are in the middle of a desert. Colored walls, litlle lakes with water running .

Refreshing. This is a must visit.It gets you out of the chaos and the heat, there's some really interesting feature gardens. Plus it has the cafe to relax at.I'd also advise walking around and exploring the area after you've finished the gardens.

Peace, tranquility and a superb Berber museum. Originally created over 40 years the Majorelle Gardens truly are an oasis in Marrakech. The gardens are a bit outside of the city walls, perhaps a 45-minute walk from Jamma El-Fna. Unfortunately once leaving the Medina the walk is not the most pleasant we’ve encountered – busy city – but the reward is worth the trip. Alternatively it is a short inexpensive taxi-ride (we returned via taxi - note the first taxi outside the entrance/exit said 50 dirham, we walked away, then 40 dirham, we continued to walk, then 30 dirham, still walking, finally 20 dirham and we got in)Once inside the walls the lush gardens are peaceful and tranquil, with a focus on bamboo forests and cactus. Being near the city centre, although not inside the walls, the gardens are not massive. Yet they are large enough, along with the Berber Museum to spend a couple of hours if you take your time. The few hours were a calming escape from the intensity of Marrakech. At 70 dirham for the gardens and another 30 dirham for the Berber Museum the entrance fee did seem a bit pricey although it certainly did not deter visitors as the gardens are quite popular.Although there is an additional cost for the museum it is well worth it. Having just spent three weeks touring Morocco, most in the south through the Berber areas the museum was a fantastic presentation of Berber culture and life. An excellent opening video of Berber people and villages followed by exhibits of costumes, weaving, doors, ornaments and jewellery, musical instruments, tools and weapons made for an informative and fascinating presentation. The Berber gift shop, while expensive has a number of beautiful, high quality items for purchase. As well there is a Café for breakfast, lunch or a drink.My wife is the gardener but I readily admit I too very much enjoyed my time in the Gardens and the Berber Museum, which should tell you how wonderful they are.
Are we human or are we denser. Trees and parks are everywhere,trees and parks are free.So why pay £5 to look at trees.You can walk around this place in 5mins.Go and look at free trees and parks.
Beautiful calm in the eye of the storm. Well worth a visit. It was a soothing distraction from the busy hubbub. Smaller than expected but also has a museum

Nice gardens. Wonderful Berber museum. Great place to escape the crowds dust and heat. Shelter under some palms and relax a little. The Berber museum held my attention for quite some time and although quite busy nobody tried to hasten me through

A must see when in Marrakech. The tranquility hits you as soon as you get through the front gates, so refreshing to get off the noisy bustling dusty streets outside. The Majorelle blue against the greenery is uplifting, and the water gardens are peaceful. Definitely recommend buying the upgrade ticket to go in the Berber museum inside too as its full of interesting artefacts (the jewellery room is stunning) and gives you a nice history of the country's oldest inhabitants. The Yves Saint Laurent connection is there too, which didn't really mean much to me I have to admit, but it all adds to the appeal :) we arrived at lunchtime so headed straight for the lovely garden cafe, and the food was delicious and well priced. We tried to walk there but got lost as the maps are named but the actual streets don't seem to be, so we flagged a taxi (always confirm the price before you get in!!) and there's a taxi rank right outside for getting back too. A pleasant afternoon spent here, def recommend.

Better than expected. Good range of plants, well laid out with a lovely cafe to refresh you. Some amazing 'architectural' plants and a good sized pond which was full of wildlife. There is also an art gallery and shop.Well worth a visit.

Such a tranquil place. Although a bit on the pricey side, we loved Majorelle gardens and thought it was well worth the cost. I could have spent hours there just relaxing in the beautiful gardens, watching the frogs and turtles in the pond. A great way to lower your blood pressure after the craziness of marrakech! Enjoyed the Berber museum, really interesting to see the costumes and jewellery- we were going to the desert the following day so it was great to get an idea of the Berber culture.
Fantastic. An oasis of peace and tranquility in the middle of a hot and crazy city. Lovely gardens, flora etc which are beautifully maintained. A must to visit.

Beautiful oasis in Marrakesk. Apart from beautiful greeney and cactus, I love the colorful decoration here (good background for photo-taking). The New Year Card collection by YSL is impressive. He is talented indeed.

Stunning. And the Musee Berbere too. This garden belonged to Yves St Laurent until his death and it shows! The colours are unbelievable and stunning. Mostly palms and cacti it's the juxtaposition of textures and leaf shapes that hold you spellbound. It's quite small, but very very interesting and well designed. It also holds the Berber Museum which is absolutely a gem! Artefacts, clothing and jewellery are displayed. Fabulous. Highly recommended. There is also a cafe, a small gallery and a shop. There is also a bookshop at the Musee Berbere. Don't miss this. Go early to avoid the queues.

Beautiful Garden. This garden is really a lovely oasis in the city. We skipped the tour of Yves Saint Laurents house and just enjoyed the gardens themselves. The color scheme is beautiful - it is worth a visit and a perfect escape from the chaos of the city

Worth spending an hour if you've nothing better to do. Compared to other attractions in Marrakesh this one costs 100 MAD to get in i.e. about 5 - 10 times more than other places. The garden is actually fairly small and unless you're very interested in plants probably takes no more than 30 minutes to walk around. There is a large display of cacti. Included within our ticket was entrance to the small on site Berber museum which was interesting enough although all in French - takes about 15 minutes., There is quite a nice cafe on site also. We walked there - it's about 15 minutes walk from the city walls and easy to find - use offline maps and GPS on your phone and you can't get lost!

Beautiful. A lovely peaceful tropical garden in the newer part of Marrakech , I love exotic plants and cactus and there were some fantastic specimens here. The Art Deco house looked wonderful but the ground floor only was accessible and was a Berber cultural museum nothing to do with Majorelle or Yves saint Laurent although well displayed exhibits. I left wanting to come home rip up the lawn and paint all my pots Mojorelle blue.
All about the museum. The gardens are nice, if a little out of place, but like others have said, it's worth the ticket price for the museum alone.

BEAUTIFUL AND PEACEFUL GARDENS. Central Marrakech is bustling, noisy. To get away from the hubbub for a while visit the Jardin Majorelle for some relax time. We used the bus touristique / oasis to get there, returning by taxi (about £4). Entry about £5, add about £2 for Berber Museum. The various areas are beautifully laid out. There is a wide range of trees and exotic bushes and plants from around the world. There are also lovely ponds. The Berber Museum (no photos allowed) is very interesting with displays of clothing, jewellery, musical instruments, weaponry, etc. There is also a memorial to Yves St Laurent, a very good café, a bookshop and a boutique. You can have a leisurely stroll though each section. You can even find a bench to sit and let the world go by. About a half day to get there and back and see everything. Definitely worth the time!

Oasis in a mad city. A must needed retreat from the crazy medina and cityVery colorful, peaceful and serene.i loved the unexpected use of color. The expulsions of blue, yellow and orange were fun. The cactus pediments were amazing.

Romantic Oasis in the City. Dappled light and plants from all round the world, combined with ponds give a beautiful effect. The Yves Saint Laurent memorial where his ashes were scattered gave an insight into his life. The museum of Berber history has some beautiful exhibits. Lunch in the open courtyard was superb and inexpensive.

A little peace and quiet in the big city. We rented a scooter for a day in Marrakech, so we could visit all the places in Marrakech too far for walking from the big square. The garden of Yves Saint Laurent was definitely the most beautiful thing I've seen that day. The walls and floor of the garden are pretty and blue, the garden itself full with all kinds of plants in it. A little peace and quiet in such a chaotic and big city! We loved it and would definitely recommend visiting.
Beautiful Gardens. Thouroughly recommend an hours visit - don't miss the cafe for the show off waiter and the mint tea or the gallery.
Great park. This is a must to visit if you can spare half a day. It's a good place to avoid some direct sunlight and relax.

Do not miss this gem!. It is valuable to see garden and museum inside of it. It worth it! Amazing plants, very good design, nice cafeteria where you can take a rest with the good food and coffee,Museum of Berber cloth and jewelry. Do not hesitate to ask questions and you will have a lot of information. For us it was a news, that in Sahara desert people can find amber.

An oasis of calm and colour. When you've seen everything inside the Medina walls it's time to head outside to the gardens for a well-earned break. The Jardins Maorelle are a short taxi ride (40 DH) from the square and are an oasis of calm and colour.look for the stunning blue room amongst the greenery and water features, then visit the surprisingly interesting Berber exhibit. Trust me - it's short yet packs in more interest and style than any of the more conventional museums in the city.
Calm green oasis. Really enjoyed this little garden. It has a fantastic array of plants from around the world and was a great little escape from the busy city.

Aplace of tranquility - absolutely stunning. We got on the hop and off tourist bus to get bearings really....this garden was in the guidebook and is a must do experience. Forget all preconceptions.......its beautiful....since we visited new cafe opened so give that a go. Take loads of photographs as the colours are truly amazing. Away from hub of the city and the buzz of the souks in Marrakech....an experience not to be missed!!

Not impressed with gardens. Visited the gardens as its one of the main attractions in Marrakech found them small, not very exciting & to be honest seen better varieties of flowers & plants in a garden centre!! £7 to get in & your around it in 15 minutes max save your money not worth visiting. The blue & yellow painted pots very tacky!!!

An oasis of calm within chaos & noise. Well worth a visit. Stunning garden interspersed with bright coloured pots & ponds. A bit busy but bearable. The main garden pavillion is beautiful and expresses Mexican influences

Very peaceful. Was a beautiful distraction in a very busy city well worth the 70 dirhams to get in, small cafe area to just sit and relax and take in your surroundings, bit out of the way, so it's worth getting a taxi if your staying in the old town
Beautiful. Designed by Yves Saint Laurent, the gardens are beautiful, not as large as expected but still stunning

Luxuriant planting, textures and colours. Visual feast away from the dust and mayhem of the souls. More walkable from the Medina than maps and guides may say - pass through Bab Doukkala (city gate), past bus station on right and Aswak Assalam building (sign on roof) on left, head up Avenue Alla El Fassi for 750 metres, turning left at x-roads with Ave Yakoub El Montour. Horse-drawn carriages will tell you're close. Brilliant small Museum with well laid out, informative collection of Berber life starting with brief film in first small room and stunning visual effect of jewellery room. Fancy luxury goods shop. Bookshop with prints and posters for sale - some at a price. Planting stars, especially the silvery Bismarkia Palms.

Great place to visit. Such a nice place to walk around. Could spend a good few hours walking around looking at all the different types of caucuses and trees. A great place for all ages to go and visit
Oasis. An Oasis from the chaos of crazy, colourful Marrakech, Jardin Majorelle is definitely worth a visit. Calm gardens and vibrant colours.

Definitely worth a visit .. Berber museum really interesting if not been since December 2011.The gardens are beautiful and peaceful , some of the plants are slightly overgrown which spoil the balance of the features.Its only a short stroll from, the Gueliz area .Cafe a bit expensive but good coffee and in a lovely setting.
wonderful!. We loved this visit. It was the perfect way to start our first day in Marrakesh. So colorful and smelly!

Pretty but pricey. This is a wonderful garden, about 10 minutes by carriage or 40 minutes by walking, outside of the old city. It is worth seeing with a nice history museum located on the inside. The only downside is the price. $20 for two is a steep price for a short walk through the garden and a small museum when most other tourist attractions throughout morocco charge $2 per person. The upside is that it is a pleasant place to relax with a well maintained garden in the middle of a nice hotel area. Safe and clean, it was still a fun site despite the price.

Tranquil and beautiful. What an amazing and beautiful place, also visit the Berber museum! Both fab the gardens are so peaceful, beautifully looked after and of striking design. The bright blues are a great contrast to the natural reds and greens.
Berber museum hoogtepunt. You can book an extra ticket to visit the Berber Museum. The exhibition of berber jewelery was so beautiful and left me breathless. I bought the book!

Beautiful garden, but a bit pricey!. The garden is certainly deserving of its reputation as a site of real beauty and tranquility, in a busy and hectic city. Both the natural and man made displays are very pretty and lovely site to wander around on a warm afternoon. However, the garden is very out of the way and added to that, pretty pricey (70dh) compared to other attractions in Marrakech. Worth a visit, but not essential if you're keeping the costs down

Interesting and historical venue. Worth a visit if you have an hour to spare. The history of Yves St Laurent and his involvement in Marrakech is interesting.Unusual plants, lovely Majorelle Blue accents everywhere and a good gift shop!
great. it was a day paradie we spent the Majorelle gardens, various plants plus a great view a romantic atmosphere with birdsong

Lovely . I would recommend going either very early or an hour or so before closing because the only thing that spoils these gardens is the amount of tourists ! You'll be fighting over a good photo spot. Despite this the gardens are beautiful and you will still feel peaceful in a city that is otherwise so chaotic. I do think it's a little too expensive but not so much that you shouldn't go. The cafe inside is also pricey but had really nice ice cream if you fancy a treat.

An oasis of style and peace. A glorious garden with great style. Beautifully laid out with fascinating plants from South America. A small window into the world of Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Bergé. The museum was well worth the extra money, well put together with fascinating clothing and jewellery from all over Morocco with detailed explanations on cards in English throughout each section. Very good cafe. Very expensive gift shop!
Tranquil site. Good for photos and very tranquil, nicely laid out with some great plants/cacti, busy at the peak of the day but still room to move about.

Serene. Cool oasis in the middle of chaotic Marrakesh. The plants,trees and cactii are otherworldly. Visit the Bedouin museum and dont forget to pick up info sheet in english on entering.Only 100 dirhams total(£6).

Fashcinating garden and museum. I used the Bus Touristique to get to the garden as it is not easy to locate as it is down a side street and not well signposted. However once there it was easier to buy a ticket for the garden and the Berber Museum, rather than buy the tickets separately. The garden is actually a number of different gardens located together. It is extraordinary to walk into a cool path shaded by bamboo, to find a large cactus garden and then find a water garden.The Museum takes time though it is only 4 rooms as numbers are limited at any one time and the pace is slow as each group is given time to watch videos and examine the displays. I had lunch at the café sitting in the courtyard. It was busy but the service was efficient and pleasant and the food was tasty. There are cafes outside the gardens which served a variety of food and looked busy and pleasant.I decided to wait for the Bus to get back to Ville Nouvelle which resulted in a long wait as the bus arrived about 20 minutes after the time advised. There are other options as there were plenty of taxis available and it is possible to walk, though it is quite a distance.Overall it was a very pleasant way to spend a few hours in a location different to the shops of the Ville Nouvelle and the bustle of the souks.

Nice break from hectic Marrakech. Jardin Majorelle is a quick taxi ride or not that long of a walk from the Medina area. If you are interested in native plants, this is not the place, but there is a nice selection of palms and cactus from regions of the world, and the garden is peaceful compared to the hustle and bustle of the medina and souks. It is well worth going into the Berber Museum located on the grounds.
Wonderful Garden. I am glad it is open to the public, beautiful place full of cactus and exotic plants, it's pricey restaurant is very delicious and hospitable.

Tranquil. The gardens were very peaceful, away from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech but weren't particularly spectacular. The Yves St Laurent connection is interesting but there are better things to see and do in the area.

Not worth the visit. It was hard to even find the entrance to this garden. By the time we asked around and found it, paid our money and walked in, we had walked around the whole garden in 10 minutes. It was mainly palm trees and cacti and a complete let down
majorelle gardens. A beautiful and tranquil place and the museum is very interesting The drawings of yves saint laurant are about love

Beautiful but crowded. If you've not been to an ornamental garden before you'll be impressed. Shaded by trees and planted with ornamental shrubs and cacti it is indeed a very beautiful, cool oasis of calm away from the madness of the rest of the city. But it's much smaller than I expected and it's the number one attraction so it's very crowded and I've been to larger and better elsewhere. The Berber museum is well worth a visit for the extra Dirham if you can be bothered to queue for it.

Too expensive!. I found this absolutely gardens money and not worth the trouble!The reception is NOT friendly and the entrance is far too expensive.There are much nicer and cheaper gardens in Marrakech! TO AVOID!

An oasis of calm in a bonkers city.... A short cab ride ( 50 d ish) from central town ( oh and beware when you leave as the cab try to charge you 100 d for the return trip- their explanation is that they have to pay for parking at the gardens...kinda not your problem...so walk away offering 60 d and they will come after you). We arrived at about 11 am and had a 15 min queue to get in. Once inside it is delightful, obviously lots of plants, colourful buildings and pots, and just somewhere relaxing to walk around to refresh yourself ready for the chaos that is Marrakech once you are back inside the walls

Must go in Marrakech. Despite a little walk from the main square this is a definite must-go spot. Absolutely beautiful gardens and scenery, incredibly interesting museum and the scenic garden cafe provides lovely food and friendly service!
Wa OK. Almost iridescent, I can't really describe them and they were reflected in the bougainvillea. You have to see to believe - don't think of this as a 'garden' think of it as an experience!

Brilliant creativity in true YSL style.. An excellent opportunity to see what can be achieved in a very hot city enviroment.A tranquil shady garden creating a refreshing change to the usual hurly burly of tourist attractions.It's best to go in the morning to avoid coach party trippers!Excellent court yard restaurant and shop where you can buy a range of locally produce items including silver jewellery and teapots ect to the YSL design..There is a very good museum of the Berber culture and how this translates in to days clothing ,carpets , Jewellry etc and well worth paying the extra to see.The plant life of cactuses tress and dramatic use of pots , fountains in vivid blues and yellows as contrasts is stunning and we're inspired to translate this into features of our garden.A very enjoyable exclusion
Impressive!!!. The jardin is painted electric blue.Cost 70dhs for the garden only. Its tranquil and peaceful. A place worth visiting.
Visitor. Enjoy walking around so much. Recommend everyone to get away for awhile from busy street of Marrakech.

Pretty & tranquil. The gardens are very well maintained, our visit here felt like a breathe of fresh air compared to the busy life of Marrakech. The gardens were a lot smaller than I thought but I guess it's a memorial tribute that was rescued by Yves Saint Laurent as the garden was left to ruin. You can stay here for as long as you like, I saw a few people sitting on benches reading novels in the garden so I could imagine that would be a nice idea if you lived in the city. The gardens also contain a book & gift shop where I bought a really pretty bookmark.
