Beautiful. Tranquil garden outside the madness of the old city. The planting is quite restrained, don't expect spectacular but it is immaculately kept and very beautiful.
Worth a visit. Worth taking time to visit as is pretty and welcome shade on a hot day but note that it is small and v.busy.

Very nice and relaxing. Went to the gardens on a recent visit with my wife and welcomed the cool shade of the gardens. The gardens themselves are very nice and have a wide range of cacti and bamboo on display. There is also a Berber Museum within the gardens and that is also well worth visiting as the jewellery, tools, clothing and history of the Berber's is really interesting.

Nice and green. We visited Majorelle garden on first day of our travel. We just come from airport to Riad and directlly to garden. It was very fine to relax in the middle of green garden with special indigo blue details. I didn't know that Yves Saint Laurent lived there on his vacations in Morroco and that he help to restored the garden.Also is nice to see museum.
Nice to see. It's good to see for up to an hour if you are in Marrakech. I wouldn't go as far as saying its the number 1 attraction, but it is a lovely garden and museum for a cheap price!

A peaceful haven amidst the madness. We stayed in the Medina Gardens and walked to the Majorelle Gardens. What a beautiful and well kept garden it was. Not very expensive to get in although in comparison it turned out to be one of the more expensive. Be advised the public gardens are not the whole gardens and what is open to the public is surprisingly small. Nonetheless, worth a visit.

A QUIET OASIS IN MARAKECH . This was a welcomed break from the hustle and bustle and labrinths of the souks of marrakech. The planting and height of the palms make you feel like you are in your own oasis. The pots,tiles and landscape gardening just make you want to go home and start injecting colour and Yves Saint Laurent imagination into your own garden. Cheap to enter for 3 euro for an hour / or more if you want. Worth a visit even if you're not into gardening even if it's just for the photos.
beyond beautiful garden...not to be missed. Vibrant colors of blue and yellow...every shade of green that exists in nature. A lovely respite on a hot day.

Fantastic. The gardens are stunning, the striking blue building with yellow makes for a photographers delight.I went back for a second visit as we'd been rushed the first time, allow minimum an hour but I'd recommend more. The second visit meant I saw the gardens in both morning and afternoon light and allowed different photo highlights to be captured.Allow enough time to see the Berber museum (25 dirham) within the gardens. I even tipped a gardener to take a photo from within the garden to get the perfect shot front and centre.

Mediocre - not sure what the fuss is about. There are a lot of top reviews for this attraction, but I can't work out why. The garden is not particularly spectacular from horticultural point of view and with the crowds (even in the off season) it's not exactly a peaceful haven either.The museum here is good, with some interesting costumes that reflect the different regions across Morocco. It's small though, and overall i'm not sure this garden is really worth the trip.
Worth seeing. It is a special place with a nerve of its own.Go see it and enjoy !!!!Enjoy the beaty and the smal shops just across....with designer things and stuff you don't get in the souk!!!

Jardin Marjorelle a beautiful gift to the people. Jardin Marjorelle is a magnificent oasis in the business of Marrakech. A truly beautiful gift for the people to enjoy. The cactus section of the garden is truly spectacular. Such a pleasure to walk around and view the plants and pools from a variety of angles. Very funky studio.

Beautiful gardens an oasis of calm. This place is a really nice calm place to visit, the gardens are stunning and tranquil. The whole thing is done really well and was a lovely way to while away an hour.

Everything you have heard is true!. A real tribute to all that is the mystery and beauty that is Marrakech. The gardens are immaculate and alive with color, contrast and beauty due to the variety of plants that have been carefully tended. The blue color used as an architectural accent is striking and yet enchanting in a timeless way. The mood is relaxing and even on the hottest of days it was cool under the canopy of trees. It was crowded on the day I went but it was not overwhelming as the other tourists embraced the wonder of the place and people were friendly and relaxed.The Berber Museum housed on the compound is very informative and people friendly. A place not to be missed! A must experience in Morocco!!

Wonderful - and don't miss the Berber Museum!. Small but bright and stunning garden, a must-see while in Marrakech. The beautiful color 'Majorelle blue' is everywhere, contrasted with vibrant yellow, and with the pink and white bougainvillea blooms. Really emphasizes the gardens' beauty. Save time also to visit the small but very informative Berber Museum on site. It is well done, and a nice compliment to the gardens. It can get quite crowded when multiple tour groups arrive together. Take time if you can to sit for a little bit in an out of the way spot until the crowd dies down; the garden soon becomes more peaceful, and easier to enjoy.
Little trip. Trip to the Gardens, simple and colourful. Great place to look around. Well looked after; worth a short visit.

Peaceful gardens. Peaceful garden, frogs croaking, little fountains, beautiful palms a large variety of cactus. The blues, yellows and greens splashed over the buildings and pots make beautiful photos. Highlight of Marrakesh.

interesting, but little overated!. A little disappointed by the gardens, unfortunately it was an very hot day and everyone had decided to visit that afternoon.... was quite suprised to have to pay extra for the berber museum .. so didnt bother ! Lots of benches to relax and shade from sun .some gorgeous plants...... cafe ok. ... expensive and not terribly helpful friendly staff ...

Pretty flowers , great history and the contemporary God of fashion all in one place. The Jardin Majorelle is such a pretty garden , enjoy seeing the lovely plants- all fro the area , bamboo, cactus, fishes, flowers in the two hours plus that one can spen here, it's colourfully / artistically done . The Berber museum is a tremendous walk through history as I have been reading books on The Jews and the Arabs- I soaked in so much of history of these two amazing religions , understood what the Berbers are about. Seeing the God of fashion YSL too buried here was a thingy experience , as someone like me who is two left hands in art - sitting by his side was an out of body exhilarating experience , miracles happen!!

Simply beautiful.. The Gardens are in a decent part of town and are really lovely. It's set out so you can casually walk about the pathways and read about all the different groups of plants at your own leisure. Not too hot either with plenty of shade and even a coffee shop to finish it off nicely at the end. Good price too. One of the top places we went to on Marrakech actually.
A great setting. The 'jardin Majorelle' is like an oasis in Marrakech! Lovely food to be sampled at the café there. Well worth a visit.
If you're from California or the Southwest save your money. I expect to see exotic plants from Morocco but instead all I got was bamboo and plants from the American Southwest

A nice morning spent in the gardens. A good trip if you are visiting Marrakech and nice to get out of the hectic streets of the Medina. Good value and very nice gardens to wander around. We also went to the museum which was nice but small

Blue is the warmest color . What will surely amazes you is this prominent blue color. The blue Majorelle is wonderful ! This place was also the house of Yves Saint Laurent the famouse french fashion designer. The Berberian museum is also a must see ! Don't miss it, it is a very important part of the moroccans culture.

Peace and tranquility!. These are beautiful gardens and highly recommended. They are much smaller than the information on the internet suggests, much less than a quarter the size of a football pitch. The taxi driver said it would only take an hour to go round, but I didn't really believe him! He was right! You can, of course, relax and sit for as long as you wish and there are toilets and refreshment facilities, but an hour is sufficient really.

enchanted marrakech . peaceful, enchanting place, plantes and birds and history of the garden a large welcome to morocco et berber Museum, bookstore, beautiful boutique and organic lovely restaurant /cajole coffee

Superb and stylish. A wonderful visit (but can be crowded) to a cool and chic site to the north of the city. A must-see place to go to; in addition, a lovely cafe near the exit, as well as a superb museum

Beautiful, a must see.. Yves Saint Laurent's lasting legacy. Never seen so many different species of cacti. Lovely lily ponds. Really nice little café, excellent service. Well worth a visit. Nothing to dislike
Great Cacti garden. A repeat visit, amazing different types of cacti, some of the biggest I've seen. A must if you're in the area. Well worth the money.
Lush!. Pretty YSL designed and well maintained garden. Can easily spend few hours here lounging and soaking in the loveliness! Inexpensive entry free. A must if on a first time bisit to marrakech!

Absolutely worth a visit. These gardens are gorgeous, absolutely worth a visit! The entrance is lovely, there is so much to see, and the postcards you can buy at the end are lovely! Definitely recommended.

Highly anticipated massively let down.. We were in Marrakech last week curtesy of BBC, partially work for me and extended holiday with my partner. It was her birthday on the 12th May and we booked a holiday to beautiful Sardinia leaving on the 12th but few days before I got given this role which meant not only we had to cancel our holiday to Sardinia but I was going to be away nearly all week on her birthday, naturally she didnt want to go alone and equally she wasnt so keen on staying in London alone. Normally this isnt an issue but she is 5 months pregnant!! :)I managed to persuade the production to take her with me so she can relax by the pool while I am working and once I am finished we could enjoy Marrakech. Anyway I dont want to do this review of Marrakech as its another story so lets stick to Jardine Majorelle.I advice anyone not to go. I know die hard fans of the garden and Morrocco raising eye brows but stick with me till the end and I will tell from by perspective why so.Firstly its an odd place. Unless you are lucky and staying fairly close distance you will need to walk alot to get to it. While we are a nature mad, trekking, mountain climbing, canyon descending kind of family but at 40c plus 5 min walk equals to running circles in a sauna. You will need to get a taxi to and back. I strongly advice not to get a tour! it will add to the cost and disappointment. Again let me explain who we are. We live in London but not loving it, only for work. We do not like to live in any city. We are a nature kind of family and feel complete when we close to to the land, nothingness, plants and vegitation, mountains and rivers, animals, forests.. So going seen these gardens was on the top of our list as well as hiring a car and just driving out of marrakech towards the Ourika valley and river which we did! Its wonderful by the way but not to be included in this review.Anyways, the Garden is pretty with full of cactuses, money plants, massive bamboos, colours of the building are lovely.. But its only 50m square or something! Its tiny and I promise you we walked in in less than 10 minutes. I live in London, and have a small roof top, I promise you I have more flowers and rare birds coming to my garden than there are in Jardin Majorelle! Not to mention I have a resident Squirrel family living on my roof top. He is pain in my..... but thats another review.Yes literally you could do the round walk in less than ten minutes. And there is nothing to make you say Wow. Only good thing about it the staff that maintains the gardens which they do a great job and guides along the paths which are more than happy to take your camera and snap you mementos in every classical angle. The Museum is worth scene though only because they have incredible examples of early 19th century photographs of Berbers in Sahara and other photographs. Photographer in my gives 5 stars. cafe isnt too bad, lovely location tucked in that 50 m square! Food ok but thats another review on Morroccon food.So there you go, I know its only 50 dirhams which is about £3.60 for the entry but its not the money but disappointment of expecting something grand which is not. I clicked late but you could actually stay outside when you finish and sell you tickets back to other poor tourists for half price, this would pay your taxi fares so you only lost out on your precious time :)1 star I gave to this not because its horrible but its just nothing amazing to worth the track and waste money and time. Most hotels have more plants and little pools and wild life than this garden. Oh just to let you know we went at 9.15 am last week to avoid tourists with white shorts and cameras but guess what, entire tourist population thinks the same. Garden is too small and We have not one photo without a tourist with a hate and camera not in it!I recommend hiring a car for about 300 dirhams, £19 and drive towards to mountains. But that again you are never alone with the nature in Morrocco!!Would I go again to visit. Only to see Sahara.

Beautiful gardens. The restaurant was excellent, good service, very pleasant surroundings. Museum was excellent also. It was busy when we were there and it is a place where you would really like to pick a quiet day for a personal experience.

Afternoon trip to the Jardin Majorelle. After experiencing a "way too much walking" day on our first full day in Marrakech we decided to take it a little easier on Donna's reconstructed ankle. After some reviews my expectations were somewhat limited and measured about what to expect at this tourist site. We ended up spending more time than expected there and enjoyed it very much. The cactus and the bamboo are particularly impressive and we got some ideas about what to do with some of our spaces back home (many same plants). We paid the extra small fee for the Berber Museum and thought the collection informative. We ate a leisurely meal at the within the grounds restaurant which met our (again) measured expectations. All and all a delightful afternoon during a stifling, early May heat wave Marrakech suffered this year. I have marked this as a 1-2 hour attraction which I am guessing it will be for most visitors but we spent 3-4 there ourselves. So it all depends.
YSL reborned. Fabulous natural environement refined with master architecture, fulfilled with good taste, romance, peace and colours.

fabulous. Superb visit / tour of this place that invites you to rest and relax, this place is just beautiful, pictures to color wereexotic, well-kept garden masterfully, a peaceful haven in the heart of city of Marrakesh ...for 5 € the entrance frankly .... well worth it !!!!!

Tranquil Place. Unique Garden. Jardin Majorelle is an oasis in Marrakech. While the Medina and Jemma-al Fanah are bustling with tourists, food stalls and shops, this garden-cum-gallery-cum monument is a tranquil place, set in an elegantly upmarket locality of Marrakech - closer to the French side of the city. The place, originally conceived by Majorelle, was revived by famous designer Yves Saint Laurent who stayed and died here. The gardens, YSL's memorial are all brilliantly colour-coordinated with blue being the central theme. The place houses YSL's posters, designs and creations as well as his memorial. But what brings uniqueness is the gardens have an amazing collection of cactus. Local experts say it is one of the biggest cactus gardens in the world. A must-see. It is not an exhaustive trip and the entry fees are quite reasonable.

Beautiful and relaxing. . My husband and I visited Jardin Majorelle on our first day in Marrakech and we absolutely loved it. Entrance works out around £3 and is definitely worth it. So many beautiful areas, it's like a little hidden maze of nature. I think the gardens took us around an hour to walk through in total including a few breaks on the comfy benches. There is also a cafe in the middle which looked good. There is an interesting room full of pictures created by Yves Saint Laurent which was good to read and snap photos of. The only bad thing is that as it's such a big tourist spot in marrakech it is packed out so if you want to take photos you do spend a lot of time waiting for people to move out of the way or you find yourself ducking out of other people's photos!
just beautiful!. Fabulous garden.Restaurant food delicious.The fish tajine excellent.Also enjoyed the berber museum which is part of the gardens.

Colour and tranquillity. A lovely garden full of colour and unusual Cacti from Mexico and Argentina which would appeal to a plant enthusiast. A pleasant place to wander and relax amongst the chaos of the city! Photogenic spots everywhere to pause and admire.The shop is full of beautiful art and craft works but over priced! A small silk scarf price £160 is ridiculous. The entrance fee was 50 dirham although my guide map said 30 dirham. A grumpy man at the ticket office but a nice friendly taxi driver outside took us to our next destination as it was too hot to walk being 44c that day.
Stylish Paradise. The gardens are beautiful. Look out for the frogs and turtles in the ponds. Stop in at the cafe and drink in the scent of orange blossom that is sprayed onto you every few seconds.
Beautiful. Visited Le Jardin last week and it is definitely a must see! The Berber museum inside was gorgeous also, would recommend doing both in one go.

The colours are spectacular. The gardens aren't as big as I expected however it's a pleasure to walk around under the shade of the trees and take in the spectacular colours of the clay pots and mosaics. The cactus area is fab as lots of different varieties and shapes. I particular loved the Yves Saint Laurent 'LOVE' gallery and enjoyed reading how each piece he did every New Year for a friend. The shop and cafe are lovely too.

Beautiful Gardens... Ok. We got a taxi to the gardens , we were going to go on the tourist bus but that route doesn't start until 13.00, and we were ready to go at about 10am. Taxi was cheap so was ok about £2 ( 20dirham) The gardens are one of the main attractions but is not a day out by any stretch of the imaginations. You can see it all in about 30 mins. It's beautiful cactus, bamboo, water features , worth seeing if you come to marrakech, but as you would expect full of tourists who have all carved their names in some of the plants (not nice) . It is also 50dh to get in (£5)

not so impressive. After seeing some famous gardens in Europe, we were not so impressed by this (small) garden. The big bamboos were beautiful, but apart from that we didn't find it worth the trip. There are other things to see in Marrakech.

Beautiful, restored garden. Beautiful, restored garden. An oasis in a frantic city. The blue colouring of the buildings and effects was dazzling. The Berber Museum was interesting. The Yves St Laurent Memorial a little understated - bit disappointing really - we expected something more eye catching and stylish.
first trip to Marrakech. Beautiful but smaller than expected.A beautiful cool haven from midday heat.well kept with very helpful staff happy to offer help with photography!
Garden Visit. My wife and I visited these gardens in March 2014 on our first visit to Marrakech. It is well worth going to see. A nice tranquil place and quite unusual.

Still the best garden in Marrakech - but this isn't difficult. The standards at Majorelle gardens had well and truly slipped since my last visit here 4-5 years ago. Then, the specimen plants were of the highest standard, all side shoots removed in relevant cases, and the gravelled beds were smart with raised rings of gravel around the plants highlighting the space between them. A genuine masterpiece. This time the quality of the plants had significantly dropped and the raised edging borders designed with little imagination with plants that can be picked up from your local supermarket. More asparagus ferns anybody? Substandard and deteriorating plants have been left in place and basel growth left unchecked resulting in an untidy appearance. Also, fewer gardens staff were seen this visit so perhaps cutbacks in maintenance have been put in place over the years to make the gardens more profitable for its owners. Surprisingly, and if my french translation is correct their leaflet boasts employing 90 staff at this attraction, but of those I only saw one doing any actual work in the gardens! In my opinion this is no longer the world class garden it once was. That being said, the shop, museum, cafe etc were just as good as before. If you want to see how it was in the good old days I have a link to my old photo album together with my original review from 2011 at: http://gardenofeaden.blogspot.co.uk/2011/01/majorelle-gardens-morocco.htmlIts true when they say you should never go back....
Trip to Jardin Majorelle. Not as big an area as I expected, but pretty and staff offering to take photos for you. A few ponds with fish and turtles along with the monument to Yves Saint Laurent.

Tourist sightseeing rather than the getaway garden. This is a true must-see when in Marrakech. Keep in mind, however, that this is a tourist magnet, and you will not be able to relax in a calm atmosphere, as there are crowds everywhere. The garden is quite small with narrow walkways, so you will not escape the crowds or waiting lines for fine scenery shots. Go early in the morning (before 9.00) to avoid groups.

okay garden, very nice shops. the garden itself should be better maintained as a lot of really stupid human beings were carving their names into the bamboo and other plants ... the blue house is impressive and both, the bookshop and the museum shop with its own fashion and hertiage product is outstanding

Beautiful Garden, too many people. The gardens are really amazing but there is such a crowd that it is difficult to enjoy. We arrived early, just after opening, but we were still shepherded through the garden with at least 100 other people. Frustrating to photograph with so many people there so don't expect to take much other than close ups. Or just enjoy the lovely space.

Amazing garden. This has got to be seen, amazing garden in the middle of the madness of Marrakech. Does get very busy so try to get there early. The cafe is also very busy but worth trying it just for a sit down!!

Must see gardens that are a well mainitained riot of colour. One of the must-see attractions in Marrakech. Not a huge site, and therefore quite busy, but the gardens are a riot of colour, enhanced by the brightly coloured plant pots and buildings. Beautifully maintained, with staff on hand to explain many of the species of plants (and take pictures of you too). Once you have visited, the shop opposite offers a really interesting array of designer curios and the like.

Exquisite. A jewel of an experience and a welcome relief form the Jemma al fna and hubbub of the medina. This is a tranquil botanical garden, beautifully executed and a tribute to St. Laurent. Be sure to get there before 9 am to avoid the tour crowd, which can spoil the soothing effect of water features, paths flowers and plantings. The garden looses an important intimate effect with crowds vying for camera shots and otherwise misbehaving.

Beautiful garden away from the crowds. Stunning garden with lots of shade. Nice museum there as well which gives lots of info and pieces on the berbere people. Lovely water features and benches to sit down. Throughly recommend (500dhs for entrance and museum)

Very beautiful gardens . I would highly recommend coming here, it's very beautiful and offers some restbite from the heat as it's very shady. There are lots of exotic plants and if you have time you can sit and read a book. There is also a small cafe there which is nice, but a bit pricey.

Small but beautiful. YSL tailored a perfect garden here. For only 5€ you are allowed to visit a nicely manicured garden that takes you into a fantasy world. Worth every minute spent there. TIP: tell the taxi attendant you don't want to queue for ticket. A little "baksheesh" gets you fast lane access...
Beautiful!. A nice place to rest, specially when it is hot.Nice and calm atmosphere, beautiful pictures...Allow you at least one hour to visit it and try not to get there when most of the tourist do.
A beautiful way to end a hectic day. Jardin Majorelle was the last stop in a long, hot day of walking Marrakech. It was stunningly beautiful and very restful. The cafe was excellent. Don't miss it.

A must see. Beautiful gardens really pretty pictures to be taken here. Nice cafe too. Really nice to be here and relax with the tropical plants surrounding you. We didn't do the museum side so I can't comment on that.

Lovely green escape. These gardens are a wonderful escape from the other crowded places tourists visit in Marrakech. Unfortunately like most places, there still were too many people to make a visit a really peaceful experience, which you can only imagine. Nevertheless, it is well worth a visit.

An oasis of calm. We visited the Gardens during our stay in Marrakech, and it was a welcome haven from the hustle and bustle of the city. We decided to visit early as we'd heard it gets busy later it the day and we discovered this to be true. It was a relatively simple walk from our hotel to the gardens, although crossing the road was sometimes interesting. On our arrival we headed to the small cafe for a mint tea before spending a pleasant couple of hours strolling around the pretty well kept gardens. There are a lot of areas in the shade to sit and enjoy the sights and sounds, although if you're not a fan of blue you may get a little bit bored. Taking photographs does require a bit of patience as everyone is trying to get the same picture, but with pointed elbows it is possible to get some great shots. Overall I would recommend a visit to the gardens just don't go expecting European style formal gardens.

Gorgeous!!!. While it is generally rather packed with tourists, it was so gorgeous and relaxing, you can easily while away a few hours just wandering around the gardens. There is a small museum inside the garden that I highly recommend visiting as it is concise, but an excellently curated collection and overview of Moroccan culture & costumes.
Great garden. Wonderful colours but a lot of tourists like myself and they sold tap water as bottled water just outside the garden entrance, so watch out.
Superb Plants. The variety of cactus and other plants - magnificent! Well kept gardens. Not many flowers but lovely plants.

A small piece of paradise. My wife loves gardens and this place is very special. also has a nice cosy and good quality snack restaurant - a little oasis. Do not rush it give yourself a couple of hours

Simply stunning. On the day we visited the temperature hit 46 degrees centigrade and the gardens offered both shade and tranquillity. The range of plants on display, the colourful nature of the location and the overall ambience of the gardens mean that it is a real 'must see' on any trip to Marrakech. And keen photographers will just love it - I know I did!

Just beautiful, nice and shady on a hot day too!. The gardens are just beautiful and so well maintained. Whilst they were also the busiest of the sights we visited in marrakech, it was possible to find a quiet bench and sit for a while to absorb the atmosphere.Lovely courtyard cafe too, will cooling mists of water sprayed from the walls, which was bliss on a hot day!

Beautiful gardens, don't attempt to walk here!. We walked from Ben Salah square in the Medina, which worked out to be about 2k. It doesn't sound a long way, but in 40' heat, it was hard work. We opted to get a horse drawn cart back to the Medina, which was expensive, but fun.The gardens are a photographers paradise, the colours are so rich and the array of shape and architecture is magnificent. We went at the end of the day, so it wasn't too busy. I seem to recall the it cost about £6 to enter, which is expensive.It was a tranquil breath of fresh air after the craziness of the Medina.There is a supermarket outside the gardens, so you can stock up on drinks, crisps and alcohol if required.

A nice change. .......from the hustle and bustle of the medina, a welcomed oasis, lots of exotic plants, during our vist we saw turtles in the ponds with the lilies, there is plenty of places to sit and enjoy, and toilets which is aleays a plus.

Beautiful gardens & interesting museum. Visit earlier in the morning to avoid having to queue for a ticket. The gardens are beautiful and well shaded so perfect if you want to cool off for a while. The Berber museum is well worth the additional 25 drn entrance fee, they have a many different language cards for each section of the exhibit so you don't have to worry about not understanding what you are seeing.

A haven of peace. Visited during our holiday stay in Marrakech. This garden presents a haven of peace, in an otherwise extremely busy city, as well as some shade and cooler temperatures, away from the burning sun. Definitely worth visiting.

Just beautiful. This garden is so popular we decided to visit early in the day and we're glad we did because it gets very crowded later. The garden is so different from the usual thing one can visit but it also gives an impression of the character of yves St Lauren. Such beauty. One could easily go round it in 15mins. If you we so minded but we spent at least 2 and a half hours visiting. Do visit the museum in there as well. A good insight into Berber culture.

Colorful relaxing place. The garden is very well kept lots of flowers I personally like the color of the buildingsthere blue and green make striking contrast,nice varieties of desert plant.a relaxing time.
always beautiful . my second time in the garden, not last for sure, !! really well kept beautiful oasis of lush green , wouldn't miss it for world! The ,, Must see!
Beautiful compact garden. good variety of trees and plants, all well laid out and pleasant cafeteria with well displayed Berber exhibition and shop. Welcome shade from the heat !

absolutely worth seeing. calm oasis in busy marrakech,lovely flowers. very expensive though,go in the early morning otherwise too many ppl. it s a bit of an journey to get there, because it s outside of the medina. it s taken care of meticoulosly, but also kind aexpensive

was expecting more colour. 50dh to get in so not expensive, nice for no more than half an hour of shade. It wasn't clear that there is a museum in the grounds that could be visited for another 25dh, we had sort of assume that this would be in a separate area
Wonderful. Wether you are a gardener or not you will enjoy this garden of calm and tranquility in the middle of a hectic city.

Tranquil, inspriring; an ideal place away from the heat. I've been a couple of times and still love it from the koi pond to the beautiful planting. There are cafes nearby although not in the garden, itself. There's isn't an awful lot of literature or to do as such; just a nice place to be . It is a major tourist spot so trying to plan a time to go when there will be fewer people makes sense,
Oasis. A beautiful garden to visit, doesn't take long to walk around but you can linger as long as you want to - stunning Majorelle Bleu!

Beautiful, a must visit. This is a beautiful garden away from the madness of the medina. We spent two whole hours here admiring the place and taking photos. Even though it was busy, we found it relaxing and took plenty of photos without other people in them. Some parts are shaded and others not and there's plenty of benches about. It was very picturesque; I didn't want to leave. It is quite small though but what it lacks in size, it makes up in beauty. It was one of the highlights of our week in Marrakech. Don't miss out.

Peaceful escape from the bustling medina!. Lovely garden with a great use of color that was a great respite. Spent the whole afternoon there -- after exploring the garden, sat on a bench just talking and also visited the cafe. Great romantic afternoon!

Museum better than famous garden. This is quite an extraordinary garden, not created but made famous by YSL. However it is quite small and the entrance fee compared to other places in M quite high. But do not miss the berber museum inside the garden. Very beautiful and interesting.
Expect a long queue to both places.

Jardin Marjorelle. This garden is worth a visit, any time of the day. Because of the towering trees, it is cool even in the hot Moroccan sun. It is beautifully laid out and maintained with gardeners working constantly. The water features are stunning. Although they charge an entry fee, it is minimal, but perhaps if they charged more, fewer people would visit and it would be more tranquill.
The best part of Marrakech. Absolutely impressive, this is an attraction not to be missed. Spend 1 or 2 hours wondering, great location!

Colourful and calming. It is best to pick a time when the gardens will be quiet - before the mass of tourists arrive. There are two fees to go into this attraction - one for the garden and one for the house. We only did the garden.Paths are well maintained, it's colourful and enchanting. You can wonder in any direction, and it is very clean. Children would find it boring.There is the inevitable shop, which is very expensive.There is an organised taxi queue outside, but if you are going back into town, then walking is as quick.If you like calming gardens, colourful inspiration, then this is definitely worth the trip.

Beautiful tranquil place. We love the Yves St Laurent Gardens. The colours are spectacular, plants lovely and visit at the right time, penty of turtles in the ponds.Its a lovely place to spend an hour or so, and is a haven of tranquility. There is a lovely little cafe - although a little pricey. Definitely not to be missed if you are in Marrakech. Fabulous for photography.

Stunning but crowded. Beautiful garden, I had no idea what to expect when I purchased my ticket, when you pass the doors, you enter a fantastic world of perfectly sculpted plants, trees. There are many benches inside which is great to have a rest, unfortunately they let a lot of people in at the same time which makes it hard to have privacy and enjoy the place fully.
Fabulous gardens. Beautiful colours and exotic planting. Great place for a cool walk on a hot day. An excellent café for lunch.

Best place I visited here but everywhere else was pretty darned poor so, under normal circumstances, I'd give this 3. Reviews on here and in guide books gave me great expectations but the gardens are EXTREMELY small as city gardens go! At least they were well maintained and the small buildings within pretty. At 5 euros entry + 2e for the museum it was the most expensive tourist venue visited here. The museum was so small that I thought a huge chunk of it must be elsewhere but, no, it was indeed tiny.

Fascinating colours. This garden is full of vibrant colours that come from painted structures and the vegetation that embraces the entire garden. Beware of the hoards of tourists - like me and you - which can make the park seem a bit small. Take a bottle of water with you and grab a seat somewhere (in the shade) to take in the beauty of the surroundings.

Haven of peace. Be there early, and I mean early, before the crowds as it is quite small and on the tourist route so gets very crowded. Beautiful place, amazing blue and yellow colours and light and shadow amongst the plants. Lovely little café area where you an sit and admire the peace and quiet, which is a lovely change from the hustle and bustle that Marrakech is.

Oasis of calm with turtles!. Had a lovely walk around the gardens and watched the turtles swimming, before having a coffee and splitting a lovely club sandwich in the cafe, free wifi! Nice shady break from the sun and crowds
Nice colours but small nothing amazing. Nice blue an yellow colours. But very small nothing spectacular. Average garden... Turtle pond is nice. Can walk around this place in 30mins max

Worth s visit. I am not a keen gardener, my partner is and she loved it! In her words they are 'just stunning'I thought it was a peaceful cool place to take a couple of hours out of the bustle of Marrakech, the trees and plants were actually wonderful especially as our visit was in Spring. They are spotless! Definitely worth a visit!

Beautiful way to spend an hour or two. The gardens are lovely and it's a calm oasis, away from the chaos of the Medina! Come early in the day or late when the crowds are thinning and you can really explore.
A colour explosion. beautiful gardens and incredible building with gorgeous YSL LOVE exhibition. so lovely to walk around and take in all the incredible colours and textures.

Beautiful but pretty busy. We found the gardens to be quite pretty, especially on an incredibly hot day, but rather crowded with tourists so not that quiet or relaxing.Also at 50 dirhams per pperson it felt a bit pricey too.

Tranquil Gardens. What a lovely place to visit. The peaceful, calm hits you as soon as you enter, the vibrant blue, green & yellow colours of plant pots & the house are such a lovely contrast to the greenery.I have an interest in fashion & Yves Saint Laurent so I found it quite interesting & enjoyable.Get there early to avoid the crowds, definitely worth a visit for the tranquility.

Beautiful place. This is a lovely place to visit. The shade of the overhanging trees offer shade in the afternoon and it's a good half hour stroll around the gardens, however they are smaller than expected, and we also had presumed maybe there would be space to have a picnic as such, but it is solid stone paths so no such luck. The gift shop and gallery are brilliant and although we didn't eat the little restaurant looked incredible (but pricey). Would get 5 stars if the admittance price got you into the house as well as that is extra.

A pleasant garden if you can see past the crowds. The Jardin Majorelle is charming no doubt. Located in the middle of the new town it is a short taxi ride away from the medina. Alas for me the experience is somewhat spoiled by the hordes of tourists navigating the garden's narrow walkways. If you are looking for an oasis of calm you will be bitterly disappointed, and your time is probably better spent visiting the fantastic gardens of La Mamounia. Nonetheless it is worth a visit if you are in the area...

Beautiful - and crowded. The garden was really beautiful and a nice break from the hectic city. Admission isn't too steep so it is worth visiting!
It was super packed the day we were there (a weekend in May). We had fun taking photos!

A sanctuary in a busy city. Jardin Majorelle is outside of the walled city and costs 50MAD to visit, with an additional 25MAD if you wish to visit the Berber museum inside the grounds. Majorelle has beautiful grounds and is a peaceful place to be if you go when it opens (9.30am) - at around 11am it starts to get a little too full of tourists which disturbs the tranquillity. I would recommend a visit, and I enjoyed the museum too. It's quite small but interesting. Look out for the plastic guide sheets explaining the exhibition in English, otherwise most of the signage is in French.
Beautiful, tranquil, peaceful. Well worth the visit, go early or later in the day though as lunchtime tends to be busy with tourist groups
A Must See whilst in Marrakech. Go visit!Jardin Majorelle is a sea of tranquility in the mayhem that is Marrakech.Whilst busy with visitors, it is peaceful and quiet and quite unique.

Beautiful - but get there early. I cannot understand how anyone could be disappointed in this garden (unless you stood in line a long time to get in). They are magnificent, although on the small side. Walking the gardens takes 30 to 40 minutes. The cacti, bougainvillea, and other plants from all over the world were great. And the Berber museum is a must.We arrived around 10AM and there was no line. When we exited by 11AM, there was a long line.
Stunning Gardens. The gardens are well worth a visit, they are beautiful and calming. Take a camera, you'll want to take lots of photos
Unbelievably beautiful!. Gorgeous gardens, lots of shade and I'm so happy to have seen where Yves saint Laurent called home. It's obvious he loved Marrakech.

Slightly disappointing. Loved the brightly painted buildings and the water features. Plant displays became repetitive, I expected more variety. The memorial to yes Saint Laurent was very disappointing.
Loved it. Very quiet and very well maintained - well organised once we get there (though not easy to find by walk...)

STUNNING!!!!. First of all, if you're a typical Botanical-gardens kind of person, please be realistic and do not expect a huge area from Jardin Majorelle.I spent two beautiful hours in this garden as I was there before it opened its doors and the tourist buses haven't even arrived. I read tips here on TA that there will be alot of tourist buses after 10am so I came very early on my last day in Marrakech. I decided to see this before I left back home as I wanted an oasis, away from the crazy Medina, souhks and the crazy people traffic at the main square. I wanted to destress from all the buzz I saw and I was very glad to have not missed this place.If you like relaxing in gardens, sitting on a bench, making a sketch or perhaps just watching blooms and cactuses....then this is for you. If you're just here to take selfies, then this is not the stop for you (aside from the area where you can take a photo of the blue house). But for those who actually love greenery, you will enjoy it here....IF you go very early! I found it very amazing to see every single detail from the lense of my camera. I believe if you only make the effort looking into the details, you will very much appreciate Jardin Majorelle....very, very much indeed :) When I showed photos of this garden to my husband and his family, they felt they needed to go to Marrakech only for this....such a beautiful oasis! TIP:Do NOT take the cabs outside the gardens....not even the small ones or the mercedes ones. The mercedes ones takes large groups and the small ones takes solo travellers like myself or couples. They are a rip off! Grab one at the main road, just a two minute walk from the gardens and ask that the meter to be run. I had no problems whatsoever and paid a quarter of what the cabbies were asking outside the gardens ;)

Very Pretty, lots of visitors. The garden is really nice and well worth visiting, possibly more so at off-peak times. There were a lot of people around, but once you got on the little paths it didn't feel too crowded.

Amazing. Over 100 species of plants from all over the world. This is definately one of the sites not to be missed in Marrakech. Very peaceful location to take a stroll and discover something new about nature.
Worth a look. A bit expensive really but ok if you've got an hour to kill I did enjoy looking at the cactus and managed to get some nice photos. It has a small cafe inside to relax in with a mint tea

Worth a visit. It was on the top of my list of the attractions in Marrakech and was not disappointed. Though it is in a small confined place but the exotic plants and their upkeep makes this place beautiful

Disappointed. I expected more and there was only a small place to see. I was disappointed. It is nice for a quiet walk but there is not a lot to see. They have palm trees there and the jardin is outside the centre.

A little disappointment. Nice garden with a lot of greenery, but almost no place to sit and relax..only a few benches were still occupied. Extra fee for the Berber Museum inside the garden. The Love gallery with the collages of the Yves Saint Laurent was the most interesting, but you don't expect this in a garden.

Jardin Majorelle. too expensive the enter ticket for what the place offers to you.
it is a nice and peacful garden, but nothing so special. I have other garden bigger and more interesting,

Beautiful. Imaculate gardens, so beautiful. Very calm and relaxing. Lots of shade so nice and cool whilst walking around and seeing all the differnt areas. lots of photos to be taken, all the differnt colours, smells ect the atmosphere is lovely.
Peace & beauty in Marrakech. An oasis of calm. Beautiful varied plants Interesting small museum displaying traditional crafts & costumes and pleasant cafe in a smalł courtyard
Nice couple of hours. A nice relaxing walk among the Cacti in a pleasant setting. Very cool as it is almost entirely shaded by a canopy of vegetation.

Just beautiful. To visit the farden where Yves Sant Laurant lived and worked is just a must during the visit of Marrakesh. The city is very busy, loud and a visit of the beautiful designed garden is very relaxing. In the garden is a good bookshop and a beautiful cafe.

Colourful & Vibrant. The gardens were stunning as promised. Best to go in the morning to avoid the crowds, and enjoy the beautiful colours and plants. I'd recommend avoiding the gift shop and cafe, as these both felt wildly overpriced compared to the local equivalents, and far closer to prices back home.
Take a camera and enjoy!

very nice - clean and atypical. This wonderful garden is super clean colorful and relaxing. It had a really good time. It is unusual in the middle of the city of Marrakech. A 30-minute visit seems sufficient to me. superb!
Beautiful gardens. Beautiful gardens providing a haven of cool on a very hot day in Marrakesh. Very well cared for and interesting museum about Berber heritage in grounds.

Beautiful and Relaxing. Le Jardin Majorelle is the perfect antidote to the bustle of the Marrakech medina... but do not expect to have it to yourself. One of the most touristed spots in Marrakech, the garden is beautifully maintained, vibrant and lush. If you are traveling during the hotter months, go early in the morning (opens at 9AM) and plan on having lunch in the charming (if a bit pricey) Cafe Bousafsaf.
Tranquil, beautiful and not to be missed.... Take the love of your life and a few hours. I took both and was uplifted by Jardin majorelle. Beautiful colours, such tranquility.
Smaller then expected but worth the visit. Very nice garden, it was quite small but with beautiful vibrant colours, a great cafe and a nice ambiance.

Simply stunning. Quite simply Jardin Marjorelle is beautiful.I won't go into the history of the establishment, as that is well documented.I will, however, lay out one or two points about the gardens which may be of use for travellers. 1. Get there early, aim for 9.30am. Part of the beauty of the gardens is that they are so trabquil and peaceful, however, due ot their popularity, they do get busy. Enjoy tyhem at their best when there is less people around.2. Pay for the Berber musuem, i's an extra 25 dirham and well worth it. 3. Take your time, the array of foliage, the botanical wonder is simply stunning. Don't rush through and rush out. Stunning...
Just Beautiful. Go very early if possible by called he to avoid the crowds, then it is the most beautiful tranquil place

Beautiful, relaxing gardens in Marrakech. Definitely worth visiting. A peaceful oasis of greenery - stunning bougainvillea, lovely planting a of cacti, love all the blues. A must see, even if you are not a gardener.

Beautiful!. Really peaceful and beautiful place to visit! If you stay in Marrakech for more than 2 days, you must really visit this beautiful gardens. Nice way to escape the busyness of town for a few hours.

Gorgeous cool gardin with some amazing cactii. Wandering around these gardins was a very relaxing experience as the day was very hot. The only disappointing thing about the gardins was the damage caused to some of the plants (grafitti) by irresponsible tourists.
Stunning. Stunning gardens, take your camera it's so pretty! Well worth a trip whilst in Marrakech. Get a horse and cart there just for the experience.
Quiet cool relaxing garden setting. Great experience in the midst of a very hot and busy Marrakech. A quiet cool oasis that has trees and plants from many parts of the world. Well worth a visit.
Beautiful and tranquil. Very beautiful gardens- smaller than expected. Berber museum interesting and the cafe was great - really good food and service
Lovely oasis in the middle of the city. A little chilly the day we went, but can imagine it is a hit with tourists on a hot day. It was also smaller than we imagined.

Beautiful. Beautiful gardens, definitely visit the Berber museum that is located within the gardens too, as it is well worth the entry price. Expect the gardens to be absolutely packed with tourists though.

Jewel in the crown. I loved everything about this place. As a photographer I shot everything and went twice. Get there early as it opens at 9. The light in the afternoon is too harsh and it does get very hot. The cafe is wonderful and take your credit card as the jewellery in the gift shop is amazing. The museum has the best collection of Berber jewellery and clothing in Morocco. The book shop is fantastic and sells postcards of all the wonderful Yves St Laurent posters

A Must See!. A calm pretty place, you're free to wander where you like and the plants and flowers are amazing. The Moroccan blue painted walls are striking and the Berber Museum is fascinating. A lovely way to spend an afternoon.

Relaxing place. We went there early morning, so it wasn't that busy. The gardens are kept very clean and it looks amazing. You walk under huge palms and cactus. Water ponds and small fountains are surrounded with water plants. The unusual buildings are painted mainly in blue color. There are various benches sit down and relax.

Stunning Blue Oasis. these beautiful garden with the stunning vibrant blue paintwork was previously owned by Yves Saint Laurent it is a collection of palms and cacti from all over the world with waterways and pools full of goldfish and turtle's. The museum tells of the history of the tribes who live and work in the mountains with an insight on what they wore and beautiful jewellery and next door a art gallery. If you want to enjoy the beauty go early as does get busy
Oasis in the middle of a wonderful but crazy City. Cool and calm...beautiful and tranquil. A must visit. Cafe is lovely with cool fans and within a walled garden.

So beautiful. Me and my partner visited during a weekend, had to queue up for around 10 minutes which range alarm bells to a very busy area. Once inside it didn't seem crowded at all and we managed to get a few nice photos of a really beautiful, yet quirky space fairly central to Marrakech. Berber museum was a bonus but disappointed we could not take photos there. Well kept and a respectful memorial to one of fashions' greatest icons
Interesting and tranquil. Worth a visit if you like gardens and vibrant colors, although it is quite popular and busy. Cafe made great coffee.

Stunning. Get there early! It opens 8.30. About an hour to an hour and a half is plenty of time before the crowds turn u. Stunning gardens, water and use of colour. A haven for birds. We thought we would do this rather than the Palace Gardens as we were only in Marrakech three days. Worth the visit. Incredible cacti and plants and trees.

Peaceful retreat. A bit pricy compared to the other lovely sites and gardens in Marrakech, but well worth a visit. Loved the cobalt blue throughout and the cactuses from all around the world. There are also nice shops and a cafe just across the street.
Beautiful - not to be missed. Beautiful gardens, helpful and friendly staff. Do not miss the Berber Museum! The restaurant is relaxing and the food excellent

Crowd control anyone???. The gardens are beautiful, if you can see them. Ok, it was not that difficult, but it was not peaceful. There were a few school groups, and tour groups there at the same time as us, and there were just too many people in the small gardens. I assume that it is always busy as it is on everybody's must see in marrakech. And it is a must see. The gardens are small and beautiful. It would be much more peaceful if they limited the number of visitors at one time. We went at 10a on a Saturday morning.

What a marvellous quirky place!. Didn't really know what to expect of these gardens in Marrakech, so the visit was a pleasant and exhilarating surprise. Not your usual park, this garden was created in the 1920s and lovingly maintained to this day, home to a collection of cacti and palms and other exotic plant species, The quirkiest thing about the place is the colour of the buildings here, which housed the studio of the artist who created the garden. Art deco style and painted in garish blue and yellow, it may not be to everyone's taste, but I loved it. Totally different to anything else you'll see in Marrakech, it's well worth visiting.

Beautiful Jardins with the final resting place of YSL. This place used to be the vacation/relaxing place for the famous Yves Saint Loureant. It has a few fountains, some with a surrounding pool and connected to others by small canals and a lot of trails paved that take you all around where you can see the extensive collection he had on palms and mostly a huge variety of cactus, pretty much any plant or cactus you can find in the Sahara Desert, he had it there with a lot of people taking care of the place. There is an small fee to pay to enter but is worth it once you get inside and see how well is all taken care and preserved. Ah, it has a covered aquarium with a few colored fishes and this is an excellent place to take a 5 - 10 minutes brake in the shade and take it in. Worth visiting Good luck

Must go to gardens!!!!. Beautiful nature, amazing colors!!! I got lost in the "Majorelle blue" a very deep and special hue. An aesthetically beautiful place, nature, plants, colors. Go and soak in it!!! Can't wait to go back :) I would also recommend to finish your visit with a drink and snack at the cafe. Divine !!!
Beautiful. Beautiful, but gets very busy, especially (the very interesting) museum. I would recommend the cafe though.
Beautiful. Great place to relax and enjoy nature. Really interesting plants and flowers. Very serene and great for kids. The Berber museum is worth a visit just for the starry room (spoiler alert!).
Lovely Retreat from the Heat. A color explosion in Marrakech. I would recommend a visit to this garden to cool off and learn about the Berber culture in the museum.

Beautifully curated.. This is a must see site not far outside the medina walls. Queues can form for tickets to enter so an early visit is advised. The gardens are predominately green due to a high volume of cacti and other desert plants and the memorial to Yves SL is a little underwhelming but the Berber museum is an excellent exhibition of the various styles of dress from the different regions and the pieces of YSL artwork are fun.Walking back to the Medina takes less than 15 minutes so taxis are not necessary.Beautiful if somewhat pricey café/restaurant.
Yves Saint Laurent memorial. An oasis in the middle of the city of Marrakech. Too bad people keep carving their names in the plants.

So much colour in this busy but peaceful garden. The guide books recommend that you get to the Majorelle Gardens early to avoid the crowds. I wish I had done this. I arrived at around midday and there was a large queue. The ticketing staff kept the queue moving along quickly though, so it wasn't long til I was in the gardens. Entry to the gardens is Dh50, with an additional Dh25 to go into the museum (opening times vary throughout the year so check the website http://jardinmajorelle.com/ang/).The gardens themselves are not that large so if you are not that interested in cactus and plants, you may not spend long there. If you are interested in the history of Morocco and the various groups that have shaped it into the country it is today, then I highly recommend you get a ticket to the museum which exhibits the many differences between the tribal groups within Morocco, from clothing and jewellery through to language and living arrangements. Enlightening
Lovely oasis of calm. Beautiful gardens and a nice museum. Don't expect to be here for hours - it is quite a quick place to get around but worth the effort.

not to be missed, house refurbished by yves st. laurent and his partner l-over. gardens and jewelry and clothing. fantastic and itme to see all even with somany pople who go there weodltravelelrs... and hsops of copies of things leather shoes jeweler right acros the street beautiful!!!
Beautiful. Walkable distance from the main square. Beautiful garden, Lilly ponds and flowers. Gift shop was expensive but a really good cafe for lunch.

Nice and calm garden. Nice garden with an interesting history. It is a bit expensive as the entrance fee is 7 euro. The money are well spent on a sunny day where you long for the shadow under the trees.
Calm. A nice oasis from the busy city. An informative museum in the gardens which is worth viewing to get a taste of the Berber culture. Lovely setting café although we didn't eat there.

Stunning!. I've studied garden design and these gardens are gorgeous. So well designed every corner you turn reveals a new vista amazing as they are not large gardens and the planting is superb. Go early or late in the day as they get extremely busy, probably too busy to really appreciate the gardens fully.

NOT SURE WHAT THE FUSS IS ABOUT??. I was looking forward to our visit to this garden & left dissapointed.It is in the centre of town & probably is chilled out if you're not following the herds of people , stood in queues to look at things as it isn't a large garden.It is mainly a garden of bamboo which I do like , some nice floral arrangements, along with vandalised cacti with tourists names carved on them ! We expected the admission fee to include a look in the villa, but this isn't included.We were told about the colour Majorelle blue being unique to Marrakech, which shade?? There were several shades of the colour in the gardens.The courtyard coffee shop looked nice but we were fed up of the crowds of people by this point & left.

Oasis!. This gardens are an oasis in the middle of the city. They have many different species and was created by a famous french painter - Majorelle who moved to Marrakech for health purposes.Worth a visit!
Just Beautiful. Beautiful Gardens, If you love all Nature, and Natural beauty with a little history, then you must visit here.

Tranquil gardens and a great cafe. The gardens cost about 50 dirhams and it's worth the visit, to simply Stroll around this tranquil garden. It's famous for YSL ownership and restoration, but the cafe also serves delicious tarjines and some of the Moroccan speciality ice creams like orange blossom is worth trying, It's worth taking time out from the busy medinas!

Stunning but go early. We had read you should go to Majorelle early as it gets busy. We arrived at 10:30am and it was already lined up outside and inside was the busiest we had seen any "tourist" attraction yet in Morocco. Our driver said it is always this way. The gardens are so beautiful and the striking, cobalt blue colour is my absolute favourite, so it was easy for me to fall in love with this paradise. We would've likely wanted to take more pictures but with the amount of people it was very hard. It is definitely worth a stop and I completely understand why it's rated #1 in Marrakech. A welcome break from the souks and mosaics we'd been looking at the day before.
Stunning. Not very large but well worth a visit. It was beautiful and a fabulous shade of blue also very peaceful and the mint tea at the Cafe was very nice.

Wow. Must see. Stay a while. . The Majorelle gardens are other worldly. You have to go see it if you have an appreciation for visually pleasing decor and botanics. Give yourself a lot of time to sit and take it all in. Great little cafe. The gardens can get very busy so go early in their opening hours or late.

Oasis. In the awfuly hot day, jardin majorelle was an amazing oasis of natural shadows, fresher air, calmness and visual beautiy. Provided a real relax. Entry isnt cheap, 50 dh, but worth it. Some plants like cactuses or bambus were damaged by people which is such a pitty, there are enough workers to check if people sctratch their names on flowers..
Beautiful paradice. Went here on the 28th April which was a lovely hot day and the gardens were well hidden in shade. Such a beautiful garden so many great photos taken here.

Stunning cacti. The best thing about this place is the wonderful variety of cacti and other plants. They are truly "magnifique", which was the word you kept hearing murmured by the French tourists. The cafe is pricey. The staff are helpful enough but seem bored. There's a few nice restaurants nearby too. Definitely worth visiting if you're in Marrakech.

The very-best sites we have ever seen !. The Majorelle Garden is a botanical garden and artist's landscape garden in Marrakech, Morocco. This is a rare gem. The first site to experience in Marrakesh !The garden hosts many bird species from North Africa, many fountains, and a large collection of cacti. It was designed by the French artist Jacques Majorelle in the 1920s and 1930s, then owned by Yves Saint-Laurent and Pierre Bergé. Continuous maintenance is practiced every single day, giving the visitors the impression that this 90 years-old garden was built recently.No way you miss it !

Tranquility. The gardens are both peaceful and tranquil. Walking round the stategically placed bamboo trees from Japan and Malaysia with numerous cactusea from all over the world. There is an entrance fee of 50dms each. Due to time limitation did not visit the Berbar museum. A very pleasant stroll around lasting about 1 hour.

Stunning. Jardin Majorelle is just stunning it is the garden where Yves St Lauren designed and is buried. On a sunny day the colours are stunning along with the plants and cacti. The museum in the middle is small but dedicated to Yves life. This is a definite must go and see and do not be put off with queues.

Extraordinary personal garden. This jewel is the personal creation of Yves St. Laurent and his partner, who endowed it and preserved it for our pleasure. Unique color combinations merge Morocco with a modern esthetic, making it a special photogenic place. The cacti collection is artfully presented. Amazing maintenance assures one of good imagery. The gift shop and gallery also fun. The Berber culture museum should not be missed. Extraordinary costumes and jewelry expand and celebrate one's love of this culture.
Compact a jaw dropping. Worth a visit. The colours and plants are exceptional. A haven of tranquility. So peaceful and unexpected just off a boring side street

Take your time!. This is a lovely place to visit, if you take your time to enjoy it. We spent the greater part of the day here, and couldn't help but shake our heads at the masses who arrive, hurry around trying to get photos of themselves in front of every viewpoint and cactus, get into arguments with others in the way of their selfies etc... Keep calm and enjoy the gardens! Go have some morning tea / lunch in the ridiculously overpriced cafe. You may just relax and enjoy it a bit. Oh, and take photos of the cacti; not yourselves! They really are a wonder to behold in their diversity and beauty!

Pretty and worth a visit. These gardens, created by Majorelle and Saint Laurent are worth a visit to see the beautiful range of plants and cacti, as well as the extraordinary colour of the cobalt blue house.

Berber museum/Nice shady garden. The garden is shady and has some benches and a little pond for goldfish.
There is a Berber museum and a giftshop. I bought two Moroccan cookbooks there.

Pleasant, interesting, not a 'must see' if short on time. We had 5 days in Marrakesh so we had plenty of time to visit the Jardin Majorelle, former home of fashon icon Yves St Laurent, and a vibrant burst of color that is worth seeing. However, if you are short on time, you might wish to spend your hours on a more traditional sight within the medina. It is a short taxi ride to the garden (about 30 dirhan or $3), about 8 euro to enter.

pretty and cool. Worth a trip if you are hot, very pretty and relaxing away from the chaos outside. The art museum is interesting as well but not massive. Great for photos, the cafe is quite pricey but clean and the food was good.

Lovely. Of course you're going to visit this - it's in the top 5 attractions of Marrakech. And it's lovely, a beautiful leafy contrast to the hot dusty city. To note, though, that it's also a relatively pricey attraction, at 50DH each entry, plus another 25DH each if you want to get into the Berber culture museum inside the garden.

Beautiful Gardens. Beautiful and tranquil grounds, but best go early to avoid the crowds. Worth buying the extra ticket to get into the Berber museum.The boutique shop has lovely original pieces but only if you have deep pockets!

Vaut le voyage. We walked out to the Gardens from the Medina (about 30 mins at a slow hot weather pace) and felt that we enjoyed the blissful cool green even more than those stepping out of their air conditioned taxis. Everything they tell you about this little sample of the garden of Eden is true. Do not miss.
Memorable gardens. Beautiful. Magnificent colours, exotic plants from all over the world . A calm oasis close to the centre of the city. Not to be missed if you like gardens

Very unusual garden.. This lovely garden has been restored by Pierre Berge and Yves Saint Laurent and the result is, definitely, worth visiting. However, you do need to choose your time otherwise it is very likely to be crowded. Having said that, we enjoyed our visit and saw some very unusual plants.

Must-visit, beautiful garden!. After experiencing the chaos of the medina, the Majorelle Garden was the perfect place to enjoy the peacefulness! We were so happy to find this gem, the pricing was cheap enough for tourists but high enough to keep others out. You'll be really glad you stopped in. It's a small garden, so you won't feel overwhelmed, but they also have a great museum and cafe.Must see, highly recommend!
stunning. Go early! It is really beautiful - but easily spoiled when it becomes busy. Absolutely indescribable colours, you'll see. The cafe is a truly delicious place to have a little mint tea.
Beautiful. Amazing mix of colours and patterns of light. Interesting plants and peaceful surroundings. While there were lots of people there, we enjoyed our visit.
Lovely garden. Peaceful place, lots of various cactus and plants to see! You can do the visit back and forth at your own pace. The vibrant colors of the building is a joy for the eye.
Perfect Oasis in the middle of Marrakech. These garden are beautiful and I found that its verry quiet first thing and was nice, enjoy the beautiful followers and the sound of the birds.

Interesting Garden. A very interesting garden - well worth a visit. It was started by Yves St Laurent and contains a monument to him. Within the garden is the Berber Museum - the jewellery and traditional clothing demonstrate the consummate skills of a nomadic people. A very pleasant way spend a few hours in Marrakech.
Beautiful Gardens. Definitely worth a visit. Beautiful gardens. We walked all the way from the Old city to the Gardens. An oasis....
Gardens. Stunning peaceful and tranquil a little oasis in a bustling city definitely recommend,not sure what it would be like on a cloudy day.we had a sunny day and it was beautiful

overcrowded with tourists. In my opinion this Marrakech site is slightly overrated. The garden is great, the villa Majorelle, and the Berber Museum inside is not worth the extra money they ask for.
All together the busloads of tourists make the garden very crowded.

Amazing. Fabulous gardens very tranquil and worth a visit, photographers heaven , architecture amazing painted with intense Morrocan Blue and Yellow, the tallest bamboo a great photograph opportunity.

Beautiful gardens. A must see in Marrakech. These gardens are beautiful and tranquil. Entry fee very reasonable. The cafe is lovely and food excellent. Caleches and taxis available outside; we opted for a lovely caleche ride back to the square- delightful.
Beautiful garden. We totally enjoyed strolling through this green, cool space in the midst of the chaotic city. Make sure to go into the Berber museum...it is the highlight of the garden.
Garden visit. Well worth visiting this iconic garden, beautiful and carefully maintained.Best to go early to avoid the queue.
Go for the Berber Musem. The garden itself is nice, but the majority of the (French) crowd are seemingly there for the YSL reference. The highlight is the Berber musem and it's well worth the visit.

A peaceful and beautiful garden. Gardens are beautiful with palm trees, bamboos, exotic plants. There are paved paths and benches to sit and enjoy the peacefulness of the garden. There is a pond with water lilies and the most beautiful blue called bleu majorelle. Yves St Laurent lived in the villa and his ashes were scattered in the garden when he died. The villa now houses the Berber Museum - all very interesting but can be crowded with tourists. Advice arrive early !

Colourful tranquility in the midst of a busy city.. If you enjoy visiting gardens and looking at different species of plants, you will enjoy this tastefully designed garden. Even if visiting gardens isn't your thing, I think this garden could be the exception.A wide array of plants and colours and flowers all arranged in a surprisingly small area. You could happily spend an hour or two here as a break from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Loved the colt blue and yellow theme. Lovely afternoon out even if it is hot the garden is design to be cool. I was so inspired by the colour theme that I came home and painted some of my garden pots.

Amazing Garden. This garden is unbelievably beautiful, the most amazing cactus, bamboos and palms, threaded through with canals of water and a lily pond. Not a speck of soil out of place, just perfect. Just over £4.00 entrance fee - not bad for a magical place. Even if you are not a keen gardener you cannot be but amazed. Did not find it crowded and very easy walking for those with any mobility problems,
Worth a visit. There are lot of parks in Marrakech but if you have the choice do not hesitate to visit this little juwel. The cost is 50 Dirham and count on 1 hour.

Thoroughly enjoyed it! Nice diversion from the medina, mosques and museums.. The Jardin Majorelle is a very pleasant experience. We visited in the spring and many trees and plants were blooming. No a large garden area but visually and spiritually appealing. Get there early before the tour buses come in. We were there an hour after they opened. it was not crowded. We were enjoying the peace and quiet which gardens are great for when suddenly a flood of people came in. It continued for over an hour and then we left.We walked from our Riad in the medina and it was not that far. We also walked from the gardens to a restaurant called the Amal Moroccan Restaurant and Women's Training Center which is another great experience. Beware of taxi drivers around the garden exits. We started to take a taxi to the Amal. One driver wanted 60 MAD to take us. I had him show me on the map where he was taking us and I knew he was going to the wrong part of the city. He argued with me and then we just decided to walk using my phone's GPS system. It was a 10 minute walk from the garden.

Tranquil, lovely gardens. We thoroughly enjoyed these beautiful gardens. The design is lush greens, with the blue paint that the Majorelle gardens are known for prevailing throughout. I loved the colourfully painted pots.
peaceful haven. a place to go to get away from the hustle and bustle of downtown Marrakechslightly eccentric colours and plants but thats to be expected. spent a nice few hours chillin.

Great hideaway spot in the craziness of Marrakech. Loved these beautiful gardens in Marrakech! It was a great escape from the craziness of the city! I enjoyed the peaceful quietness, smell of nature, blooming flowers and Spring vibes!

Beautiful gardens. You don;t need long to visit here but it is well worth it. Stunning cacti in a beautiful setting. and very peaceful. We visited early in the morning, around 9.30am, before the crowds and it was absolutely lovely.
Beautiful tribute to YSL and very peaceful.. Entry to the Jardin Majorelle was a very pleasant experience and one not to be missed when visiting Marrakech.
Beautiful Peaceful Garden . Well worth a visit, numerous cacti, palms, semi tropical plants, great compact yet comprehensive Berber museum, fabulous and expectedly expensive shop selling YSL goods

At 50 DA's still a wonderful visit.. I've been waiting years to come here and visit, and although it had the most expensive entry fee, it was outstanding.. even if crowded. I love gardens and this one, small but with stunning vistsa's and wonderful planting schemes, made the most of the space available. The range and variety of tree's,shrubs, succulents and flowers perfectly complimented the eye popping colours of the pavillions and pots. The staff perform an outstanding job in maintaining the gardens to perfection. There is a courtyard cafe for simple meals and drinks.

Pleasant walk in the garden. I spent a pleasant hour casually walking through the garden. There is an abundance of palm trees with other desert plants. At the time of my visit there were not a lot of blooming flowers so I had to focus on the palms, cacti, etc. This was a pleasant diversion but not an eye-popping, "wow" type of attraction for me.

A quiet Oasis. A lovely visit to a beautiful garden. A quiet oasis in the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. A fantastic collection of cacti one of the best I've seen all in pristine surroundings. Worth getting there early as it gets very busy later in the day and can be hot too!

An experience not to be missed. Went in daylight and then after dark. What a place. Yes you get hassled but they take a telling if you are polite and smile. Food stalls after dark are really cheap and food freshly cooked. I've no time for snake charmers or monkeys. Music amazing but they want money from tourists to play. You've got to experience it as you can't really explain what it's like.
stunning gardens. Very pretty gardens and an interesting museum. A bit pricey entrance fee though , but worth it. I highly recommend it!
Not to be missed. We took a taxi to these gardens early morning before the crowds arrived and found them to be very beautiful and serene. I have not seen cacti like this before. Very special.

Oasis. Beautiful gardens well worth a visit! They're not too big so would recommend visiting the Berber museum as well to make the most of it. We walked from the centre but was a hot trek and took quite a while so would either get a taxi or go first thing in the morning. Also very busy so might be quieter in the morning. Full of palm trees, bamboo and cactus!!
Beautiful colourful little garden. A bit pricey but lovely, quiet garden with gorgeous plants and trees. The garden hosts beautiful building (haven't visited the museum though).
Fine Garden / Brilliant Berber Museum. The gardens are ok, small and walled in and very repetitive. However the Berber museum is a must see and definitely worth the extra 25 DHM.

Busy, underwhelming. In the context of a late season visit, I found the gardens incredibly busy, but with little attraction. The tiny Berber museum is a very interesting gem in the middle of this underwhelming experience.
Beautiful and peaceful break from the hustle and buzzle of the Medina. A must-see stop on your Marrakech trip. Very peaceful and beautiful. And a nice break from the Medina.

Beautiful garden with stunning colourful pots, prints of Yves Saint Lauren 'happy' cards, & seats to sit & reflect.. The stunning Jardin Majorelle is well worth a visit although we got there late (around 5pm and closes at 6pm) so only had an hour. The garden was created in the 1930’s by artist Jacques Majorelle and restored in the 1980’s by Yves Saint Lauren and if you need to take some time and sit somewhere tranquil, this is the place. Until hearing the call to prayer, I’d forgotten how close we were to the hustle and bustle of Marrakech, and hearing this muffled by the garden, added to the atmosphere and experience. As we were staying in the Medina, got here on the hop on/hop off ‘bus touristique‘; on the ‘Tour Historique’ route. Although you could get closer on the ‘Tour Oasis’ bus within the same price, we had just missed one so rather than wait 1/2 hour for the next, walked from stop no. 1 near the Office de tourism which took about 10 minutes.You could pay a little extra to see The Berber Museum but given the time, we didn't do that but did have a lovely mint tea in the lovely little courtyard café.

Funky little hangout. we are a young family with a 4yr old son. It was the perfect size. Not too big to get around, can do in a couple of hours. The colours, the cactus, the bamboo, the water feature...a real oasis!We visited the small museum though didnt have time to stop off at the cafe. It looked nice.A must do, dont leave it out!
An oasis into the city. If you are tired of the messy of the city and its powder you should go to that place! Quite, beautiful and calm. The price is 50 DH, just avoid the museum which not worth.
Lazy afternoon. Majorelle Gardens are wonderful to stroll around for a couple of hours. Tranquility and Beauty in a bustling city .Second time I have been and still enjoyed.

So beautiful. To enjoy this beautiful garden at its most peaceful, go early! Berber museum is very interesting and worth a visit. Dont forget your camera for stunning background to portrait shots of loved ones!

Blue Blue Blue Beauty. Blue Blue Blue Beauty! Don't miss the trip to this beautiful garden. The colours and sculpted garden is zen like. The little café is delicious. The menu is full of local tastes and flavours. Highly recommended for a visit
An Oasis. This was owned by Yves St. Laurent. Was a lovely garden to relax in for an hour or so. The Berber museum was very interesting.

A Place to Relax. Go early in the morning and beat the crowds. Then enjoy a leisurely breakfast -- some would say it's expensive, but not compared with US/European prices. After that, walk around the gardens and enjoy the amazing flowers, plants and trees. When you're done, take the horse carriage back to the city.There is no better way of spending half a day in Marrakech.

Well worth your visit!. The gardens are breathtaking and the Berber museum is captivating. We could have stayed longer. The colors and types of plants and flowers provided for fantastic photo opportunities. And, the Berber museum provided some interesting insights before our trip into Imlil Valley.

Beautiful and interesting . Great place to see for a couple of hours in Marrakesh. Took some wonderful pictures in here.
