We went at around 9:30am so managed to miss all of the bus loads of people who were arriving when we left about 11:30am. Would recommend going in the morning and of course take a camera.

Colourful, peaceful and cool . Compared with the heat and bustle of Marrakech generally, these gardens are a chance to experience a bit of peace and tranquility. The shade is welcome and the colours are beautiful. It is a lovely place to unwind and relax. We didn't visit the museum, but it is reputed to be good too.Be careful of the taxi drivers just outside the exit. They will overcharge. Turn right on leaving and walk to the end of the street and hail a petit taxi there instead.

A highlight of our stay in Marrakech. My daughter and I had a wonderful morning in the gardens, enjoying the colours and the people. We loved the Love gallery! My daughter was very inspired by the whole complex. I was impressed by the bookshop and the fabrics shop, made some very dear to my heart purchases. It was fscinating to watch the visitors and how they admired the beauty around. The cafe served the best coffee in Marrakech!!!! A friend of mine has visited since and was also pretty impressed

Fashionably Timeless jardin. It changed the way I think about the garden. There were plenty of trees inside the garden so you got different feeling while passing different zones. However, what makes this garden special is how they created fashion with such simple colours. It was just lovely and there was a Berber museum inside this garden (extra charges) and I felt that this was a proper museum even though lots of descriptions were mostly in French.You won't be disappointed here.PS. Try to go in the late afternoon so at least you got less crowd....that is according to our hotel's staff.
Inspirational. Loved the Jardin Majorelle - was truly inspirational, particularly being a huge fan of Yves Saint Laurent. Highly recommend!

Beautiful. Gorgeous gardens, definitely get a ticket for the Berber Museum at the same time....When you leave do not get a taxi outside as they are very pushy (unless you know exactly what you want to spend) they are very expensive....
a great way to start the day. The gardens are not large but very well looked after, and the berber museum was worth the visit in itself.
Such a cleaver lay out, great for a couple of hours. It cost 75 Dh each and we really enjoyed the rest bite from the busy streets. A little oasis in a busy day of sight seeing..

Stunning gardens. Interesting museum. Make time to go here and if possible go early in the day to avoid the crowds and their cameras. It's a stunning small garden, the riot of greens of the foliage set against blue structures. There are succulents from all of the world, things that were familiar and others that we had never seen before. There is also a small, well presented Berber museum, displaying everyday artefacts, jewellery and clothing of the various tribes / regions. Definitely worth a morning.

Oasis of calm in a buzzing city, best for the last day of your visit.. This garden is so beautiful and calm. It keeps a traditional local charm, while it is not large (you cannot get lost), it has many places to sit down and take in the view. You can not hear the hectic city outside, only the bird calls.I think it is best to got to this garden on the last day of your visit, only after experiencing the hectic nature of Marrakech will you take your time and truly appreciate the tranquility this garden offers. This garden is not cheap to enter and can get very busy, visiting in the morning to avoid the crowd is advised.
A Tranquil Oasis. a lovely, tranquil place to visit for an hour or two. the garden is beautifully kept, with a fab variety of plants. well worth a visit
Some calmness in Marrakech. Lovely garden that gives you a bit of peace and quiet in the otherwise hectic Marrakech. A real oasis that brings some calm to your heart.
Mesmerizing. Very elegant and beautiful garden. Has a wide collection of cactus placed in a captivating arrangement. The design and colors were very calming and unique.

Well worth a visit !. We visited the gardens in April this year and they were stunning ! Would recommend those who visit also purchase the tickets for the berber museum which is really interesting and situated within the gardens
An oasis. Lovely gardens but small and didn't take us long to see all of it. The boutique is nice and the cafe serves some lovely food.
Beautiful garden. Well worth the visit, even if you are not that into gardens you will enjoy this. Try and go early when it is cool and the tourists have not arrived

Beautiful place & a must-see when in Marrakesch. The gardens have been bought and re-novated by Yves Saint Laurent who now has a memorial witihin the gardens. Beautiful fauna including a café, a museum, an art gallery plus shop! Better go in the mornings, as it gets very crowded during the day.
such a beautiful place. such a beautiful place, very peaceful, very quiet, in the middle of the city chaos.very very colourful
Day at Jardin Majorelle. The garden is really nice, well looked after. The museum inside the garden is very interesting. And not expensive. Great experience.

Very pretty, but a bit crowded and small. The gardens have a lovely variety of plants, but they were quite crowded. The price of admission is also way higher than any other site we visited in Morocco. We enjoyed our visit, though. I will note that the taxis in front rip you off. They refuse to use the meter, and wanted to charge 10x the correct fare to get us to our riad (we walked away).

Around the plant world in an afternoon courtesy of St Laurent. The garden is a must visit, a perfect blend of gorgeous trees, plants, flowers,pools and running water. Plants from every continent in perfect condition to be enjoyed at a leisurely pace and a lovely tea room for a cool drink or a light bite. Make sure toTo visit the Berber museum too.You may have to queue to get in so a hat and a bottle of water is advisable as there is little shade until you get inside.

Lovely to visit. This place is a must see to take lots of pictures - it's beautiful!! We travelled by horse and carriage as we weren't too keen on getting a taxi and that was a great way to see some sights on the way!!

Stunning Gardens. Marrakech is a wonderful assault to the senses and this is definitely a calming and beautiful place to visit. Morrocans love plants and the gardens show off the finest, amongst the most brilliant Majorelle blue background. Ponds that look like a Monet painting and a lovely cafe to sip a mint tea. Do visit here, you will not be disappointed.

Beautiful garden , a real surprise.. Our tour group took us there. I had no idea what to expect. What a surprise! The garden is very nicely laid out and the rare plants and the variety of cactus was simply impressive. The Berbere Museum on site was a gem. The best collection i have seen. Definitly worth the visit.
Jardin Marjorelle. beautiful gardens and very colourful. well worth a visit. Definitely recommend a visit, nice to get out of the heat of the day

Overrated. To be honest I wasn't too impressed with the gardens - there is nothing really amazing, I've seen much nicer gardens with lesser/no entrance fee. If you are a fashion aficionado (re. YSL) then it may be of more significance, but in my opinion it's better to spend time elsewhere, Morocco has many more beautiful things to see!
Please full and beautiful. Worth a visit for an hour or so. Nice place to have a mint tea. Museum not great but worth it for 25 dirhams
Beautiful. The garden was beautiful. The combination of colours an plants was breathtaking. My finance was in photography heaven, we enjoyed the many colourful and cool surroundings.
Beautiful Gardens. The Garden was well planned. You will see many suculents from all over the world. There is a little cafe inside garden which was quite nice.

Colourful gardens. Bright and well sculptured gardens by majorelle and YSL. Lovely cafe to stop and grab a drink. The food looked amazing, but a little more expensive than other places in Marrakesh. Bit of a walk from the medina and souks and I'm sure most people take a cab, but we walked. 50 dir to get in and 25 more for the museum, but did not bother with that. Had to queue to get in, but only 10 mins or so.

Wonderful garden - don't waste money on the museums inside. A brilliant stop on our journey, a really nice place to sit and take some nice photos. Unless you are particularly interested I would not waste any money on the museums inside as the gardens are more than enough.Take your time and get an ice cream from the gelato restaurant opposite before you go in.A great place and photo opportunity, a welcome relaxing stroll after the hustle and bustle of the medina.

Stunning. A beautiful place to visit, the garden was in full bloom and looked very colourful. Even though it was busy when we visited, you still got a real sense of the colours and atmosphere. It was easy to see why YSL fell in love with this place.

Peaceful escape from the city. We stopped here in the morning for a bit of peace a quiet. It is slightly more expensive than the Marrakesh standard 10 dirhams but I think it was only around 25 each (which is around £2) which isn't OTT. It is reasonably small but I wouldn't let this put you off, it's nice to have a seat and escape from the busy city outside. The museum (again smallish) was interesting and worthwhile. We had a nice lunch at a small restaurant called Pause Gourmand just outside. Would go again.

Typical Tourist Trap. I was in Marrakesh for a couple of days in mid-April 2015 and decided to visit the Jardin Majorelle, since it came so highly recommended on Trip Advisor. Frankly, I have a hard time to understand how is it possible that this place ranks so high on Trip Advisor. Here are the facts: it is a very, very small garden (I believe less than 400m x 400m!) yet it cost 50 Dirham (about 5 euro) to enter. The only thing in there are some exotic plants (mainly cactuses!) and bus loads of tourists walking around in that small place. If you have been to any other city in the world with a botanic garden, then give this place a miss because it will not be anything special. And you won't find any locals there! Only tourists go there!Besides, there is the challenge of getting there, with taxis charging at least 10 euro for a one-way trip. Personally, I decided to walk there from the Medina: it was a very enjoyable walk, passing through lots of cafes and local neighbourhood, and is less than 2km. So in my case, it was the journey there (rather than the destination) which made it worth it :-)
It's a garden. As you probably know, Yves Saint Laurent's ashes were spread around this garden in 2008. Human and sentimenta value aside, the garden itself is really nothing to get excited about.
Wonderful. This garden is well planned out with something to new look at with every turn you take. What huge cactus! Loved the colour 'colbalt blue'.
Living Art. A mysterious canvas of plants from around the world. We especially enjoyed the water lily pond and bamboo garden. The painted cobalt blue touches were a feast for the eye.
Too small. Not sure what I was expecting but felt these gardens were way too small. Not worth the effort to walk 20mins to get there. There are other nicer parks in Marrakech.

YSL gardens are beautiful.. Highly recommended when visiting Marrakech. A very beautiful and peaceful place. The colours are absolutely attractive. If you love gardens and exotic plants, this place is a very nice treat.

Best place to visit and start your Marakkech tours. This place can be reached in 15-20 minutes from Jemma El Fnaa by taxi paying around 50 MAD. Entrance fee is around 50 MAD. Once you enter you see a simple fountain in between Bamboo covered surroundings. They have colored blue and white structures to present contrast to green nature. Then you see a lot of varieties of Cactus and other trees. Through out the path, trees provide shade from the sun. In the middle, there is a pond having white and pink lotus flowers, charm little tortoises and fishes. At the end of the trip, you see like a climax - variety of trees, colored Bougainvillea flowers, gigantic cactus plants providing you a scenery worth memorable. This place is the first day first tourist attraction for us and it provided the comfort we required for the rest of the trip in terms of peaceful surroundings and appreciation for overall Marrkaech.

Nice place, but not 'waw'. This garden is a nice oase in the city, but it is everywhere discribed as very beautiful. It is a special garden, but not something you can't miss. There are nicer things to see in Marrakech.

Beautiful and Serene. Very peaceful place and a good place to relax away from other high-energy Moroccan experiences. Leisurely walk around and take pictures or sit and people watch. I'd definitely go again!

An elegant stylish and chic open space. A real attraction that is calm and tranquil after the hustle and bustle of the souks. The majorelle blue sings in the sunshine and there are some excellent places to photograph the amazing array of international plants

A restful oasis. A pleasant way to spend a relaxing hour or so just wandering around these gardens. Nothing spectacular but a pleasant mix of well laid out cacti, bougainvillea and trees. A pleasant change from the city's hustle and bustle.

Pretty gardens with dull and expensive sandwiches.. Pretty and interesting gardens, despite the constant pressure to get out of the ways of someone else's photo shoot... Berber museum is worth poking about for 15 minutes. What could have been a really nice cafe turned out to sell the most overpriced, under seasoned sandwiches imaginable.
Beautiful Garden. An amazing and unique garden full of history. The restaurant there serves good quality food but is a little slow, so allow plenty of time. An experience to teasure.

Beautiful but busy. We ignored the guidebook that told us to go early morning or late afternoon and it was very busy (we went at lunchtime). It's worth a visit and is stunning (the blue is just wonderful) but to fully enjoy the serenity in a bustling city I'd try to go first or last thing.
jardin majorelle. Truly breathtaking. We had a lovely day, stopping for wonderful lunch. There is so much to see, a must for any keen gardener, the layout is stunning. A piece of tranquility.

Beautiful and shaded, but too crowded. The gardens are lovely and walled, so no traffic sounds which was very nice. We visited early in the morning and the garden was already very crowded and a bit people noisy. I would recommend, but avoid busier times.

"Splendorous and serene". This garden is nothing like a normal garden with colorfull flowers and fountains. This is a harbor of beauty and peace. This is not only a "must see" in marrakech but one of its type aswell.

A wonderful colourful haven . The colours and tranquility are magnificent. All the colours that a notion of Morroca conjures up... It's in the northwest of the Medina. If you join the back of the queue don't be surprised to be pulled out and taken to the front. You pay the entry fee of 60 dirhams each but you're then expected to tip the man on the door. Well worth planning to spend a couple of hours here soaking up the peacefulness before rejoining the clamour outside.

not so special. Visit it, but don't expect a big garden. It's rather small and filled with a lot of people. We visited the garden of the Mamounia Hotel. This one is for free and a lot bigger. For us no must.
wonderful. lovely peaceful garden with colourful pots and a huge variety of plants. Go early to avoid the crowds.
Sublime. An oasis of calm and colour. Fantastic to lose yourself in for a few hours. Had lunch and saw the Berber museum, both worth it.

An absolute "must" while in Marrakesh.. These gardens are beautiful and carefully tended. Yves St Laurent developed a treasure for the Morrocan people and tourists to enjoy. there is also an exquisite Berber museum on-site. it is small and quite wonderful, even for non-museum people
Stunning garden - do not miss it. This is a completely magical place - vibrant colours and exotic plants. The highlight of a wonderful few days in Morocco.
Jardin Majorelle - beautiful but really small. Very pretty garden but extremely small comparing to other gardens I've seen. Very clean and well taken care of.

An hour before closing. Not too busy but still sunny. Didn't have to queue for tickets. Have been before but still find it tranquil after the hustle and bustle of the town. Everyone needs quiet time. The cacti are amazing but people have taken to scratching their names into the leaves - such a shame. The water features are beautiful. About 50 md to enter. There is a little shop on site, cafe and Berber museum, which I think you have to pay a further entrance fee. There is also a memorial to YSL . On leaving if you take right and walk to the end of the street you can walk past the block of apartments and there is an ornate gate where you can look through and see the gardens to YSL house. There is a plaque on the gate

Stunning garden. An oasis in the midst of a city which can be noisy and dirty. The garden is beautifully crafted with plants from all over the world. It is a must see. We missed the Berber museum, but it probably is worth a visit, as well. The entry fee is high by Moroccan standards.

Pleasant and stylish gardens. A short horse and cart ride from the main square - 6 of us paid Dir 250 for a one way trip - the gardens are very stylish and make good use of the vibrant blue colour associated with the gardens. The visit doesn't take long but there are a couple of reasonable cafes nearby for lunch or a snack.

Beautiful gardens. Great place to see exotic plants against vibrant painted pots and walls. Not that big and lots of benches so easily accessible for all. Did not bother to pay extra to go in the museum.
Beautiful.. Good for some calm during your stay in Marrakech. Good cafe for a relax during a hot day. Do not miss the Berber museum and take your time.
a true gem!. If you go early in the morning, the tours and busses haven't arrived yet and you can enjoy and admire the wonderful layout and fantastic colours at their best...absolutely loved it!
Beautiful. Very beautiful gardens and water features. Loved the use of brightly coloured pots. Relaxing walk amongst an amazing collection of cacti.

Stunning and tranquil. Such a wonderful, beautiful garden, in the "backyard" of the former home of the late iconic fashion designer Yves St. Laurents. Colorful fountain, striking cacti garden with examples from around the world. Many lovely places to sit and relax in busy Marrakech. Go!
Great collection. Small jewel of a garden in the center of a bustling vibrant city. The Berber museum was not impressive. The garden is a wonderful collection of bamboo, cacti and succulents.
La Majorelle. It is well worth a visit and has a very different feel to a lot of gardens in Marrakesh. Spectacular Cacti. Cost about £5 -- worth it we thought.

great escape from the busy city. This is a great place to find some peace and quiet. The entrance is affordable and it can be anywhere from an hour to a couple hours. The guard helped me get a great photo and the garden was so well kept. Many great selfie opportunities.

Refreshing. Most of the places tourists go in Marrakesh are crowded, noisy, dirty, and full of people trying to sell you things. The gardens are a refreshing break from this, by far the most beautiful place we visited in the city. Even my 8 year old son, who normally dislikes anything as boring as a garden, was enthusiastic about how nice it was there. We didn't go into the museum. We just enjoyed a break from the medina with a nice stroll around the gardens and some reading on a bench in the shade of the bamboo forest. Ahh...

Pretty but busy!. I thought the gardens were very pretty and could be peaceful/relaxing if not for the crowds. The pathways were narrow and with big crowds I felt the need to keep moving all the time, so I did not really get to appreciate the tranquility. If you time your visit well it is a lovely place to visit.

What is the fuss all about ?. Of course Jardin Majorelle is a beautiful garden but it did not blow our mind. It is quite small and I'm sure there are gardens that are much more impressive. Not really worth a visit unless you really don't know what else to do.

Peace and quiet at last!. This really is an oasis among the noise, hustle & bustle and dirt of Marrakesh. It was so peaceful strolling round the garden and you don't hear the traffic just outside. I have never seen so many different cacti from all around the world in one place. Yves St Laurent's ashes are in the Memorial to him in the gardens. The gardens are well tended and has a great cafe, museum and library. This is well worth visiting and good value for the 100Dh for the two of us entrance fee.

Pretty garden. Lovely garden, smaller than I had anticipated. Disappointed with the museum, but it's cheap to get in (cannot take photos inside) Gets very busy, difficult to take pictures when there are a lot of people about, but worth a visit.

Magical Gardens not to be missed. This was a real highlight of our trip - the gardens are an oasis set in a busy part of Marrakech. Once inside the scale of the plants are overwhelming and reminded me of the childrens book "Where the Wild Things Go".One tip - go first thin gin the morning as the queues build quickly which could be frustrating.

Pretty but very crowded. It's a pretty but quite a small garden. The colors are beautiful. Better visit it early in the morning. There are usually a lot of people. i could barely take a picture without someone walking into the shot. I also visited the museum inside the garden (blue building). There was an exhibition about the Barber Women. It was nice to learn a bit about the culture. The entry fee is around 50dhs and additional 25 dhs for the museum. It's more a one time thing.
Be sure to go!. Beautiful, tranquil and colourful gardens. An oasis from the hustle and bustle of the Medina but not far from the centre.

Jardin Majorelle - cool Berber museum but only if you have lots of time. A weird garden in the middle of the city. Yves St Laurent and his partner donated it to the government. I would have rather spent my time walking the streets of Marrakech. However if you have an hour to kill and some spare cash the Berber museum has some nice pieces.

Tranquility and colour. Loved how calm this was, the price was a little high in comparison to other attractions in Marrakech at 50 dirhams but not high in comparison to western prices. Loved the colour and vibrancy and the history of the place.
Lovely in the sun. Really lovely gardens, well worth a visit if you are in the area, only takes 20mins to walk around but still very good
Marjorelle blue at its finest. All of it, go early and avoid the crowds. The colours are stunning and the museum has fabulous jewellery, Yves St Laurent clearly found it wonderful.

Couple of hours of tranquility. Gardens are in Gueliz so if your hotel is that area you can walk with a map , if you want a quiet break to relax and contemplate away from the heat try here ! Children may bore quickly but very beautiful

Absolutely wonderful smallish gardens. Picturesque, peaceful, very reasonably priced - why would you not go there? Lovely courtyard cafe where small bottles of water are included in the price of a coffee. Don't skip the add on ( all of 10 Dirhams!) Berber museum. Excellent!

Perfect paradise . Just returned. Stunning beautiful serene gardens, one could sit for hours transfixed by the beautiful plants and cactus; the serenade of the birds song or the hypnotic swaying of the fish. This is truly a small piece of paradise on earth a must visit in Marrakesh!

A peaceful oasis in an amazing city.. Comparatively expensive at 50 dh per adult, but still interesting. I had nor realised that Yves Saint Laurent was so closely associated with Marrakech. This is the garden that he designed, where his ashes are scattered and where ha spent o lot of the later years of his life. It is beautiful if you like plants, and the date palms are really amazingly tall. Look out for the terrapins in the ponds.
Tranquil. Absolutely worth a visit. Get away from the noise of Marrakech for a while. Costs about £3.50 entrance. There is a nice cafe/restaurant there offering reasonably priced snacks/meals.

Beautiful. The gardens are tranquil and the blue building is stunning. The museum is quite interesting and worth the small extra cost. Go early to avoid queuing for tickets and the tour bus crowds. There is a small cafe which is a nice place to sit and drink tea.

Beautiful. Simply beautiful garden. Not large but so lovely it's almost impossible to capture in a photo. Rich colours and immaculate design. Wish my garden was like this. If you're staying a Riu hotel the free bus will drop you off here. 50 dirhams entry for all except with NUS card. Lovely cafe.
Oasis of tranquility. A must see if in Marakkech. One minute you are in the bustling city, next in a the most exquisite gardens that feel like another world.

Beautiful oasis in the city. this place is do nice to visit, just beautiful.
Liked the place, think that ticket should include museum

Must see in Marrakech!. This was top of my list for my first visit to Marrakech and I wasn't disappointed! A stunning calm oasis in the middle of the city, we walked from the main square, which took a little while but was easy to do. Beautifully maintained, the gardens are home to many species and there are water features, a gift shop, restaurant and YSL gallery to see too. Even although it was busy it felt calm and relaxing, a must see!
Stunning. Really beautiful. The garden is ornamental and a lovely oasis from the area nearby. Its not a place for a picnic but more a place to observe beauty and have a peaceful moment

Beautiful oasis in the city. Such a beautiful spot to visit in the city. Loved the gardens and the architecture. The museum inside was a surprise and very interesting. I only wish they had a terrace cafe!

Meh.. It was lackluster. It was pretty, but not beautiful. Lots of cactus if you're into that. The grounds were a bit messy...you'd think they didn't own a broom. I think people come here because they love YSL. About every other garden I've visited was prettier than this. I would skip it & enjoy a more authentic Moroccan experience elsewhere. The cafe was nice for coffee.
worth a visit. lovely gardens, great gift shop, peaceful and easy to get to. love the colours and overall design. yve st laurant would be proud.

a piece of tranquility.. i cannot believe people moan about paying 50 dirhams to see these beautiful gardens in the middle of a manic noisy city.three pounds fifty pence ,PLEASE.its nothing.the gardens are small and beautiful.go early around 9am.much quieter .no queing before the loud american and canadians arrive on their coaches.take your camera .very colorful.get a taxi their .again we only paid 50 dirhams,but i suppose some people are so mean they would walk to get their ,but it is hidden away down a side street.dont think we would have found it otherwise.spend around an hour and half their .,enough.

Extraordinary Garden. Photographs do not do justice to this lovely garden. The agaves and other cacti are spectacular and I have never seen bamboo used to greater effect. The museum is beautiful and the boutique offers some great things.

A little piece of Giverny in Marrakesh. Absolutely worth a visit. Provides a stark contrast to the frenetic, voluable, sensory overload that it the Medina. Buy tickets for the Berber Museum too, really classy.
Pleasant visit but not essential to quick trip. We enjoyed walking through the garden and exploring the museum on site, but it was not the best part of our trip. It's nice if you have time.

A lovely oasis from the Moroccan sun!. A lovely collection of flowers and trees enhanced by the water features and brightly coloured buildings and bridges.
Stop off at the courtyard for some mint tea and ice-cream, or lunch if you have time!
Very Tranquil. Visited gardens and found them more interesting than expecting. Very colorful and very well kept. Many photo opportunities of the many cacti that grow here.
Wow!. The gardens are a must see. They offer a tranquil setting with something for everyone. we especially liked the cacti and the use of colour. it is a photographers paradise.
Calm and colourful. Very attractive gardens. One of the best sights we visited in Marrakech. It is dotted with colourful pots and has a serene atmosphere.

Refreshing garden for a sunny noon walking. Jardin Majorelle is a beautiful and shady walking place for hot summer days. It is a beautiful botanic and artistic garden with palm trees, bamboos, cacti, many flowers and other plants. The Berber Museum is well worth a visit as well as the memorial of Yves Saint Laurent and the blue fountain Majorelle. You can have a rest and refresments in the nice café of the garden.

Beautiful, slightly hard to find and expensive. After spending some time finding this beautiful park, we had to pay 50 dirham to enter. This was annoying as it's both more expensive than other sights, it was also a present to the city. In comparison you can have a tagine at Jamaa El-Fna for that price. When my anger subsided, though, it's an extraordinarily beautiful park. It should be made available to all, it's a beautiful oasis with a colourful and carefully arranged garden with plants from all over the world.
Smaller than you might expect. Nicely done, but unless you're a plant buff it won't detain you for more than a couple of hours. A coo oasis in the madness that is Marrakech.
Lovely garden. Beautiful succulent collection. Unfortanately it rained the day we visited but this allowed us to visit the cafe to warm up.

oasis of tranquility. even allowing for it being one of the most visited locations in the city, it really is an oasis of calm. taking time to go around and appreciate the garden of cacti and just sitting and taking in the sounds was just wonderful and calming

Don't get it. I was recommended to visit the Jardin by friends & relatives who have visited in the past. Was expecting to see a well laid out colourful garden. I was aware that it was mainly made up of Cacti but not that they had been planted in such an unimaginative way. I have seen that this tour gets good reviews so maybe it was just me who thought the £15 we paid was over priced. Our friendly taxi driver we had hired for the day said he would wait as it only took 30 mins. We td him we expected be at least 1.5 hours - the driver was correct we had seen a that was on offer in under 30 mins. nice cool place to sit but I thought that on the whole it was a bit run down & tatty. Kew Gardens it isn't .

Timing is everything. I suppose the Marjorelle Garden could be, as another reviewer suggested, "an oasis of peace" in the middle of a bustling city... but that depends on the time you go there. I was there with some people from a high-end tour company around noon who were allowed in free. They were looking at it as a possible lunch spot to include on their itinerary for their very wealthy clients. We found scores of people in the garden itself, everyone taking the obligatory photos, and in the restaurant section there was no place left to sit. Basically, we just walked in and walked out and they crossed it off their list for lunch (would up choosing Dar Moha instead. So --- if someone feels this is an absolute must, I'd say get there right after it opens in the morning.

Peaceful place in the bustle of the city.. Really worth the visit as this garden is very beautiful and unique. The cafe is a great place to rest and watch the comings and goings of visitors to the city. Easy to walk to from the old town, however, not for the faint hearted due to the road crossings. Taxi ride is very reasonable.
So many colours. Full of colours. A garden very different that all others. The museum and the shop are also very interesting. Long queues.
The Marrakech Oasis. Jardin Majorelle is the Marrakech Oasis . A very well kept haven of peace in the middle of a vibrant and exciting city. Cool, calm and captivating.

amazing. the jardin majorelle as the bahia palce are must sees in marrakech.its very romantic and relaxing t spent your time there! incroyable!its anoying the cab drivers always try t blame you with the prices:-)

I know why Yves and Pierre loved it. Absolutely beautiful and peaceful oasis just next to the busiest areas of the centre of Marrakech. You can spend hours just wondering around. Take your favourite book and sit down for a mint tea in the cafe / restaurant. Nice shops also in the neighbourhood, e.g. 33 rue Majorelle.
Worth going to visit!. Its 50 Dirhams for the garden and then 25 for the museum would recommend doing both, very nice garden and museum to learn a little about Moroccan history.

Oasis of calm in a mad city. We enjoyed our visit here, we had a very pleasant stroll around the gardens, my husband rescued a drowning frog from the pool, well it looked like it was in distress and struggling to get out, haha!It was very busy when we got here so mornings would probably be better to visit, the Berber museum was interesting with lots of artefacts to look at, it was expensive for what is was but I am glad we went as it is worthwhile seeing.
YSL's house. Beautiful blue gardens with interesting exhibitions of berber cultural artefacts as well as artwork by YSL. Remarkable

Tranquillity and beauty. The gardens are peaceful and relaxing - definitely worth making the effort to leave the medina to find them! Try to avoid middle of the day or late afternoon when the tour groups arrive.

An oasis - simple yet sophisticated. Really enjoyed the gardens which are immaculately maintained and a real haven amidst the bustle of a busy city. I think the museum should be included in the admission price. Well worth seeing

Pretty garden containing the Berber Museum - get there early!. Interesting small garden, quiet and tranquil away from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. It does get very busy so go early to miss the crowd.
You need to go through the garden to get to the Berber Museum which is definitely worth a visit.

Gorgeous Gardens. Very interesting garden collection. We enjoyed our stroll through the garden as well as the Berber Museum. Such an interesting people! My daughter and I are huge fans of the colors of Marrakech, especially Majorelle Blue.

A wonderful way to spend a couple of hours outside the Medina. Spent a couple of very pleasurable house strolling gently round this garden, Some very pretty planting, beautiful views and fabulously vividly painted walls and plant pots! The café inside is well worth a visit; we had a fabulous lunch in there with great food and service. There's also a very swanky little Yves Saint Laurent boutique inside, which we didn't buy from, and there's a Berber museum, which we didn't see! A very memorable visit.

Magical, peaceful and pretty.. Magical, peaceful and pretty. Especially compared to the busy and chaotic medina. Take your time to take in the beauty of this garden, sit on a bench, relax and watch the fish. Would suggest to take a whole afternoon to sit, walk around and watch.

Amazing garden witha fabulous Berber Museum. You only pay for the garden at the entrance, but do not miss the Berber Museum in Majorelle's old studio as it is beautifully presented with all notes in English and French. They also have an original Majorelle painting.I bought myself a small pot of the trademarked 'Majorelle Blue' paint and painted a large pot with a small olive tree in it set in a bed of lavenders - lovely result and souvenir.

Jardin Majorelle. Having read about this in the tour guide I was very keen to go. When we arrived there was a large unruly queue with people pushing in with very little consideration for others. Inside it was too busy for the little pathways. Sadly some of the plants had been broken, written on by other visitors or just neglected. Trying to get near the pond with the beautiful water lillys was impossible. It was pretty and I am pleased to have ticked it off my to do list, but I won't be returning.
Beautiful. Really worth a visit although it gets quite busy. Great collection of cacti. Enjoy a refreshing juice drink in the cafe.
Okay. Nothing spectacular.. Underwhelmed. Maybe I missed something. Yes there were exotic plants. Nothing impressive. I think that staying by the pool would have been a better option.

Photographer? This is your dream. For a photographer, or even just a person equipped with a handy compact camera, this location is incredible. Some poor reviews about it being just a place with old plants - they obviously came here in the wrong frame of mind. It gives you a break from the noisy streets and shouting. Beautiful to look at, to take pictures of. May I say you have to admire the design also. Why is it humanely possible not to look at the beautiful waterfall, great looking house and a lovely blend of colours. Recommended to all.
Waste of time. I wish I'd skipped this option. Over rated, crowded, dying plants... Not worth the admission price of 50 dirham. It's small and there's not much to see.
Just a small saturated garden. This is just a small and saturated garden. If I wouldn't have been the yves garden, I would have been free and no visit
beautiful afternoon trip. well worth a visit. stunning garden and education and well layed out museum. Lovely to relax and soak up the tranquil atmosphere after the hustle and bustle of the old city
gorgeous. Go early as it gets busy. Beautiful colours, a delightful garden of cacti, tall plants in coloured pots

A little piece of heaven on Earth. So peaceful and beautiful, even after reading these reviews I had not expected it to be so lovely. We went off peak so it was quiet but as the garden is quite small I can imagine it can get very busy witch would detract from the peace and cools breezes. Loved the blues and yellows. The cafeteria is gorgeous and you must go! The shop stocks excellent quality things but is expensive.
Awesome. Beautiful!!! We loved this garden and the shop inside! Not far from the city center, definitely worth visiting!
Beautiful but can't enjoy it cause it's so busy. waited up gardens with beautiful colours. I would have enjoyed it a lot more if it wasn't so damn busy. You can't a photo without other people in it.

Only pitstop in Marrakech. The garden is extremely pleasant and calm. Nobody is bothering you there. Unfortunately it is only place worth seeing in Marrakech (in my humble opinion). If God decide to send me in Marrakech again, I will spend all my time in this garden. I will even sleep there.
Beautiful oasis in busy city. Lovely shaded gardens with amazing colours and features, designed by Yves St Laurent, worth the admission charge. However they are quite small and do get overcrowded.
Away from the hustle and bustle. Very tranquil and serene, a place to chill and relax after all the hustle and bustle of Marrakech and somewhere to sit and drink the lovely mint tea.
Beautiful with nice cafe. This is a wonderful escape from the busy streets of the city. Beautiful gardens with a comfortable cafe.

Crowded gardens, nice museum. We arrived at the same time as several tour buses so had to queue to pay to get in. Inside the garden is lovely but very overcrowded which made it impossible to really enjoy. The Berber Museum is interesting and far less crowded (there is an extra charge to get in). The 'gallery' is a small collection of YSL's 'Love' posters - colourful, derivative (especially Matisse) and unremarkable. Not sure it was worth it - if you time it to go without the crowds it would be a much better experience.
Well worth a visit. Well worth a visit even if you're not into flowers (I'm not). If for nothing else for the tranquility and the cats. Exclusive gift shop and restaurant inside.
Primary Colours. Nice for a break from the Medina. Only 10 minutes walk from Baby Doukkala Some good photo opportunities.

small, but espetacular!. The garden is very small. About half an hour is enough to visit. But is very beautiful and well maintained. Worth the time and money (50 dirhams, more than the other main attractions).Is an escape from the noise and confusion of the Medina. And I have greet the staff, that are very friendly.Tip: is better to go when it's not very crowded, since it's small and lot of people visit it.

Definitely the highlight of our visit. We had a wonderful afternoon at the garden. The foliage is complimented by the use of colourin this peaceful oasis, but I'd suggest going early or perhaps later in the afternoon when its not too busy. As we arrived a school trip was leaving so it wasn't too noisy and as the afternoon wore on we found the gardens became very peaceful and the colours used in the gardens become more vibrant as the sun goes down. We also had drinks in the little cafe garden which was very nice. We visited the museum in the garden which was twice the price of visiting the gardens alone, and whilst it was quite interesting, you don't really miss much by not going in - and a shop which sells overpriced objects in the style of Yves St Laurent, but is in fact NOT Yves St Laurent! I'd say visit the gardens for definite and if you really want to see a lot of really old berber tools and costumes, before finding the well disguised YSL shop then go for it!.

Okay gardens, nice museum. I think this garden is very overrated. It is small and crowded and even though it has some pretty plants, it isn't worth the trip. The Berber museum inside the gardens is nice.

Stunning garden. This medium sized garden houses a lovely Berber Museum in the centre. The gardens are beautiful with stunning Cobalt Blue and yellow artifacts. The path winds around the ouside then across the middle. There is a restaurant but we thought it looked a little expensive for lunch.

Nearly perfect. I thought 50 dirhams was pushing it a bit by Moroccan standards (40 for an orange juice in the cafe definitely was) but it is beautifully kept. Many of the plants are identified but I think it would be improved if all were.
Beautiful gardens. As soon as you walked through the gate it was like the birds had been turned on! lovely setting, lush, quiet and beautiful. A must during your trip.

Beautiful but busy. We took a taxi to the Jardin which was a good idea as they are quite tucked away.I felt that the entrance price of 50dirhams was a little steep but they are very well maintained.Do not expect a large garden, it is quite small but very beautiful and peaceful. best to get there early before it gets too busy!

Reasonable gardens but not exceptional. The gardens are quite a long way out from the centre, we walked there and then got a horse drawn carriage back (for a third of the price originally quoted!). The gardens were busy and crowded so it was hard to get good photos. Admission was much higher than for the other attractions in Marrakech as it is not government run. Places like the Bahia are fantastic value at only 10DH and had far more things to see and be amazed by. Plant collection was OK and there were a few nice architectural features but I wouldn't bother to go back.
The garden is small and full of people - but the museum is a gem. It's a garden, and nothing close to Kew or others.. but very crowded, but the museum inside is a gem and well worth a visit.

The blue Paradise. Outside the Medina, it is best just to get taxi (about £5.00) as it is not easy to find it and it will be a really long walk. The gardens and the mixture of colours are beautiful.Pictures of my trip on my bloghttp://latravelera.blogspot.com
beautifull gardens. Lovely unexpected gardens but amazing museum and artss and crafts display. The gardens are busy so go early to avoid crowds but the small cafe is luxurious and smart a real treat
Nice but not cool. The jardin majorelle is nice but is Wery quaiette in you likie very quaiette place exactly to you yes.

Well overrated. The gardens are actually small and very busy. I found that it only took 20 minutes to see everything. In my opinion they let to many people in at any one time and you were consistently having to wait to take the photographs you wanted. Given each person has to pay 50 Dirhams to enter I would have expected the gardens to be much cleaner and prettier.

Truly spectacular, a must see in Marrakech and my favourite spot during our holiday. Jardin Majorelle may be a little tricky to get to as it lies a fair bit outside the Medina - but it really is worth the visit. The gardens itself are STUNNING - incredibly relaxing - everything is well maintained and there's also an interesting museum on Berber culture which you can visit at an additional price.The gardens have to be my favourite spot in Marrakech - a wonderful place to visit - they really do live up to the hype.

Breathtakingly beautiful. These gardens are the most beautiful I think I have ever seen. The "Majorelle Blue" of the pots and buildings in the Moroccan sunshine has to be seen to be believed. The Berber Museum was interesting and worth going into. We enjoyed a light lunch in the courtyard cafe there.

Beauty in Blue. The Majorelle Gardens are a lovely oasis of calm away from the travails of city life. The collection of cacti from all over the world is stunning and the walks through and around the grounds are a delight and bring you to an assortment of buildings, fountains, pools and views that are just lovely. The Majorelle blue and the contrasting terracotta and yellow make for a stunning combination of colours against the green of the foliage. There is a coffee shop where you can partake of a drink and/or a snack and the whole experience is both calming and wondrous. If you don't like this you have no soul.
A beautiful and tranquil place. This was a lovely peaceful garden of many variations with a good restaurant and toilet facilities. The Majorelle Blue house is amazing with the museum contained within
so so. a chance for a few good photos, but not more than that ! a bit overpriced compared to other tickets you pay in Morocco.

Blue is the colour. Loved the Plants lots of different trees,Flowers are excotic very colourful got some great pictures and there are Ponds with fish of terepins and the Berber Museum was worth a visit loved it.....

It's not Kew!!. We enjoyed our visit here but the gardens, although immaculate and very interesting (mainly succulents and trees and not many flowers), were a lot more compact than anticipated and only took us about 30 minutes to do. The walk into town is about 20 minutes along main roads.
UNMISSABLE!. This delightful facility is well worth a taxi ride from centre of the Medina. While the gardens are spectacular, the Berber museum, in Jacques Majorelle's former studio is awe-inspiring.

Amazing plant collection owned by YSL at some point . must visit. The oasis of the city! I could spend the whole day here. so relaxing, beautiful!! Colorful walls and benches all over, water flowing through the fountains, all sorts of trees and exotic plant species throughout. There is shade here, so if you'd been walking for a while this can be your refugee.There is also a tiny YSL monument and museum, being that it was taken over by YSL after Majorelle's death. Fun fact!

Beautiful oasis. A lovely cool spot to wander around for an hour or two.There is a great book shop, gift store (without cheap trinkets) and a delightlful cafe/restaurant serving great food and drinks.
A nice getaway. Refreshing oasis in the middle of the desert. Love the dromedaries nearby. Doesn't require much time, but worth a visit.

Excellent Museum. Very popular so expect a queue. The gardens are great if you enjoy exotic plants/cacti but the highlight was the very modern Berber Museum - great collection of artifacts and very informative. Very good quality items in the various shopping outlets.
Below Average. It really was just a pretty garden. It was nowhere near as large or grand as you'd expect, especially as you have to pay to enter. Stop by if your near but don't go out of your way!

Truly beautiful. To be honest I hadn't planned on coming, thinking garish bold colours and lots of cacti weren't something that appealed to me. However on the recommendation of Riad staff and another couple staying there who had visited I changed my mind. It's a really gorgeous place, so bright and vibrant and fresh and healthy. The gardens are kept to a wonderful standard and the whole place really was beautiful and so unlike most botanical gardens. There is a very simple memorial to YSL, a small exhibit of his seasonal greeting designs, and a museum of Berber history. The garden alone is 50 Drm and despite quite a few tourists we really enjoyed it - probably worth trying to go earlier though to enjoy on your own without the queue of people waiting to take selfies in the same spots

Beautiful manicured desert garden. This is a private garden. It is outside of the medina, the cost was about 50 dirhams per adult for the garden and another 25 for the berber museum. It was a nice way to cap the day of walking around the city.
Great . Great garden with stunning features with great Berber museum and nice cafe with great food and not expensive to see or walk round

Small and very Busy. A small enclosed garden including a dedicated section to Yve St Laurent. Peaceful this garden was not, unfortunately the day we went 3 coaches turned up at the same time and we had to wait for 40mins before we could get in. Once inside there are several lovely areas with benches to sit and take it all in (in the hight of summer it would be littered with wonderfully scented flowers). Also a few ponds with turtles and frogs splashing about.

Stunning. An absolute beautiful botanical garden full of colors! Originally created by Louis Majorelle, it has been redone later on by designer Yves Saint Laurent who bought the place. His memorial can be found in this garden. It is a MUST SEE place to visit on a sunny day, with your camera! (Only negative point: a 5 euros charge per person for the entrance).

Pretty but busy. Pretty gardens, wouldn't really say you can spend time relaxing here as it was too busy for that. There's a Berber museum within the grounds which was interesting. I would say it only takes about an hour - an hour and a half to do everything.

Lovely - but small!. These gardens are beautiful and a cooling oasis in the hear of marrakech. I was astonished how small the gardens were. We spent about two hours there. When we first arrived, at about 0930, the gardens were quiet but, by the time we left, you could hardly see the plants for the tourists!The tea rooms in the gardens are good but expensive - the tearooms across the road are far cheaper. The merchandise for sale in the shop is extortionately priced!
Pure nature. The garden is full of different kind of plants, especially fat ones, the gallery of love is really nice and the Berber Museum is a wonderful collection of original and old crafts.
Peace and Quitte. It's a nice place to get some rest, but it smaller then we expected. You can see the garden in 30 minutes. Definitely worth a visit.

Gardens with a difference. We enjoyed the Majorelle Gardens, they are quite compact in size but the palms a cacti are very striking and imaginatively planted, it is unusual to find a garden planted mainly with these plants, we loved the bright splashes of blue and other colours of the pots and the peaceful lily ponds. Well worth a visit

Colours and forms. Great garden with plants from all over the world.
Go early in the morning, to avoid the crowd. It's a populair place but worthwile!
Beautiful!. Definitely worth a stop for a few hours. Colors are wonderful and good for photos! Its a good change of pace from the noise and crowds of Marrakech center.

One of the Top Places to Visit in Mararkech. It is calm, cool, quiet & some of the most beautiful botanicals grouped together in one place. We spent hours walking, talking, visiting the museum, taking photos, sitting & really enjoying the time in these gardens.

tres jolie. Lovely arrangements of palms and other tropical trees. Superbly maintained. Go early as got very crowded. Restful and reasonably priced coffee shop. Go to the museum aswell as some fascinating exhibits with very good descriptions . Better if you can remember a little schooldays french but still get gist without it
Lovely tranquil oasis. Beautiful tranquil place,full of vibrant colours fantastic array of plants and exotic flowers,nice for a relaxing timeout from the Husle of the city

A Must See. The gardens of Yves St. Laurent must be seen if you're in Marrakech. The Berber Museum on the grounds is also an added highlight and bonus, with incredible jewelry and clothes of the Berber people. After you're done, if you're tired of seeing the same merchandise over and over again in the souks, head across the street to the lovely shops that have clothes and wares by Moroccan artisans.

A little blue oasis. A lovely place to visit to contrast the hustle and bustle of the Medina. Look out for the little turtles swimming in the pond! The Colbalt blue is worth going to see. I don't really appreciate plants that much but the garden was still nice too see and well looked after. The museum is worth paying extra for.

Who Would Have Thought?. Not being Europeans, we had no idea (shame on us) of the influence Morocco had on Yves St Laurent. And with good reason! This is a great site to visit; be sure not to miss the Berber museum also on the grounds. The grounds themselves are immaculate! Can get a bit crowded at times, so try to go early and avoid them. Well worth the visit.

Beautiful escape from the busy medina. Beautiful, creative showcase. Can be a little bit difficult to find on foot, around 20mins walk from the main square of the medina. Entrance is reasonably priced at 50dh pp, discounts for students ! The garden itself is one of a kind for the region and is spectacularly designed. Lovely for photos and a picnic. Would have loved to have seen some more open space - but not a fault of their own. Great exhibition by Yves Saint Laurent also included in the visit. Would definitely recommend a visit however, don't expect it to last a whole afternoon (1-2hours max)

Marjorelle Garden. I enjoyed my visit to the garden because I was getting tired of waling around Marrakesh, but to be quite honest with you, the garden is a disappointment to ppl who are from or live in the Southwest of the US. We see cacti like this a lot. I was disappointed because for me it was nothing new, but it is a peaceful setting. Not worth the price of admission though as you can see all in about 15 minutes top!
Majorelle Gardens. Beautiful planting in a tranquil setting. We walked from the square with no problem. Interesting to see paintings by Yves St Laurent. Stop for Mint Tea in the cafe

Love this place!. Small and Beautiful. A place to really enjoy and spend a lovely moment. I liked to go there and be inspired by the beautiful gardens, museums and all the beautiful color! So happy to have experienced it!

Worth a visit - beautiful gardens!. A very peaceful and beautiful garden albeit a little small. Can get very crowded so try to go early in the day. Some excellent opportunities for budding photographers

Peacefull and beautiful. What a quiet and beautiful place in the middle of a bustling city. Brilliant blue, yellow and orange planters. We walked around and then just sat to absorb the atmosphere. An added bonus was the Berber museum for a few extra dirham.
Well worth a visit. An oasis of calm in the middle of a crazy city. Wonderful colours and the museum is well worth a visit .

only ok. It is a nice enough garden but it is quite expensive for all the time it takes to go round it.Also its a bit out of the way from where we stayed our taxi was quite expensive and there was very little else to do when we had finished in the gardens.

So so. Beautiful garden. Specially cactus section is amazing. But it's small. Crowded. Nothing authentic Moroccan except for a Berber museum inside the garden. 50 Dh for entrance plus 25 Dh to visit museum is way too expensive. Wouldn't say it's bad, but wouldn't be sorry if I have missed it.

Beautiful, trendy, picturesque but tiny and crowded. We went here on a perfect day and enjoyed it but you are literally jammed in elbows to elbows on a weekend. Try to go early. Its very tiny. Would be excellent on a hot sunny day if you still want to get out

BEAUTIFUL GARDENS. We visited on recommendation of friends and was not disappointed. The gardens are a sea of tranquility in Marackesh madness!! We took a horse carriage which allowed us to look around the city too. The garden is set out beautifully and the cobalt blue colour which is everywhere made it beautiful. We had lunch in the restaurant which was very nice but more pricey than the restaurants in the main squares. It was a bit cloudy when we were there but on a Hot day it would be beautiful and cool.

A joy to visit - tranquility in the madness of Marrakech!. Lovely gardens, well maintained, tastefully done accented with blue painted pots and railings. Great cactus garden, also water features. There is an excellent museum, beautifully designed featuring Berber clothing, jewellery and tools. The cafeteria looked appealing but we had already eaten. Don't miss this place. Probably best to get there early morning or late afternoon to miss the crowds from the big tour buses.

Love this place!. I could wander this lovely garden over and over again. Don't miss the Berber museum so very well put together! A nice calm oasis after the hustle and bustle of the Jamma el Fna square and just a quick jaunt away.
Pretty garden. It's much smaller than I expected but beautifully laid out with mostly palm trees and cacti. Can get busy if a coach tour turns up.

A feast for the eyes. The Majorelle garden is a truly feast for the eyes. Amazing trees, bushes and cactusses which we, as Europeans, only get to see in miniature/small sizes. The garden is an enourmeous contrast to the Medina and can be uses as a refugium in case you need it!!! The berber museum is payed extra - but it fine, neetly organised and presented.

Peaceful Sight. We got to this via the Tourist Bus - but I think you could get there more quickly & cheaply by Taxi.The gardens were beautiful. Although popular the small lanes wind through the bamboo, cactus plants and around the pond. Inside there are toilets and a small café.We really enjoyed a peaceful hour here, although we saw people chatting and reading - you could stay a bit longer.

An oasis of tranquility. Majestic! The best thing I like about Jardin Majorelle was the combination of colors, giving off a subtle reminder that this space is private made public by an exquisite creator (Yves Saint Laurent)

Mediocre. Calming , nice colours and lots of different plants. Only downfall is I wouldn't call it a garden it's more like a square filled with plants takes you 10 mins to walk round no longer. 50dnh each to get in for a ten minute look at some plants....
long weekend. the gardens are worth a visit but was not bowled over by the experience. don't plan on a long stay the gardens are not that big. Bit of a queue to get in

A Serene Oasis in a Bustling City. The Jardin Majorelle has a wonderful museum of Berber jewelry, dress and tools. The garden also has an incredible cactus collection among its many plantings. It was a treat for us to visit.

A must see. Lovely garden and a must see in Marrakech. Too pricy admission though and too bad that you can't buy reproductions of the art pieces in the love gallery - there's a lost business opportunity!
Must see!. Beautiful gardens which were restored by Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Berge. A photographers dream location. Peaceful and tranquil and truly beautiful.

Not worth the effort. If you lack a garden , and want to see BIG Bamboos and cactus collections from around the world this is a haven , but for me not worth the effort to find it, having said that the fact there is this "green oasis" might temper the raw city streets , Legacy of Majorelle who created it and later Yves St Laurent who saved it , Accompanied children only allowed , Admission 50DHM a head @ 03/2015. Pay the attendant for use of loos! Wheel chair friendly although Marrakech definitely is not.

Very busy. I'm sure this is a beautiful garden, but it's quite small and it was very busy the day I went. I didn't actually get to see much because of all of the self-important selfie taking people blocking the pathways. A little expensive for what you get...50 dirhams.

A true Oasis. My suggestion is to go as early in the morning as you can to avoid the crowds. It is a beautiful garden - not big but packed with interesting and unusual specimens of cacti and palm. There are lovely fountains and brightly colored pots of flowering bushes. Majarelle blue is everywhere. I ate lunch in the small cafe, and it was quite good. Make sure that you take the time to go to the museum - it is very small, but worth the few extra cents that it costs. It is full of artifacts and history of the region.
sublime oasis. a beautiful garden in an otherwise dessert town an amazing attraction very reasonably priced it paint a beautiful picture of what life was once like in this amazing city

Lovely garden. A very nice garden in a busy city. From the tall bamboo to the wonderful assortment of cactus and flowers, the Jardin Majorelle is a lovely place to spend an hour or so. You'll forget all about the noise and chaos outside!

A little over-hyped. While it is still probably worth visiting, I found the Jardin Majorelle a little over-hyped and under-whelming. While it is a very nice garden, it is very expensive to visit by Moroccan standards. You could probably see most things within 15-20 minutes but it is a calm and cool and makes a nice contrast from the crazy Medina. If you have a lot of time in Marrakesh or if you are big into gardening, then this should be on your to-do list. Otherwise, it is really take it or leave it. There are far more interesting and memorable things to visit that do not cost as much.
Beautiful and calm. Great for peaceful walk, and Exquisite photo opportunities every where you turn. A good place to escape from the chaos of the city.
A Little Gem. The Majorelle is a little oasis in a dusty town. Take your time stroll the garden and enjoy the museum, it is small but very well done. Worth the walk over.
Really good experience.. 50 dirham for entry and 25 paid for the museum. Medium sized garden mainly with collections of cactus and desserts around the world mainly from mexico and USA.

A colorful oasis. While I love the varying shades of red buildings in the Red City, it was a wonderful change to explore this garden, with its cobalt blue house and pillars, the vibrant pots and flowers. Color is everywhere here and shade too, with the leafy trees to keep out the hot sun. There are benches here and there so if you want to escape the heat of the medina, just come here and relax. There is a small restaurant, restroom, a gift shop, and a museum (pay extra).
Gorgeous. Tranquillity in the mayhem! A fabulous place to take a little time out. The staff are great and take photos of you standing by the amazing cactus and the fish. And a lovely café at the end.

Oasis in the city. Was suggested to come here by our guide on a group tour and it was well worth the trip!It was such a tranquil setting and well laid out. There was a lot of variety in the foliage in December, and I'm sure it would be just as nice throughout the year.

Great Place to Take a Breather from Busy Marrakech. Beautiful gardens,amazing colours that really strike the eye. It’s a small haven from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. It won’t take you more than an hour to walk around and the cost of entry is extremely low. Some great photo opportunity’s inside. It was one of the highlights of my trip.

Gem garden just outside the Medina. Probably the best thing to visit outside the Medina (30 min walk from the square). The garden was not so big and we were out again after 30 min, but it was worth the trip. The color combinations were beautiful as was the cactus collection. Look in every corner, and you will find an Yves Saint Laurent special! Great place to just sit and relax for a moment away from the busy medina (although you will not be alone...)

A must-see place when in Marrakech!. These gardens are so tranquil and beautiful to walk around - we were there in February, but I imagine the huge palm trees, etc would make it lovely and cool and shady in the hotter weather. The best part for me was the Berber museum though, it was so well set out and interesting - I could have stayed in there for hours! We also had a lovely rest and more mint tea in the cafe there, and sat with a very friendly cat! The toilets were nice too! (Always a plus in my eyes!)
A must!. A quiet and peaceful little garden just outside of the main tourist areas. Pretty easy to find and cheap (5 euro). Beautiful garden, but I didnt go into the museum though.

Beautiful. Liked it all very easy to walk around. The little coffee shop in the garden is lovely good friendly service. Toilets clean and easily accessible. Not very big so doesn't take very long to get around. Don't rush enjoy this little oasis.

Over-rated and crowded. I don't really think this garden merits its listing in all the guidebooks. The place is so crowded and you have to follow the hordes along designated walkways. Much better to visit the free public gardens around the city.

Beautiful. We arrived late afternoon, it was still quite busy but nothing major!
This was easily one of my favourite places we visited in Marrakech. Pictures can't do it justice! Majorelle blue is something else, highly recommend.

An oasis!. The gardens are an oasis in the middle of the chaotic and dirty city. The cerulean blue pottery and plaster combined with the creative display of plants are a feast for the eyes. Although, the gardens are on a small scale they are worth a trip. There are plenty of benches where you can sit and simply admire the gardens and observe the other visitors, read or draw. Les Jardins felt wonderfully restorative and I would definitely visit again and spend more time. The café inside les Jardins offers a good variety of quick meals and snacks. The fruit juices were very good. There is sitting in the open courtyard or indoors. The courtyard was a glorious place to have a bit of lunch and relax on a sunny day in March.I also enjoyed the tiny exhibition of Yves Saint Laurent’s New Year cards he designed for friends and customers. The shop next door has lovely items, many of which are inspired by YSL’s designs but the prices are a bit dear.

Trip to the gardens!. Very educational trip as it's not just the beautiful gardens you get to see but also the Berber museum. Fascinating history and very informative. The gardens are a peaceful welcome after the hustle and bustle of the roads, traffic and the busy markets! Well worth a visit! Obviously, Yves Saint Laurent thought so!!

A garden!. This garden is a nice place if you juste wanted to walk around and don't have any expectations. The entry is 50 dirhams each person and extra 25 for the museum. Its not very big, but it has a variety of plants and some water features. If your not into gardens its not worth wasting your time.

Beautiful. We visited here during our stay in Marrakech, the gardens are absolutely beautiful-brightly coloured pots, beautiful plants and cacti, and a lovely relaxing place. Would definitely recommend a visit to anyone staying in Marrakech.
Well worth a visit. A beautiful garden - had a lovely lunch too. A relatively peaceful place after the hustle and bustle of the souks.

Go for the museum not the garden. The garden itself is rather dull just full of cacti and raked sandy soil. The museum is interesting with a video of Berber life, a good display of jewellry, costumes through the ages, eating and drinking vessels, then you exit through the shop in true Disney style! There is also a boutique with clothing and jewellry. All in all a time filler but not the number one attraction for me.

Not worth a visit. I was part of a group tour and a visit to this garden was part of our itinerary. It's very small and clearly I had the wrong picture of "gardens" in my mind since it's just a bunch of cactus. I found it to be boring and would have preferred to stay back at the resort at the pool.
Beautiful And colorfuls. very nice garden with nice cactus and other plants.The museum is also really interesting.I would recommend

glorious. The garden is beautiful and peaceful. It is well laid out with plenty of different plants and trees. It is great for pictures. Reccomend going early as it gets very busy. We had a lovely relaxing morning there.
Worth a visit. Gorgeous colours in this cool corner outside the Medina. Wicked ice cream just outside in a small cafe...
Beautiful and small. Colourful and well looked after with plenty of information as you walk round. cafe is in a beautiful setting. Great Orange blossom ice cream!

Lovely and worth the trip. It's a bit far from the old town, but its worth the cab fare and entry fee (about $5 each). It's rammed full of French people gawping C'est Jolie! Hard to take a bad picture in here if you can crop out the tourists. The cafe is nice for a coffee if it's not full.

Oasis of calm. Go because it's like stepping into a painting (think Mary Poppins chalk style ;) )
Don't go if you're expecting an insight into YSL.
I personally loved it, the cafe is an unexpected extra treat, great quality.
Beautiful. Manageable size. Berber permanent exhibition excellent. YSL shop has lovely products. Café good, in shade if needed, good local food as well as western.

On everybody's top ten, but overpriced for what it is.. Just about every guide book will tell you to visit the Jardin Majorelle during a trip to Marrakech, and it does deliver by way of a lush garden setting with its famous striking colours. On the whole we thought it was over-touted and over-priced, although of course not by European standards. With entry at 50 dirhams (5 euros) it was the most expensive place we went to, with sites such as the magnificent Saadian Tombs and Ben Youssef Medrasa charging only 10 dirhams (1 euro). So it is clearly a tourist magnet and exploited as such. Taxis will overcharge to get there, caleches will pester you for a ride, and of course there will be many, many visitors, especially at peak times. The best time to go is as early as possible, before the first coaches arrive.The cafe looks delightful but is also expensive - there are other options outside the gardens, if you make it through the barrage of taxi drivers wanting to take you to your next destination.If garden are your thing, go to the Mammounia Hotel (dress sensibly), where access is free, and you can even enjoy a delightful cappuccino on the terrace while star-spotting. The cappuccino costs as much as the entry ticket to the Majorelle but that would be my choice.And by the way, talking of 'gardens', don't bother with the much-touted Menara gardens, where there is little to see apart from the 'famous' pavilion and pool. But at least they are free too.
take an hour break in oasis. an impressive mix of colors ,trees and architecture + a small museum about Berber culture.very nice for a break of the heat.do not eat there :-(

Lovely Oasis in the middle of Marakech. The garden could have been better looked after but the colours were beautiful. The day we went it wasn't to busy but I imagine it can become quite busy in high season.
Very Good. Short queue, beautiful surroundings lots of people there but didn't feel like it as it was so spacious. Worth a visit

Celebration of the diversity of the nature - luonnon monimuotoisuuden juhlaa. Small park presents hundreds of beautiful and interesting plants. Even on the hot day you find areas were air is fresh and you can sit down and just enjoy the view. If you like to take photos, take you camera with you! Same in Finnish:Pienessä puistossa on satoja hienoja ja mielenkintoisia kasveja. Kuumanakin päivänä löytyy alueita, joissa on raikas ilma ja voit vain istua ihailemaan näkymiä. Mikäli pidät kuvien ottamisesta, ota kamerasi mukaan!
Enjoyable...worth seeing. Very beautiful garden with an interesting history. Worth visiting to explore and take some nice photos.

beautiful gardens,nice place to relax when hot. I like all the gardens the city has to offer,but Majorelle is perfect for a relaxing couple of hours when is hot,the aroma from the fruit trees,flowers and shrubs is amazing,

Very Photogenic!. Get there early - the whole point of this place is that it is aesthetically beautiful, great for photos. Even the plants are beautiful colours and shapes. So there's no point in getting there after the morning as it is too packed to appreciate properly. We got there at about 9pm, which was fine, but on our way out it was filling up and the ticket queue was round the street. Don't pay for the museum or cafe. Too expensive and not worth it.Don't pay more than 50 dirhams for a taxi from outside jemaa el fna. It isn't a long journey and tourists can get ripped off. Always agree the price with the driver before getting in the taxi. You can walk back or else there are lots of taxis in the area to catch.Overall, it's a beautiful place with a juxtaposition of vibrant colours, including the beautiful blue sky, that is unlike any other place. Definitely a must visit if you're in Marrakesh and be sure to take your time walking round and take loads of photos. If you walk quickly you'll do the whole thing in 15 minutes, but you'll regret not capturing more images to remind you of how stunning it was once you get home.

There are gardens and gardens. This one was relatively small, but a work of art. In magnificent condition, with the most extraordinary cacti and other trees, it is not a typical city garden. One of the most beautiful I have seen.
A MUST SEE. Colourful gardens,fine museum,comfortable cafe.Walk there,or take a horse drawn cab,and see the city.
Loved the museum and gift shop. The gardens were lovely, peaceful and different. Not very large.Berber museum very interesting. Gift shop was very reasonable and well curated.
Beautiful gardens. Attractive, interesting, small to medium sized gardens - well worth a visit. "Majorelle Bleu" colour comes from here.
must do, great lunch. beautiful place. ate lunch in the cafe even though more expensive than town and loved it, the setting, the tagine was one of the best i ate whole trip! drinks great too.
Beautiful gardens and peaceful. We went early in the morning.. Cool in the shade of the trees.It is a very small area so early in the day is good. Take a camera as the cactus are so unusual.

Just a garden. We were somewhat underwhelmed by our visit. Yes it is a pleasant garden but smaller than expected and unless you like trees and cacti you will be very disappointed! If you are staying in a hotel with nice grounds, save your money and have a relaxing day there instead.
Beautiful. Designed by Yves St. Laurent, beautifully landscaped, beautiful colors. They also have the Berber museum inside the garden which is a must see. Very nicely done. Highly recommended.

Overrated. I was not thrilled at all. Maybe I had high expectations, since I resently viewed the movie about Yves St Laurent, and I have a more spectacular imaginafion of the place. I am interesyed in art and gardena, for me this was, just something organized and boring.
Waste of time. Waste of time and money..50 Diram just to see the garden (with only kactus and bamboo) that's a total ripoff.
Quiet and relaxing. Amazing contrast between the noise outside and the quietness inside the garden. Colorful, calm, perfect for photos as well
Beautiful place. Don't miss this place. Absolutely beautiful. The café in there is overpriced, so avoid it if possible. :)

Beautiful. We visited the garden on the first day of our trip. The gardens are beautiful and so peaceful. It really is a little gem! It was so nice to saunter around and sit from time to time among the glorious trees and plants. Visit the museum - well worth it!

Stunning light. Not the easiest place to find. With people around even found the pay box hard to find. Helpful staff and beautiful gift shop and book shop. Real style in designs.Best photos on a 10 day tour. Stunning designs. Wished there was more. Switched on camera flash to counter the reflected bright light. Gardeners heaven. Photographers heaven. Worth the trip to Marrakech. Relax and reflect.

is that it?. not especially impressive garden. the garden itself is over-manicured and little more than a collection of various cacti. the excessive use of the yves saint lauren 'blue' was noted. half the garden was closed to the public without any notice or explanation on my visit in march 2015. expected much more.
Beautiful. The gardens were beautiful. The blue popped out so much and made for some great pictures. The gardens are not that big so dont expect too much of a visit. Still worth it though.

Dissapointing. If you like bamboo then this is the place for you. No flowers..some cacti.Out of town.Walk around in tranquillity. 100 dirhams entry each for this. Best part was negotiating a carraige ride back to jenna de fna for 70 or was it 80 dirhams. I gave him a tip of 10 and he was delighted! He had asked for 200 for the ride but lots of smiles and fun we had a deal!
Gardens of Yves St Lauren. The gardens were a cool oasis in a dry arid country with pools and Cacti and palms. Not a European garden as we know it but beautiful all the same.

Surprising. Well I didn't expect to like the gardens this much. Not the most appealing area of the city but when you step inside you could be anywhere. The colours, the plants and the ambience was beautiful and very romantic. Take time out from the madness of the city and spend a couple of hours here

An oasis of calm. Thoroughly enjoyed the visit to the gardens. Shame about the graffiti on the cacti. A must visit for all visitors to Marrakech. Getting there by foot is an experience, and don't listen to anyone on the way if they tell you the gardens are closed, because they are only trying to divert you to a place where they hope to earn some commission.A horse-drawn journey back into the city is a good way to complete the visit, and much easier on the feet.

Worth an hour or two. Beautiful, well kept up. Not too expensive for the time it takes. It is about 10 minutes by taxi from the Medina. On a nice day, it is worth the visit, but I wouldn't have been too sad in retrospect if I missed it.

Fantastic place, great lunch in the cafe insight. when you are in Marakesh, reserve 2-3 hours to spend in Jardin Majorel. It is very nice place to be, to walk, to have lunch in the cafe, and of course to make hundreds of nice photos for your insta and FB:).
Magic athmosfere. Very nice garden, well maintained and with the wonderful plants!!On hot days of August we found a bit of refreshing ...

Small, But Perfectly Formed.. If you were in a hurry you could most probably walk around these gardens in 15 minutes, but you would miss so much. I had no idea what to expect, and went on the recommendation of my riad's staff, and I am glad that I did. The views are stunning, and the cacti awesome.
