I have never seen such beautiful specimens.Seek out the momument to YSL whilst you are there (a lovely back story), and spend the extra 25dh over the admission price of 50dh to gain entry into the museum.

Beautiful Place!. Amazing!! Such a beautiful place with all the plants, palms etc. and also fishes :) It has it's own magic and helps to calm down and find "inner" peace! I can definitely recommend it! Enjoy :)

Lovely garden. I thought this garden was lovely and provided a great retreat from the hustle and bustle of Marakesh. However, it was not that big and we managed to walk around the whole thing in half an hour. We only paid £2 with a student card though so can't complain!

If you love Cactei ....visit YSL garden. It is worth a short visit if you have the time or if you want to pay tribute to YSL. The boutique is interesting to look through. And of corz knowing the history of the Majorelle Garden will make you visit interesting.

Nice, but not amazing. Let me be clear, this is an extremely well-kept garden, and the blue of the structures is pretty. But should it really be the #1 attraction in Marrakech? I don't think so. This is a fun place to stop by for 10-20 minutes, and again, it is pretty. Most of the cacti and other succulents were imported from Central America. Other then that it happens to be in Marrakech, there's not very much that's Moroccan about this place. It just doesn't seem that special, and I had to look at my notes of what we did in Marrakech to remember to review it.

Beautiful. Well worth a visit, and well worth the entry fee. The gardens are cool quite and and beautifully laid out, a great place to wander round or to just sit and loose your self in your thoughts.

Beautiful oasis!. The contrast between the bustling souk and this haven is dramatic. Its a beautiful garden with loads of different variety of desert plants such as yuccas and cactuses from around the world as well as palm tree varieties. There are different paths to wander along and large colourful pots. We particularly liked the blue coloured ones which is also the colour of the building at the back of the garden which houses the museum and the gift shop and cafe. We only paid to visit the gardens and thus can not give you any information about inside the museum. We would recommend visiting the gardens early in the morning to avoid crowds especially groups as they ruin the peacefulness.
Small, but nice garden. A must see for all botanists or just for travelers seeking a bit of shadow in the heat of the city of Marrakesh.

Beautiful place. We went here on the last day of our trip. Our flight wasn't until the evening so planned to take the group here for something to do. Truly beautiful place and worth a visit. We walked from Hotel Ali and stopped in a supermarket for some snacks along the way. Very peaceful compared to the business of the main square.
A peaceful oasis away from the hustle and bustle. Well worth a visit to these tranquil gardens the colour of blue against the foliage is just wonderful. 50dh entrance fee

stunningly beautiful!. This place was one of the highlights of our trip to Marrakech. The entry fee is cheap for what you get out of this beautiful place. The smell and sight of the many different varieties of plants, some of them in beautifully coloured large pots, is breathtaking! I could have spent the whole day here between the gardens, the amazing cafe, and the fantastic Berber museum (25 dirham's entry), but unfortunately we had to leave aafter 3 hours as we were going out later that night. This place is a must see. Indescribably beautiful!
WOW. Nothing to Dislike. A wonderful experience. Beautiful and peaceful. Great cafe and interesting museum of the Berber people
Beautiful garden amongst the madness of Marrakech. What a stunning garden totally unexpected in this mad and crazy city. It is full of beautiful botanical plants in a calm environment
A damn good morning out.. One of the best tourist experiences in Marrakech. A must-see.It perhaps says it all that we went on a grey, rainy morning and still thoroughly enjoyed it. Beautiful gardens.
Gorgeous gardens!. Beautiful gardens,definitely a must in Marrakech.Ticket 50 drh plus 25 for museum which I did not visit.Beautiful in sunny weather,amazing colours and light.

Unusual gardens. This compact garden is full of the most unusual collection of cacti I have seen blended with indigo blue pots,walls.
The large bamboo trees offer welcome shade.

A truly beautiful place. We are so glad we visited this garden whilst in Marrakech. We spent a couple of hours wandering around, absorbing the tranquility of the plants and the beautiful colours. We ate lunch in the courtyard cafe, and very glad we did - whilst it is a bit more expensive than most food in Marrakech the courtyard has a lovely atmosphere, and the service and food were great. A must visit.
Tranquil gardens. Really peaceful garden to walk around, used to belong to Yves Saint-Laurent. Stop for a drink and a piece of Lemon tart in the tea garden

very pretty. Typical moroccan style. Worth the 10dhm to enter. No seating, just for viewing. An hour at most there, spent more time in museum there. Shops inside, inflated prices, not your usual marakkech haggle!

Beautiful botanical garden and house. Beautiful oasis of calm, botanical garden covering 12 acres – photographers dream. Stunning blue and yellow painted house in this very well planned and kept garden. There is wonderful bamboo plantation, olive and banana trees, palms and cactus from all over the world. All just for 50MAD.I am not fan a museum but the small Berber Museum, included exhibition of the Berber culture, art crafts and history, based in part of the YSL house is worth a visit. It is just 25MAD extra, but definitely worth spending another 20-30 minutes in there.Majorelle Garden was part of our 1st day - taxi from Majorelle Gardens to Bab Debbagh(30MAD-40Max after haggling, we have been asked to pay 200MAD) to see Tanneries. Next go along the main round Rue de bab debbagh into the city centre. On the way on the right side Maison de la Photografie with café on the roof. Next visit Ben Youseff Medersa and Marrakech Museum (buy combined ticket). Next walk through souks to Jemaa el Fna square and next see Koutubia Mosque and finally relax in Koutubia Gardens.

Beautidul garden. It is a beautiful and lush garden, it is however a garden and not the honåme of YSL. Yves Saint Laurent was the owner of the Majorelle garden but lived next door (not open for the public), it is nice and wortha visit but there are many other things to experience so dont go there unless you are in town for a while and have time on your hands
classic garden. this is 'a must see' for visitors to Marrakesh. The gardens are well laid out, , but can be a little crowded, so patience is needed if a particular photo shot is needed,

Loved this. Difficult to find - walked around for about an hour looking and no signs so recommend to take a taxi (bargain hard - should be around 30 D from main square). quite small and fairly crowded but gorgeous nonetheless. Also like expensive cafe - nice place to have a dish of ice cream.
Pleasant. I did like it but it just wasn't that exciting and was quite expensive really. It made a change from the medina and is a good reason to go Gueliz and see the new Marrakech.

Serenity amongst the chaos. Spent an hour here late afternoon in March. as soon as you walk through the gates a feeling of calmness drifts over you. Lovely, small, well manicured gardens with exotic plants. The noise of the city is shut out and allows you to enjoy the tranquil array of primary colour ornamentation against the green foliage. Good photographic opportunities to be had here. Wasn't busy when we went late afternoon but expect it could be busy earlier in day when the experience might not be the same.

Beautiful but busy. The gardens are well laid out and well kept. The famous Blue, looks amazing so there are plenty of arty photographs to be taken here. You pay to go into the gardens and then again for the museum. Worth a visit but go early when it's a bit quieter
bursting with colours. friendly staff at the entrance, great design (what else can you expect from Yves Saint Laurent??), nice collection in the boutique, well worth a visit
Great you like cactii. Very crowded and a little smaller than I expected, maybe it would be more impressive in the summer. The bright blue buildings do make a good backdrop for photos.

Wonderful. This is our third trip to the city and we always visit the gardens several times as its so special .Its a matter of taste if you like cactus , blue cloudless sky and peace which we do . I expect its very busy in summer but thats why we choose to visit in March !

Average. Visited here yesterday, there wasn't a huge amount to see, but there were a few nice photo opportunities.I would recommend going early as when we left (about 11am) the queues were building! Overall worth a visit if you have spare time in Marrakech but I didn't think it was that special and wouldn't visit again.
Delightful gardens. Beautiful gardens with an amazing array of cactus plans. Wonderful open courtyard with great coffee and the lunch looked delicious
Aways a joy!. The Jardin Majorelle just gets better and better - this time, I went into the little museum and was so glad I did. don't miss that!
Beautiful garden in Marrakech!. A great garden with a nice Berber museum onsite--one of the highlights of our trip. Easy to walk around, but save time for the bookstore and gift shop...

BEAUTIFUL COLOURS. Thanks to the introduction of the Majorelle blue on walls and railings, this garden is a vibrant array of colours with the plant pots and huge collection of cacti. Take the time to visit the Berber museum inside the gardens as well - only another 25 MAD but well-worth the visit and has a lovely small gift shop. I would thoroughly recommend visiting the gardens early in the morning before it gets too hot and before the queues start building. Some lovely shops just outside the gardens as well as in the Berber museum.
Beautiful park in Blue.....photo ops everywhere~!. This was very picturesque and has a lovely monument to Yves Saint Laurent and his ashes are scattered in the garden.

not quite what we expected. the garden itself is not that impressive and quite expensive...the house is rather ugly but that is just our opinion...on the other hand the little museum is certainly worth a visit

Jardin Majorelle. Beautiful gardens and museum. We had a lovely afternoon strolling around the different areas and there were lots of photo opportunities. Beware of the taxis outside which charge outrageous amounts for short trips unless you haggle. We eventually paid 40 dirhams instead of the 100, but only becuase we walked away and said we'd get a taxi from the main road

Lovely, tranquil gardens. If you need a break from the hustle & bustle of Marrakech, this is a great place to visit. The gardens are not huge -- and only a few things were in bloom when we visited -- but they are well-maintained with lots of shaded places to sit and some nice water features. There is a cafe on site that is a bit pricey but has good food, and the Berber Museum is definitely worth the extra fee.
Splendid. The best garden in Marrakesh, one of the finest in the world. A wide variety of plants in an eye-popping setting.

Shades of stunning blue. The rich diversity of Marrakesh was for me the most memorable thing! A visit to the jardin Marjorelle is an absolute must to contrast with the bustling markets and hectic city life. You don't have to like plants to visit, just be able to appreciate design and colour. Its an interesting walk from the centre as you pass through the sights and smells of a huge fruit and vegetable market. The restaurant is obviously designed for the tourist wallet but offers a good selection of traditional food - there are a few restaurants just outside the walls of the garden too. Don't bother with a taxi there and back, just walk and enjoy the diversity Marrakesh has to offer the visitor.

jewel in the dust.... A beautifully maintained botanic wonderland with loads of colour, tranquil water and seats to sit in the shade. Berber museum is worth the visit too, exquisite berber jewellery and costume and 5 minute photographic tour of high Atlas mountains way of life.

Beautiful. Read about this place in a guide book and would highly recommend going to visit. It is a beautiful garden with lots of things to go look at, the Berber Museum and Galarie Love are a must. This was my favourite sight to see when visiting Marrakech.
,Gardens. Nothing to dislike, Exquisite goods for sale in shop if you have small fortune to spend .Once the home of Yves St Laurent
lovely garden. nice peaceful way to spend an hour looking round the cactus, bamboo and palms mixed with bright coloured pots and fish ponds
Absolutely Beautiful. What an amazing and pretty place and such a well thought our museum that is inside (it is worth buying the museum ticket).

Cool place to visit. Take your time and enjoy the calming gardens at the Marrakesh attraction. The Berber museum, although compact, is filled with beautiful exhibits from all around Morocco. Cafe is charming, the tarte citron is lovely with a local coffee....I defy anyone to not enjoy it.
Tranquil. So peaceful, calm and amazing cacti. Good value for money. Ate at a cafe before we entered as we understood cafe in the Gardens was not good value.

A treat for the eyes. Stunning azure blue and yellow paint colour combinations in this very planned and ordered garden. Varied range of established plantings with some fascinating succulents and palms. It's not huge - you can get round it in an hour without rushing, provided you don't get waylaid in the bookshop as I did… As it's not huge it can get busy so try visiting at a non-peak time.
Beautiful Gardens. There is nothing more to say except that they are well worth the visit. The Berber Museum at the gardens are worth a visit and the cafe was excellent.
Jardin Majorelle. It was expensive for what it was. Ok if you are keen on bamboo and cactus, but I preferred to see the orange trees around the city.

Beautiful Garden. This is a photographers dream. The garden is a peaceful haven in the middle of town. The colours are amazing and it's lovely to stroll round or sit and relax. Best way to get there is by horse and carriage, the HOHO bus takes forever and only runs every hour.

lovely garden. This is one of the more expensive attractions in Marrakech, but worth a visit. It will occupy about half a day including getting there. There is an YSL shop and a bookshop within the garden. The Berber Museum within the garden has an additional charge, but we found it particularly interesting. We took a taxi from the main square for which we had to negotiate quite hard on the price (having been told to pay 30 dhs). The taxi driver was keen to take us other places as he said the gardens would be busy - we didn't take the bait. We manged to walk back to the Medina.

Garden for resting. Although a small garden it was so lovely to wander in and find some respite from the midday sun and sit on the terrace sipping refreshing mint tea which the waiter poured from a great height. Also purchased a great book from the shop there - Ricks Cafe written by an American lady and her struggles in opening Ricks Cafe in Casablanca.

A must on a visit to Marrakech. This is a very interesting garden with its polished red concrete pathways, colourful pots and Klein blue walls. There is a bamboo grove, a cactus garden and a large pond among other features. Very photogenic! The only drawback is the large number of visitors so select your time carefully. I understand that the earlier the better.

Hmmm!. Likes - Colourful, different,
Dislikes - quite a walk for what it was, artificial, preferred the natural Marrakech,

An oasis of tranquility in a crazy city. What a delight this place is! Tucked away in the heart of Marrakech is a magical garden full of trees and plants from all over the world. But this is not just an exotic garden - it's a place of calm in a city that probably doesn't know what "calm" means! You step through the gate and what meets you first is the colour green, everywhere you look. Then you notice the vivid blue of the artefacts and structures that adorn the gardens. Only when you get over this smothering of colour do you then start to notice the astonishing blend of bamboo, palm, cactus and so much more. It's cool too - not in the trendy sense, as you seem to lose awareness of yourself, but in the sense that the temperature inside seems so much more bearable when it's stifling outside. I love this place and will definitely return.
Stunning Gardens. A place of relaxation & beauty amongst the pace & hustle of Marrakech. I am no gardener but I couldn't help be amazed at the beauty of these gardens. Avoid the cafe - it's a rip off

Very blue. This garden is quite small and can get rather crowded. Having said that, it is well worth a visit. There are pathways amongst giant cacti and bamboo, some water features and a small museum. The buildings are painted a lovely deep blue colour and there are large pots scattered around in matching blues and yellows all adding up to a very beautiful oasis in the middle of busy Marrakech
Beautiful tranquility. Definitely visit these! They are beautiful and a great escapism from the hectic nature of the city. You can easily walk there from the old city - takes around 20minutes.

Magical and peaceful gardens. A symphony of colours, Jardin Majorelle is an attraction that you should not miss.Cool and colourful it's a serene and lush space in the busy, crazy town of Marrakesh. The museum although small, offers an interesting exhibition of the Berber culture, articrafts and history. The cafe inside the gardens is also a great spot for a light lunch and refreshments. Overall, Jardin majorelle is a great little trip and attraction

Over-crowded and expensive admission. I was disappointed by this attraction. It was the most expensive entry fee in Marrakech of anywhere I went, and beside the gardens and a small berber collection of jewelry there was very little to see. I had hoped to see the inside of the house, or at least some information and photos of the home. This was also the most crowded attraction in Marrakech.

Inspiring.. Spectacular!!. It's been a long time since i went to a place that inspired me so much!5*!! The Aesthetics, the lay out.. the feel of the place is just out of this world! I came home and started painting again after a very long time!!! Thank you Mr Majorelle and Mr. YSL!!!

A beautiful garden of unusual colours. A visit to the Majorelle gardens is a unique experience as you will see there plants, cactuses etc that you will have never seen before, and the colours used to paint the sides of garden paths, ceramics etc,. are extraordinarily vivid and unusual. The only problem with these gardens is that they are too popular - there are always long queues and the place is often too crowded. My advice is to go at 8am when there is no-one - and you will get in quickly and be able to enjoy the place in peace!
Beautiful garden. This garden is a beautiful and tranquil contrast to the Medina. Excellent cafe in the grounds and a very interesting museum
A peaceful walk. The gardens, although small, were exquisitely maintained and promoted an aura of peace and well being. They promoted quiet and people talked quietly even though it was very busy.
A beautiful, calm, colourful garden. The peaceful surroundings and the bright colours were a joy. The courtyard restaurant was delightful.
A tranquil paradise.... The gardens are tranquil and peaceful and a great place to escape the hustle and bustle of the busy city. A definite must see if you are in Marrakesh.
Special and unusual. Hint of mystery, exotic cacti and other plants - brightly painted pots add to the character. Peaceful
Great place!. Great place, for relax and meditation. Lovely colours, trees and plants. Excellent museum inside the garden. Must see.

Thank you YSL for this magnificent garden.. I always visit this garden when I come to Marrakech, it is simply divine.Everything is exquisite, the tiles, the cactus section, the blue colour of the walls juxtaposed with the yellow of the wrought iron and plant containers. Breathtaking. Good news is they now stock the blue paint in the gift shop and its a total bargain at DHM 100 for 850g. Enough to take home & paint something to remind you of this special place.I really recommend you visit, even if you aren't into gardens, this magical little part of marrakech is an oasis amongst the craziness of the medina.

Pretty Gardens. The gardens are very well maintained and offer quite a lot for the size. It's not free, but the price also helps maintain the peacefulness as it keeps the people trying to sell you stuff out. Very nice palms, bamboo and Cacti.I would recommend coming here at the middle or end of your trip to Marrakech. You will love it here a lot more after a couple days in and around the Medina. We came here as the first thing to see and did not fully appreciate it as much as we would have on day 3 or 4.

beautiful place to escape the craziness of marrakech. Well worth spending a half day here stunning gardens and nice courtyard cafe with great photo opportunities as the colourful structures contrast with lush green plants A highlight of our trip

Place to find some Peace. After a few days in the desert, we Went here in the morning. From the center of the city it will usually be 12 Dh for locals and 50 Dh for foreigners. The place is a welcome rest from the crowded and loud streets and souks of the city and ideal for a 'break' during the day!It has a lovely atmosphere and contains even a cafe where one can stop and have (a bit more pricy) drink.

Pretty garden, with nice cafe. In Marrakech, this was a pleasant diversion away from the hubbub of the city. It's very nice, and was designed by Yves Saint Laurent, and great if you're a fan of cacti. The cafe was nice too, and very reasonable for lunch. Good place to divert yourself for an hour, or 2 hours if you want a bite to eat. No need to plan for longer. It's not huge.

Fab Garden. Great cacti and lovely, cool shady spot on a hot afternoon.
Interesting museum
Good value at 75dh per visitor
Beautiful retreat. Yves St. Laurent owned this place and it is lovely. A nice respite from the busy-ness of the medina and if you are tired of shopping and looking at jewelry etc.
A must in Marrakech. Almost everybody seem to like Jardin Majorelle and we happily join the choir! This is absolutely a must when you visit Marrakech!

Peaceful and calming. This petite garden, designed by Yves St Laurent, is a peaceful and pleasant retreat from the lively bustle of the Medina. Opportunities for photographs abound and there is something to see at every turn. Get there early (it opens at 8.00am) and avoid the crowds, you can always enjoy a coffee at the little cafe once they arrive! The only slight negative we noted was the fact that some past visitors had clearly felt the need to carve their names into the leaves of the aloes and bamboos closest to the paths.
Bel Jardin. A beautiful, quiet place to wander through after all the hustle & bustle of central Marrakesh. Beautiful flowers and setting.

Bland, unnatural. I really don't know how this has got the reputation of being one of the best parks inside of Marrakech, it's awful. All of the plants and greenery are sectioned off, they look as if they've just come hurtling down and smashed into there respective places with the soil having this weird ripple effect.As we walked back, we happened upon the Cyber Park, which is actually stunning and natural, reminded me of regents parks. Oh, and it's free!
A nice little garden. Very nice little garden, but hated to see how some visitors have carved their names on cacti. Very disrespectful to the garden and the overall beauty but worth visiting.

Double Wow. Not what I was expecting at all but this garden was magical and the collection of cacti amazing. We were there last month but could imagine what a haven it would be in the hot months with the shade and water. In fact we found ourselves finding the patches of sun as it was so cool! Loved the colours - expecially the blue and as I use YSL Rive Gauche I felt very much at home. The Berber Museum was really good and so informative. We really loved the whole experience.

Lovely, structured gardens - great for photography. The admission fee is a little steep in my opinion, and the best thing about the gardens is the colored walls providing fantastic background for photography.

Gorgeous, relaxing and informative. We loved spending an afternoon here! The small museum is informative and beautifully curated, with explanation sheets in multiple languages. The gardens are beautifully maintained and incredibly peaceful. While it's a little bit pricey, it's worth it.
Wow!!. A real highlight in this frenetic city - a true oasis. The YSL connection seemed a little overplayed but the gardens were amazing in their own right

Worthwhile trip. We hadn't made it here on our previous visit to Marrakech so glad we visited this time. Taxi was just a few pounds. Well worth it for the gardens, Berber museum and the cafe. A very enjoyable few hours. We got a caleche back which was about £7 after some serious bargaining.

Lovely colourful gardens. Beautiful gardens set with lovely, bright colours. Every kind / size of cactus you could possibly think of is here! A nice place to visit to get out of the heat of the day, well worth a visit. Gets very crowded in the afternoons so go early in the morning if you can. Expensive gift shop and cafe though so be warned!
Blue gardens.. Lovely and cool to walk around these lovely gardens.Nice restaurant in there as well.No toilets,only in the restaurant.

beautiful small garden and museum. wonderful place to wander around for an hour or so; bright colours, shady paths etc. Museum of berber life small but interesting. Room of Berber jewellery beautifully set under stars. Shops with lovely but very expensive items for sale

Beautiful surroundings. We had a trip here as the weather was not so good for sunbathing & it was a truly beautiful place!Lovely colours & very interesting-the Yves St Laurent memorial garden is really beautiful with a wall dedicated to some of his works-very colourful & informative.It was not too busy so we had plenty of time and space to look about & the gardens are very close to the shops in the European quarter of Marrakech-you can get a taxi for about 20 dirhams.Some really unusual plants and trees in the gardens-enough to inspire me on my return home when we get better weather!!

Unforgettable. Eerie, wicked cacti in myriads of different haunting shapes inhabit a garden with running water, orange earth and blue edgings. It's unbelievable. Only a top designer could have envisaged this! and Yves St Laurent's ashes were scattered here.

Small but worth a visit. A haven of tranquility just off a main road, a garden of green plants full of solid bright blue and yellow objects/constructions and a small gallery/shop. A little expensive for what there is but a pleasant hour's visit.

Pleasant. Very calm and pleasant area after the hustle and bustle of the city.Surprised at how small it was. Mostly cacti,no flowers,lovely splashes of colour on walls and pots.Not to many people when we visited,around 3pm, a large crowd would spoil the atmosphere.

Great place. Brilliant garden, great museum, just wait as the tour parties go past you and wait for the space to be able to enjoy he gardens. Museum was really interesting. Taxi rank outside the attractions so no worries there, pick a price u want to pay and just wait till u get a person willing to take u.

Beautiful. An extremely pretty garden. It is not very big but it is very calming and cooling and a definitely change of pace from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. A must visit if you are in Marrakech.
Lovely. I enjoyed this place a lot. It is small and you can see it all in a few minutes. The shops in the area are really cool.
Beautiful. Beautiful gardens everything spotless. Well worth a visit. Calm and quiet. Lovely shop but quite pricy!!

Stunning colours and shapes. So different from the traditional style, yet very Moroccan; well thought out planting with different shapes and colours and in the Berber museum is very interesting. Definitely worth the visit and dwell a little longer in the restaurant and shop.
Beautiful. This place was gorgeous with its Cactus garden and versatile trees along with the must-go-to Amazigh culture museum by Yves Saint Laurent. It is highly recommended.

Very nice garden. Majorelle is a beautifull garden. It is not very big but the tranquility and colors are really amazing. its cost 50dh for the entrance to the garden (approx 5 euro) and 25dh to the berber museum (which we didn´t do). We spend 3 nice hours including a nice break in their café. The blue/yellow colors are so fantastic and shouldn´t be missed. I can reccomend going if you like Peace and tranqulity and a break from the noise in the Medina. Nice shadow Places as well.

A Very Special Place. After spending time in the insetting of Marrakech's medina and the constant hard-sell, it is a pleasant respite to visit Jardin Majorelle. It is a peaceful oasis with an interesting history. Before or after your garden visit, spend some time in Marrakech's New Town; it has a totally different character than the medina.

An enchanting garden harbouring many species of exotic plants. A beautiful garden created by Jacques Majorelle and made famous by Yves Saint-Laurent. We were really impressed by this wonderful collection of exotic plants. Every time the following cactus was more strange and more beautiful than the previous.

Do NOT miss Le Jardin Majorelle. This garden was the project of French artist Majorelle--the famous Moroccan deep blue is his invention--a color he developed for architecture. The garden features many species but has a huge number of cacti and euphorbia (cactus-like spiny desert plants.) The surroundings are idyllic. There is a small but excellent museum of Berber artifacts. After Majorelle died, Yves St. Laurent, the celebrated French fashion designer bought the Majorelle and kept it in a trust so after his death, it would be maintained. This is a real gift to the world. Do not miss the museum, which has a small selection of the costumes St.Laurent acquired, as well as videos of Berber life. The museum is extraordinary--one room makes you feel you are in the open desert under the stars, but it's a trick of mirrors and lights. Incredible. Do. NOT. MISS!!!
A hidden oasis. An unexpected delight! Great that the garden has been restored and brought back to life by Yves St Laurent' and his partner. Also interesting Berber display
Quite space in a busy city. Lovely opportunity to walk around these gardens - calm and quite - plenty of shade available to shelter under in the warmer weather.

A must see, an oasis in the middle of Marrakesh.. we loved this garden with its elegant simplicity, and it's gentle colours.the museum is also a must with it's fascinating collection of Berber artefacts and costumes, also its collection of photographs.there is also a very good cafe for lunch.

Beautiful colours . We walked to find the garden with some road crossing of epic proportions and eventually found it after asking a policeman but walked back far more easily. The gardens were tranquil, the museum was interesting but the colours were stunning in the sunshine.

Relax. I can't go to marrakech without having a stop in jardin majorelle,It always feel great to leave the noisy tiring part of the city and go have a relaxing and enjoyable time in the park.The price isn't expensive (student price possible :-p).From the first step you feel like you are in an other world, sound of the fountain, the fresh air in the shows of beautiful trees, the beautiful color of blue majorelle, it's great mixture with a nice yellow and white. Fresh color and atmosphere in a city where temperatures can go up to 49°Ctry it, you won't regret ;-) Oh ! And fans of photography gonna feel like in Disney land!You can make great pictures in there
Loved the little museum. Whilst the garden itself was a little underwhelming, I would highly recommend a visit of the small but fascinating museum within the grounds
Nice. I love cacti and this is what its all about! the bamboo garden could do with a tidy up though, looking rather sparse.

Beautiful, tranquil gardens. Well worth a visit. Such tranquil gardens with the memorial for Yves St. Laurent are an oasis in the middle of bustling Marrakech. Berber Museum is small, but absolutely fascinating and the plants, from all over the world, stunning.

It's okay. The entrance fee to the garden is 50 dirham or 5 euro. Born and grow up in a tropical country, I found the garden is not too interesting; a bunch of tropical plants and cacti are not something unfamiliar to me. If you don't have much time and not really into plants or botanical things, you can just skip this garden.

Great Exhibition but dodgy garden !!. We walked to the gardens & wished we had taken transport as it was difficult to find !! We stopped off at a Café & asked for directions & we were met with blank stares even though it transpired the gardens were only 100m away.The gardens were OK & we could not believe that there was graffiti on the Bamboo & Cacti themselves !!! There was discreet security personnel presence in the garden - too late to have stopped this vandalism. But the Berber Museum exhibition in my opinion transcended anything seen in the garden.A marvellously presented exhibition which is in my top five things to see in Marrakech - brilliant. Well worth the entry fee.

Beautiful oasis - but not a must-see. Jardin Majorelle is a beautiful little place all in green and blue - we took some really pretty pictures there. But it's definitely not the amazing must-see spot that you might think (or as some guide books like to sell it). If you have some spare time and want to escape the quirky bustle of the Medina go there. But for goodness' sake, don't take one of the horse carriages! You only get really poor animals and a lung full of smog!
Beautiful. The gardens were fabulous, loads of fab strong colours and a museum of Berber costume. Look out for the gold fish in the blue pond and the architecture of some windows..
Ok. Thought it would be better. Spent a couple of hours at most and got bored towards the end. Worth a visit if you are in the area.
Worth the visit. A splendid garden full or rare species. Just a please to stroll along the lanes and enjoy a coffee at the restaurant.

An absolute must in Marrakech.. Jacque Majorelle created an absolutely stunning if a bit surreal garden. It was taken over by Yves St. Laurent and beautifully maintained. Go very early or late to avoid the crowds.

Pretty gardens,very relaxing. A peaceful retreat from the madness of the main square. We took our 3 children and were warmly invited. Lots of interesting cacti and fauna, spotted some frogs and a terrapin in the pond. Cafe was great, lovely sandwiches, coffee, smoothies and my husband enjoyed sardines. We stayed for 2 hours which was enough with children. Defo recommended stop to take a breath and relax
Small but packed. A fairly small garden but packed with colour. We didn't bother with the Berber museum so can't comment on that but it costs a little more and there was quite a queue to get in.

Small and crowded, but the museum inside is terriffic.. Maybe the expextations were too high but the Majorelle garden was a little bit disapointing. Small, crowded. Maybe if you like cactus plants.... The Berber museum however was very beautiful and made up for the garden.

Overrated but the museum is nice. Anywhere else a nice but rather small cactus and bamboo garden would not attract that much attention.... yes it is pleasant to stroll there (if you manage to stroll despite the crowd....) but if your time is limited you can easily skip it. On the other hand, the Museum is very small but well done and informative.

well worth a visit. As a big Yves Klein fan, I had to visit Jardin Majorelle, that boasts this beautiful deep 'royal blue'. YSL made a nice job in getting the place back to its old state. It's certainly worth a visit and it has some nice (but pricy) shops and bars surrounding it.

Tropicana in Marrakech. What a garden of tranquillity in the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. Even on a rainy day, the gardens were beautiful, calm, fantastically maintained. The Berber Museum was very interesting and informative. I would definitely recommend it.

Incredible. One of the nicest places on earth
Colors
Fowers plants, history...it is all there...
I would defenitely go back there!

Made my heart sing....... The colours, textures, architecture and general ambience of these gardens is fantastic. It really lifted my spirits and made me smile.
A beautiful shop is included but most of the items are expensive.
Must see when in Marrakech. An amazing collection of cacti. A small garden but very well maintained and definitely worth visiting.

Something different. A short walk to the north of the medina, this is something a little different and worth a visit for that reason A garden full of green - palms and cacti, against a background of blue walls, red buildings and yellow pots all planted around the obligatory pools filled with lilies.
There is a cafe but we didn't use it.

Peaceful gardens. Such a nice experience, although not sure why they were painting some of the pots yellow in a blue garden. A haven of tranquility amid the madness, my advice would be to get there very early, we left at 11.00 and there was a big queue outside not sure what that would do to the peacefulness.

Beautiful colours and peaceful. Enjoyable and relaxed visit round Majorelle Gardens. Exquisite plants and beautiful blue colours of the buildings set against the exotic plants. A definite to visit in Marrakech!
Beautiful and blue; an oasis of calm. Museum of Berber life small and interesting. Gardens beautiful and serene. You can imagine the attraction for YSL.
Peaceful Garden. Beautiful calm serene place to spend an afternoon wandering around the gardens. You can also get a bite to eat there in the very busy cafe!

Beautiful. Beautiful gardens, and lovely tea in the cafe - slightly pricey, but a good morning out! Try and time your visit with the cooler time with the sun, and avoid the big rush of tourists if possible

Lovely contrast to full-on-ness of rest of Marrakech. This place has interesting history and development and is lovingly tended now. Stunning plants and greenery interspersed with brightly coloured pots and benches - very exotic. For 12 acres it felt much smaller but parts not open. Fascinating aspect to Marrakech all the better for being unexpected. Really recommend the delicious ice-creams, juices and shakes at the cafe just by entrance. Good value and well worth the walk there. Shows another side of Marrakech.

Lovely small garden. This is a lovely small garden, worth a look. They are impeccably manicured with very interesting plants. The museum is interesting too - small but has very good displays. These gardens were established in the 1920s by the French painter Jacques Majorelle, with marble pools, raised pathways, and lots of trees and flowering bushes. After years of neglect, the fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent restored them.

Little gem in Marrakech. This is a must see garden for garden lovers. The planting and the general atmosphere are great. We loved the colourful pots and seats which all add to the general attraction. We enjoyed a very nice lunch in the very pretty courtyard garden. We took a taxi there and back and followed the advice of our Riad staff about how much we should pay. Don't know about wheelchair access.

Beautiful. A fabulous oasis in Marrakech and well worth a visit.Lots of plants, trees and interesting things to see.Excellent trip. Very busy outside but lovely inside and some amazing plants etc to see. A must do on your holidays.
Beautiful park. This park is really worth visiting. A real treat for mind and eye! Go there in the morning if you want more solitude. Don't miss it!

#boring. Went with a group, only had 45 minutes there and we spend most of it in the cafe as it was pretty dull. Expected to see plants from all around the world, not just cacti. Didn't even make it the whole way around as we were bored. Nice coffee though.

Majorelle Gardens. Beautiful 12 acre botanical garden designed by French painter Jacques Majorelle and bought by Yves St Laurent and Pierre Berge in 1980. Hosting an impressive collection of exotic plants collected from Majorelle's travels around the world, you can feast your eyes on the stunning cactus and yucca plants, coconut, banana and bamboo trees, water lilies and white water lilies, water fountains and ponds and of course his villa paint in "Majorelle Blue"; a striking ultramarine blue he created in 1937 and used to adorn the large ceramic jars dottted around the garden. Small but enchanting and well worth the visit. There is also a museum of Tamazigh culture which I did not visit.

Worth a trip to Marrakech. I had been looking forward to this garden, but was not prepared for the glorious colors of the buildings and pots, and the variety of plants, especially cacti. The Berber museum is outstanding - I would have liked more time there. Plan on at least two hours for the complex.
Oasis of calm. Beautiful and unusual. Well cared for and useful information about the plants was clear. Shop was well stocked a pleasure to visit.

Favourite part of Marrakesh. It was a total surprise when I visited as I am not a huge fan of gardening or gardens (hay fever). This was though an exception, beautifully laid out, vast amount of colour and nice little shop and memorial for Yves Saint Laurent. Enjoyed every minute and have recommended friends and family to go since.
Jardine. I liked it all. The cafe was a bit expensive but the food and service were very good. The Museum was interesting if you like social history and there was a magic moment!

Do not expect something on the scale of Kew Gardens. A nice quiet spot and well maintained but small and at 50 Dirhams entrance fee for the garden (almost £5.00) and 25 Dirhams for the museum, rather expensive.

Nice garden and museum. Watch out for the taxidrivers and make a price before you get in the carr. specially the museum of the Berbers was very nice and gives a good impression of the different tribes
Garden!. You have to visit to say that you have been! If you like to see a garden then it's okay. It is very small and if I am honest we thought it was poor value for money. Nothing special.

such a nice place. The first time I visited this garden was in the 1980s. It looks so much better now and is like a liitle piece of paradise not far from the heart of Marrrakesh. You cannot skip this visit!!!
A very special visit. This is a beautifully conceived and spectacularly colourful garden. Do visit the museum while there. It provides a wonderfully executed history of Berber culture.

Pretty garden (especially if you like cactus). There is a small Islamic Art museum located here (extra charge for admission), but the signs are only in Arabic and French. There were no pictures allowed while in the museum. We walked through the entire museum in 5-10 minutes and spent the majority of our visit strolling through the gardens. There are a amazing number of different types of cacti and palms in the gardens along with several beautiful fountains. It is worth a visit.

Peace. What a delightful break from the hustle of the souks. Leafy, quiet, calming. The colours of the surrounding pots amongst the giant canes are lovely. The museum is also a welcome surprise and nicely set out.

Go early!. Lovely colours and interesting plants- really well planned out. But at about 11am it gets really busy - queues to go in, so try and be there before 10am. Most signs are in Arabic and French. The Berber museum in the grounds is worth a visit (Pay extra for it, but not a lot)
A must see. Can I say any more? The colours, the vegetation... Just go there. Do not miss the museum. There is also a coffeeshop with very good coffee.

Unexpected lushness and beauty. A perfect place to spend a few hours relaxing after the madness of the markets. The gardens are cool, quiet, and beautiful. The Berber Museum in the grounds is very interesting and worth visiting

a cute garden. this is a fresh and peaceful stop, after the mess of la medina.
designed with taste and elegance by Yves Saint Laurent, who had his house just beside.
but its just a small+cute garden, nothing really amazing....
Super.. It is a green oasis of green, rest, shadow in this big city. The beautifull blue house is this garden makes the light different. Not that big, but you have to see it when visiting Marrakech !

Little Picturesque Garden YSL. Nice break away from the hectic city of Marrackech as hidden behind the walls is this beautiful garden where the home os belonging to Yves Sain Laurent. Worth a visit :) peaceful retreat.

most overrated thing in marrakesh. sure its a nice cactus garden, of which almost all were from mexico, but its so overrated. i would not recommend going there for 5€ when the rest of the tourist attractions were more like 1-2€. plus its quite small.

Nice oasis in a busy city. The gardens are well kept and they have a very good selection of tree & plant species from all over the world. It was ideal for a relaxing walk and plenty of benches to sit and admire the work of the gardeners.

A serene Garden of blue!. Deliciously designed Garden, indelible colours, a dream knit together, enchanting Cobbolt blue or Majorell blue colours that would paint the canvass of Your mind for ever after ........ it is absolutely worth visiting!
Beautiful Garden. Wonderful garden that once belonged to Yves St Laurent, Would be even more spectacular in summer when flowers out but this did not really detract being the winter when we visited.

Beautiful place to visit.. We visited these beautiful gardens in the city with our guide. The colours are amazing so vibrant. I especially loved the room displaying the YSL yearly posters. Do visit if you have time. A peaceful haven.

Probably need to be keen on gardening!. Nice to visit if you've got time though we visited in feb when not that much to see apart from cacti. Would prob be a very different place to go during the summer.

ok but not amazing. The free palmerie in the new town is as good, however, if you love blue...go for it :)
Smaller than i expected.

Oasis. Lovely gardens after the hustle and heat of the souks. When baring this in mind they were lovely. We went at 8.30 in the morning as reccomended prior to tourist buses coming in. The gardens are not that big though but are beautiful. Was expecting more if im honest.

A must see. Prefer the opening hours to avoid the tours and the numerous visitors and take advantage of the quietness. A pleasure for the eyes thanks to the plants diversity and the presence of the famous majorelle blue in several places of the garden.
A cool relief from a hectic city !. Beautifully maintained a little oasis ..totally managed but a real change from the medina and half way house to the Gueliz new town

The only properly curated collection in Marrakech. We enjoyed the gardens and the Berber museum. Most of the sights in Marrakech have poorl to no labeled signs, guides, brochures, historical context. This is a pleasant exception. Well designed and identified collection of tropical plants and interesting Berber artifacts, especially clothing in the museum.

Tranquility amid the chaos that is Marrakech. Beautiful tranquil gardens in memory of Yves St Laurent. Superb walled patio area in which to sit in the sun and have coffee and an excellent lemon tarte! Very nice gift shop too. The whole garden has been revamped and the cacti, palms and succulents are beautifully set off against a background of coloured pathways and iridescent blue paintwork - Sounds rather 'in your face' but in typical YSL style, it works amazingly. Entrance is in the side road (turn left where the horse drawn carriages are situated and its about 100 yrds on the left - mind the smell of the horses as that can really take the romance out of the carriage idea!) Great place and definitely worth going

Beautiful. an absolute delight, when you arrive once you pay and enter there Is a delightful water feature and courtyard/seating area. Strong blues and terracotta colours everywhere with pretty trailing flowers. Once you enter the garden the beauty and scale of the place is overwhelming, in a lovely way. Took some brilliant photos here, and I didn't want to leave. There is a gorgeous little restaurant/cafe within the garden, enclosed within a brick courtyard, the atmosphere is special and the place extremely pretty. The food was good (mixed morrocan salad/ club sandwich). A highlight of the gardens is the love gallery, such vibrant colours. If I am ever lucky enough to return to this amazing city I am returning here. One of the nicest experiences I have had. We also paid to visit the small museum, the clothing and jewelry on display is interesting, but the exhibition is a lot smaller than we had anticipated. Please be assertive yet polite with the taxi drivers vying for your business near the doors, and agree a price before getting in the cab.
Its a must!. If you are marrakech this place is one of the places you should visit.You can visit only for to see hundred kind of cactus or great colors!
Tranquil . A perfect place to escape the madness of Marrakesh in this beautiful oasis. Thoroughly enjoyed it and recommend going to see.

Colourful tranquil spot.... well worth the minimal entry fee...and pay the extra euro to see the Berber museum which although small is beautifully set up and displayed. The selection of jewelry and costumes along with a well made video of the Berber people was fascinating.

Swamped with nature.. Amidst the urban nightmare of a busy city this is a spectacular oasis of nature. The gardens, beautifully maintained, are filled with an amazing collection and variety of cacti and other plants. The joy of these gardens is the contrast between the plants and the yellow and blues of the few buildings. It is artistically pleasing and stunning.

A magical oasis of calm. Never, ever visit Marrakech without taking time to stop here. Beautifully laid out gardens and lush pools all carefully maintained by the lovely staff. A collection of Yves 'Love Posters' - one for each year he lived there and a little gift shop Elling vintage art and design books. This is one of my favourite places on earth.
Tranquil gardens, lovely colours. You can reach the Marjorelle gardens by taxi or horse cart. It is a very nice athmosphere, lovely colours and makes a nice change from the busy centre of Marrakech.

An oasis of calm. This was our 3rd visit, and enjoy the peace and tranquility. Although the weather was cool in January it was nice to wander in the shade. We spent an hour or so inside, although the area is not particularly large.

A beautiful garden. I had read about this garden in the guide book and it did not disappoint. The use of colour is beautiful and the plants well chosen. The Berber museum was well worth the visit. One of the highlights of our trip.

Beautiful tranquility.. Colourful treat with fabulous plants and quiet space to wander around. The colours of Morocco were reflected at every turn, a nice way to spend a couple of hours and catch your breath from the kaos of Marrakech. Some great photo opportunities too.

Museum the best part. The Majorelle Gardens are pretty enough and the cobalt blue buildings are pots are stunning but the best part of the visit for me was the Berber Museum. Very interesting with lovely photos, relics and clothes. Great key in English for non Arabic or French readers. The gardens and museum can be seen in the space of about 2-3 hours.

Incredible garden - a must see. No visit to to Marrakech is complete without a visit to Jardin Majorelle. Jacques Majorelle a Frenchman who in 1924 bought this land and started to landscape it. It was opened to the public in 1947. It was acquired by Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Berge and was given to the Foundation Pierre Berge-Yves Saint Laurent in Paris to ensure its survival because it was almost turned into condos.There is a very nice upscale gift shop with Yves Saint Laurent items. Worth a quick stop.

A stunning 'must see' place in Marrakech.. This was a truly magnificent place. When we entered the sunlight on the floors, water and coloured walls took your breath away. Fingers clicked on cameras and every photograph is a gem. A creative sanctuary which dazzled the senses.The museum is well worth the extra money- small but breathtaking. The guide inside gave such value for money and embraced our questions with many smiles.
Tranquility. Beautiful, well cared for garden with small museum and restaurant.Loved the artistic use if colour.
Beautiful botanical gardens. Beautiful botanical gardens well worth a visit. Lots of interesting plants including cacti and shrine of Yves Saint. Laurent.
A must see in Marrakech. These gardens are one of the wonders of Morocco - try to get there early before the crowds. The Berber museum is well worth the small extra cost

Beautiful Oasis away from the hustle & bustle. We visited the gardens mid afternoon, after a long morning of walking around and seeing various other attractions.
It's very peaceful and a great getaway from the carnage of the Souks and Medina. There are benches to relax and soak up the scenery.
The gardens could be walked around in about 20minutes if you were in a hurry!
So beautiful . . .. The Majorelle gardens are absolutely beautiful and well worth a visit when in Marrakech. The only downside is that so many people visit that it does get crowded very quickly.
Amazing place. Amazing and relaxing place at 40 mn walking from the Jemaa el Fna place. It's worth the effort. Not to miss!

beautiful, but small and expensive. as others say, these gardens are not very big and expensive, but still worth seeing. Beautifully restored by Yves St Laurent. Get there early as by the time we left (around 11) there was quite a queue outside.
It is worth paying the extra for the museum inside for the history (and clothing) of the Moroccan tribes.

Nice but only worth visiting for 1 hour then you've seen it all. 50 dirams for going in a garden is a bit expensive, especially compared to the other attractions in Marrakech which are 10 dirhams. It's nice and we spent an hour here walking round and sitting on the benches.
Nice but not much to see. Quiet and peaceful. The cafe was ok and the food nice. Not much to see there and probably not worth a special trip

Really nice. Very nice place with exotic plants. Don't expect extraordinary things to see, it's just a simple but beautiful garden, with plants, especially cactuses from various parts of the world. I would recommend to visit half an hour before the sunset, you may appreciate the shadow/sunlight changes in the garden. If you'd like to visit thoroughly though, spare at least one hour, and another half an hour for the museum.
Underwhelming!. It was just okay - It is by no means awful but it is underwhelming as it is essentially just a garden and I didn't find it particularly breathtaking - far from it!
One of top attractions in Marrakech. This beautifully restored with the help of Yves Saint Laurent and is well maintained. It is known as one of the nicest Gardens in the world.

An imaginative well laid garden with bright, happy colours. A must see garden in Marrakech. Created by a all known botanist for Yves Saint Laurent, with cactus and other plants, set in a shaded and well laid out garden. It is an oasis of peace, with twittering birds and well worth the modest 10 dirham entrance fee. With the botanist, Yves Saint Laurent, created a special perfume, 'Soir de Marrakech', which can be bought in the perfume shop adjacent to the gardens.The Musee de Berber, painted in a beautiful deep velvet cornflower blue, is in the grounds and can be visited. A pleasant hour and a half can be spent here, restoring equilibrium and peace after the bustle and hustle of the souks and traders. Then go across the road and enjoy the special chicken and almond pastiche that is typically Moroccan and down it with an orange ginger cool drink. Bliss

Stunning. Dazzling colours and beautiful planting - I would class this as one of the world's greatest gardens. We came on foot from the centre of the bustling Medina and found this to be a relaxing yet inspiring place. The museum of Berber life is informative with outstanding displays.

Gloriously Beautiful. I had no idea just how beautiful cacti could be. The care and setting that these desert plants receive here are not to be missed. The intense Majorelle Blue colour is absolutely stunning. To have the garden to myself just once would be priceless. There are so many photographic opportunities but so many visitors make it hard to get that perfect shot. Leave your cares at the door and meander along the pathways. Do not be in a hurry.

Deco decadence. The gardens, residence and restaurant are all beautifully presented and maintained. A tranquil oasis in a magic city. The shop has some superb books on YSL and his era, worth visiting for that alone.

A breath of fresh air. This beautiful garden, situated well outside the Medina, is a bit of a haven. Very quiet and peaceful inside, though depending on when you go it might be overly crowded. not a big space, but filled with a great number of different plants, from five continents.A very nice place to take a break, breath the air, learn a little about plants.

Nice and well taken care!. Nice place to visit, although very crowded. The gardens are well kept and the Berbere Museum is a must. The organization and the design of the museum are extraordinary. The shop although extremely expensive is nice to visit!A must see attraction!
A quiet wonder. Interesting place, set aside 90 minutes. We walked from the Medina and it took about about 30 minutes.

Compact garden of cacti and bamboo. Well worth a visit - greater variety of large specimens of cacti than I've seen for a long time and the bamboo are massive. The garden is well kept and the splashes of blue and yellow add interest and style. Best bit was the Berber museum - additional 25dh fee pp; compact too, but just the right number of interesting exhibits to convey the history and culture of the indigenous people.
Lovely gardens - worth a visit. The gardens are quite a long way from the main city but definitely worth the walk. We spent an hour walking through the gardens and found them very interesting.

A must. The gardens are not the largest but it's not about size. The colour, design, formation and reflections have to be seen. Recommend you read up before the visit to get the most out of the visit. A quiet place to relax in away from the busy City.

Better than i thought it would be !. Went there as a bit of a fill in as we had some time to spare, but glad we did as it is very interesting and a well laid out place. the gardens are quite amazing and well laid out, and id imagine a bit of an oasis in the summer. well worth a visit !
Simply beautiful. Really worth the effort. The museum is really well done and informative. The gardens - stunning. The cafe for unusual teas is worth a visit as well.
Unusual Vibrantly coloured Gardens. Allow at least an hour here... just to stroll around and soak up the tranquillity and colourful artefacts. Our taxi driver seemed to think half an hour would do!
Unexpected delight. Beautiful blue house in a delightful desert garden. The museum was well worth the visit too, particularly the jewellery and costume displays.
Stunning. Beautiful gardens filled with colour; topped with intriguing history and works of YSL. A must visit even if you only have an hour to wonder...
Quiet, colourful moments. The garden is lovely. I like these intense colours and benches to enjoy quiet moments only few minutes away from busy markets.

Small, but beautifully formed!. Our return visit here and this time we paid the extra 25DH for entrance into the small Berber Museum which was well worth it. So 150DH for 2 of us to see that and the garden was a good price. We liked lazing in the cafe with a mint tea and a traditional almond pastry that's served with it. If you are planning on going to the cafe, nite that there are additional loos in there. The YSL 'love' posters used as his Christmas cards are great and the bright coloured pots set off the garden which is mainly palms, cacti and bamboo.
Awsome place. Great place to releax and chill. Awesome cactuses in the garden plus the house painted cobalt-lime colours is amazing.

Stunning!. This was such a difference to the hustle and bustle of Marrakech! It is not a large garden but it is vibrant yet calming. We arrived early and it was very tranquil. We left just as the crowds arrived. There is a lovely cafe, a great place to chill! A great, although expensive, quality boutique. Certainly a great place to visit.

Nice garden but nothing special. If you like plants or you are an expert in botanics.....well this is the right place, otherwise enjoy the architecture and the beautiful color you can find inside this well maintained jardin.
Pretty!. It was a nice experience,the nature is lovely,pretty flowers,beautiful garden, worth seeing if you have the time, and if you are into that sort of thing!

a haven in madness. 15 min walk from shops in new town. Well worth trip. After a walk through the hectic streets of Marrakesh, this is a welcome haven of peace and tranquility. Not huge but so well done. The museum was also well worth the visit.

If you love cacti and color this is the perfect place to relax. As a cactus fan this was a must see for me, the garden is beautif and intertwined with many a winding path all connecting to each other, the (what was) the main house is a quaint little building in bright yellow and bright cobalt blue absolutely stunning in its own right against the cacti garden! They have a great little cafe where you could enjoy a freshlu squeezed lemonade or a coffe and a tasty looking menu to boot! If you enjoy a beautiful sight come and visit this place you barely recognize the rest of the tourists there, and if you do you cant help but smile!
Lovely gardens. You can walk round the gardens in 10 minutes or meander and take an hour. There is a lovely sense of calm there and a little tea shop in the centre.
Very photogenic. Smaller that I imagined, but very photogenic tourist trap. Glad we visited, got some great shots. Did not enter the Berber museum on site which was an extra 25MAD
Beautiful place.. I enjoyed visiting the beautiful gardens and seeing the home of Yves Saint Lauren however the museum inside felt a little rushed.

Oasis of Tranquility. Lovely peaceful gardens, beautifully laid out and well worth wandering around for a short while to enjoy the peace & quiet. Berber Museum also interesting with some stunning phographic images.Around an hour is most you will need - well worth it
Majorelle or Yves St. Laurent Gardens. A wonderful garden, full of different kinds of Cacti, plus a museum and a small cafe that gave us free bottled water with our coffees!

Nice, but not worth the money. It costs 5 Euro to get in, which in my opinon is alot considering that it costs anoter 2,5 euro to get in to the Yves Saint Laurent Museum. The garden and the house is beautiful.
Gorgeously Blue. Worth walking around but don't expect a beautiful garden unless you are a lover of cacti. Interesting museum to visit there.
Great day out. Gorgeous gardens - would highly recommend visiting! A very tranquil and enjoyable day out away from the lively chaos of Marrakech.
Fantastic garden don't miss. The only problem is the number of visitors and we went in February! otherwise what a gem! well laid out, interesting history nice cafe, expensive shop.
Tranquil oasis in Marrakech. Good contrast between colours of plants and majorelle blue buildings. Berber Museum worth a visit, also the cafe.

Beautiful but pricey. A really nice place to visit and if you are tourist you will be told about this at a your hotel or Riad. Worth the visit, it was pretty quiet when we got there. I can imagine it would not be the case during the high season! Quite expensive for what is essentially a small walled garden but it is well maintained and it has a great selection of plants on show. Go and enjoy the peacefulness of the gardens before venturing back out into the madness!
Fabulous garden. This is a well-maintained and beautifully landscaped garden, worthy of the Yves Saint Laurent connection.

Hard to think of much to say!. A small garden, some nice cacti and plenty of tall bamboo... guess it must feel shady in the hot summer but nothing special when we were there. Packed with tourists of course.

Beautiful place!. Visited this garden a few days a go and it was stunning! Can spend quite a bit of time looking around and taking in all the vivid colours. Also went in the cafe then which was beautiful and has tasty food and great service.
Interesting Berber museum. The garden are nice and relaxing, but the most interesting is the Berber museum. The folk costumes, juvelry and silver told us a lot about how they lived and their history.

One of the most tranquil places I have ever been to!. That's the whole feeling this amazing place brings you - the feeling of tranquility, of everything being allright, of beauty, of love. Spend as much time as possible, have a coffee at the inner yard coffee shop, listen to the birds, look at the plants... Buy something from the little boutique... You will feel rewind!
Poor value for money. Paid 100 dirhams entrance to gardens, and could walk around it in 15 minutes max. Dissappointed at size of garden, although plants available to see were well maintained.
Peacefull place, but full of people. Jardin Majorelle is one of the best places to stay and visit during your Marrakech trip, but it is small and full of people .
A place of peace and beauty. A unique experience. As near perfect in terms of design and maintenance as one will find. A real oasis in a noisy city.

Beautiful, can be relaxing if there are no tour groups, otherwise over crowded garden for the fashion lover.. I'm in the fashion business so this was a must-see on my list. We arrived around 3:30 pm, unfortunately so did 3 large tourist groups. Still very much worth the inexpensive visit, I would recommend this beautiful home and garden. Well taken care of, the colors are very pretty, and if you get there while it's slow, bring a book and chill out on one of the many benches.
Wonderful gardens. The gardens are lovely and the museum is fantastic both in terms of content and presentation. The Yves san Laurent connection is also very interesting.

Beautiful and cosy. Its a small beautiful garden, you can quickly take a walk or you can sit and relax. It costs 50 dh pr person. We spend one our there and that is enought unless you wanna sit at the caf�.

Le rip-off.. As another poster has said - it's just a garden. An attractive garden, it's true, with great specimens of cacti and tropical plants from various corners of the globe, in a tranquil setting.But they are really playing off the history of Yves Saint Laurent owning it and living there. They charge 50 dirhams per person for entry - for comparison, most cultural sights in Marrakech are around the 10 dirham mark - and there's very little to hold your attention. A quick walk around (10-15 minutes) and you're done, with very little in the way of information about the plants etc. The house within the garden has been converted into an interesting exhibit of Berber art and clothing, but you have to pay an extra 25 dirhams for this, and I really feel it should be included in the price of entry to the garden.One tip - if you do go, head there early in the day - when we left at about 1030-1100 it was starting to get crowded and there was a long queue at the gate.
Always wanted to visit. I was not dissapointed, an oasis of calm in the bustle of the city.We particularly enjoyed the small museum and the carriage ride back to the city.
Tranquil green area with such beauty. The wonderful selection of delicate cared for trees, shrubs & plants.Such peace!Great restaurant with excellent selection of dishes.Don't misses a visit to here.
Beautiful colourful place. It is must see place in Marrakesh. I never thought cactuses can be so big and bamboo so high. Despite many visitors the place is quiet and calm.

A Garden Paradise. Really wasn't sure, if I am honest, that I wanted to go as I was interested in the more historical sights but for a few hours and not much money - an absolute must!!An idyllic little garden in the city. Thoroughly blissful.

It's a lovely garden. It's a lovely garden, but that is all it is. I went in, looked around and fifteen minutes later I was done. Don't get me wrong, if you're interested in plants then go here. If you like tranquil settings then go there early (it gets busy and you don't have the room to appreciate anything before you're being pushed forward by other tourists) but if you're like me, then don't bother going. Save 50dh and save a space for someone who would really appreciate what they're looking at.
The colors are stunning!!. The colors are stunning and inspiring, especially on a cloudy day. Do not leave Marrakech without a visit to these gardens!

Jardin majorelle. Visited in Feb 2015. Cheap to get in and a good little tea room in a charming courtyard. Plants are amazing especially the tall bamboo. Shame so many have been graffitted. Colours of pot are mostly cobalt blue which match the overalls of the gardeners. The monument to Yves Saint Lauren is a block of incongerous stone. If you don't visit the tea room you could go round in about 30 minutes. Rick London

Worth visit to have a look. Went I walking to visit this place and it easy to get lost, but lovely local moroccan people help me which direction is the front entry and when I got there, it cost 50 dirham per person to go in. When I went in, it was a beautiful garden, plants and trees from all over the world to bring here and grow big. Also there is pretty blue building and if you like go in and it is a museum, but I didn't went in cos you have to pay extra for it to go in which I think it nothing much interesting in my opinion, but maybe I am wrong. There also have cafe and I drank mist tea and eat some biscuit to relax. It's worth visit to see it for yourself.

A fabulous birthday treat!. I went here with a friend for my birthday whilst I was in Marrakech. A beautiful, peaceful and calming place to spend a couple of hours out of the madness that is Marrakech itself! A 50dh entrance fee is about £4, not bad at all. The little cafe there is slightly more expensive than other places in the city, but is really in a gorgeous setting, and still not that expensive by European standards! The crepes and the coffee are lovely. All in all, a really nice place to spend a lovely afternoon.
worth visiting. Pleasant, definitely worth seeing. Peaceful and interesting, beautiful landscaping. Interesting museum
A beatiful garden with unigue buildings.. One could walk around this place for hours , it is unigue in design, with numerous trees and fish ponds. You,ll want to go more than once.
Christmas Day 2014. Gardens very good and the museum was very interesting - think it worked because we asked questions of the guides standing around.

Just an amazing place in busy Marrakech. Very nice park with a great varity of exotic trees and plants. Colorful jar placed around in Majorelle blue, yellow and organge. Its a peasful place to hide for an hour or two in busy Marrakech. You have to pay for entrance but its absolut worth it. Dont forgot to see the monument of Yves Sait Laurent who has acentral role in the park.
Get out of the noise. The only place to go to get out of the noisy Marrakech, our of the shops and the people that always asking for money.

Surprised how beautiful the park is. I had gone there thinking it would be an average garden but surprised by how beautiful it was. I have never seen cactus plants being so tall. Really amazing ! Took some really beautiful pictures. The museum inside was nice and the entire garden is really green and peaceful. Had a great time walking around the garden clicking pictures. Definitely a must see in Marrakesh
Interesting. This place is pretty and interesting also a peaceful place.You could also buy a ticket for the museum next door. Small cafe also on sit.

nice escape from the city noise. Calm atmosphere inside, relaxing time, place surrounded by palm trees, cactus, green plants, with shady garden alcoves, aged trees and fish aquarium. Not expensive tickets. Possibility to buy a separate ticket to museum.

Not stunning. The gardens are quite small and consist mainly of cacti and palm trees with little floral colour which may have been due to the time of year..The vivid blue achitectural pieces provided some interest but apart from that there was little of note.
Amazing. Amazing place. So worth it, it is lovely. It's a paradise all the selection of colors, the nature, if I go to Marrakech again I definitely go again. Is a MUST.
a worthwhile visit. Used the city bus tour to visit - an hour is enough time for a visit although the shops and cafes around the gardens were also very good

Beautiful but small. These gardens are fantastic even if you're not a huge fan of nature/gardening. Lots of Palm trees and cacti and the air is beautiful clear and oxygenated. Yves St. Laurents memorial was definitely the highlight - it's breathtaking to look at. The gardens are quite small, I was expecting a lot bigger but nonetheless it was still a good trip.

Love that majorelle blue. An extremely beautiful garden designed by YSL. Very peaceful and relaxing, with a pricey shop selling expensive designer YSL items that reflect the culture of Morocco. A tiny, but nice museum is also present. Oddly, my wife and I were hypnotized by the blue painted items dotted around, which was the deepest and most glorious blue you can imagine.

Incredibly relaxing. Beautiful gardens. The price (50Dh) is not "cheap" if you compare to Arsat Moulay Abdaslam (which is also very nice, but free), but the beauty and harmony of the place more than make up for it. Birds chirping, away from the noise of the city, with lush green surroundings and vividly coloured buildings and pots, this place is a work of art (it is, after all, the garden of Jacques Majorelle, a painter). I could've spend the entire day there if I had had the chance. Tip: avoid the café in the garden if you can (and most cafés in the area, for that matter); it's very expensive. A 5min walk outside the garden will bring you to nice cafés for half the price.

Great place to visit depeding on length of stay in Marrakech. My wife and I had a lovely afternoon at the gardens. Since we been in Marrakech for three days, it was a welcomed respited from the hustle and bustle of the square. The gardens feature and impressive collection and palms and cacti from all over the world. My only complaint would be graffiti carvings in some of the plants should be dealt with. If you are only in Marrakech for one night I'm not sure you would find it necessary to trek out there and miss all the action inside the medina. But by the third day I would say it's a welcoming break.
A most unusual garden. The uniqueness of this garden is just what you would expect from a designer of the calibre of Yves Saint-Laurant. I won't say anymore as it would spoil the impact for you
Truely stunning garden!. Beautifully maintained and a very relaxing place. Lovely plants from all around the world. The cats section was wonderful. Loved the paint colors used on pots and walls!
Not so nice as they say. Apparently, Jardin Majorelle should be the most visited place in Marrakech. But unfortunately it's not very special. Paved walking and nothing else as some cacti.

Glad I went. I am glad I went, but it was a little disappointing in terms of size and cost. There was an amazing selection of cachti and in the heat of the summer it would be a lovely place to just sit and "chill".It was lovely to hear the bird singing - in fact if I was a bird then I would most definitely want to be there.It is very pretty and relaxing.
Not great.. It's a bit overrated. Gardens are well kept and it surrounds a small pond. Not really a lot to see there.

Pretty, but small.. I was expecting for the price and all the hype about this place that it would be a lot bigger than it actually was... Sadly that was not the case. It was definitely very pretty, that can't be denied, but it isn't something that I'd go out of my way to do again.Bring a book though and you can definitely justify spending hours here.

Nice little walk around... Very pretty to look at and can be quite relaxing. Go on a warm day though, get's quite chilly in there. Museum was an interesting discovery too. Note: learn to read in French.

Beautiful cocoon. Visited the garden at the end of January.The place is very welcoming and from the beginning you feel cuddled as in a cradle made of high bamboos. I trust this must be even better when is very hot outside.Colors are beautiful and is nice to escape the city and relax your eyes and mind here.Don't bother with the museum inside, not worth it, instead spend your money at the cafe so that you can buy some extra time in this little paradise.
Very Enjoyable. It is small and very pleasantly quiet, with beautiful cacti and bamboo. The garden consists of many plants from around the world. Well worth a visit

Beautiful peaceful oasis in an oasis. The diversity of plants and how they have been sited is extremely pleasing to the eye and the soul. The strong colours of garden furniture contrasted with the greenery of the plants. A long hike from the Medina on foot.30-30 dhms by cab.

Oasis in the middle of the city. The Jardin was recommended to us by some other tourists at a dinner the night before, so we decided to check it out. It was a quick and cheap taxi ride from the big square (50 Dinar), and we were dropped off at the front door. The entrance was 50 Dinar per adult, and free for our kids. The garden is beautiful and really makes you feel like you are somewhere else entirely. There are lots of Palm trees and cactus, and they keep everything manicured to perfection. The actual garden is not huge, but there are many different paths that you can take through, as well as a cafe and museum to see while you our there. Our family enjoyed the 90 minute detour, and would recommend it to others if the crowds get to you in the Medina.

A pleasant visit. A very compact garden filled with plants from around the world. Many of them are very large and makes the garden quite shaded in many areas. Disappointing to see people have carved their names and initials in a number of them. A very nice coffee shop to relax in. It was certainly worth the couple of hours we spent there. The taxi back to the hotel was twice the price of going -best to negotiate the price before you get in if you are going there privately.
