Nice. Tourist point, even with the weather and temperatures not that high many tourists there. Nice to be, but not a must. Maybe if it is really hot in summer and you are in need of a place to cool down.
A must. A must ... This is the place where you get inspiration and can enjoy life. Can also see YSL love posters .... .

Really beautiful and Magic.... Yves Saint-Laurent's garden in the middle of a busy city a time, a garden is a peaceful and zen environment filled with bamboos and cactus - so many species, and water reservoirs and fountains with cobalt blue color, merveilleux!

Unmissable. As an avid collector of cacti/succulents, this was a dream come true. The plants are really well cared for and displayed to their best. They are arranged artistically with beautiful backdrop of painted walls or traditional Moroccan architecture. There are even tastefully placed diagrams giving the plant names for anyone interested to identify a particular plant.
Beautiful gardens well worth a visit. Easy access a very peaceful tranquil place with beautiful pools and fountains small entrance fee of 50 dirhams

Small & blue. It is indeed a very nice garden, and it's a lovely oasis from the noise of Marrakesh.It is however quite small, so the entry fee of 60 dirhams for two students might seem high, if you aren't a botanical connoisseur...

A splendor in color!. You can not miss this beauty! The colors do not completely translate to photos as seen in person. It will take your breath away. We took a horse carriage back to the Medina, but before this, went shopping near this beautiful home in the swanky part of the new city!

Green oasis. The garden foliage and colour create fantastic forms and shapes. A photographic paradise and I would imagine a cool oasis in the heat. The Berber museum is worth visiting because it provides a lot of background information about the history, lifestyle and culture of the local people and their crafts.

Ok Garden but overpriced. Garden is just OK, and the cacti are fine, with plenty of specimens, but the trip is over in 20 minutes, and the entrance fee is overpriced. Especially, as then they want you to pay to enter the small museum once inside - Overated , and not worth the money if you are short on time.
Fridfullt. Peacefull bit not that spectacular bit relaxed and a nice atmosfär. CSN understand Whyred The man wanted to be buried here.
Stunningly beautiful gardens. Had no idea this would be quite so amazing, some incredible plants. Not as big as expected though so we did walk round the whole place in less than half an hour.

Tranquility in the heart of the City. This is a lovely place to visit. Beautiful gardens to walk round and so peaceful. Entry is 50Dh pp (about £3.50). Best way to get there is on the green route of the hop on hop off bus (which costs £10 pp for 24 hours.

An idiosyncratic garden. This garden is a wonderful retreat from the noise and bustle of Marrakech and is very different in its design - very much an individuals idea of what a garden should be. It is definitely worth a visit as is the Museum of Berber artifacts to begin to understand some of the culture.

Fab garden if in the area. Nice garden, a bit out of the way, but rather pretty anyway. If you are taking the green loop of the hop on hop off bus, plan to do it in the afternoon as the green loop doesn't start until 1pm.

Blue Blue Blue lots of it!. A short bus ride from our riad, once your there its pretty and full of colour, flowers and plants. Lots of wildlife!
Fun day out! Great little cafe, Yummy Hot Chocolate!
A must See!.
Wonderful...... This place is so stylish and the colour so cobalt that it is a must see when visiting Marrakesh.....you will not be disappointed.
Stunning. The colours here are so vibrant you just can't stop taking pictures - planting very fen Sui and so unbelievably calm in such a hectic city

Nice but much smaller than I expected. We walked from the Medina to the gardens - a bit of a trek to visit such small gardens. They are beautifully laid out and well maintained. I was surprised at how small they were though. We were lucky to visit off season when there weren't any bus loads of tourists but I'd imagine one coach load would fill the whole place up. I wouldn't go out of my way to visit the gardens though
visitasguiadasenmarrakech.com. Great place to visit, well preserved and Fati from visitasguiadasenmarrakech was excelent showing us around.

Cacti and more cacti. A very pleasant stroll through every type of cactus imaginable. Well designed and maintained. Gods vale at 50drs. The museum is well worth a look if you want to learn about Berber life, costumes, weapons etc. well worth the 25 drs extra entrance fee.

Lovely Jardin. Easy review - cost DIR50 each, the downside was it is a busy place - clearly well liked by the French. The upside it is pleasant and easy on the eye and worth spending an hour or so here and enjoying the sights and the smells of the flora. A very interesting and magical display of cacti especially the ones climbing 20 feet in the air up a palm tree.

Peaceful but probably not worth the money. Very peaceful and quiet, but I wouldnt say it is worth the 100dhs per person. Not a lot to see, only the memorial of Yves Saint Laurent and plants/trees etc along the way. Quite a small place, we probably got round in about 20/25 minutes. Would not really recommend.
Amazing Colour and Design. Worth visiting if you enjoy design and gardens. Great use of colour and an oasis in Marrakech. Easy to combine with a lunch in new area of Marrakech.

Quaint YSL Garden. Small neat garden with bright colorful pottery that offsets the plantings. I expected more vibrant colors since YSL was known for his use of primary and jewel tones. The highlights of the garden was the small Berber Museum and cactus garden, The Berber Museum have a great collection of jewelry and native costumes. If you have time in Marrakesh, Jarden Majorelle is worth visiting.

Very pleasant, but small.. The gardens are a very peaceful escape from the bustle of the souks. They're somewhat overpriced compared to other attractions, but it was worth the extra money to visit the Berber museum which is situated inside the gardens.

Escape the Madness of the Medina. After a three week tour of Morocco we were souk-ed and medina-ed out. The garden is a wonderful quiet refuge in which to spend a peaceful afternoon away from whizzing scooters and aggressive vendors. It features an impressive collection of palm and cactus varieties from around the world, and a bamboo forest. The small museum has a nice multimedia display of old Morocco by a French photographer taken in the 1930s and fantastic historical collection of all things Berber, that is worth the visit in itself. If you only do one museum in Marrakech, this should be the one. The cafe is very nice, but we thought it was somewhat over priced. We would suggest using a petit taxi to get here.
Nice garden and museum. Don't miss the Berber museum, interesting display of traditional clothes and bijouterie.The garden is a quiet oasis - if you like cactus and Palm trees

beautiful. within the charming hussle and bustle of marrakech this exquisite garden is a must see, the gardens are beautiful and the little berber museum is very interesting and also a must see! dont mind the people trying to get you to go on a horse and carriage! its not a long work!

Waste of time and money. The Gardens were about an hours walk from El Fna and it costs 50 dirham to enter, about 5 euro. And what a waste of money. The garden is small and there is only cactus and palm trees in there.
Amazing!. Fantastic garden whith many types of trees. I've loved the arrengements of cactus, special place. The garden was built where was Ives Saint Laurent house.

Don't miss this one.. This garden, though small is really beautiful and unusual. The colours and plants are really eye catching and the whole place was very peaceful and relaxing. For a 5 Dhm entrance fee each ( not 10 as stated by another reviewer) it was outstanding value. There is also a very good and cheap courtyard cafe there where we had an excellent coffee and mint tea. If there is one place in Marrakesh that I would revisit, this is it!
Beautiful Oasis. This is a must do for anyone visiting Marrakech. Beautiful gardens and amazing design, thanks to Yves Saint Laurent. It is the perfect respite from the chaos of the city.
January trip to Marrakech for 50th year celebration. If you like Cactus's this is the place for you! will take about 10 minutes to look round, don't go out of your way to visit

Don't miss it. Really nice afternoon a garden full of architectural plants bamboo cacti palms set amongst a 1930s villa. Don't expect to many flowering plants that's not what it's about.Do include the museum which is full of local artefacts, the infinity jewellery room is amazing. And do if time allows a stop for the cafe the food is excellent and well worth it.
Very beautiful. The gardens were beautiful and vibrant and I really enjoyed the Yves St Laurent gallery that is situated within the gardens.
Majorelle Gardens. This small garden is sublime - it is serene and peaceful (well in January it is). Beautifully taken care of everything looked loved and growing well. Small coffee area. A must see.
Surprising. Small but wonderfully green and beautifully laid out in the heart of the dry city.It was busy but that did not matter. Loads of photo opportunitues. Nice cafe too.

Tourist heavy but beautiful. We didn't arrive early to the gardens which meant we did run into a lot of other tourists visiting the gardens. This wasn't a huge issue but i imagine if you come to the gardens when it is quieter they are even more lovely. Still a very beautiful and peaceful place to visit and refreshingly lush looking place to explore.Stopped for a coffee at the cafe, it was alright but nothing particularly special.

Small but perfectly formed. This garden is outside the Medina and we travelled by horse-drawn carriage (make sure you barter the price down). It is more expensive than other attractions but worth it. The gardens themselves are small but interesting, but the Berber Museum is really interesting with artefacts, jewellery and costumes beautifully displayed. The café was overpriced so we didn't visit.

The famous blue. i always love to visit these gardens...many nooks and crannies amongst the lush greenery and blue buildings, which can be used for meditation or contemplation :-) the souvenir shop, although pricy is quite goid!

Nice Tranquil Place!. Lovely setting for the holiday home of the designer Yves Saint Laurent! Peaceful and Tranquil are the best words I can use to describe this Oasis just on the edges of Marrakech! 30-1hr was enough! Worth a visit!!

A very nice afternoon. It is an unmissable opportunity to see very nice gardens and a different view on Morrocan culture as you must get to the Musée Berbère.
It won't take long and you will have a very nice time.
Jardine Majorelle. A lovely tranquil place to visit, we visited the museum as well and stopped off at the cafe. All in all a nice few hours spent

ysl should have gone to specsavers too. it took jacques majorelle 40 years to design and create it, it took me 4 mins to walk out of that chaos,botany gone wrong completely DISconnected , wrong location wrong plants and you get driven there by the wrong people ( taxi drivers) = TOTAL WASTE OF TIME AND MONEY,
(admission to regents park should be 1000 pounds upwards)

Once owned by Yves St Laurent. This is a lovely place to visit - has it's own character and atmosphere, and was so peaceful and calm. The design is exquisite and the colours superb. There is a cafe where we had mint tea, and an exclusive gift shop as well.
A bit of a fashionista. I thought it was going to be a varied garden, not just grasses. I loved the colour of the garden ceramics. It was not expensive so was happy with what I saw.

Not worth 100 dirhams. You pay 100 dirhams to walk around a garden, there should be at least some mint tea being offered or something! It was beautiful but not worth that kind of money to see some painted plant pots and cactus :? :/

A very special place.. One of the undoubted highlights of Marrakesh. Mustn't be missed. The formal gardens are a work of art which is not surprising as they were designed by an artist, and improved by Yves St. Laurent. The cafe and gallery are beautfully appointed.

a quite paradise in the midle of the city. Take a tea in the inside terrace. and enjoy it.
It is small so it is better if you take your time and enjoy the
birds and the light of the sun going through the bamboo forest

Beautiful!. You cannot go to Marrakech without visiting the Jardin Majorelle!
It is very peaceful, quiet and relaxing, beautiful colors, lovely atmosphere - a must see!
The perfect place for a nice moment. If, you go early, have your breakfast there. It is such a beautiful place. Do not go too late because then the place becomes very crowded and it looses its charm.

Beauty and simplicity. The colors of the buildings and infrastructure enhance the beauty and simplicity of the plants. I found the memorial to Yves St. Laurent a little wanting. Despite that, the garden was beautiful and peaceful

place of calm. Beautiful. Well worth a visit. Its amazing to walk through the gates and not feel like you are in the bustling city of Marrakech. The men inside will be happy to take your couple/family photo for a price! Excellent value for money.
Don't miss it. You couldn't call it typically Arab at all but this is a must-see in Marrakech. It has a wonderful atmosphere.

Not Much to See. Strange place, Quite a lot of tile work and nothing I hadn't seen elsewhere. Maybe it's good for Marrakech but there are plenty of free public parks elsewhere in the world that are far better.

Jardin Majorelle. Escape the hustle and bustle of the City for a couple of hours and be transported to a tranquil botanical garden. Definitely worth the entry fee, to be surrounded such beautiful flora and vibrancy. Take in the intricate designs and view the YSL 'Love' gallery and shop. A must see!

Relaxing. Just a beautiful peaceful escape. Wonderful colours and plants. Great to spend a morning or mid afternoon in. Definitely a must in marrakech. Cute shop however can't comment on cafe or museum as didn't go.
Colour everywhere. Brilliant gardens, museum about berbers excellent, not to be missed, starlight room with mirrors very clever
AMAZING. Beautiful garden, and excellent museum on the local culture. Great respite from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech.

Best sight in Marrakech. Except for kew at the toi let and very expencive giftshop it was fantastic.
The garden colours decided the fashion of the western Word from 80 to 90.
And as an extra bonus you have the memorial of Yve saint Lorraint

Do go and visit a beautiful space in a busy city!. Highly recommended, a lovely garden filled with light and colour. The plants are fantastic and the atmosphere is peaceful and beautiful.
Make sure to visit the Berber museum which is small but really interesting. The exhibits are well presented and very informative.
The cafe is serves lunch and refreshments and the food was excellent.
Quiet spot. This garden is an oasis of peace. Bamboo and cactuses form a large part of the collection. Water in pools and fountains help maintain the feeling of solace.
Yves St Laurents Garden. A beautiful garden well worth the walk round. Planned out very thoughtfully. Reminded me in part if a mini Kew Gardens

Lovely scenery and design. Jardin Majorelle is one of the nicest tourist attractions in Marrakesh. The gardens are of a reasonable size (spend maybe ~2 hours with museum) and are something like an outdoor Kew Gardens. The gardens are exremely well designed and landscaped and the coloured pots really make the place a great place to be. I also enjoyed the museum inside the gardens. Although very small, the museum is informative, interesting and high quality. The book store and shop though are outrageously overpriced with random books costing up to £100, so this can be ignored. Note the taxi dirvers outside will try ripping you off in price: the cost from here to the medina is under 50 and to outskirt hotels ~70.

Excellent Garden. Although raining and cold on the day of our visit, this garden still kept it's charm: the colours are beautiful and it is well worth the visit. Not very big and you can walk round in 30 mins. Plants very unusual and beautifully kept. Peaceful place to visit.

Exceptional. This is a beautiful, calm place. Go on a sunny day - the light makes all the difference. The museum is small and interesting. I can imagine it gets very crowded so chose a quieter time to get the most out of it. There is a courtyard coffee shop which serves lunch and drinks.

Top place to visit in Marrakech. Try to only go on a sunny day, the blues and yellows of the buildings look stunning against the blue sky. These colours not so much seen in Marrakech - more the colours of Essaouira, but gorgeous all the same. Essential to visit the exquisite and fairly newly refurbished museum in the gardens.

tranquillity. If you're in this part of the world I highly recommend this as a visit. The garden is not huge but the planting is lovely. Massive cacti and succulents thrive in this environment. Good value.

A chance to escape. I'm not much into flowers and gardens but this was a lovely escape from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. The entrance fee is a little steep but justified given the constant attention a garden like this requires. We sat for a bit on one of the numerous benches and just talked. Rather pleasant.

the coolest place to be in Marrakech. The plants, the colour, decor and the coolness are all the things that made me want to stay there for the remainder of my trip!! Everything has been kept to a very high standard and it is a joy to look at! Definitely recommend a visit.

Short but sweet. Interesting layout and would be a nice place to chill on a hot summer afternoon. There is a charming courtyard cafe area and also a museum in the grounds which can be visited at an extra cost.

Memories of YSL throughout the Jardin. It is walking distance from the Tachfine Hotel where we were staying (off M'hd V Avenue). We paid 75 dh each to visit both the Garden and the Museum. Yevs St Laurient's (YSL) trademark vivid blue colour provided the lasting memory for our visit. Exotic plants from around the world were there. They were well looked after and user friendly for visitors with shaded corridors and seats, dotted around. The museum, on the other hand, is well worth visiting as it gave us a very in depth understanding of the Berber history and culture. Do not miss the gallery where YSL's LOVE greeting cards over the years were on display. We took pictures of the ones significant in our life, e.g. marriage, births etc. The cards actually gave an indication of changing times, colours and popular culture of the different years. Quite endearing.
Beautiful tranquil garden. Beautiful and worth seeing for the array of cacti and the tranquility and the sound of many birds . It is a oasis in the middle of the centre of Marrakech
Small gardens . Takes about 20 mins to walk around the garden in it's entirety (not big at all). Mainly cacti and bamboo. Very peaceful but overrated.

Good for 15 minutes. This garden is a great place to get away from the busy city with some really interesting species of cacti. I can also imagine it's a lovely place to seek shelter from the beaming sun, however in 12C degrees in January we wanted all the sun we could get!The gardens themselves are pretty small, two laps took us 20 minutes which we were pretty disappointed with.

Little Oasis of Calm. The gardens were perhaps not as big as we expected, but certainly they are beautifully laid out with Cactii and pools.When you need a break from the madness of Marrakech, this is a good place to go.

Unusual Creative Garden. This is a very unusual garden and definitely worth the visit. There are lots of cactii and unusual plants, with water features and gazebos. There is also a small picture gallery and shop. The cafeteria is worth a visit. A beautiful oasis in Marrakech.
Beautiful and organized amidst the surrounding chaos. Beautiful gardens, very colorful, cheap entrance fee (I believe $2 each...) and Yves Saint Laurent's cremated ashes are actually buried here.
Beautiful. Beautiful gardens,very nice place to go and to spend some time,to relax...went last weekend with friends.
Lovely experience. Small, beautiful garden in the heart of Marrakesh. Pleasant hour stroll. There is a boutique and bookstore that have interesting pieces for purchase.
Beautiful. A must see! Also go to the Berber museum which is really informative. I can see why Yves Saint Laurent lived here.
The vases!. It's a beautiful garden, indeed. But in my humble opinion, what makes it really different and special are the colorful vases. I didn't expect much from the pics I'd seen, so...

Great Garden. It is small piece of quiet and beauty inside a city. The entrance price is 50MAD , quite steep , my guess is to keep the locals. The locals have already made their mark on the bamboo carving their name in some places. there are huge range of trees from all around the world. My son was specially fascinated by the huge variety of cactus. Well worth of visit. We went a rainy day and the floor was very slippery. There were several people sweeping the water but it is still slippery, so visit on a day when it is not raining.
Good place tondiscover while you are in marrakech. The gardens are just amazing, the blue color is everywhere and the mesum is beautiful too even a little bit small

Green tranquility. A calm area of green tranquillity on the edge of the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. A beautiful garden with amazing cacti and bamboos and water features. If you are a flower lover there are not many but the green planting is stunning.
Great place to visit. Come early, definitely go to the museum. Bring some water and camera with you. Excellent gift shop. Place to visit to all nature and or fashion lovers
Lovely garden. Well worth visiting the garden and museum it is stunning the garden is a work of art in its own right highly recommended
Beautiful. Lovely feel to this garden - would liked to have seen it in full bloom. Can just imagine what it was like in Majorelle's lifetime
Very photogenic. Very photogenic. Berber Museum absolutely fascinating Café very expensive. Peaceful gardens, well worth a visit, then walk across to the Sky Bar
peaceful haven. step in to an oasis of calm with beautiful plants and tranquil location amid the hustle and bustle of the city. there is an excellent restaurant with very nice mint tea.
jardin majorelle. beautiful gardens and amazing cactus's,lovely tribute to Yves St Laurent very nice cafe for some refreshing mint tea

Disappointing. Walked up from the souk and risked life and limb to get here only to find that it is a shabby looking garden with very little to stimulate! Not sure if I missed the point but it didn't float my boat. Wasn't worth the visit but on the up side we did stumble into a great place for lunch en-route and had a carriage ride back to the square.

Lovely, if not a little small. We went straight from the Atlas Mountains to the Jardin on the last day of our time in Marrakech as it had come highly recommended. The entrance price was cheap as we both had student cards (30DH), and the garden itself was beautiful. Relatively small - we thought it would be much bigger than it was - but full of beautiful plants, exotic flowers and cacti, and the most beautiful Majorelle blue features. Would definitely recommend a visit, but be warned it is quite far outside of the city - after a long hike in the mountains we were very close to ordering a taxi back but managed to stumble back to our riad, about a 30/45 minute journey on foot.

Over Rated. The gardens are jam packed and queues are long. This defeats the idea of a relaxing garden. If anything, the gardens are more hectic than surrounding Marrakech. The plants are often transplants from the Americas, not native North African varieties. The over all feel is more New Mexico or Mexico. The small Berber museum within the park villa is the most interesting feature

Lovely and colorful gardens. The gardens are very well kept, succulent plants dominate, and the colors were gorgeous . The blue buildings fit very well with their surroundings. It's a small garden, but well worth a visit!
quiet oase in Marrakech. entrance 50dhNice way to get away from the noise in the medina of Marrakech. in walking distance from the medina.
It s a Paradise!!. For me...as Garden Designer.. and Cactus Lover ??? A paradise.. Heaven.. Just leave me there!!! MUST Visit!!

Very calm. The gardens are small but beautiful. There was something incredibly calming about them - really peaceful and we had a pleasant, relaxing stroll.I read a review that said 'not worth paying for' and I understand the comment, but it only worked out at about £3 each so I really don't think it breaks the bank! It is worth the entry fee to keep the gardens open. The cafe, however, was expensive by Moroccan standards and we chose not to eat there.We spent about 30 minutes wandering around the cactus' and I don't think you could spend much longer unless you visited the cafe.It made a pleasant change from the hustle and bustle of the shops and markets.

Rather contrived but a break from the lunacy of town. It's a strangely contrived environment. Formal gardens are contrived but meticulously planned and laid out, this one neither fits the formal nor the planned, with 'specimens' spread out on an ad hoc basis. Beautifully tended. The best part of the garden is the cactus plantation, which is impressive. Lovely shop, pricey, but top quality compared with elsewhere. The gardens are worth going to if you can't find anything else to do or you need a break from the noise, but it's a paying experience which is OK but not great, it gets quite crowded with visitors and coach trips, all jostling on the narrow paths. It's a small place so you will not be alone to enjoy the tranquility.
Beautiful. Very photogenic. Berber Museum absolutely fascinatingCafé very expensive. Peaceful gardens, well worth a visit, then walk across to the Sky Bar
Nice. Very enjoyable, a calm oasis away from the hussle and bussle, but if I am honest I have seen better gardens! Theses are pretty small!
Do not miss it.. Amazing and relaxing gardens. It's a wonderful experience walking through these very beautiful gardens.

Oasis Of chic calm. My second trip here, much more established this time, the Berber museum worth the price. Calming and cooling experience away from the madness of the city. YSL shop very chic although expensive as is the cafe.
Nice to visit. Nice place to visit and to be out of the busy medina for a while. Good access. Loved the colours and the beautiful garden very well.
Nice quiet place. The gardens were beautiful, we loved their collection of cactuses. The only down side was that it was full of people and we could not appreciate to the fullest.

Stunning gardens. Still a work of art after all these years; maybe even better than when we first saw the gardens 12 years ago. The planting (plants from deserts around the world) is beautiful and combined the use of water and the brilliant blue of the buildings makes the gardens a 'must see' in Marrakech.
Lovely. Would recommend to take both gardens and museum tour.The Berber museum was a very pleasant surprise, with many beautiful exhibits.

A remarkable balance of nature and colour.. Maybe it's the light that gives the quality to Majorelle blue. I have never seen such a vivid hue. The garden is exquisitely planted and tended and always set against the fabulous blue with accents of orange and vicious yellow painted plant pots. The shops and librarie are a joy and the cafe is an elegant and peaceful haven. It is an absolute joy and not to be missed.

More expensive than other places!. We've visited here again today after our first time 2 years ago, don't get me wrong the views really are great, but when you compare the price of entry to that of the other historical sights that are usually 10dhs or below each then its very over priced

wonderfull. A marvel. Large gardens with lots of different plants from around the world and designed when it was not so easy to access these species. The plants are divided into cactus, palms, bamboo, garden plants and water plants

Break from the madness. Me and my girlfriend decided to go have a wander round one of the recommended gardens and we chose this one. 50dh each which I didn't think was bad. When we got inside there were loads of shaded areas which were nice just to sit and relax.There was a nice looking cafe that we didn't go in. Just by the museum there was a glorious area to sit in the sun. What a lovely place to remind you that there Is peace in all the madness around this city. I would recommend but as we came away at 3 there was a queue for the kiosk so perhaps go earlier if you don't want to be mobbed.
Seriously good food. Not the cheapest place in the Medina but one of the most beautiful with its gorgeous garden, and the food is really good.

nice for a walk. The gardens are nice to spend an hour of your time,i was expecting more to be honest. The gardens are kept very well and clean. The museum i would not recommend it, just a walk in the garden!
What a beautiful garden. This privately own garden is worth to stop by, the plants and tree are just beautiful, the colours. one of the best garden in Marrakech
Cacti!. A nice garden with a lot of cacti but not worth paying to get in. Not something I would recommend to travellers.

A must see place. A nice and must see place. Our first trip was short as we had hired a horse carriage to take us to Jardin Majorelle and the carriage was outside waiting for us to take us on city tour. We had to stand in a long line to purchase tickets and wasted half an hour. The time remaining with us to explore was less. We planned to go back again but unfortunately could not fit it again in our already planned itinerary. The place is excellent and must visit destination in Marrakech.

An oasis in the city of a different kind. This garden was recommended by a local person and we were so pleased we went there. The atmosphere was calm and the range of cacti amazing. A very photogenic place. The connection with Yves St Laurent is interesting, as he bought the Garden when it was in danger of falling into disrepair and restored it. Hence there is a monument to him in a quiet corner.We particularly liked the museum. Although small, the displays were stunning, especially the jewellery in a 'starlit ' room with mirrors, and the range of costumes worn by people in different parts of Morocco, shooing woven and embroidered materials. There's a book shop, a cafe and a shop selling beautiful examples of Moroccan crafts of high quality. Outside the garden Marrakech is such a contrast; step inside for an oasis in the city.
Nice oasis. Beautiful and peaceful gardens with good opportunities for photos. There are some lovely colours here.
Quiet time. Peace and quiet away from the centre of Marrakech with all the noise with the scooters , cars and all the people etc
Peaceful garden. Very unusual for the green fingered amongst us! Very peaceful and nice get away from the marketeers calling you.

Only for fans of the art or YSL. The garden is a collection of plants from around the world, and together they make an interesting garden. Its 100 dh to get in, but its only worthwhile for fans of YSL, otherwise its a bit far from the old town center.
Garden oasis and great museum. The garden is beautiful but the museum is the real gem. It is wonderfully out together and an excellent introduction to Berber culture.
Beautiful. I did a whirlwind tour of it on my last day, but I would definitely go back. Lovely peaceful atmosphere in the midst of a busy city.
Vibrant. Vibrant n colourful gardens. Awsome tea garden with amazing crepes. Beautiful sunset. A Photographers dream.

Nice garden, but great little museum. We went to see the gardens which are nice, but I was most impressed with the little museum they have. The museum is very well done and not too long, so kids won't get bored too quickly.

Exactly what it says in the guide books..... ......a garden with a collection of cactus from all over the world. A bamboo forest and water features where Majorelle situated his studio. Not very big. An oasis of calm 50 Dh entrance fee about £3.50 so won't break the bank. If yiu want to go in the museum its another 25 Dh. Little shop selling jewellery bags and clothing etc and a cafe. Spent about a hour there as we sat on a bench and watched the world go by.Kew gardens it isn't. Made famous by YSL.
Jardin Majorelle. Nice tranquil place to visit try getting there in the morning before the tour bussesRound trip town tour bus can drop you off there
Serenity in the city. Amazing colour and calm in a bustling city. Very enjoyable, especially if you enjoy gardens, water features etc.

total ripp off and waste of time. Extreemely basic garden, which you can find in any citi and the fact that one has to pay to enter I find it a total ripp off. Unless you are a fan of YSL then maybe can be of your benefit otherwise its an absolute ripp off and waste of time.

Majorelle Gardens. Beautiful gardens in the centre of Marrakesh. Well hidden behind a wall. Pretty and unusual. Even saw some catcus that I had never seen before. If you go with a guide you have no hastle.

Stunning gardens. Amazing gardens set on the edge of the new town. The bright colours look even brighter in the midday sun. The garden café is a small tranquil courtyard where you can sit and listen to the birds. If you want to go to the museum, get there early or you'll be queuing for a long time!

Oasis from the mayhem . We choose to go to the gardens via taxi directly from the Djemma El Fna where our Riad was located. We arrived around 10.30am and the taxi cost 40 or 50 dirhams. There is an entrance fee to the gardens which includes entrance into the Berber museum on site. When we arrived the gardens were still peaceful and quiet, which is exactly what you want in comparison to the hustle, bustle and sometimes hassle of the medina area. It is about 5 minutes in a taxi from Djemma El Fna. The gardens are not big, and I imagine in the height of summer perhaps not so peaceful either as we visited at a fairly quiet time of year just before Christmas. The colours are so vibrant and I don't think I have ever seen such an immaculately clean and orderly garden before. There are many benches to sit on and listen to the trickling of water fountains. The Berber museum on site was also an interesting diversion and the star lit room made me "wow" on entry. A lovely why to start off the day.
Well kept gardens. Serene and beautifully maintained gardens. Very expensive shop but with top quality range of goods. Nice little cafe too.
Cacti and peace. If you are looking for peace and the largest cacti then come to these perfectly manicured gardens. Reminded me of Japanese gardens.
New Year trip. Beautiful gardens but very busy and had to queue for the museum - even in January. Very expensive gift shop!
No no no. It doesn't worth your time !It's just a little garden with nothing special ! It's not even in the medina , we were really disappointed ! Use your time to do something better !

Brilliant colours. Slightly tired gardens with a memorial to Yves Saint Laurent. Extraordinary blue colour on buildings and pillars, mixed with acid yellow colour on plant pots. Plants very varied but in their winter dress, so no flowers which was a pity. Good shop.

Architectural fashioned garden. Totally unexpected experience in the y s l gardens - well laid out beautiful contrasting plants, and welcome tearoom facilities.Spent about 2 hours within the walled enclosure-best spot in Marrrakeche

Horribbly overrated. The garden is small and although pleasant, we did not find it worth the trip from the center of marrakech. It did not seem like an attraction to go out of your way to visit, but rather a way to encourage tourists to spend a little more money.

Glorious garden. An extremely pleasant way to spend an hour before the medina opens. Stunning bamboo groves, cacti and beautiful ponds and fountains. There is an art gallery of yearly YSL paintings and a cafe

Nice but not a must. We did go to this garden since it was well rated in most of the information i read. However I was not impressed. There are two things that might explain this. 1. I visited the garden on winter. 2. I live in Colombia where plants and flowers are beautifull all year long.

A lovely place to visit. The gardens are beautiful and very well looked after. It is not a huge place to visit and does not take long to visit but is definitely worth it for the price. The people of Marrakech seem very proud of these gardens and this is obvious through the care take with them.

Do not miss the phallic cacti. peaceful escape from a busy highway outside old walls. Very formal with paved paths so rather artificial but very beautiful with an interesting history and some extraordinary plants coming from 5 continents. Nice cafe and costly shop - an antidote to shopping in the souk!
Beautiful oasis. Beautiful restored gardens. Small museum although not described in English. Column memorial to Yves St Laurent. Nice place to escape the city hustle.

Colorful but crowded. The Majorelle Gardens are a little out of the way from the medina. I would recommend a taxi to get there. The grounds are beautiful and the colors of the plants create a visually stunning effect against the bright blue buildings and yellow and terracotta planters. We waited in the queue for 40 minutes to get into the Berber museum, which was crowded and poorly managed. This was unfortunate because the museum seemed beautiful with interesting historic artifacts, but it was too crowded to be able to see the exhibits. If you go, it may be worth going to the museum first (for an additional fee) then explore the gardens.
Great but crowded. The gardens are nice, but have become quite crowded. We went on to La Grand Cafe de Poste for lunch afterwards which was excellent.

bright colors and many many plants. I'm glad we went to the gardens. We did not take part in the museum, we just walked around the gardens. The price is too high for what we experienced. I believe all children below 18 years should enter free with their parents/guardians. The layout of the garden is easy but it is not in a huge park. The gardens seems to be in the city limits and is very peaceful. On the day we went we took a lot of pictures. We didn't spend the day there because the garden is small if you compare it to Aburi Botanical gardens in Ghana. We loved the way the garden was clean and well kempt. You could see that the gardeners and the staff really value what they have. It is a beautiful garden and well worth a visit for those who are curious. If you have other plans you can skip it.

Well done. A great place for a morning stroll and the cafeteria serves good refreshments, The garden is attractively laid out with some interesting planting. The Berber museum is worth the wait in the queue.

Lovely, shaded gardens.. These are beautiful, shaded gardens with an array of fascinating cactus plants and trees which are shown to advantage against the layer of beige stones below. It has a very modern feel with the shop, museum and various earthenware containers painted in bold yellow and royal blue. There is also a lovely terrace where you can enjoy a welcome refreshment. Definitely worth a visit.

In fact, I was a bit disappointed.. We walked out to Jardin Majorell. Quite an experience. The garden itself is like an oasis in the busy Nouvelle Ville of Marrakech. Even though the garden is very well looked after and maintained meticulously, to my personal taste it looked rather plain. I believe to remember that there were fountains and waterways made of mosaics. Today everything is painted blue. Even flower pots are painted blue and yellow. Yes, the garden is still a magnet for tourists. However, I would rather say it is a mausoleum to Yves St. Laurent.

Can't believe i paid an entrance fee for this. This garden is often highly rated and recommended and I have little idea why. With a 50mad entry fee and an extra 25mD fee for the museum I'd expect something worth while. First, the garden is small, you could walk the one path in under 10 minutes. While walking you will see variety of cacti and a plethora of Europeans taking pictures of those cacti with their cell phones and iPads. There is only one circular path in the garden, but map is provided so you don't get lost. After you pay homage to Yves Saint-laurent, who is commemorated by a rock, you can look at the Berber museum, which is the size of small house and will require you to wait in line, which for us took over 30 minutes. Don't worry, when you leave the park any cab driver there will ad 30mad to the fair because he or she will have had to pay to park in the taxi stand.The only upside, and there reason this got 2 stars from me, is that there is a liquor store right next to the entrance.
Magical. Going to the gardens is a great way to take a break from the medina. So tranquil and beautiful. But go early as it is very popular.

This is a must see gem. Go early in the morning before the crowds show up to really see and enjoy this wonderful garden. The water feature and the many blue pots and containers are wonderfully displayed.
Most beautiful garden in Marrakech. A must see while in Marrakech! Very easy to find and central if you're staying in the new or old part of the town.
Attraction. Very peaceful and quiet place to visit. Interesting gardens and the Berber museum within was interesting also

If this wasn't Yves Saint Laurent no one would go. If you're a big fan of desert gardens you'll like it, otherwise you'll probably be disappointed. Supposed to be a haven of tranquility, might be true if it wasn't busy but even then a bit dull... Saved by the Berber museum, quite interesting, otherwise a wasted trip.

fantastic garden. very well maintained. fantastic garden. all kind of plants are fascinating. must go. inside there is a berbere museum to visit too (pay for the garden and the museum together) and a restaurant/bar for a sandwich if you are hungry
expensive but worth a visit. since I visited it in winter time it was not in blossom. The ticket is expensive compared to the other attractions in Marrakech but it s still Worth the while

Green, Lush & Prickly. We explored the Majorelle Gardens on our first full day in Marrakechk. After travel and the first experience of the Medina and Souks on our arrival day we needed a break from the hustle and bustle and thought the Gardens seemed ideal! We walked all the way from the heart of the Median which was absolutely fine with regard to distance (even with a 5 year old) albeit dusty although a bit mad traffic wise, so entering the Gardens was an amazing experience - green, lush and calm! One of the first places you see is the Bamboo grove which is very impressive. We were lucky and early and could sit on one of the benches and just look up, which was fantastic. There is a pathway through the gardens but plenty opportunity to stop, look, enjoy, take, photos ... Marrakech is overall quite hectic but this was a really tranquil and peaceful break.The colours are amazing and the Majorelle blue of the museum at the back of the Gardens creates a wonderful contrast to the green. Our little boy especially loved the cacti secion where we spent a lot of time.We walked around for more than an hour and were really sad to leave. Personally I could have happily walked around for longer, it's such a wonderful oasis!

A bit of a let down.. Waiting in the que, I expected something grand or even wow. But this was a bit of a let down. Coming from a country where most houses have beautiful big gardens, this was a bit arid, lacking any flowers. The bright pots were beautiful but not something I'd pay money to see. For a garden so highly rated in terms of places to see it was a major let down, I could do it at home.

meh.. It was pretty, but crowded. I might have liked it more if we had visited at a not-so-busy time. I just didn't feel like dealing with throngs of people while I strolled a lovely garden. Hard to take in the serenity of the place.

Unexpectedly tranquil and beautiful. Much smaller than we expected - a very leisurely stroll round the whole gardens takes less than an hour - but absolutely immaculately kept and very beautiful. A nice way to while away an afternoon. Outside the entrance are a couple of very good cafés.

This peaceful tranquil space is a delightful contrast to the frenzy of the city. I would recommend visiting this enchanting garden as well as The Berber Museum which is also located within the garden grounds. You can walk to the garden or get a taxi to drop you off. Do not ask the taxi to wait for you, as although the garden is quite small, you can easily while away 2/3 hours enjoying the garden, the Museum and having a meal or snack there.

It was absolutely beautiful. Definitely recommended. The gardens are peaceful and wonderful with plentiful opportunities for you to take pictures. There's also a nice cafe inside that serves really nice food.
Tranquility!. Beautiful gardens, ponds and wonderful collection of plants and cacti. Ralxing here is easy, -so much to see and such tranquility. Well worth the money and a MUST when in Marrakesh.
Some rest!. Nice garden and nice museum inside. There are amazing plants. The museum is so small that we had to wait 1h to enter in.
Botanical garden in memory of Yves Saint Laurent!. Many beautiful, interesting cactus. Rare huge white Bougainvillea trees and bamboo. Worth a visit to spend a relaxing hour.

Lovely Garden. Lovely garden, nice to walk around and chill out, the museum was okay, it's pretty small. Over all it was a nice day out. Good walking path and suitable for pushchairs as well, although we didn't use our in Marrakesh at all because of the roads and motorbikes were just everywhere!
Perfect. Great morning out. Everywhere was perfect and immaculate. Worth visiting as is an unusual place given its location. You could be anywhere

Lovely Garden and Colors. This was our first stop in Marrakech. It was fitting because we had a very long plane ride and it offered the relaxation and slow pace that we needed. It's a lovely garden with beautiful plants and colors. There is also a tiny museum inside. Worth a stop.

Nothing special - ok for a quick outing from the medina. They charge a fairly high price for something that is nice and clean but could easily be skipped. In the end it is just a simple garden with a few "designer" painted planters.

Beautiful Tranquility in a crazy city.. We enjoyed the garden very much, beautiful specimens of plants from all over the world, we visited in December and it was mega busy, our guide fast tracked us into the gardens, there are a lot of people milling around outside but once you're in its a haven of calm, beautifully kept and ythe blue and yellow of the buildings are a stunning sight. It didn't take long to walk around, we probably only stayed for about 30-40 minutes.You can get a horse drawn carriage to the Jewish quarter from outside the gates across the road.We enjoyed that very much.

Decent 30 minutes of calm. A garden with a designer touch well paved ways to explore it and a memorial dedicated to Yves St Laurent located on a street that bears his name There is a museum at one corner which I chose to skip. Come out and there are a couple of cafes where you can take a break before starting toe explore the newer part of Marrakech on foot

A calm retreat from the action of the Medina. This was a really nice garden, and the colour scheme was very much in my wife and I's taste. The garden whilst not a big one for flower lovers has some amazing trees and buildings and is definitely worth a detour during a trip to Marrakech.

Overpriced, crowded. Apart from the impressive bamboo canopy it's hard to see why you came. The Berber museum is pretty perfunctory but the taxi/caleche mafia outside are full on. You may do better to check the pictures on their website and then go for a walk in your local park when you get home.

A must visit!. I have wanted to visit Jardin Majorelle for a long time and it did not disappoint. I enjoyed it so much I visited twice in one week! The gardens are superb - a delightful mix of plants and vibrant colour - and very peaceful given they are in the middle of Marrakech (although we were in Morocco in early to mid December which seemed to be the low tourist season). When you buy your ticket to the gardens, make sure you also get a ticket to the Berber museum. While small, it is very impressive and well curated and on display is an amazing collection of traditional dress and jewellery. The cafe is also excellent and the beautiful items for sale at the gift shop, while pricey, are one of a kind. A lovely and peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech.

Enjoyable, but no must-do…. The Jardin Majorelle is situated in the modern part of the city. This is a short taxi ride away from the Medina (about 50 Dh). The surroundings are not very nice, not much to see or do close by.We came early in the morning and still had to queue for tickets (50 Dh gardens only, +25 Dh for the museum). The garden itself is very pretty, especially the cacti and palms. The famous “Majorelle-Blue” is rich in contrast to the skies, greenery and colored pots, so it is a nice spot for photos. Unfortunately the garden is very small and it was very crowded even early in the morning, so it was not easy to take pictures or just enjoy the scenery.All in all, I’d suggest to skip this, as it is just not interesting enough for the price and hassle. If it is included in your carriage ride, it is worth a stop, but I would not go out of my way to visit.

A lovely garden to see. Impressed by the wide range of plants especially cactus. Arrived about midday no queues to speak off even if gardens fairly busy. Well worth a trip even if you don't bother with museum as we did.

A quiet oasis in the city centre. We went one morning - more for an escape from the madness of Marrakech than the significance of the gardens.There are stunning plants growing - the variety of cacti amazed me. There is a small museum and gift shop as well as cafe there.My latte in the cafe was probably the best in Marrakech. I had a banana split - swapping the strawberry, vanilla and chocolate flavour of ice cream for 1 x pistachio and 2x almond - to much amusement :-)

Nice quick stop. We stopped by here one after noon escaping the busy medina and we not disappointed. It was only a few pounds to get into the gardens. They have an additi museum but we did not do that part. We wondered around, admired some of he plants, took a quiet seat in the sun and enjoyed the quiet.mwe were only there for about an hour at most. Good visit if you are nearby.

Eden Garden, Blue Yellow, Berbere inspiration. It is indeed a must to visit. One will understand a lot more about Yves Saint-Laurent and the influences he got in his arts. It is worth stopping and a photo shoot the small blue indigo? pavillions like in India. When you walk in the garden with all those amazing cactus and bamboo forest ou almost get the notion of how were the days passed there by YSL. The fountains and do not forget to admire the very strikingly simple hommage to YSL monument. Prepare yourself for the Museum and how you will be surprised by the Berber exhibition especially the stary ceiling. Finally do not forget to visit the store with absolutely amazing beautiful designed YSL objects... Incredible indeed to find such a cultural spot there...
gardens. think it was far too busy to enjoy these gardens - queued of an hour to go in the museum which was very good.

Definitely worth a visit!. Lovely garden, amazing cacti! Nice colour added by the different coloured plant pots along the paths, not to mention the cobalt blue building itself. Buy a ticket to the Berber Museum too! It's small, but interesting.

Garden of Earthly Delights. The grounds are pretty captivated- with a terrific range of cacti and Palm. Designed pools and walkways make this the kind of place you can sit in for a long time. The Berber museum is painted an impossible blue- incredibly beautiful- and the Berber exhibit interesting about a subject I knew nothing about.
Boring. Ok, but a lot of cactus and bamboo! Other gardens are much more worth a visit. We queued a while and paid 5€ to walk around a smallish enclosed garden of much of the same content.

Pretty gardens. A must for cactus lovers!. Gem in a unlovable area. That said, it is smaller than I imagined and very busy. Enjoyed the Berber museum but the queue can be very long. An enjoyable couple of hours nonetheless & historically significant. There is a nice looking cafe here but we didn't use it.
Nice. Is a bit small, but very beautiful. It's an homage to Yves Saint Laurent, with a nice cactus garden and other floral varieties.
Interesting. Not a day trip - an hour or 2 is adequate to wander around this garden of bamboos and cacti... there are nicer public gardens though - this was around 10 euros each
Small, garden get-away. This was a nice small, botanical garden visit, but if you haven't much time in Marrakech, you certainly wouldn't be missing much, by missing the Jardin Majorelle.

Beautiful garden. The garden itself is well worth a visit - a fresh and shady place in dusty and sunny Marrakech - and the story of the owners just adds zest to the experience. The museum is small and the exhibits are limited but it is very pretty anbd tastefully done.

Favorite place is Marrakesh!. This is a stunning, calm, beautiful place in the middle of a chaotic but equally charming city! The garden also has a nice cafe, a shop and a book store, all worth the visit.

Lovely garden. This garden is definitely worth seeing. Again, it is not a huge place and when we went it was late morning and it was very, very busy. We queued for about 10 minutes to get tickets. The garden is full of huge cacti and massive bamboo, with lovely water features (complete with fish and turtles). Recommended.

beautifully tasteful. lovely place to just take a book and relax , lots of plants and cactii and even a musuem with Berber artifacts
definitely worth a spare afternoon visit
Very pleasant tranquil garden. Well maintained garden with a lovely cafe area.Mainly cacti and bamboo garden and cafe serving good quality food.A lovely Christmas Day experience.
Beautiful but not so much. The place is smaller than you've imagined. The Berber Museum inside is interesting with objects and clothes made for Berber tribes around the country.

Medina escape. Unless you are here because you watched the movie about Yves Saint Laurent (not my case), the key attraction of this place is the break it offers from the chaos of the Medina.
Tough luck it's crowded of tourists too...
Not the most amazing garden I have seen but some can enjoy.

Not a must see destination. We were expecting something more from these gardens having heard so much about them from locals and fellow visitors. We certinly dont think they are a must see destination while in Marrakesh however they are a pleasent place to spend a 1/2 hour away from the busy city. The gardens were quite crowded when we visited and the highlight would be the many different cactuses that are to be seen. The gardens are very well kept up, so you see where your 50 dirham entrance fee goes.

A "must see", a French jewel in Marrakesh. This is a real must see in Marrakesh! Fantastic garden, with great cactuses, clean, organized with great French taste. The berber museum is small, but very interesting.Unfortunately the house of Yves Saint Laurent is not open for the public.

Signature Marrakech Style well worth it. Always make sure I come him when in Marrakech - and it never disappoints to deliver that 'wow' factor you so rarely find - this is a real slice of Marrakech style that is a true design classic

Peaceful oasis. Very pretty, and a great escape from the hustle of the Medina. It is very Western, but if you like well kept gardens this is perfect! We visited the garden around noon, it was very crowded, perhaps it is better to go early in the morning. A little bit overpriced, but well worth a visit.
Lovely gardens. The gardens weren't at all as I had imagined - it's quite a small area and was very crowded the day we went. They are beautifully kept.
Beautiful sanctuary. This was a great short trip outside of the Medina where you feel for a moment that you are no longer in a city. The gardens are tranquil and beautifully landscaped.
Very special and tranquil place. Beautiful gardens, AMAzing landscaping, peace and tranquility. And a gallery with a selection of YSLs LOVE posters
Nice-ish but overpriced. Lots of public gardens around the city are more beautiful than this collection of cactus plants for which you need to take a ~40-dirham taxi ride from almost anywhere.

Beautiful garden. Beautiful gardens, small area providing lovely escape from busy roads outside. Huge amounts of tourists going in not making for the most relaxing stroll. Still definitely worth a visit, try to go early.

Nice garden, way to many people. We were there in high season so this review might be biased by that! Entry fee is 50dhs each, but many people want to see this garden so they sell many tickets. As a result you can barely move inside the garden because its packed with tourists. Many nice plants, great layout, a little small for what you pay though.

So very well maintained!. I would recommend everyone to go there! The place is so beautifully kept! has really beautiful cacti to see and is really a knowledgeable experience. It has a beautiful cafe just inside where it is all so cozy and nice! Have a nice cup of hot chocolate and life is just perfect! :)

Colorful oasis. If you love cactus, this is for you! If you want a quiet respite from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech, this is for you! Very clean, well-kept, and peaceful (except when large groups of tourists arrive.. but they usually disappear rather quickly). Very interesting for those who appreciate Yves Saint Laurent

Nice and neat but obviously very French. This garden has none of the otherwise typical moroccan spontaneity and style. It is very western. That being said it is very pretty just don't expect a Moroccan experience apart from the plants used of course.

Stunning little gem in Marrakesh. Beautiful lush green garden away from the hustle and bustle of the city. We spent a few hours just absorbing the natural beauty and taking a relaxing lunch in the cafe which was very good too. For photo enthusiasts this is a great place for taking pics with the contrast backdrop of royal blue and canary yellow painted fountains, ceramics and buildings. Definitely one of the top things to see in Marrakesh and with a cheap entrance fee too.
Beautiful oasis. A great break from the hustle and bustle of the Medina. Green and beautiful - remember your camera. Well worth a visit.

Lovely gardens. I highly recommend these gardens. They aren't huge but very peaceful and interesting. There is also an Yves Saint Lauren memorial and small exhibition. The deep blue colour is very striking and you can buy the paint from the shop.

Magical Oasis. What a lovely tranquil garden set in the midst of the chaos and noise of Marrakesh! A paradise planted with cati from all over the world and Palm trees that make it cool and shady. There are lots of wonderful indigo blue and yellow pots and some lovely pools. There is a lovely cafe which serves delicious food. A Berber Museum and a beautiful shop full of extremely expensive gifts. The garden is a must for any visitor to Marrakesh.
An oasis within the city. Surprising garden with cacti and palm trees, beautifully kept and very tranquil. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful gardens, and make sure you eat in the restaurant!. The gardens were beautiful. The highlight was definitely visiting the restaurant - the food was wonderful; a modern take on traditional Moroccan dishes. Not to be missed.
Jardin Majorelle. This is a beautiful place, well worth a visit maybe even more than one. The peace and tranquility is overwhelming and the Berber museum a real experience.

beautiful garden. A beautiful garden with hundreds of palm trees and cactus in all kind of shapes and shades. The museum linked to it is very interesting. A great place to relax from the hassle and buzzle of the Medina.
Lovely!. Loved our visit to the garden. Beautifully kept, colorful, interesting, and memorable. Only takes 20 minutes to see.

Oasis in the heart of marrackesh. When escaping to the medina is wanted, jardin majorele, this oasis of yves saint laurent is what you need. Except of the wonderful gardens and the berber museum, which is a must, you will enjoy the style of the other visitors...most of them Are YSL fans, so the garden alley is like a catwalk.
Very well kept gardens. Oasis like gardens on the outskirts of Marrakesh.Well kept with interesting variety of plants and of course the Yves St.Laurent connection !

Busy but great value for money and beautful. I recommend the gardens for a purely beautiful experience. Down side was the queue. We waited to buy tickets for 20 minutes. Once inside there was another 40 minute queue for the museum which meant we passed on this.The cafe is perfect, hidden away and serves great authentic Local food and avoids the usual tourist menus that you'll see the fools eating from outside (there's a pizza place outside which was full of people scared to try any of the local food).

A haven of peace!. Beautiful art garden with a thousand photo opportunities. We visited off season and it was still fairly busy - I think you would want to find the quiet times during peak season as it is not a big area and too many people would spoil the effect.
Lunch in Jardin Majorelle. Well maintained gardens. Lunch was fresh, tasty, clean venue and good service. Be aware of prices quoted by the horse drawn carriages outside when you leave.
Beautiful garden!. This beautiful colourful garden is worth a visit while being in Marrakesh. It's refreshing and brings you far away from the lively city.
Amazing! Very creative!. Very pretty! Definitely a MUST go while you are in Marrakesh! The garden is also a tribute the Yves Saint Laurent.

Stunning gardens. A wonderful respite from the medina. The gardens are stunning and beautifully maintained. Café Bousafsaf serves good food in lovely setting within the gardens. A real treat for cactus lovers. The colors (majorelle blue and yellow) are amazing.

Nice way to end the day. Jardin Majorelle was the last stop in our Marrakesh day tour. There is a fee of 50dhr for entrance into the gardens, with an extra fee for the museum. We strolled around the gardens for about an hour. There are many different types of cactus which are very interesting. There is also a small cafe where you can order a drink and we saw some people ordering a meal. I think the fee is a little steep for Marrakesh standards, but you know where your money is going as the gardens are beautifully maintained.

Colourful graden - calm & cool. We weren't going to go here as I don't really do gardens on holiday but someone in the hotel said we should and we were glad we did! Its lovely and very calm - the cafe was nice as well.

Garden. Two things here. A magnificent, small garden of exotic desert plants and bamboos. I have never seen anything like it. Also a small but extremely interesting museum of Berber life and artefacts.

Very Nice but Doesn't Require Much Time. The gardens are very well maintained and it is wonderful to see the unique property and the famous Yves Saint Laurant blue. Incredible varietals of plants and wonderful colors create an oasis in busy Marrakesh. I found that we managed to do just about all that we wanted to in roughly an hour or less so don't budget a whole day towards the gardens. Definitely a good quick excursion. Don't let cabbies rip you off like they did us!
Beautiful garden. This was a beautiful garden and an oasis of tranquility. There is also an interesting museum in the grounds.

Cactii, Flowers, Garden Beauty - a contrasting experience to the bustle of the Souks/Medinas. After most likely having some intense times tackling the busy Souks and crowded Medinas, my advice is definitely to then come to a place like this "Jardin Majorelle". This advice comes from the feeling that this place can be perceived as boring if one is not into gardens/flowers/nature but no one can deny that it offers a relaxing experience.Abundance of cactii and lily pads; there are many photo opportunities here where some pretty pictures can be added to the precious family holiday selection!Don't make this an urgent priority but more of a lovely atmosphere for a relaxing walk.

A little paradise. Absolutely a must see when in Marrakesh. The colors, plants , maintenance all world class .Only one problem too many people almost fighting to find the nice spots to take pictures . It spoiled the pleasure.Next time we come early morning to avoid the crowd.A suggestion would be to limit the number of people inside at any time.

Victim of its own success. Went here today and a couple of days ago. Both times the gardens were very crowded and it was difficult to get a good photograph. The first time we missed the Berber museum because of the queue. The custodial staff are very careful to only allow limited number of people in at a time. Great exhibition and well worth seeing. The cons are the crowds and the café staff, who seem to think they have a right to tips. We had a coffee and an orange juice (80Dhs), I paid 100 and had to ask for my change! The staff seem to think a 25% tip normal! Not in my world and not when the service was so slow.

The one Tourist place to visit. We didnt do much of the big tourist places recommended to see in Marrakech after reading reviews on trip advisor but we decided to check out Jardin Majorelle especially as I am a fashion designer, I had to see what the big deal with Yves Saint Laurent was…………………Overall verdict is that its very beautiful, the colours are amazing and it’s a nice quiet escape from the crazy hassling Marrakech surroundings………….Just be ready to do some serious photo shooting whilst you are in there as there isn’t really that much else to do except from look at the different plant, but hey what’s a holiday without pictures :)For 5 euros, its worth a visit
Ok - good for a short visit. Nice gardens, quite busy, quite a long way out (need a taxi) but worth visit if you have time, but if in a hurry its not a must see!

Pleasant but a little underwhelming. We stayed in Guelize and the Majorelle garden could be reached by walking or by the Tourist bus on its hourly outside the city tour, The layout was clean and simple but the planting arrangements lacked variety and colour changes. It was also very crowded in the afternoon we were there.

very peaceful. Everything was well laid out, quite liked the YSL shop and museum. Lots of areas to sit and contemplate. On site cafe busy but nice things to eat and drink. Worth a visit at least once.
Majorelle. A tad overrated in my opinion but a welcome break from the vibrant and noisy medina. Nothing special but nice colours.

Stunning, simply stunning. Well worth the money, the gardens while not extensive are wonderous and the museum is filled with treasures more beautiful than I have seen before and I have seen king tuts items on display in London and this museum beats that hands down

Worth a visit. Not a huge garden but beautifully laid out. Amazing variety of cacti and bambo. A nice break to wander in peace from the bustle of the city. Minor point we were there in rain (!) and painted paths were like an ice rink! Berber Museum is worth a visit.

From insanity to bliss. For Moroccans this is not likely to be considered bargain entertainment but, if one appreciates Zen-like surroundings, a visit is in order.
A 20 or so minute walk from Jemaa el Fna via traditional Morokkan souks, Jardin Majorelle is a welcome respite from the craziness of Marrakech's medina.

Extravagant fee for a cactus garden. Having just been after reading the reviews, both me, my wife and a friend, were trully dissappointed. Entrance fee was 5 euro for a stroll in a cactus and bamboo garden... No flowers, nothing extra and too many people! Not worth it unless you have time to kill.

must be seen while you are in Marrakech. Garden is one of the best attraction point in Marrakech. The garden located in the heart of the new Marrakesh is an important relaxation area with its peace and quite atmosphere. The plants in the garden are arranged very professionally. There is a museum exhibits barber's people culture inside garden.It takes around 2 hours to visit the garden.See our pictures https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.10151167953361157.437643.24118791156&type=3
Not a lot to see. Very nicely landscaped but was very disappointed I had hoped there was more, it was lovely and tranquil just not much of it.

gorgeous. a must do in marrakesh. beautiful, peaceful and quiet not like anything else. more expensive than other attractions 50 dirhams but worth the money and overall still dirt cheap compared to england about £3.50!

The Blues again!. This garden stands out not so much for the foliage which is largely cacti, but for its brilliant indigo blue hues, interspersed with flower pots in yellow. Definitely worth spending half an hour here

Tranquility. Lovely tranquil gardens with coloured walls and a nice cafe. There is an entrance fee for both the gardens and the museum inside. We spent about two hours or so photographing inside and had a coffee in the cafe.

Beautiful! Dont miss it!. Go very early to enjoy it more. Absolutely beautiful.
The cafe inside is nice although over priced. The must: grab a book and go ready under the bamboos

Go every day of your trip!. Our taxi driver told us it was a waste of time to visit and we were a little apprehensive, but he was totally wrong. I wish I'd gone on my first day so that I knew I wanted to go back every single day. It's so peaceful and beautiful. Such a change from the hectic streets of Marrakech!

Nice, but small and a bit over-priced. Jardin Majorelle is a very well manicured garden. But it is small, and for what it is, a bit over-priced at 50 DH. There is a berber museum in there that costs another 20 DH. There is a nice cactus garden in there. You'll see brilliant, vivid painted pots and buildings too. Good place for photography too.

Cool and colourful. So tranquil, full of colour and very well looked after. I have never seen such beauty in a garden not to mention the vibrant colours of the buildings. The gardens are really well looked after and they have a lovely coffee shop for you to enjoy and soak up the atmosphere.
Visiting gardens and museum. Ok but not great . Berber museum more interesting though . Gardens themselves ok but you just walk around the perimeter could be made far mor interesting
Quick visit. Not a place to spend a day at. Beautiful but smaller than expected. Cost for entrance is nothing though. Still worth a visit.
Overstated place . This is a small place with average garden but various travel guide has overstated this place. We were disappointed and the entry was expensive.

Pretty but not worth the hype !. Everyone in Marakkech told us not to miss these gardens so maybe we were expecting too much. It is also quite pricey for what you pay to get in compared to the area and size of the garden. It is a small but well maintained garden with a variety of flora and fauna. Honestly thought we struggled to spend more than 30-40 mins in the garden. Maybe still worth a visit but do not have very high expectations.
Very nice...but nothing special. It is a very nice little garden, but it does not have the 'wow factor' I expected!!!! What is more is VERY expensive (50 MAD per person). Quite disappointed!!!
charming oasis. Perfect collection of plants and style ...small charming place. The location is just a little outside of the old quarters. So it is recommendable to take a cab.

Beautiful and full of colour. Wow - we arrived just as the gardens were opening and so we were the first visitors.This gave us chance to take wonderful photos - our girls aged 8 and 9 loved it and talk about it all the time.

Pretty gardens. We took beautiful pictures at the gardens. It was truly and oasis. Over 350 botanist worked together to design the grounds. There were plants from all over the world not just this region. I found the museum very interesting. Each room had an English card to translate the signs. The displays were well designed and informative. The gardens fill up early do go when they first open. Also in the winter bring jacket it's quite cool in the shade.We spent about 45 minutes in the garden and museum. We could have spent a little longer, but not much. The gardens could 50dh and the museum another 25.

Very pricey for what it is.. It's a nice garden but that's it. It's very small and expensive for what it is. If you've been to Garden like the ones in Sintra or Versalles or The Palaces of Austra, then you will be very much dissapointed with this garden. Very very tiny. Pretty, but tiny.

Pricy but pretty . An oasis of calm tranquility in a bustling city, albeit a rather long walk from the centre of town. The jewel bright colours, gorgeous flashes of indigo and saffron, mixed with varied cacti and exotic plants. Regrettably it is quite small and, at 50 MAD, rather expensive for what it is, but certainly a beautiful place to visit.
Beautiful gardens. lovely botanical gardens with interesting architecture and plants. Difficult to find on foot and taxis at the door asking silly prices.

Do not miss. This was a fantastic surprise which over delivered for both my husband and I. No mean feat given I was interested in it from a design and Architecture pov and he ( having recently completed a book on ecological restoration) is interested in gardens from a plants and nature pov. We were both blown away by its beauty ( and despite its small size and crowds) it's meditative ambience. The stunning colours were shown at their best in the clear, soft December sunlight we were lucky enough to have on our visit. It also has a lovely outdoor cafe, and a very fine gallery exhibiting YSLs Love poster designs plus a small photo and book store. The Berber museum ( reviewed seperately) is well worth a visit also. The shop has some ( as one would expect) very fine and beautifully designed pieces but is very expensive. Near the Jardins, a street of cool designery small stores have opened varying in quality - but worth a look. Overall, a chance to visit these gardens should not be missed.

Dissapointingly small . Will always try and go to a botanical garden in a city. We decided to get out of the old city to get some peace away from the hassle and filth of the souks. The gardens are only a few acres and are certainly well maintained and have a nice selection of cacti. Unfortunately most of the plants are unlabelled and unlike scientific gardens, there is no recognition of a particular geographical biosphere. There are plants from various continents planted together. I found Marrakech totally uninspiring and this was undoubtedly the best part of it. It's a shame it's so small. Mo

Must visit!. That blue is unforgettable! I saw a photo of this place long before I knew where it was located and I knew I had to go. I dragged along the group I was with, insisting they needed to see it, and everyone was glad we came. Everyone who visits Marrakech needs a photo here in front of these insanely blue walls. Please go! You'll never forget it.
Beautiful quiet gardens. Its beautiful bright and colourful and its breathtaking plants that reach high in the sky. Great shops on site and its cool to get out of the sun.

Beautiful Gardens Outside the Medina. Took a horse carriage to get to these Gardens outside the Medina. The ride was as much fun as the destination. Beautiful manicured gardens with local plants and flowers beautifully arranged. A must see and they have a cafe if you are in need of refreshment.

Verry peacefull place. I went in Marakesch on friday and i visited jardine de majorelle and i could say the weather was great and the garden was really beautifull and if you go to Marakesch you should spend 50 dirham (£3,3) coz is not that expensive and really deserve it and after you could walk up to Medina (for me that wasn't a long walk)
Excellent,. The muse Berber was wonderful in the gardenSetting. The blue color of the architecture was incrediblespirituality.
Pretty Oasis. Lovely way to spend a couple of hours. Beautiful gardens. Bit pricey for the experience though as there is not a huge amount to see/do.

Far away and not cheap. The garden was a very long walk from the old city - we just happened to stumble upon it. It was 50 for entrance. Inside was nice, quiet, and lush. The garden was well kept. There were quite a few difference plants. If you like gardens, check it out. If you could care less, save your money,
Beautiful garden and great Berber Museum. Pay the extra amount for the Berber Museum, it totally worth it. This is an activity which can be left for any day, especially a lazy day.

Very pretty & good value. The gardens themselves are pretty and peaceful and a pleasure to take a slow stroll around. My highlight was the Berber anthropological museum in the grounds of the Jardin - it's set out beautifully and the information in each section is detailed and available in a wide variety of languages.
A oasis in the middle of Marrakech. This place is really enchanting with plants from the world over. It's laid out with paths so nothing is damaged

Nice cactus garden with bamboos. It was a little difficult to find the entrance, we had to walk around walls, because we had not the navigator with us. The entrance fee was much higher compared with other museums in the town.
One of top ten. Seen and done it can't figure why this is special unless you are into Yves St Laurent just a garden full of cactii Berber museum was more interesting
Magnificent . U should visit the garden it will take around three hours tour nice place with a lot if collections of different types of plants and memorial and museum for yve Saint Laurent

Beautiful and peaceful. Intense colors and peace from the noise and crowds of the medina, we really enjoyed this place. The plant diversity is really amazing. Entrance was 50 dirham (around €5) plus 25 dirham for the museum; but for students the entrance to the garden only was 30 dirham.It´s a little bit far from the medina, we walked for around 45 minutes, you can also take a petit taxi, they told us to pay no more than 40 dirham.

The colours of Morocco. Let's face it. That's what European tourists come for to Morocco - the breathtaking architecture, beautifuly carved doors and colours. The blue of walls, the red and rusty orange of the stone. All that - in miniature - you'll get in Jardin Majorelle. Not far from the main market (walking distance), nice and relaxing atmosphere and a wee Yves Saint Laurent drawings exhibition. Worth to see, especially if you're tired of the loudness of the Medina.
