Unusual garden. A very different garden with a lot of colors and nice plants. It's well worth a visit and not far from the old town if you like to take a walk.

Stunning Oasis Away From The Crazy Medina. We opted to walk from our Riad to Le Jardin Majorelle which took around 30mins from Riad Chi Chi. We decided the get there early to beat the grounds and although it was busy we had parts of the beautiful gardens to ourselves at times. It's incredible how peaceful the gardens are despite their location in the middle of a city. There is an amazing cactus section of the garden and I loved the Colbalt Blue Building which houses the gift and book shops. One a side note the gift shop is super expensive! I think it trades of YSL's name but I certainly wouldn't pay the prices they were asking for jewellery and scarfs. We're talking hundreds and sometimes thousand of pounds which for me is ridiculous. A great way to spend your morning on the whole!

Stunning gardens, quiant cafe!. The gardens are beautiful! YSL did a great job transforming the grounds. The cafe is a small oasis at the end of your journey. Stop in for some traditional mint tea or enjoy a pleasant lunch!

Worth the walk. Many "guides" will offer to take you around the city (for free with the expectation of payment later). They will also tell you the gardens are too far to walk. If you are healthy and want some exercise, then walk. We loved this small jewel of a garden and found it a welcome respite from the hustle and bustle of downtown.

Peaceful but Pricey. The moment you step in you leave the loud streets behind and instantly step into a beautiful and peaceful gardens. Impossible not to feel relaxed in this place, peaceful ponds and a nice stroll around looking at all the plants. When visiting in December they was doing some work which created a bit of noise, I imagine during summer this wouldn't be a problem. The cafe was lovely with nice food, however it was fairly expensive compared to the rest of Marrakech. Definitely worth the entrance fee though.
Very mundane. Having seen various gardens in China (and this garden was full of bamboos) I thought it pretty disappointing and certainly quite small.

Immaculately maintained garden!. a lovely place to wander in the green tranquility of this special city centre garden.quite busy even in December but with the Berber Museum it was a nice contrast to other areas of the city.
Highly recommended! . Really nice, calm, care & peaceful! Another colourful&calm world few steps from the heart of Marrakech.Lots of different colours, smells and nice memorial. Worth it
Disappointed. For sure it is not worth the money you spend!!!You will find gardens like this one everywhere around the world.

An amazing oasis. This is a magical garden that offers a respite from the heat of the city. The plants are incredible and the colours of the house are a stunning contrast to the lush vegetation. The layout was much more ordered than I expected but worked well with the ponds. The museum was really interesting and helped us to appreciate the local people and their heritage much more. We enjoyed a refreshing drink in the café which, although relatively expensive, was amazing.

Bamboo, cactus and colourful paint. It's a simple garden, it was pipped as a 'must see' but we were massively underwhelmed. Perhaps it was the time of year as there was not much in the way of flowers etc just a lot of cactus and bamboo. It was however, an area of calm amongst the chaos outside. I liked the brightly coloured pots and walls.

"Must see" place.. Nice, peaceful, green place. completely different than the rest of city attraction. Composition of green and blue looks amazing. Garden isn't big, you need more or less half an hour to see everything but it's good to sit down and just look around :-)

Very nice place, but come early!. I visited the garden with a group, and we were there at 9 am when they opened. The light was excellent for taking photos of the different plants and trees, and the place was still empty.It is really a lovely place at that time of the day, you can really enjoy the atmosphere.I went in to see the museum about the Berber culture. The museum is rather small, but extremely interesting, and I think you can buy a ticket that covers both garden and museum. I would definitely recommend it as you get some informations about an important part of Moroccan culture.Only 45 minutes later, the place was starting to fill up, and I decided to leave, so my recommandation is to visit the garden, but do it as early as possible.
Luxury gardens. An oasis of calm and colourful corners. Great collection in the museum section. Unfortunately didn't enjoy the restaurant.

worth a visit. beautiful gardens and the berber museum inside is worth a visit. Would definitely recommend. Watch out for the taxi drivers outside as they will scam you. Agree a price before entering and have your hotel address at the ready as they purposely took me to the wrong hotel and charged me triple to return (they convinced me there were 2 hotels by the name of Takida garden, which isn't true).

Oasis in Marrakech. Lovely must see restored gardens . Beautiful and not to be missed whilst visiting this city . Colourful and very we'll cared for . We enjoyed this place and not expensive to enter .
You must go!. This garden is a wonderful place where you can feel peace in this very chaotic city. We loved it and had a great time there resting and drinking some tea.

really beautiful. Well worth a visit. Amazing gardens. I had previously visited in may and it is a better time as many more plants in flower. But it is a must visit anyhow whenever you can. (BTW - all the other gardens in Marrakesh are not worth visiting)

Overpriced and sparse. Disappointed - but then I guess I am comparing it to English Gardens which are so floriforous. Mainly bamboo and cacti, quite small. Cost 50Dh ( £5) I much preferred the free Cyber Park in the city, and even the gardens around the base of the main mosque were beautiful.
Expensive garden. The garden is well laid out and peaceful. However the entrance is steep compared to what you get for it.

Very nice oasis !!!. Beautiful garden. Entrance is cheap and there is a discount for children and students. The garden is large. There memorial YSL, YSL museum, shop and restaurant. In this garden there are many species of cactus and plants, which are very interesting....

a lot of money for what is was. Maybe its me I thought it was very average, as we are well travelled it takes a lot for me to think something has the WOW factor which I did not think this was it.Big queue to get in, some other tourists seemed to think it was ok.I was not impressed.I was on the other hand more impressed with the small museum especially as I am more into history.Personally I think there are better thing to see & do.
Not great. I do not understand why people rave about these gardens. It seemed a lot of the plants were dead and the amount paid was not worth the size of the place!

Beautifully kept. Co owned by former Yves Saint Laurent ,these gardens are a must to visit. For a fee of 50 Dirhams you can spend as much time as you require admiring the gardens which are imaculately.
An oasis in the city. Wonderful garden, beautifully arranged. A Berber museum on the premises. Highly recommendable. A small cafeteria serves coffee and tea.

Small but lovely. There was a large variety of cacti, apparently YSL traveled all over and brought them back to add to his collection. It's absolutely gorgeous although smaller than I expected it to be. You can also see his blue house inside the garden!

Far too expensive. It was quite misleading that you enter a garden in the middle of a city that takes no more than 10-15 minutes to walk through - and yet be charged 50 dirham each for the privilege - for what is a rather poor country. It is really not worth the money - and there are various other gardens around that are free to roam around in far less congested locations. sorry - not one for me, and i'd rather have given the money to a beggar.

Best spot in Marrakech. For me was the best spot in Marrakech.Elegant, fine, very well made with the memorial of Yves Saint Lauren.The Jardin is not very big but is a relaxed experience with several different types of plants from all over the world.

Relaxation time. This place has a great architecture, it really does not look like Morocco at all, but the atmosphere here is very peaceful makes you relax just by walking around the gardens, the ticket was a bit high. My girlfriend liked it so it was not so bad after all. No wonder why Mr Laurent liked here so much

Average garden. Everyone hyped this place up, it is pretty. very dirty on the approach to the place from the medina, and inside the garden are some cactuses and aloe Vera plants. It's nice but I would not rush back.

quite interesting place to visit. An exceptional garden in a city like Marrakech.
Very touristy but visiting 30mn poses with tea inside on a shaded terrace equipped with misters very useful in August.

Small but fantastic architecture. Clean gardens, the extent of bamboo makes you think if you are in Thailand :) nice museum, make time for coffee / lunch at the cafe, take a book and relax as not much to do just outside the gardens.If you are not into high end fashion or designers when you hear these gardens belongs to YSL, you will change your mind when you visit the room where YSL painted annual pictures to be sent as cards - that reflected the true nature of YSL.

Cacti and the French!. Before entering the gardens, be sure to eat at the cafe opposite the entrance and check out the designer shop. Great quality for both and free wifi. The gardens themselves are really interesting, pass on the painted pots and pathway. Do not miss the Berber museum however. Great reprieve from the hustle of Marrakech.

Good to relax. The gardens are really beautiful. They have a good variety of plants and flowers. But I like the calm atmosphere of this place. You can seat and relax for some hours before you go back to the crowded city.

A beautiful and tranquil garden in the middle of a noisy city. It is such a pleasure to walk around in the garden and a MUST to go into the small museum with all the tribal exhibitions and thorough explanations in many languages

Vive YSL!. When entering after experience the bustling city Marrakesh, it feels like walking into a completely different world: It is relatively silent (depending on the amount of tourists), it is very clean and perfectly maintained, it is modern and simple, but with lots of colors, it is simply the world of a, no two geniuses!

A very unique and beautiful garden. The garden can be found as the last stop (7) on the green hop on hop off bus route which runs in the afternoon currently. Or you can walk it from stop 1 of the red route. It is a lovely place with many plants and cactii, unfortunately lots of people seem to have carved their names on the Agave succulents

Great but not a huge miss if you don't have the time. The entrance was £25 I think and the garden is quite small but very beautiful. It's very relaxing. It took us only 10 minutes to visit the whole garden so it's quite small and it can disappoint people but I wasn't. I thought it was a good addition to our trip :)

Not my cup of tea. I know very little about gardens or vegetation but it seemed like it was just a lot of different kinds of cacti and palm trees. The majorelle blue house is quite nice but I would not recommend the gardens as an attraction.

An oasis of calm and tranquillity. This is a small oasis of calm and tranquillity compared to the hustle and bustle of Marrakech life. Leave yourself time to relax and enjoy the gardens as they are wonderful and the wildlife it harbours such a surprise. Don’t miss the turtles in the lily pond. And if you do have time, spend the money going into the Berber museum as it is very interesting although a little expensive compared to Government museums.

Really Lovely Formal Garden. A huge collection of cacti and other flowering plants (some against the very vivid cobalt blue backdrops) arranged very thoughtfully, which makes for an excellent meditation on aesthetics and provides myriad opportunities for picture-taking. The entry fee is expensive (by Moroccan standards), but the experience worth it. Interesting bookstore on the grounds as well as a boutique, and a restaurant that serves excellent (though overpriced) juice concoctions. Probably best to go in the morning when there are not masses of tourists, though when we went -- at noon or later -- the garden was not overly busy. Good place to spend a few hours; great way to dodge the frenzy of the medina for a while.

Oasis of Serenity in a City of Bizarreness. Quiet, tranquil and calm but small garden recued by Yves St Lauren - well worth the trek from the Medina.Also contains an excellent small museum of Berber traditional life.
A beautiful garden. The gardens are really beautiful.There is a wide variety of beautiful flowers and displays.A must visir
Oasis. These gardens are a fair walk from the medina, but are worth the effort! Red walkways contrast with the blue building and colourful pots. INteresting plant species too.

Beautifully colourful garden. Pretty, colorful garden, with different paths, a bit small, expected this is a bigger thing as so recommended everywhere as a must see. It is interestingly made, but I think mostly popular because of the famous designer.

Don't miss it. The ancient summer retreta of Yves Saint-Laurent and Pierre Berger, has become a sort of museum. I say sort of, because although there's a small yet beautiful collection of Morroccan artifacts, the "forte" of Jardin Majorelle is the Garden, specially the incredible variety of cactos. There's a shop where one can find beautiful - yet expensive - Morroccan inspired clothes.

A teriffic surprise!. A lovely place and totally different from anything else in Marrakesh. Pay the little extra and visit the small on-site museum - very interesting and the museum guide was very knowledgeable and helpful.

Unusual experience. We had lunch in the cafe, a little chilly at this time of year, but good food. The gardens are very different, not much colour, but unusual, and we negotiated a horse drawn coach to take us back to the main square.
brilliant. Have to see, an oasis in midle of town. Air to breath after medinas motocyckels. Berber museum is allso. Couleurs bleu Majorelles? Expensive, entrance 7,5o€.

Nice gardens. Much smaller than I anticipated but lovely to wander round. Landscaped areas of ponds full of lilies and flowers, paths surrounded by exotic plants and streams are quite beautiful. The small Berber museum in the gardens houses very interesting information about the culture of the Berbers, and each section of the museum has a hand-out listing details of the exhibits. The Love Gallery is full of artwork of Yves St Laurent. Each year, he would send these posters as New Year's greetings to his clients and families. In the grounds there is a memorial dedicated to him. An oasis in Marrakech, which is definitely worth a visit.

A welcome respite from the hustle and bustle. The gardens were on the top 10 to do and they did not disappoint. At 50 MAD it was the most expensive by far but really really beautiful place to spend an hour.
Overrated. Good to waste some time and money! Nothing fantastic - stick to the free gardens such as mehmoona hotel

"Amazing place in the middle of the city". Words alone cannot describe this magical garden in the middle of Marrakesh. Considering Yves Saint-Laurent lived there tells part of the story. Don't miss it!
Different. Don't be fooled by the other attractions. This one is well maintained and the Berber museum is well worth a visit.A must visit when in Marrakech.
Lovely Gardens. Lovely gardens and a good small museum. We visited in December so the gardens were probably not at their best. However a fine and peaceful place to visit.
Jardin Majorelle. The landscaping plants and ponds beautiful, shame about the weather it had been raining so we couldnt take full advantage of the gardens. It kept drizzling.
Peaceful. The colours and planting are wonderful. A very pleasant couple of hours and good photo opportunities. Nothing to dislike really.
Lovely garden. Garden is beautifully laid out. The Berber museum was a super bonus - excellent insight into the Berber culture. Lovely cafe too!

It's nice but not impressive. I guess it depends if you are a garden person. It was nice to walk around but it was PACKED with tourists. It's comparable to any garden or greenhouse you see in north america.
Nice gardens. This is top sight in Marrakech, nice gardens but not too big, worth of visit, but don't expect too much.

Stunning!. Despite a grotty wet day, and getting lost trying to find it, the gardens are gorgeous. Such an amazing collection of plants set against the vibrant pots and building. I love Majorelle Blue!! Also, the YSL Love art was very beautiful. Definitely worth a trip.
Great little oasis. Beautiful, well laid out garden, very green and varying types of plants and themes. Well worth getting a cab here. Museum is OK.

Unexpected pleasure. For me Marrakech sounds more exotic than the reality but found this garden a really pleasant way to spend an hour or so. A very formidable collection of cacti, if that is what you call lots of cactus, as well as a cool and quiet atmosphere. Fairly easy to find as opposed to anywhere in the Souk.
Lovely gardens!. Beautiful lush gardens in the heart of Marrakech , lovely water feature, tranquil stroll in peaceful surroundings. Well worth a visit but small place & can be very busy!

YSL garden. A beautiful garden with lots of interesting trees. Unfortunately we did not have time to visit the museum, which we were told was full of Berber artefacts. We just have to come back for another visit. The garden certainly is worth it. There is also a very nice cafe on the premises.

Incredible gardens and museum in Marrakech. You can spend most of a day here and have a decent lunch. Dont miss the museum, it is very well done and contains some exceptional jewelry and weavings. Slow down and spend time just relaxing amongst the large variety of plantings

Unmissable garden. Everything I expected and more ! An oasis in the middle of a busy city. Completely wonderful. it does get busy so I suggest you get there early to avoid the rush. We were recommended not to use the taxis outside the Entrance as there is a cartel.

Nice peaceful gardens. Not massive. These gardens are nice, tranquil and shaded They're well kept and lots of staff around. Terrapins and fish are amusing. Lots of cacti and large trees. Good photo ops since it wasn't busy (this was in December though)50dh each is expressive for MK and probably the palaces are as nice. They're 10dh. But when in Marrakech etc. Monument is understatedThe love galerie is ok intersting. Where's 1984 though?Museum is extra I think. We didn't do this. We had some fruit and chilled here. Yeah it's only 5 Euro and you're on holiday!
Beautiful home. It was lovely but very touristy. It's a nice garden but not moroccan at all in my opinion. It was nice to see the color palette.
Nice if you like that sort of thing. It's certainly quiet and a peaceful spot - didn't find it as beautiful as others there. More unimaginative and bland.

Beautiful gardens . It's definitely worth seeing but going to get away from the crowds, I don't think so. It's a small place and was very crowded, managed to get some nice photos but was all done in about an hour maybe less. If you like plants, gardens etc then a must visit. Difficult to find anywhere to sit as it was busy and as others have said the gift shop was very expensive.
wonderful morning. Well kept, well priced, interesting place. Would recommend a taxi to get there as a little bit hard to find entrance from the local maps!
Beautiful blue oasis. The tranquillity in contrast to the chaotic city outside; the use of the blue which takes its name from this place; the cafe and Berber museum.

One of the lushest gardens in Marrakesh. I loved this place. The plants, the bright blue and yellow against the arid backdrop. The pond and cacti. It's def a stop if you're in the city. It's very small, and can be crowded, so maybe go very early. Also the surrounding neighborhood is very upscale and has a few pretty cool shops. In this area you don't have to haggle about everything you touch, which is a relief from the Medina.
Nice oasis of calm. Nice gardens, beautifully laid out with some super planting. museum is of interest but not much of it. Nice quiet garden to escape madness of the town centre.

Beautiful garden - lovely museum. Beautiful garden, peaceful and quiet within the city. Don't miss the museum on the grounds. It was certainly worth the extra price. Gift shop appeared to be "pricey". Jardin Majorelle certainly worth a visit.

Jardin Marjorelle. We arrived at this spot by caleche (harose drawn carriage) and can recommend this form of travel! The gardens were superb and very cool and tranquil, with a very interesting museum. Well worth the trip.
Beautiful. Such a beautiful, vibrant place. Fantastic colour and plants, especially the cacti, made this a fascinating place to walk around.

Beautiful garden, overpriced boutique. Small charming garden when it is not crowded. Go early in morning or one hour before closing to avoid the bulk of the crowds and mass tourism buses that come in from outside Marrakech. Most expensive orange juice was had in the tea room and the boutique is completely overpriced but hey this is the Yves Saint Laurent gardens. A couple of cleanish WC so very handy. Go to the cafe 33 outside with the juice bar for refreshments! Lovely for outdoors within a dirty dusty modern town.

So pretty. This place is not very big and doesn't take a lot of time to get around but the colours are beautiful and it's a nice escape from the noise. The café is serene and the hot chocolate was divine!
Very pretty garten. Very pretty garten, i reccomend it.Very pretty garten, i reccomend it.Very pretty garten, i reccomend it.

Peace & Quiet. There was total peace & quiet in this beautiful & tranquil garden the trees plants & cacti are amazing, you really wouldn't know you have just come off a very busy street In Marrakech.We took a taxi ride from our hotel for 50 dirham & the driver arranged to pick us up in an hour but there is no shortage of taxis or caleche if you want to wander about.

Little Gem. Lovely gardens to spend an hour or so in .Best to arrive early morning or later in the afternoon to avoid any crowds. Entrance fee was 20 dir .So nice to see that such care has been taken to the gardens . They are mainly cacti but magnificent all the same
A beautiful tribute. It's like no other garden you've seenGo visit - it's worth it Nice and close and considered one of the best

A Feast for the Senses at Jardiniere Majorelle. I was in Marrakech for a couple of weeks and saw incredible art and architecture, and the Jardin Majorelle was one of the highlights of the trip.Not only is there incredible beauty in the range of flora, fauna and plant life, but combine that with the vivid colors and artistry of the buildings and le Jardin Majorelle is a visual feast for the senses.The Berber Museum located here is an added bonus, with its detail on the tribes, history and exquisite native costume and jewelry exhibit is truly breathtaking.Absolutely worth the visit, plan a couple of hours to restfully sit and enjoy the outside beauty on the benches or seating provided.

Botanical Garden / Museum. I always enjoy visiting a nice botanical garden. This one is very well maintained. It's not a real big place, but well worth seeing. If you have been here a few days, you will appreciate the peace and quiet. Morning is best to beat the crowds. Be sure and get the combo ticket and visit the museum. I took my time going through it and learned a lot about the Berbers.

Small but beautifully formed. . A haven from the madness of marrakech. Get there early to avoid the crowds. I went on my own to get away from the all inclusive break, just beautiful with lovely colours and planting.

Fascinating gardens. Would certainly recommend a visit. Coming in from a busy area and walking round in this area of trees and plants (especially cacti) from around the world is such an experience. The grounds themselves are very well managed.

Stunning even in the Rain!. We visited these gardens on a rainy day. The bright blue of St. Laurent's former home (now the Berber Museum) and the beautiful cacti gardens/pools were gorgeous even in the rain. I walked and photographed the gardens from every angle. There is also a lovely shop that sells quality merchandise. I purchased a pillow cover designed by St. Laurent. There is also a coffee shop, but we did not stop there as it is open air and rainy. It looks lovely though. The items in the museum are few, but first rate. It is too bad that the only thing in English was a small brochure. I enjoyed it anyway.

A Tranquil spot in the middle of a bustling city. We are not generally the sort that go to gardens but this was part of a city tour. We are glad we visited as it really was a delight with cacti and bamboo gardens, beautiful flowers and fountains.
Well worth a visit. A delightfully peacful space. Rescued by Yves St Lauren from dereliction and tended lovingly until his death, the Jardin Majorelle is an oasis of calm in this frenetic city.

A beautiful green oasis in Marrakech. A very beautiful place to visit in a very hot day. Many cactus and bamboo, and a very beautiful blue colour for the vases, It is a quiet and tranquil garden in the midle of noisy Marrakech.

Very tranquil. Lovely gardens and museum a little break from the hustle and bustle of the city.It also has a little cafe too which serves typical moroccan food.Only a short walk outside the city walls.

Nice park. Beautiful flowers and buildings in this park. We only walked around, didn't see the museum, but it was still worth the visit. If you are a student (even in your home country) bring your student card, because you'll get a discount.
Serene relaxing and well designed. Nice place to go to get away from the madness of the medina if a little expensive for the time you spend there. Particularly nice if you like cactus and bamboo!
Beautiful but small. a lovely place and a tranquil garden amongst lively Marrakech. Quite pricey entrance fee compared to the rest of Marrakech but worth a visit

Stunning blues at Majorelle. The garden is smaller than I expected. One could circle it in 10 minutes at a brisk pace. After getting over the small size, I appreciated the sense of intimacy the gardens bring, a welcome respite. The colors used by Majorelle for the accents and the planters are stunning and what makes this garden unique.

The Sun made the difference. It was grey and cloudy when we arrived so we headed into the Berber Museum. this is wonderful and the design is really worthwhile. Small but interesting and colourful collection of Berber clothing and jewlry and other artifacts. When we came out the sun was shining and the gardens and their colours took on a totally different look. Wonderful majorelle blue and yellows with fountains and those magnificient Cacti. Cafe was full and a bit shady so we headed out for lunch. Worthwhile experience for very little money. Yes, recommend a visit.

beautiful. Come here to the see wonderful scenery of flowers, cactuses and other trees and plants. great place to take great photos as everthing looked beatufil in the sun. was very relaxing and albiet very touristy, but nonethless an amazing place to visit.
Beautiful garden. beautiful shady garden with more cacti than any other place I ever visited. It was a lovely sunny day but quite hot and the shady areas were well provided with seating.

Well kept and reasonably priced . One of the more expensive places to see (75dirams for both things). Inside is a well kept garden with many water features and a small 'pond' with fish with a larger 'pond'. YSL memorial is here, which is a touching fit given the work/money he put back into this. The small museum is good to go and see how the berbers lived/worked/dressed. Probably about a 25min walk from the Medina, worth walking to, just to get to see more of Marrakech.

"Don't waste your time". After the rave reviews, we arrived with eager eyes. Alas - what an utter disappointment. ANYWHERE in marrakesh is more interesting than this place. We would've walked out had it not been for the 50 dirham we forked out at the entrance. To sum it up - Yves st. Laurent should have stuck to cosmetics
Must see in Marrakech. This is a weird and wonderful place - the gardens and the Berber museum are outstanding. Accross the street Rue 33 Majorelle is well worth a visit.

Beautiful. Jardin Majorelle is a joy to visit. We went mid morning and it wasn't particularly crowded. The use of blue and green makes it feel very cool and peaceful. It's well laid out and we were surprised at how long we stayed there, just wandering and enjoying a mint tea ( served with a small Moroccan pastry) in the courtyard café. We paid the extra to see the Berber museum and I recommend it. There is a bookshop, a shop and a display of the annual greetings designed by Yves Saint Laurent.

Cool, calm and very relaxing. After a long, hot day spent in the centre of Marrakech, I walked out to the gardens about 2 pm. The entry fee was 50MAD and an optional 25MAD for the Berber museum.I instantly felt relaxed, walking into the gardens with very cool blues and greens in the tiles and fountains. I had expected the gardens to be larger but wasn't disappointed. There was an air of peace and calm as you walk through. I spent about 2 hours there, including the museum and bookstore, which I found very professional and extremely interesting about the Berber culture. A wonderful place to escape to after the hecticness of the Marrakech square. I could have easily spent more time there, sitting/reading/relaxing and having a coffee in the cafe.I was a little disappointed that we weren't able to walk around the residence, which is now closed off.

Gardens don't come better than this.. An absolutely stunning garden with a wonderful small museum which is beautifully laid out showing jewellery, different Berber clothing and other Moroccan crafts in the original studio. We were the first visitors of the day and it was very busy when we left so I would recommend an early start particularly if you driving as parking in the avenue outside is very limited.
Jardin Majorelle. Beautiful & well kept. An escape from the heat of Marrakech. Also includes a memorial to Yves Saint Laurent as well as some of his annual "new years" cards.
Great retreat. Easy to find and a great soujorn from the hustle of the city. Worth paying for entry into the berber museum as well.

A must see.. This is a perfect garden that will inspire any genuine lover of nature. One feels a sense of being in a tropical forest in a semi desert country.
It is artistically made and maintained.

Stunningly beautiful. Beautiful gardens and tea room. I would recommend you make your own way rather than go on the excursion as they also include a horse drawn carriage ride along the roads which is not much fun.

Very average. The gardens were something we were very much looking forward to visiting however they are quite disappointing. They are very sparse and full of bamboo which we couldn't understand the use of? You also have to pay o see the small museum inside which is ridiculous when you have already paid to get into the gardens and you can walk around the gardens in 20 minutes. The staff are very eager to take photos for you but be wary they are looking for tips! I would go to some of the luxury hotels instead which have better gardens.
Beautiful gardens. Stunning gardens. Lots of great photo ops. Can skip the museum or not depending on how much you wish to learn about the Berber culture.

Something different in Marrakech. Jardin Majorelle is very well maintained. It's not very huge as you might expect, but it's worth to visit this place during the day. There are not many places to seat for a while though. Plenty tourists visit this place. Tickets 50 dh per person plus 25 dh if you want to visit berber "museum". Inside Majorelle garden there is also shop with Yves Saint Laurent stuff, but prices are extremely high (e.g. wallet 600dh, iphone case 450dh). There is also small restaurant which is also overpriced. We spent there circa 40 mins and it was enough time. I wouldn't compare this garden to "real" gardens as it's small and completely different/unique.

Visit when quiet or the peace is utterly lost. So many visitors pass through that the Jardin loses it tranquility. See also the Orientalist pantings of Majorelle - the early work seems to possess more spirit.

Ok if you are in the area. The gardens are well manicured, but once you get past the name Yves Saint Laurent are they really that special ? I think if you are in the area, they are worth a visit...even if its just to get away for a peaceful moment or two ....but I would not make a special journey.If you are a true botanist that can decipher one cacti from another or you know your Trachycarpus from your Chamaerops then this could be the place for you.For me it was a pleasant stroll for an hour at most

Great for nature lovers. Unless you like gardens or a budding arborist, then I wouldn't rate this as a priority location to visit. Having places to sit and admire the greenery might have made this better. I did prefer seeing the life of the medina and souk much more.

Shangri-La in Marrakesch. Fabulous surroundings, cool and beautifully landscaped. The café is very nice for a rest and a snack. Don't miss the Berber Museum and bookshop; be sure to purchase the combo ticket for garden/museum and hang on to the tickets as the museum is at the end of the garden.
Average place, unexciting and overpriced. Average looking garden right outside Gueliz (the new city.) Nice and peaceful, but definitely overrated and overpriced for what it really is.

A Beautiful Lush Paadise In The Centre Of The Busy City. Spent the afternoon here. What a wonderfully dense and beautiful getaway.Nestled in amongst he hustle and bustle of the city the Gaardens are a serene solitude.An abundance of sights,sounds and smells await you in this horticultural paradise. It's verdant and dense surroundings offer you a wide range of things to see and do,its a lovely getaway for everyone to enjoy. The walled cafe is an added bonus offering you a stylish sit down in it's tranquil surroundings. Add it to your list whilst yore in Marrakech. You won't want to miss it.

Good for a break, small for a park. Don´t come here expecting a park. Be prepared for a lot of people. Stay away from the restaurant. On the other hand it is green, protected from the sun, and includes a wonderful small museum on berber traditions (as well as a ridiculous memorial to Yves Saint Laurent) as well as a big selection of cactus from all over the world.
best. A good place is absolutely classic visited the Majorelle blue, beautiful place to have great pictures .the service and very well too keeper and very friendlyThen you kick her to do so

The Best Botanic Garden! magic. The perfect place for Forget any probléme .Superb botanic garden.All,Is beauty and serenity.Dont'forget the muséum.The shop with a good sélection.Special mention for the Tea room restaurant.Try the ice Céram inusual! Argan oil, fleur d'oranger .
Cool oasis. Lovely cacti and palm garden, immaculately tended. Great colours. Nice cafe for lunch. Garden much smaller than I imagined though.

DO visit this. Loved the small Berber museum inside the gardens - very well done, don't miss it! Loved the fact that the garden is small and intimate, but choose your time to visit - early morning or last thing are times when there are less coach tours! Great litle cafe too!
Worth a visit. The garden is beautifully arranged, in pretty colours, it's quite small so our visit was quick but we saw people having lunch there in the cafe which seemed nice.

November 2014. A small garden and heavily planted with high trees and bamboo, cacti and succulents. A few nice photo opportunies but need to beat the crowd and go after they have. We arrived around 0930 just after one small tour, as we left there was several large coaches outside.
Nice garden but crowded and not relaxing at all. Garden is nice. We went around 1pm and it was crowded. Very touristic. Nothing much to do around. Good to go but don't have too much expectations.

Small but Cool, calm, and oh the blue!. Entry to the garden is 50 dirham, and the berber history museum inside is 25 dirham. the plot of land was donated by Yves St. Laurent and I think it was a great decision. The garden is naturally small and contains many desert plants arranged around simple water features like fountains. There is a cool aspect to it though as it has bamboo and a few imported plantsthat surround a koi pond. In the garden, the heat and noise of the city evaporate and despite the gardens taking maybe an hour -it is well worth the calming change of pace. Do not miss the berber museum - bright blue cobalt building -and the gallery beyond. They are small but give a nice insite to the local culture (Note the museum is all in French so bring a guide book if you don't understand the panels). Worth the visit.
Lives up to expectations. Exquisite gardens with lovely café, library and gift shop. Majorelle blues and greens abound - very evocative!

A bit of tranquility amongst the chaos of the city.. The one major tip for this location is go early. We visited about lunchtime and they don't seem to put a restriction on the amount of people entering. So it was very busy. From memory it cost about £10 to enter including the additional Berber Museum. Its a garden filled with trees from around the world with a few water features thrown in for good measure.As with everywhere in Morocco ensure you have a few 1 diraham coins in your pocket to pay for the use of the toilets.There is a coffee shop, can't say if it was any good as it was far too busy for my liking.The Berber museum was very interesting especially as we had just come back from a week round tour with Explore Worldwide around Morocco and we spent a lot of time in Berber villages where life has not changed that much in the last few hundred years.Both parts are certainly worth a visit.
Exquisite garden. This beautiful garden manages to absorb the many tourists and remain an oasis of calm. Use of still and flowing water and brightly painted buildings complement the mature plantings.
Gem. Tranquil island in the city. Lovely café and a lovely couple of hours spent wandering. Don't expect a large variety, but there is a large variety of Cacti and it is beautiful.

Pretty Gardens!. Very pretty gardens. A photographers dream. I'm only giving it 4 stars though as its heaving with tourists taking photos left, right and centre (including us!). Still not to be missed!

Tranquil. Brave crossing a few busy streets if you are based in the Medina to visit these relatively small but artistically designed gardens with an interesting Berber museum.This was previously the Jardin Yves St Lauren.

Stunning tranquil location. I can't understand any reviews that don't think these gardens are stunning. I don't think we were expecting too much but I have never been amazed by any gardens as much as these. A very tranquil and relaxing place.We also had a light lunch in the cafe which was amazing.Definitely recommend visiting here and it's onlt a few £'s to get in. Amazing place.

Pleasant stroll. An oasis of calm and tranquility. Lots of bamboo and cactus plants in a small and busy garden. Despite lots of people, well worth visiting for people watching and recharging your batteries. The Berber museum worth visiting, although small. The courtyard cafe was lovely we enjoyed lunch there.
Joint top attraction along with the medina - an oasis. Stunning gardens, a must see when in Marrakech. Very beautifully done; tranquil yet vibrant. Very easy to get to from the medina

A little piece of paradise.... .... even if you're not an Yves Saint Laurent fan. A wonderful respite from the hot and dusty city. The gardens hold an amazing variety of succulents and are wonderfully maintained and staged. Have a smoothie or fresh mint tea and a snack at the cafe afterwards and enjoy the boutique with beautiful merchandise.

Interesting, but not compelling. We thought we'd be seeing plants native to Morocco. Our bad. Plants from all over the world are gathered here. It was interesting, but we've been all over the world, and we have seen most of these plants.
Relaxing. in a wonderful and well tended garden. You wil be surprised with the huge variety of cacti and a building with Moorish charm, with a hint of Art Deco, painting and a vribrant indigo.

Beautiful gardens, interesting museum. Lovely gardens located in the 'new town' area of Marrakech. Very peaceful, lots of cactus, exotic plants & water features. Interesting Berber cultural museum also worth checking out. Nice little cafe in the gardens also. I particularly liked the small YSL Love artwork gallery. Nice place to spend the afternoon after a morning shopping in the souks.
Oasis of beauty. Not to be missed for the beauty of the gardens and the architecture of the building. Well organised throughout, despite the large number of visitors

A great time-out in Marrkech. The gardens (entry 50 DH) are lovely and peaceful - a perfect time-out from busy Marrakech. I went in the late afternoon, and the gardens are several degrees cooler than the rest of Marrakech, due to the water features in the gardens. There is a cafe, if you want to enjoy the gardens in that fashion, or plenty of benches if you just want to pause and absorb it all. The Berber Museum (25 DH) and bookstore are also fabulous - very well presented.

Makes you wonder if you are in a desert country!!. I am always a slave of greenery! I love lush green, cosy and quiet places!! Reasonable entry fees into the garden, you will really be amazed at the type of plants brought in and the maintenance is remarkable! The contrast of colors and bringing in just the right combinations is very typically YSL! Quick Tip: Keep it for after a long tour day, ideal for relaxing and recouping.

Must see in Marrakech. We visited this garden on a dull, showery day in early November - not many flowers but superb planting schemes of Mediterranean plants and huge pots painted in orange, yellow and "Majorelle Blue", a rill, ponds and fountain - just gorgeous. I imagine that in the hotter months it would be a delicious oasis of cool shade. A must see for garden lovers.

Really beautiful garden, queue because it is worth the wait.. This is a really beautiful serene place, tiny but immaculately maintained.The plants are varied and unusual, the blue and yellow backgrounds set them off to great advantage.There is a calm little cafe in a quiet corner.One of the best attractions in Marrakech.

Vibrant haven. Walked all the way from the Old Medina and headed straight for the cafe upon arrival. Service from staff was 50/50. One waiter was a bit 'straighty-one-eighty' and the other offered a more friendly, enthusiastic service. Food was good, slightly 'expensive' for Morocco but the best part was their flexibility on payment - they accept card and euros. As for the garden: beautiful and interesting. Especially loved the fact that it used to be maintained by Yves Saint Laurent & his partner. The Love gallery is cute. Berber Museum is beautifully displayed and well thought-out. Great spots for photos and overall a memorable experience.

Nice garden, don't queue though!. Ok for something to do, nice garden of morrocan style. Not worth queuing for though. In a back part of marrakesh I have walked and got a taxi on an occasion, pay for a taxi £5
Yves St. Laurent's remake of Jacques Majorelle's garden. Small, intimate, mediterranean garden with giant cactus, water fountains, and tiny museum; loaded with tourists, but definitely worth seeing.
Nothing special.. Nice to visit if you fancy some peace and quiet, however, I found the horse and carriage ride to the gardens much more interesting!

Oasis of peace. Visiting these gardens of Yves Saint Laurent after a hectic day in the Medina, is the best thing to do! Take your time and relax the atmosphere between the most special cactusses and under the palm trees.
Oasis. Wonderful to take a look. Very cool and nice just to sit and relax. Not the easiest place to find if walking - certainly from new town but worth the effort. Felt safe wherever I walked.

Mmm.. It's ok?. With all the hype to visit Jardin des majorelle, I was expecting a garden oasis of colour and was expansive. When we walked in and around I suddenly saw within 10mins of a slow stroll I could see the exit sign.. But all we saw was greenery, cacti, and some flowers with small ponds.We checked out the memorial area for YSL and it was small and again not much to look at...I must say there was a public park on our way to this site that was far prettier!!!I still wonder why every local told us to visit this place... Very underwhelmed.

Peaceful garden in the midst of bustle. Liked the variety of plants, palms and cactii and enjoyed a very good mint tea and 'corns de gazelle'. The visit was spoit by a very unpleasant guard/attendant asking to see the last photo I'd taken, and then asking that I delete it - no explanation, no politeness.

Wonderful Place, Marred Only by the Crowds. These are beautiful gardens of arid-environment plants, with many water features and tall trees that give lots of good shade. Many benches too, but alas, many many people also, the reason I don't give it five stars. The Berber museum within the gardens is a must-see: a gem both in the things displayed and the way it's shown. Small numbers of carefully chosen things - not too much to look at, but shows a good sweep of Berber material culture - the tools, household objects, religious objects, clothing and best of all, the jewelry. The room with the jewelry is dazzling - all dark, with well-lit cases and a ceiling covered in tiny points of light.

A Quiet and Cool Respite in a Energetic City!. We visited the Jardin Majorelle on a warm day in November. The gardens are beautifully maintained with a wide variety of plants from around the world. We enjoyed walking the gardens, sitting in the shade, and visiting the shops. The gardens are small, so one can visit here and still have time to explore more of Marrakech. There is a cafe and a Berber museum on site to enjoy. There is fee to enter (50 dirhams) and the entrance is along the side of the garden.

Lovely tranquility despite numbers. The gardens are well worth visiting and are a manageable walk from the medina. The layout and variety of planting and design is both attractive and deceptive in a relatively small area with many visitors. Café was good too!

Beautiful!. OK - negatives first - it is more expensive than many other sites in Marrakech, and it's not huge so can feel crowded if a tour bus turns up. However, for all that it's just mind-expanding beauty is something that makes it worthwhile.

Don't bother, you aren't missing much. If you believe the rave reviews on here you are in for a huge disappointment. Yes it's a peaceful stroll but it's all looks the same, cactus and bamboo! I'd imagine on a very hot day it's a nice to escape the heat but this can no way be described as anything other than that. We saw some families with children there and honestly felt sorry for them as they must have been bored senseless, it was bad enough for us adults! The cafe looked to be the only bonus until we saw the prices and decided not to bother. I would recommend searching for something else to do or see as this place isnt worth it.

Magical and inspiring.. No trip to Marrakech could be complete without coming here. As soon as I walked in I felt I was in heaven. The colours are typical Moroccan...Blue, Orange, Green, Red, the plants and foliage are breath taking, giant cacti and palm trees, flowers in an array of colours. Nothing anyone can write would do this place justice-go and be amazed at the beauty and serenity of this oasis.

Beautiful oasis. Absolutely marvellous colours, shapes, textures, light and energy here. Soooo cool after the heat of the medina, and even though there wasn't a huge number of different plants, those that were there were perfectly matched ...good job!

Walked there from our Riad....worth the trip!. We walked there from our Riad and it took a long time but was an interesting view of the Medina walls and how the city is layed out between neighborhoods. The Gardens are beautiful and well maintained. It's a nice respite from the sun after the walk. The Berber museum is excellent. Traditional Clothing for men and women is displayed and old jewelry. And there is a great collection of art books you can read on textiles, history etc. in the bookstore. We didn't stop at the cafe but went on to have lunch at Cafe de La Poste in Gueliz. There are also some interesting Art Collective shops across the street from the Gardens. Yves exhibit of artwork is nice too.It's a nice quiet day spending time there.
Stunning oasis in the middle of the madness. Just beautiful , amazing cool tranquil oasis of beautiful plants from around the world - well worth a a visit.
Botanica exotica. Fabulous colour and form, both in the moorish architecture and the fabulous plant and cacti specimens

art and plant design garden. Beatiful gardens with cactii, artisitically designed and the use of colour is very striking. A calm oasis in the hubbub of the city, with a taxi rank outside and a great healthfood cafe on the corner outside.

Worth a visit. The gardens are beautifully kept and very tranquil. Now owned by Yves St. Laurent. There is an exhibition of some of his art work. We did not visit the museum so cannot comment on this but enjoyed our visit.

A beautiful oasis in the middle of a mad city :). we visited the gardens by cab from our hotel in the kasbah (being in Gueliz it's actually quite a hike from the old town with very little to see in between save for residential neighbourhoods, but doing the walk once, back into town was fine). Odd place as you're dropped off on a main road and the entrance is down a side street where you immediately spot other tourists. 75Dh for entry and the Berber museum - worth both. It is a beautifully maintained garden which, but for the other tourists ( though to be fair we were there in November so it wasn't unduly packed) is quiet and restful and set out lovingly: the bamboo forest is wonderful and then the other array of cacti, agave, money plants, aloe vera, tree ferns to die for and the strikingly beautiful colour of the pavilion which has been made into the museum - it's hard to miss the blue! Museum was interesting and tries, in a relatively small space, to cram a fair bit of Berber context together. The cafe in the courtyard behind the museum pavilion is lovely and calm, food choices were good, fairly priced with good service. If you go anywhere in Marrakech, go here!
Fine for a brief escape. Nice enough for a brief escape from the madness of the medina - walk amongst the cactus and long plants - but not spectacular. Quite small as a garden.
okay. 50 dirhem to enter its not worse it . If you are a cactus lover you can go and see it . I did not find it very interesting at all but my wife enjoied it.
Lovely Place To Wander. A little oasis not far from the hustle and bustle. Lots of different plant varieties. Strong design of the layout and buildings. Both garden and buildings are full of colour

Half/half but you sould enjoy everything you get. Despite it's way too expensive to get into the garden we really enjoyed the time. An impression wasn't that big but anyway I've never seen those huge plants, every kind of trees and stuff. This blue color makes everything cozy and calm also. Let's say if you don't know where to have a nice walk anymore and want to have a nice calm time not in the loud city then pay a little for that :)
poor. smal garden with an entrees fee for 50 dhm, not wort it, extra for the museum and the villa of ysl is not in sight(maybe because Pierre still uses it)

A welcome change of pace: Zen Garden-like oasis outside the medina. The Majorelle gardens are a striking and tranquil break from the noise and activity of the medina. If you're not impressed by giant cacti, palms and bamboo, or Zen Garden-type design, you possibly wouldn't make the trip up outside of the city centre, but we really enjoyed the change of pace after a morning in the souks, and were glad we went. We got a horse-drawn taxi from the Kasbah region at the south of the city up to the gate nearest the gardens, Bab Moussoufa (cost us 200 Dirhams - about £14 - although we haggled that down from 300 Dirhams each!) and walked up Boulevard Allal Al Fassi and along Avenue Yacoub el Mansour. We decided to walk back to our Riad in the Kasbah, which took about 45 minutes. Entry to the gardens was just over a fiver a head, and you could walk round the whole lot in under an hour - but we sat and took in the view, enjoyed the quiet and contemplated the evening ahead. The Yves Saint Laurent memorial was neither here nor there, but the cactus gardens and fountain area were truly beautiful and very photogenic. We arrived a bit late for the café in the gardens, but there was a place just outside the gardens (called Kaowa) that was very nice.

Interesting and Unusual Garden. An interesting and unusual garden, primarily making use of succulents mixed with strong architectural forms and colours. It is perhaps a little expensive given its relatively small size, but it is unique in my experience and thus worth a visit.
Lovely Gardens. Go early as the gardens seem to get busy and do visit the Berber Museum as well - it is so interesting and unexpected.

Calm time in this vibrant city!. These gardens are absolutely stunning!the layout, plants, colours, cleanliness, and just the total management is amazing. The Berber museum is fascinating and very well laid out, we had tea in the cafe which was nice and no more expensive than in UK. We paid 75 dirhams each for 4hrs spent in the gardens and museum, it was worth every one. We walked there from the medina to experience the walk, 40 pleasant minutes, no hassle - apart from the mad traffic once outside the medina, but the sightseeing was amazing if you like to see what is going on. We were quoted from 20 - 50 dirhams for a taxi back as we had picked up a couple of bottles of wine (hard to get hold of!) and paid 20 but did a few dirham tip, 20 being around£1.50. I've detracted, but it is all the one experience, the gardens are not to be missed on a trip to Marrakech!

Don't waste your time here. Although the gardens are beautifully it's definitely not worthy to go there. It's kind of out of the city center (which means you have to catch a taxi or one of those horse ridden wagons) on the way there and then back to the city center. That means you have to bargain for the price again.Despite this there are few corners with palms, other bushes and flowers, a Barber museum (this was the only worthy thing there) and an ugly Yves Saint-Laurent obelisk (or something like that). The admission fee was like 6-7 euro but it's not worthy the money.

Underwhelming breath of fresh air. The good: Serene, fresh air, with sunlight filtering through the bamboo and cacti, creating an atmosphere conducive to contemplation and tranquility. The bad: quite a small garden, featuring really only bamboo and cacti. The water features appear quite poorly designed and/or maintained. The underwhelming: the Yves Saint Laurent memorial - there are many signs pointing to it, if you're curious, google images would save you 50 dirhams entry. Overall, wasn't a bad visit, but I wouldn't go out of the way, especially if short on time, located away from city centre.

So pretty (in not-so-pretty surroundings). This place is well worth a visit. If walking from the medina, the area is not the nicest and quite desolate. It is about 10 minutes from the nearest medina gates. Enter this garden and you feel instantly relaxed and inspired by the colours and beauty. It is quite well-kept, and the cafe inside is worth the visit alone! (Such delicious food!)
Inspired. Although it was raining when we arrived it really didn't matter as i was blown away by the atmosphere that was created by beautiful planting (and we were loaned an umbrella by the staff!!)

Peaceful. It's a nice little jaunt out of the medina to this quiet and colourful space full of trees, shrubs and flowers. Worth a visit if you have the time and fancy a change from the souks - we took our books and sat reading on a bench for 45 minutes – very tranquil.

Beautiful enticing gardens and museum. The gardens and fountains were beautifully appointed, with Moroccan tile and design. The best part was the Berber museum which was amazing. The layout of the museum allowed you to savor each of the pieces, and the displays were expertly done. There is a rich history revealed in the museum, worth the price of admissions.

Not worth the trip. While this is a very nice garden, it is quite a way from the centre of town, and charges for admission. It could be quite tranquil, I suppose, if it wasn't thronged with tourists vying for the best spot to take their selfies. The cafe is nice, but expensive. I wouldn't recommend visiting unless you have an interest in cactus varieties.

Marvellous Majorelle. A beautiful space full of wonderful planting,water features and a magnificent cobalt blue studio,now a fantastic Berber Museum.It was very interesting to visit at opposite ends of the day and I would advise going before 10 a.m. and after 4 p.m. to see more,through fewer people. It costs 25 dirhams to see the very interesting museum and 50 drs for the garden alone. We spent two hours there the first time and a further 40 minutes the second..and could still enjoy another visit, such was the imoact of the colours and plants. This alone made our visit to Marrakech and the Atlas Mountains worthwhile. The walled garden cafe is also very pleasant and serves good light refreshments at reasonable prices

A cool oasis on a very hot day. I had heard about this garden, but was totally unprepared for its beauty. As soon as you walk through the gate, you feel the welcoming coolness. It can get very busy with tourists, but nevertheless it is possible to walk round slowly, taking in the beautiful and varied plants, shrubs and trees, together with the pond which is reminiscent of Monet. There are also lots of benches where you can just sit and rest and take it all in - an inspired design. We had some cold drinks before we left and I have to say that they were wonderfully refreshing and the service was excellent, so I am at a loss to understand why some people feel it is not good value for money.

Heaven on earth.. If you go to one place in Morocco go here. Stunning. Basically it a garden of succulents but not like any of the tiny cactus on your kitchen windows. These plants look like they've been on steroids all their lives! Simply enormous and beautiful. The famous 'Marjorelle Blue' is wonderfully surrounding and emphasising all the lovely features of the garden. The house in the middle of the garden rises like a blue monolith from the garden around it. It is accented by plants whose pots are painted in sharp lemon as a perfect foil to the blue painted walls that you feel you could dive into and never bother to return for air. Go and lose yourself in a landscape that you can't believe is real. But it is. Go and see.
Stunning garden. Great collection of cactus and tropical plants. The huge bamboo as you come in are lovely to walk under. The cafe did a very nice lunch too.

Beautiful gardens. In a city with fabulous gardens, this is still a treat. Yves Saint Laurent gathered plants from all over the world, and they are beautifully displayed. Inside the gardens is an informative museum about Berber culture, including history, jewelry, clothing, and various appointments. The gardens are an oasis of peace and quiet in a very hectic city.

Had a morning to kill, visited, still had a morning to kill!. If you like cacti and bamboo,This is the place for you,You'll sit and stroll, expand your brain,If not you'll wonder why you came,Blues, oranges, yellows, but not a flower,We walked the garden in half an hour,I kid you not, even though I jest,The berber museum is the best Yves St Laurent a french man renown,Can't design gardens like capability brown,50 dirhams, plus 25 more,So folks, found the gardens a bore.
An oasis of calm. A beatiful and tranquil oasis in this bustling city. Do take the option of visiting the Berber museum as it is well worth it

Very pleasant, but do not go out of your way to visit. This is one of the rave must do trips when in town, but we were not over impressed. By local standards 50 dirhams was a bit high and the actual area of garden not very big, when compared with others in the area, some of which are free. My wife found it a bit claustrophobic and the other factor was, no grass, to us not a real garden
superb cactus and succulent garden. Some lovey windy little paths thru the plants, the water features were very nice especially the long blue trough like feature running thru the shadowy bamboos.

Fantastic garden. What a fantastic garden! It is not big, and if you look for a lot of flowers, you are at the wrong place. But the mix of trees, plants, water and colours is great. It is clean and calm, espesially after the noise in the streets. I loved it! It costs 50 dirham, and have a cafe - did not try it.
Ok but not a wow. It was worth a look but mainly ferns, cacti and palms. Cafe quite expensive and you really do need to visit early as it's a small garden and gets packed taking away the calm.

COOL, TRANQUIL HAVEN. Beautifully laid out, immaculately kept gardens with the cobalt blue pavillions adding a unique splash of colour. The plants are exotic cacti, succulents, palms, bougainvillea and much more with waterways / pool / terrapin and a Cafe that offers superb food especially the Tajine Kefta - meaballs and egg! In season, can imagine Majorelle is bustling with tourists however there were few tourists the day of our visit which added to the calm, cool, tranquillity of this small, intimate space. The choice of shrine to Yves Saint Lauren is not as expected. Sadly the Berber museum wasn't opened however it was simply delightful to sit, relax and drink in all the beauty. Very impressive and definitely recommended.

A truly beautiful place with a great cafe nearby. Enough has been eloquently said of this place but it really is fab and worth the 50 DM per person fee for the gardens. It gave us great inspiration for our new garden. Worth the effort to go there. If you look through gates and over walls you can see where YSL lived as what we are allowed you see is but a small Portion of the real garden. Walk around the block and see the now tired pillared entrance to the real house. The neighbours on the back street have even made an effort and created nice cactus and Palm front bays. Some of the security staff will offer to take pictures of couples together for a small tip of course but they do it in just the right way, waiting respectfully without hustling. 5dm for the service should be more than enough as he does it 1 couple per two minutes or thereabouts so is on a good earner!This time of year is great to visit Marrakesh as the weather is still warm but not cold and certainly not scorching. As always ignore the taxi touts outside, walk round the corner and get a real cab back to town by the petrol station. Far cheaper. 30-40 DM back to main square.Nearby to the garden entrance is a great cafe called Kaowa which serves really nice burgers and the most enormous quiche plus good juices. Not cheap but good quality and smart service worthy of any place in Europe.. Well worth a break there. There is also a boutique shop selling nice stuff but bloody expensive. Upmarket Parisian style with prices to match. Really nice metal cactus....yes metal cactus but at eye watering prices. No haggling here as everything is priced and labelled which is nice after days of laughable prices in the Medina.

A peaceful haven in the city centre. A gem of a find & one to add to your to see list if you visit Marrakesh. The peaceful tranquillity of this garden, is a true oasis. Do yourself a favour & go visit!
Very beautiful garden. It's cheap to visit and very beautiful. It's fun with the signs that tells where in the world the different plants comes from.
Quiet and small. an ok way to spend an hour or so. Not as good as I expected, but maybe worth a look if you are in the area. Nice selection of plants, and pleasantly quiet in an otherwise crazy town!

Best Museum in Marrakech. Three cheers for the Yves St Laurent foundation for creating the most informative museum in the city. The overview of Berber life, cultures, and even jewelry was impressive and very well layed out. The museum was very interesting and each room was different. If you do not go to this museum, you will not have a good understanding of the Berber people and their culture.

Beautifully manicured gardens. This was really a neat garden with some amazing varieties of cactus plants. Since this garden is dedicated in the memory of the fashion designer YSL, it has a high number or French tourist and almost did not feel like Morocco. The entry fee of 50 dhs, I thought was a bit off a rip off especially if it is dedicated to YSL. All in all was worth a visit
OK. It is about 5 euros to get in and another 2.5 for entry into the museum. It is colorful but really you aren't missing anything if you don't go.
Calm and relaxing, small.. Great place to getaway from the excitement of the medina, but a little small and over priced. The museum inside is well worth the extra cost.
Colourful Gardens. Fantastically colourful, but not very large gardens, it was quite crowded on the day that I visited, not a lot of room to move around in.
Tasteful. Gardens were a delight but they are quite small and inevitably get very crowded. Allow about an hour and go in the afternoon if possible.
Small but interesting. Tiny garden which has lovely plants, but the best bit is the museum. Tends to get busy, so go as early as possible.

Beautiful, but small.. I really enjoyed looking around the garden. It certainly provides a beautiful and peaceful escape from the medina. Though the garden is quite small, there is plenty to see- unusual trees, plants, cacti, water features etc. I only spent about an hour here, but if you have a drink in the cafe and check out the Berber museum, then you could spend much longer.I am very glad that I went and feel that it us definitely worth a visit.

Disappointed. I went to the Jardin Majorelle expecting to be absolutely blown away given its prominence and rating as a must see sight in Marrakech, but I must say I was disappointed. Unlike the various UNESCO sites in Morocco, the Jardin Majorelle felt like a tourist trap more than anything else, commanding a higher entrance fee than other places at the door (50Dh vs 10Dh) and being staked out by high priced souvenir vendors and taxi drivers (if you want to get a cheaper fare to the Marrakech medina from the garden, walk the one block to the main street and hail a metered cab traveling away from the garden drop off). The garden itself was beautiful and enchanting, but smaller than I imagined it would be and relatively crowded with tourists for a Sunday afternoon.
A bit of peace in a hectic city!. Beautiful gardens with lovely colourful buildings. Can get a bit busy but definitely worth a visit to escape the exciting madness of the city.

Ok garden, lovely museum.. This was a nice enough garden to spend an hour in, nothing fabulous but nice. The memorial to YSL is deeply disappointing, but the gallery of his 'love' pictures is good.
The Berber Museum within the gardens is well worth a visit though, full of amazing Berber jewels and fashions.

Quite,quite beautiful!. Really luck to visit on a warm and sunny day in mid November as I guess it could get far to crowded in peak season. As it was there was room to mooch about at one's own pace. If you love bamboo this is the place to be other than the far east and you could say the same about cacti. Can't speak for the rest of the year but the November light in Marrakesh seem to compliment the different flora and fauna etc and made for me one of the most memorable memories I'll take with me from my visit to Marrakech.

Too busy. The gardens are small and there were coach loads of people arriving just before us so it was impossible to appreciate the calmness or quietness of these gardens! Choose your visit time carefully.

Really pretty, ideal escape from the chaos.. Very pretty palm trees and amazing cactus. Loved the majorelle blues and yellows of pots and buildings. We got round the gardens in 20 minutes, but so glad we made the trip.

Well worth a visit but get there early. This is quite a small garden, but it's packed with very interesting plants and trees. Also a great place to escape the hectic world of Marrakech for an hour (includes a little cafe with outdoor seating). But best to try and get there around opening time to avoid the biggest crowds (when large coach parties seem to arrive). Well worth a visit.

A peaceful and brilliant park with good bereber museum. Really enjoyed the quietness and the atmosphere of the park as well as the many plants and trees there. The berber museum was excellent, especially one room with stars in the sky was great!
Great gardens. Surprised to find so many different kinds of plants in a relatively small area. Worth a visit just to see the cacti

Back again. We have been to Marrakech three times and have been to Majorelle Gardens every time. It feels very sophisticated and cool, contrasting well to the medina. It is not huge but densely packed with lots of cacti. The cafe is very good but expensive. We tried to visit using he hopon hopoff tourist bus, but that did not work very well, as we needed more than an hour when the last bus came so negotiated a taxi back.

Nice, peaceful but small. Nice and beautiful garden with one of the most peaceful atmospheres as when you have the sensation that you're not in the noisy Marrakech.It is a small place and I would not recommend for the people who doesn't like a calm place.
If you have one place to visit in Marrakech, make it this one. The Berber museum beats any other museum we visited, hands down. The gardens and area for shopping were great.

Colourful and relaxing oasis. Lovely garden with amazing colourful buildings! I went with a group of people interested in photography, and we had an incredible choice of subjects to photograph. From amazing colours (mainly blue and yellow) to great texture of the myriad of cactuses scattered around to the multitude of people visiting. But you don't have to be interested in photography to enjoy this place! Also a stroll around the garden reveals lots of peaceful corners where to stop and chill for some time while enjoying the settings. (Unfortunately when we visited the cafe was not open as they were preparing it for the evening).A visit to theJardin Majorelle is a definite must when in Marrakech!

Cool and relaxing. A really hot afternoon in November and what a lovely cool spot in the middle of a bustling city. Not too crowded and lots of benches for sitting and admiring all the plants. Really nice cafe/restaurant for lunch which was appreciated.

Gem in the Nouveau Ville. This is a very unusual garden - not to be missed! Its art deco aesthetic is loads of fun - bright orange, yellow and cerulean compete with the greens of the many different kinds of cacti. There's a beautiful cafe where you can sit in the courtyard and gaze out through the gardens. We could have happily spent several hours just sitting in this garden (too bad we came only an hour before it shut!)
A garden of peace. A very busy place,mainly palms and cacti with not too much colour except the house which made up for the lack of colour in the garden.

Too crowded. Visited the garden on a Monday in November. It was so full of people that it was almost impossible to take any pictures or to move around on the paths. I assume the garden would be a nice oasis during the hot summer months. On a rather cold November day, we were not too impressed. Visit the really cool designer shop/cafe on rue majorelle.
Amazing. Taken there in a horse drawn carriage, it was very nice to walk through. The blue coloured buildings, stood out from the rest. Very peaceful
COOL SPOT. This garden is an oasis in central Marrakech and is a must to visit dedicated to Yves St Laurant. Full of exotic plants and an interesting museumi

Not to be missed. Lots of tourists though.. The Jardin Majorelle don't really need an introduction. It isn't a huge space but it is gorgeous and definitely a highlight of Marrakech. When we went there were quite a few tourists, and bored kids running around, but we just took it at our own pace and tried to make the most of it. Really stunning gardens here and the YSL history is of course a draw. Allow enough time for (the line) Berber Museum, which is small but really special. Also, just south and across the street (outside the Jarden and not related) there is a great cafe that is attached to an awesome shop selling new-spins on Moroccan crafts from a variety of artists. We got a lot of great gifts here, stuff you won't see in the souks.
Very nice garden. Very nice garden a little outside of town center. It is a nice treat for the hustle and bustle of the city center. A must visit when you are in Marrakech.

A hidden gem. The garden is so gorgeous and hidden away! A real surprise when you walk through the gate. I would say it's more just for looks than a garden to spend a lot of time in but really lovely to see and very well done

Amazing…. A must see when in Marrakech. Was there on a very hot afternoon and then shaded by all the greenery, bamboo and saw loads of different cacti. Mediative calming atmosphere with water features. Had a lovely egg salad and home-made lemon juice in hygienic surroundings, with quick attentive service in the cafe. Clean toilets. The Berber Museum was also very interesting. Go…..

Beautiful. This is a quiet place away from the mad Jamaa El Fna. This garden is owned by Yves Saint Laurent. The garden is full of cacti, palms, bamboos and other plants. Its a good place to take some beautiful photos. The ticket cost 50 Dirhams per person. Petit taxi cost 30 Dirhams from Jamaa El Fna.
So many varieties of cactii. On the plus side a nice little oasis in central Marrakech. Very green and lush.On the minus side - near by parking and heaving with tourists.

no trip to marrakech without a stop by Majorelle. Very beautiful garden.. come and discover the beautifule garden created by Yves St Laurent . Good place to go early afternoon as there is lots of shades and it is cooler than in the medina
Peaceful Escape. Spending a few hours in this lush garden marks a significant contrast to the intensity of Marrakech. Beautiful space and a peaceful escape.

Gardens are lovely - but the Berber Museum is superb!. The Majorelle Gardens are lovely with tons of good photo ops - great color and foliage. But the Garden's Berber Museum - a small additional entrance fee - is really excellent. Beautiful displays and information cards in each room that let you do a good self tour in your language. This is a small but seriously good museum. It's wonderful to see authentic Berber jewelry and artifacts after all the "real" items we've seen (and been offered) in the souks. The museum offers a wonderful insight into the rich diversity and creativity of the Berber culture. .And the gift shop is excellent!
beautiful oasis. quite moment out of Mad Marrakech, lovely little café area (just remember people still smoke in cafes in the this part of the world) well kept gardens

Nice gardens, informative museum. The gardens and the Berber museum are worth a trip (outside the medina). You can spend around 2 hours there. Definitely enter the museum too, it's very informative and also has English translations. The museum is 25 DIR and the gardens around 50 DIR (you get it for 30 if you have a student ID).

Too contrived for my liking. This experience is referred to in the tourist guides as the "yves Saint Laurent " gardens.They are not. Saint Laurent paid towards the maintenance/refurbishment of the same only.The gardens, pathways and actual planting looks very contrived.There is a BERBER MUSEUM-at extra cost-that is worth seeing, but overall not a great tourist attraction

Small and colourful. We visited in November, a small oasis in a large city. Its a compact garden with an amazing assortment of cacti set against the wonderful brilliant blue building as a backdrop. Lovely hot chocolate to be had in the tearooms.
Peaceful oasis. Apart from the entrance fee, which was bit steep, we really enjoyed walking through the garden of peace.

Astonishingly Beautiful Garen. This is honestly the most beautiful garden I have ever seen.The combination of trees, flowers, arbors, pools, winding paths, and huge pots painted in the most gorgeous colors, combined to create a unique and memorable experience. These are the gardens owned, renovated, and beloved by Yves St. Laurent and his partner. Just incredibly beautiful. And on the grounds of the garden is the Berber Museum - definitely worth a visit!

Must be visited. Beautifully maintained by (late)Yves St Laurent and Pierre Bergé, actual owners, the gardens created by the painter Majorelle are worth the visit. Try to come early in the morning to avoid the crowd and the heat.
A TRANQUIL GARDEN. A tranquil and interesting garden in a very busy city. Worth a visit although only took us half an hour to do the visit

A very formal garden. I had read of this garden and looked forward to seeing it. We took a horse and trap ride from the hotel, that was great. We were rather late arriving and had only 1 hour before it closed. It's rather expensive to go in, 50 D's and more if you want to go into the museum. There is a lot happening in a fairly small space. The garden is well set out with particular plants in each area and brightly coloured pots everywhere. The are ponds with water lilies . Everything is closely packed. There is the usual shop selling very expensive goods and a cafe.

Don't miss. Haggled the taxi for taking 2 people here for 40dh. We went at opening time 0800 which meant it was very quiet and empty, best time to go since it is not very big and you don't want people photo bombing your pictures. Museum was also very informative so definitely worth seeing. The English translations are on a card at the entrance of each section.
Pleasant visit. Spent an hour wandering here, calming oasis type place, lovely selection of plants.Easy enough to find and some great spots for photos
Fantastic garden and museum. Fabulous place - a highlight of Marrakesh. Don't miss the museum and plan on staying here for a couple of hours
