A visit to the Berber Museum which is extra is small but also worth visiting if only for the wonderful starry sky inside.
wonderful place not to be missed. Allow more time than you think. The garden is wonderful Thenn there is the museum, Thens there is the YLS shop So do not hurry.
Beautiful Gardens. This is a wonderful place to take pictures and see where YSL lived when he was in Marrakech. Worth the trip!
Very interesting. Well worth the time. A cool (temperature) and interesting display of the joining of art with dessert botany.

a botanical garden you can find anywhere. I was rather disappointed as this in my opinion was nothing special in comparison to other botanical gardens. And as you would expect from the YSL reference in a climate which allows a more exuberant, dense and colorful vegetation.

Oasis of calm. This is a beautiful garden in the new town of Marrakech, developed by Jacques Majorelle initially and refurbished by Yves St Laurent more recently. It is an oasis of shade and quiet (provided a tourist party hasn't just turned up en masse!) in the craziness that is Marrakech, and well worth a visit (but try and go early in the day or later in the afternoon if you can). Embrace the tranquility....

Worth of visit. Excellent garden. It is unbelievable that this place is in Marakesh - there is no noise, not so hot (you walk all the time in shade). The best place for relax. Café in there is very expensive, food is slightly above average. And "traditional hot choccolate" is poor.
Stunning garden. Beautiful, modern, an oasis in a dry desert! Very peaceful and relaxing. Interesting museum. Cafe too. Yves St Laurent's garden is a tribute to him and his ashes are buried there.

Beautiful. This is really a wonderful escape from the city, with beautiful sights, smells, colour and wonderful shade. It is mainly covered by the plants with breaks of sunlight, the glorious majorelle blue painted on pots and buildings and lovely water features. Easy to spend an hour within this oasis, and a lovely café and nice shops are also inside. Must see
Beautiful gardens. Well worth a visit - we didn't do the museum, just the gardens. Easy to walk round, nice café and well worth the walk out of the old town
A Designer's Legacy. Jardin Majorelle is lovely cover for warm Marrakech days. It is perfectly planned with accommodating attention to detail.

An oasis. The Jardin Majorelle is in the newer part of Marrakech and has a strong connection with Yves St Laurent. We enjoyed ambling around it for half an hour or so. The planting features a huge range of cacti and many sub-tropical shrubs and trees. The design is distinctive, with a lily pond and other water features, and there is much use of pastel colour but also of that wonderful lapis lazuli blue. It isn't a huge place - you could scurry round in ten minutes, but that would of course miss the point, which is to enjoy the tranquillity of a special place. Indeed, we would have stayed for longer but it was close to closing time when we left.
50dh for that.... Its too expensive and full of turists doing photos at bambu and plants that you can find anywhere. You dont need to go to morocco to see this.

a real let down. After being told this was a calm and tranquil garden - we thought we would pay a visit. To be charged 50dirham...you think, Ok - maybe a smaller Kew Gardens then?...wrong...a lovely fountain as you enter, then cacti, pam tree, cacti...and few posters by YSL housed in the smallest of rooms with only one door in out out...more cacti...a carp pond...YSL memorial (a 'roman' pillar set in gravelled square)...more cacti then you are on your way out!!takes all of 15-20 mins to walk around the pre-set paths - a couple of reflection benches - cacti with tourists names carved in them is a little bit of a liberty for the price.Shame - was really looking forward to quality designer plant architecture - or maybe I am missing something? it was however cool in there...so maybe that's was you pay for...natural air conditioning!

Stunning, tranquil garden. We visited here on recommendation of friends and were not disappointed. Beautiful garden, stunning colours provided by painted pots, walls and lovely ceramic tiles. All the backdrop to cacti and palms. Inexpensive admission. We didn't visit the museum or cafe so can't comment on these. Well worth a visit

Beautiful. Amazing gardens, definitely worth a visit for anyone staying in Marrakech. Also features a lovely museum about Yves Saint Laurent, whose ashes are buried within the garden.A tranquil oasis outside the busy capital of Morocco.

An oasis of peace and serenity. We were advised to go early as it gets very busy but as we're were there at the beginning of September ( not high season ) it wasn't too busy and we arrived around 1pm. A beautiful place well worth visiting; renovated by Yves St. Laurent who has a memorial in the gardens. Some unusual plants and a picturesque lily pond and welcome shade. We bought the combined ticket for the museum as well which is situated in the gardens and worth a visit. A really pleasant cafe there is described as expensive but we thought it was good value even if only for the benefit of the fine mist which is pleasantly cooling. Don't miss a visit.

BEAUTIFUL. The garden was very pleasant although not as big as expected. You only really need 30 minutes to get round everything, with breaks for photos, if your not that interested in plants. I think I would definitely have appreciated the garden more had we visited in the heat of the day as it would have been a lovely place to shelter from the heat and hustle bustle of Marrakesh. It was beautiful place and along with many sights of Marrakesh it was recognisable from the spot the difference game.

Wonderful. In the hot, dusty and frenetic city that is Marrakech, this is a calm, peaceful and green oasis. Beautifully kept, stunning displays and colours, helpful staff and a lovely little courtyard café where we stopped for a coffee. Even if you aren't particularly into gardens, this is definitely worth a visit and the Berber museum of clothes and jewellery was very interesting. Perfect!

A bit overrated. I was somehow expecting something more spectacular. It was not unlike botanical gardens I have seen other places. There was also a Berber museum on the grounds but it required a separate admission fee which we did not feel was worth it.
Beautiful. A little oasis of calm and beauty. Definitely worth a visit. Immaculately kept and great photo opportunities

Stunning and Tranquil Oasis. Before ging to Marrakech Jardin Majorelle was a place I really wanted to visit and definitely wasn't disappointed. Gardens are stunning and well kept with the Majorelle blue featuring heavily. The restaurant serves fresh and tasty food in a beautiful courtyard, well worth visiting.

Which I had a house like this!. Unbelievable place a must if you travel to Marrakech.
Everything is just perfect about this garden, the cactus, the other trees, the displays, the organisation... it's just perfect
The magic garden. The colors more variety of cactus than I ever thought possible roofed by giant palms with the exquisite ponds and the magic of Yves Saint Laurent.
wonderful. so beautiful and colourful can spend a few hours taking in the splendour of the plants and colours and absorbing the beauty
Fabulous. Must see!!! Everything was perfect in there. Strong blues, nice shadows to enjoy the garden!!! Birds sounds there...
Was nice for a cooler afternoon. Was a lovely garden - nice and cool but it's pretty small so doesn't take up that much time but worth visiting as its fairly iconic

Calm and peaceful. We enjoyed our time here as a total contrast to the noise and craziness of the centre. It was peaceful and so relaxing especially in the heat. I'm not a great garden lover but totally appreciated the garden and its beautiful layout. Worth visiting if only for a change of pace - it's like pressing the pause button for an hour.

Good. Fantastic plants if you like that sort of thing, good walk around the gardens and plants were labelled giving interesting information about them. Tranquil fountain/pool which is an amazing blue colour. Also has a nice cafe area and a tiny museum.

Spot the difference!. The garden was very pleasant although not as big as expected. You only really need 30 minutes to get round everything, with breaks for photos, if your not that interested in plants. I think I would definitely have appreciated the garden more had we visited in the heat of the day as it would have been a lovely place to shelter from the heat and hustle bustle of Marrakesh. It was beautiful place and along with many sights of Marrakesh it was recognisable from the spot the difference game.

Great way to escape the heat!. Quite a tranquil, interesting and quirky garden. Full of colour and cactus'. I wouldn't say it's a 'must do', but its a nice way to spend the afternoon and escape the heat.There is a nice coffee shop inside the gardens too

A Beautiful and relaxing place to visit. Lots to see, the layout is really lovely and the little museum is apparently well worth a visit, although we didn't go in as it looked so small. There are many beautiful and unusual plants in this collection a must see for plant enthusiasts.

Good if you are into gardens. We just went on this trip as part of discovering Marrakesh as we were recommended by the hotel we were staying at, i am not really into gardens or gardening and i expected something thats wow, i guess it probably is if you are into those kind of stuff. The whole history of it all is interesting and entry fee is cheap 50 Dirhams so worth it as part of discovering Marrakesh but i would not go back in, not my kind of thing.

A piece from Heaven. It will give you another definition for gardens.. amazing atmosphere.. you will discover the Bleu Majorelle color and its beauty, the Memorial Yves Saint Laurent as it was his favorite place to stay in Morocco, in the small villa there..
Hidden gem in hot Marrakech. There are plants from 5 continents. Interesting arrangement. A lot of benches in shadow what is a gem in hot Marrakech. The price of 50 dirhams ( 4,5 euro ) is adequate.
Stunning garden. We loved the how the colors of structures complimented the lovely plants and trees. The gardens provide a serene setting apart from the rapid pace of the surrounding city.
Amazing cactuses. The highlight of the gardens for us were the cactuses - amazing variety! The rest of the gardens weren't so great, but it was still a great place to come and escape the heat!

Enchanting!. Don't miss it! Quaint little garden by one of the world's greatest fashion designers. Worth an hour (or three), stroll around and visit the Berber museum which contains a wealth of knowledge on these ancient and diverse people with a history going back millennia. Cafes just outside the main entrance serve decent fare. The place is buggy friendly so you can bring your strollers along if visiting with kids.

Beautiful oasis in Marrakech. We got a horse and carriage from the main square - I know, super touristy, but it was fun and we haggled to a fairly decent price. I wasn't sure if the gardens would be worth it, especially as the price seemed to have gone up when we were there, but I am so glad we went for the beautiful scenery and fantastic photograph opportunities. It is only a couple of hours out of the day and nice to get some peace away from the medina.

Stunning Gardens. These gardens are well worth a visit and are a welcome respite from the heat of the city. They are well maintained and the plant variety is excellent. The colour that abounds everywhere from the pots to the flowers was a treat. this is a must see spot in Marrakech.

Tranquil gardens, although very popular. We visited the gardens during August. Quite expensive to get in relative to other sites in Marrakech however it was a calm and peaceful place to visit and stroll around the various plants and trees. The Museum was very interesting and showed much about the Berber people down the ages, well worth a visit!The major downside was that this is a small garden and you are rightly restricted to the pathways, however, it is very popular and not all visitors are considerate of others and as such this can be more noisy that it should be.The cafe was a pleasant surpise and served nice snacks and light meals, and cooling drinks.I would certainly recommend a visit to these gardens however i do feel it is a little over-priced.

Extremely Peaceful. It was a really nice place to escape the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. There were lots of plants that I had never seen before and I especially enjoyed the Yves Saint Laurent part. Highly recommended for a trip to Marrakech and very inexpensive entry.

Colourful oasis. Calm shady gardens with vivid colours and unusual plants are relaxing and cool but the memorial to Yves Saint Laurent was disappointing.
Shop, bookshop and 'love gallery' are good to see.
Beautiful experience. It's a thing of beauty. About a 15 minute taxi ride in the traffic from central Marrakech but a good place to spend a few hours if you have time.
fantastic. A fantastic and extremely relaxing place to visit, without doubt one of the must see highlights on any visit to Marrakech. The restaurant serves reasonably priced and excellent food.

nice place. the location in Rue Yves Saint Laurent close to Yaccoub al mansor street in Gueliz.it far from 2.5 km from madina.The Majorelle Garden is a twelve-acre botanical garden and artist's landscape garden in Marrakech, Morocco. It was designed by the expatriate French artist Jacques Majorelle in the 1920s and 1930s, during the colonial period when Morocco was a protectorate of France.It was interesting & i like walk around the gardens , but it small .
Serenity. Beautiful. Highly recommend a visit.The gardens were extremely peaceful and the museum most interesting.

Lovely place. A nice garden to stroll around and take some pictures. Perfect mixture of colours and plants... Bamboo and cactus star this magic surrounding just a nice promenade away from the Medina :)
Overpriced and security guard was rude. It was interesting esp the museum, which was hard to get into because of the security guard. Nice cafe too
It was okay.... This was quite a nice afternoon, wandering around the gardens, they arent very big and it didnt take very long but it was very peaceful.
Shady garden. The garden is pleasant for 40 minute or hour stroll in the shade, but it is not exceptional and mainly contains cactus.

Wondrous Blue Gardens. This has to be the most delightful garden in Marrakesh. It's almost an advantage that it's fairly small, so can be enjoyed without a lot of walking. Water courses and pools abound. There is lots of trees and shade, which is an advantage in this hot desert climate. And of course there is its signature-piece Majorelle Blue on the walls, water tanks, and buildings, as a dramatic foil to the vegetation and bright flower colours. An absolute joy, and a highlight of any holiday in Marrakesh.It's just a 20 minute walk from the old city of Marrakesh (the Medina) so ideal to visit without having to organise transport.
Its beautiful but did not blow me away. Very nice but small. Expected a bit more given it is no6 thing to do in marrakesh. Only need 1 hour here.

beautiful, garden in a busy place. beautiful, peaceful, amazing garden . Very nice to experience the combination of nature green and blue painted attributes.
Very good display from the different continents.
I make my walk twice. First time to see everything and a second time torecord everything in your perception
Cool gardens. It must have been over 40C degrees that day but the gardens were stunningly refreshing and we did not feel the heat

Trees and plants - Art. peaceful, tranquil and interesting, great plants and trees, well tended, a beautiful sanctuary in the city, to be enjoyed by locals and visitors and local community and schools groups

Very nice place. . It's quiet and after all the crazy traffic of the city you can relax in this place. There is a nice cafe inside and bookshop. Lots of different plants, benches to sit. Entrance is 5€ (50dh), i think it could be cheaper. The garden is not big, without taking fotos you can walk it round in 10 min. I din't regret that i visited it

Peaceful Place. Beautiful tranquil gardens, one can understand why YSL loved to relax here. There is a YSL monument and a room with some of his art work in frames. It only takes about an hour to view the entire place

I don't understand the hype.... While it's refreshing to find a garden like this in Marrakech, I didn't quite understand the great reviews.Pros -Scenic enough small garden for a half hour stroll. Surprisingly had bamboo plants near the entrance, giving it an Asian vibe. Had a pretty pond in the back. Cons -Most of the garden consisted of various cactus, spaced fairly far apart. While there were some picturesque spots (esp near the front and all the way in the back), the majority of it seemed a bit deserted, which may be apropos for that region of the world, but did not leave much of an impression on me. Maybe I am simply jaded. It is also very small and you can easily stroll through in less than half an hour.It's quite a good distance from Jemaa el Fna and cabbies will try to swindle you to get there. Definitely do not pay more than 30 dirhams to get here!

Must visit while in Marrakech. I'd definitely recommend visiting this beautiful garden while in Marrakech. The colors and plants are so vibrant and the history is also interesting. There is a museum inside the gardens with Berber artifacts, I'd definitely recommend checking it out as well. It costs extra, but it is well worth it. It is one of the better designed museums I've ever been to. You can really see how Yves Saint Laurent was influenced by the Berber textiles, jewelry etc. A word of advice, the garden can get very crowded, our Riad recommended going after noon, we went at 11 because our morning plans fell through and it was packed. By the time we finished with the museum etc. it was afternoon and the crowd had cleared out considerably.

Romantic Walkways and Beautiful Views. We really enjoyed the Jardin Majorelle! You do not need to spend more than an hour in the garden, as it is not very big. Unless you plan on touring the shops and want to enjoy lunch in the cafe.The garden is ornate with beautiful fountains, cactus plants, trees, and flowers. The combination of landscaping provided a canopy for a good section of the path which made for some great photo opportunities! I also really enjoyed visiting the memorial for Yves Saint Laurent. This garden is worth the visit!
Amazing. Amazing place to visit in Marrakech.Beautiful gardens, unique colors All together.Don't miss this one!

pretty good- only need about 30 minutes to see. This was a nice place to visit. To be honest, my hotel Dar Ayniwen had gardens that I found just as beautiful, as my husband and I were able to visit them alone. Jardin Majorelle is a nice place to get out of the sun in the afternoon- just don't plan to stay all day as it is something that can be a quick in and out. Cost to enter is 50 MAD per person.

Soothing and Calming. If you get the chance, visit the gardens. We were swindled not taking a carriage ride there, which was nice, but it is a little far from the Jemaa el Fna. We went on the hottest day of the year, it was about +45 C outside, but sitting under the beautiful trees with our water and books made it bearable. The colours in the garden are fantastic, some of the plants exotic. We went into the shop, which was very expensive but had a lot of beautiful souvenirs.

It's a garden... as Expected. We visited the Gardens in the afternoon in August. It was a nice garden but not much else. You can take some nice pictures but that's about it. The cafe wasn't too bad, with some nice beverage choices to help you cool down. The garden is however a nice respite from the hot weather which I enjoyed.
Soothing. Semi-formal garden with bamboo grove and many and varied cacti. Style and colour of buildings and urns are a bonus.
Exotic garden. Loved the ambiance and fantastic cati and bamboo plants. Good cafe with nice food. Shady cool places to sit and soak up views of the garden
Cool. It was so busy and it would be beautiful to walk around with a drink in the quiet... The photographs and art on display were interesting and it is clearly popular, hence the hordes...
50dh is a bit much. Very nice garden, but pretty expensive for what it is. Went here to kill time waiting for a bus, worked great for that purpose.
outstanding. a beautiful garden oasis in the middle of the city bustle - and so, so peaceful. don't be afraid to take paint home as a souvenir, you can't get it anywhere else.
Family visit. Beautiful and peaceful, great for photos - didn't bother with museum though, entry was 50 Dhs each can get busy so go early or later on in afternoon.

Stunning gardens so peaceful. Great place to visit I would advise the visit to the museum as well as the gardens, as with most of the attractions and places to visit in Marrakech very reasonable entrance fee

Do not forget to visit this place!. Outside the medina there is an oasis of peace and rest from the crowded streets of Marrakech! The plants, the colors, the temperature everything is really beautiful. Don't forget to include in the ticket the visit to the berber museum inside the villa. It is worth it!

Pretty but not a full day. We went here on a day trip - we had an hour to explore which was more than enough. This is pretty much just an attractive garden behind a house. There isn't a huge amount of signage explaining what things are, but it was a pleasant walk.

Peaceful and Wonderful Garden. It was a bit packed when we went, but the garden was gorgeous my husband and I loved it. It was a nice break from the heat to walk around in the shade admiring the landscaping and ponds. I would also highly suggest going into the museum that's inside they have a lot of neat artifacts on display from the Berber culture.

A must see for Marrakech. A definite visit to this amazing garden first deigned by Marjorelle but then brought by Yves St Laurent & Pierre. There is little reference to Marjorelle which is a shame. Be sure to get there early , like before 10.30 to ensure no queues & be able to look at the garden in relative peace
Beautiful .... What colours, an amazing garden. Beautifully kept with delightful pops of gorgeous blue everywhere. The café is a welcome spot for lunch.

Go early. Everyone we spoke to told us to "Go early!" and we smiled, nodded, then rocked up for around midday, which for us, on a holiday, is pretty damned early!! But they meant really, REALLY early, and we could instantly see why. The serene beauty of this place was scuppered by the slow marching pace of 100 tourists all waiting to have their picture taken at the same points of interest. There were literally queues forming, just for people to take their one snap, then shuffle onto the next one. Had we arrived a few hours earlier and been able to walk round at our own pace and soak up the atmosphere and incredible popping colour of this place (blues, yellows, greens) I think we would have enjoyed it much more.It's also worth noting that the Jardin Majorelle isn't near a single other thing. You will need to take a taxi/horse & carriage there AND back. It's a long, long walk to the next sight. And no bars/restuarants of note to enjoy before or after.

stunning. a beautiful and serene garden, so many plants, flowers, shrubs and trees from all over the world,streams and stunning lakes with incredible viewpoints. and a small museum to explain its origins. this is a must see site in marrakech
beautiful garden. Beautiful garden, well maintained and very colorfulGood atmosphere for romantic visit.A bit expensive though!
Nice place. Wonderful garden to spend an hour or or so.The locals obviously love the place as everyone we spoke to about things to do in Marrakech mentioned this garden and knew its history.

Beautiful gardens try and go early. We loved these gardens. So well designed and so well maintained. We arrived mid morning despite the guidebooks suggesting and early or late visit. It would clearly be better to visit with less people there, because these gardens could be a serpent place to sit and relax, contemplating life, which is a little more difficult when it's busy. Though we still loved this place and the array of cactuses was really impressive.

Beautiful and peaceful. These gardens are well worth a visit. The tickets are a bit steeply priced at DH 50 but once inside the price is soon forgotten when confronted with bamboo plants towering overhead, exotic plants from various corners of the planet and streams.

Absolutely gorgeous. A superb set of gardens, absolutely worth a visit. We walked there from the square... on reflection, a poor choice (take a taxi!) but it made the gardens all the more relaxing once we finally made it! Truly beautiful with a satisfying little book store, lots of lovely postcards to buy.
YSL garden. Unmissable it is breathtaking and has to be seen at all cost. Do not forget to go and see the paintings and the boutique.

An absolute must when you visit Marrakech. Though a little out of the way if you are staying in the Medina, the gardens are an absolute delight, with an amazing collection of Berber jewellery in the museum. There are plenty of shady areas to take refuge from the sun and then of course, there is the lovely little cafe....
Perfect.... hey everyone, nice colours and flowers. you will like if you have time to visit. you may have coffee and take a visit to museum inside also

Beautiful tranquility. These gardens are just the most beautiful, tranquil place in the centre of a bustling Marrakesh. We went on a hot August morning and spent a peaceful and cool hour or so there enjoying the wonderful plants.
A lovely touch is that when you enter you can buy a small bottle of much needed water for only 5 DH.
Superbe visit. beauty, nature, cosy, colors, it was fun and I loved cactus and bridges, also I loved the small museum and berberian art, though it's small but very rich...

Gorgeous gem in Marrakech. We took a taxi from the medina, it was 30 dirhams. The gardens are worth a visit, they are really beautifully done! It was such a splendor of color - yellow, blue, and so many great places for pictures. It was not crowded and very serene. There is a beautiful cafe inside, and it feels like being in paradise. We did not go inside the house, but didn't need to, there was so much to see. Definitely worth a visit if you are in Marrakech.
Beautiful desert garden!. Not a must-see attraction, but a nice place to get a break from the hustle and bustle of the medina. Not a large garden but still very beautiful.

Excellent. A calm oasis in the bustle and craziness! I really needed this after a very busy week, the walk there took in some not so pleasant sights but the gardens are amazing, really tranquil and beautiful. Highly recommended.

Maybe skip it. We walked here from the Medina, which is about 2.6 miles away. It cost 50 Durhams, which seems like a lot for going in to view a garden. Super crowded, the only reason I can think that everybody thinks it is so amazing is that it is a peaceful place to get away from all of the motorcycles trying to run you over. I like the cobalt blue and plants, but too expensive and crowed to make it worth the visit.
Beautiful oasis for a hot day. The gardens are beautiful and worth a visit on a hot day. It was wonderful to relax and enjoy the beauty of the garden.
Array of colour. Very well kept and well presented although not many of the signs were In English but staff were helpful

Busy but beautiful. The gardens were really lovely. Unfortunately it was quite busy when we went and you either mistakenly walked in on someone taking a photo or they walked into yours. However I still would recommend the gardens - it was a beautiful setting to cool down in the midday sun. Would have liked to have spent more time in there but was time restricted. Also the staff were really friendly and took some great photos of my boyfriend and I.

Bit boring . Sorry, but I thought this was a bit boring. I did not understand how or why this was highly rated or on the top things to do in the city. It was a garden to walk around for a little while. The whole experience was seriously underwhelming and I left wondering why I had parted with money to walk around it. Go and sit in a cafe in the city for a while and watch the world go by, the call to prayer or the hustle and bustle of the streets from high above. Go read a book, go do anything, but don't bother going here. It's boring and a waste of time and money.
Oasis. A relief to visit after a sweltering day. The gardens are worth the visit. Well tended, cool due to foliage and fountains.

If yves Saint laurent came back to like he would kill himself after seeing this.. Terrible. Do not go unless you want to see barely leafed plants and cacti (which by the way do not come from argentina)

Peaceful. We paid an entrance fee here for adults only (children uner 9 are free). The gardens were easy to get to and peaceful and a lovely shady spot from the afternoon sun. Gardens are not very big and not geared for children really - more for adults in terms of plant names and landscaping. After a couple of hours at the most here, we continued our exploration of Marrakech.
Lovely garden and museum. Very good. The museum was especially interesting with exhibits of traditional Berber costumes and jewelry.
Not to be missed. Such a beautiful, interesting house and garden if you like beautiful places! Probably best to taxi as the walk from the medina isn't very nice. I also love the museum inside.

Plants Plants and More Plants. There's not really a lot to say about Jardin Marjorelle part from that its stunning. If you're a budding enthusiast of horticulture then you cannot miss this wonderful establishment. Let the pictures speak for themselves.

Peaceful and Tranquil in the heart of Marrakech. What a wonderful experience ! The gardens are amazing, the running water, whilst the bamboo sways slightly in the breeze was amazing. The sense of calm throughout the garden was lovely. The museum gave some great insight into the Berber history. Well worth a visit!
underwhelming. Takes 10 minutes to walk round this garden which is pretty mundane. Not sure what the fuss is about.
Yves St. Laurent's Home. Gorgeous! This is not to be missed. It was absolutely beautiful. Go early because it is very popular and not a large garden.

A piece of Heaven .. green paradise a few kilometers away from the desert. I can't describe how much I enjoyed this place ..After a long walk in the hot weather of Marrakech , I entered this heaven to relax ...It is really an amazing place , where you will feel from the first step that you are really in a quiet wood or an amazonian jungle but peaceful Long trees is everywhere , covering the sky by its leaves , and perfuming the air with its virgin lovely aroma .. birds are singing and red rare fish is swimming in lagoons arround you ..the place is very well organized , quiet , peaceful and amazing , you will see a marvelous home with wonderful colors , the stairs are yellow and the walls are blue it is a magnificent architectureyou can enjoy also the art crafts musuem of the Barbar .. and see their old musical instruments and their women clothes & jewlleryAlthough the price of the ticket is so high but the place worth the visit , it is one of the wonderful attractions of Marrakesh belt by the designer Yves St LaurentAn attraction I recommend everyone to visit and to take lovely photos ..

Great place to relax. This was the last place I went on a day packed full out sightseeing. Beautiful place though the museum was closed when I got there. I was happy just to wander and enjoy. I would recommend a taxi at least in the summer heat.

a cool escape. was a relaxing afternoon in the cool shade of the gardens, interesting to see the Versace house! the café was quite expensive so instead had mint tea back at the riad on the roof terrace

Even our teens appreciated it !!. Price would be the only reason to mark this down, its 50 Dh each which is cheap by European standards but on the high side locally. This is a haven though, take a book and laze around in the gardens ... sadly we have teens with us so lazing around in lovely gardens is not an option, but even they loved these guardens with the flowers, cactus and water features.A must see in Marrakech.

Incredible let down.. You can not spend more than half an hour here as there is so little to see but several species of caciti and palm trees. The Musee Berber housed on the same site, which attracts it's own entry fee was also an emphatic let down - other than a few cool berber costumes. For a park experience, try the Arsat Moulay Abdeslam Cyber Park instead.

Tiny and overrated.. After all the hype we expected more from this than a 20 minute walkabout - albeit in a relatively calm surrounding. If you are a fan of cactii, or a fan of defacing plant life with random visitors/tourists names then go visit.The berber 'museum' housed in the jardin majorelle was also an anticlimax, it holds a few interesting costumes and little else of note. In short - avoid this majorelletdown!

Cool and calm.... Spent around 2 hours wandering around these peaceful gardens. Was a welcome break from the seriously hot heat. Loved the YSL Love gallery-included as part of your entry fee. The prints were fab. Cafe quite expensive...skip and visit one of the cafes outside the gardens instead.

Great photo opportunity. Tranquil and shaded, this offered a relief from the heat of the city for a while. Small beautiful garden that offers some great photo opportunities. 50 Dirham entrance with children free.

Beautiful garden. This is a beautiful garden, in contrast with the Medina. Beautifully arranged, the recognisable blue majorelle is king in this oasis in Marrakesh. The Musee Berber is also remarkable. However, this is strictly a tourist attraction. It will answer your question "where are all the tourists hiding??". Don't expect to run into any locals. I also found the Yves Saint Laurent statue a bit disturbing given all the reports of misconduct during his visits to the country.

Tranquil. Really enjoyed the tranquility of the gardens and making faces at the fish. Loved the vivid colours (blues, oranges etc) that made up some of the painted colours. Nice mix of water and plants and great to visit simple memorial of ysl. Location is walkable from / to centre so good to avoid the taxi rank outside. Tip- give yourself plenty of time to explore and really immerse yourself.
Unique. A visit a well worth it, it takes around couple of hours to see whole garden. Well decorated plants and trees.
Cool and calm. Lovely for a wander around in the late afternoon, the bright colours really pop at that time of day. Stop for a cup of mint tea in the little cafe and chill.

For garden lovers, this is one is imparative. I have seen quite e few gardens, and this one certainly stands out as far as the original colours are concerned and the beautiful cactuses. I little jewel in Marrakesh, which I very much enjoyed for a few hours.
Lovely garden. Very nice! I enjoyed this pace very much so.Saint laurent did a good job... There are plenty of things to see to keep you busy

Worth a visit bit overpriced for what it is. Had high expectations for this attraction and it was very good. The architecture and colourful pots and structures were lovely but i did find the range of plants a bit limited and not out of the ordinary. Its a very small site and therefore over priced for what it was 50dh compared with other beautiful sites like badii palace coming in at 20-40dh. Water is sold cheaply on site but i dont recommend the cafe as it was very over priced! Overall worth a visit but theres other more beautiful things to do and see!

A delight.. Easy to find after a 45 minute walk from the madness of the centre, a very reasonable entrance fee and a wonderful way to spend a few tranquil hours. The food courtyard was wonderful with one of the best salads I had on the entire trip. The gardens are beautiful, lovely walk ways and many photo spots.

Fantastic garden. Well worth a trip. It is an oasis of calm and tranquility to relax and unwind. We spent over 2 hours wondering arond the gardens. Yes it is relatively small (2.5 acres) but it is packed with plants, water features and areas to sit in the shade and take in the spendor of the design and the variety of vistas that Yves Saint Laurent re instated to it's former glory. The Berber museum is also worth paying a visit. The costumes on display are great and give a real insight into the life of this community.

colourful. the home of Eve St Laurent, who purchased it off Majorelle an artist, is a superb and colourful home in true deco style with Moroccan twist, now a museum and full of items and clothing of his life, a must see....!!

The perfect getaway. The downside was that you have to pay 50 Dh to get in, which is pretty expensive if compared to Moroccan prices (but then again, it's only 5 euros). The plus was... Everything else! I had time, so I spent there pretty much the whole afternoon, just slowly walking about and drinking the place in. If you are into botanics, it is definitely the place for you, but even if you're not, it's still a peaceful garden, an oasis in Marrakech's chaos.They also had western toilets, very clean.
jardin of love. Absolutely beautiful and a great place to go with someone you love as the atmosphere is very romantic.

Nice relaxing outing. There are lots of different species here. We saw some very interesting types of cacti. The yves saint laurent shop was very nice but pricey. The garden has nice places to sit as well.

Good place to remember Yves Saint Laurent. As far as gardens go, this one is not overwhelmingly beautiful, however it is lovely to rest a bit and admire the life of Yves Saint Laurent. There is an impressive array of rare cacti, many from the soutwestern US and Mexico, and a nice place to have a tea on the terrace. The Berber museum is also delightful and houses traditional tools, jewelry, clothes, and instruments.

Trying hard to become a tourist trap. Okay, it is a nice garden, beautifull, lots of nice cactus and flowers, but overwhelmed by bamboo. And yes, there is a nice little blue house in it, and there is a small expo about the fantastic designer Yves Saint Laurent. But that's it. Actually you can visit it in 10 minutes or less, as it is so small. And the entrance price has skyrocketed in last years, up to 50 dirhams now, plus an extra 25 for the house. That may not seem a lot, but as confirmed afterwards by local people we knew in Marrakech, the overall price was just 30 not so many years ago, and all other PUBLICLY held musea and so do only charge 10 dirhams.So for me this attraction is just not worth the money ... If you are in Marrakech and want to have a stroll in an amazing garden, go to the garden of the posh Mamounia hotel ... entrance is free, and it is like 5 times the size of the Jardin Majorelle ... it has an amazing cactuscollection, and an educating herbs and vegetables garden all the way in the back.

Beautiful - well worth a visit!. A couple at the hotel we were staying at recommended this - and we are so glad they did!We spent a tranquil couple of hours walking through these gardens, admiring the plants, and then spent a happy hour in the on site cafe, enjoying local food and mint tea.Strongly recommended!

A must see. Perfect place to go after a busy day going through the hustle and bustle of the medina! Go early one morning and leisurely enjoy this beautiful garden and museum. Sit on a bench and meditate, stroll the pathways, enjoy the ambiance of this oasis hidden in this very busy and beautiful city.

Beautiful!. Peace and tranquility. Had been advised to go late afternoon as the light on the garden was just right, we did that and it was perfect. We got a horse drawn carriage back to Bab Doukkala for 60dh for five people.
Beautiful!. Definitely worth a visit when you're in Marrakech. Gorgeous walks around the garden. A lovely place to relax!

Must visit. Excellent oasis of calm and cool away from the heat - lovely to visit on an afternoon and great for taking pictures. Lots of places to sit down and relax. Definitely one for fashion lovers.

An oasis in the heat of the day. Located in the modern part of the city, this is a worthwhile diversion and a welcomed respite from the heat of the day, which, in our case, was 40 degrees plus when we visited July 2014. This meandering garden of cacti, bamboo, palm and much more is interspersed with water features and vivid splashes of blue and yellow from the various buildings, pots and tubs. There is seating in shaded areas to sit and reflect and, for a moment, to forget the hurly burly of the busy streets outside. Beware, though, of the on-site cafe which is expensive!

Amazing *-*. Seriously this was one of the most amazing gardens I´ve ever seen..The ambient was so calm and it felt like an oasis.. The colours are really nice. I spent a very pleasant hour here away from the heat and noise of the city and it wasnt that crowded, but that maybe because it was Ramadan.
Tranquility in a city of chaos. A must see garden if you're travelling to Marrakech. A little tranquility in a city of chaos. Beautiful colours and some great photographs for the album.
amazing gardens.. loved this place,beautifully set out and amazing plants.The cafe was set in a lovely enclosed garden and the food was top notch.
Stunning garden. Don't miss this gem in Marrakech. It is utterly beautiful and immaculately kept. I spent a very pleasant hour here away from the heat and noise of the city.

Interesting place, very expensive though. At first it felt like an oasis cause it is cooler than in the surroundings, but it turned out to be expensive and crowded. Prices in the café outrageous, compared to marrow an standards.
nice place to cool down. During the hot summer days it's a nice to cool down at the Majorelle Gardens. I expected it to be a little bigger though.

Calm in the heart of the new city. The gardens have been much improved since the last visit 5 years ago, and although they are not huge (several acres) it is worth the 15 minute walk from the old city. It was 100 degrees outside of the garden, and far cooler within. The Berber museum was the most state of the art museum we saw in the country. Coming here, you can see why Yves St Laurent fell in love with the grounds. His kind donation allows us to share in his love for an amazing country.

Excellent place, quality food, not cheap. Excellent, relaxing and fresh place. Quality food.
But it is quite expensive.We paid 40 euros for a lunch for two: one main dish each, one share salad, plus one shared fruit salad and Morrocon tea for two.
It is worthy if you want to continue visiting the wonderful Jardin Majorelle after the lunch.
Tranquil and Beautiful. This is a nice change of pace from the hectic streets and sites of Marrakech. Thank you Yves St. Laurent.

Colourful, serene and wonderfully historical.. Colourful, serene and wonderfully historical. It's wonderful to see where the magic that is Yves Saint Laurent happened and why it did, the vibrance of the entire garden is amazing in the sunlight.

Beautiful haven of calm. Possibly the best way to reach this wonderful garden is by taking a traditional horse and carriage for the morning from the main square in Marakech . This costs about £50 and it's yours for over two hours with a stop of between 30 and 45 minutes at the gardens. A perfect way to see the city at a relaxed pace. The gardens are a rich mix of towering bamboo plants in shady settings through to giant cactus in the full glare of the sun . There are koi carp in the water Lilly ponds and even some turtles . There is plenty of homage to Yves Saint Laurent who rescued these gardens after they fill on hard times. There's even a monument to him. The gardens have a very nice cafe serving breakfasts, tasty salads and drinks - among other things . It's a pity that people seem to think its a good idea to carve their names into numerous plants . But if you Like gardens, like design and want a change from markets make a date to go here - especially by horse and carriage
A must see in Marrakech. Beautiful place, amazing garden. One should absolutely go and see this. The home of famous Yves Saint Laurent has a small cafe, museum and shop in a gorgeous garden.
Beautiful Oasis. The most wonderful cool, calming place in the middle of the madness of the city. Go, you won't regret it!

Beautiful but very small. It's worth visiting here if you are in marrakech for many days.Otherwise it's not a big attraction and you may want to spend your time elsewhere.I visited as it was very hot and the gardens are very shady. It's 10dh each for the garden and there is lots of colour to be seen.

A must-see in Marrakech. Created by the painter Majorelle and fashion pioneer Yves Saint Laurent, now owned by the Majorelle-YSL Foundation, the gardens are an absolute must-see in Marrakech. Rare plants from around Africa and the Mediterranean are proudly displayed against a pastiche of YSL colours, including the beautifully-vivid deep blue which is characteristic of the garden. These are then supplemented by superb architecture which stresses the harmony and tranquility of the Majorelle Gardens, despite a throng of tourists constantly photographing themselves in every possible direction.The gardens have a DH50 MAD entrance fee, and for an extra DH25 MAD you may also buy entrance to the small, but still interesting, Berber Museum. The Museum features images, objects and textiles from Morocco's Berber heritage, alongside a delightful little gift shop with a broad range of French and English books. This is supplemented again by the nearby Garden-wide gift shop, which sells fabrics, paints (such as the YSL blue), metal objects and literature... all at the price characteristic of a famous European fashion label. Certainly a nice place to visit, if only to take some of the heat away from your day and relax in the mist-covered Jardin Majorelle cafe. A great must-see for the beautiful plants, architecture, colours and landscaping.

Nice ambience. This is a pleasant enough place, although getting there from Jemaa El Fna, which is where I was staying, was a bit of a hassle because of inflated taxi fares.I liked the general ambience of the place and the overall colour scheme, although the cobalt blue was, at times, a bit overwhelming.The gardens were much smaller than what I'd expected.I actually preferred the Koutoubia Gardens and the Cyber Park, both of which are free and within easy walking distance of Jemaa El Fna.
Beautiful Gardens. Tranquil, not really for kids, many varieties, tea room can be a little pricey. Look out for the Turtles in the lilly pond
Worth a visit. Was not as busy as I had thought from some other reviews, glad we went, nice to wander round for an hour, easy to get to by taxi or horse and carriage from the medina
A must to enjoy in Marrakech!. Great place to take a breath and enjoy. Great restaurant inside the marrocan breakfast is the best option. Nice to know a bit of Yves Saint-Laurent

Oasis in Marrakech. Very fresh area full of plants, springs and palmtrees.
Don't forget to use the student card if you're under 25.

a beautiful idyll for a gentle afternoon. We took a horse-drawn carriage here from the main square, which was a lovely way to go through the city walls and see life trot past.The gardens are beautiful and tranquil, and a great place to take a book and relax. Not a botanical gardens and so not somewhere you might wander for hours, cafe and shop overpriced. BUT a lovely idyll away from the hustle and bustle, and you can see the artistic talent that went into designing the gardens.
Tranquil and beautiful. Went early to avoid the crowds. Simply beautiful and so peaceful. Take a book and enjoy sitting on a bench to soak in the atmosphere.

Good place to go when you have lots of time. It is nice, however if you are short of time in Marrakesh, this would be a candidate for leaving out.Unless you are an cactus lover, then this is a must see.Also the entry is relatively high.

Overrated, but nice. I expected more. Too expensive and crowded. Nice, but more for mass tourism than the urban idyll I expected. And seriously: the YSL shrine is embarrassing. And the museum store's shop has prices and merchandise suited for Paris, but not Marrakrsh.
Must see. Great oasis in the middle of a big city. Must see I think, and very cheap to get in. I would also visit the Berber museum, very interesting.

A tiny treasure trove. Saved by Yves St Laurent from falling into total disrepair is an island if exotic plants, in particular succulents and cacti. It also contains a memorial grove to ysl and a couple of very interesting shops such as the museum, prints and a book shop. Consider spending 90 minutes or so there ,even in the middle of summer, as it captures a tranquility and graciousness from times gone by.

Coolness & Peace. Loved this place it was such a pleasant relief to get out of the intense heat and sit in a cool corner in the garden. A lot of the elements reminded me of a Japanese style garden. It's not a riot of colourful flowers but rather sleek lines and subdued colours. The pots, pathways and pools bring in the colour. I now want to copy them and paint all my terracotta pots blue & yellow.

Wonderful colourful gardens not to be missed in Marrakech. Do not miss going to these gardens - colour, flowers, trees, shrubs, birds, shops, café.
Watch the price of the taxis outside when you return - you have to arrange it with the main taxi man and then take the taxi.

Pricey but good. Really lovely gardens. Museum was better than average and with nice air conditioning, and very impressive lighting in the jewelry section.We did not try it but the cafe looked good and someone else told us it was good. I'd recommend this above the Bahia Palace.Suggestion - get a horse & carriage there - or back or both. There are loads of carriages and taxis outside the venue, so no risk of getting stranded there.
What a garden!. An absolutely must-see when you are visiting Marrakech. Spectacular architecture, plants and trees surrounds this garden ind the middle of Marrakech.

Great place to find shade in Marrakesh. It was 37 degrees whilst we been in Morocco! we found a great place here to look at Berber history and to get out of the sun! The gardens are small, we managed to spend a couple of hours, sitting amongst the bamboo, good to go early as the place fills up with coach loads of tourists and doesn't really have the capacity.

pretty little garden and cool in July heat. very pretty garden with lots of shady places to sit and enjoy. The Majorelle blue is stunning. It's fairly small so even walking slowly and sitting in spots will take you under an hour.
Good food, interresting people. Tanjine, the best!!!! i enjoyed very much the food and the entire atmosphere was nice. Thank you for the experience

A decent garden, but not worth the entry. A nice garden in all respects but with four people at 50 dh a head it was a bit pricey all things considered. Would probably pass on it since there is so much more to see in Marrakech.

Not what I expected. I guess we went on one of the hottest days and just one small bottle of water we took each was insuffice.Gardens were mostly in shade but even here the heat was intense and walking around them was an effort.Smaller than we expected with mostly trees and cactus-a bit dissappointed

Oasis of calm - an absolute must. These gardens are absolutely stunning, and you can easily while away a couple of hours amongst the succulents here. The gardens, walkways and ponds are immaculate, and burst with assorted ferns, bamboos and cacti. The sound of traffic disappears as soon as you enter ...There is also a wonderful museum dedicated to the tribes people of Morocco, featuring their clothing, jewellery and everyday treasures (beautiful wooden boxes, carved spoons etc rather than stuffy objets d'art) which you should definitely include on your entrance ticket. It takes about half an hour / three quarters of an hour to stroll through. There is a lovely cafe / restaurant in the midst of the gardens, for mint tea, coffee or even a full meal. Prices are moderate, not cheap.The area has recently been improved too, now offering a fabulous cafe (with brilliant coffee) and a range of small artisan shops. There is a wonderful bookshop too, offering both English and French language coffee table books on Morocco and north Africa. It has the most gorgeous wooden front, and is almost directly opposite the entrance to the gardens.One word of caution - DON'T take a taxi from outside (or even look as if you're the sort of person who might want a taxi). They will pretend to offer low prices, but then jack up the price as soon as you agree to go with them. It is distinctly unpleasant, and can be avoided by walking the 50 yards back to the main road and hailing a small taxi to take you into the city (no more than 30 dhirams).

beautiful, go with your camera. Even if you're not green fingered you'll enjoy. It's a little tucked away but it's a treat. So calming. So many beautiful plants and flowers. Even some photos from the designer, they're about 30 years old. You will take loads of pics. Cheap too. It's the most beautiful place in Morrocco.

Pretty, but not worth the hike. We accidentally thought that the iconic view of the mountains that you see in all of the photos was at this place, but it's actually Menara Gardens. It is lovely, can't fault it for that. But it's a bit of a hike away from the action and nothing much is there. If you're a fan of Yves Saint Laurent then definitely, but otherwise a bit uneventful

A Treat for your Eyes!!!. Simply Beautiful!!!very beautiful garden with lots of variety of plants...specially cactus and bamboos. Few structures, building, pathways, flower jardiniere etc with very bold colors have been used to make this place a really eye candy. One must visit this place in Marrakech. It is one of the best place in Marrakech as a traveller and for photography.

Beautiful colours. Loved the design and the colours ( especially the famous blue - which you can buy), the art and the boutique shop with the most beautiful Moroccan bedding - random and expensive yes but stunning . Not so keen on the crowds - OMG forget about trying to take a picture without the world and his family in it - particularly some people (sorry to the nice French people out there) who could be on the rude side occasionally !

Pretty Cool, In All Senses Of The Word.. No need to take a tour to see the Jardin Majorelle, it's simple to find and nicer to wander around at your own pace enjoying the peace and cool air. This is a great place for photo opportunities so don't forget your camera. The blues and greens are so intense they almost hurt your eyes. A surprise gem is the small gallery included in the price showcasing the YSL Christmas cards over 25 or so years. We didn't find the cafe particularly welcoming but dined in a wonderful cafe called Kaowa across the street - friendly, clean and they speak good English.
beautiful, beautiful, beautiful. beautiful garden with beautiful museum!a breather in Marrakech!worth spending a whole afternoon there.

Peaceful little garden in shades of blue and yellow. Jardin Majorelle is a peaceful little garden worth a visit for a relaxing rest from the chaotic souks and vibrant life of Jemaa El Fna. Characterized by colorful pots, buildings in yellow and blue and plants from all over the world (especially cacti), this place offers the opportunity to take lovely photos . The price to enter is 50 dh. Inside the garden there is a small café which serves Maroccan teas and refreshing beverages. The garden is located about 40 min walk from Jemaa El Fna. If you decide to get a taxi, make sure you bargain the price first.Visited in March 2011
Very nice.... Loved this place - cool oasis in marrakesh. Colours are amazing, photographers dream.. Good value, take plenty of water, restaurant quite expensive but so good

Greenes place in Marrakech. I think this is by far the greenest (and bluest and most yellow) place in Marrakesh. Bamboo and cactus give the green color, Majorelle-Blue and yellow in pots, walls an buildings. A Must-See.
Beautyfull place.. This is a small garden but in my personal experience is worth seeing. Entrance fee is not high. You can see many interesting plants there.

Beautiful and peaceful. The gardens are beautiful and an incredible collection of plants from around the world. The entry is a bit steep (50 dh) but it is well worth a visit if you need some solitude.

A garden bursting with character and colourful buildings. This was one of our stops during our city break. It is a nice contrast to the hustle of the souks and the city's famous square. It's a little out of the way but worth a visit. Not particularly child friendly, I suspect young ones will become bored very quickly. Lots of young couples both foreign and domestic visiting the gardens while we were there.

Beautiful, However I wouldn't go back.... Very nice gardens, but not worth the price. Costs abour 50 dirhams, and gets very crowded, and we went early. The museum inside is nice, and the house is beautiful, but there really wasn't much to it. Not a big wow factor on the plants they have. Go just to say you have been there. Maybe I was expecting more, but I heard there was a bigger garden that was less money and larger in the new city

STUNNING COLORS AND PLANTS. This is a beautiful botanical garden covering some 12 acres. Stunning colors, especially blues. Lots of cacti of many varieties. A pool with water lilies. Colorful pots. YSL did a great job in making this garden and house beautiful. He died in 2008. Supposedly, his ashes are here. There's a gift shop and café, which I didn't bother with. There's a museum with ceramics, paintings, textiles, and jewelry, which is worth stopping into. I didn't spend much time there as I was here for the gardens.
Beautiful.. I loved it, purely because I love the colour of Majorelle Blue. It outside of the old city, where my hotel was, but well worth the journey out.
What a garden. The most amazing collection of plants from around the globe, such a peaceful place in such a busy city
beautiful. amazing cacti, went on a trip but museum not included, about an hour is all you need. YSL did a good job of the gardens afte Marjorelle
Beautiful, and out of the heat!. Beautiful and unique gardens which were out of the 40 degree heat as they were shady! Lovely day out to have with a family.
Stunning gardens. A calm oasis in this frantic city. Definitely worth a visit. Small gardens which can be walked around in under 10 minutes if you wish, with lots of seats and shady corners.
Colours are amazing. Loved this place - cool oasis in marrakesh. Colours are amazing, photographers dream.. Good value, take plenty of water, restaurant quite expensive but so good
shady and beautiful. nice for a break from the craziness of Marrakech. Well kept and with a huge variety of plants and some amazing cacti.Nice ponds and sitting areas.

a Shrine to YSL. a very small and poor effort at a tranquil garden. The garden was funded by YSL and he seem have dedicated it to himself. nothing to see except palm trees and ......more palm trees. Steer clear.
Beautiful. Was tranquil, beautiful and ornate. Overpriced gift shops but the cafe was quite reasonable. Got some beautiful photos. Quite hard to find but taxi was only 30 dhms from our hotel.
Beautiful gardens. Lovely gardens,beautiful pond with water lilies and mainly shaded which was a real bonus on a hot day

A Haven of Peace and Tranquility. We were taken by our driver to this place of peace. It cost 100 Dirhams for two to enter which was about £7. It offers plenty of shade from the searing heat of Marrakech. It is easy to lose yourself in the peace and quite even though there are many more than a hundred visitors there at the same time. It has many Cacti and a large pool covered in Water Lilies. I wish that we had had more time to enjoy. There was plenty of seating to sit and contemplate and reflect upon the beauty of it all. It is a not to be missed attraction for anyone visiting Marrakech
Mr. Very colourfull. Not big but interesting .my clients loved it and also easy to get there. However the local guide was not the best for this place
A must visit. It's worth the queue at busy times, always a joy to see the beautiful gardens and the Berber museum in the grounds are recommended

A little slice of saved paradise in a very busy city. YSL did it proud!. These gardens were saved by the famous Yves Saint Laurent. He was horrified to learn they were being bulldozed to make way for some concrete monstrosity! So.. He stepped in.. bought the land and over the years, honed it into the little oasis that is Marjorelle Gardens.It's 20dirahms in. I think 10 more for the museum tour which we didn't bother with. We were there purely for the shrubbery! The photo ops in here are ample but impossible with everyone wanting the same thing. Patience is a virtue if your a budding photographer and want that fab snap!This place is serenity.. lush bamboo growing; with lovers who've cheekily carved their initials into the bamboo or leaves of the Agarve plants growing here (they're used in tequila don't you know!). HUGE palm trees jut out of the canopy into blue skys! There's a hut just as you walk through the first part onto your right side that springs out into a long thin water feature that makes a great photo.Such variey her in foliage and fauna. So very tranquil even with all the tourists about.The gardeners are about tending to their pride and joys. They do smile at you- some any way lol. There's lots of staff wandering about too in bright blue t-shirts who'll always offer to snap you and a friend next to a 50ft cactus! The cactus's by the way...even though they look smooth they're really not. I put my hand on one and got HUNDREDS of tiny spines in my hand and were very painful and got all over my body!! I had to change my clothes when i got back to the hotel..DO NOT TOUCH!! There's no signs anywhere giving you that advise so be warned!!It's hot. REALLY hot. It's in the shade but still hot. There's benches dotted about so you can sit down. The little memorial plot for Yves Saint Laurent is simple in design. A lovely spot. But again, lots of tourists ooooing and aaahing at it.. If you look really closely you can spot turtles living amongst the water Lilly's!The cafe inside... #Looks# great. But we didn't eat there. Too expensive in our book! There was a much cheaper place directly outside the gardens called Kaowa! That did HUGE wraps and cold as ice smoothies for half the price. Don't waste money on a pretty place i say..It's there for sakes sake. Like the gift shop at the end of a museum. Kaowa people. There's toilets. No baby facilities at all... One poor lady was changing her newborn on the floor of the bathroom with tourists stepping over her!!!!! Not cool. The maid looked quite annoyed she was doing it but where the hell was she meant to go???!! Morocco is quite anti-baby and anti disabled i must say!It takes around an hour 30min to get a real sense of these gardens and why YSL saved them. A good deed i say! Sometimes city's NEED their greenery! A must see it's simply a lovely break from the car horns and and road fumes.

lovely garden with a bit of shade from the summer heat!. A lovely little garden with highly contrasting coloured pots and plants, great for photography. Wonderful place for a bit of shade from the sun and also away from the busy city. Costs 50 dh to enter. Make sure you bargain first before entering the taxis outside.
Beautiful gardens. Lovely gardens with variety of plants. Must see, a great place to take a break during your walk in the Madina.
Beautiful cool oasis. Amazing cool oasis just outside the Medina. Well worth a visit, takes you away from the hustle and bustle of the city.
Fabulous gardens - well worth a visit!. The setting and colours were quite stunning. If you go, do pay the small charge extra to visit the Berber Museum - well worth it.

Didn't love it. This garden is chock full of tropical plants and designed to feel like an urban oasis. I found it small, crammed with tourists, and sort of fake-seeming. To me, the royal blue painted touches and paved walkways seemed to stress the artificial, rather than the natural. Did not have the feel of a botanical garden or natural outdoor space.

Fantastic. We visited the gardens as they were a short walk from our riad and were amazed by what we saw. If you like cactus this is the place to go. We have never seen so many different varieties and the gardens are a nice oasis in the middle of Marrakesh and well worth a visit.
The best place in Marrakech. Or should that be the only nice place in Marrakech? We stayed for about 2 hours to get some peace from the horror of the city.

So peaceful. Couldn't believe how quiet & calm it was inside the garden compared to the madness of Marrakech.
Well worth a visit.

I'd go back just for the food!. Loved walking around the gardens but the highlight for me was definitely the amazing food in the cafe. I was with a group of five and everyone's meals were amazing! Great coffee, ice cream, drinks, sweets and lunches.
Beautiful. Beautiful gardens but didnt see the house inside. It was 2006 . The colours are magnifiquent, remembers mexico e morocco at the same time

Peace & Tranquility. Beautiful gardens and a 'must-see' whilst you are in Marrakech. Easy to find from the centre. Not overly big - you can cover all of the gardens at a mild stroll in around 90 minutes.Fabulous selection of plants and trees from all around the world with the added style of YSL design thrown-in for good measure! Please visit, you will not be disappointed.

Don't miss this!. The Jardin Majorelle is a stunning garden created by French artist Jacque Majorelle over a period of about 40 years. If you love plants and bold colours then this is definitely for you. It might seem odd to go to Marrakech a visit a garden developed by a foreigner but he was clearly inspired by his surroundings (among other things) and it shines through in his garden. It is delightful way to spend an hour or so, wandering around in the shade and admiring the many different species of plants carefully placed among pots, benches and walls all bursting with colour.A bit hard to find but worth the effort.

An afternoon well spent. Lovely gardens. Variety of plants. Quiet and peaceful. It rained and was thus a tad slippery but the rain was refreshing and made the gardens more alive. Lovely buildings too and lunch at the cafe was excellent.

Beautiful!!!. I cannot compare this garden to any other as it is such a particular one. Firstly it was Yves private garden & then used to gather vegetation from around the world, mainly cactuses. It's such a beauty on its own!!!It's small & colourful, gives you the feeling of a little oasis within the dryness of Marrakesh & also links the town to its spanish past connection. A lovely vegetation display where you will also find a Berber Museum inside, at an extra cost of course.Worth the knowledge.

Beautiful gardens. The Majorelle Gardens were a real treat to visit, so peaceful and wonderfully cool even on a nearly 40 degree day. The museum was very interesting and the jewellery room was quite breathtaking, we'd both recommend a visit.

Great Visit. Although not a huge garden it was superbly designed and maintained. Visit both the garden and the museum - both worthy. This is a huge expanse of greenery. Museum entertaining and informative too. A must see in Marrakech.

Must visit.... It was nice to be back here at the Majorelle Gardens after seven years. Well kept. A very relaxing place.There are some new areas, like the memorial for its former owner Yves Saint Laurent & more artifacts and exhibits at the Berber Museum. The cafe is also worth a visit for lunch or a short break.
A haven of tranquility. Friends said go to the Jardin Majorelle, if you do nothing else then you must see that and they were so right. So peaceful and utterly beautiful.
VISIT THIS PLACE. Very pleasant little oasis in the red hot city, the vegetation keeps the place cool, well worth a trip.

Nice garden but great Berber museum. Very nice but very small gardens, Ideal to just chill out and relax the hustle and bustle of marrakech. The highlight for me was the Berber Museum, The displays are amazing and very informative fact sheets.
Beautiful. A great place to take a break from the chaos in the street. The garden is really beautiful and they have a small café with Maroccan teas and refreshing beverages.

Tranquillity. Having decided to venture out from our lovely hotel in the midday sun. We had a lovely stroll to the Jardin Majorelle. Going there we did not really know what to aspect. I can honestly say the garden grounds, staff, facilties were all first class. Some of the pictures we took were just breathtaking. A great way to spend a Sunday afternoon. Steve & Karen.
Not amazing.. Better gardens at La Mamounia and you don't have to pay to get in at the hotel. Save your money go to La Mamounia get a drink and wander round the gardens there instead.

An Oasis in the middle of a manic city. Whilst in Marrakech,one of the most longed for places we wanted to see was The Jardin Majorelle.It was more beautiful than we had imagined.The colours of the blooms,against the mosaic work on seats and walls of buildings was absolutely amazing.Total tranquillity within its walls,it was like an oasis within a manic city.As you walk up to the gardens you can be fooled by it's unimpressive entrance on the street,but as soon as you enter into the mosaiced courtyard it is breath taking.It didn't seem to matter that it was very busy as you slowly walk through the winding paths gazing at everything.We stayed and enjoyed it's beauty for 4/5 hours,untill we had taken it all in.....beautiful,truely beautiful..

Beautiful Garden. Loved the garden. So colourful and you can get lovely pictures. The people working there are really helpful also. However, the museum inside the garden was a bit of a let down. So small.

A magical refuge in Marrakech. Beautiful garden with wonderful plants, architecture, and colours. Very pleasant even in the heat of the day as there is lots of shade and benches next to cool pools of water. The Berber museum is also worth a visit, it's affordable and has an excellent display of Berber costumes, jewellry, and crafts. One of the highlights of Marrakech!

Don't miss out!. If you are in Marrakesh, this is a must see! Jardin Majorelle is beautiful. I advise anyone to go early, to avoid being in an overcrowded park. It is very relaxing to walk around and see all the beautiful palm trees and cacti! I can also recommend the Berber Museum. There are only three rooms which makes matches with the available attention span in the hot weather ;)

Don't miss the Berber Museum. The garden is OK - compact botanical garden with trees and plants from around the world. On the other hand, the Berber Museum really brings out the best from Berber culture and history.

Make sure to visit the Berber Museum in the garden.. The museum represents Berber history and culture well, and is the only really Moroccan element in the garden - which is otherwise a compact botanical garden with trees and plants from all around the world.

Beautiful Garden worth a look. A beautiful garden with plants from all over the world, is around a 20-30 minute walk from most parts of Marrakech (that your likely to be staying) or a 20Dh taxi ride from the main square (Jemma Da Fina). 25Dh admission is worth it, the museum is extra (so we did not go). Only takes about an hour to see it all at a slow pace.

Colour. The most amazing place, full of colour, beautiful plants laid out in very relaxing and meandering style. It is not very big, but, has to be seen to be believed. As with all the places we saw, the outside does not do justice to the inside!

Beautiful. Very pretty. But honestly if I had missed it I would not cry. You Can do whole thing in 20 min. Good for photos. People try to sell fake watches at the entrance. Clean place and good for nice photos, but could be any where in world.

Beautiful garden. A very beautiful and serene garden within the busy city of Marrakech, had a relaxing walk for a few hours taking in the picturesque surrounding nature. Museum also was well organised and informative, with useful different language card options within the various exhibitions.
Stunning gardens. A little piece of garden paradise amongst the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. Lots of shade and vibrant colour

Pleasant oasis. The garden is pleasant enough. I went in February and there were not too many people. The Berber museum is very interesting. It gives an insight into the lives and culture of the Berber people.Well worth the extra money.

Enjoyable but Average. We went on an organised trip via Thomsons. However, this is the sort of Garden that you bring a book with you and a good camera, find a spot you like and sit and enjoy for as long as you like. It isn't very big and I would guess you could rush around it all in 15 minutes, our guide gave us 45 minutes free time in the garden which gives you an idea. I thought that the cactus plants were amazing and the ones in flower stunning. As others have written the Café is over priced, there was also a charge for the extra museum within the Garden which we were unaware of, 25Dhm pp. Although I think overall it should only be rated as average, that is mainly based on the fact I couldn't honestly say it was "very good", good possibly but very good I am not so sure. I enjoyed the Garden but wouldn't argue with those that have rated it either better or worse than I have. I wonder if it wasn't for the name YSL would it be as popular?

Delightful. Definitely worth a visit. Lovely surroundings, beautiful gardens and cool under the wide range of exotic plants. So different from the hustle and bustle of the city and well worth the trip.

cactus. not what i was expecting but pretty good. i would advise a guided tour as i overheard the tour guides passing and they had very interesting information which makes a huge difference in this garden.
Stunning. Beautiful, did not disappoint. Everything we wanted and more. Wonderful atmosphere, could stay in the gardens for hours. The true wow factor as soon as you walk in.

Beautiful on Another Day. You never really know what you'll find in a public place in Morocco. Your lunch could include entertainment by acrobats or a man in wheelchair rolling up to your table to exhibit his stump of a leg. Looking back at the photos of the Jardin Majorelle I am stunned by the colors and re-enchanted, though on the day it was too hot and too crowded for maximum enchantment. Unfortunate timing brought us on a day when there were two weddings and temps were the 100's. Benches were at a premium, so meandering was the only course of action. But don't let me bring you down, it's utterly gorgeous and unique. Don't miss it. The dose of intense coloration alone is worth the price of admission. The cafe was quite over priced, 45 dirhams for three or was it two? tiny boules of ice cream. At that point in the day any cold was considered a medicinal must have item.

Very beautiful. A calm,beautiful and interesting place in busy Marrakech. Worth a visit especially if you are interested in plants. Lots of shady place to sit and contemplate the beauty surrounding you.

Go early. I must agree with some reviewers that the garden is slightly underwhelming. I find the whole concept of bringing plants from five continents together and cramp them all into a rather small space a little over-ambitious. If you have travelled the world a little, you won't find anything new or exciting here. I did like the indigo blue throughout the garden though. It seems unconventional if not disturbing at first but it works. It breaks up the garden into little focal points and eventually makes you look at the plants. Without the blue vases and structures, the whole garden would be pointless in my opinion. I also don't agree that the Yves Saint-Lauent memorial is laughable. He was a rather private and shy person, so a small pillar in his memory seems more fitting than a giant marble tomb. He did not want to elevate himself above a place and culture he loved, and this should be respected and appreciated.The key to appreciating the garden better and to see how the green and blue work together, is to either go very early in the morning or very late in the afternoon. We arrived at around 11am and it was a total zoo. Go either before 9am or after 4pm. In between it's more like summer sales in China.I believe the best part of the garden is the Berber museum inside. Most people don't want to pay another 25 dirham on top of the 50 dirham entrance fee for the garden. But that's a huge mistake. The museum provides an extraordinary insight into Berber culture and art. The majority of Moroccans are Berber, and we have to thank Pierre Berge and Yves Saint Laurent for an astonishing collection of art pieces. There's nothing like it anywhere in Morocco. While I would give the garden an average score, the museum is a straight five. If you have time for only two museums, it should be the Berber Museum and Maison de la Photographie.

Quiet afternoon in Marrakech. Took a taxi to the Jardin Majorelle (it's too far from most places to walk) and enjoyed a quiet afternoon strolling among the various plants. It's very peaceful in the gardens. The cafe is very nice, a great place to relax. I did not order food there, just the mint tea.
Stunning. If you love gardens/landscape - well, if you love beauty, then you have to visit this place! So well maintained and just absolutely breathtaking!!

Majestic Marjorelle. Quite simply, if you to go to one place in Marrakech, make it this one. Gorgeous garden, extraordinary plants, fabulour architecture, interesting wildlife, cute little Yves Saint Laurent "Love" exhibit, fountains, peace and quiet. Lovely. There's also a shop, decent toilets (always worth noting in Marrakech!) and a (pretty expensive in context) café. A little way out of the Medina (and if you walk you'll have to cross some fairly busy roads) but definitely work seeking out.In riposte to the review below, 50 dirhams equates to less than £4 so I would rather call this place a bargain.
TO MUCH NOISY FOR .... It is a beautifull garden in the midle of a city but It should be ok if it was for free.I couldnt understand why I have to pay to see a garden .Nothing special!!

overrated and terrible. we came here because it had such great reviews but when we arrived we didnt understand why. the garden is underwhelming and not that pretty. the blue they paint on everything is overpowering and clashes with the colors of the garden. the yves st. laurent memorial laughable, it's just a small pillar. 50 dirham was also pretty steep considering what it was. it was also absolutely packed with people. gardens should be relaxing but it was mostly just stressful. dont go here, there are wildly better gardens in other parts of the world.
