Colours. Very beautiful garden with variety of colours. It was a peaceful experience. The garden is outside old city so in case you are tired of kebabs there are other restaurents you can try especially pizzaThe ticket is bit pricey but once you are inside its a blissful experience

have a drink here. Brilliant place to have a drink after exploring the garden. So peaceful and quiet, just you and your thoughts. Sit under the lemon tree- plan your next trip, doodle or sketch, listen to some sufi music and just enjoy the mint tea!
Beautiful!. Such a great outbreak from the big city in the centre of Marrakech. Clean colours, nice food and very romantic:) although 50dh is a little too much for seeing a garden:)

A very nice place to visit. These gardens are tranquil and picturesque, an ideal way to relax for an hour or so in the middle of a busy city. The gardens are quite small so a visit is not the equivalent to some of the botanical gardens in other cities but is well worth a visit nonetheless. We went into the store that is onsite and were a bit taken aback by the very nice prices being asked. Not somewhere I would recommend for a shopping experience but maybe that's just me!

Dream garden. A beautiful well-maintained garden. A real green paradise with several kind of plants. In the garden you find the blue and yellow villa Majorelle. Pity that you have to pay an additional fee to visit the small museum of Berber art. The bookshop and library of the garden has an excellent choice of books about Moroccian and Berber craft and art. Not to miss !
Lovely Gardens. Great place to visit , sit in a shady corner and enjoy the ambience. The museum was great very interesting the Yves Saint Laurent collected all the artefacts.

Gorgeous. We went to the harding on May, it was a really cool garden so if you love plants, and relaxing places this is a place you MUST visit. The colour mixture is like an electric salad of peace and modernism. The museum is pretty cool, a bit small, but well maintained and it is price worthy, specially if you look for AC. You can stay for a while inside the museum before returning to the warm Marrakech climate. Its a landmark in Marrakech and must go if you are nearby. The museum exposition is also worth to check out.

Like stepping in to a rainforest!. The gardens are certainly worth a visit. They are a refreshing escape from the dry heat that occupies Marrakech/Morocco since there is a lot of shade provided by the trees which have created a somewhat canopy. Cacti, aloe Vera plants and different forms of trees dominate the gardens - however there is very little else to see. So if you are expecting to see amazing and unusual displays of plants you might be a little disappointed. Though, if you are looking for a bit of respite, like myself, from the busy lights of the city then this is the place to go. When inside you forget where you are, it is so quiet and tranquil. Definitely more of a place for adults to go to as children may become bored.

Peaceful spot just outside the Medina. If you find yourself towards the north of the Medina, you're nearly at the Majorelle Gardens so take an hour or two to visit this oasis. The gardens themselves are beautifully cared for and the pools and fountains are very pretty. The Berber museum is well worth visiting - a fascinating journey through the Berber way of life. The restaurant is also very good and a perfect spot for a relaxing lunch.

nice and relaxing 30 minutes. a nice garden to walk around and is only £5 per adult. nothing too extra ordinary, and the plants and cacti are 'graffittied' which is odd but adds a little to the gardens. Worth a visit if you are there, but don't go out of your way.

deep blue oasis. The strongest impression is certainly majorelle blue color. Together with green plants it is great visual contrast to earthy orange city of Marrakech. Garden is outside of Medina but it`s about 30 minutes walk from it and it is worth taking the walk to see it. Everything in the gareden is well oranized and maintained. All informations about garden and museum are avaiable on english. Place you must visit if you are in Marrakech.

Beauty in an arid land.. This garden has the chic of France and the charm of Marrakech. It is well worth a visit. Savour the colours and beauty of this delightful Oasis . A place for all ages to visit.Take home some ideas for your garden,the use of pots maybe..

Beautiful but small. There is no denying that the Jardin Majorelle is a beautiful, tranquil, spot with impressive flowers, trees, colors and design. If you have plenty of time in Marrakech to go exploring I would suggest you make a visit. We took a horse drawn carriage to the gardens which added to the experience.However, if you are pressed for time I would skip the gardens as there are plenty more impressive things to do and see. The garden is quite small and if you stroll casually through you have seen everything in 20 minutes. We did not try the café on site so I cannot comment on that.

Peaceful contemplation. These gardens are the most delightful place to visit, whether or not you are a gardener or artist. It is a place where you can escape the noise and madness of the Souks and Medinas, a place you can find peace and tranquillity. It was the summer residence of the designer Yves Saint Laurent.I went with a dear friend a couple of years ago. She was recovering from a serious car accident, which sadly, her partner didn't survive. The garden has many many different species of plants, but notably cacti, set in the most beautiful gardens, and in the centre, the most magnificent bright blue house, that gleams with the clashing purple bougainvillia and bright blossoms that surround it.My mother used to collect cacti when I was a child, and seeing these magnificent plants suddenly reminded me of her. I felt sad, and a little reflective and tearful. I turned to my friend, and said, "I'm having a moment abut my Mum..." She turned to me and said "Today would have been Nick's Birthday." We hugged, and shed some tears, but in the most beautiful, peaceful, healing space.We went on to have delicious freshly squeezed juices in the lovely cafe, and there is a shop which sells a particular brand of Saint Laurent perfume that my friend can only get there. So whenever we go to Marrakech, we have to go to the Jardins Majorelle to restock her supply!There is a little gallery with some lovely samples of Yves Saint Laurent's artwork, books, and photos of Marrakech.It is best to get there early, or certainly out of season, as it can get quite crowded, which does rather spoilt the lovely peace and calm.
Very relaxing. If your into gardens, beauty, relaxing and just a stroll this ones the one for you!! Holding hands and walking though with the love of my life was amazing!!

Nice - But not as big as I thought it would be. But the museum was ace.. The gardens were nice and given the current exchange rates cheap to visit, but I thought they would be a bit more extensive. For a "round the world" garden there were a lot of cactii (which were fascinating in their variety), but felt it lacked a bit. It was though very pleasant to walk around and an oasis from the heat and bustle of Marrakesh. But... get the dual ticket to involve the Berber Museum. It may have only been four rooms, but it was fascinating and we spent a long time in there. It gave a really good insight into the background and history of the whole area and was well worth the visit, with informative displays of how the people have lived for the last millennia. If you are in Marrakesh, well worth going to for the museum alone.
Lovely garden, once inside. This is a beautiful, refreshing and relaxing place to visit, once you find your way here through the not so pleasant surroundings.

Cactus galore!. Well worth a visit to view an extraordinary collection of plants, trees and cacti from around the world. A pleasant time wandering around the shady pathways - a welcome respite in sunny, hot Marrakech!

Inspiring garden. The palm trees, the different cactuses, the colours of the cobalt blue colour are stunning. The garden is small, so one can still have time for a glass of Moroccan tea. Don't forget to visit the berber museum

A must see!. absolutely stunning, very easy to find and the hotel offers a free shuttle bus service. This services is meant to take you to the main square but the driver will drop you off near the gardens if you ask for free too.

The most beautiful place in Marrakesh. This garden is full of trees (palmas, bamboo and many others) so dense that it is almost in permanent darkness and thanksAlso a water channel is there. In the shadow the climate here is very pleasant. The attendance fee is reasonable (around 5 EUR) despite the surface of the garden is quite small.

A cool oasis of calm. This is the place to go to beat the heat and noise for a few hours. There is a wonderful display of cacti and palm trees and it is nice to spend sometime walking around the shady paths next to the pools. The Berber museum is also worth a visit for its costumes and an appreciation of the culture and history of these proud people.

Oasis of calm and beauty. We spent 4 days in marrakech in jan 2014. The Jardin majorelle was a peaceful paradise with striking colours and beautiful gardens. Highly recommend a visit and I I imagine in the heat of the summer it would be a cooler place to be

Stunning Gardens. The gardens that were part of Yves Saint Laurent's estate are absolutely beautiful. You walk into an oasis of striking bamboo that makes the walk serene and tranquil. There were many different plant species and an abundance of cactus. Plants are well labeled and the meandering path over bridges and past ponds is very relaxing. The bright blue ceramics and tiles make the garden seem like a piece of design work. There is a lovely monument dedicated to Yves Saint Laurent and a room highlighting the artwork he used over the years for his holiday cards. Not a large place but definitely worth the visit if you enjoy natural beauty.

Jardin Majorelle. on the face of it I would not have selected this as somewhere to visit, but, having been there this is a very peaceful garden to visit. The colours are very vivid and reflects the mood. Not too far away from the noise and business of the medina. A tranquil worthwhile garden to look at.

Great escape from the crowds. Lovely gardens and a lovely place to have lunch , it was the perfect escape from the hustle and bustle of the souks .would definitely recommend.we had a lovely day weather was so warm and sunny and we took some super photos .
Beautiful and tranquil.. Well worth a visit to escape the hectic Marrakesh, as soon as you enter, it's peaceful and quiet and calm.
Oasis amongst the madness of Marrakech.. Very nice gardens. Bright colours amongst an abundance of different and interesting plants. Great cup of tea.

One of the most beautiful Jardin I ever have seen. No wonder any more, why Yves Saint Laurent wishes that his ashes should be spread in this particular garden. You don,t feel yourself beeing in Marrakech but beeing in Heaven. I have seen Paris, Wienna, Geneve, Nice... but this one in Marrakech is awesome!

Beautiful. Tip - if you are getting a taxi from jamaa el-fna it is no more than 20 dirhams , no matter what the driver tells you. We spent a lovely relaxing morning here, stunning place of tranquillity and beauty, worth every penny - don't follow the tours go the other way round and it's less busy. The YSL sections are lovely and pay to enter the museum it's very interesting and well presented. Before you go nip into the cafe for a drink, it's a bit expensive but the location and drinks are worth it. Well worth a visit.

peaceful oasis. We took a caleche from the square and got a sight-seeing trip as well. By arrangement the driver waited the 2 hours we were in the gardens, and the rate was very reasonable. The visit was everything we expected - lovely laid-out features with lots of shade, and a nice café area to have lunch. Well worth the visit.

My favourite visit in Marrakech. We were a group of four and I think we all thoroughly enjoyed these gardens..... so green, so lush, so exotic and so beautifully maintained (as all the public garden spaces in Marrakech seemed to be). Plant pots and buidlings are painted in vibrant blues and yellows which contrast wonderfully with the lush planting and the stillness of the beautiful calm water 'feature' (sorry, that word just does not do the long narrow pool justice). The museum was interesting and the Love Gallery delightful. The gift shop had some beautiful items but a little too pricey for us, also the book shop. There is a delightful little cafe with a courtyard garden - the food once again was pricey - we just had a coffee which was excellent. Disappointing was the memorial to Yves Saint-Laurant which was entirely dull and uninspiring. Also, I had not realised that the house that YSL had lived in was private and not open to the public. The street leading up to the gardens also has some charming little shops and it is easy to grab a caleche there for the ride back to town.

Oasis of calm. Surprisingly small but a welcome respite from the relentless African sun and the madness of the traffic. We chose to walk from our Riad in the Medina and, although this was late January and therefore relatively cool, we were still grateful to escape the busy streets for the quiet and shade of this delightful little garden. Even at this time of year it was busy so I imagine there would be queues forming in the summer months. I guess the best time of day to visit would be early in the morning. And take a taxi – they're cheap, they'll drop you at the entrance and you'll not risk life and limb trying to cross the roads on foot!

Tranquility amongst the madness. I love the Jardin Majorelle - it is a truly beautiful and peaceful place to spend an hour or so - the colours are vibrant and you can get some marvellous pictures.After the hustle and bustle of the streets outside, it's like stepping into another world when you cross the threshold. So much so that we were reluctant to leave
colorful garden as a contrast of busy marakesh. nice colorful place to be away of the busy city life; in spite of many visitors a relaxing experience

Beautiful Garden. Visited this garden in May whilst on a long weekend break to Marrakech. This was YSL's home for a number of years and his ashes were scattered here. It's a very beautiful place to stroll round and not expensive
Jardin Majorelle. These gardens are an oasis in a very busy city. Plenty of shade when the weather is very hot. Lovely coloured cacti . Interesting Yves St Laurent posters. Certainly worth a visit

garden to delight the senses. Get here early!!!!!!!!!........what could have been a glorious stroll through this not too big garden, was somewhat ruined by the masses of tourist that flocked here, around midday, one hot and sunny day. If you can snatch a brief respite from the crowds, you will be rewarded with stunning vistas, that attack your visual sences with the use of such vibrant blues, oranges, and yellows on the architecture and pots etc. The surrounding planting is somewhat of an antedote, to the bright hues of the buildings.The café is also worth a visit, if you can get in!!

well worth the trek. We hopped off the tour bus at the nearest stop to the gardens,well worth the moderate trek,it was a stylish oasis of calm,tranquility and beauty in the midst of the hot,mad streets
Beautiful and tranquil. This was lovely to walk around and soak up the YSL experience; colours and plants were spectacular. Museum of the berbers was also really interesting.

An oasis!. It is an oasis of peace (and greenery) in the middle of Marrakech. It's very well kept with a good variety of exotic flowers and different kind of trees. Owned by Ives Saint Laurent - it was his refuge (and personal garden) for many years. The Berber Museum is inside the "Jardin Majorelle" and it's an amazing place to visit as well - not to be missed.Even though it turned to be smaller (in size) that I was expecting - it is a very beautiful place to visit once you are in Marrakech; especially, after a couple of days struggling through its overwhelmed bazars and attractions. I recommend it!

Colours. The stunning gardens are a cool retreat from the heat of The city. Well worth a visit, it's not a huge garden, it easy access for people with mobility difficulties. The use of cobalt blue and reds always blows me away. Had coffee in the restaurant, expensive, but a free bottle of cold water was given to us free of charge. Do visit, it's well worth it!

Soothing contrast to Medina. Calm, cool and peaceful despite being full of visitors. The main appeal is the contrast to the hustle and bustle of life in the Medina and Souks. We went on a very hot day and counted the taxi fare worth the saving of feet and heat. On the recommendation of our host, we walked down to the street corner after the visit and avoided the line of overinflated set price taxis outside the entrance.

An oasis in busy Marrakech. Beautifully landscaped garden with lots of palm trees and bamboo. Very busy with lots of tourists but if you sit down on a bench and see everyone walk by it's actually also part of the fun.The pavilion is very nice too.

Lovely,calm garden. Well worth it!. This is a great place to spend tranquil time resting from the intensity of exploring the city. Sorry we didn't learn about the great museum until after we left. Others said it was very worthwhile.

Tranquil & quiet away from the hustle & bustle of the old medina .. Easy to get to , not far from the old medina area and you can get to it by using "The Big Red Bus" and getting off at the scheduled stops and get back on.Jardin Majorelle is an oportunity for an excellent photo oportunity even for the very inexperienced with buitiful colours and greeenery and settings all through the gardens that make this place a truely magical experience , hard to beleive this small oasis is in the middle of an arid area .Memorable time.

Worth the visit!. Worth the visit! We had read some conflicting reviews on this spot prior to our visit, but are so glad we went. Just beautiful! I can't wait to edit and print my photos, plan to frame them for sure. It is not a huge place, as some of the critics here report, but there is certainly enough there to keep you busy for 45min to an hour. And the memories will last forever (; they need to figure out how to prevent the graffiti on the plants though-it's killing some of them );

Magnificent blues. The cacti are amazing and very healthy looking but the star is the blue walls and pottery as an ensemble. Parts of the garden made one feel one was going to come across Manet painting. A must-go site.
Awesome. Wow complete tranquility and a little oasis with Marrakech , beautiful beautiful beautiful . The YSL love gallery was fabulous . I had a fabulous few hours here worth every penny .
Beautiful. If you are in Marrakech, you must make the effort to visit this gem of a garden.. Very unique. And the colors are so vivid!! The blue is stunning.

Small but peaceful. Good place to go to on a hot day. Lots of shade with benches to sit down. The plants are minimal for those who are used to more variety; however, those that are there are arranged in a very aesthetic way. I would rate it 3.5 if that was possible.
Colour and coolness. It was peaceful and cool and at last some colour other than orange. wish I'd gone into the Museum as even looking through the door it looked interesting.

Blue is the coolest color. An amazing garden surrounding a villa painted in the coolest cobalt blue that's used often by YSL. The fashion house mogul has established a fund to maintain the property and there's a small room housing a collection of his cards.

The Garden is the draw but the museum is remarkable. Whiile the garden is the definite draw here-- and it certainly is lovely and beautifully laid out and enjoyed-- the Berber museum is absolutely not to be missed. That is the real jewel of a visit here. It is one of the best small museums we have ever visited anywhere. Brilliantly curated and imaginatively presented.

This is a delightful garden and their Museum is a "Must See" extremely well executed. It was on the Berbers.. The garden is quiet, the design is simple, beautiful display of cactus and a lovely waterlily pond. There is a very cool place to have a drink and something to eat. We ate there and it was delicious and the staff extremely helpful. The Exhibition was terrific and the shops were extremely good.

An oasis in the chaos of the city. Cannot say how wonderful this place is.Absolutely adored it. The peace and tranquility were a welcome break from the hustle and bustle of the souks and the heat!!. With plants and trees from the five continents of the world the fusion of colours,smells and differing shapes and sizes are breathtaking. Truly inspirational. Thankfully it was not overly busy as I think it could get quite claustrophobic and uncomfortable ,due to the narrowness of some of the walkways, if there were too many people there. However my understanding is that it never gets overly busy. Very reasonably priced entrance fee and some wonderful photo opportunities of some of the more unusual plants and trees.

A tranquil space. Our visit here was very peaceful and chance to get some shade from the Moroccan sun. It was such a contrast to the hustle & bustle of Marrakech, and we had a lovely time meandering through the bamboos, many succulents, and cacti. We didn't eat at the cafe as we know of quite a few people who've had upset stomachs after eating there (whilst being fine with street food) but it did look a very pleasant courtyard to stop and rest. We'd walked around the whole place in 45 minutes, but for me it was well worth the 50 dirhams.
Serene and Stylish. A must do for Marrakesh. The most beautiful peaceful gardens acquired by Yves Saint Laurent. In the heat of the day there's nowhere better to retreat to. Wonderful.
Amazing. This was beautiful! It was a walk outside of the city, which we didn't mind but it may be easier to get a cab. It was so amazing and so worth the trip!

FOR GARDEN LOVERS ! SHOW UP AT 08am !!. This is the place to go if you like gardens and especially different forms of cactus , beatifully arranged round ponds erc.Its not large, remember its a townhouse garden !Rose , tulip, hibiscus etc lovers will be disappointed.We loved it and spent an hour or so there and were glad that we showed up as the gates opened( 8 pm every day except in Rammadan when its 9am)
gorgeous gardens. this is a beautiful garden so different and calming. It is several degrees cooler stepping into the garden from the outside... cant believe this place is in the middle of the city!

Great price,lovely pictures. It was just 50 dirhams to enter and we got some lovely pictures, there are many cactuses to see and a pretty pond with beautiful flowers on and turtles in if you look hard enough.
A simple garden.. We expected a large lush garden, and admittedly, it is a nice garden for the middle of a desert, but otherwise a waste of time.
Not to be missed. loved this place, so gorgeous. The colours were breathtaking and the gardens so beautifully kept, a real memorial to Yves St Laurent

Beautiful garden. If you like garden, this is the place for you. Truly beautiful place to spend a couple of hours. However, a bit expensive on a budget. It costs 50 dirhams for entrance. And you would have to pay more to visit the berbers' museum inside. Everything there is quite pricey

Beautiful Gardens. Beautiful gardens in Marrakech. We did have to take a petit taxi from our hotel (Le Meridien), but it was not more than 30 MDH. The gardens were beautiful and the trees and plants provided an adequate amount of shade from the hot Moroccan sun. The museum was another 30 MDH inside the garden, and it was a great insight into the historical progression of another culture. I especially enjoyed the tribute to YSL and the few of his art pieces displayed within the gardens a few steps away from his monument. Definitely a relaxing way to start a busy day in Marrakech!

Go early. We were told this was a "must visit" at our riad and it was already on the list. Attractive gardens and cool breezes make it pleasant to wander round but go early to avoid tour groups. Shop and cafe overpriced. A taxi from the medina to gardens should be 30 dirham and nothing much else in the area.

A lovely garden in the noonday heat!. Don't go expecting manicured lawns, panoramic vistas, lakes, grottoes or statuary - this is more like a walk through through the palm house of a botanic garden! The paths meander around pools with water lilies in full bloom, bamboo plantations rustling in the breeze, cacti sweltering in the summer sun and palm trees of all different shapes and sizes. Not to mention many other plants combining together to give wonderful aspects just crying out for pictures to be painted or photos to be taken!The colours are amazing; from the cobalt blue and brilliant yellows of the planters to the pink and purple of bougainvillea not forgetting the flash of gold from the goldfish in the ponds.It's a lovely spot to while away an hour or two in the heat of the day with plenty of seating provided and a cafe to refresh yourself, if you can afford the prices!Mornings in the gardens seem to be pretty busy with large groups of tourists being shown around but by noon, it had quietened down.By the way, the main entrance gates are locked; if you are standing looking at these gates, you need to continue down the main road to the right and the small entrance for the public is down a side street, usually choked with caleches, taxis and coaches!

Hidden gem of a garden. How do they make such a beautiful place in a desert?Well worth a visit and also see the museum. Worth taking a Caleche (horse carriage) from the main square to take in the sif=ghts on the way.

Oasis of Calm. We visited the gardens early on Sunday morning before the coach tours arrived and enjoyed their tranquility. The colours and the light are fantastic and complement the plants perfectly. They are immaculately clean and tidy with gardeners constantly sweeping dust and flower-petals from the floor. A place I will never forget!
Serene. Beautiful and tranquil. A real treat away from the hustle and bustle. Take a picnic and just chill out. Or sit in tthe Café.

Cool, colourful and full of beauty. Probably our best find in Marrakech. Much smaller than the Menara. gardens, but a brilliantly designed network of paths through cool and shade, sun and water, water lilies and cacti, with lots of places to simply sit and chill. Great colours - man made and natural - and lots of photograph opportunities.

Traquil Oasis. We spent a lovely morning wondering around the garden, it’s hard to explain, it feels so busy but yet so peaceful, tranquil is defiantly a good description. The garden is full of a wide variety of plants and scrubs. It costs D50 to enter the Garden and a further D25 to enter the museum. Its about a 15 minute walk from the outskirts of the medina. We planned to eat lunch in the café, we had been informed that the food was really good, we weren’t disappointed. A visit to Jardin Majorelle is a must while in Marrakesh

A beautiful paradise in Marrakech. In my opinion this is one of the best places to go to properly relax in Marrakech. Enclosed by huge trees separating the fumes and noises of Moroccan life you forget where you are. You can even take a nap on one of the many benches. There's plenty of shade if you're thinking of bringing small children here, and a cafe to rest your legs with a refreshment, but not really for a backpacker budget. Learning the history behind the park also adds to your visit, you get a small flyer with your ticket explaining the background. There is a fantastic array of over 300 different species of plant, including a great cacti garden. The park is full of contrasting colours, making the green from the trees look really lovely. When we went it was relatively quiet, people were respecting each other; reading, napping, drawing etc which was lovely. There is a very small room in one corner filled with posters of Yves Saint Laurent's 'Love' collage artwork he made every New Years. You can buy postcards of these from the shop opposite which is a cheap way to remember your visit and take away something colourful.The only thing I would advise is taking a large bottle of water as you can only buy small un-refridgerated bottles inside the park for a steep price. Packing a small lunch might be a good idea too as lunch at the restaurant is a little overpriced. Overall, it's a lovely place in the city to waste away a few hours if you like, or just visit for half an hour. I got the impression I could've stayed all day. There is NO need to get a horse and cart if you arrive by taxi and it drops you a street away - it's only down the road!

Money machine. The garden is probably vast and beautiful but tourist are packed in a tiny corner with mostly bamboos. What a disappointment to walk along the outer wall for 500 meters and to see lots of flower above the wall to discover that you're stuck in a 50m by 30m corner with very basic features.
Stunning. Beautiful serene oasis. Lovely place for some peace away from the medina. Had a superb lunch in the café. A must visit!

Jardin Marjorelle. The most serene space to walk in. Fantastic array of plants trees and foliage. The Cacti are so sculpturally spectacular. I loved the cobalt blue that featured heavily on the buildings and pool surrounds, so typically Moroccan. Got some super photos. Really enjoyed the Berber museum. Cafe god was'nt bad either.

Good value. An oasis in the madness!. We spent a lively morning in the peace and tranquility of these gardens. We were recommended to visit by a friend, and were not disappointed. A lovely setting in the middle of the madness, only a 15minute walk from the main medina. A very peaceful & tranquil morning. Although you are sprung upon by "sales people" at the main gate, trying to sell to you watched, hats or tissues, the gardens and the museum are worth every penny. The cafe there is also worth a visit. It can get a little crowded at time, but if you visit at the right time, then you will not be disappointed.

beautiful, photographic, lovely cafe. I've been here twice now, once in May and then again in June. Both visits we so different, the plants/flowers were at different stages. On saying that though, I'd recommend going mid week rather than weekend and on the coolest day of your trip. The cafe is lovely. The museum is FASCINATING and you must go to the Love Gallery too!

Paradise. This is a lovely spot to spend a few hours away from the frantic activity of Marrakech. It is an oasis of calm. There is a lovely shop on the premises as well as a very small but good museum - when we visited - there was an excellent exhibition of the Berber culture. Highly recommend it. It is a definite must see. Although we did not eat at the restaurant, my understanding is that it serves well prepared Moroccan food.

Unexpected oasis in Marrakech. I expected a garden and found an "art work". No pretty flowers just plants chosen for their shape and colour. Walls and structures painted cobalt blue against brilliant yellow. Unusual and definitely worth a visit.

Lovely Place to Relax. We were there late afternoon and were tired from a long and hot day of sightseeing. It was a great late afternoon spot as the gardens were shaded and you could sit and relax.Do visit the Berber Museum. It is small, but nicely done.
A must see in Marrakesh. Small but beautiful. Worth going. Perfect escape from the centre. We also had a dinner in the restaurant inside... which was quite ok for such a touristic spot.
peaceful. This place is great definitely a highlight of the trip if you want to leave the madness that is Marrakech go here

Getting Lost in Morocco. Jardin Majorelle is a must see attraction along with the Berber Museum located inside. We found the pace leisurley but crowed. You had to wait your turn when it came to photographing various spots within the gardens. But it was worth it. The staff on hand were very helpful when it came to explaining certain aspects and even offered to take your photo with a beautiful backdrop. All without asking for a tip or a ransom for your camera. They gave the impression they really liked being there, answering questions and being of service to the guests.The same held true for the Berber Museum. No photos were allowed and you had to carry your backpack in your hand (to avoid accidently knocking into anything). The staff was very helpful providing a lamenated card offering descriptions of the items on display. They were very attentive and made sure no one tried to "sneak" a picture with their phone or camera. Worth the time to visit.If you need a taxi afterwards, there are plenty just outside the exit. Just be sure to bargain and lock in a fare before getting into the cab.

Peaceful & beautiful. Not too expensive at 50 MAD, offering a visit into a brief but colourful and enchanting garden, with subtle YSL tribute. Cafe wasn't particularly expensive, and had wonderful thin fries, tasty mint tea, and pleasant staff.

Chill and relax. Great to visit in the afternoon when it's hot and sunny since it's cooler hiding under trees and other plants! Nice garden for photos. Also, there is a Berber museum inside that cannot be missed.

Oasis in the dessert. We can see why Yves Saint Laurent loved this place. Beautifully maintained and wonderful café in the middle as well as lovely gift shop. Would have liked a little more English translations. Looking forward to seeing it featured in the upcoming YSL movie

Oasis of calm.. A great place to visit, the place is full of vibrant colours (you expect nothing less from the former home of Yves Saint Laurent). The plant collection offers some respite by providing much needed shade from the Moroccan sun. The gardens are well laid out, spacious & colourful (with plenty of places to sit & relax to just take it all in). It's also a great place for a budding photographer to hone their skills.Also, be sure to visit the Berber museum (you have to pay extra to enter as this brilliant museum isn't included in the garden entrance fee). The collection of artefacts, photo's & video's on show give a great insight into the Berber way of life (the women's head dress collection is pretty amazing, it's just a shame that you aren't allowed to take photo's inside the museum).The on-site cafe is excellent, if a little bit on the expensive side! But if you want quality, you normally have to pay that little bit more.
Worth the trip. Gardens are exotic desert plants. Museum is well worth it. good on site cafe. very relaxing. good place to go and hang out

Lovely story behind the garden. This was our second visit to the gardens and a little disappointed as the water ponds were very discoloured where as last year they were beautifully clean. Also, trying the cafe this year we went into the conservatory area and it really could do with a good old spruce up as it was looking like a faded glory, however, the gardens are well worth a visit and wonderfully designed with a wonderful story behind it but wouldn't go again.

Peace and quiet from market mayhem. Open 0800 to 1800 with large gardens full of cacti and bamboo groves and arches. Created in 1919 by Jacques Majorelle a French artist and botanist 1886-1962. Nice café with courtyard and small restaurant (UK prices). 40 MAD entry (discounted for student to 30 with ISIC card) 20 MAD extra entry to berber museum of Islamic art and costume. WC free. Allow 2 hours. Also: Shop, Libray and bookshop, Majorelles blue Villa, 12 basins and fountains... Don't miss the YSL Art Gallery with one LOVE new years greeting cards - paintings per year from 1962 until his recent death in 2008. Cards accepted over 300 MAD.

Serenity and Shade.. Calm, tranquil, gardens with excellent variety of 100 Cacti and Bamboo created by Jacques Majorelle and maintained by YSL until his recent death and now by YSL Trust. Also features: YSL Memorial stone column where his ashes are scattered, Majorelle famous blue villa home, several ponds and fountains. Perfect place for a picnic in the peaceful surroundings on one of the many benches with a view. Discounted entry to Gardens for ISIC (only) student card holders. Cash or Cards over 300 MAD (£21) accepted. Also Café (UK prices), Bookshop, YSL Art Gallery, Shop, Berber History Museum (Payable extra). Facilities: WC, Benches. Visit their Website or FB page for more information. Best time to visit afternoon to escape the sun and heat; busy with tour groups AM. Don't walk there as outside Medine and Walls, get a public Taxi and agree price before you get in (incl. tip). Safe and secure. Taxis rank outside to get you home but do walk first and see the quarters elegant cafes and shops and YSL's villa home outside next door. www.jardinmajorelle.com
nice little place. A cooling relief from the chaos of marrakech. Nice well kept gardens with a nice museum and cafe. a must for any holiday in Marrakech
A real gem. Closes at 6 in summer so go around 4.. Amazing colours & a peaceful haven . Photogenic. Taxi anywhere back 100 MAD but insist, as they pay a fee to park near the garden.
Loved it. Well worth a visit just stunning stylish and you can imagine the party's that must of been held here , Really enjoyed our trip here .
It's a garden.. It has cacti, it has some nice blue walls, an expensive restaurant and some ponds. Go there if you want, I don't think Yves St Lauren would have minded either way.

beautiful garden. we really liked being in such as green place in Marrakech. It's a breathtaking garden with blue walls, and different kinds of flowers and plants. My kids got an insight about many plants there! It's a great place to visit in Marrakech!

Slightly disappointed. Not sure why, but I was expecting acres of manicured gardens, given the fact this attraction was billed as a must see.It's nice enough, but you'll only need 15 minutes or so to walk around the gardens themselves, which are beautiful albeit relatively one dimensional in terms of the fauna.You'll need to take a taxi here if you're staying in the Medina and if you're pressed for time in terms of what to pack into a short visit, then unless you're a real fan of gardens or YSL then you might want to give this one a miss.

OK. I didn't quite get it. The garden was nice although far too many people there. After winding through a bamboo forest it opened out into various pleasant vistas. I was disappointed at how small it was. The museum has some interesting things in but they charge you again to go in.

Nice place to visit.. We went here as it's advertised as one of the main attractions in Marrakech, it was nicely laid out and we enjoyed a relaxed walk around.Café is pricey, the museum is very good and it's worth a visit.

Beautiful gardens. Beautiful gardens but way too busy. Wish we had gone early or later to miss the crowds. Didn't eat in the cafe as it was so pricey. Nice museum staff throughout museum and gardens a bit rude!

small but beautifull. It was the last place I visited in Marrakech and I was a little affraid that I will pay, again, for nothing. I am very glad that I did pay, it was a hot day and the place was amazing. The colors, the bamboo forest and the small lake with lilies were worth the entry fee. There is a book store inside and a Yves Saint Laurent store, with prices to match the name, so you can shop a litle if you have the money and the time :P.The gardens are small, but you can take a book with you and something to eat, and just stay there on a bench and have a small picnic. There are no food stores inside, so you should bring your own. We had some cakes with us and wather and it was very nice to just stay and savor the cakes (there were the only good thing we could find in Marocco, they do not have any sweets the are worth the money).The entry fee was 50DH.Before you go, you should check out the website for the visiting hours. I posted them here, but in case something changes. Open every day of the yearOctober 1 – April 30: 8 am – 5:30 pmMay 1 – September 30 : 8 am – 6 pmThe month of Ramadan: 9 am – 5 pmGarden and Museum: wheel-chair accessible

A wonderful oasis in the city. Was better than we anticipated : a must for gardeners and a pleasure for anyone who want a break from the hot pink city of Marrakesh. The berber museum ( the "Berbers" hate to be called like that as it derived from the Romans calling them Barbari- the real name is AMAZIGH) is small but extremely fine and representative of the many rich crafts.

The Majorelle is A calm place in this Red city.. According to our private tour guide, The Majorelle Gardens were donated to Marrakech by Yves Sant-Laurent. Yves has a phallic pink memorial in the Gardens. Although Morocco is a relatively liberal Islamic country, it's still slightly odd to wander the former home of such an overtly gay celebrity. In the souks a shopkeeper was trying to sell me a pouf - "it is a pouf not a poof - we don't like those here either". Yves Sant-Laurent loved the city, though, and there's a definite ambivalence to homosexuality in Marrakech. You only have to wander the Djemaa el Fna and witness the cross-dressing men dancing seductively and clashing their zils with a rhythmic passion to see that. This behaviour is not just tolerated, but watched with great interest and cheered on by the mostly male crowds that gather around.Yves didn't build the gardens, he bought them. They were originally laid out by French artist Jacques Majorelle when Morocco was still a colony of France. The gardens are marked by their extensive use of a strong cobalt blue paint, this colour became known as Majorelle Blue. It's a beautiful and tranquil oasis and a great place to escape to when the crowds of Marrakech start to overwhelm you !!
lovely gardens. beautiful peaceful gardens, lovely and tranquil visit, close to Medina..... a nice way to spend an hour and see the lovely gardens
relaxing garden visit. a tribute to Yves St Lauren and a visit to these gardens is a perfect way to spend a couple of hours relaxing and well worth the £3.75 entrance fee.

For label devotees. It's a nice little (100m square) cactus garden. It's only worth a taxi ride and 5 euros if you really like cacti, or YSL. The usual taxi madness outside (no one will use their meter if you're a tourist).

Don't waste your time and money. As an experienced traveler who tries to stay out of tourist traps, all I can say is: what a hustle. First, to get there, you will have a very difficult time finding a cab willing to take you for metered fare. They all demand at least 50 Dirham (fair price on the meter is about 17) and say this is the standard "special" price for Majorelle gardens. I had to start walking towards nearby police officer before the coalition of petit taxi drivers standing there would finally relent and give me a fair price on the meter. Once you get there, you find out that admission is 50 Dirham per person. For Moroccan prices, this price implies to me that you're about to see something really incredible. Okay, so you buy the ticket and walk in. Oh boy!! What's in there?! You see a small garden, packed to the gills with tour groups who have been dumped by the busload. It's far too packed to stroll properly, and no one quite knows what to do there, so many people are taking banal selfies and cactus macros with their phones to the extent that you can't enjoy what little that this garden has to offer. Fifteen minutes later, after two circles around the pathways, we began anew the exciting journey of finding a metered cab back to the city center. Only this time, the hustle is systematic! There's a man standing out front with a clipboard who will arrange for you to get into a cab for 50 Dirham. Ignore him, and walk a few blocks away from the tourist area and flag down a cab that isn't circling. Either get him on the meter, or offer him 20 Dirham to Marrakesh center (this worked for us). When we got into the cab, the first question we were asked: "so, second time in Morocco, huh?" No, first time actually; tourist hustling operates about the same the world-over.In summary, I found this garden to be highly emblematic of Yves Saint Laurent and the fashion industry that he embodied: overrated and overpriced.
John & Shelagh June 2014. Beautiful, tranquil, delightful. Wonderful Cafe/restaurant - great Berber Museum - take a camera - wonderful

Total serenity within Marrakech. The gardens are a pleasure to stroll around. Plenty of shade. It's the peacefulness and the calm that quite takes your breath away, very unique and definitely worth a visit.

Tranquillity. This was my second visit about 10 years apart. A few changes, all for the good, have taken place in the garden. Although very busy it is possible to have moments on one's own, sitting on a bench and just absorbing the beauty. The café makes good coffee.
Impressive. In the middle of one of the major cities of todays world, this is an oasis of rest, smells and beatifull colors.
Lovely gardens - worth a visit. Beautiful spaces, tranquil and cool haven. Water features were lovely. Worth a half hour visit - but very busy.

“Beautiful”. Would defintely recommend a visit to this place, it is so quiet and peaceful compared to the city. There is a lovely little Berber museum which is worth a visit. Defintiely a place to escape from the hustle and bustle.

A Calm Oasis in the Madness of Marrakech. We visited on our last day in Marrakech and spent the full day enjoying the changing light of the garden. Do not miss the Berber Museum, it was one of the highlights of Morocco. We took time to enjoy the cafe both for a coffee break and lunch. I will return!
Add to your 'to do list'. This is a beautiful calm garden with plenty of shade. Lots of great photo opportunities and reasonably priced. It was amongst the top 5 things I've seen in Marrakesh
Fantastic. If you only visit one garden in Marrakech this is the one ! very peaceful and great planting and only 5 MAD entry bargain !

cool garden. a cool refreshing lovely garden to visit in order to relax
lots of beautifull trees and big choice of cactus variety
great place for a snack and cold drink too when very boiling outisde

The blue peace. Go there and enjoy, definitely worth for the unique pieces you can see and the beautiful garden. As many public attractions there it is cheap to visit and overall not far from the center.

Incredibly beautiful but crowded. Get there early! This is a major tourist attraction, but definitely worth dealing with the number of guests to get a view of the gardens and museum.The plants and flowers are beautiful and the striking blue buildings that once belong to Yves Saint Laurent are impressive along with the Berber Museum inside the former artist's atelier. There's a decent restaurant serving fresh fruit juices, sandwiches and tea with shady areas to sit.
Oasis in the middle of busy city. It is a beautiful garden, away from the noise and dust of the city. Well worth a visit to take some time out and relax in the shade.
Majorelle blue. Beautiful garden and home of Yves Saint Laurent.The former house of the Painter Majorelle is painted in a vibrant blue. Situated in the new part of Marrakech

Beautiful garden in Marrakech. Definitely worth including in a visit to Marrakech. This garden is an oasis of palms, cacti, towering stands of bamboo, water features, exotic flowers, and birds. The richly painted buildings add to the beauty of this garden. The small Berber museum exhibits tribal clothing that clearly distinguishes the differences in dress among the various tribes throughout Moroccan history.
Blue Oasis. The garden itself is a cool oasis with greenery dramatically set off with swaths of cobalt and yellow. The museum of Moroccan costume, jewelry and artifacts is exquisite.

A stunning small garden with nice restaurant. This is a lovely oasis in Marrakech, varied pretty plants in an interesting layout with a Berber Museum in YSL's house. There is a great cafe for tea and light meals with a courtyard and covered areas. Go early or late to avoid crowds. In June it the admission was roughly £3.50 for adults.
Small but well worth seeing. Nice quiet area away from the hassle of Marrakesh. Great water features and well planned dessert garden
Adorable!. Went with my friends to have a nice afternoon walk! So cute, with a lot of trees, cactus, coloured decoration, fresh air and Berber Museum! Great place to spend some time!
Trip out. A lovely garden in a busy city nice for avid gardeners due to good labelling and a very pretty place to vist.

Beautiful, calm and cool!. Although the gardens are not huge it was cool seeing all the different types of plants. The famous blue and yellow paint used throughout was gorgeous and great for taking a few snaps! Its also a great little hideaway from the heat and hustle of the city :)

A manicured oasis. Located about 30 min walk from Jem al Fna Place, these gardens were enhanced over four decades by Yves St-Laurent and his partner, Jacques Berger. They are an oasis within Marrakech and they are definitely worth a visit. Plants from around the world thrive in this rather dry environment, there is a water canal and beautiful basins. The architecture is rather striking and there is also a small Berber museum, a true gem, with exhibits about traditional berber daily life and artifacts (an additional fee is required). The museum, although small, is the high point of the visit. There is also a small restaurant for snacking or a cool drink.
Tranquil and revitilising. when you consider how intense and overbearing Marrakech can be, the Jardin Majorelle is a great breather; beautiful to look at, quiet and calming.

Beautiful gardens for a short retreat. Very pleasant gardens to walk around - giving peace and tranquility. These are the gardens of Yves Saint Laurent and also his home. Certainly worth a visit and a good photo op.
Beautiful Gardens. Not that big but definitely worth a look. Styled beautifully, every type of cactus you can imagine! The colours are stunning.

ENCHANTING ATMOSPHERE. The garden, the little berber museum, the exposition of Yves Saint Laurent (greeting cards designs for friends and clients from 1970)... very chic! In this twelve acre botanical garden, the "Majorelle blue" is the star, a ultramarine blue created by the french painter Jacques Majorelle.

to bad it's so small. this was the last of our trip, and I'm glad we visit it, because the other palaces and so on were a bust. The yard it's impressive because of the bamboos and the mini lake that is full of water lilies.

Beautiful tranquil gardens. Loved this little oasis of calm with enormous cool bamboo, huge cacti and many other beautiful plants and flowers. Great for photography or art with all the brightly coloured pots. Recommend.

Beautiful!!. The beautiful home and gardens of Yves Saint Laurent were definitely worth a visit. The gardens are welcomingly cool in the heat of the day and a peaceful spot in which to sit and reflect. There is a lovely café and a YSL shop and exhibition of his Love posters. So glad that we didn't miss out on this delight!!

Touristy attraction. Good for those who like to holiday in home like places away from home, completely westernized included paved streets. As this is not my type of holiday I would've rather spent my money and time walking the streets of the new town. Nothing special about this Jardin.

Beautiful. Beautiful garden, the collection of plants is quite impressive, the design is amazing It is very small though. there is a charming restaurant/ caffe in there as well. It is very touristic, and the place is usually always full of people. The taxi drivers will hassle you as soon as you come out.
Our favourite attraction in Marrakech. Beautiful exotic gardens, vibrant colours, very atmospheric - particularly having just seen the French film about Yves Saint-Laurent.

An oasis in the city. This garden is beautifully presented and is an oasis within the busy city area. We enjoyed the variety of plants from around the world and the microclimate within the garden that enables them to thrive.

probably a bit overrated!. Beautiful gardens but we felt they were a bit over rated. The garden is not very big, you could have a complete tour in 15min. Just a bit of calm and order in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Marrakesh!
Beautiful!. Beautiful amazing place!!! There is a small cafe too, service is very slow, took 20mins to bring out one very small banana split but beautiful surroundings.
Beautiful. A bit crowded so I would advise to go early. Otherwise it is beautiful. Make sure you enough space on your memory card as you will take a lot of pictures of everything!!

Peaceful Oasis in the midst of chaos. Well worth a visit whilst in Marrakech. Not large but beautifully laid out, calm, serene and very well kept. Lovely little gallery and shop and lots of spots to sit and appreciate your surroundings. There was a restaurant within the gardens but we didn't try it so cannot comment.
Beautiful blue. Magnificent gardens a little bit of paradise in the big city - you can certainly see why Yves St Laurent fell in love with the place!

Peaceful and cool. This intricate garden is beautifully planted and decorated in bright colors. The bright blue accents, however, grace it with a cooling serenity. Couples, seniors, and a group of preschoolers and their teachers shared the visit with us. There were many people visiting, but the garden did not seem crowded. Kudos to the landscape architects!

Yves St. Lauren's garden gift to Marrakech. worth a visit. Plants are out of this world. Small garden but glorious.
I especially liked the cacti section as it was so different and the variety was enormous. Can get very busy due to coach parties so go early. Walked there from our hotel in the old part of town.
Expensive but nice. It is pricy for Marrakech but it' did provide an enjoyable hour or so Porthole a trip if your at a loose end.

Waste of time. Not very big and not worth the trip unless you have a particular interest in cacti and blue paint.
Very disappointing.

A Very Special Garden. This garden is special and impressive, don't miss it! A beautiful lovely well maintained garden with many varied plants, including different species of cactus, and also bamboos. Though it is not of big scale, it is very interesting and photogenic. There is a small museum focusing on Berber culture, which is pleasant and well presented.

Lovely little place. Would defintely recommend a visit to this place, it is so quiet and peaceful compared to the city. There is a lovely little Berber museum which is worth a visit. Defintiely a place to escape from the hustle and bustle.
Loved this garden, don't miss if you are in Marrakech. A peaceful oasis with giant cacti and bamboo, fountains and peace. Interesting Museum of North African dress very good cafe,
Beautiful Gardens. The gardens were extremely well maintained. A little oasis in the heart of Marrakesh away from the hussle and bustle. Worth the entrance money.
Jardin majorelle. When you like gardens and plants you have to see jardin majorelle.even when it is warm, you have shadow there

Great tourist spot. Brilliant quiet escape from a very busy city. Yves San Laurent must have loved this place One could spend the best part of a morning here (or an Afternoon) in the peaceful setting well maintained still by the locals.
Beautiful. What a tranquil, lovely quiet place to visit. If you are into photography the perfect place for you. The cafe was a gorgeous courtyard with delicious treats. Well worth a visit.

Flora & Fauna Lovers. It's a good break from the city's hustle and bustle. I love the cactus garden in particular. They have a berber museum so make sure your ticket includes that as well.
The garden was just ok for me. I would probably give it a miss the next time I am back in Marrakech
YsL Had impeccable taste. Just beautiful and well cared for gardens. The colours of the house and the various gardens are breathtaking. Brunch in the restaurant is a must.

Beautiful Gardens. Beautiful tranquil gardens which were well worth the walk! We'd been told about an hour from our Riad but we wandered and got a little lost (nothing major) so it took us two hours. But it was so worth it, the gardens are stunning. The cafe/restaurant serves lovely food too.

A must see in Marrakech. The Majorelle Gardens are almost breathtaking in their beauty and variety. The Berber Museum on the grounds is a fairly quick introduction to Berber arts, crafts, culture. The Gardens are a nice respite from the hustle bustle of the medina.

One of the most beautiful gardens I 've ever seen. Species from all over the world contained in this magical garden. The colors were so vivid and the design was so clean and simple, yet you were just enchanted. Nothing I disliked.

Serene..well maintained..educational. The gardens are beautiful and well maintained. The layout makes the most of the available space. Gardeners tend their plants as you wander through and birds sing from above in this oasis from the exterior environment. The option Berber Museum contains a wonderful display of Berber cultural artefacts including clothing and jewellery from different regions. A quality Cafe offers a relaxing refreshment at the end of your tour.

Incredible!!. This was definitely the highlight of Marrakech for me. It was so tranquil within the thick walls and so incredibly peaceful. The vibrant colours of the pots are a beautiful contrast to the greenery. It must have been a very inspiring place to have lived in...
Beautiful gardens. Very tranquil place ...and was beautiful done. The blue is stunning with the sun shining on it. Was very busy in there when we went though. Cool n shady when very hot.

lovely. was expecting a large venue , however its a very unique botanical garden , with a coffee shop, a mini library, a boutique and a museum & of course the tomb of Yves Saint Laurent who loved Morocco
Worth seeing. Definitely a tourist spot but beautiful. Be sure to head across the street to Rue 33 for some interesting finds of Moroccan craftsmanship.

Stunning. A must see when in Marrakech. These gardens are beautifully laid out. They are shaded and cool even on very hot days. The enormous cacti and the lily pond, complete with terrapins were my favourite areas. The cafe looked lovely and toilets were very clean. Taxis wait outside to take you to the next sight or back to your hotel.

Nice garden to cool off and have a day rest with families.. One of the best place to visit in Marrakech, garden is well maintained and it is a lovely place to sit and ease all your worries away and enjoy what nature has to offer.

an oasis. beautiful, quiet and calm...even with ALL of the tourists that were there! The number of plants is astonishing and the little Berber museum has many beautiful exhibits. Would certainly go back.

Pretty awesome...too small.. If you go here try to go with a guide or read a head about what it is and the history. The place is not big nor a lot to see but it a lot of meaning and stuff behind everything. In all actuality it is something that you should see if you are several days in Morocco.

Desert-City Oasis. Once inside this garden I felt I was a million miles away from the noise/chaos of the city. The quiet, shaded pathways were perfect for silent contemplation. The variety of desert flora was incredible. The garden is so well laid out - it invites one to wander. The main house/villa painted in an electric blue is beautiful and the museum, while small, is well worth a visit.
Beautiful tropical garden. Beautiful tropical garden. It is very small; not a lot to see. You can do this entire garden in 15mins.

A calm and relaxinh walk. We got a taxi to the marjorelle gardens as it is too hot to walk, and were surprised by the queues. We joined the end as it was moving quickly, but the doorman ushered us to the door and murmured random prices. He was offering us entry for 30dh, which I think was going to be a "back pocket" job. He went and got our tickets handed us our change and lingered. I think he wanted a tip, but we didnt give him anything. The gardens are beautiful. Plenty of photo opportunities, although modern tourism has brought people to carve into the bamboo which was sad to see, rather like la casa di giulietta in verona. We enjoyed lunch in the cafe which was expensive but not too bad. Taxi drivers leap on you as you exit. Ignore their pleas of "it costs 10dh to park" and state your lowest price and walk away. You will find he grabs his keys and grumbles the same price. They would rather make a little than nothing at all! Xx

Another World. The Jardin Majorelle well worth a visit - so different from its surrounding, a haven of tranquility. It is beautiful and inspiring, in fact gave me lots of ideas for my own garden at home.
was nice. was nice to see and tick off our list, but next time ill hold onto my dihams and skip this one. there are nicer gardens and museums to see in marakesh over this!

beautiful. The Jardin Marjolle is amazing.
It's a very beautiful place.
It's a bit far from the medina
But I really enjoyed this place.
Avoid the taxis outside!. A pleasant garden, disappointing to see that some of the cacti had been vandalised with grafitti. Take some time to sit and enjoy the surroundings.

Beauty and tranquility.. The gardens are beautiful, quite unlike any I've been to before. On a very hot day the Jardin Majorelle was a cool, calm oasis which was such a pleasure after the hustle and bustle of the medina. There are lots of benches dotted around to sit and drink in the lovely peaceful atmosphere and just gaze at the gardens or people watch! It's possible to walk here from the main square in the Medina, it takes approximately 15 minutes, there really is no need for a taxi although crossing the roads is pretty scary!It's worth buying the double ticket for the gardens and the Berber Museum as both are worthy of your time. I wouldn't recommend visiting with children, there is nothing to amuse them.The on site restaurant is lovely, it's not terribly expensive although there are much cheaper eateries in the medina. The food is pretty good quality and the fruit drinks are to die for. Staff were very accomodating.

A very special oasis in the middle of Marrakech.... This garden has been photographed so many times that I was afraid it would already be a cliche by the time I visited. Fortunately I was wrong. It is a charming testament to the vision of its founder, and to that of Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Berge, who restored it and made it a public garden. The small Berber Museum within the garden is a stunning collection of Berber textiles and objects, beautifully displayed and curated, with multilingual signage. The major disappointment with the garden is that it gets very crowded. Best to arrive very early or very late in the day. It is difficult to enjoy such a contemplative space when surrounded by noisy crowds. It can be seen in a short time, or one can linger here for hours, especially if visiting the Berber Museum.

Spoiled by spoiled people. It was early and already busses, screaming children and seemingly bored people were waiting to get in. The colours and the set up were nice but to be honest: there are a lot more beautiful and bigger gardens to be seen all over the world without being forced to listen to other peoples conversations. Personel had no idea about plant names, and it was, all in all a dissapointing experience.

Serenity in Marrakech. Jardin Majorelle is a must visit attraction in Marrakech. It is such a contrast to the madness of this city and was so pleasant to sit in for a few hours.The gardens are laid out nicely and immaculately maintained. There is also a nice café on site and although the food is nothing special the atmosphere is nice and there are a few shaded areas for enjoying an hours respite from the intense heat.

.... Visiting Jarden Majorelle was average. The museum kept us occupied for only 20 minutes and the gardens itself took us half an hour. The cafe/restaurant was stunning and served a variety of Moroccan food, our family enjoyed the food here and the staff were very friendly. Overall it was a pretty and picturesque garden but not the most exciting place in Marrakech!

Taste, color and art converge here. Loved the place... The colors of the garden, the building, the whole atmosphere and I think what is most striking is to consider the environment in which the gardens are set... A must!

Spectacular Secret Garden.... Walking from the taxi to the gardens you are hard pushed to believe that such a beautiful place could be situated in the middle of the very dirty and smelly Marrakech! Walking through the little door you are presented with an immaculate, peaceful and pristinely presented garden, with a path running all the way through. Lots of different sections to the garden; with ponds (complete with tortoises) a memorial to Yves Saint Laurent, a lovely shop and a bookshop all inside the walls. Beautiful architecture and real attention to detail from the hard working gardeners.There is also a slightly overpriced restaurant. Al in all I think this attraction is good value at £5 per person, and I would return without hesitation. Tip: no need to pay extra for a tour guide.

Stunning gardens. A little expensive for the amount of time it takes to have even a fairly thorough look round, but it was worth it for us. I'd have liked a little less YSL emphasis, and a little more about Majorelle, but putting that to one side the little oasis is very interesting. The cobalt blue is even more stunning in real life than in the photographs we'd seen. We had a really nice an reasonably priced lunch in the pretty cafe too.

gorgeous, not to be missed. The moment you step into the garden, the street noise disappears. The colors inside make for great photography so a camera is a must: deep saturated blue, gold and orange colors for the buildings and flower pots and the green of the plants make for some truly striking photos.The restaurant inside is a tad pricey for Marrakech, but the food was excellent. Do visit the Berber museum inside the garden.
Lovely gardens. A feast for those who love color and greenery. Beautiful gardens to walk through or just sit and absorb the surroundings.

Beautiful Garden; EXCELLENT Museum. The Majorelle Garden is a lovely surprise behind a wall on a residential street in Marrakech. It's not the plants (lots of various cacti and bamboo) that distinguish it but their use on paths and in contrast to the structures in the gardens: the tiled pools and the breathtaking vibrancy of the green, yellow and 'Majorelle' blue gazebo and museum building. A great place to sit a while on a hot day, it's like an oasis in the city. But the crown jewel of the property is the Berber Museum! The collection includes jewelry, everyday implements and traditional dress and textiles of the Berber peoples.; a truly remarkable cultural collection. As an aside, I was very disappointed in the gift shop.

Our favourite part of the gardens was the large cactus garden!. These gardens were created in the 1920's by the French painter Jacques Majorelle and now maintained by the fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent. With dwarf palms, bamboo groves and lily ponds, these gardens are worth a quick visit if you want a break from the chaos of central Marrakesh (no, I've not nicked these words from a travel guide).If you want peace and quiet, get there early, as they're becoming the worst kept secret in Marrakesh as more and more tourists discover them.

Beautifull Tranquility. Absolutely stunning, did not realize Yves Saint Laurent lived next door and used to own, donated back to state. Never seen Lilly ponds/ Pads like it.Amazing Cactus, Bamboos pathways.
manicured and yet real. Beautifully exhibited flower, trees, cacti. Great place for breakfast/lunch. Museum a treat with controlled entrance.

'Haven' from the hustle and bustle and the heat. It provides excellent escape from the heat. The design, the foliage provided excellent photo opportunities, not to mention Yves Saint Laurent memorial.

Serenity Now!. This is a beautifully maintained gardens with some interesting history. The collection of cacti is stunning. Considering the noise that is Marakkesh this is nice respite from the traffic and constant calamity going on outside. The cafe inside is lovely and worth a visit.
Tranquil. Small and beautiful. Stunning colours in this garden. Get there early in the morning to avoid the hordes of tourists.
Paradise. This garden is beautiful! The changing light, the colours, the birds, the ponds and water lilies - like paradise.
Paradise. This garden is one of the most beautiful I have ever seen. The changing light, the colours and the serenity makes you feel like being in paradise.
Oasis in the city bustle. Really loved my afternoon here. Fantastic place to revive from the heat. Some beautiful plants and wonderful North Africa colours.

Overrated?. I found the gardens to be a pleasant respite from the heat of Marrakech but was disappointed with the standard and upkeep of some areas. The memorial to YSL was really surprising as it was extremely plain and ordinary, not befitting something for such a creative man. The exhibition of his personal greeting cards was charming. Enjoyed the caleche ride from the main square, a lovely way of seeing the sights.
Attractive gardens. Peaceful ,shady gardens in the middle of the hustle and bustle that is Marrakech . Loved the colourful painted pots amongst all the greenery. Nice cafe in a courtyard garden.

One of the "Go To" sights in Marrakech. This garden was started by the French Painter Jacques Majorelle and was taken over and maintained by Yves St. Laurent. The specimens are largely native, desert or dry climate, and do not include many of the species seen elsewhere in Morocco. It is a nice quiet walk.

What a little gem. Once we found the rather insignificant gate in the side street, we entered into a beautiful tranquil garden - early in the day, before the coach parties arrived! Do pay the extra and visit the Berber Museum.
just ok. was nice to see and tick off our list, but next time ill hold onto my dihams and skip this one. there are nicer gardens and museums to see in marakesh over this!

Lovely gardens. Amazing gardens, nice break from the husstle and busstle of Marrakech, very well maintained, an abundance of vibrant colours and exotic plants. Try and go early morning before it gets too busy so you can enjoy it even more.

Beautiful Moroccan Arts. The garden shows the collection of cactus and it was lovely to walk around seeing many different kinds of trees. I went there when there was many group tours and it was a bit difficult to walk around. Go there early morning or late afternoon. I was advised by Moroccan people not to bother paying to see the museum as it was full of rubbish (unless you want to).

Beautiful and peaceful gardens. This garden is truly the most beautiful garden of Marrakech. I expected it to be a little big bigger though. Especially on the hot summer days, it's a good place to stay. If you go by taxi, ask for 'Acima Majorelle', that's the supermarket close to the gardens. It'll cost you less than saying 'jardin majorelle'. I haven't visit the museum inside the house, but the house itself looks stunning in the middle of all the palmtrees and cactuses.

Absolutely stunning!. The gardens are so peaceful & tranquil. I can imagine what it would have been like when it was part of the private residence. Make sure you get there as early to opening time as possible to miss all the tour groups. We managed to have the place to ourselves for about 20 minutes which was enough time to take some magical photo's. It's a must see when in Marrakech if you have the time.

Doesn't live up to the hype!! . Visited here & have to say it was extremely disappointing. The gardens are much too small to accommodate the many tourists that flock there. We certainly expected more.

Excellent garden. It is a wonderful garden and is a good alternative on a hot afternoon. They have a wonderful collection of cacti. It is a small but beautiful garden and you do have to take a taxi as it is a little far from the Medina. Has some nice cafes around too.

Nice gardens. It was nice but there are hotel gardens which are nice too and you can see them for free.Watch out for the taxi drivers wanting to give you lifts as you leave. Negotiate before getting in the car.Nice places for lunch nearby.
Yves san Laurent Garden. Here we found the memorial to YSL. Colourful gardens with plenty of water features. Had a refreshment café in the centre.

The museum made the difference and got the 4. The gardens are nice enough but be aware that because of the YSL connection there are a lot of fashion lovers. They will not budge until they have taken photos of themselves in particular spots all over the gardens and you better not get in the way. There is a little gallery with YSL posters and a stylish but expensive shop. At 50 Dirhams the gardens are expensive by Marrakech standards but pay the extra 25 for the museum, it's well worth it, particularly the berber jewellery exhibition which is in a stunning setting.

Well worth a visit. Stunning colours, my third visit. The museum which has been added since my last visit has some incredible outfits. The Berber jewellery is amazing. A great palce to viist and to chill with a fresh lemonade afterwards. Grab a horse drwan carriage back to your hotel to complete the experience!

Yves St Laurent's garden. A striking garden with beautiful local planting. the setting is well deigned as you would expect from a fashion designer. The experience is a relaxing change from the hustle and bustle of Marrakesh. Don't miss the Berber Museum which is very well done with very interesting and beautiful artifacts from the Berber culture.
COLORFUL, a photographers dream!. Do not miss this place, thank you YSL! It is an amazing place and an easy walk from our riad El Mansour.

Garden of Eden. Jacques Majorelle, a painter, began to construct this exquisite garden over 90 years ago. It is a mysterious and mesmerizing place in equal measure, offering a cool, calm retreat from the heat and bustle of mid-day Marrakech. On entering one is encouraged to follow a defined path which takes you through a variety of plantings, palms, shrubs and trees all stunningly positioned to make full use of their impact. Water is used to great effect, and the colours of the buildings, furniture and standing pots is eye-catching. Yves St.Laurent rest here.

Escape the mopeds and scooters. Beautiful gardens, shaded and tranquil if you happen to visit outside the bus tour times. Although it's a walk from the Medina, the contrast is well worth it. Lovely planting and well cared for.
Cool gardens. It was smaller than expected but very peacefully and the yves st Laurent memorial was worth a pic or two.

Underwhelming. Well if there are 99% of the world's plants in here - there are less plants in the world than I thought !!! Not what I expected from YSL very underwhelming in design, size and everything.
Amazing Gardens. These gardens are beautiful. Well worth the visit. If you're a photographer, this place is a dream site. Enjoy!

Home garden. I used to live in Marrakesh and Majorelle garden was my favorite get away. It's cool, quiet, and greeeeen! I don't understand much in plants and I'm not much into gardening but there's an air of serenity in the place that makes one feel embraced by nature.

stunning. we had 30 min here with our guided tour, jostled by other groups and no time for the Berber museum inside. We had a free Sunday morning prior to returning home, so into a taxi, and back we went.There were no large tour groups that day:very quiet. We started with coffee in the lovely courtyard cafe (had the place to ourselves) and then spent several hours wandering, sitting and looking., A horticulturist and photographer's paradise, and despite being relatively small, there was so much to see. The birds sang throughout and it was a fantastic experience. Returning to the cafe for lunch, we had fresh, tasty and inexpensive food beneath the orange trees. Magical. The admission cost to the gardens is 50 dirhams, around 5 euro, and the the Berber Museum was an extra 250 dirhams: great value for an impressive and beautifully displayed exhibition. The jewellery room was the most stunning museum display I've ever seen (and I've been to many!) with clever hidden mirrors giving a infinitepanorama of stars and the artegacts glowing in the clever lighting: just superb. You won't have time for this unless you visit independently: even the taxi driver suggested waiting for us, since he said we would need just 30 mins. If you like gardens, and want to relax in a stunning, cool environment away from the city bustle, allow at least a good couple of hours. So beautiful: wished my partner had been with me as it's a romantic spot! Will definitely go back again some day.

Fab. Visited early for coffee & had the place to ourselves, then again at lunchtime: busire, service excellent and the food was fresh and delicious. A beautiful setting beneath orange trees and in a secluded courtyard garden accessed through the Majorelle Gardens which are an absolute must-see.

Fabulous gardens. I love these gardens and have visited several times. I love the history of majorelle blue and the YSL -Pierre Berge connection.During the last visit they were not quite as well maintained as previously, but nonetheless an outstanding garden.

YSL Oasis. Beautiful exotic garden. Strong and contrasting colors. An oasis in the middle of the town, with an interesting museum, a small shop and a lovely tea house. Good service and good organization.

Tasteful and well-established gardens. Lovely to drift round these gardens admiring the juxtaposition of the green hues of the plants - mainly cacti - and the vivid blues and yellows of the hard landscaping.It gets very busy, my advice would be to arrive as early as possible, we were certainly pleased we got there by 0845 (it opens at 0800) as by the time we left at 1030 there were 30-40 people queuing to get in. The vistas of the garden are easier to enjoy with fewer visitors!

disappointing ... on so many levels. I found the garden to be disappointing. It is, simply, far too small to accommodate the hordes of tourists who descend upon it. While quite pretty and well maintained, it really doesn't justify the 50 dirham admission price. With the literally hundreds of tourists likely to be there at any given time, it is hardly the peaceful place it was designed to be. If you're interested in observing the behavior of European package tours, this is a place to go; if you're more interested in a quiet, contemplative spot, head to something like the Jnane S'bile in Fes.

A brilliant oasis. If you go to Marrakech make sure you visit these gardens which belonged to Yves St Laurent. Exquisite - although not very big - an hour or two is enough - you will be enthralled.Not to be missed.
Isle of relaxation. It is not a botanical garden, but worth a visit. Spost cacti, bamboo, water ponds, studio Majorelle ... But there is silence - incredible in the chaos all around :-)
