The impression I get is that the exhibits vary, I was lucky enough to find a display on the history of Berber culture, a people I knew little about. The ticketing system was slightly confusing though - the signage outside the gardens suggested a combined garden-and-museum ticket could be bought at the main entrance. Upon getting to the ticket desk, we were told that we had to buy museum tickets inside the gardens, at the entrance to the museum. It turned out that we could, but almost every other customer had a combined ticket that they had bought from the main entrance.But the highlight by far was the turtles: a mother and 3 children. They live in the main pond with the fish, and even as a big, 6ft, toughened Scotsman I found them pretty adorable.So yeah, worth stopping by for a few hours to de-stress.

A place to come to rest. Well, normally I am not so fond of gardens designed by humans, but here I need to reconsider my idea. It is not such a big garden but the design and implantation is, at least to my taste very well done, certainly with the pottery and buildings painted in Berber blue and lemony yellows. See through parts, ponds and fountains are very beautiful.Very easy to make beautiful pictures.

An tranquil oasis in an urban Jungle. Worth a visit for sure. Try and go very early or very late to avoid the maddening crowds. We were tehre mid March and it was impossibly crowded which detracted from the tranquility they were trying to achieve with the gardens. One of the better attractions we visited in Marrakech in our 4 day stay there.

Peace and Quiet. This is a little way out of the main city so, with the heat, I'd recommend taxi or caleche for the journey. There was a short queue at the entrance but it only took a few minutes before we entered the gardens.It is certainly very peaceful and the shade makes the area quite cool compared to the open areas surrounding the gardens. It's probably a combination of the lack of city noise, hustle and bustle and the heat but it is really peaceful in here with the water features helping with the cool feeling. Unfortunately you have the usual idiots who have carve their names in the beautiful large bamboo stems, defacing them in the process and taking something away from the pristine feeling of the gardens.Even a relatively quick walk around would take about an hour but you could easily spend a couple of hours here. Enjoy.

definitely one of Marrakech's top 10 places to visit. The garden, established by Jacques Majorelle and further developed by Yves Saint Laurent is quite different from any other I have seen. It is small enough to get round, and include lunch or a snack in the lovely cafe in a couple of hours. The cactus planting was particularly impressive, and bougainvillea provided splashes of colour, as did the vividly painted building and plant pots, including the striking, iconic, Majorelle blue. The pools with water lilies, goldfish, and a fountain were restful features. However short your visit to Marrakech, this is well worth including in your programme.

Nice gardens but would need some maintenance. I had been advised by many people to go visit the Majorelle Garden - very colorful, I really loved the colored pots all over the garden. We queued to get tin, paid 100 DRH for 2 and after 30mn in the garden, were told to exit it (end of the day). It was disappointing that we weren't told at the entrance that they would advise at least 2h to benefit from the beauty of the garden as opposed to cashing another 2 entry tickets….Many of the plants were engraved with messages / names by indelicate visitors. The garden was a bit dry, I didn't feel it was well maintained (time of the year maybe)? I'd recommend a few hours to spend there, especially for photographers as there are many close up shots to take, but beware of the opening times. I wish the Garden owners did pay more attention to keeping their plants free from people's own silly tags. Very quiet place.
Must see!. Loved these beautiful and very interesting gardens. Areas of bamboo, palm trees and cacti. Great use of bold coloured pots, pergola and buildings. You will take many photos!
Stunning. Stunning small but incredibly stylish garden. The mixture of the planting and colourful painted structures and pots is beautiful. Well worth the 50MAD entrance fee.
Lovely small private garden. Since it was the hottest day on our tour, the shade and peacefulness of the gardens were quite welcome. Does not require very much time to seen.

a beautiful garden. This is a stunning garden which absorbs the crowds so you don't notice them. It would be a great place to go in the hotter months too as it is shady and cool. It is not expensive, there is a little Berber museum and a café and clean toilets.

Meticulous garden worth visiting. The garden was smaller than I'd imagined but it's beautifully looked after with some incredible mature plants including many cacti. Paths are flat in painted concrete so walking round is easy. An oasis from the heat and traffic.

Nice Garden. We walked to the gardens from the old city. Not too far but nothing of interest along the way. We visited at morning opening time and as expected there was a queue. However it was managed well and we entered with little delay. Gardens are well laid out with solid footpaths and waterways. The main interest is the trees but my favourite was the cactus garden. There are interesting paintings too. A pleasant place to spend an hour or two.
A truly beautiful garden.. Quiet at both ends of the day, Busy in the middle but still worth seeing. The Berber museum is icing on the cake.
Lovely Gardens. Small gardens but clean and quiet in a busy city - don't think about the cafe as it is very expensive.
very orderly and colourful. The beautiful colour contrasts and the sense of peace and order of the place. Otherwise it's not a big garden and I'm sure half its popularity is due to its last owner!
Peaceful. Lovely gardens with a lovely courtyard cafe. nice and relaxing after being in the medina. Good for chilling out.

Most famous garden of Marrakech. The Jardin Majorelle in Marrakech is the most famous garden in Marrakech with a 50 Dhs admission fee. Named after French painter Jacques Majorelle in the heart of the City complete with fountains, boutique, Cafe, bookshop, the water lily pond and the Yves Saint Laurent Memorial. The garden wasn't that famous until Yves Saint Laurent bought the Jardin Majorelle in 1980.Other than the fact that the gates, pergolas, pots and studio are all painted in the now famous “Majorelle blue” colour, the only interesting thing about this garden is pretty much it's fame.It also houses a Berber museum within the grounds for which however you'll have to pay an extra 25 Dhs admission to get in.

worth the walk!. we stayed in the old city and the walk to Jardin Majorelle was a little long, but what a strange and beautiful garden!!! The colors are so saturated, we got the best photos from our trip there! It can get a little crowded, but it's worth it.

Oasis of Calm. Its a nice change from the hustle and bustle of the city to spend a few hours wondering round here. Its a photographer's heaven. Very reasonable admission prices. Berber museum can be visited for an extra 10dirhams (about £1) - Buy the combination ticket. Well worth half a day. Only downside is getting here on foot from Jamaa El Fna (Pedestrian crossings are few and frankly ignored), and the arrogant, aggressive taxi drivers when you come out, ( usual trick , want to get you in the taxi without telling you what the fare is going to be). Not very well signposted, so study the map before setting off.

Quiet oasis. It was pretty. Don't let the taxi drivers just outside cheat you when you're returning to the Medina. We paid 50 Dirham (for a family of four in a Grand Taxi) from Djema el Fnaa to the gardens, and they wanted 100 for the return. When we refused, then they found us a taxi for 50.

a delightful quiet botanical experience. fascinating well-designed gardens with the Yves Saint Laurant touch. The Bereber museum in the gardens well worth the extra cost to visit. Do try to get there early before the crowds arrive and do not pay the taxi from the square more than 25dh for the trip out.

A haven of tranquility. I first visited the gardens about 10 years ago. I also went inside the house, which I did not do on this occasion. The gardens have matured so much since my last visit and it was truly a haven of peace and tranquillity in such a bustling town. The prevalent blue colour is such a contrast to the plants and flowers but it is magical. We enjoyed a 45 minute stroll around admiring the different varieties of plants from tall bamboos, to wacky cacti and colourful bourgainvilla. There were a few water features which added to the ambience. It is not far from the centre of Marrakesh (150 dhms from the Medina by taxi and the driver will wait for you for about 30-40 minutes). It is walkable too.

A tranquil garden in manic Marrakech. I was a bit surprised how central the gardens were to Marrakech. It was a tranquil garden that was oddly quiet being in more or less the heart of Marrakech.The gardens were immaculate and I loved the vibrancy of the blues, yellows etc. Seeing all the varieties of cactus was interesting and the heights they grew to were impressive.The staff/wardens were friendly and helped with taking photographs. I noticed umbrellas too in case of rain. I’d recommend this attraction as it is a ‘must see’ in Marrakech.

Jardin Marjorelle. It was rather busy when we were there at about 0930 , short queue, also really recommend the Berber Museum which is in the house within the grounds...had to queue quiet a while for this but worth it!!

Nice, but only nice. By the time we found this place we had very little time to actually look around. Missing out the museum was probably a mistake as in all a ten minute loop and we had pretty much seen all the garden had to offer.

Well worth a visit - most unusual gardens. It was lovely and also peaceful and different to any other garden i've seen. The whole area is just cacti, but very very unusual ones and they are planted to make the most dramatic impact, which they do. Lovely to simply wander without being pestered or have shouting tourists guides in your ear. Nice little museum of Yve St. Laruen clothes
Peaceful and quiet. Lovely place to visit. Though it was not a big as I had expected it was interesting, peaceful and quiet.

Oasis of calm. I was expecting to be underwhelmed but was in fact overwhelmed by this beautiful oasis of calm in the middle of Marrakech! The history of the garden was fascinating and there was a lovely little shop and cafe amid the gardens which served a lovely food and refreshing smoothies! The plants were mostly succulents and there is a memorial garden to Yves St Laurent.
A beautiful garden. If you like to see exotic plants in a colorful garden, then you need to go here. there is an entrance fee!

Tranquility in a bustling city. Loved the colours and layout with such a huge collection of plants from around the world.Disliked the cafe! such a lovely place to have a cafe and yet the staff were very unfriendly and was really overpriced.

Small but lovely!. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit here - a little oasis from the madness that is Marrakech! Very pretty and tidy garden, beautiful coloured pots and tiled areas and a lovely little café.Reminded me of the same concept as Portmeirion in North Wales - no little houses to stay in of course!Loved the little courtyard café - I could have stayed all day here!
What a gem. A relatively small garden which is so quiet and peaceful. A mix of lush green shrubs and large spiny cactus.
Small, beautiful and peaceful. Shame that cacti has been defaced with graffiti but this alone can not spoil the gardens and its beautiful tranquility.

Stunning - the best place to visit in Marrakech. This is an island of calm in the sea of chaos called Marrakech.It is a "must see" if you are visiting the city. Absolutely beautiful gardens with a wide variety of palms, cactus, bougainvilleas, trumpet vines and other exotic plants, contrasted by masses of cobalt blue architecture and pottery. Although small, we went round twice just to make sure we saw everything. A pity that the Eves Saint-Laurent house is not also open to the public.
It's a garden.............. Not much to say, it has plants and trees and flowers as you'd expect in a garden, would imagine it to be a haven from the heat in the height of summer though

Very Different. Cacti and succulents but very well planned and maintained garden. Great to see different type of garden totally suited to a hot climate. Not exactly a large meandering garden but certainly worth a visit.
Quiet piece of heaven. After the hustle and bustle of Marrakech this was very peaceful and pretty. Some great photo opportunities. Plants from every country

Outstanding gardens. This was a highlight for me on our trip to Marrakech. The gardens are outstanding in how the reflect the diverse and outstanding landscape of not only Morocco but the world in terms of its flora. The visitors mirror that diverse and cheerful nature, and the entire experience transform into one of relaxation and beauty. The cafe on site reflects this calmness as well. And if you happen to be as lucky as we were when we visited, you may even get to sit a table away from Pierre Berge as we did, who graciously offered up his time to sign autographs and take a moment to speak with a number of patrons who came up to say hello to him.Well worth the walk, time and money. This is a top attraction within the city of Marrakech.
Beautiful Gardens and Museum. Beautiful gardens of various succulents and local flora.And a very interesting Museum about the Berber culture.
Oasis in blue. Lovely peaceful garden, go early morning when you can easily walk around and take pictures, it is quite a small garden.
great trip. Lovely tripGreat gardens nice area to visit lovely cactus and wildlife great for keen gardenerNice bars nearby

Beautifull!. A delightful garden and restaurant. A very busy attraction but none the less very enjoyable as there is lots to see. Probably the best place to go for natural air conditioning in Marrakech. Its very cool and tranquil.

Almost a getaway from traffic, but only almost. The garden is peaceful, clean, more lush than we had expected. When walking in Jardin Majorelle, it almost feels like you have escaped the pollution and traffic of Marrakech - you cannot smell the pollution, but you can still hear the car horns.
A break from the medina. No, it's not huge! Worth the walk from the medina to stroll round the gardens, listen to the birds and it just feels so peaceful there. Time to chill!

Tranquil. The gardens are beautiful. We paid 50DH to enter and there are english signposts detailing what different plants/features are. It is worth getting a taxi there as it is outside the Marrakech walls and the walk there isn't great. There is a restaurant/cafe inside, but it looked very expensive. Great place to have a wander, but no need to spend a long time.

Orientalist fantasy. This garden is absolutely beautiful. It's also devoid of Moroccans, except those working on the gardens or at the cafe, and I'm not exaggerating. No Arabic here; just English, German, Spanish, French, Italian, and Dutch. It's a place where European tourists could escape from Marrakech, whilst in Marrakech. That's essentially what Jacques Majorelle was doing there as well, a tourist building a fantasy of an exotic Northern African gardenscape. For the same price as the admission price, you can have a nice meal out for two, and the entry fee is five times more than that of historical places that are hundreds of years old, like Bahia Palace or the gorgeous Dar Si Said. The cost of entry per person is about 10% of the average monthly salary in Morocco--which I would imagine would make this a very cost prohibitive place to go for most residents. The garden is essentially a European post-colonial intervention in the middle of Marrakech. It's a lovely place to linger for an afternoon, but it should be recognised it for what it is.

Not as good as expected. We had heard so much about this but were disappointed, there isn't much there apart from some great giant black bamboos which people seem to have carved there names in and some water features and a lot of cacti. Disappointed
Beautiful and unique gardens. Such an oasis of beauty surprised and delighted by the plants sculptures and water features. Very cooling in the heat of the day

Vist to Majorelle Gardens. A great garden.The cati are just amazing and this has a great little cafe, though a little pricey. I think the best in Marraekech. We paid 50dir from the Menara gardens to get here.

Beautiful gardens!. Would definitely recommend a visit as part of a trip to Marrakech. Although the entrance fee (50D) is slightly more that some of the other sights (10D) the gardens are beautiful and well worth it.
Jardin Majorelle. The garden is lovely but the real jewel is the Berber Museum inside the garden. So few people seem to visit it which is a real shame as it is a gem

Great for gardeners. A very attractive, arid garden. We arrived at midday, the garden was very busy with coach parties of tourists, so heed other posters advice and arrive early if you can! The greenery is punctuated with the bright colours of the pots, lots of Marjorell blue, yellows and oranges. The walls of the buildings are also painted in the same palette of strong colours. There are ponds filled with fish and turtles.The Berber museum is worth the extra charge and is well set out inside, again this was busy and we spent some time in the cafe waiting for the crowds to thin out before going in. I think you need to have an interest in plants/gardening to get the most out of this place.There is also a shop there which sells a range of items (jewellery, textiles, etc) but these were expensive.

Go early!. This most beautiful garden fills up quickly. Beat the rush if you can, otherwise you'll be standing around all day while people take pictures of each other.
You must see the Berber Museum in the grouns for a small extra charge.

Boring and not worth the money. I do not know why this garden is hyped so much. We found it quite boring and not even that pretty. I have regretted to pay 50 MAD entrance as there is not much to see. We prefered walking through Cyber Park much more and there are probably much better things to do in Marrakesh.

Welcome shade. This is a very attractive oasis amid the bustle of the city. The gardens, though not large, are beautifully laid out and very different to the other green spaces in Marrakech. They are quite expensive to enter by Moroccan standards, but well worth it. However, they can get very busy in the afternoons.

Beautiful oasis in the middle of the noisy busy city.. Jardin Majorelle is a very special and beautiful place in the middle of the noisy busy city. There are hundreds kind of cactus, flowers, bamboo forest….. attract a lot of birds. There are a lot of tourists around always, but if you calm down and listen, birds are singing and it’s very cheerful! I love the bright colors, studio, museum, walk ways and pots are painted in cobalt blue, yellow and orange. And all the blooming flowers of fuchsia, white, orange…. It’s one of the most unique gardens I’ve seen.The museum shows Beber art, clothes and accessories. There is a bookstore, gift shop, Yves Saint Laurent’s gallery and a nice café. We had lunch in the garden café and enjoyed it!

Peace and tranquility in Marrakech!!. on a march day when temperatures hit 38 degrees the coolness and quiet were both very welcome.The garden is so well laid out and organised it is a complete contrast but even without that it is worth visiting to see the plants

Gardeners Haven. You need to visit this garden if you come to Marrakech. There are a huge collection of different cactus , palms and flowers... A peaceful haven from the hustle & bustle. Well worth a visit, an interesting Berber museum is located inside the garden at a small extra cost. All in all loved my visit to the famous Yves Saint Laurent gardens.

Great break from the city. Jardin Majorelle is a nice little break from the centre of the city, doesnt take too long to go around but has the gardens and the museum which tells you all about Morocco. Extremely well kept and with a lovely cafe in the grounds which served lovely food and drinks.

Highly over-rated! Go to La Mamounia instead. We paid about 40 dirhams to get to this place then paid 50 dirhams to enter, the ticket booth woman was a total cow, sooo rude! The gardens are small and full of either people blocking your way while they all get photos of the endless cacti (engraved with people's names! - how trashy of them) and palm trees. It is not calm at all and is also full of men crying on each others shoulders, presumably over the death of a man they've never met - get over yourselves! It was crowded (we were there out of season) and so highly over-rated. We paid another 40 dirhams to escape this dirty neighbourhood and went to the Hotel La Mamounia where we paid 60 dirhams for a lovely Moroccan mint tea on their beautiful terrace. We walked around their gardens (free of charge) and they were far superior to the rubbish at YSL's. Lovely friendly staff. Two totally different experiences. Let's see -130 dirhams to go and see a dump and no refreshments, or 60 dirhams for a drink in beautiful calm surrounding and gardens to wander at your leisure - what would you choose?

A garden designed by an artist. With plants from five continents, and a focus on the aesthetic, this is a fabulous place to visit. Have a mint tea on the terrace of the restaurant and then wander among the bamboo and cacti.

very unique. amazing garden, very nice to walk through. Peaceful, colourful and unique. Lots of amazing species, very well maintained and clean. Lovely courtyard to have a cup of tea and amazing juice restaurant opposite the entrance. Totally worth it.

ONLY OK. Be prepared to pay approximately 5 euros to enter the garden which in my opinion was extremely expensive for what was on offer. The gardens are superb but it will only take you approximately 10 minutes to walk around the place. Steer clear from the café and shop unless money is no object as the prices are extortionate. Did not feel I got value for money and was let feeling a little seen off

Take Your Time And Relax. An interesting garden to wander around take photos and relax in. Lots of Cacti, I understand some French chap set it up in the early "0C but died in a car crash and YSL liked it so now funds its continued upkeep though doubtless it rakes in a bit on ticket sales. There is a small outdoor cafe where you can eat and drink and also a very interesting Berber museum with lots of interesting historical artifacts, though don't take photos in here as the staff freak out and make you delete them.
Peacful dessert of cacti. A peaceful garden of Cacti and bamboo As always with such attractions so many people difficult to enjoy the peaceful walkways

Lush and beautiful. Although quite busy if you don't arrive early these gardens should be on everyone's list of things to do in Marrakech. The colours are stunning and it is a lovely place to visit. Not expensive. Would recommend that you take a horse carriage and have him wait for you which is not expensive but you otherwise are stranded and have to take one of the waiting taxis outside - not good.
Oasis in the maze of streets. A nice change of scene after walking around museums and palaces. Tranquil and beautifully maintained collection of enormous cacti and other exotic plants.

peaceful garden. we visited here in march, I imagine in the height of summer or at peak times of the day it would not be quite as peaceful. if you like cactus plants then this is the place for you, the plants are well maintained and the area is very neat and tidy with a couple of water pools with fish and terrapins. I prefer to have a bit of variation when visiting gardens to see all sorts of plants and trees and this is quite a compact garden. you wont spend much longer than an hour here but for 5euros each it isn't an expensive trip.

beautifull garden. beautifull gardendo not miss it, worth to pay 50 dirhamslots of different cactus species, YSL garden is very peacefull and beautifulli do not like the blue color but who cares  hugh
If you like nature.... or if you have an eye for photography, this park has some beautiful trees, plants and natural lighting for some great photography.

Breathtaking colours. I am utterly in love with this place! The colours are so vibrant, so beautifully coordinated, it's an absolute haven of style, design and interesting vegetation.The intense blue found throughout the garden now carries the name Bleu de Majorelle! You can buy a pot of it from the shop and I would urge you to do it as I - ALAS - didn's and have regretted this decision as soon as I returned.You can also visit le Musee Berbere for 25 dinars and it's an interesting glimpse into the customs and the fashions of Morocco's native peoples. It will also help with choosing jewelry and blankets as you'll be able to identify authentic (looking) pieces! We also had a light lunch at the cafe and I had the Moroccan salad - delicious and plentiful! Definitely GO!

Lovely but crowded. The gardens are lovely and make a welcome change of pace from the city. Lovely cacti and and other plants, and contrast from the great paints used for pots and buildings. The museum is well worth a short visit. It's was really crowded when we were there, so maybe try going early in the morning. The taxi drivers outside are a bit of a rip off so go round the corner to get a taxi.

Beautiful relaxing gardens. The gardens are beautiful and relaxing. Definitely worth going. You walk through a great mixture of colours and plants. Also worth a break in the cafe, although a bit expensive it's a really nice place.

Very pleasant. This was very calm and tranquil in the middle of a very busy city. I cannot read a map so it took a while to find. The food was quite nice inside the garden as well. Well worth a visit.

Okay. I'm not sure why this place is so popular, it's certainly nice but not really anything special. And it can be very crowded, so you can't sit somewhere quiet and relax. And the surrounding area is not particularly nice. By all means go, if you have nothing better to do, but don't let anyone tell you it's a must-visit of Marrakech.
Stunning. Can recommend a visit to these gardens, very beautiful and well kept, nice coffee shop and gallery with a gift shop as well which is very expensive but worth a look!!

A Gardening Gem. Go early or go late to avoid the crowds as it is a small garden that soon fills up and cannot take even a moderate crowd. Do go to the Berber Museum. Informative and beautifully presented.If you go nowhere else in Marrakech go here. We entered as the door opened. A gardening gem.
A bit disappointing!. Very busy even in february. If you know something about gardens ,it is a bit dissappointing. But I saw it as a hommage to YSL.

Great place!. Very quiet nice ambiance, even with tuns of tourists. Beautiful colors and most of all, it has the Yves Saint Laurent memorial in the garden. skip the museum, and just go to the garden, it's enough. The lunch at in the garden is quite nice too, if you choose to go to the café.

Jardins Majorelle Marrakech. Haven of peace just outside Medina walls. Beautiful gardens laid out with plants which withstand an arid climate, mainly cacti. Immaculately kept. Excellent small museum of Berber history and artefacts. Very nice cafe with good range of food on site. One of the highlights in Marrakech.

Peaceful and Beautiful. After some busy days in the Medina, these gardens provided a wonderful and quiet afternoon! The gardens themselves are lovely and tranquil and would highly recommend stopping in the cafe for mint tea!! Definitely worth a visit!
Marjorelle magic. lovely food in wonderful surroundings . service very good . Have been several times in the last few years and have always had good food
Le Jardin Majorelle. Peaceful escape! Beautiful planned. Watch out for the street sellers on the way in and out! But overall a great place to visit.
well worth a visit. Enjoyed the garden and Berber museum-worth the queue. Try the Moroccan salad in the café, really tasty and good chef's salad

Beautiful Gardens but very hot!. Visited the gardens a little while back on our first trip to Marrakech. It was a welcome retreat in comparison with the hustle and bustle of the main area. Really peaceful and beautiful colours. The day we went was extremely hot and whilst there were a few shady areas overall we had to leave because the heat was unbearable! Would have liked to have stayed longer.

nice break from the busy streets.. We enjoyed it just to get away from the heat and busy streets. It is small and a little underwhelming but maybe I missed the point. Not being green fingered maybe it's a real delight and achievement to those in the know. Little cafe inside is great, lovely refreshing ginger and mint shakes. YSL tribute too. It's cheap so you might as well check it out!

Pricey by Marrakshi standards, but definitely worth a stop. Gorgeous oasis tucked away in new town — worth a few hours wandering around the shady gardens/ponds that were once maintainced by Yves Saint-Laurent and a stop in the relaxing cafe. Excellent sandwiches!

Visit early, during the week, and prepare to be bowled over by colour!. We had read and heard so much about thes gardens, and were delighted to be able to see and enjoy them for ourselves. Like many attractions in Marrakech, I would recommend visiting them during the week, and early in the morning before too many coach parties invade. The gardens were larger than we anticipated. Prepare to be bowled over by colour! This goes not only for the shades of green of the plants, or for the magnificent Majorelle Blue, but also for the other colours used to pain the planters, such as lemon yellow, apricot, and forget-me-not blue. The Berber museum inside the gardens is also well worth a visit.
Magical. Our third visit. What a lovely peaceful place even if this time it was rather full of tourists. Hardly surprising really

A stunner. A garden built for the tropics but with imagination and flair. We visited here in the morning when it is at it's busiest. The tip would be to go in the afternoon and on a sunny day when the shadows and light will give you spectacular photos. Well worth a visit, beautiful colours and shapes and planting, seen from a winding red path. Glimpses of the cobalt blue house through the cactus are wonderful. Highly recommended.. Go to the cafe but ask for a menu. Visit the shop, the prices are high but you can buy a pot of the cobalt paint. And the Berber museum is with a visit too.

Like EVERYTHING in Marrakesh: Overpriced. I'm going to use this lines to make a Marrakesh overall review because it's the perfect example for this city. Morocco it's a wonderful country, with great people and beautiful landscapes. It have a huge growing potential that can be ruined if the rest of the country follows the increasing greed owning Marrakesh. Yes it's worth a visit but 50 MAD it's too much!

Interesting but could be more. There are some nice plants in a nice setting. Not as big as I had expected with the way around set out very clearly down the formal paths. It was not for me but many there were clearly enjoying the experience and I can't say not to go. We walked there and got a horse drawn carriage back. I enjoyed the experience but felt sorry for the horse. Paid 150 d for the trip and then gave a good tip. Better value than the gardens we thought
a bit dissapointing. The gardens are nice enough but nothing magical. Much smaller than expected, I think only part of the property is open to public. Overpriced at 50 dirhams.

beautiful oasis in Marrakech. Prepare your camera for many photos to take in this wonderful garden where Yves Saint Laurent used to stay!A tour will take about 1 hour and the ticket cost 5 Euro.The garden is not very big but it is excellently designed to enchant your eye at every step you take: different plants in different shapes, striking colors on vases, walls or banks, a lake with red fishes and a clean air.Yves ex-house holds now a museum and a cosy boutique and you can have also a light lunch or coffee at the beautiful cafe-garden.Don't miss it even if you are staying for a short time in Marrakech.

A fabulous oasis. Tucked away in the middle of busy Marrakesh is this gem of a garden and Berber museum. The garden is planned so you wind your way along paths lined with cacti and ponds. The intense lapis walls and bright yellow accents are breathtaking. Not to be missed!

beautiful tranquil gardens. Well worth a visit, stunning little garden of bamboo and cacti, not very big but beautifully laid out, and all painted in stunning shades of blue! Lovely escape from the hustle and bustle outside.

A place to recover!. Tucked away in a residential area, this is a true oasis in an hectic city! It was great to feel the tranquility and to have a coffee in the garden bar. Sometimes we kept asking whether it's entirely genuine as many plants seem to be added. Overall a good decision to recover before heading back to the maze of Marrakech.

An Oasis of Calm. This was one of the highlights of my trip. It only cost 50 dirhams to get in (about £3.66/4.45 euro/$6.79 CAD) and I would have paid more. The cobalt blue art deco pavilion in the middle is striking against all the green. This is a stunning garden and a nice break from the red clay buildings of the city. It isn't very large but still an adequate size. I didn't opt for the Berber Museum but that wouldn't have cost much more. I loved the YSL prints near the book shop and bought a postcard of my year of birth. Must see for sure. Tip: if you are taking a taxi then walk down to the main road and haggle a price there. The taxi's right outside will gouge you.

lovely oasis. lovely maze of paths, pools cobalt blue buildings, lovely quiet time from main town Marrakech, we walked from the main square and got a taxi back, good small restaurants just outside on the main street

a little bit of paradise. Very difficult to find as not well signposted until you get there!Very cool and peaceful .Unusual plants mainly Cacti /desert flora.Colours beautiful, painted pots and an interesting water feature running through the middle.The onsite cafe is a little on the pricey side and toilets are clean.

A great escape. The Jardin Majorelle is a great escape from the madness of the Medina and the souks. Such a relaxing spot with plenty of benches and seating spots among the Cactus and bamboo. The Yves St Laurent exhibition in the garden is marvellous.

Like a green sun umbrella. My only reservation is that, although the whole point of the place is the brightly coloured Morroccan style ceramics, I couldn't help feeling that I would prefer the garden to consist only of plants!

A must for Cacti lovers!. This was by far the best part of our trip to Marrakech.If you don't have a interest in plants, cacti or gardens then this really isn't for you. Me and my family all love gardens, cacti and plants so this was a perfect way to spend a day. Reasonable entrance fee, 50Dh, yes it is a small garden but we spent 3 hours there, this did include lunch in the cafe, and we still could have wandered around again! Full of stunning mature cacti and succulents, a long with impressive cascade of vines and bougainvilleas, I can't recommend a visit here enough. The cafe was nice, limited selection and not the cheapest place to eat in the city but still enjoyable. The museum was also good, very informative and a good added extra. The whole garden was well maintained and in good condition, but why people feel the need to graffiti the agave plant I don't know! It was a shame to see such mindless vandalism to plants of all things.

Oh. My. What beautiful place!. The peaceful oasis in Marrakech. People will say it's crowded, but the place is so relaxing you don't even notice. Bring a book, spend a day sitting on the benches. The cafe looked lovely too, but it was really busy so we couldn't go. The museum of Berber objects is stunning, one of the best collections of this kind I've seen.
BEAUTIFULL GARDENS IN TRANQUIL SETTING. A must see, Go fairly early before the queues build up. The Berber museum within, is well worth a visit as well.

Winter garden sunshine. Whilst in Marrakesh this was my no.1 stop I wanted to see, I'm qualified in horticulture so I really wanted to see this attraction, I loved it and although my friends have no interest in plants they liked it to, a hour takes you round the garden, I was surprised when I realized it was in the middle of the city it was so quite and a great place to get some shade. For the plant lovers reading this there is some amazing varieties of Cacti was amazing to see. would come back!!

A stunning garden, a must to see in Marrakesh. The garden is named after a French painter, Jacques Majorelle, who lived in Marrakesh, acquired this plot of land in 1924 and opened the garden to the public in 1947. After his death It was taken over by Yves Saint Laurent, the famous French designer, and has been restored to absolute splendor by him. Not only the plants are interesting, in particular a fantastic collection of cactus, but also the choice of colors on the flower pots, pathways etc. There is a memorial for Yves Saint Laurent in the garden so that you do not forget his part in creating this small paradise.If you want to, you can also visit a Berber Museum in the park.Most visitors, however, will flock either to the café or to the Yves Saint Laurent shop where for out of this world prices you can acquire absolute top quality goods beautifully displayed. Beware to go in there !

Peaceful and exotic gardens with a strong sense of design. Outside the medina, these gardens are a short walk away which is worth the effort. Bright red paths and blue pots give the hint that this is no ordinary park but a striking experience. We especially enjoyed the amazing range of cacti. Better to eat in a cafe outside the gates than the expensive, if nice-looking one inside!

Beautiful gardens and wonderful art!. Just go... the most beautiful gardens, lovely place to get reprieve from the chaos of the Medina.the gardens are amazing - but the Yves St Laurent LOVE art was the BEST!!!

Pretty pretty. So glad we decided to visit this garden. Its well worth the admission of 50Dhs.My group of girlfriends all became models as soon as we enter the garden. Everyone posts like crazy with the beautiful garden as the backdrop. The colors are amazing.The museum is small but beautiful illustrated the Berber cultural and history. Don't miss it. Its only cost 25Dhs.The location is not near anything so have to take a cab. Needs to bargain and decide on a price before getting in.
Nice museum. Very nice small museum with exhibits of Berber life.Garden was very peaceful with some beautiful plants, not so many flowers yet because its February

Beautiful gardens. Very peaceful - well planted with cactus and other exotic species. Easy to walk around and seats dotted here and there to watch birds and plants. Unfortunately we forgot our camera and there were no postcards for sale.
Early is best. Get there early, walk round the garden and museum, then enjoy a coffee in the cafe whilst the crowds tour the garden

Expensive and boring. 50 dirham entrance each, and all you get is a small garden, all of which you will have definitely seen within 10 minutes. In addition we paid 40 dirhams to get here, because it is quite far from the square. I thought it was very expensive for what you get, there a plenty of really nice parks in this town, which you can visit and chill out in for free (alright, so thise may not have huge cactus, but so what). The restaurant is nice though, a bit expensive as well. Tagines are good, club sandwich very plain and expensive (I guess that will teach us for ordering a non-Moroccan dish).
Extraordinary garden.... Wonderful and unusual garden, a blaze of bright blue and fullof amazing cactii and succulents. A really extraordinary experience.
Quiet place in a noisy city.. After 3 days in the noisy city of Marrakech, this place was such a relief. A very nice garden to see, to walk around and to come a rest a little.

Great escape from the pressures of the market.. Wonderful things to experience. go to the Berbere Museum. go to the shops. go to the cafe. Needed peacefulness and luxury to balance out the chaos. There are also some of the best, coolest shops across the street.
an exotic oasis. surprising exotic garden with lot's of flowers. extremely clean and well kept secret. allthough crowded with tourist we really enjoyed the place

Famous historic garden. So pleased to finally get to the Majorelle garden. It was no disappointment and still looking very fresh - in the sense of the ideas. A unique and informed planting makes it exceptional and the colours used in the ceramics quite extraordinary and vivid in the bright Moroccan sunlight. There is nowhere like it and it deserves it's reputation . Good cafe as well.
Beautiful gardens. These gardens were lovely, well laid out, calm and well kept. A great place to go to cool off, make sure you do the Berber museum at the same location.

Not much to see. Pleasant little gardens, with not a lot to see, overcrowded and a poorly curated Berber museum, overseen by security people more intent in shooing us through than allowing us to see the exhibits.
So blue!. Just so beautiful. I can imagine that this would be a spot to escape to in the heat of the summer. Excellent Berber museum in the grounds which was well worth seeing.

Beautiful but not for everyone. I came here as many people had recommended it and had said it was a very beautiful place to visit. We decided to walk to the gardens which was probably why we were a bit disappointed once we had finally made it through the heat! I fail to see how people have managed to spend more than an hour here in the gardens. Beautiful and well maintained they are, with an interesting story with YSL, however, the entrance fee is a lot more than we expected. It is a rather small garden, considering the price you are paying, and although very nice to look at, there were a lot of cactus.We did not have a bad time in the gardens, and it is a lovely place what with the colours and the plants, however, the price and the amount of time spent in there did not exceed our expectations.
wow!. Really beautiful n tranquil well worth a visit! Beautiful on a sunny day with the landscape n Marrakech sunshine

Fascinating and calming experience. A garden with history. A tranquil haven amongst the chaos surrounding it. Fascinating museum of items collected with very informative information guides, in English, that make each item come alive. Reasonable entrance price. Prices in café a bit high. Arrive early am (before 10) to be able to appreciate the garden before the coaches arrive.

a gardeners garden. Exceptional design, style, colour and plant selection. Everything in this garden has been planned with expertise and grand ideas. There is a peace and grace that compliments the intensity of the majorelle colour. The museum is beautifully designed especially the jewellery room. Although the entry fee is quite expensive I found everything in the shops and café extremely expensive.
Very special garden. Beautifully conceived and kept - wonderful colours. The museum was exceptionally well presented and was gave the best feel for the local cultures of anywhere we visited.

A charming couple of hours. Amid the hustle and bustle of Marrakech lies these gardens designed by YSL. We found it to be an enjoyable way to spend a few hours. The gardens are wonderfully designed with plants from all round the world. The Love Gallerie is also worth a look to see copies of the New Year's cards YSL used to send his friends. Upon departure be prepared to haggle hard to get the best price for a taxi back into the Medina.

Beautiful gardens but way over-priced. Majorelle's gardens, restored in 1980s by Yves St Laurent and Pierre Berge, are beautiful with excellent global plant selection but entrance very expensive (75 DHR for garden and museum compared to 10 DHR for other museums in Marrakech) and cafe is a total rip-off (130 DHR for 3 small drinks) - not worth the money in my opinion.

Disappointing. We walked to it from Jemaa el Fna - our first mistake as it was almost 3 miles in raging heat. When we got there it seems to be little more than an olive grove with a pool and a few vendors. I failed to see why it was rated so highly.

A convenient and tasty lunch. The cafe does what it does well. I imagine in the height of the tourist season finding a table may be challenging. We enjoyed our food and the environment was of course superb.
Beaultiful Gardens. Well worth a visit. Go early in the morning (before 10am) to avoid the crowds. The berber museum there is great and well worth visiting.
Oasis. Calm in the midst of chaos. A delight of colours and textures. The planting is kept magnificently. Shops and gallery all add to the charm. Inspirational.
Fantastic Gardens but Often Is Too Crowded. These gardens are a must-visit but go early or late to miss the tour parties as they often get very crowded.

A beautiful oasis. Go early to this beautiful oasis as it gets busy by late morning even out of season. There are some stunning plants, large bamboo, succulents all carefully landscaped amid fountains and man made waterways. It isn't a large place so a couple of hours is enough to walk around and sit awhile. The Berber museum is also well worth the cheap entry cost as it gives an excellent insight into the local culture.It is a romantic place with the famous blue painted walls and pots and provides a calm refuge from the frenetic pace of the streets and the rest of Marrakech. I would say this is worth visiting but from another place like Essaouira on a day trip as the city is not a place I would stay in again. Easy to see all of the three main sights in one day.
Peaceful.. A delightful garden design by Jacques Majorelle. A nice break from city life and a bit of shade from the sun.

Beautiful and Serene. This botanical garden is beautifully well kept and a visit can last as long as you like. There are some amazing plants and flowers that provide lots of shade, if you just want to sit and listen to the birds chirping away. You also get to see the memorial to YSL on your way around this serene garden.

Blue Heaven!6. This garden is well worth a visit. It's a beautiful peaceful place to wander away from the hustle of the rest of Marrakech. We took a carriage there and it was a very pleasant way to enjoy a tour of the city as well. However I would recommend you hire a single trip and then get another carriage or a taxi when you come out so that you don't feel rushed. There is a beautiful shop selling souvenirs. It's lovely to look in but although everything is lovely it is very expensive! There is a cafe there which is a lovely place for tea or lunch which completes a worthwhile trip for a relaxing morning or afternoon with lots of photo opportunities.

My favourite thing in Marrakech. The gardin is simply beautiful. It's well tended and designed, with a startlingly gorgeous choice of colours. The place feels very on trend although the garden dates back to the 1920s (I believe). Obviously very touristy and a little bit crowded, but still peaceful and a lovely way to spend an afternoon.
Yves pad. A 30 min stroll from the Riad. Beautiful & peaceful. Stunning colors. We just visited the gardens - good value. But you can visit the museum too if you wish.

Brilliant but shop better than museum. Really loved this location - but save your dirhams for the cafe - the museum is tiny and you aren't allowed to take photographs. Ed Sheeran, or some actor that looked like him, seems to have been behind me in the queue today, with his fame-loving girlfriend and was signing autographs. He was not enjoying himself either. Gardens beautiful, however, and I do not think 50 dirhams was a lot for the wonderful maintenance they obviously get.

One of my favourite places. Amazing place and amazing café. A gorgeous atmosphere. Really one of my favourite places I have visited. It was great to visit as a couple but would have been just as lovely with friends.
lovely gardens. amazing plants, offset by some fantastic buildings. lovely shade from the sun ! at 50 Dirham/person very good value

Expensive but beautiful. Compared to other attractions in Marrakech (like Bahia Palace or the Saadian Tombs, both at 10 dirham's each) this place was expensive, at 50 dirham's (around 5 euro).
They are a bit small but well taken care of and really peaceful. We went there on Valentine's day and it was very romantic.

Expensive but beautiful. Compared to other attractions in Marrakech (like Bahia Palace or the Saadian Tombs, both at 10 dirham's each) this place was expensive, at 50 dirham's (around 5 euro).
They are a bit small but well taken care of and really peaceful. We went there on Valentine's day and it was very romantic.

paradise. yes definetly you should see.how rich people lived in thiis poor country.
garden is nice.they worked realy hard .of course we have seen much better gardens.but this one is in desert

Beautiful gardens, very busy and expensive shops. The gardens and are lovely and do not disappoint. My teenage daughter had to dragged away from the Berber museum. We had a lovely morning here. Just a bit disappointed that the shops were so dear and unaffordable. Realistic prices would have been nice and I would have bought.

A quiet and lovely oasis. Beautifully maintained gardens and a tranquil atmosphere. There are desert plants from all over the world as well as lovely fountains and ponds. We went to the Berber Museum but it wasn't anything special and the queue was quite long. If you are very interested in different Berber styles of dress it is worth a visit, but there isn't much else to it. Stop in the café and have a snack or meal. The carrot soup was fantastic!

Just another tourist site. As others have stated, it's small, it's a bit on the pricey side (for a garden), and it can get a bit crowded. That being said...It's a tourist place. Something to perhaps add onto the agenda if you have a bunch of smaller actvities planned (Marrakech isn't that big afterall & at least you can say you've seen the gardens). Nice but not needed.

amazing place. well, when preparing for this trip, the botanical garden, Jardin Majorelle was recommended everywhere. Rightly so! Yves St.Laurent did a wonderful job restoring beauty to this garden that was created by the painter Majorelle. The so called majorelle blue can be seen everywhere. I can only imagine how intense that would have been with sun light. Unfortunately, we did not have good weather. Enjoy!

Nice, quiet garden in the new city. The plants and architecture here were really beautiful and this is a nice break from the craziness of the Medina square and souks. The blue used on the buildings around the proper is really striking, I can see why they sell the paint in the store.

A pleasant escape from the city. Marrakech is very tiring and stressful, so we came here on the second to last day of the trip. We walked from the medina and it took around 40mins to get there. It was 50dhrms (5euro) each. The park is small, but very very well kept, quiet and a nice place to spend a few hours. I would recommend paying a little extra to include the museum admission, it a museum about the berber people, interesting stuff.
So beautiful. Amazing colours!!! Beautiful weather!!! Just pure heaven!!! Such an amazing chilled relaxed day. The cobalt blue is so gorgeous. There are terrapins in the pond. Very cute.
"pleasant". A pleasant way to spend and hour and a half. We went in February when it was cold, would probably be more enjoyable on a sunny, warmer day.

An oasis of cool...in all senses of the word!. Really worth a visit. YSL lived here. It is all blues and cacti..and wonderful colours, very arty. Fabulous place to visit. The restaurant is also fab and sells good mint tea.

Beautiful on a sunny day!. The gardens were beautiful! We were so glad we went on a sunny day, it made it a much more relaxing beautiful atmosphere. The colours and all the flowers were beautiful! The cafe in the gardens was delicious! The museum is worth paying for, if you're interested in Moroccan culture. We saw the Yves Saint Laurent memorial among the flowing streams and cactus's.There were little terrapins and fish in the water.It was a lovely day out, definitely worth doing whilst you're there.It was ridiculously cheap, maybe 80 dirham for entrance and the museum.

Beautiful & calm. A colourful garden in the new town of Marrakech, with lots of different features including fountains, a cactus garden, bamboo forest & museum. The garden is small, so you can easily see it all in a hour, but worth a visit.
Stunning. Brilliant ! Would revisit. Small, intimate and very stylish with tons of panache. Go later in the afternoon when crowds are less and the sunlight is better for photographs.

Cacti Garden. Wonderful cacti haven - if you love Cacti, then you will love this garden. Contains many species I had never seen before, and were tree-sized!Also a lovely museum is inside and the room with the jewellery has a wonderful optical illusion effect as you enter.

Beautiful garden and museum. The garden is always very busy apparently, but don't let that put you off, it is worth a visit for the beautiful planting and if you only have time for one museum this is the one to visit

Always stunning. Even after many visits, the Majorelle gardens still astonish and delight. It is worthwhile paying extra to visit the Museum with its beautifully displayed Berber artifacts. There is a delightful reasonably priced courtyard restaurant, and by using its toilets you avoid the queues at the public toilets elsewhere in the garden. There is an official outside the gardens who organises the taxis. Beware, they charge more than twice the going rate, so walk down the short distance into the main road where you can flag down a cab at normal prices.

Interesting Green diversion amongst the best and dust. Walked here from the Medina which was easy to do and no hassle along the way apart from some taxi drivers beeping every now and again for trade. Good mix of plants and a noise tranquil spot. I guess it could get very busy in the summer with coach parties so would recommend going start of day in the high season. The cafe is good and not priced for a captive audience.

Escape from the crowd. This lovely run garden is a real escape from the trouble and hustle of the Medina. We arrived here after hours of crowded Souks and found the perfect place for the moment. The fact you have the pay to enter the Garden makes a audition of 99% tourists- so not dealing and cheating in here. Have a look and take a rest- it´s with it

Marvellous Majorelle in Marrakech. The gardens were magnificent; extremely well maintained and very relaxing to walk through, especially after the crazy Marrakech traffic outside! The connection to YSL was an interesting bit of information as well. This is a well worthwhile attraction; suggest you put it on your list to visit!

Visit to Jardin Majorelle. We visited these gardens around 10 am before it got busy. The garden isn't very big but interesting and beautifully manicured grounds with cactus, palms and the beautiful blue indigo pots and house. We stopped off and enjoyed a mint tea in the cafe in the grounds. An enjoyable restful space away from the mayhem of the Medina. We arrived by taxi and then walked away from the exit and picked up a taxi on the street slightly cheaper, always negotiate price before getting into taxi.

one of the major tourist attraction of Marrakech. Well maintained garden, exotic plants and water ornaments.Created previous century by mr Majorelle et now maintained by the Yves Saint Laurent organisation.In the blue house is a small exhibition on the berbers with clothes, juwelery, pots,..Beside is also an expensive shop and small bar (interiour/exteriour).Worth a visit if interested by above mentioned topics.
Oasis of Calm. What a beautiful botanical garden - really peaceful, relaxing and a burst of colour and fabulous trees and plants. an absolute must when visiting Marrakech.

Beautiful. For us the high point of the stay in Marrakech for its tranquility and atmosphere away from the fascinating but hectic Medina. Do not miss the museum either. Well worth the taxi ride! Lunch in the garden cafe was lovely.

Blue and yellow surprise. Stunning studs of bright colour from yellow and blue and orange pots in this garden of cacti,succulents,bamboo and trees. An true artists garden. Delightful pavilions. Hordes of tourists stopped this from being a highlight of my trip. Go early in the day. Expect to queue. But still worth a visit. A chance to meditate here in peace would be fabulous

Beautiful Gardens for a Stroll. We took a caleche here from the main square and enjoyed our leisurely stroll around the gardens. There is a very nice boutique as well as a coffee shop to enjoy a drink at.

A beautiful garden, currently under maintenance!. I visited Jardin Majorelle with someone I'd met in my hostel, it was approximately 1/2 an hours walk from the Jemaa el Fna.The garden itself is very nice and costs 50 Dirhams to enter. The only downside was the fact that it was under maintenance when I went and many of the bamboo trees had been cut down. Despite this I'd still recommend this little piece of tranquility to people visiting Marrakech.
Blue Majorelle. All beautiful. Only the entrance fee could be cheaper. The place has a wonderful cactus, palm garden. The blue indigo house is very original.
Not very surprised. I liked the garden but I guess it is bit abussive 5 eur the entrance plus paying for the museum plus the taxi we had to pay before. And the size was quite small.

oasis of calm in the caos that is marrakech. 50 dhl entrance is a little steep...would take about 20 mins max to walk through the garden of bamboo and tropical plants....very pretty but nothing to write home about.....
so colourful. Go early as it was busy - but it didn't matter as it was so beautiful. The shop was great too. I would go over and over again.
Amazing oasis hidden from sight. We visited these Gardens in February this year and loved the quality of the gardens , the café, and the amazing designs which made this a very worth while trip

Amazing!. Our taxi driver insisted that this was one garden we should see. And was he right! The history of the gardens is interesting with its links to Yves St Laurent. Beautifully laid out and very peaceful. The fact that there is information about the plants is helpful. A lovely cafe for coffee or lunch is set in a very peaceful part of the garden. The complimentary bottle of water that arrived with our coffee was much appreciated on a warm day. The inevitable gift shop is quite expensive but has some smaller items that are unusual for gifts. Overall a lovely way to spend a couple of hours before taking a short walk into the new part of Marracek and it's upmarket shops and cafes.
pure beauty. this is a MUST visit attraction- the garden is wonderful haven of beauty and design- which is a direct contrast to the immediate vicinity - worth the effort in going!
A bamboo oasis. Quite unlike anything else we saw in Marrakesh. Tall bamboo plants provide shade over the whole garden, it is very calming to stroll around.

Beautiful! Worth it to get out the sun and take in a bit of paradise. Well worth a visit, if a little pricey (50 dhms each) compared to other attractions. Beautiful colours, gardens, ponds, buildings. We went on our last morning there before our flights and well worth the visit. We did not go into the Berber museum however, but you can see some YSL prints and some photographs in the shop.
A must see. A must see garden - it opens at 0800 in the morning so get there early before the crowd - allow 2 hours max
Beautiful!. This well maintained garden and gallery is worth the visit. Yves Saint Laurent impresses with the Love Gallery.

Lovely. I spent abt 45 mins inside. Thought it was great but perhaps I should have chosen a better time as it was rathee busy. I also thought 50 dhs was abit on the pricey side. Despite this, well worth a visit.
What a beautiful place. despite hordes of school children a quite place of great beauty, no wonder YSL loved it. and I collect cacti so it was great to have the plants named

A small but beautifully maintained property. The gardens are quite lovely and well-maintained, and there is a small but nicely appointed museum of Berber artifacts in what had been Jacques Majorelle's studio. There is also a pleasant cafe and gallery and bookstore on the property.

Well worth a visit. Once you've done the Medina, have a relaxing walk in the gardens. A small charge to enter but well worth it. Well maintained and very artistic. A welcome change to the hustle and the bustle of the souks!
unusual. To small,but february not a good season to go.Lots of bamboo and cactus plants and palms.Admission fee acceptable.It was o.k.

I don't understand all these positive reviews. There's nothing peaceful about this garden that's filled to the brim with tourists. Its small enough to walk around in 10 minutes, making the entrance price ridiculous. You are confined to a pathway, with barriers on either side, that does a small lap of the garden. The only part that looks like its had any care and attention paid to it is the shop.Unless you're really into cacti, steer clear.

YSL Sponsored oasis. Beautiful if you like bright colours and cactiI went twice despite the high entry price which was 50dmGet a horse and cart from the medina and take a round rip but don't pay more than 150dmIts an experience and well worth it
A nice peaceful garden.. Love the blue tiles and paint and the silence in the garden is a nice break from the hustle and bustle of the Medina.

Smaller than expected. We were lucky that we got straight in and did not have to queue (like those who were waiting when we left).Gardens were very serene and well kept, but less than we expected. 50Drh for entry and 25drh for entry to museum.A fun way to pass an afternoon.

a little oasis. visited by accident! so glad we did, very calm and beautiful inside, the berber museum is brilliant, a must see. Nice little cafe in the middle with good coffee. I can imagine on a very hot day this is a lovely place to chill in for a couple of hours.

Pristine and colourful. Well looked after, swept within an inch of it's life and a haven in the mad city of Marrakech. Photogenic and interesting and quite tiny, watch out for theHorse drawn transport and the taxis who cajole and use their persuasive powers to extract as much from you as possible. WE paid 5 for a journey from the main square in a taxi, we walked back, what a slog! The gardens are glorious, soaring bamboo, prickly cactus and song bird darting throughout he trees and bushes, cool water in rills and turtles basking in the cool winter sun. We visited after rain was forecast so the crowds were not there, and neither was the rain so we were lucky. Recommended for a morning excursion and top it off with lunch at the Amal Association, about 20 mins walk away. Get a map though!
Nice place. Definitely worth a visit!! Take a cab and walk to Gueliz. Nice bistro with great mint tea. Beautiful gardens

Beautiful. We enjoyed a delightful morning just wandering through the garden and recommend it wholeheartedly. It is relatively small, but is crowded with plants, particularly cacti. It's the sort of place where you can spend half an hour or several hours and provides a complete contrast to the hustle and bustle of the medina.

Very nice gardens, one trip was enough!. These gardens are very interesting and they are worth visiting especially if you are staying in the Medina because you get to see some of the new city getting there! The gardens themselves are quite compact and offer some lovely views. It was very pleasant to stroll around them and I'm glad I visited but I wouldn't return to be fair.

Beautiful gardens. Beautiful gardens to walk around and interesting museum. Cafe is nice but over-priced compared to similar food in places such as Djemma el Fna. Good way to spend a morning in Marrakech

magical. Definitely worth a visit (even if just to get out of the noise and mayhem in the souks and medina). Quiet, serene and oh so beautiful. Everything one would expect of YSL. Exquisite colours, immaculate gardens. Get the combined ticket for gardens and museum and make the most of it. There's a restaurant and couture shop as well.

Magic Majorelle. Fantastic place for colour, peace and serenity. Incredible place on the outskirts of Marrakech. Not sure I'd want to go at the height of the tourist season as it's not a huge place, but in January it was not overly busy. Would recommend the joint ticket for gardens entrance and museum.

Colour colour and peace. Brilliant place to get a bit of peace , if you go early or late, some nature and a colour explosion and lots of photo opportunities. The cacti are amazing and the place makes you feel happy. Cafe good but bit pricey. Well worth a visit.
lovely to walk around but nothing special. It was a lovely walk around but I really did not find anything that caught my attention. I am glad I've seen it but I don't think I will visit it again.
Colourful, with nice little museum.. The museum is particularly interesting for people who like to see the clothes of the different tribes. Beautiful small collection.

Lovely and peaceful.. OK, this review may be biased due to us spending a frustrating morning in the Medina trying to find various things and failing, but this place was a delight. Considering how close it is to a pretty major road it was lovely and quiet. The different plants were interesting, and the gardens are laid out well and show off the various features within. We pottered for a while then went to the café for a very pleasant dessert and drink. And it was so nice to find a toilet where I didn't have to argue with someone to get in!After our snack we strolled around again and you could tell how popular it is by the numbers of people there. It was nice to have a quick look in the gallery and souvenir shops, although they were pricey! There is a large shop outside near the garden entrance which is fascinating and was worth a look.It is slightly higher priced than the majority of tourist attractions in Marrakech but if you need to get away from Moroccan bustle (and they really know how to bustle!) then I do recommend this place.

Oasis of calm. Beautiful garden, the museum is well worth the additional ticket to understand more of the Berber culture, particularly if you are planning a day trip to the Atlas Mountains and the waterfalls.

Tranquil and interesting. Colourful, cool and peaceful garden that provides a stark contrast to the Medina. We had an enjoyable and colourful walk from the Medina to the gardens, so it was a nice place to take a breather. The vibrant colours of the buildings and decorations was lovely, and there was an interesting selection of plants. Warning: even outside high-season in February the number of other tourists could get a little irritating, so I can imagine it might be chaos at other times!
Beautiful, peaceful escape from bustle of city.. Really enjoyed an hour in here. Calm, stylish oasis outside Medina walls. Good value. One hour enough.
over priced. Very small for the distance we walked to get there. 50 dirham to get in. Got horse and carriage back to hotel

very relaxing gardens outside the Medina. A really attractive public garden, especially attractive to painters and those interested in exotic plants. Just a nice place to go and wander for the rest of us. Final resting place of Fashion designer, Yves Saint Laurent.Very cheap at just £3 €4 or $6 per person. Worth a visit for an hour or so but as a tip, visit the café on the street outside rather than the garden's own café.

Average garden but a nice place to get away from the frenzy of Marrakech. Average garden but a nice place to get away from the frenzy of Marrakech. Full of tourists so perhaps pick the time you visit.

Very Impressive. I am not one to go to Botanical Gardens but I thought I would check this place out. It was well worth it. I was astonished at how interesting some of plants were. Also the Berber museum was very interesting. Well worth the visit.

pretty garden with interesting museum... tiny though and could have done with more.. For starters, it was much smaller than I imagined and could have definitely done with more but the garden itself if beautiful and is like an oasis for the weary traveller after a hectic day in the souks. The cobalt blue of the building and the teracotta red flooring provide a beautiful and striking contrast to the flora and fauna. I didn't stop for a coffee but did the muesum which has print artworks from Yves St. Laurent. Spend an hour or so there and then head out elsewhere.
Beautiful!. A wonderful garden full of colour, water, birds, peace. Head for here after a hectic time in the souk or elsewhere.

Lovely, but most expensive meal of the holiday!. We visited the garden is January and it is lovely, after the chaos of getting there in a caleche, it was very peaceful. We lunched in the cafe which was very quaint, but on the expensive side for what we had (small tagine and a nicoise roll, tea and juice for two - 250dh). Definitely better value places to eat lunch but it was a nice setting.
bit boring. the gardens are quite small and given largely to cactus which isn't really our thing. Probably be better in the summer.Great coffee from the corner cafe outside the gardens

Really liked it. Another lovely, relaxing place to spend an hour. Beautifully maintained and beautifully laid out. Criticism is only that it is small so you could be in round and out in half an hour, but we wandered and took photos and loved every minute.

Nice but nothing special. I was there in winter and I found the place worth the visit only if you have to kill an hour.Giant bamboo and nice cactus area but nothing more.Take it as the eventual last thing to do in Marrakech

Pretty - but just a garden. Very pretty gardens to spend an hour or so in... but at the end of the day, it's just a garden! How long can you spend seeing flowers, fish, trees and foliage?Recommend for a couple of hours if you have the time - but not a necessity when visiting Marrakech.

Lovely blue. Its all about color in this garden. The stunning blue walls and pillars with the bright yellow pots. The number of succulents is just overwhelming and I was happy to see agave in its cactus form, since we use the liquid as sweetener all the time.

An oasis in an otherwise hectic city.. A perfect place to get away from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. The gardens are absolutely beautiful. Go early to avoid the crowds. You can also purchase a ticket on entry to the Berber Museum which is located within the gardens, whilst small it is probably one of the best museums I saw during my two weeks in Morocco. There is also a lovely cafe within a small courtyard near the gardens shop which serves very good coffee. Something that is not always readily available in Morocco.

See colour differently.. All superlatives have doubtless been employed.The "Dry garden" is a truly stunning visual experience and the separate museum provides an excellent curation of Berber culture.A must for the discerning traveller and a fitting shrine to an icon.

A beautiful piece of tranquility. These small but beautiful gardens were gorgeous. Very cheap entry price & a lovely cafe for a drink or lunch. (Would recommend the club sandwich!)Amazing colours & the cacti were brilliant! Try to go on a sunny day to really appreciate the vibrant colours. Other reviews I read said that entry was over-priced but we thought it was really cheap. It was really nice to have a quiet bit of time away from the hustle & bustle!Well worth a visit.

Smaller than expected. The gardens were smaller than I expected and we probably wouldn't have spent much time there if we didn't eat at the cafe. It's a lovely relaxing place to visit (and I definitely needed a rest after walking from the Medina to the new town, and then to the gardens!). The cafe was a bit expensive but we all really enjoyed our meals there. My couscous was delicious, although the bread wasn't anything special.
Nice. Nice garden with lots of tourists. A bit expensive compared to other things (50 Dh), but worth a one-hour visit.

Tranquillity. The Jardin Majorelle are really worth a visit, they are an oasis of calm in an otherwise busy city. The area around the gardens is hectic but step inside and you are immediately transformed into another world. The Berber Museum within the garden is really worth a visit giving an insight into the history of the Berber people. The cafe in the corner of the gardens is also worth visiting for drinks or light meals.

A must. The Gardens cost 20dh and the museum 10dh both a definite must see. Do sit on the benches and just immerse yourself in the equity around you. To learn more about the people the museum provides some good info.
nice plants. The price is good with or without a berber museum. In the berber museum you can see the clothes of traditional.

Brightened up a rainy day. We visited during the rainiest day of the year but the vibrant blues and vivid yellows of the plant pots reflected in the red tiled paths brightened up a soggy day.This is a very well laid out and maintained collection of cacti, succulents, palms and flowering shrubs.It is impossible not to come away with good photographs even on a wet grey day. There is such a choice of vistas through, between and around the plants with pergolas, arches, water features connected by meandering paths. The book shop and boutique are interesting but not cheap. The cafe in the little courtyard has a wood fire to welcome you in from the cold.To get back to the Medina, avoid the overpriced taxis just outside and hail one on the main road, Avenue Yacoub Al Mansour, instead.
Modern garden with old sights. The botanical features in this garden are excellent and well arranged around various features. The museum is definitely worth the 25dh. Excellent overall attraction.
A must!!. Suggestion: to take a carriage from near the main Square costs 10€. It's worth.If you take a táxi back to the center, it costs 5.€
Small but Beautiful Gardens. Very relaxing and peaceful small garden mainly of cacti and succulents. The cafe was a more expensive than elsewhere but worth it.
Do not miss this, and go to the museum. This was our favourite place in Marrakech. The gardens are very beautiful and calming, and the little museum is an absolute jewel.
Tranquil. For 75DH you can go in both the gardens and the Berber museum. Neither are particularly big and are both best appreciated by sitting and taking your time with them.
Interesting. The best bit for us was the Berber museum which is situated in the gardens, extra to go in but worth it.

Bit dissapointing. Smaller and less spectacular than expected. Very little variety, basically a walk around a garden of mainly Bamboo.
Pleasant experience but perhaps over rated in terms of what Marrakech has to offer.
JARDIN MAJORELLE - It was only OK but nothing special.. It was OK but we expected it to be much better & it only took half an hour to look round but was not expensive to enter.
Nice place to visite. Nice and clean and very colourful, nice cactus , and the place is very clean, I find 6 euros is a bit expensive for the time you spend in the garden, but it is something to do.

Beautiful Setting - Great Visit. Spent a few hours here and enjoyed the amazingly beautiful gardens and a quick meal in the cafe.The gardens are well maintained and the small gallery with drawings by Yves Saint Laurent were a nice getaway from the busy streets of Marrakech. We didn't visit the museums on site but just walking around was enough.Note, the taxis outside the gardens may try to rip you off so be careful!
Stunning!. Amazing, beautiful and well looked after! Gorgeous colours and very informative. Took some great photos.

Very beautyfull garden.. Colorfully view and rich botanic garden. Crowded, so you need 2 or 3 hours to complete the visit. If you want to buy anything be aware that credit card are accepted but never complete connection, as usual in Maroc.

A Nice Break from the Hustle of the Medina.... We enjoyed these gardens, It was a nice break from the constant 'hey lady', 'just for looking', 'where you from' of the Medina. The entry fee is reasonable, and the gardens are calm despite being full of other people! We walked to the gardens, and in walking out of the medina we got a bit off track and came out on Rue El Gza, where the local market is. We were approached by a man telling us the gardens were closed, because it was Friday, the sabbath, and that there was a Berber market, with camels, so we started walking towards the market. Once we were close to the next gate, the man showed up again. At this point we realized he was trying to get us off course. If you are approached by people like this just ignore them, and stay your course...

A blue garden. been here in dec 2013, Well Majorelle was donated by a French man to marrakesh then later bought by the famous Yves St Laurent in which a dedicated place and museum was built, As an asian and have seen the beautiful gardens of China and Japan, Majorelle is unique on its own, some selected exotic bamboos will welcome you from the entrance, it is quite small, there is an entrance fee. Wild and giant cactus can also be found , what I like in this garden is the lovely dark blue jars and pots all over the place and the lovely combination of red, orange and yellow walls and windows of the small museum and private house in the center of the garden. They also have lovely Spanish Bougainvilla ! made some lovely photos from here and have copied some pots deco for my home.
Mrs. Absolutely beautiful place. Peaceful and estetic. Recommend a visit there. Good place to take a lunch too.

Nice Gardens. 10 Dirham entry, so good value.
Beautiful laid out, very small (but peaceful).
Nice cacti collection
Statue dedicated to Yves St Laurent
Yves saint Laurent garden. This was a lovely afternoon out and well worth the trip. The gardens were fantastic, very well kept and beautifully kept.
Beautiful. A lovely couple of hours spent walking round these gardens. Worth a visit. There was a small museum inside at an extra cost which is optional.
lovely!. such an unusual place, great colour scheme! such a well kept property. Nice museum and good coffee bar.
beautiful gardens. The Marjorel Gardens were a gorgeous oasis of calm in Marrakesh but I thought slightly overpriced when you consider that the ancient palaces were only 10 dirhams for entry.
over priced and v small. to be honest, quite boring, very small, over priced ( unusually for marrakech), even the toilet attendant expected tipping

Very Good. Definitely worth a visit, not a very large place however, although it's calm and peaceful as you're transported away from the hustle and bustle of the main road.
