Well maintained gardens and beautiful water features (don't forget the camera)! Bookshop and Boutique on site but expensive, nice little outdoor café to enjoy a tea or coffee although not cheap. Gets busy around lunchtime so an earlier visit avoids the worst of the crowds. Would be a pleasant respite from the heat of the high season.

A very unique Garden. It was very nice to see the garden restored to its former glory with the support of YSL, It felt like an oasis in the middle of a very dry and dusty city. It was lovely to see all the different kinds of cactus so amazingly different. Worth a visit especially arriving by caleche ( horse drawn carriage).

Crowded and overpriced. We were a bit disappointed by the gardens. We had expected more colour. They were quite small and very busy with bus loads of tourists. The entry price was very steep compared to other attractions in Morocco. It was a cold wet day when we were there, so I am sure they would be much more inviting on a hot summer's day. There was a lot of bamboo which is considered a noxious weed in our country so we were not that impressed. We were more impressed by a couple of the parks in Marrakech which were free to walk through and were more colourful.

Lovely garden and cafe. Lovely shady garden, mostly succulents and palms, with a couple of ponds and blue painted museum. A decent size to wander around, although not as big as it looked on the map. The cafe is a great place for lunch - excellent service and good food (I had a Caesar salad and my wife had the Moroccan salad) albeit at a European price. The museum has a lot of Islamic jewellery and traditional dress from the various native Moroccan tribes and is perhaps a bit too much to take in.

Not sure what all the fuss is about!!. We were a little disappointed with the gardens especially as every guide book we looked recommended them. First of all, they're pretty small. You could easily walk around them in 10/15 minutes. Secondly, half of the gardens is just made up of bamboo. The rest is mostly a collection of cacti. Although this was probably the better side to the gardens.Very little colour throughout although this may be due to the time of year we visited (Jan).50 Dh entry

Wow, what a place. I was so looking forward to seeing this garden and it didn't disappoint. It is certainly unique and lovely to wander round. We did the museum as well. We also had refreshments in the cafe which was a little dear but excellent quality and good service. It made for a whole experience. Not a big garden but don't miss it and we were advised to go later in the day when the coaches have left so we got there about 3pm which worked well.

Very peaceful Oasis. We loved walking round the gardens and looking at the shrubs and cacti as well as the ornamental pond. The bright yellow and blue pots and the pictures and items in the shop captured the essence of Yves St. Laurent. We spent around an hour there which was sufficient.
Not to be missed.. Beautiful and peaceful garden. The cacti are really impressive and the blue studio building gives a wonderful contrast to the planting.A real oasis not to be missed.

Welcome respite. from all the hustle and bustle that is Marrakech.The cacti collection is amazing and the size of the bamboo awesome. All very clean and tidy, well kempt. Can walk here from tourist bus stop 1 about 20 minutes up straight road, (1st left after oasis tourist bus stop or iron gates for main house) or my advise would be get a taxi which will drop you right outside. It is open daily and all day unlike some attractions.Café/restaurant was very pleasant, probably more expensive than could get elsewhere but the service and presentation was very good.Garden is away from all the other things to do in area but worth the trip.If you are walking and a local approaches you and tells you it is closed carry on - it almost certainly will be open - to our cost.

beautiful place. The gardens are really beautiful. We liked the decoration, the colours and the amount of cactus each one with its name. The only disadvantage is the price, a little expensive for Marrakech
Peace and Tranquility in the Heart of Chaos!!. Beautiful... Colourful... Peaceful... and a tea room!! Jardin Majorelle is the perfect Marrakech chaos getaway!!
An oasis in Marrakech. It was pretty nice to find such a nice place to visit in Marrakech. The colours, the temperature, the ambience,... a pleasure for the senses.

great gardens. the entry fee is the most expencive in marrakech but the gardens are lovely and the House looks amazing. we went early morning and still there were people waiting for the tickets (only about 15 munites) as is was very early and the trees were tall it was chilly while we were there . so i think later will be more pleasent . a good day out

Good garden to kill some time. Not a very large garden, can be done within 1hr. The colours are very interesting and make very good pictures. The shop outside the garden sell very artistic goods and is worth a visit.

A tranquil haven amongst the madness. We loved this Garden, We arrived by horse and carriage and saw quite a bit of the new City en route. The Garden is well maintained and has a very large range of tropical plants and palms all within a lovely setting.
Haven of peace. What a lovely tranquil place to find in such a busy city. Although small they are exquisite ,especially the cacti.
Oasis of calm in Marrakech. Beautiful, calm, restful, cool. Perfect little oasis of calm from all the noise and very easy to get to by public bus or taxi if you are feeling flush.
Outside the Medina. It was good to see this "formal" garden which was quite unlike any we would see at home comprising as it did of mainly trees, palms cactii and bamboos.

Overrated and over-priced. We walked to Jardin Majorelle from the medina and enjoyed the green and coolness of the place. It is a postage stamp-sized garden, and is too much given over to bamboo and bare earth. I did love the cacti, but as gardens go, this one was not worth the admission charge.
majorelle gardens. a peaceful and unexpected oasis of colour and plant architecture hidden behind large walls . beautiful surroundings

Stunning. This is the most beautiful garden I have ever visited! With the added bonus of the Berber museum within its grounds. An extraordinary collection of cacti and an incredible blue decorating it's grounds. Wonderful.

Maybe for summer respite from the medina.. If you are staying in the medina, in the heat of summer without a garden at your hotel or Riad, then we can imagine this would be worth a visit. The gardens are well kept and the Berber museum is small but interesting. We visited on a cool and rainy day and to be honest were underwhelmed. However, we are staying at Les Jardins de Medina, which itself has beautiful gardens hidden in the medina. So perhaps for us, we ventured out to discover what was in fact on our doorstep. Don't let that put you off!

An oasis of mystery and tranquility. We arrived late in the day after touring around the city and found the bamboo and cactus filled garden a tranquil and exotic place to meander through. The contrast of greys, greens and blue of the many large cacti were remarkable. The cobalt blue of planters and wooden structures was a nice vibrant contrast. There is a tea garden as well as a small boutique and bookshop. We returned a second time to se the wonderful Berber Museum. We travelled everywhere in horse and carriage. As with taxis there are no set prices or meters so yell the driver where you are going and negotiate the price ahead. They will offer to wait and take you on.. It worked great for us and there was no extra charge.

A beautiful place to visit. Well laid out gardens with very unusual plants from around the world reflecting the world of palms, cactii and other plants from the more arid regions of the world. Very busy so not so easy to enjoy the quietness that would make it so special.

Tranquil in the middle of madness! . Interesting to read reviews saying the gardens are small. They're not massive, agreed, however an hour or hour and a half was long enough to really wander slowly and appreciate this gorgeous place. For 50 Dirhams, I don't know why you wouldn't go there! Well worth it, especially if you're British like me (vs our US friends in Arizona who've seen it all before!), because like me you probably won't have seen plants that require sunshine grow that tall!!A great 'filler' for a rest from the craziness outside the garden walls!

“Must see if you love gardening!”. The colors, the plants and the overall garden design are magnificent! We had a blast walking around and looking at everything. They have a very nice cafe too that serves breakfast so you could get there first thing and have a wonderful morning exploring. We tried to walk there from the medina with our guide ahmed hwo guids us from our hotel as we booked the trip with trekinatlas.co.uk company. its a lovely lovely Gardine honestly

A shrine for love and cacti.. I never wanted to leave. Actually, we had to come back the next day, cause this is an experience to dwell upon. There is i sobre form of peace in the Majorelle. The odeours(as much from all the beautiful men pilgrimaging the Memoir stone of Yves st Laurent as the flowers) caress you on the way through and the art in the collection, montage and proportiones of the plant life lowers speach and holda attention. We had to loveley visits and a little internal gallery og memories.

Worth a Visit. Worth a visit if you have time.. couldn’t agree more with other reviews… It is well maintained and very pleasant, delightful gardens, well designed with interesting flora throughoutThe reastairant withion the garden was very nice can't recollect the name.. decent food with very good service..
It is a must go!. One of the most beautiful places I have ever been! It is well maintained and very very pleasant. It has delightful gardens.
Eutopia if you could be alone there.. This is a beautiful well designed garden with interesting flora throughout. Water features that calm, shaded paths to stroll with places to sit and reflect.

amazing place. Very unusual garden with loads of cactus types. it is small but nice to stroll around for an hour. The memorial of Eve San Laurent is also inside the garden. It is within walking distance from old Medina and if you are in Marrakesh it is worth a visit.

incredibly vivid memory. This garden was renovated by YSL, whose ashes are in his rosebeds on the other side of the wall,and anyone interested in design and, above all, the use of colour, will be dazzled. I'm not a major fan of cacti either, but the combination of them with other trees, the pavilions, winding paths, and the boldness and elegance is marvellous. Small and stunning. Great cafe. Great museum.Thank you, Majorelle and YSL.And Pierre Berge.
10 minutes of your life!. Don't expect to spend any more time there unless you are very passionate about cacti and palms! Nice for a bit of peace from the madness of this city but that's about it!

A beautiful little garden. We loved jardin Majorelle. a beautiful little garden full of bamboo, succulents and cacti some of the best I have seen. I should imagine it would be even better in spring or summer
Family holiday. Only one word comes to my mind: Awesome Too bad you can't visit the house of Yves Saint Laurent; The Garden Majorelle is beautiful, the colors incredible and the blue inspiring
Top experience !. I just tell you that this will be the first place I will visit again when back to Marrakesh. Elegant, magic, unique atmosphere.

Nothing Great. If you love to look at cactus plants & palm trees, then you'll love this place. If not, go somewhere else. This small garden, and I emphasize the word small, is not worth the time or trip to visit. If you live in Florida or Arizona, you'll see a lot more in your backyard.

Cool beutiful garden & great museum. The temperature of the garden was cool due to the structures and plants. The plants were interesting from all over the world, walls and pots were painted in bright yellow, azure and terracotta. The best part of out trip was the museum (you need to purchase a separate ticket) at the end of the garden. It showed the history of Berbers through agricultural tools, jewellery and costume etc. , very interesting.

Outstanding Garden/Museum visit. The Jardin Majorelle, restored by Yves St.Laurent was a fabulous find, cool, beautiful, the finest collection of Palms & Cactus that we have visited anywhere. St.Laurents former home is now a Berber Museum and so well done. Introductory photos of Berber life, followed by a wonderful collection of costumes, jewelry & handicrafts. The cafe is also excellent!

Peaceful. Just a few steps from the noise and hubbub of city traffic, the gardens are a delight to behold. The peacefulness seems to mesmerise the senses and calm even the most stressed traveller. Just sit back and enjoy the view.

Not worth it. Just a simple garden, the old nice hotels in Marroco have nicer garden so does the restaurant Boi & Zin, and hired a balloon ride there from a french Woman it was the scaryest thing i've been… Dont go! If you want balloon rides take other companys!
Very nice garden. Was a nice garden however the museum was unfortunately closed when we got there. The garden is small so you won't be there very long but the cafe serve great ice cream & coffee.

Must see if you love gardening!. The colors, the plants and the overall garden design are magnificent! We had a blast walking around and looking at everything. They have a very nice cafe too that serves breakfast so you could get there first thing and have a wonderful morning exploring. We tried to walk there from the medina and got lost so get VERY good directions or spring for a taxi.

Lush, tranquil Oasis.. Most of Marrakech is arid the depth of greenery at gardens are a nice distraction from the usual hustle and bustle. There is a lovely insure courtyard cafe with indoor seating alternatively I would also recommend a visit the kitch snack bar Kaowa while you are in the area. Just round the corner from the gardens. For only 39 dirhams you can have a little snack and a drink. It also offers free Wifi and has a shop selling excellent quality Argan oil, kitch paintings and other souvenirs. The gardens are small and there is not much variety in plants (Bamboo and cacti) but it's designed nicely with little water features, walkways and seated areas. We spent 1.5hours here and sadly didn't get to see the Berber Museum. It's a great place for pictures.

Visit to the gardens. The place is quite a nice little escape but it is overpriced. We had a great time walking around but the museum itself is rather small and too many visitors are allowed at one time.

Jardin Majorelle, Marrakesh, Morocco. Interesting little garden with trees from all over the world. Well worth a visit at a small cost (extra for the little Berber museum). Allow for an hour. Lovely garden terrace cafe inside at Yves St Laurent prices.
Brilliant photo opportunity.

Stunningly restored garden. This is a small patch of heaven. Walking from the ramshackled and busy bus station you take your life in your hands crossing the roads to get there. The area around the garden is clearly well to do and there is a lovely coffee shop almost opposite the entrance. The gardens themselves were rescued by Yves St Laurent who has a small shrine there to his memory. "Majorelle Blue" was invented to paint the buildings and post with and is wonderful. The gardens themselves contain many plants that survive in hot climes, including the most amazing collection of cactii. The main building houses a fabulous museum of Berber history and is a must see. Admission is covered by the entrance price. There is an excellent cafe too and if you time it right then a good look round, with lunch, could take a couple of hours out of your day. However it is a major stop for tourist coaches so if you want to be alone arrive early or late - at midday it will be heaving and you will inevitably appear in alot of other people's photographs!
Peace. After a stressful morning this was an oasis of calm & peace. Beautiful with some lovely areas. It is out of the way so negotiated a taxi fare

Back again!. Second visit to Jardin Majorelle, and as beautiful and tranquil as before, so peaceful here, after the wonderful craziness of Marrakech, got here early to avoid the crowds:) fabulous place to take lots of photos, infact since I returned to the UK I had a couple of my photos developed and blown up to poster size, to frame and hang in my lounge, they look beautiful and a reminder of my lovely holiday.I spent a couple of hours here walking around, taking pictures and then had a café au lait in the café sitting by the roaring fire, highly recommended.
beautifull. make sure you take atleast 2 hours it is lovely and relaxing in the shaded gardens. we took the tourist bus and dropped of there for a nice and quite few hours

Attractive but Limited. Our visit to the Jardin Majorelle was a short one. After entering through a very attractive door, we had the opportunity to freely walk through the gardens. Apart from a nice gazebo near the entrance, there was however nothing special. It seemed like any other ordinary palm tree garden. If you were to venture over to the left, you could see through a large gate into what was basically a building site. After venturing past the rather dull Yves Saint-Laurent monument, we were finally greeted by something interesting. A beautiful pond and a lovely over-vegetated bridge that then led us to the vibrant cactus farm that sat next to a large bright blue building. This was more like it! However, to our disappointment, that was it. There was nothing else to these famed gardens. So be warned, if you're expecting a grandiose walk then you might as well go somewhere else. However, for a quick short walk around a rather pleasant environment, go for it.

Magical gardens. The gardens themselves are well worth the trip out of the medina and the Berber museum is full of wonderful objects, displayed with lots of additional information about Berber life and culture.
Tranquility. Beautiful! And after the hassle and bustle of the markets and traders it is a welcome chill out. Also nice shops around and cafés to eat

beautiful gardens. As soon as you walk through the gate and see the giant bamboo growing you feel somewhere else. The hustle and bustle it long gone and you are surround in green & peace. The use of water is good and so many different plants shapes and sizes. If going on your own you an find a quiet spot to sit and read, what ever just to enjoy the peace and colour.
Jardin Majorelle. its a garden full of cactus collection. Although I could not see a single exotic collection which i have not seen before. Worth a view if you are in Marrakech
Beautiful. Amazing place. Calm and peaceful, lovely plants. My son loved to run around. A bit crowded, but very respectfully, as if everybody was simply enjoying their visit. Wish to go again.

A must see. A tranquil haven in the heat of Marrakesh. Stunning gardens and excellent photo opportunities. Well worth wandering around then nipping into the cafe for a drink.... then wander around again... Only downside is the lack of signs & directions finding it !!

OASIS. Arrived by taxi and the taxi driver was happy to wait a couple of hours in order to take us back. No need really since the site is well served by taxis. You wont get stranded. Its a garden mostly of Cactaceae and in that it is excellent but it is not a garden of general flora. I could have spent far longer than the 2 hours not because of its size but because ever step presents another photo opportunity. Great for photographers!We had a drink and pastry in the cafe and that was also excellent and worth a visit.I would go again

Jardin Majorelle - A Marrakech Must!. Beautiful Gardens created by artist Jacques Majorelle and owned by Yves St Laurent & partner Pierre Berger. Entering the gardens you are met with a sense of serenity and calm. Walk down paths between an exotic variety of palms and cactus. See the final resting place of Yves St. Laurent. Only three rooms, the Berber Museum-a collection of artifacts, costumes and jewelry of The Berber culture - is one of the finest displays I have seen. Enjoy a memorable lunch or breakfast from the wonderful offerings of the Jardin Majorelle Cafe
Lovely garden. Not as big as we expected but beautiful, statuesque forms in the planting. Very crowded though - the number of people got in the way of really appreciating the gardens fully.

beautiful gardens. Beautiful gardens, definitely worth a visit, especially in combination with the museum inside. Here are in three rooms the berber history displayed with their tools, jewellery and clothing. Very nice. And the garden is lovely to walk around in.

Bulbuls and Berbers. This very lovely, stylised garden splashed with the brilliant colours of Morocco (notably electric blue) on pots, jars and the stunning Berber Museum at its core is a place to lose yourself: in the rustle of bamboo, the otherworldly shapes of cacti, the lapping of water, and the intermittent calls of bulbuls and house buntings. As with so many of the city's delights, this mini-paradise is just off a dusty road, making entry into its cool confines all the more wonderful.The aura of the great Yves San Laurent, who lived nearby, is palpable; but the Berbers win out in the end. The museum collection reveals the truly stupendous inventiveness of their garments, musical instruments, tools and jewelry, and the remarkable endurance of their culture and language. There's a very nice cafe-restaurant in a courtyard too.
Oasis in Marrakech. This is an amazing garden, laid out with plants from all over the world. The Berber Museum is a delight, with very informative exhibits.
Visit to gardens. Was very busy and a lot smaller than I thought it would be.. probably better to go early or late. Pretty - but too crowded.

Very nice. Worth visit,pleasant setting and lots of photographic opportunities due to colours etc.
Interesting museum on Berber culture and fabulous courtyard cafe.

Strikingly beautiful gardens. Absolutely beautiful place, with a very striking arrangement of plants and colours. a bit pricey, specially the shops (book store, and fashion. Still, it IS Yves Saint Laurent…)

Absolute must-see when you are in Marrakech. This place should definitely be on everyone's to-do list when travelling to Marrakech. Bright colours of design and architecture objects, as well as various plants from around the globe. You'll fall in love with the majorelle blue colour. Though I did not like the boutique, as there was nothing I wanted to buy (usually I'm a big fan of museum shops).
Oasis in the city. Visiting again this garden is still enchanting. I had never realised it was packed with mexican and latin american plants but being there with my Mexican friend opened up my eyes.
A deeply blue oasis of calm. An oasis of calm out of the lively and chaotic life of the Medina. Wonderful plants and colors and unmistakable Yves Saint Laurent taste

Peace, even when crowded.. Worth the half-hour queue for the shade, calm and botanic interest. Not huge - easily doable in an hour. Very photogenic. YSL connections, but only a small monument and a small exhibition. Very good but not mindblowing

Stunning!. The Majorelle Garden, created by the French painter Jacques Majorelle and restored by Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Berge is stunningly beautiful. The simplicity of the exotic planting, the tranquil ponds, the organic bamboo fences and the vibrant but limited colours used for the pots, building, etc. make this garden a peaceful oasis in busy Marrakesh. At the same time its impact on the senses is huge. The garden is immaculately kept. There is a Berber Museum and a small gallery containing Yves Saint Laurent's original Love paintings used for his New Year cards. If you visit Marrakesh this place is a must.
A wonderful garden. A place of peace - huge bamboo, giant cactus, blue everywhere - look for memorial to Yves St. Laurent and also the gallery of his Christmas cards.
Amazing. We love the Majorelle garden and the museum, the best in Marrakech. The trees and the atmosphere are awesome, and having a coffee at the restaurant is priceless.

A crowded oasis in the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. These gardens are well kept and it was interesting to see all the plant and cactus varieties as well as some of Yves Saint Laurent's posters, etc. However there were a lot of people and the cost (50 dirhams per person, I think) was relatively steep considering you could walk round the gardens within half an hour.

Beautiful place, good cafe. The gardens, landscaping and colors here are incredible! Went with my family. Came from a camel excursion, so we were dropped off here. Small entrance fee (smaller kids are generally free in Morocco; the cutoff seems to be teenage-appearing). Very tranquil place. Cafe is very pleasant, busy, but with decent food. Even one of the local cats was dining on a goldfish that it had caught in the pond in the gardens! Gift shop and book store available. We did not go into the museum (another separate, small entrance fee). There is also a gallery of the original 'Love' art that Yves Saint Laurent sent each year as a holiday card.

Not all that much to see but it is pretty. It's cheap to get in and theres some pretty pottery and colours, but you will get round it in about 15 mins and it's quite a walk away from the old town. nice if you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of it all.

Well worth the visit!. Beautiful garden where you can easily spend a few hours. However, the best part about our visit was the food in the cafe. By far the best Tagine we had during our 14-days in Morocco.

My favourite hour in Marrakech. An oasis in the chaos of Marrakech. I LOVED the feel of this place. It's calm, beautiful and tranquil. A million photo opportunities! Lunch was excellent too (a bit expensive for Marrakech, but worth it.)

Magical Place. This place is so peaceful that you forget you are in th middle of Marrakesh with all it's hustle and bustle. There are some fantastic plants to see. Yves Saint Laurens ashes are scattered here, you can also see his memorial in the gardens. The Berber museum is inside the gardens and well worth a visit. There is also a cafe here. It was very busy when we visited but we were very glad that we did.

Colourful but small. We were there before lunch at it was quite crowded. It is quite beatiful thanks to the colourful backdrop of the houses in the garden, however it was quite small and full of people. We enjoyed it because it felt like a quiet oasis compared to the dust-filled streets of the medina.

Yve St Laurent gardens. Its a tourist must see in Marrakech, its basically a house with some nice trees etc, fancy blue building that look great in photo form. But it won't break your budget but nothing worth stressing out over as a must see.
A garden oasis. Really well kept and lovely environment. Great value for money too and lots of places en route for coffee etc
Worth the visit. The gardens are lovely but we really enjoyed to visit of the Berber museum. It's worth taking the time to go in.

Beautiful garden with bright colors and interesting plants. The contrast of the bright "marjorelle" blue and the plants was great. Over 400 different species of palmtrees and 2000 cacti. Very busy park. One big negative was the long line to enter the park. There was also a second long line to enter the small inside museum, so we've skipped that part.

Beautiful garden. When we entered here we were a bit surprised - a lush, green garden in the middle of a desert city! The best jardin in Marrakech that we went to, with various trees, plants and fountains. There is even a memorial to Yves Saint Laurent. Well worth visiting, we just wished it could have been a bit bigger. Be prepared for a crowd.

Beautiful garden. This garden was designed by the painter Jacques Majorelle and was owned by Yves Saint Laurent, whose ashes were deposited in it. It is the repository of several hundreds plant sepcies and a couple buildings mostly painted in the 'bleu Majorelle' color, quite strong and fresh ! A lot of nice photography opportunities. Don't miss the museum !

A Haven. Peaceful haven from the bustle of Marrakech . highly recommend walking here if it's cool enough to appreciate this (15 mins from Medina) .. gorgeous shop with extremely high prices and reasonable cafe that you absolutely must try, the cornes de gazelle and mint tea are the speciality, along with rosewater ice cream .. nice design shops outside the gates, good for high quality modern souvenirs

Quite nice but not impressive. Nice shade from the bamboo, lots of interesting plants and a nice vibrant blue colour scheme for planters etc, but not a large garden. I thought it was overpriced considering the cost of other attractions in Marrakesh, and how little time we spent there - 20 minutes was sufficient to have a good look around. It was pleasant but not remarkable at all. I actually enjoyed the Cyber park more (free entry, public park down near the medina)

beautiful but crowded. beautiful and a must to see but very crowded, we paid extra for the museum inside the gardens but gave up after queuing for too long so no idea what missed out on. try to go early in the day to beat the crowfs
Amazing cacti!. Interesting tropical garden with memorial to Yves St Laurent who once owned it but not really a major attraction

Beautiful but not so much when crowded. Timing might be everything. The garden is absolutely beautiful, but when it's crowded it kind of ruins the effect. We went at 4:00 PM and it seems everyone had the same idea as us. Nice boutiques on the premises.

Escapade.... We were excited to visit St Laurent's house in Marrakesh; but it actually was not, it was painter Majorelle's, and then the St Laurent- Pierre Bergé foundation renovated it, from what I understood. The "Jardin" in itself isn't SPECTACULAR; although classy with all its blue and yellow dots, dispatched in the whole exotic garden, it is quite small, and especially full of tourists (all right, that's quite normal...). I think the real point of interest in this is the Berber (?) museum, which displayed great objects of Berber everyday-life and ceremonies. You can see a wide range of marriage and special events clothing and jewelry, and a lot of interesting, typical objects. It also explains a lot about the origins of this community, its religions, beliefs, uses... It really worths it. It's not too long, doesn't cost too much, is well-made and perfectly arranged, and clean. Go! But otherwise, I'm not convinced by the garden...
Beautiful Gardens. A beautiful but small garden in the new town area of Marrakech. The cafe in the gardens is worth stopping at for a drink or a bite of lunch. There is also an interesting museum.

Popular well laid out gardens with excellent cafe. Smaller than I had expected but well laid out - dominatied by huge variety of cacti and bamboo. A haven for birds - fish and turtles in ponds.Small museum with Berber artifacts - worth seeing.Very pleasant cafe.
Majorelle Gardens. Everything we expected and more, quiet and serene after the noise of the city outside, loads to see in the Berber Museum as well.

My kind of heaven. Visited this garden about 6 times so far- it was always a revelation. Suptle changes each time, but always the same exaltation and wonder that up lifts the heart and soothes the senses.The Museum is a must see. A ' Paris' grade display (set up by M. Berger) of ethnographic material from the numerous Berber Tribes. Truly inspirational patterns and colours.

Okay for cactus lovers. Thought it would be a nice break from the hustle and bustle outside. But this was just as busy inside. The actual garden is pretty meh and small. Tons of cactus. So you better love them. There's a shrine to YSL hidden somewhere at the back amongst the bamboo. Wasn't really worth the time. There is a YSL store on site. Same prices as back home. Doesn't have full range. Just scarfs bags and jewellery. But nice change from the rubbish they sell in the souks. For a moment forgot I was in Morocco. They also have some of YSL's prints in a display room which is nice. He does them, well did them, each year to send to his company's clients. I wanted one as a poster. But as I said the store here onsite is a proper one and not a normal site giftshop.

Best thing in Marrakech.. We much prefer Fez to Marrakech but this garden alone almost made us change our minds. A wonderful oasis of green plants, including some of the most exotic cacti we have ever seen set in a beautifully designed memorial to the great French designer. There is also a museum (separate entrance fee required) which presents exhibits of the history of the Berbers, things which one really has to know to appreciate Morocco. Don't miss it! It beats the medina and the much promoted snake-charmers in the square.

Too Small, Not Enough Variety of Plants. I was excited to visit the Jardin Majorelle with my daughter after spending too much time shopping in the Medina. It was a change of scenery but really not worth the effort. It is very small and there isn't a great variety of things to look at. We were in and out of there in 20 minutes. I can imagine in the summer that it would provide some much needed shade when the weather heats up but it wasn't that warm and I would've preferred to be sitting by the pool. I did like the cacti and bamboo though. Perhaps we are spoilt as we have visited many lovely gardens but this is not one of them.

great style. great place to stroll around and enjoy the overall ambiance of the place. One can see why it is such a popular location. Would try the cafe there next time.Majorelle blue is pretty stunning and has to be seen in situ.

Wonderful experience in a noisy city. What a beautiful place - although relatively small, it's like entering an entirely other world. And the café is definitely also worth a visit. Highly recommendable!
Nice. It is a very nice decorated garden. But to be honest we did feel that this is a "must-see" in Marrakesh.

Lovely garden, avoid peak times. Lovely garden, not as big as I had thought it would be. Its main virtue is probably as a shady space away from the hustle and bustle, but it was packed full of people when we went at midday: perhaps get there much earlier to best appreciate it, or take a book and park yourself up on a bench for a bit. We found the small Berber museum interesting; there were cards available with English language explanations of all the items on display in each of the rooms.
pretty gardens. Very pretty gardens with plants from all over. Smaller than I thought it would be. Lots of visitors. Morning was a good time to visit

Pretty Gardens with an amazing variety of cacti. These gardens are not huge in area and are full of different shapes & sizes of cacti and the blue cobalt buildings look very pretty and you can view some of Yves Saint Laurents drawings and there is also a small museum you can walk around
what a lovely garden. Loads of Mexican cactus and agave plants, we loved the layout, the paths. A very nice space to be in and enjoy a bit of wonder. Beautifully tended! We loved it!

A must!. First a colourful garden, and do not ,miss to visit the Berbermuseum that is the best museum in Marrakech. You can buy ticket for the museum at the door.
The cafe has excellent food for its price. And very friendly staff.

Pleasant visit. A very pleasant walk around the gardens. We didn't know there were so many different types of cacti. Some good photo opportunities if you enjoy experimenting with light and shadows etc.

An oasis in the heart of bustling Marrakech. This is a beautiful place to visit and has a very tranquil atmosphere, despite the large number of visitors. It is well kept and contains plants from all over the world. A welcome respite from the noise and bustle of the Souk.
Stunning garden and villa.. Best viewed on a sunny day, the garden and villa are striking. The villa contains a small berber museum which is worth the extra entrance fee.
Totally useless. Apart from a much needed break from the medina, this visit served no purpose at all. Why pay to see a mediocre, small garden?

Great photo opportunity. A bit samey but worth a visit. You have to be patient as there are lots of other people taking photos.Take a caleche there. It is up a side street you wouldn't expect so as with everything in Marrakech look out for the signs.
Beautiful secret place, to relax and inspire. If your in Morocco you must visit the gardens, beautiful, colourful and relaxing - especially needed in the hustle and bustle of Morocco.
a garden of delite. settled behind a tall wall. quiet and pleasing. There is a entrance fee. the gardens are well organized and easy to move around in.

Beautiful. A beautiful garden with such vivid colours amongst all the greenery. Not the easiest place to get to but so worth it - we could have easily spent more than an hour wondering around the garden.
Wonderful Beautiful Place. A beautiful place away from the bustle of town, and great inspiration taken for garden design in future!
A oasis of calm in a crazy city. Stunning garden and so peaceful. It is not big but after exploring find a quiet place to read or people watch. Enormous cacti!

Nice, but definitely overrated. Considering that this garden is quite away from anything else and you're likely to have to take a taxi to get here, there is very little to see for your efforts. Although the entrance is not particularly expensive (50 dirham), you can get into the far more impressive and interesting Palaces Badi or Bahia for only 20. Yes, there is a nice array of plants, water features and buildings painted blue (i appreciate a good garden), but it took us less than an hour to stroll around, and we weren't particularly interested in the YSL shrine or his career. It can also get extremely busy,and there weren't many places where you could sit or lie and relax. Do it if you have time to kill.

Scenic beauty. When we visited Jardin Majorelle, it was indeed quite crowded. Though we still went in and had a lovely time. We strolled around and enjoyed the scenic beauty this garden had to offer. The garden was clearly well maintained and well tended to. The gardens have a lot of bamboo, which is considered a good luck charm too. There were some cacti too and beautiful, mesmerizing mosaics as well. There was this place called Café bathroom too. The place was so colorful, so lively, so cheery, it was amazing. We really like the gift shop in here, a small cozy place. The tranquil atmosphere of the garden made our day worth visiting it.

disappointing. The Jardin de Majorelle was disappointing to me. It's expensive and very small and filled with too many tourists. Don't waste your time, go to the souks. If it's already done, go again, but avoir this garden.

Avoid like the Plague. This place is a shrine to YSL littered with cactus and palm trees....once you have seen one you have seen them all!! Managed to get around the garden in less then 10 minutes and this is coming from someone recovering from double knee surgery! the question that kept running through my mind was why would someone who brought the garden dedicate it to themselves? please do yourself a favour and avoid this place! don't say i didnt warn you :)
An Oasis of Blue !. Cool, striking and quite with a lovely tea room ,well worth a visit just to get away from the hussle and bussle and the noise!
Beautiful gardens. Very impressive, the trees & plants are very well kept and the blue painted pots and central building are a fine juxtaposition with the greenery
Gorgeous. Perfect excursion - really beautiful. You get some absolutely stunning photos from the gardens and we had a coffee in the cafe which was lovely and not expensive.

Beautiful!. This place is well worth a visit while in Marrakech. If anything, it is a respite from all the madness in the Medina. We loved walking through the tall cactus, soaking up the sun and admiring the stunning 'Majorelle Blue' building. Would give the Berber museum a pass.
Beautiful Feb 2012. This place is stunning! Its just a simple blue garden but it was lovely 25dh we paid to enter In feb 2012.
Pleasant and peaceful. Cheap entry, cool and restful. Nice place for a recuperating stroll The little museum is interesting and well worth a visit.

Exotic and Magnificent. If you like your Gardens and outdoor space then visit the" Jardin Majorelle" or The Majorelle Garden.Was once owned by the designer Yves Saint Laurent.On a hot sunny day in Marrakech what more could you want than to meander around this wonderful garden at your leisure.Soak up the sun,the atmosphere and the beauty.In Marrakech there are many wonderful things to see and do if you don't behave like a tourist!!!!LOOK for things and explore this GREAT city.......A "Morocco" lover........

Beautiful, lovely garden and berber museum. Definitely worth 2-4 hours of your time. The garden is very beautiful with all sorts of cactus and the most incredible indigo color you can imagine. The berber museum is also an added bonus. Go see it!
Beautiful gardens and great museum. A must in marrakech. Lovely atmosphere, very pretty gardens. Go to the museum too - great exhibits of Berber life.
Not sure what all the fuss is about. A short walk thru bamboo and other plants...I don't know much about so perhaps I missed something. I could miss this.

too crowded. Having waited so many years to visit these gardens, I was sad that they were so overcrowded, it was hard to enjoy the 'spirit' of the place. Plus the memorial to YSL was underwhelming and peculiar!

Go Early. We visited areound 11am, the place was already full with many visitors. Even with all the people it was a nice visit. There is a lot of bamboo as afore mentioned but it's a cool space and fun to imagine it being your own and sitting on the patio enjoying breakfast. Cafe Bathroom was good, sneak in or use the regular bathroom.

Just a beautiful garden. I'm sure that the plant collection you may find in Majorelle is impressing if you're coming from a cold country. Overall, it's a well preserved, beautifully designed garden but it doesn't worth paying a taxi cab (unless you're good with orientation, it's not far from the medina) and an entrance fee (50 dirhams) for a 20 minutes visit. If you go late, you will find it crowded, so an early morning visit is a good idea.

Exoctic. Tranquility and exotic and peaceful and beautiful Garden
I have ever visited. Very different from any all the Garden I have
visited.

stunning. This is a lovely, romantic place for a wander. The gardens are beautiful with a very large variety of interesting plants. A nice cafe, a lovely gift shop and a wonderful display of collage work that Yves did over the years. Very touching really...

A beautiful inspiring garden. This was well worth the trip. The garden was beautifully laid out with amazing cacti and mosaics. The small museum was interesting and the vibrant colours a treat. Shops near by have mad prices.

The Gardens - Private St. Laurent. This was a beautiful way to see how others have been influenced by this magical city. Before exploring the gardens I had no idea there was a connection between Yves St. Laurent and Marrakech.
Good but crowded. Beautiful but since it is not very big it is worth coming when the tourist buses are not there. An easy walk from city center or medina.

Moroccan mini version of Kew gardens.... A very reasonable price of 50 dirhams entrance fee allowed us into the gardens. But on a whole not very big and not very spectacular, but probably paradise to many garden enthusiasts out there! There is also a suggestion that the only reason Majorelle has over 6000 reviews, is because of its affiliation with YSL. But the site does give a completely different complex on Marrakech, especially with its multi colours away from the pink city...the plants on show are very eye catching and you can surprisingly carve your name on selected cacti on show! The cafe and souvenir shop are most definitely at YSL prices. The strong points of the gardens are tranquility, peace, relaxation and colourful. Most importantly if you have never been to Marrakech then you would never believe a place like this existed, so expect the unexpected but don't expect greatness...

Wow!. This was the best attraction in Marrakech. It is an absolutely stunning and immaculately kept garden. The instant you walk in, you forget about all of the hustle and bustle outside. Great place to bring a book and just relax.

Not to be missed!. These amazing, exotic gardens are a pleasure to visit and offer exceptional photo opportunities. One can spend the best part of an afternoon enjoying the planting from many parts of the world but there is also a café/restaurant, a small exhibition of paintings by Yves St Laurent, a sales gallery, a shop (expensive!) and the new museum. There is an extra charge for entry to the museum but the gardens alone are spectacular and are complemented by the colours of the buildings, walls and planters which are a combination of 'Tuareg blue' and citrus yellow. Enchanting!
worth a visit. this is a tranquil place in Marrakesh. the garden is beautiful but also the tour of the place lets you see a lot more history about the people.
This garden is well worth a visit. Superb little garden in the grounds of a villa, subsequenly purchased by Yves St. Laurent. Variety of rare trees.

An oasis after a wonderful but very long walk from the Medina.... I luxuriated in the beautiful garden listening to the astonishing bird song. A true oasis in the hurly-burly of the Nouvelle Ville.Startling colours that should not work together, but absolutely do. I sat for a good 30 minutes just letting everyone go by.Berber museum is worth looking at, but the star is the joy and peace of the garden. Prices in the shop require an insurmountable level of Zen like thinking however... 4800 dirham FOR A TABLECLOTH. That's £380. Best not to touch anything.I didn't eat at the cafe as I was already booked in elsewhere, but the menu looked nice, but not cheap. Wouldn't require sale of first born though, unlike the tablecloth. All the information as to price and location in the 2013 Lonely Planet Morocco guide complete codswallop. Annoyingly so. The entrance is NOT "corner of Avenue Yacoub el Mansour and Moulay Abdellah" - that would be a Shell petrol station. In fact it is 0.3 km away back along Yacoub towards the Medina. When you get to the caleche stand, turn left past the row of restaurants and nice clothes shops and the entrance is 50m on the left. Cost is also 50 Dh for teh garden and 25 for the museum.

Colors, colors, colors!. This was such a gorgeous retreat. It was too bad that there was some construction going on when we visited, but the grounds were really pretty and serene that it was still worth it. The amazing colors within the garden were beautiful and added some great photos to my Marrakech album.
peaceful place in the middle of chaos. It is a really nice place to go, specially if you wanna run away from the chaos, dust, and the sun. nice and relaxing.

A different take of Morocco. My trip to the Jardin Majorelle located in the new medina (new city) was a welcome change to the busy activities in the old medina. This place was quiet, almost serene with the sound of leaves rustling and occasional birds singing. It was nice but I would say this is more like "third-day-in-Marrakech" kind of activity.
Beautiful place. Le jardin Majorelle is a gem in Marrakech. I truly can understand, that Yves St. Laurent fell in love with this place. A must see during your stay in Marrakech.

Not to miss!. Had seen this featured on a garden show in the UK. Amazing collection, unusual layout and kept the whole family delighted for about an hour and a half. Quite a way out if you are in old Marrakech like we are, but well worth the taxi ride out. Taxis from the Koutubia Mosque area charge approx. 90-100 dirhams, worth haggling to bring this down a bit. But the gardens make it worth the visit.

If you have a half-hour to spare. Not a very large garden, but a nice cacti collection. Early morning is the best time to visit, as the sun peeks through the bamboo, and dapples the walkway beneath the trellis. It is quietest then, and you can have the place to yourselves. (If there are large crowds, leave! It is too small a garden to handle them.) Small bookstore with titles mostly in French, a somewhat pricey cafe, and a memorial to YSL.

My wife really liked it!. My wife is an artist and a keen gardner so she loved Jardin Mojarelle. It is well kept, a little expensive to visit especially if you eat in the restaurant in there. Worth a visit anyway.

Private garden to relax and enjoy. Normal admission price is 50MAD, but for students it only costs 30MAD.Greeted by a cool breeze when we entered the garden and a lot of bamboo. The place is very nice and cooling to walk about. Explore other types of plants available and also the Berber Museum to learn about their origin. Admission cost 25MAD. There is also a cafe in there to relax.Overall a pleasant experience
Small but pretty.. Beautifully laid out, amazing colours and lots of variety of plants. Take a book, as the coffee shop is worth visiting to enjoy the mint tea under the orange tree.

Pleasant. A nice tranquil garden, but not very big & quite busy.
Some impressive Cactii - all very well kept, but an hour is about all you need here.
smaller than expected. The Jardin was nice...that's about the best I can say. I would give it three stars except that the restaurant was ridiculously priced.

Unique. A beautiful oasis of calm with a unique collection of plants and cacti. A short taxi drive from the medina for approx 25dhms. I was not impressed by the overpriced tea or biscuits in the cafe although the orange water ice cream was very special.
Ok.... A very small site that isnt that impressive. The museum was a waste of time. Probably not worth visiting despite the positive reviews

Beautiful Garden in the city!. I have been here before, however I always visit. It contains a large amount of plants and cacti from similar climates and is a nice little oasis within the city. It is also only 50 dirhams to get in, however the Berber museum is a little extra.

A calming oasis. Such a welcome sight after the hustle and bustle of the city. A calm beautiful oasis with riotous colours amongst a sea of greenery. the cafe offered a great variety of food and a refreshing low key experience. The garden are well worth the visit.

Green oasis. This extraordinary garden, and especially the wonderful collection of cactus is a lovely place to escape to after the hussle of the city. It was much smaller than we anticipated, but well worth the visit.

Beautiful and peaceful. Went first thing in the Morning around nine so very few people there. Very nice and peaceful garden, Was great to walk around, got quite busy shortly after arriving.
The Berber museum although small actually had loads of things on display, mainly in French but still nice to see

No blues here. Great place to relax in a semi-tropical quiet spot. Don't miss the Berber Museum either: really nicely laid out. The night sky over the Berber jewellery exhibition is a technical marvel.

Pleasant Gardens. The gardens were peaceful with quiet seating areas but were not extensive. Lots of the plants had initials of previous guests carved into them (a bit like it was when we visited the Eden Project!). The villa was not as described as in our guide book but a small artists studio turned into a Berber Museum, which was in itself interesting.
Wonderful. An oasis of calm in a busy city. Not far off the usual tourist routes but well worth a visit, a beautiful arranged set of gardens, and a wonderfully calming hour or so.

Amazing. This was an Oasis of calm. Beautifully set out and amazing collection of plants.. We loved our visit. Recommend highly the Berber museum , so very interesting and so well organised. Stunning collection. Relax in the cafe before hitting the streets.
Its good. Ticket cost EUR 5. Well there is nothing much to do in Marrakesh anyway therefore you might enjoy experiencing something different.

Spectacular oasis of calm!. I'm not sure what I can add to the thousands of great reviews, which this place thoroughly deserves! Absolutely spectacular, the collection of cacti and other dessert plants really took my breath away! The space is beautifully cool, calm, and airy if a little touristy. It's got the special YSL touch with the spectacular bright blue and terracotta accented with other yellow, green and orange shades. Overall, totally worth a visit for a couple of hours - pick up a caliche (horse cart) from Djema for a round trip and enjoy the ride!

One good garden.. We did a trip to this garden one afternoon and it was really for my wife as I am not into gardens myself. I must say there were some impressive bamboos and cacti there.We were told about the gardens before entering and then allowed to walk around on our own.We then went to another "wild" garden which consisted of olive groves and large concrete pool,basically not a garden,but with a horse drawn carrage ride afterwards.
Better than expected. For those that are interested in a wide variety of plants arranged in style. A visit is a must. Entrance costs 50dh per person.

beautiful and tranquil. Beautiful and tranquil garden. Amazing plants and design.Lots of different cacti from all over the world. Nice way to spend an afternoon. Very relaxing atmosphere. The museum in the centre is interesting altho a lttle small.
Relaxing. Loved it here - totally relaxing away from the hustle and bustle of the busy Medina and only about a 15 minute walk away

One of the great gardens on the world. Jardin Majorelle is relatively small, but has an exceptional cacti collection combined with small stands of bamboo and colorful hardscape. The garden is well maintained and a visual treat. Be sure to also see the collection of jewelry and other artifacts in the Berber cultural museum that is on site.
Nice Gardens. Nice place and worth a visit when in marrakech. they had many different type of plants. Just wish there was some english translation and not just french
Beautiful Oasis. Amazing garden design loved the use of shape and form as well as colour. Not a traditional European garden nor an Arabic one but well worth visiting as it is unique

Local Garden Centre will probably offer a greater variety (and be larger). We walked from the old town up to the Gardens which was a bit of Hike and once you are outside of the old town walls really not much to see until you get there so hop in a cab if this one is on your list. The most surprising thing about this Garden is its right on one of the main roads though has a large 10ft wall around it. The entrance cost was high in comparison to other attractions in the city 50dhs per person. Once inside it was basically an oval path with two centre paths which even at a slow amble took no more than 20 minutes to get round and apart from a lot of bamboo which was quite impressive after the first couple of metres but got a bit repetitious after that there was not a great variety of plants and nothing that had any wow or unexpected factor. The place though is a little oasis of calm from the madness which is Marrakesh – as said it’s right on a main road but once inside the walls all that is blocked out. It’s one to see and tick it off the list but if you are only in the city for a short stop do not waste your time with this one go to the main square and the souks every time there are hundreds of things you can see out there that are unique to Marrakesh any posh garden centre in the UK would give these gardens a run for their money.
beautiful. Brilliant and would recommend a visit. We took the option of doing this from hop on hop off bus. For 50MAD per person very good value for money and we recommnend the cafe.

Small but Tidy. I'm not sure this was worth the visit or the 50dhs per person. It took us about 30 minutes to walk around and whilst the plants were interesting I saw nothing that gave the WOW factor having visited many other gardens.

Excellent and interesting gardens. As with most places in Marrakech, not easy to find, but this attraction is worth finding! Some fascinating bamboo and cacti give some good photographic scenes, we also recommend adding the museum located in the gardens to your entrance, from memory the garden entrance was 100 dirhams with the museum an extra 50. The other attraction is the tranquility that awaits you after all the hustle and bustle! The Cafe was expensive, but you will find 2 outside more reasonably priced.

TOO MANY BAMBOOS. Entrance € 5 pp. A sandwich at the restaurant € 35 for 2 people. Beautiful grounds for its collection of succulents. Well kept. Nothing exceptional but nothing remains in Marrakech. To see in every case.

A Good Break. This is a small garden & if your idea is to sit on the grass & contemplate lush greenery, then this is not the place for you.This little oasis is more for a quick stroll and some photo ops.They do, however, have a great little shop with items designed with the influence of Yves St Laurent & I highly recommend paying the extra fee to go see the Berber museum which I foundvery interesting & informative. Kudos to YSL for amassing & preserving all this items that showcase Berber artistry at it's best! This museum only makes the trip out to Majorelle worth it.Also suggest that you take the time to peruse the shops right outside the garden entrance. They have wonderful shops there that offer unique & edgily designed items that you won't find elsewhere. Totally loved the shopping there. Well worth the time to do all three - the garden, museum & shopping!
Quiet time. Lovely quiet beautiful gardens even in the middle of DecemberThe blues are amazing and have a real feel good factorWell worth a visit

Majorelle. The garden is a lush, compact space, teaming with visitors, so it’s a benefit to visit early or late on in the day. Although it is tricky to find trying to locate the garden itself, rather than just going by taxi, will add to the experience and give a deeper insight into Marrakech. Elsewhere two similar highlights are the Cyber Park and Hrati gardens, both offering an enjoyable stroll with plenty of shade from the sun.

Like bamboo...?. The taxi driver (30DH from the main mosque) said "it not good" and "go to another jardin which is free with camels and quad bikes"... So anyway we got there and it's ok. We envisaged some grass to lie down on but nada and it's also shaded. The red concrete path looked a bit like that which one night find in a zoo-the type that gets hosed down to get all the much off-low maintenance. If you like bamboo and cactus-this is the place for you however for us the roof top terrace of our Riad provided more peace und tranquility. :)
peace and tranquility. a peaceful oasis in the heart of a busstling city. The gardens are well kept and a very quiet place away from the hustle and bustle of the streets nearby

A brilliant idea. A visit to a garden in this city might seem strange but it's really worth seeing what has has been created and lovingly maintained.as an added bonus it has an excellent cafe with clean toilets . Would certainly say a venue not to be missed even if a slight walk from the medina area. Not badly priced either to enter and a fifteen minute walk to new town area afterwards makes it a good place to start the day and have lunch. Might benefit from slightly more plant information but they do seem to be installing new signs.don't miss the terrapins in the pond either.

Not to Miss. Most of us wouldn't go far to see a garden, but do make the trip to Jardin Majorelle. It's not large and you don't need hours to see it, but the overall atmosphere is special. The colors are delightful and it's relaxing to just stroll through the trees and plants. We used a carriage to go there from the spice market area--not cheap (don't pay more than 150 Dh for 45 min to one hour ride), but it's a pleasant way to take in some of the new town and enjoy the fresh air and sunshine. You won't be alone; we saw more tourist buses unloading here than anywhere else.

Pretty gardens, not as relaxing as it could be. The gardens are very pretty, interesting to have a look around and a cool during a hot day. But we expected it would be somewhere to spend a morning, lay on the grass and read a book. This was not the case, most of the gardens are pathways through the (admittedly) pretty trees. And it is very busy most of the time, even in October.

Interesting plant combinations. The garden is a quiet place with lots of mature bamboos, palms and cacti, with intersting plant combinations. The gallery and bookshop are well worth a look. We didn't go into the museum (extra charge). The cafe is a bit pricey compared to usual Marrakech prices. Watch out for the taxi drivers on leaving who will tell you anything so that they can take you to places other than where you ask them to go (quite usual in Marrakech).

Beautiful gardens - kinda small considering.... We enjoyed our walk through these gardens. They're a very nice change from the frantic pace of the city. We walked to the gardens from the Jemaa el Fna - and considering the time it took to get here we were a bit disappointed that the gardens weren't more extensive. Had we taken a cab, we might not have felt that way.
Tranquil, attractive garden.. Don't miss the Berber museum in the middle of the garden. Try and time your visit to miss the crowds so you can experience the tranquility of the place.

Unmissable. Allow yourself at least two hours to give justice to the garden. The tranquil quality of the space and the variety of plants set against vibrant colours including the famous Majorelle Blue (pots of which are available in the shop) is a memory you will keep with you for a long time.

Not to be missed,a truly uplifting experience .. I would say this was one of the high spots of our trip to Morocco. Such beauty and colour. We visited in November and spent a morning there. Had we not been on a tour we could easily have spent so much longer.The sculptural forms of the plants,the bird song and the pools and the beautiful flashes of Majorelle blue colouring in tiles and glass were wonderful.We owe the late Yves St Laurent a debt of gratitude for saving this masterpiece of garden design.

Not to be missed !!!. I don't usually go out of my way to see a garden but I'm very glad we visited this one. The vibrant colours are dazzling and the flora and fauna are worth at least an hour or more. As we visited on a sunny December day, we were thrilled and happy to have some much needed light. The Berber museum within the property is worth the extra ticket cost. We also had a nice cup of tea in the small cafe. I also treated myself to a perfume in the (expensive) boutique.
Beautifully manicured garden. Stunning gardens, once owned by Yves St Laurent. Not really suitable to sit and relax, you kind of constantly feel the need to move onto looking at the next plant.

Peace in the city. I really enjoyed walking around the gardens on a warm day. It is really beautiful and peaceful inside. There are also benches throughout to sit on if you just want to relax and enjoy the tranquility. The trees, plants and flowers were beautiful and make for some great pictures as well. There is a small gift shop (expensive) and a cafe that serves soups, salads, sandwiches and such. The entrance fee is 50 dirham. If you enjoy gardens, peace and beauty, definitely add this to your list of things to do while in Marrakech.

Lovely gardens. We visited the gardens at the end of November and they are very lovely with lots of bamboo and cacti and other structural plants. There is also a large pond and some lovely terracing with lots of the Majorelle blue dotted about. I should imagine in the heat of high summer this would be a lovely shady spot to visit. We didn't look in the Berber museum, but we did go into a small but very interesting exhibition of Yves Saint Laurent's annual Christmas cards which he designed and were shown as posters. There is a cafe - we didn't try it but it looked like a nice seating area, again very shady and prices looked good. Overall a pleasant way to while away an hour on our last day. It's in the new city, but not far from the old. It was easy to find and entrance price was very reasonable.

stunningly beautiful gardens!. if you like cacti and cobalt blue then you won't go wrong here! WOW! it's so cheap to get in and so peaceful! it's not overly big but plenty of sitting space on the way round to rest and soak It all in.

An oasis of calm and peace in the middle of the city. I love this place and I've been there several times to escape the hectic of the city. Best time to visit seems to be about an hour before closing time since then there are less visitors.

There's a reason it's so highly rated.. From the moment I saw this place in a travel app, I wanted to go. I'll be quite honest here, I honestly don't know anything or care in the slightest about Yves Saint Laurent and his connection with the City and Country, I was going for the calm and tranquility.I think it's 50 dirham for the gardens and 25 for the Berber museum, or vice versa, either way it 75 dirham entrance fee, which is a fair and decent price. The gardens are ( and I know this phrase has been used to death ) a real oasis of calm. From the abundance and selection of cacti to the beautiful flowers, palm trees and other tropical plants of which I have no idea what they were, you can very easily just spend an hour walking around the gardens, totally chilled and relaxed. The Berber museum, for me personally, was ok. Don't get me wrong, as museums go, it was spotless, highly informative, educational and filled to the rafters with "stuff from the past".......that last statement probably telling you that history really isn't my thing. But in the World of credit where credit is due, it was a fantastic and well spent hour looking around and taking in all the history of the Berber people, the tools they used, weapons they fought with, clothes they wore etc. In short, I loved the gardens, and although the museum wasn't for me as such, I still found it highly impressive and enjoyed my time there. Oh, I almost forgot the wonderful cafe hidden away in the middle of the gardens, you really need to stop for a cafe au lait or mint tea here.
Beautiful gardens. The gardens are really beautiful, with all its exotic plants. The area is a green oasis in a hectic city. Highly recommended

Gardeners dream. A Moroccan version of Beth Chattos concept of a dry garden with agaves, yucca, cactus etc. also has a well displayed Berber museum. well worth a visit, and if possible take a caliche and enjoy the scenery on the way.
Little Oasis. Very calming spot even when fairly full of tourists. Would be especially good in the full summer sun.
Must See. Wonderful garden to visit. Very well maintained. Restaurant has good food as well. Place is near the local shopping and residential area.

A getaway from the city traffic. They are rather small but very beautiful gardens, decorated in bright colours. A very nice place for taking photos and just relaxing after long walks in the souks. You will see palm trees, exotic plants, fountains, benches and many cacti. You won't need much time to explore the place which is nice especially if you are already tired! Easy access if you take the Tour Oasis bus from the centre of the city. There is also small museum that you can visit there, mainly jewellery and traditional costumes. I would expect to see wildlife in such a lovely place but you could only hear birdsongs. We had a nice time there, it wasn't crowded at all and it was a sunny afternoon.

just gets better. I revisited the gardens today after several years and it is more stunning than ever. The size of the plants, the amazing contrasts in colours and the cleanliness and lines are wonderful. The groundkeepers do a fantastic job and can be seen discretely tidying around the garden. Even with a large number of people visiting as there were today you can find quiet spots to gaze at the beauty around you. The monument to Yves is simple in the extreme but rather touching nevertheless. 50 Dhs entry is expensive I grant you but what a delightful setting and so tranquil and anyway it must cost a fair bit to maintain such an immaculate space. One of the must see attractions in Marrakech.

Essential to visit.. Not as interesting as on previous visits. This was November -we have been here in August. Maybe more flowers previously? But essential to visit. It was a little crowded but maybe because it was cooler to visit? Berber museum excellent. Cafe good but not cheap. do visit Museum of Vivrein Medina.
Tourist trap. I went to this place against my own will, didn't even know what it was when I first arrived. Its nice but really not that much to see, a tourist trap.

Allow plenty of time. I loved the colours, the different textures of plants and paths, and the feeling that you could be in a jungle. Allow plenty of time for the excellent Berber museum - the best one we found for detailed information.

A photo opportunity, but little else. This garden is peaceful, shaded and has some brightly painted garden furniture, but little else. Most of the small garden is filled with tall bamboo and where these are not planted there are some relatively interesting cacti. Probably not worth the 50DH entry unless you are really short of things to do.

World's plants sample at desert. Jardin Majorelle is a sampler of plants from "all over the world" ( an old private garden for a wealth family ) .For those perfume and fashion lovers, it has the memorial where ashes from Yves Saint Laurent rests.
Quite place, fresh air. I like the cleanness and organization, I didn't see the variety of plants from the world same as they advertized.
Artificial looking garden. It was pretty but looked fake, if you're in the area go and have a look but if you miss it, you haven't missed much.
Nice to have a beautiful and quit place in Marrakech. This place gets you away from the busy Marrakech. Beautiful walk to the garden and relaxing stay there.

"Pretty cool. "Pretty Cool" We asked Rosie many questions about the history and important places to visit around of Morocco before we travelled to Marrakech. Our city guide, Houssain was a lovely man, incredibly informative about the history of Marrakech and the surrounding monuments. He took us to many different areas in and around Marrakech with the most memorable place being Bleu garden. This magnificent garden was calm, serene, and colorful. We stayed in a lovely riad all organised by Trek in Atlas with airport transfer door to door. We had a wonderful stay in Morocco and would recommend this company for organising any tour or trek, the standard was professional.

Had hoped for more - content and size!. The gardens themselves are very small and we probably could have got round them in half an hour. As it was we had a taxi return for an hour and so made the most of the time by having some refreshements in the lovely little courtyard café. The gardens are very nice with lots of tropical plants but the gardens are small with not much variety.

Great Management. The Management of the Jardin Majorelle is spectacular. Soraya is a true professional. If more Public gardens were run by people like her, There would be beautiful gardens all over the place.

Really Nice Garden to Visit. If you are looking to get away from the madness of Marrakesh and the old medina, this garden is a great. It was a bit busy, but had great opportunity for photography of the beautiful colors and plants. There is a small berber museum in the garden, which is short but well done.
peaceful. I took my mom here. It is pretty but not the most important thing to see. Good if you need some down time from the hustle and bustle.

Clean and cool. This is the Yves St Lauren garden and its mostly Cacti bamboo and palms but there are pretty flowers and some ornamental pools. A cool place to go on a hot day or any other day really. Shop and cafe ( not cheap ) in the grounds
Oasis. I used to live across the Jardin Majorelle. It is a great oasis from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. While not huge in size, it is a lovely garden and a must see.

Not enough bamboo. I planned a visit based on another review that promised there would be a lot of bamboo. Unfortunately, when I entered the garden, the bamboo wasn't enough. It was only at the entrance and very sparsely distributed at that. There were lots of nice flowers and plants, a gorgeous cactus collection, a Berber museum, but alas, no more bamboo---even inside the museum, I failed to find any more bamboo. I truly enjoyed my visit of the garden, but I'm a bit disappointed at the lack of perspicacity of fellow reviewers...
nice walk. Not expensive and quite a nice walk round. Nice little tearoom and shop available. Gardens a bit too small but worth the visit.

Blue oasis. An exceptional modern garden that contrasts with the noise and bustle of the surrounding city. Lots of beautiful water features and a great collection of cacti and plants from across the world. We really enjoyed the peace and tranquility. Well worth the admission charge.
It's to small. only about 1/3 the area shown on the map. Its nice enough and very "groomed". the cactus collection is particularly nice. there is to much bamboo

Stunning gardens, unforgettable colours. The gardens involve quite a trek out of town, but it's worth it. The plants and trees are beautifully arranged and all labelled so that you know what they are; the cactus garden is particularly impressive. There is a very interesting and well-presented Berber museum, from which I learnt a lot. But what makes this place unforgettable is the wonderful colours - the 'Majorelle blue', bright yellow and greens - of the buildings and garden features. Marrakech has many fine things to see, but these gardens were our favourite.
Striking. Striking displays and colours but a bit small and was crowded when we visited. Get there early in the morning if you want to take good photos.
Lovely. beautiful and peaceful garden behind those walls. Go early before the crowds build up. The "Berber" museum was the only one we saw and found it quite interesting.

Oasis in the middle of Chaos. Went here and it was awesome. Terrific bamboo and cactus plants cover the area making it a lovely green. Very peaceful and tranquil inside and the YSL painting gallery and memorial are both very inspirational and artistically soothing. Goes to show that the French foundation has done a terrific job thus far. Would go again in a heartbeat.  A MUST VISIT!

OASIS OF TRANQUILITY. As a contrast to the bustle of the Old Town these gardens offer peace and calm. We went early and the gardens were quiet and the early morning sun filtering through the trees and tall plants added to the beauty. You will remember the blue colouring used extensively in the gardens, the exotic cacti mainly from South America and you will appreciate the story behind the creation of the garden and its "second coming" thanks to Yves St Laurent.

Stunning and tranquil. After the previous day's exploration of the at times stressful souks, I wanted to experience something more relaxed. The gardens were beautiful and quiet, and, a nice cool respite from the heat. It is well worth paying for entry to the Berber museum, if only for the optical illusion of the jewellery room. If you like photography you'll spend a good while trying to get the right angles and colours at the same time as waiting for people to get out of your view!
A Garden worth the visit. Very beautiful garden with a variety of cacti and palmtrees! - great for a stroll if you have an our or two to kill!

Don't miss this!. Friends had told us about this place and we were so pleased we took their advice, It is a stunning place to visit - a feast for the eyes around every corner - you will take loads of photos! Walkways around the gardens, the blue blue plant pots, water features, the amazing cacti collection make it a very special place. Don't miss the museum tucked away - it has the most fabulous collection of Berber costumes and jewellery.

Beautiful gardens and a museum as well. This beautiful garden in a residential neighborhood was a treat, with so many different kinds of trees, flowering shrubs, ponds, and bridges. The Yves St. Laurent poster room as also interesting and the Berber museum is a MUST see!
An oasis of peace. Even though there were a lot of visitors, it was still peaceful. The staff were happy to answer any questions and help take photos!

Tranquillity in the fast lane. Just off one of the main roads into Marrakech the Jardin Majorelle is a tranquil place for reflection, relaxation, restfulness and peace. For the gardener there are so many different types of plants, shrubs, cacti and water features. As a tourist you can't fail to note the gently undulating paths merging smoothly into the architectural features of bridges and galleries.It's now the Yves Saint-Laurent memorlal garden and so a shrine to the fashio guru. But it's also a museum of Berber culture, clothing, history, art and jewellery. A delightful couple of hours with a visit to the cafe included.
Tip!. As if you enter another World completely disconnected with the busy citylife of Marrakech. It is well worth the entrancefee.

Botanic art. Would be a lovely place to go to for a relaxing couple of hours. However this place is so crowded that this would be impossible. If you are into serious gardening this will not impress, but it's attractive and worth a quick visit. The crowds are a problem

Pretty and tranquil. Worth a visit if in Marrakesh as a tranquil break from the hustle of the main square and souks. On a hot day it is shady and cool and several interesting plants and flowers in an eclectic mix from around the world.
Nice but not amazing. Lovely for a stroll around, was very very busy when we visited, hard to even get a photograph without someone being in it that you dont know! A fair walk away from the souks

bit over hyped!. Was fairly disappointed by the gardens; expensive to get in and not that impressive inside, plus if its busy you can't really escape the crowds especially at the most stunning bits- was very toe curling to hear a loud English voice shouting across the gardens! If you are in Marrakech go and see it (taxi from Jemaa El Fna roughly 40 dirhams rtn!!!!) if not don't worry!
Majorell gardens - November 2013. Well worth a visit. The museum in the grounds costs an additional 25 DH ( about 2GBP) but it is well worth the money.

A nice garden... So??. From the reviews and recommendations we expected so much more than what we got. If this garden hadn't been saved by YSL, it wouldn't have been a big tourist attraction. Thank God we stayed in Marrakech and hadn't traveled by buss for hours to see it... I do recommend to go early before the herds of visitors come. But really... Yes it's an oasis just between the walls if the old town and the new town.... but, if you're just here for a couple of days.. there is somuch more to see than this.

Something different from the rest of Marrakech. Lovely gardens. Lots of shade and water, so cooler than most of the rest of Marrakech.
