Berber museum is an easy way to get some insights into local culture. And some interesting insights into life of Yves Saint Laurent. Minor downsides: lots of other tourists there, and more expensive than other sites of interest. But worth it.

Beautiful - well worth a visit!. This is a beautiful garden. Very tranquil and peaceful which makes a welcome break from the rest of Marrakech! Lots of different trees and plants and some nice water features. A great place to spend an hour relaxing among the plants.
Beautiful garden. Interesting visit to this beautiful garden with lots of story. It's not a big garden but for sure different from everything I've seen.

A pretty oasis within Marrakesh. A pretty, quiet, relaxing place to spend an hour feeling like you are in the countryside -- and not in the busy city of Marrakesh. The flora is not native, but has been arranged in a very pleasing fashion.
Simply beautiful. It's a must see when your in Marrakesh. There are very little beautiful things in this city but the gardens are simply gorgious

Beautiful. It is a beautiful garden to visit. When we entered we both said 'wow'! :)
It is quite small but worth a visit!!

Visit to Majorelle. The garden is very beautiful and the tranquility very welcome after the busy streets of the city.
I liked the fact that it isn't far out of the city and it could be reached by walking -if you could find your way!

Feeling like Yves Sant Laurent?. A place to escape from the heat from Morroco, Beautiful place, a bit overprice the entrance but very well worthy the price to see it. Toilets overcrowded so much better to go before you go in as it is a very popular location.

Highlight in Marrakech. This garden was lovely. An oasis in the city. It was a feast for the eyes and soul. A great place to relax. Plus, they have an amazing book shop with new and antique books and vintage photographs.

The perfect escape from the souks. The garden (renovated by Yves Saint Laurent) is immaculate, with stunning colours and a beautiful lily pond. Take a horse and carriage back to the medina for the perfect experience.

Go early!. Beautiful gardens. Wonderful specimens of amazing cacti and palms. Cafe serving lovely looking lunches and beautful mint tea. The museum is really worth queuing for, giving insights into berber life, some wonderful images, artifacts & costumes.. Especially interesting and beautiful is the jewellry exhibition. Entry to the museum is thankfully limited so there is no crowd but this does mean a wait.We were advised to go early to avoid the influx of coach parties so have an early breakfast & go :)
Dont bother. Its a bit of a let down as I was expecting it to be a bit larger and really colourful. IT WAS NONE OF THESE THINGS. Its not much. A few trees, bit of bamboo and a pond. Done.

Top Garden in Marrakech. Not very big, very busy, and a hot walk along busy main roads to get to. But well worth it. A unique and beautiful garden of historic interest just outside the Medina. It is immaculately preserved, not a stone out of place among the cacti, every pot carefully painted, every view considered. And the mature bamboos and palms keep it shady. The Yves Saint Laurent memorial is underwhelming though, somehow a broken doric column does not sum up the genius of the man, who owned the garden in his later life ( his ashes are scattered here)

Calm oasis. In the hustle bustle that is Marrakech, Les jardins de la Medina is a calm oasis to start exploring the city. I visited on a Saturday morning, and found it lovely and peaceful. By the time I left, a few bus loads had arrived which I was glad to have missed. It is a very small garden of tropical cactus, and a memorial to YSL and a beautiful gallery of his Christmas 'Love' cards. Thoroughly enjoyed, once finished I walked onto the street outside where I had coffee before taking a horse drawn carriage tour of the city, which I would also surprising recommend, not my usual thing, but its certainly is one way to experience Marrakech

Charming garden. Suggest go by horse drawn carriage from the Medina and get the driver to wait for you. Negotiate your price in advance. Although not particularly large it is an interesting and unusual garden. Also has a small restaurant/cafe with a lovely outdoor seating area.

Small, but well worth seeing. I was so glad we visited to the Majorelle gardens. They felt so tranquil, compared to the hustle and bustle of life in Marrakech, so we are really glad we went there. We visited them before we visited the Menara gardens, and the Majorelle gardens were by far the best. We bought bottled water in the gardens for less than 50p.

Majorelle an oasis. The gardens are a huge tourist attraction, lots of people meandering around. But it is peaceful and tranquil inside. Lots of shade.The blue hues are lovely and the reflecting pools quite picturesque. Should try to see it if you have a spare hour or so.

Beautiful and Peaceful Garden. Again another great place to escape the bustle of the City. Take a horse and carriage from the main Fna square and they will wait while you spend an hour inside. Very clean and tidy and interesting too all.

Nice garden but a bit of a letdown. Don't get me wrong, it's a beautiful garden and it's a great place for some serenity away from the everyday hectic environment of Marrakech. I just expected a bit more, especially knowing it was owned by YSL. I didn't look up any pics online of the place since I thought I would be really overwhelmed by the place if I didn't, but it just lacks a bit of design inspiration I would've expected reading some of the reviews.It's just a nice garden with a lot of plants and trees, especially a lot of cacti.

Jardin de Yves St Laurent. Like an oasis within the hustle and bustle that is Marrakesh. A quiet and tranquil garden, planted primarily with succulents, an amazing house and a fascinating Berber museum. A restaurant completes the visit. Well worth a look - plan to spend half a day getting lost in the garden and the culture

Lovely. This is the garden of YSL.. Treat for your eyes. The blue is so sharp and its mélange with the green of plants – amazing.Lovely color combination. Have not seen so many varieties Cactus in my life. The little shops and the café gives a touch of welcome. Don’t miss the Berber museum hidden inside the book shop.

Bit of an anticlimax. The gardens were much smaller than I imagined with far more people. If there had been less people there I can see what a tranquil spot this would be but we probably enjoyed the horse carriage ride there more than the gardens themselves

An oasis of style. These wonderful gardens were a joyful respite from the hustle of the Medina, however the gardens were nothing special in themselves. The joy was the wonderful blue of the Majorelle Blue. But that said, the Berber Museum in the old studio was brilliant. The best example of Berber history we found, compared to the Musee of Marrakech. you must visit the museum when you go to the gardens. It completes the visit. Go early as can become tourist crazy too.

Amazing Cactii. It is a pretty garden with large and amazingly large Cactii. The atmosphere is serene and lush. It houses a YSL museum, a memorial and a beautiful store with lovely things. Plenty of benches around to rest while absorbing in the greenery.Apparently this belonged to YSL and a small building in the garden has been painted in this eye catching blue which has the touch of a creative master

Nice samll garden. This is a nice small garden. You will porbably finish up the tour of the garden in less than 30 minutes. However, the colors are abosloutely beautiful and your will find a vriety of cactus plants.

Go early and have the garden to yourself!. We were lucky to spend time in the garden early on ad Saturday morning! it was perfect! before the tourist buses arrived. We did not try the cafe and the gift shop was very expensive, postcards were 10 Dhs each. Outside the garden is a small kiosk selling more postcards. The garden is immaculate and very peaceful in such a busy city.

One of the highlights of Marrakech - a must see. This garden, bought and restored by Yves Saint Laurent is a lovely oasis in Marrakech.The YSL took the garden, restored the planting and walkways and added his own splash of colour which turns this into a magnificent and fabulous creation.It is a bit out of the centre so you can either get there via a long walk over some busy roads or you can get a taxi. There are plenty of taxis to get you back. Or I'm told you can hire a horse and buggy from the Jemma al Fna to take you and bring you back.Either way, this is a must-see. But go early morning or late in the afternoon to avoid the crowds.

A nice bit of peace and tranquility. The garden is very peaceful and full of beautiful desert plants and bamboo. It was rather full of people, mainly French, but it was still very enjoyable. The small museum was extremely interesting and they managed to pack a lot in to a very small space. At 75 dirham, it is not the best value of the sights of Marrakech.
Worth a visit. Fantastic arrangement,very peaceful break from the hustle of Marrackech,Beautiful plants and great to see pictures painted by YSL.Memorial to YSL

Oasis in the middle of Marrakech. Beautiful gardens, and a very relaxing attraction, but a mid-morning was a bit crowded. I would recommend going when they first open to avoid the crowds. Also, Yves Saint Laurent's memorial is nothing special. If it's too crowded to see it, you're not missing much. Go watch the koi instead.

Very busy but certainly worth seeing.. The cacti are incredible and lots of beautiful flowering plants. The Berber museum is well laid out and less hectic then the gardens. There is a display of paintings but it is easy to miss! The gift shop has good post cards and beautiful jewel coloured purses and bags
Lots of cacti. Wonderful garden with many plant species. Just the variety of cacti is immense. Good for a visit of one hour as there is not much to see aside from the plants and museum/store.

Calm and tranquility!. Worth a visit at the end of a busy day in the city, nice to get out of the hot crazy city and relax for a couple of hours in these beautiful gardens that are bursting with colour.
Peaceful setting but dont expect large gardens. Worth a visit, a bit of an oasis - rather small though so if you want to truly enjoy the tranquillity then going during off peak times is recommended.

Nice plant collection. A bit overpriced compared to other museums in the city (Gardens: 50Dh; Bereber museum: 25Dh; Nov 2013). The garden itself is not very big but, despite being packed with tourists, it is a real haven to have a rest and recharge batteries before going back to the chaos outside its walls. The fountains and ponds surrounded by many different plants from around the world for the joy of those interested in botany, and the buildings and plant pots painted in vibrant colours make a strange but somehow harmonious mix.

A tranquil spot. Although relatively expensive to get in compared to the entrance fee to other attractions, the gardens are beautiful and an oasis of calm and tranquillity in the heat. The colours are amazing and there are information boards around the gardens detailing the different plant species and their origins.Watch out for the taxi drivers outside though. The gardens are not in close proximity to the city centre and make sure you are happy with the price and are clear on what you have agreed before getting in. We paid 30 MAD to get there from the Medina but found that drivers were demanding more than twice this to get back!
Nice place to visit. The gardens are worth a visit and lots of different plants and ponds to look at. Nice café to have a drink in and very nice place to walk around for a couple of hours

Arrive early. Smaller than I anticipated but very well kept and worth the 50 Dirham entry fee (we didn't go in the museum).We arrived at peak time and this did detract from the visit as by then you're constantly tripping over other people.
Not large but worth a visit ..... Some amazing cacti set in lovely surroundings and a great place to get some shade on a hot day. Nice boutiques with local products on the street outside the gardens.

Beautiful, but crowded. The gardens are stunning and the Berber museum is very interesting and informative, but it is very busy. Unlike other gardens in Marrakesh, Majorelle is much more sculpted and landscaped and it shows with the number of people there. Great for photographs, but you will have to accept crowds of people in every frame. personally I preferred the museum to the gardens. The jewelry and costumes were superb and gave an insight into traditional life in Morocco.
beautiful.. Gorgeous gardens top escape the smoke and hustle of the city. Get a taxi though as it's quite a way from the centre.
Peace and tranquility. The colours, the water, the sitting areas, the plants, the quiet and the beautiful courtyard area for coffee/lunch. And it also contains a very good museum on Berber culture
Clean air in busy Marrakech. It was a lovely garden, seemed like a very popular site in Marrakech for tourists, therefore many people.

Worth a visit if you want a relaxing day. The price for the gardens is 50Dh and 25Dh for the museum. The garden itself is beautiful, it's nice if you want to escape the hustle and bustle of the main square for a few hours. Here you can have a wander around and take some stunning photos. I feel that the Berber museum located inside the gardens is absolutely worth paying the 25Dh, it's small but still fascinating and rich with cultural Berber artefacts.In a nutshell if you're going to visit any of the gardens in Marrakech, this one should be at the top of your list.

Berber museum a must. The garden was lovely, but must admit I have visited much more interesting. Felt like we we're somewhat herded down the narrow paths. The museum however is well worth a visit, very interesting.

Just lovely!. What a great surprise, to find such beautiful gardens in Marrakech. The fountains with koi and turtles, the varied species of cacti, the mature trees and the Mediterranean colors used all over...just delightful. There is a wonderful boutique with gorgeous items...a feast for the eyes. There is also a cafe/restaurant at the Majorelle. This is really a most see during any visit to Marrakech. Definitely recommended.

Peaceful sanctuary. Although small, lovely, tranquil gardens with a modern and new Berber Museum inside. Nice cafe, although we didn't eat there, and clean toilets.50 Dh for garden entry and 25 Dh for the museum entry.

Enjoyed visiting on both occasions. Ticket is slightly pricey but it is a good day out. Be prepared to walk slowly and spending a few hours there; not your sort of stuff if you don't appreciate nature. Found it cool even when it was hot outside during the day time - by courtesy of the lovely plants.

Not huge, but so worth the trip. Perhaps an acre or two at the max, but nicely done. Killer thing to do there is enjoy lunch. Very fine avocado salad, and a pretty terrace to enjoy it. Same goes for the fries...

3.756 really but can't give it 4. Bit underwhelmed to start with, especially after 50dhs [€5] each entry. But it grew on me. Not very big but a very pleasant space and shaded all over. Shame the entire gardens aren't open to public. Get a price for taxi outside before renting one - this is a prime tourist trap place. Easy to walk to and find - about 5 - 6 minutes west of Gare Routier just outside the walls.

Peaceful if you go early. Lovely gardens...and contrast to outside in the street. We went at 9.30am and it was reasonably quiet..but by the time we left at 10.30am it was heaving...I would go at 8am when it opens. loved the cacti...very tall! We didn't go in the cafe..it looked nice..but a bit pricy...

Tranquillity and Beauty. French artist Jacques Majorelle lived and worked in Marrakech where he created a beautiful garden and home. It fell into disrepair after his death but was then rescued by Yves Saint Laurent who brought it back to its former glory. There is an almost reverent hush as you enter the gardens from the bustling street despite significant numbers of visitors. This gives a very peaceful and tranquil feel to the gardens which are easy to walk around. The plants and pathways are well maintained and the memorial to YSL is simple and elegant. What truly stood out for me, though, were the colours. Majorelle blue is a stunning, vibrant blue that can be seen everywhere from the house to the ponds and plant pots and are interspersed with pots of equally vibrant oranges and yellows.Even if gardens are not your thing then a visit is well worth while to see the fantastic Berber museum created by Majorelle. Certainly the finest display of artefacts in Marrakech depicting the life and customs of the Berber people who live in the surrounding Atlas mountains.The book shop after the museum is expensive as is the gift shop although the souvenirs are not your average tat.

A Tropical Sanctuary in Marrakech.... Beautiful, tranquil retreat of the late Yves Saint Laurent. The Berber Museum which now occupies his former home, although small was crammed with fascinating artifacts. The gardens are a lush, tropical sanctuary with vivid indigo blue and yellow structures and pots.Beautiful lily pond, loved the turtles. Lovely cafe also. All well worth a visit.

Cool & calm. Cool and calm, a lovely contrast to the heat and dust of the souks and the busy streets of Marrakech.we walked from the main square and got a bit lost- bewary of men being helpful who then want you to visit their uncle's shop or want payment for being a guide !

So peaceful, even with a crowd of visitors.... Grabbed a taxi in Jemaa el Fna on my final day in Marrakech and headed out to Jardin Majorelle. Such a lovely spot; quiet despite the number of people visiting. I thoroughly enjoyed the variety of cactus, bamboo, and palms; however, for me, the museum celebrating the culture of the Imazighen was the highlight of this visit. Jewelry, clothing, and artifacts from daily life are displayed beautifully. No photography is allowed, but there are pictures on the museum site (http://bit.ly/1ffhcYZ).

Beautiful gardens. We came here in the morning and it was still pretty packed with tourists. It's tucked away in a side street so no It's such a beautiful & colorful garden with lots of different plants but as it's quite small,you can see the whole place very quickly.Definitely worth seeing!

Visit an hour before it closes or opens.. Beautiful and relaxing garden. I hear the garden is very crowded during the afternoon. I was advised to go an hour before it closed. Not only was the weather cooler but there was just a handful of people in the gardens. Also - bring a student ID for discounted rates if you have one!

A "must" visit when in Marrakech. These gardens offer a welcome relief from the heat, hustle and bustle of Marrakech. It is surprising to see what can be achieved through clever planting and care in a reasonably small place. The use of colour, mainly a rich royal blue, to enhance the overall green of the plants and trees used is sensational.Spent several hours here it was so lovely.

had never realized how beautiful indigo is!. After a day in the souks we needed to relax a bit so took a caleche, a horse drawn carriage from Jemaa el Fna,(should be no more than 50 DH) to the Gardens. We enjoyed wandering about. it is very well kept. with nice quiet spots to sit and relax as well as a cafe if you need a drink. The indigo color with which walls and pots are painted make such nice contrast to the plants that is unique.

An oasis of tranquility from the hussle & bustle that is Marrakech. We found this to be worth every single penny we paid to get in.As soon as you enter you come to a little courtyard type area with a fountain and it is just then you realise you can no longer hear the traffic or noise from outside, just the sound of the birds singing in the trees.Very well laid out and immaculately tended gardens which instill a nice sense of calm and tranquillity as you walk around, the trees obviously provide some very welcome relief from the sun and I can imagine in high summer they would be be a huge boon to visitors.Plenty of flowers still in bloom which was nice as it added a splash of colour every now and then to the greenery and they perfumed the air with a nice light scent. I'd love to see the riot of colour that must happen in spring and summer though.Usual goldfish in the ponds but plenty of terrapins too.The museum is full of Berber artefacts and we found this to be very interesting, it was about a 15-20minute wait to get in and I think we were in there for about 30 minutes. The museum is extra on the garden entry fee and I'd say it is worth paying. The museum is also right by the cafe in the gardens.By the time we had a spot of lunch and a final wander we realised we had been in the gardens for over 3.5hrs! yet it didn't seem that long at all whilst walking.There is a gift shop on site but the pricing is verging on high to ridiculous in there.This is very well worth a few hours of your valuable holiday time and we'd highly recommend it.
Tranquil place. Lovely gardens offering a peaceful place to spend a few hours away from the madness of the medina. There is a nice cafe serving food and drinks at reasonable prices.

Peaceful, lovely food and service. Delicious food, lovely peaceful place to go in the midst of the madness of Marrakech. I found the garden interesting but a bit underwhelming. The best thing was visiting this café. Best ice cream I have ever had, though it is pricey.

Succulents. Beautiful serene garden full of cacti from all over the world.
In the center there is a nice berbermuseum worth a visit. The restaurant might be worth to sit down for a drink, but eat elsewhwere.
beautiful gardens. colourful and interesting, one of key attractions in Marrakech but there are not loads of tourist attractions as such.

Fantastic. We visited here on a whistle stop tour through Marrakech - so glad we did as its stunning ! You must visit if your in Marrakech its beautiful and even if you only spend 30 mins there you get to see all of the gardens within that time

A calm oasis in a busy city. I have very limited time and visited late afternoon which was probably a good bet as it gets quite busy
Beautiful garden and Berber museum. Loved the upscale shop which was expensive but fantastic quality. Nice cafe. A must see but not more than a 2 hour visit as the garden is quite small

An oasis for the soul. It was good to come here - Marrakech can be very challenging after some time, with all it´s noise, the lively atmosphere and the masses of people on the streets.This garden is an oasis, and it´s colors are like a healing for the soul. It´s quiet and wonderful there, and you can find some place on your own and come down a little bit - a rare experience in this city!

Very nice, but not a whole afternoon. The gardens are a beautiful oasis in the middle of the french part of the city. The colors, especially compared to the dull desert color of so much of the french part, is quite striking. The opportunities for pictures are everywhere, and the staff are very helpful in taking scores of pictures of you for a pittance of a tip.Other reviewers have mentioned that there is not as much information as you might hope for, and that is true. That said, the gardens are very pretty, even if you don't necessarily know what kind of plant you are looking at at a particular time. Also, the gardens are smaller than you would expect, and you can get through them quickly without trying to.Lovely gift shop, and not nearly as expensive as comparable gift shops at major stateside attractions. Stop for tea and some lunch...the lunch is little expensive, but the view is worth the cost. Just make sure to get post cards other than at the stand outside...the cards were nice, but much much more expensive than anywhere else in the city.

Great photo op. The contrast in counts makes for some great photos. Some good items in boutique that combine traditional items with good style and design, however very pricey. Gardens are ok, respite from the dishevelment of Marrakech

Tranquil space in Marrakech. The entrance to the Jardin Majorelle is on the eastern side up a side street from Avenue Yacoub Al Mansour. The Jardin It is quite small, but is worth a visit none the less as it is quite a unique garden with different types of cactus etc. It provides a nice peaceful space to chill out in the shade and amongst the ponds.It is also worth visiting the museum inside the Jardin, which incurs and extra charge, but is is certainly worth it. It is extremely well set out and the exhibition items are in of extremely good condition.

Attractive but crowded. We went in the late afternoon after a day's sightseeing so it was a real contrast but you have to be a cactus expert to make the best of the visit. It is a shame there isn't more information about the plants and arrangements. The museum was interesting and the clothes and artefacts amazing, but again not enough information (in English).

Place of Repose and learning. Inside this. Beautiful, beautiful garden is the only Berber Museum in the world, with photographs, jewelry and utensils, and clothing of the Berbers.
A few little gift shops of unusual things.
The metal bookmarks are a nice souvenir.

Unexpected but tranquil in Marrakech. We watched a programme on the TV about these gardens so were determined to visit whilst in the city. On a hot and busy October day it was very pleasant to walk around the gardens which were cool very different to the rest of Marrakech. Well worth a visit to discover the history and the influences of Yves St Laurent. It gave us some inspiration for our garden!

Got to visit . Don't rush as it will be over in a blink. The cacti and succulent are truly beautiful a got to visit if in Marrakech. It's so interesting and pretty - don't wander off the paths or the staff will give you some grief lol yes my ears hurt
Peaceful!. A very peaceful garden, pretty incredible as it's in such a busy area. Be aware that you don't need long and the museum isn't worth seeing!

Wonderful garden. Such a beautiful garden, a real surprise. Make sure you visit the Berber museum in the garden as it gives a fascinating insight into Moroccan history. One tip - go early before those dratted tourists arrive!
Expensive. Whilst the plave is an oasis of peace in a crazy city I am not an expert in Cacti and bamboo so probably didn't make the best of it!

Crowded. Lovely gardens (I think) - very crowded with tourists (we went about 11.00 a.m.) and everyone walks slowly around a designated path. What I could see was great but we were out in 20 minutes because there were simply too many people to enjoy it.
Very colourfully bold. Beautiful haven of tranquility and beauty. Large collection of arid area plants - cactii and succulents, palms, bougainvilleas etc.
Must see. This is a must see you cannot beliwve you are in the noisy busy city, it is so peacfull in these lovely gardens, the planting and the atmosphere is fantastic

Just a chic garden and museum. Yes just a garden but the bamboo ant tropical tree groves are shady, picturesque and tranquil. Get there early (9-930?) though or be prepared to shuffle round and past people. The Christian Dior bits of limited interest to many, I suspect, but the Berber museum was really good - excellent rolling presentation showing how the art and carpets reflect the landscape.

peace within the Marrakech chaos. We decided to take a horse cart to the gardens -- wise,a real treat. And then the gardens themselves : awesome the amount of different plants and the perfect gardening. Quite a few visitors there but still enough room for many many photographs. Also the boutique with Yves St Laurant designs is worth a visit

Nice garden, but nothing special. When you have some extra time to spend yoy can go to this garden. It is nothing unique and can be very busy.
But it is nice to walk around
Just a garden. Really, It brought me no especial surprise, maybe because i come from a tropical country. A woalk on it is nice, and that is it.
Fashion and History. A must if you are in Marrakech. Fashion ,history and a beautiful garden. Do not miss the museaum you would be impress.

Just Lovely. A break from the dessert feel of Marakech. Cool and very green a respite. I understand that Yves Saint Laurent's home will be available to tour soon. He designed the garden and there is a monument to him there. It is a very quick stop but worth it.

Amazing garden, definitely visit. Brilliantly designed and laid out, the Majorelle Garden is a definite must see in Marrakech. A stunning combination of water features, cool bamboo-lined pathways, tropical plants and an incredible cactus collection provide a welcome break after the intense experience of th medina. The beautiful blue used throughout the garden shows the artists eye of Jacques Majorelle and the legacy was continued and developed by St Laurent and Berge. The cafe provides a reasonable meal but is worth it for the ambiance. Included is an excellent bookshop and the shop which goes way beyond the obligatory souvenirs to provide YSL love themed items among other high quality stock. The shops across the road from the main gate are also worth a visit for higher quality shopping.

Garden of beauty and peace. Wery beautiful place to visit, it is about 20 minutes walking distance from old Medina centre. It is doubtless worthy to visit. Very clear and cozy place where you can find shadow and hide against desert sund between bamboo and cactuses. It will be spectacular place for all lovers of nature. You can just sit here and meditate or marvel at garden architecture.
Enchanted garden. Amazing place, full of colours and special, rare plants, nice cafeteria, wonderful bookshop!A wonderful break
Fantastic!!. This is a must see while in Marrackech! One of the most amazing and beautiful and inspiring place I've ever visited!
Garden oasis. Although slightly away from the medina, the Jardin Majorelle is worth the short cheap taxi ride to see. A beautiful garden with some interesting features.
Serene. A wonderful place to visit but get there early before the crowds.interesting Berber museum and great shop too? visit excellent perfume shop just next door afterwards.
Beautiful. Amazing plant life, from around the world, south America, Argentina we even saw a pomegranate plant. Not very big though.

Nice enough and a bit different, but only worth a 45 minute visit. Small gardens, completely devoted to bamboo, cacti and a few small water features.
The whole venue would easily fit inside a football pitch.
The Berber museum is extra, and some of the older guide books say it features yves st laurent costumes on display. It doesn't.

A Riot Of Colour. A gorgeous little oasis amid the chaos that is Marrakesh. The perfect place to take a breather and get back to nature, heightened by the gorgeous use of colour, jewel blues and bright yellows, all displayed to perfection in the Moroccan sun.
garden tour. Nice garden with interesting and quirky choice of plants but very crowded. Might be better display of flowers a bit earlier in the year.

Stunning but too many people!. Try to go early morning or late afternoon if you truly want to appreciate the peace and beauty of this wonder-full Moroccan garden.
The restaurant was excellent and good value.

A visit to Jardin Majorelle. It was Eid holidays and everything was closed apart from Jardin majorelle so we decided to take a look. The garden offered a welcome shady experience in contrast to the blazing sun outside. The layout was beautiful and the primary blue/yellow/orange coulours of the plant pots made a positive addition to the surroundings. The cacti plants looked amazing! We also paid a visit to the museum which offered a brief history of the Berber tribe and also houses a beautiful collection of costumes and Jewelry. At the end of our tour we had a nice drink and traditional snack at the small cafe/restaurant housed in the grounds of the garden.

House and museum colourful ; garden for cactus lovers only !. In sunshine the blue house was amazing. And the Berber Museum was worth a few minutes. Unless you are really keen on cactus and other "dry climate plants" the garden may not thrill you.
An tourist filled oasis. Its hard to believe this garden exists in the middle of such a busy city. Expect tour buses unloading their passengers most of the day and some erratic parking :o)
the most wonderful blue. The garden is beautiful, the blues nd the mixture of plants and art is great.Also have a look at the berber museeum - it is tiny, but beautifully made!

Just Beautiful. This was definitely a highlight of my trip. Its so peaceful and calm, the blue house is just beautiful. Its lovely just to wander around there for a couple of hours in the peace and quiet to escape the craziness of everywhere else. Its also a great place to take photos and to sit and have a coffee without being pestered.
Small but well kept. The gardens are pretty and a nice place to escape the busy medina. It doesn't take long to get round them though- we went very slowly and still took only around half an hour.
Lovely and peaceful.. Nice to walk around and take photos. Lovely cafe for a mint tea. Easy taxi ride there. Pennies to get in.
Fantastic!. This is a truly fantastic garden unlike any garden we have ever seen. There were a lot of people visiting but at no time did we feel crowded. Don't miss the museum!

Great place to visit. Jardin Majorelle is a very nice place to visit in Marrakech. Every time I go there feels like the first time. The area is so calm and the gardens are stunning. Also, this is where Yves Saint Laurent used to live and is also burried there. A must go

Gorgerous gardens - must see. This was one of my favourites in Marrakech. It was so beautiful and quiet - a peaceful visit. The garden look amazing, including the little ponds etc - and you can clearly see that they maintain them well. The ranges of cactus they have is impressive. We did visit the museum which is lovely but unfortunately everything is in French only

OK to kill half an hour. Given that this is one the "must see" attractions in MK it's a little dissapointing to be honest! You can walk round in 30 minutes - its very pleasant but not as stunning as you are let to believe and a lot smaller!

tranqill setig. I have been to Marrakech many times I always love going to these gardens it is breath taking there is yves saint Laurent memorial there shops and a nice eatery place it is a nice place to visit while you are in morocco im disabled and I found it quite easey to get around there is no need to rush once you are in side

Beautiful garden. It is really recommended to visit if you're in Marrakesh. Very nice places to take pictures; the trees, flowers and oasis. The museum inside is very important to enter; you can learn a lot of the Moroccan culture. You also need to take the ride in the city on the horse carriage, very nice.
Fantastic. Beautiful gardens once owned by Yves saint Laurent. Go early in the motning as it gets very busy. Berber museum on site is a must do !
day visit. A beautiful garden not very large but well laid out.Berber museum worth looking at,only about £2.00 extra to get in.Fascinating archifacts.

Oasis!!. This was some time ago now but we visited Marrakech for New Year. The gardens were an oasis from the acrid smell of barbequed sheep which it seems are slaughtered and burnt everywhere in the region on the streets, gardens etc. Put me off lamb for months but the gardens well worth a visit, relaxing and interesting

Alright for an hour or two. There's a not a great deal to say about this place other than it is pretty and not too expensive to get into. We walked to it from the medina which was a bit challenging. The easiest way is to go to the square and walk up Ave Mohammed V. We tried to get there through the souks and invariably got lost. There's a supermarket not far away called Acima if you are in need of supplies.

Probably our highlight. In total contrast to the mayhem in the square, an oasis of calm. Almost impossible to leave without at least one stunning photo, the colours and light contrasts make it a snappers paradise.I am resolved to paint our flower pots when I get home. A couple of hints. A taxi from the main square cost 25Dh. The organised rip-off at the exit wanted 80Dh to return us back to the square. We walked away to the right and within 50 metres we hailed a cab and returned for 30Dh. We also made a mistake of eating cold carrot soup in the delightfully situated cafe. We regretted it for the next 48 hours.Overall its a "must do"

Beatiful gardens and new museum. Very nice garden park, a oasis in the midlle of Marrakech, used to be a vacation house of YSL and his partner, who open the gates to everybody to see how beatiful can be a garden. New museum with nice story of Morocco. Take your time and Enjoy !!!
take your camera a relaxing oasis. just don't wear electric blue like my daughter did unless you like your photograph taken. take a taxi there and a horse and carriage back enjoy a relaxing day.
Quite artificiel. Nice, but quite artificiel gardens. Not all that vast and a good walk from the medina. Too busy with tourists to really enjoy the place,
Peaceful haven. The Jardin Majorelle is a lovely cool and peaceful haven that's a great place to visit during the middle of a hot day.25Dhm per adult, children go free. So reasonably priced too.
Very beautiful well worth a visit. . Liked the amazing light and colour throughout. A very nice cafe inside the gardens which also seemed to do a pretty decent breakfast.
Truly spectacular. A wondferful oasis in the city. The finest display of cacti that I have ever seen set in amongts beautiful architecture.

Amazing colours!. It's a massive garden with loads of different plants ,fountains ,waterways/ponds and amazing blues, yellows ,whites. Great place to cool down in the heat and take photos!
You could just sit and relax for hours! Good restaurant too (see my reviews).

Go and see this phantastic oasis!. Once we arrived we spent more then an hour walking in this beautiful garden park and the little museum and cafeteria. It costs an entrance fee but its well spent. A relaxing contrast to the busy life in the Medina and the exhausting traffic around it. Go and see for yourself.
Beautiful Gardens. A lovely garden. The cacti were amazing. We went on a thomsons trip and they give you 1 hr here but as none gardeners this was too long.
Beautiful. Nothing more to be said, it really is and I can fully well imagine in full flora just how fantastic it really is

Beautiful cactus and palms, cool and quiet, worth a visit. This is a stunning collection of palm & cactus. Do not expect a flower garden! Very well maintained and beautifully arranged, the map guides you round this garden. There are seating areas dotted around to just sit and admire the view. There are several picture guides advising where certain cactus/palms are from around the world. The house is the Berber museum (an extra charge on top of the 50Dh to get into the gardens each).Cool, sheltered and quiet. Is quite a way out of the city centre so would need a taxi to get there and back. Toiltets (lady there as usual wanting small change). Cafe, boutique, museum bookshop, and Gallery. The prices in the cafe looked expensive (although still very busy).

A beautiful place to visit. Visited these beautiful gardens on our first day in Marrakech. What a pleasant experience, very tranquil and peaceful. Spent a hour or two amongst the sights and smells of the beautiful plants and flowers. An oasis amongst the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. Well worth a visit.

an oasis of calm. Beautiful gardens, and so quiet and calm given that they are in a quite mad city. The café is on the pricey side but the food is of a better quality than you might expect. Both garden and café were well worth the visit.

Quiet Oasis in Marrakech. The Jardin Majorelle was one of our favorite experiences in Marrakech. Located outside the city walls, and near the former home of designer Yves St. Laurent, the garden is a cool, quiet oasis within the exotic cacophony of sights, sounds, and smells of Marrakech. The garden features a number of trees, cacti, flowering plants, and water features. There is also a nice café inside the garden where one can take a break and rest. The entry fee is 50 dirhams (4.50 Euro / $6).

a little oasis of cool. If you want to escape the bustle of the souks and find a really peaceful shady spot this is it. Created by the painter Jacques Majorelle who died in an accident it was lovingly restored by Yves St Laurent and his partner. The designer is commemorated both by the road name and by a very tasteful memorial within the garden. There is a very pleasant courtyard cafe which serves a decent lunch and then you can wander around the fairly small but very beautiful estate. The gardens are really well maintained by the trust and are well worth a visit.
Beautiful. This garden is well-kept, popular and informative. We spent several hours here. The 25 dirhams to enter the museum within the gardens is well worth it

Among the bamboo..... We visited the gardens at high noon in the heat of the day delighted to be welcomed by the umbrella of bamboo. A very lovely garden but disappointed to find there were initials carved in the ancient trees . Now guards are stationed everywhere to prevent further damage.....thank goodness.

Surpassed exepctations, but very crowded. Thought this was going to be a "filler" stop in our itinerary, but it turned out to be a lovely and very interesting gardens - especially the wide variety of cacti. Even more amazing, we couldn’t get our two your children, 7 & 10, out of the place. We made the mistake of offering them the camera and they competed on who could get the most interesting picture of flowers, cactus spines, turtles and tourists. Finally had to bribe them with ice cream. Who would guess?

A nice oasis in the middle of Marrakech. We visited the Jardin the last day of our visit to Marrakech. It is outside the Medina and you can reach it by walking with no fear. The day was very hot and decided to visit this well advertised place. The garden has a wide range of plant varieties from all over the world and a large pond that is worth a picture. The houses painted with that particular blue are really the attractions of the site, very nice. It also has a cafe where you can sit and drink some good mint tea. Worth it if you're in town for a couple of days and you run out of things to do or buy.

2nd time round.... My husband and i travelled to Marrakech 7years ago, and although i enjoyed it then, I think going back to the gardens again, I think i enjoyed it more. The garden is a wonder place to chill and just potter around. Such a beautiful place. We tried the restaurant for lunch too, and i would say, it was one of the best meals we had during our stay in Marrakech. The beef tagine was fabulous....I tried alot of tagines during our stay... and this definitely up there. The quality of the beef was very good, cooked to perfection and the flavour was lovely.
Yves St. Laurant's gift to Marrakech. An oasis in Marrakech with a lily pond and a wide variety vegetation as well as a memorial to Yves as well as a small museum.

this is small and can be 'done' in 30 mins but was good. his is small and can be 'done' in 30 mins but was good chance to see some greenery in the very concret-y Marrakech! We took a taxi rather than the horse and cart and it cost 100dh return which is better than the horse and cart (and kinder?!) which is about 350dh

A really calm oasis in Marrakech. Very pretty gardens. Well worth a trip to experience the clever planting and brightly coloured pots. A lovely tranquil place to escape the heat and bustle of the souks.

Don't miss these wonderful gardens.. A visit to the Jardins Majorelle was a real highlight of our visit to Marrakech. The surprising use of bold colours for architectural elements, the sculptural layout and landscaping are world class. The garden has an extensive collection of succulents and other arid area plants including bamboo and other exotics was around the pools and fountains. An excellent museum of Moroccan art and artefacts, a good cafe and shop make for a very pleasant few hours.

A stark blue shot of colour. I never fail to visit this calm, colourful, fragrant, garden oasis in the middle of frenetic Marrakech. It is a beautifully landscaped, serene place to unwind and forget for a short while the chaotic sounds of Marrakech. A photography enthusiast's little heaven.
I guess this place is beautiful if you like cactus. Was hoping to spend half a day here but the gardens are very small. They came highly recommended so I may be alone in my negative view.
Top five attractions. The only highlight in the "new" city the gardens of YvesSaintLaurent created by Majorelle are a must.

Oasis just outside city walls. Beautiful, cool and relaxing. Don't miss the Berber museum! My wife loves terrapins so was very please to find a family of them living in the small lake there. Fantastic cacti and exotic trees.
Stunning. Great place to spend an hour. Beatiful surroundings and a fascinating Berber museum make for a must visit spot. Should be higher on to see list.

Small, but unique. Visited the gardens at the end of a trip to Morocco. Lovely way to end the week. The gardens are small but unique as I've said. Only maybe takes half an hour to wander round if you don't visit the Berber museum as well (which we did not), but the colours are very vivid and different to other places in Morocco. Beautiful array of varying plants and trees in different part of the garden. Very peaceful. Worth a visit for the contrast to the busy souks of the Medina.
Gem ithe desert. Visit to Marakesh would not be complete without visiting Jardin Majorelle. Fascinating plants, beautiful colours. Best way to reach it is by horse carriage.
MOST BEAUTIFUL GARDENS. Majorelle Gardens are worth visiting! The colors are uunbelievable! Full of exotic flowers and sounds of birds !

Beautiful but very crowded. This is definitely worth a visit as the gardens are truly beautiful. However, it would strongly suggest going early in the morning as soon as the gardens open. The coaches generally start arriving around 10.30am - 11.00am and then it gets absolutely packed. It is well worth looking at the book store as there are some really beautiful books to purchase.

Garden paradise with magical exhibition. These gardens are truly beautiful and I'm not really a garden person, not that I don't like them I do but I'm the sod who totes the chain saw and shovels,whilst my wife plans and spends and makes us into horticultural bankrupts.Marrakech can get very hot 40C plus and even in April we had 32C, so when you find some where with charming water features, flora and forna to wonder at, a really nice cafe where mint tea just has to be done, well what more can one say, apart from the mind blowing Berber exhibition with its star feature,a Berber environment created with a cuboid mirror and a lights creation, which as you stand within makes one feel like the there is just infinite space,a sort of night sky feeling when you stare into the stars.

Tranquil oasis amid the chaos. Get here early to avoid the queues and the tour groups, and step into a tranquil, lush, shady oasis and of peace and quiet. Such a contrast to the hot, noisy bustle just outside.I really enjoyed my time in the gardens- having read previous reviews that complain that the gardens are really small, I found them bigger than I was expecting.Wandering paths meander through bamboo 'grove' and paths, past small pagoda-follies, fountains and pools and yes, lots of cacti. I found it really relaxing, but I can see how having too many tourists there would've changed my experience. The courtyard café has a few interesting teas to try , and its nice to sit here and reflect.I really enjoyed the visit here and was one of my highlights of the time spent in Marrakech. But do get here first thing, and skip the crowds.

Disappointing, small and garden. Much hyped garden in the newer part of Marrakesh, restored and revived by Yves St Laurent after its initial creation and design by the unknown French painter Majorelle, crazy colours and bad architecture. It's a big disappoimntment in that, quite simply, there is nothing much to see except a wide variety of cacti from around the world and some very tall bamboo trees. And a rather self-obsessed little museum in the grounds. It certainly does not merit the entrance charge. This for us was a waste of a trip. 15 minutes was quite enough time to devote to it assuming you also had an expensive cup of tea in the cafe. It does not deserve to be on the same roster as other magnificent buildings and gardens elsewhere in the city

Gorgeous Gardens. This place is very nice I definitely recommend these gardens as part of a visit to Marrakesh.
There is a very nice (and expensive) shop inside, as well as a cafeteria.

Beautiful Gardens. Being in the gardens was one of the most beautiful moments of my life, the plants, trees and flowers not forgetting all the tidiness of the place.
Nice place to go relax with a book or just a friend and enjoy the scenery. I will definitely go back.

Very underwhelming. We have just visited the gardens and have to say what a massive disappointment. It's a small quiet area which is nice but that's about it. No colours. Apart from a seeming obsession with the colour blue - every plant pot and building is painted blue or occasionally yellow. Other than that it's just a LOT of cacti. And bamboo. I'm afraid I can't quite understand the appeal.

Small but pretty. The gardens aren't that big but nevertheless are worth a visit. At first we weren't that impressed but when we got round to the small bridge, blue house, pond and many, many cacti we thought more highly of it. There were lots of people so we had to wait to take photos of some things, or to have a seat in the shade but we still found it relaxing.We didn't visit the museum but had fresh lemonade in the a shaded, outdoor café. The café serves lunch, snacks and drinks. The toilet facilities are kept very clean hence you pay a small fee to use them.Taxis and carriages wait outside the park exit so going on somewhere afterwards is easy although we flagged down a taxi on the main road as there is no commission that way.I think it cost 30 Dirham per adult to visit the gardens. The museum costs extra.
Beautiful!. Well worth a trip! Its like another world once you step in side all of the delicious greenery and learn more about the culture of Morroco.

Amazing Berber Museum. I visited here in July with my sister and brother in law and although our visit was primarily for the gardens I have to say the unexpected highlight for us was the wonderful Berber Museum that Yves Saint Laurent has created. Amazing to see so much of their culture gathered under one roof - a real legacy. The jewellery collection certainly allows you to see the inspiration that Yves Saint Laurent then took to the world in the design of his own jewellery and the bottles for his perfumes.The gardens are really refreshing to visit on a hot day (it was 45 degrees the day we went) and appear as an "oasis" within downtown Marrakesh where you do not see a lot of parks and gardens.Taking a horse drawn carriage there helps you wind down and arrive at the garden in a relaxed mode. Even if you are not into gardens do make time to visit here while you are in Marrakesh.

Disgusted. I have visited these gardens many times and always love the calm and beauty of the place. However when I went back there for the first time since the little museum had been redone I was horrified to find not one poster, print or book on Majorelle, purely a homage to YSL. Whilst I appreciate that YSL saved the gardens after Majorelle's death, let us not forget who created this magical space
Stunning and unique. Very unusual gardens, fascinating plants, electric colours beautifully laid out really worth a visit.
Nice garden but over hyped. It was a nice enough garden but its attraction is really all about its famous owner Yves St Laurent.I guess also Insight Tours had to use it as a feature of its Tour.

The perfect chill-out spot. Absolutely gorgeous, and well worth the 50 dirhams. One of the shadiest places in Marrakech, so it's a relief from the heat, but it's also beautifully and lovingly designed. A great place to spend an hour or two with a book, on one of the many benches.

Don't expect the unlikely. Firstly, it's worth going just for the Berber museum, which is modern and a bit of an eye-opener.The garden is in the middle of a dry country that should be concerned about water conservation and it gets packed with people - so don't expect too much lushness - it has palms and plenty of giant bamboo that makes it mostly shady and cool, but it is the cacti that are the stars.Is it a world class garden? NoIs it a welcome break from the city? YesWould you be missing an amazing experience? No, but the museum is worth a look as it's very different to the others.It took an hour to walk very slowly around the garden and the museum, taking lots of photos and reading everything (ie: it's not big). There's also a great little shop after the museum with books, prints, etc.
dissapointment. I have seen much more beautiful gardens than this. It is lovely and has a beautiful atmoshpere but I found it Overpriced, touristy and just a dissapointment.

A haven of peace and tranquility. The Jardin Majorelle is a short walk from the centre of the new part of Marrakech and about a 20 minute walk from Jemaa El Fna, and well worth the trouble. We had to walk past the central bus station to get to the gardens, so after the smell and noise, piles of rubbish and chaotic traffic, it really did seem like a small piece of heaven. Although there were quite a lot of other people in the gardens, this in no way detracted from our enjoyment of the beautiful colours, amazing cacti and other plants and the quiet area around the memorial to Yves St Laurent. The gardens are beautifully kept and definitely should be on everyones visit list. The Berber museum inside the gardens is very well presented with some spectacular displays of costume and jewellery, worth the small extra payment to visit.
beautiful,iconic, well worth a visit. the museum is worth a visit too. unfortunately the cafe wasnt serving food as it was being refurbished
Beautiful. This place was amazing - so unexpected so close to the centre of Marrakesh. Definitely make time to see it. Particularly in summer, it was such a gorgeous relief from the heat.

Structural Plants. A garden composed of structural plants with colour provided only by the buildings and pots which is to be expected given the water shortage. Nevertheless they are well tended. It is difficult to get decent photos as you cannot get the distance to capture the size of many of the plants. Smaller than I expected. Beware the price of return taxis. If you use the Marrakech Tour Bus buy a 2 days pass and go using that.

Awesome. I am not normally one for gardens, certainly not when visiting somewhere totally new like Morocco, but the other half wanted to go so I dutifully trotted along… and was so glad I did so.. Marrakech is so full of bustle, sound and smell, and yet the Jardin Majorelle was a total contrast to all the mayhem. Luckily my partner had taken heed of the warnings to go early and we arrived at 09:30am, it was quiet enough that I could take photos unhindered by other visitors and view what I wanted to. By the time we left, the queues had started to form at the entrance and the coach parties were turning up, so please do go early if you want to enjoy the garden at its best. The myriad of plant types and colours really are a joy and provide a nice shade from the sun, there are plenty of places to sit and quietly take in the experience. It may not be the largest garden in the world, but I certainly believe the small entrance fee worth every Dirham. The garden is well tended and the facilities – tea room, toilets etc clean and inviting. Again, going early meant that we could slowly peruse the gardens yet still be the only ones in the tea room at the end of our visit. I would heartily recommend a visit to the Jardin Majorelle, it’s only a couple of hours out of your day and more than worth the jaunt away from the Medina.

Take a break from the whirl of Marrakesh. Plan to visit, but go early as it gets busy. Enter this beautiful garden and enjoy the coolness and peace that will greet you.The Majorelle Garden is a mysterious garden, and nothing like it anywhere with its abundance of plants in shapes and forms from five continents - collected by Jacques Majorelle after he acquired the land in 1924 (open to the public since 1947). This garden is art!

Tranquility in the City. In the hustle and bustle of Marrakesh, the Jardin Marjorelle offers peace and tranquillity and is a lovely way to spend a few hours relaxing in the gardens, or taking a snack and drinj in the café area.

Must-see. I almost didn't make it to this garden, donated by Yves Saint Laurent to the city of Marrakesh, which would have been a shame since it was one of the highlights of my stay. Free of the hustle of the city, in this place of beauty, I felt a sense of calm and renewal. And I came away with some great ideas for my garden back in California. Be sure to also visit the small but well-curated Berber Museum, also on the grounds.

The most amazing place in Marrakech. Amazing place
But too many visitors midday
Go early morning or late afternoon
Would not recommend the cafe

Beautiful calm space in the heart of the city. Do go early to beat the crowds.The light and colours are wonderful and enhance the exotic plants . The cafe is excellent.Use the loos there rather than the public ones.
Beautiful. The gardens are lovely for a short stroll away from the busy city. 5 Euros entrance fee per person seemed a bit steep just to walk around a small garden!

Jardin Majorelle. What a beautiful and peaceful place! Well worth the entrance fee. We spent around 1 hour there and found it to be very relaxing. The driver we hired for the day suggested here and we were very pleased we said yes.

Not to be missed. This should be number one on your siteseeing list! A truly beautiful garden with an amazing history. Take a camera for some simply stunning photo opportunites. Soaring bamboo creates shady pathways through this artists garden. Breathtaking cactus frame superb vistas through pergolas of flowering vines. Golden fish filled pools, lush vegetation and jewel-like flowers are set off against glowing cobalt blue painted landscaping. A museum, gallery and cafe completes the visit - allow at least two hours.

Majorelle gardens. Living in Spain and so seeing palms etc., all the time the gardens were a little disappointing, but the Berber museum was very informative and we enjoyed this part of the gardens very much.

Peace and Serenity!!. Spent a fantastic half day at the Gardens. Beautifully kept and easy to navigate!! We were there in early March 2013 and it wasn't too crowded. Having wandered around the amazing gardens, water features and house, I found a quiet bench to sit and read for a while. Very tranquil. There is a really nice cafe on site in a lovely courtyard.

Stunning. The gardens are stunning, with a fabulous collection of cacti. The house is beautifully painted in Saint Laurent's vibrant colours. Even though I went mid afternoon, and it was pretty full, it's still possible to find a quiet corner and enjoy the tranquilty of the place after the hustle and bustle of Jemaa El Fna Square. Also pay a little extra and visit the museum with a lovely collection of Berber treasures. There's a pleasant little cafe too, a little overpriced, but well worth it.
a living memorial to evies sant lauren. a beautiful garden with fountains and water cascades, palm trees and semi desert plants, a must see in Marrakech

Fascinating gardens. Bit of a queue to get in, so go early. But a brilliant visit, especially the inspiring plant designs, the wonderful water features and Moroccan designs. Also pay the additional money to take in the Berber museum, well worth while.

Pretty as a picture. The garden looks like a Matisse's painting. The color combination is perfect. In the heart of the garden is a museum of Berber culture, a shop and a cafe serving some tasty lunches. It's not the cheapest place to eat but it's affordable for the average traveler.
Magical Gardens. This is a very charming oasis in the middle of Marrakech. Lots of history, very interesting plants and so very colourful and photogenic.
lovely and quiet place.. Take in the abundant shade and different vegetation, Mrs Yves saint laurent makes a good botanic job.
A little overrated. Yves St. Laurent and his partner owned this famous Marrakech garden. It is famous for its blue color. The gardens are nice, but not necessarily exceptional.
Good escape. As said, good escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. Nothing spectacular to see, just quiet. The gardens are nice but it takes you all of 15 minutes to see it all.

Meh.... I guess the fact that it was owned and designed by Yves Saint Laurent is what draws the crowds. I thought the Majorelle was pretty average and not really worth the entrance fee. Couldn't really see what the big deal was?

Beauiful. An oasis and piece of art in the midst of the dust and traffic.
The colours, smells and planting are amazing.
Well worth a visit.

An oasis of tranquility in an intense city. This garden is beautifully laid out in Moroccan geometric patterns that includes rare and spectacular plants and trees bisected by fountains and water features..its a lovely refreshing and tranquil place in the hustle and bustle of this teeming city...the strongest colors used are the Majorelle blue and terracotta with Yellow...visitors will come away wanting to tranform their own outdoor space to create the same atmosphere..their own private slice of Morocco.

Delightful gardens - not to be missed. As a keen gardener, having read up on the jardins prior to our trip to Marrakech, I felt that they were a must and I had high expectations... and I was NOT wrong, nor was I disappointed! What an absolute delight our visit turned out to be.For me, Jacques Majorelle's gardens represent a wonderful break from the crowded, hot and at times overwhelming streets of Marrakech - a complete contrast! The collection of plants, many of which cacti and succulents from the world over, is impressive and clearly lovingly maintained, and a feast for the eyes. I would recommend no less than a couple of hours for a thorough visit - well worth the 50 dirhams a ticket.

Disappointed. I heard about how beautiful the Garden was and I am actually disappointed.It's nice, but not spectacular. The Berber Museum was a lot more interesting. I would recommend that. As for the garden, I just found it a 'nice' garden.
Nice but overcrowded!. Nice but packed with people! Although we got there in the morning the garden is just too small for all the visitors

Visit the famous Majorelle Blue. Nestled nicely away from the noisy streets of jemaa el fna, the Majorelle Gardens is worth a visit. For 50 dirham, one can enjoy lovely interior painted with unique majorelle blue. The garden offers plenty of shade and also a perfect venue for a massive photo op.
The garden is relatively small. So take your time and stop rushing.

It wasn't good Garden to visit.. you pay for it, but there is nothing special about this garden. people visit that place because of Yves Saint Laurent. few follower and a lot of Sahara desert plants . my home will never look like his.

Nice if you're in the area. We visited the gardens but not the museum so cannot comment on that. It's a nice place to visit if you are already in Nouvelle Ville but we made a special trip for it and were a little disappointed as it is pretty small and we got round it quite quickly, go early so it isn't packed with tourists. There are some really beautiful plants there and also some really interesting little rooms dotted about, our favourite was the Yves Saint Laurent 'Love' collage room.
Very nice worth a visit. Beautiful lush gardens worth the couple of pounds it costs, you can take a horse and carriage to this area and they will wait for you negotiate a price before you take one

Exquisite Gardens. These gardens are a haven of tranquility in a busy environment of sights, sounds and smells. They are designed in a way that makes a stroll through them a peaceful and calming experience. Be prepared to take many photos.
Beautiful gardens. Must visit these gardens they are beautiful and shaded so you don't need to worry about the sun. Some wonderful species and lovely café - must have lunch!

loads of tourists. the gardens are relatively small (in comparision to other cities) but definitely y worth a stroll. pretty much inundated with tourists but still a relaxing afternoon out. Yves St Laurent's ashes scattered in the garden.

Not what we expected!. Very stylish gardens, but plants from USA and Mexico - not local. The Berber museum is well worth the extra 25 dirhams entry fee, especially the jewellery. YSL clothing in shop very expensive but classy. Don' t worry if you miss this one!

Refreshing but nothing spectacular. Nothing special. Refreshing but entry free was a little higher than other sites at 50 dhms (vs. 10 for Bahia Palace for example). The cafe directly across the street was awesome - quinoa wrap and cucumber/apple smoothie!

Escape from the chaos in this lovely, unique garden. Relatively small but beautifull design garden offers peace and shadow for its visitors. Given the weather, its has very unusual plants selection compared to traditional gardens. This was my second favourite attraction in the city.

A total surprise. What a brilliant place - not at all what we expected. It is peaceful, exotic, varied, and well organised. There is a wonderful display of cacti, trees,and bamboos from many countries. The water course runs the length of the garden, and we quite understood why Yves St Laurent bought it as it would inspire anyone in their work. A great 50 Dirham's worth.

Marrakesh September 2013. Upon entering this amazing garden I was speechless. It is truly a sanctuary, exceeding my expectations and an amazing exquisitely haunting highlight of my journey to MoroccoMargo Fremantle Western Australia

An unusual Garden. Majorelle collected plants from all over the world for this garden. It has some fantastic cacti. The pots and buildings in the garden are in deep blue, turquoise and lemon yellow. There are luxurious bougainvillea, yuccas, bamboos, geraniums....it is a photographer's paradise

Good, not spectacular. Entrance fee seemed a bit steep especially after having visited amazing palaces in Marrakech where the entry fee was only 10 dirhams. It's a nice enough place to stroll around for an hour but that's about it. Particularly liked the cactii.The actual Yves Saint Laurent monument is surprisingly plain. Dull even. You don't even get a glimpse of the house. The staff seemed very disinterested.

peace and tranquility. I think it worked out at about 4 quid to get in, the Majorelle blue with all the plants is lovely, never seen such big bamboo, really peaceful, we walked there and the signs to get there weren't very clear, worth a visit.

Lovely tranquil gardens. An impressive garden setting designed by Jacques Majorelle and latterly owned by Yves Saint-Laurent and Pierre Bergé. Plenty of cacti, bamboo, water features and all expertly laid out. Its easy to see what Yves Saint-Laurent and Pierre Bergé saw in it
lovely. a nice walk from the new town and the gardens were great along with quiet restaurant's and cafes well worth the visit

Beautiful Jardin. I knew I would love this place and I did. I love cactus, I love bright colours, I love Yves Saint Laurent, so what do you expect. I loved it! My partner was a bit underwhelmed but that is nothing new for him :) Not too many tourists, and it is a beautiful place to spend some time soaking up the sunshine and imagining the atmosphere back when Yves was here.

Nort worth trip if there wasn't a hip store nearby...... I was surprised this got such a high rating. I suppose if there is nothing else to see then it is ok but it is a lovely bamboo and cactus garden in a funky part of town. We were not very impressed and there was not much to see. It seems like something to do if you were stretched to find something to do. I went there only because there was a highly rated shop next to it called 33 Rue De Majorelle. The shop was well worth the trip to this part of town though.
Relaxing. An oasis in middle of mad Marrakech,restuarant serves good coffee !try to get there early morning before the crowds

What a beautiful place to visit. I really enjoyed walking through this beautiful garden and marvelling at all the tress and plants on display. You can view flora from the five continents all set out beautifully in a tranquil setting. It was one of the most relaxing things I did while in Marrakech and afforded a lovely cool escape from the heat and the hustle and bustle of the city. Well worth your time.

Gorgeous, vibrant, artist's garden. A magnificent experience of overwhelming colour and design. The cafe is great, if a bit expensive. Don't bother taking a horse and carriage - better to spend the time in the gardens and museum.
blu colours. the garden is designed by a french artist, the choose of the blu clours is really succefull. it's located in the center of the new medina.

Nice garden but too congested.. The garden (entrance fee of 50 dh) was very nice and looked to have been designed sophisticatedly. But one felt congested as there was just not enough space.Berber Museum (an additional fee of 25 dh) was small but the stuff inside were delicate and very interesting.
Peaceful. Very stylish garden but could do with a few more explanatory panels. The museum adjoining the garden is a gem.

Jardin Majorelle. This was definitely a tourist site we didn't want to miss as we had heard a lot about it. To be honest, whilst it is a very nice peaceful garden, it is a little overrated. It is not very big and there really isn't a lot to see other than the surrounding greenery and the memorial - there is a museum which you need to buy separate tickets for which we didn't go to as we had already been to a Berber village and inside a Berber home. So whilst it was nice to go, you wouldn't be missing out on a lot if you skipped this.
Worth a visit. A tranquil place in the middle of a busy part of Marrakesh. Enjoyed strolling around the gardens looking at the various cactii and plants.

A relaxing visit. This garden is so beautiful and wonderfully arranged. majorelle garden is an excellent break from the noise and the hassles of a big city like Marrakech. The cactus plants have incredible variety and the Berber museum is a must to visit! The shop in the garden was quite nice as well and if you like more shopping, try 33 Majorelle outside the garden. Too bad we were running late we didn't get to try the really nice cafe inside Majorelle garden.

Very beautiful cactus garden in middle of the city. It was smaller then we expected, but worth visiting. It is facinating how Yves saint Laurent designed this special well looking garden. Also well soignated.

Amazing cacti. A cool and serene garden. Nice place for an ice-cream and some tranquility. Amazingly different types of cacti and well maintained overall. Small but interesting museum housing traditional costumes and jewellery.
must visit. go early, gets busy in pm. peaceful, quiet, shaded, cool, lovely. take your time to sit and look around, not one to rush

Excellent place. I loved this place. Was a nice little oasis amid the heat and hubbub of the city.
All in all a definitive must when visiting Marrakech.
Hidden Jem. cool, calm and collected. Great place to spend a hot afternoon. Blue paint and green plants -Beautiful
visit. the gardens are beautifully layed out well maintained . Yvs St Laurent has a home next door and a monument erected within the gardens

pretty but busy. Very interesting and great photo opportunities, but can be busy with others having the same idea!
The on site cafe was well worth a visit, and boutique shops outside worth a browse.

peaceful and stylish. a beautiful oasis in a very busy city. If you are inetersted in fashion (Yves St laurent) or plants this is perfect for you. If you need to get out of the hustle and bustle it is a nice place to spend a couple of hours

A pleasant couple of hours. We popped in to the gardens and enjoyed a wander round, they are well maintained and interesting but you won't need more than a couple of hours for the garden. It is a perfect place to retreat to for some shade.
Love the place. Gorgeous garden. Small but deserve a visit. Nice color mix between the blue of the building and the plants.

Oasis. Beautiful spot, oasis in busy Marrakech.
I understand completely why Yves St Laurent bought this place..

A garden to escape the Moroccan heat. Our tour guide took us to Jardin Majorelle in 50 degree heat and it was amazing!! There are plenty of places to sit in the shade amongst the beautiful trees and plants. And best thing of all is the colours!!! Such incredible colours throughout the garden. Highly recommend if you are looking for something to do in Morocco, definitely worth the entry fee.

Worth going to see. The gardens designed by Yves Saint Lauren were a lovely afternoon out. Although there is little to learn about or read in the gardens they are nice and peaceful to walk around as a change to the busy city. Entry was cheap and getting a taxi there and back is simple.
Lovely gardens. Beautiful gardens, clearly well tended by an army of staff. Nice cafe and clean toilets. Pay for ticket to museum which is very interesting.

Too expensive for a little Garden. The entry fee for the garden was 50 Dirham. This was a lot of money for a real small garden. It was really nice but not worth so much money. No Informations about Yves Saint Laurent but three shops to buy stuff. Better visit the free cyber park.
Breathtaking colour. One of the most beautiful places I've ever been. Stunning! Especially liked the Yves St Laurent Love Postcards exhibition

beautiful place, full of tourists. of course this place was absolutely stunning and a marvellous creation but just dont go there thinking youll be in a secluded paradise, full of tourists unless maybe if you go at 8am!there were loads of builders restoring the walls with loud machinery which also took the magic away, but the building and gardens itself are amazing!

a haven in the city. this place is not as big as you would imagine, but it is well worth the visit, it is a great place to get away from the madness of the city, be careful getting there, taxi should put on the meter for you but they can charge the earth, also beware of the horse and carriage that you can take there, nice, but they will rip you off
nice place. i would say beautiful gardens, incredible plants, trees, cacti and colours, just a lovely experience for a few hours...

Worth a visit. Really lovely gardens - lots of cacti and pretty water features, all of which are well maintained. We spent a good hour or so wondering around and sitting in the gardens. It's 50d to get in (so less than £4) and seemed worth that. There's a small cafe on site but it's pretty expensive so we didn't use it. The gardens are a little out of the way so most people take a taxi - be warned that the taxi drivers that wait outside will try and rip you off. It should be 30d max back to Marrakech centre. Keep haggling and just walk away if they want to charge more, it won't be long before someone takes you for a reasonable price.
Beautiful. Beautiful, peaceful garden, well worth a visit.Take taxi from Jemaa El Fna square, it will cost around 20 Dirhams. Taxis outside garden for return to town.

Tranquility in a mad city. Beautifully laid out and peaceful until the crowds arrive. go in the morning! There is a lovely cafe serving nice smoothies. Lots of tranquil areas within the gardens to sit and think.

Pretty. A splash of colour in an otherwise dusty city, these gardens are very pretty. We were a bit disappointed as I think we've been spoiled by the lush gardens in the UK, which clearly this country can't compete with due to the very different climates, but it was a nice place to visit.
A different scene. This is a nice place to just come sit and relax and get out from the heat. The gardens are well maintained. The best part was the shade provided.

A hidden gem and a must visit !. This beautiful garden is only quite small but is stunning with its bright colours, amazing planting and water features. You can easily spend an hour looking around and definitely buy the visit to the refurbished museum which is only small but very interesting. The low cost of entry is a bonus as the gardens and museum should not be missed. If you can then get there early or late as the coach trips seem to be there through the middle of the day.

Yves what a lovely legacy..... This was a lovely tranquil oasis but also the home of a very unique personality & oh so creative soul...this garden is a wonderful legacy to Yves St Laurent & the maintaining of such a culturally significant personal space. Thoroughly enjoyed the beautiful gardens so well maintained & also the lovely courtyard cafe/restaurant & buildings. You can't visit Marrakesh & not stop in here for a look inside the world of such a beautifully talented designer....

Disappointing. I'm a big fan of Yves Saint Laurent and as this garden was "restored and acquired" by the great fashion stylist I expected to see something stunning. While all gardens are relaxing to stroll and have a sense of their owners, this garden lacked style. The colours were interesting and vibrant, the "Yves Saint Laurent blue" against yellow, but next to a cactus garden it all seemed to Mexican. Also the house in these gardens were not that of the great man but his guest house. ( Winston Churchill stayed here according to our guide) and there is no access.The great man's memorial was here (boring) and his house was on the other side of the fence which nobody can see nor enter. I would have thought his house would be a great museum piece and many whom come to this garden think they are going to see something of Yves Saint Laurent's life, but alas it is not to be. Some of my neighbours gardens are more impressive.

beautifull. a calm and beautifull oasis in the midst of the bustle, famously restored by yves st laurent after the gardens had become neglected they are stunning the gorgeous blue colour, named majorelle blue stands out and the planting is amazing
discover. Pleasant surprise in the middle of the city. Had no intention to visit the place but it was recommended by my taxi driver
Very very pretty. Well worth a visit, as it is a very pretty and lovely garden! The colors are awesome. You can walk to it from the Medina, it is not that far...
NICE PLACE TO BE SEEN. If You have half an hour to spend in a nice garden this is a place where to go. Just to look and understand why YSL chose this place
