Found it very boring. Although the gardens have a lovely selection of cacti and plants, that's about it. It was nice and quiet, compared to the rest of marrakech but we walked round within 30 minutes. I wouldn't recommend it.

Must be seen !. The absolute # 1 place in Marrakech. Nicely maintained and colorful. If you are visiting Marrakech do not miss the opportunity to see this. You have to take a cab from the city because there are not too many directions placed for this attraction and you can get lost easily.

Tranquility. What an amazing collection of flora specimens gathered and designed in such a harmonious beautiful manner. The light and shade and landscaping provided a sense of beauty and peace. The museum of clothing and jewellery was fascinating and worth the visit..

Tranquil gardens, YSL Memorial. We were a group of 16 ladies. We walked from our Riad in the Medina to the gardens which took us a very leisurely 40 minutes through the market and past the bus station. There were lots of taxis and coaches dropping people off at the entrance, but it is easy to find walking there if you have good instructions. There is an small entrance fee to the garden and another fee to the Museum. There is a cafe where you can get a drink and a snack, meal and refreshments (no alcohol). We did not go, so cannot comment on the restaurant. The gardens are lovely, people taking advantage of the many seating areas, but we did not linger as we had a lunch reservation elsewhere. Nice way to spend a leisurely couple of hours

Interesting. Great, colorful garden. Has a very nice garden restaurant with some good food and refreshments. Wonderful place to take pictures.cost about 50 Dirhams per person. Worth the price and travel.Could be reached by hop-on bus from Marrakesh center.

Colourful peaceful respite!!. Expensive, but worth it for some well earned peace from the magical chaos of Marrakech. The restaurant was crazeee prices catering for rich, but I loved the tranqulity here and some great photo opportunity's!!Some lovely Art and arabesque wooden carvings, seen better gardens but not in Morrocco. lots of cactus and palms.
Beautiful. Very beautiful and tranquil spot in the middle of marrakech. well worth the visit. don't touch the cactuses

Thank you Yves and Pierre. If you have time for only one sight in Marrakech then this is a must. Saved and restored by Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Berge.Every where you turn as you walk around the peaceful garden you will find Cacti, Exotic plants, Palms large and small. All planted to give a different vista and texture.The Berber Museum has an extremely well curated display of costume and native jewellery which is unrivalled in Marrakech.A true delight - but go early before it gets busy and enjoy the enchantment.

Tranquil. We walked from our Riad about 15min.Walk around and explore....it's so much better than taxi.Gorgeous gardens well kept. Easily spend 3-4 hours.We also went to the little restaurant/cafeI'd just get a drink, 3times they brought out our order, the complained that we left no tip.;)
Nice garden. Quite small, takes longer to get there than to look around but the gift shops had some nice things and the cafe/gallery/shop in the street outside looked very nice

Tranquil and beautiful. The most amazing gardens I have ever visited. Plants and cacti from all over the world were ace. The berber museum was very interesting indeed and the cafe was exceptional. Get a taxi here.

A little oasis. We walked to the gardens as our Ryad was only 10/15 minutes away so it was surreal going from the hectic roads into the beautiful quiet oasis that is the Majorelle Gardens. The gardens themselves are relatively small but they are beautifully laid out and looked after. The paths allow you to walk rounds as many times as you like and there are benches along the routes so you can sit and relax. The towering bamboos provided great shade so its lovely and cool, especially as it was 39C on the day we went! We chose not to pay the extra for the museum but had a lovely mint tea in the café there instead. It wasn't the cheapest but the location was beautiful and the mint tea delicious, it also came with a Moroccan pastry which was tasty. There is a small shop on site, mainly selling traditional Moroccan gifts but it was a bit pricey, there is also a small book shop. The Love Gallery displays the Yves Saint Laurent artwork posters that were produced each year. The garden does get very busy with tour bus loads of tourists so I would recommend going in the morning.

A calm oasis in the middle of bustling Marrakech. as we were only spending 3 days in Marrakech we wanted to make sure that we found the right balance between sightseeing and relaxing - fortunately at Jardin Majorelle, you can do both.We chose to visit as it was one of the hottest days in Marrakech and didn´t want to be walking around in the heat. This was a great choice as it has a fantastic selection of plants and trees, it was peaceful and quiet and you can hardly feel the heat - breezy and cool. Very beautiful place overall

Paradise. After walking from our riad we couldn't believe this place could be so nice in amongst the busy roads and hotels that surround it. Once inside your surrounded by an array of palm trees flowers and all sorts. I'm not one for gardens at all bit thoroughly enjoyed it. The Berber museum is worth a visit and we also had a nice lunch in the cafe. A real peaceful paradise in such a hectic city!
the only nice thing in Marrakech. After all the dirt all over the place garden was the beautiful oasis in the city. I really enjoyed it. Can make nice photos there.

Jardin Majorelle. We were taken to the garden by our driver, Houssam, of Enjoytours-Morocco.com and a local guide referred by the tour company. They were magnificent. Marrakech was not one of our favorite spots in Morocco, so getting to the oasis of Jardin Majorelle was wonderful. The motif is green and cobalt blue. The buildings and walkways are cobalt blue amidst the most beautiful gardens. The site is run by Yves St. Laurens foundation in Paris. It was designed by French expatriate and furniture maker Jacques Majorelle in the 30's. There are many birds, cacti, and ponds in an exquisite environment. Do not go to Marrakech without seeing these gardens. I will attach some photos.

Well worth a visit. On a hot June day this was a delightful place to visit. It is beautifully laid out, well kept with many interesting trees and plants. The Berber Museum was excellent and with ample information available on the exhibits. The "gift shop" was expensive but the cafeteria reasonable.
Beautiful place to go!. Loved the variety of plants! I suggest you to go around 5.15pm so you can still visit the museum inside and it's less hot. LThe light is less strengh at this time
Beautiful. Beautiful shade-filled gardens. The Berber museum on the grounds is worth paying the extra 25 dirhams to visit.
Jardin Majorelle. It is a very nice place to visit in the amazingly animated Marrakesh. It is an oasis of tranquility and relaxation.

Outstanding gardens in the shade. Other than Spain's Alhambra, I can't think of gardens I've enjoyed more than these. Dominated by tall green bamboo, but containing a wide variety of unusual plants, there's a lovely artistic quality about these gardens, derived from alignment and colour. The cool flowing water and ponds enhance the experience. There's also an excellent museum about the Berber culture in the grounds, well worth a visit.

Beautiful Gardens - well worth an excursion outside the Medina. The gardens, as designed by Yves Saint Laurent were absolutely gorgeous and more than merited the 50 MAD entry price. Located conveniently down the road from Gare Routiere making for an ideal morning trip before purchasing any bus tickets etc.

Awesome. Absolutely fantastic gardens. Real class and style about the place. Make sure you visit the Berber Museum. Also a lovely little café set in a gorgeous courtyard halfway round. Probably the best/biggest display of cactus plants you'll ever see !

Nice garden. We went to Jardin Majorelle as part of a tour. It is a lovely garden and very peaceful although I was a little disappointed with the lack of flowers and range of plants. The buildings are beautifully coloured and it offers a good opportunity to take photos.
Nice to see. From my personal point of view, I think the garden is really nice to see, but the fee of approx. 5 Euro is rather high for local price niveau.

Peaceful garden but expensive in cost ;). The entry fee is much more expensive than other sites to visit in Marrakech. The garden isn't too big as I expected but it is maintained pretty well. Good place to hide from the heat in Marrakech

Calm, peaceful and beautiful.... Whilst the gardens are not huge, its worth an hour out of your day to see them. They are stunning, with a great collection of bamboos and cactus plants from all over the world. The gardens and ponds make for great photos and offer a shaded respite from the relentless heat and bustle of the city. Entry is about £4 each and they have a nice cafe as well.
Sublime. Go early before the coach loads arrive and you'll be rewarded with a tranquil setting in the heat of Marrakech.

Beautiful Gardens. We visited Jardin Majorelle after being recommended it by a number of people. Lovely gardens, beautifully presented and very peaceful. It was 10 dirham entrance fee and a slow wander around the gardens took about 45 minutes. Definitely worth a visit- plenty of benches to sit and relax and lots of lovely shady areas and quiet corners.

Not as great as expected.. Perhaps because I have been to some other great gardens (Lotus Land in Santa Barbara and Huntington Gardens in Los Angeles), this was somewhat disappointing, especially because my expectations were high because of other reviews. The garden itself is somewhat small. The outstanding feature is the color. The Berber Museum inside, however, is very good.
A Highlight!. A visit to these gardens is a must whilst in Marrakech. It was one of the highlights for me - so beautiful and colourful.
Great stroll. A fantastic way to spend a couple of hours. Walk through the mellow, colorful botanical gardens. It's a quiet reprieve just 5 minutes from the madness of the center of Marrakesh.

an oasis in a bustling city. These gardens were beautiful designed by yves st laurent the colours and flora and fauna are stunning.A really nice place to spend a very pleasant morning or afternoon.Very tranquil and not too crowded.

Oasis of calm. Beautiful garden, house is a colour sensation! Can get busy so best time to visit is around 10am
Monument to Yves St Laurent disappointing.
Gardens majorelle. Gardens so beautiful and it is worth the bit extra to sit in the café and have some lovely mint tea. Great place for photos
jardin majorelle. it was very wonderful and so beautiful. we recommend it. the gardens are very nice and very well made
Beautiful Gardens!. These gardens are definitely beautiful. The way the trees are very artistic, so beautiful that it looks unreal. but YSL did an amazing job. Clean, nice walk, it is worth the time.

A Diamond in the Rough. These gardens are a must see in Marrakech! I absolutely loved them and could of sat in the garden for hours just taking in the surroundings. You leave the busy hustle and bustle of the Medina only to discover this jewel behind stone walls. Take a cab or horse and carriage ride (or you could walk for over an hour like we did) and relax in the gardens. There are also many cafe's and a few shops close by.
cactus town. nice place, a great collection of cactus and a nice place to spend 1 hour in the fresh area. Taxi stop is in front of the door , no problem to arrive and leave

Gardens. We loved these gardens ,we walked from the main square which was a bit of a hike but when we got there is is a real oasis of calm .The berber museum was worth a visit also it was very well layed out and the costume section was dazzling.

Lots of dry plants, a little over rated. I went there because I heard about it a lot even before I planned on coming to Marrakech. I was disappointed because it's not as colorful as I was hoping. Only the blue and yellow of the pillars and pots give it some color. It's a collection of green plants from all over the world. If you are not a big fan of cacti you are better off keeping your 50 dirhams plus expensive taxi rides money for something else.

Beautiful place to visit. These Gardens are really really beautiful, and a lovely way to spend the morning. I went there on the morning of my birthday, and I can not say just how delightful and peaceful it is, beauty upon beauty and such vibrant colours, took loads of photos and stopped for a café au lait at their café, which is expensive, but very very nice. A must go place to visit.

This is one of top three things to do in Marrakech.... Over the last 20 years, I often take delegations to Marrakech, and along with Jemaa El Fna and Madresa Ben Youssef, this is one of the top three attractions in Marrakech. The trees, the plants, the cacti, the wildlife, even the decent cafe, its a little oasis of calm in the heart of Marrakech that never disappoints.
Jardin Majorelle. Beautiful but small. If you are staying at Rui Tikida Garden hotel don't bother as the hotel is 5 x Jardin Majorelle.
Lovelllyy. Loved the garden. So colourful. Make sure you leave yourself enough time to enjoy the cafe though its so pretty!

Fantastic gardens of French artist & Yves St. Laurent. Fantastic gardens created by the French artist Louis Majorelle (1859- 1926) filled with birds, exotic plants, gold fish in pools, and vibrant coloured architectural pavillons. Once belonged to Yves St. Laurent who took care of them and createda ceramic museum inside (not always visitable) (check hours on entry).
beautiful and tranquil. A peaceful sanctuary from the hustle and bustle of the city and the tree lined paths keep you out of the sun for a quiet 1/2 hour visit. Really beautiful.
fabulous!. oasis of flowers and trees in a wonderful setting. cafe good berber museum as well. 50 euros for gardens and 25 for museeum

Cacti oasis! Peace, quiet and beauty.. The garden is smaller than we thought, but nevertheless well worth a visit. A true oasis in a very busy and loud city. Entrance was 50 dirhams (without the museum).The plants are so well cared-for, the stunning 'bleu majorelle' is everywhere, it's a feast for the eye. There is a huge selection of cacti. Not that I'm such a fan of cacti but they are quite impressive I must say!We didn't visit the museum as we ran out of time, will do next time. Inside there is a nice café to sit and have a smoothie or ice cream. Friendly service.Not medina prices but worth the money.Also, great little design shops around the garden. (Luna Sarah!)We actually walked all the way there from the medina and back, cause the temperatures were just perfect. It was a bit of an adventure, but really nice! But there are plenty of taxis or caleches to take there and back if you want.A must see, a true oasis!
Lovely garden. Dramatic, with well cared-for garden. Provided some useful ideas for our own garden. Also showed what could be achieved in a dry soil.
Beautiful. Well worth a visit stunning and tranquil . A lovely court yard cafe for drinks and food and loads of seating for a rest
Jardin Majorelle. Definitely worth the trip. An oasis in a busy city. The Berber museum is a must visit in the property as well.

Beautiful and tranquil. We visited the gardens in March and, although it was busy, it's well worth a view for the array of colours. Easy enough to navigate within an hour and entry is inexpensive. Look out for the bedouin museum and the cafe terrace. Although the memorial itself to Yves Saint Laurent is underwhelming, the gardens offer a diverse range of flora to view and a peaceful, calming atmosphere.
Brilliant. Well worth a visit and so unexpected as you walk through. Sit and have lunch in the outside cafe, extremely peaceful.
Jardin Majorells. called also Yves saint Laurent garden is located in the new area and it is an amazing gardendon't miss to visit the Berber Museum Awesome

A Peaceful Space in a Busy City.... Hidden amongst the dusty and busy roads of Marrakech is a little slice of paradise, the perfect escape from the bustling souks and kasbah. The Majorelle Gardens, also known as the YSL Gardens, is a colourful and cheerful space which manages to combine a sense of calm with pops of vibrant colour, a place for reflection yet also inspiration and a serenity amongst the hustle and bustle of this major Moroccan City. These botanical gardens are unique, especially in Marrakech where everything is so fast-paced and a little hectic at times, but they also combine nature and art and you can see why YSL chose to have his final resting place in this exquisite spot. There is an homage to the great designer with a collection of his works of art – fun, pop-art style posters with the central theme of love. Take your loved ones for a memorable stroll in this sublime space and absorb it’s essence and beauty as you take a deep breath and appreciate all the wonderful things in your life.

great. The Jardin Majorelle in Marrakech is one of the most visited sites in Morocco. It took French painter Jacques Majorelle (1886-1962) forty years of passion and dedication to create this enchanting place in the heart of the “Ochre City”.

Cool Berber Museum. Gardens not so impressive but the small Berber museum is definitely worth it. It had a small but wonderful exhibit with various items from daily tribal life including a fabulous dispaly of Berber jewelry. The ceiling in the museum is worth the small entrance price alone.
Beautiful. Well worth a visit! The gardens are just heavenly and it's hard to drag yourself away when you need to move on! Quite crowded but not a problem as there's no rush to get around.

Oase of rest. An oase of rest within a busy part of Marrakech. Great atmosphere and beautifull vegetation. In comparasion of other visits in Marrakech the entree fee was quit high, 2x more than the Baia palace for example, but worthed.
Lovely gardens. Lovely gardens - very calm. The cacti were very impressive and plenty of photo opportunities. Worth a visit.
Worth a visit. Easy to reach from the old city. It was a great contrast to the souk and dirty street. Cool, relaxing, and downright enjoyable. Highly recommended.
Heavenly. This place is a must for keen photographers. There are so many photo ops around every corner and everything is so serene and colourful.The plant/cacti shapes are spectacular.

Bit steep but lovely. A relaxing mirage-like experience, but for Marrakech the entrance price is pretty steep! Walked from the Djemaa with the help of our lonely planet map, but this was nothing special. Couldn't afford the tea or coffee.

Don't miss the museum. We arrived early to enjoy the visit before it became busy. The garden is well manicured and the design is interesting. We were advised to visit the small museum and were glad we did. The information provided was was very helpful and we came away with greater understanding of the Berber culture

Garden of beauty. Amazing variety of plants in the most beautiful surroundings that takes your breath away. With connections to Yves St Laurent ther is a small boutique and art gallery with a berber museum. There is also a lovely little courtyard cafe where you can relax with a meal or drink, Incredible!
Beautiful. Busy but beautiful gardens with some lovely features. Our taxi driver got us straight in so we did not have to join the very long queue. Loved the cacti - so big.
Very nice. Liked it, but expected more... there are many gardens in Toronto and Niagara that are spectacular, so in comparison to these, the Jardin Majorelle fell a little short.
Absolutely beautiful. Peaceful, tranquil, beautiful, lovely little cafe (expensive!), memorial to Yves St Laurent, interesting history.

Garden Shade and Museum. For your respite from the souks take a stroll in this garden. It is located a little from the center but it is walkable. I would suggest to have a map or GPS to track your position as the streets are not grid type.The garden is usually full of tourists. It is a major spot in the tourist stops. It does not make this any less of a stop but you should come prepared that the garden will be full of people. The garden has a nice collection of plants and a walkways on wood. The trees provide a nice cool shade. The museum has some art from local artists and some history of the local people. There is a small shop also attached to the museum. The cafe is as stated overpriced. But if you need a place for a quick drink this will do.The whole event should take no more than 1 hour.

Not bad, gardens smaller than thought, cafe a rip off. Cost us 50 dirhams for a grand taxi from the Jemaa El Fna for 4 of us. Was advised by our riad that you should pay no more than 20 dirhams for a petit taxi there from the square. The gardens are quite small and the cafe a rip off but never the less a very pretty place and a welcome break from the carzyness of Marrakech old town

Soothing. These incredibly beautiful and well kept gardens are a great respite from Marrakech's madness. The Klein blue vases and the vast array of plants from all over the world will transport you to an oasis of calmness. Just wander around and relax. But make sure you alo visit the Berber museum. It's brand new and really well made.
Quiet and beautiful. A stunning sanctuary just outside Marrakesh for £2 per person,we walked there and got a 25 dhr taxi back.so nicely laid out and colourful, one of my favorite places
colour and style. beautiful, must visit. Early in cool better and more peaceful.just love the plants, cacti especially, and that BLUE and coloured pots...very special.

JUST OK. This place is a little bit of an escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. The gardens are quite pretty but I def. think its a bit hyped up. It was quite croded for small gardens, would not vist again although quite pretty , but nothing spectacular

beautiful oasis in dirty city of marrakech. loved everything about it. neat, bright, eclectic mix of trees and shrubs from around the world. bright blue painted low walls and pagoda set off the green of the plants superbly. berber museum worth paying extra for as it is well laid out, informative and modern
garden. it is a must in marrakesch, the graden of the painter majorelle, later of ysl. phantastic and colorful combination of bauhaus style house and hundreds of plants...

Poor and full of tourists. We thought this would be a tranquil spot in a busy city, in fact it was body to body tourists moving along at a snails pace too many people in at one time couldnt even really stop to take pictures as people wanted to move along. dissaponting

Art Deco feast for the eyes. This is a really beautiful place. I have never seen so many different cacti - some of which look incredible lethal! The building itself is superb and the jewellery section of the Berber museum is very inventively done with myriads of tiny lights which make you feel as through you have walked through a mirror into a different world.Nice café - though the fruit juice is hugely expensive.The shop is a bit snooty and over priced. Also I would recommend going early in the morning because it gets really busy.

Beautiful & Peaceful Garden. This is Paradise in Marrakech....beauty is everywhere! Strolling through the garden give you a calm-serene feeling. All the plants and flowers are amazing. Do not miss this....

Small but nice. Very beautiful gardens, but smaller than expected and quite full of tourists. Cafe good, but pricey. Queue culture (or lack of same) at entrance annoying - apparently guides with groups of tourists (even smaller groups such as families) are allowed to cut queues to get tickets..

Beauty and tranquillity. Other reviewers have said that it is a small garden which is true but the intensity of colour, the design, the views, the water features and the choice of planting makes this a most special visit. Worth the time and effort to walk from the medina. Take a camera and walk slowly around several times!

Worth a visit. Try and arrive early to avoid queues at entry (it was 12.00 when we arrived)
The cafe is worth a visit
Gardens immaculate but quite small, however some amazing plants

Wonderful oasis amid the chaos of Marrakech.. Wonderful little oasis which oozes such positive energy that it helps calm one's nerves & mind. A great escape spot to come to in the afternoon to chill & restore your energy, especially after you've been negotiating with anyone and everyone on the streets in Marrakech. Highly recommend this place to anyone who fancies a quiet moment from the hustle bustle of Marrakech.

Lovely gardens. Small and compact but lovely and very well kept. We arrived around 10.30 am - at the same time as a couple of coach loads so for a while it was pretty busy. Would recommend a trip to the gardens.
A paintbox of colour. Fantastic gardens and experience not to be missed. Cafe sells excellent food in a pretty courtyard setting.
Beautiful colours. Lovely garden in May. Very green plus colourful pots and buildings etc, pools etc. A delight for the senses.
Very beautiful. The gardens are a must visit. Take your time to admire the plants and delightfully colored corners. Especially beautiful are the koi ponds and the cactus areas.

Great, but far and expensive. If you have a driver and guide for the day, this is a great stop, but if you have to hire a taxi and then pay the 25 dirham entrance as a budget traveler, and if you don't have a particular interest in the Berber culture or Yves Saint Laurent, then you might be disappointed, though it is beautiful. If you are going on your own, make an outing of it, and take a book.
Nice but..... Small but nice, very tourist orientated. Gardens are pretty but pricey given how long it takes to wander through.

A green sanctuary. Nothing to dislike; small gardens with a good variety of plants. All very well maintained to a high standard, a large team of gardeners and maintenance. Bookshop, cafe and toilets. A pleasant hour.
nice, many tourists. The Jardin is nice, but smaller than I thought, with many tourists going through. Worth the visit, but do not expect too much.

My favorite place in Marrakech. I loved the Jardin Majorelle. What a spectacularly beautiful place and in spite of the crowds my visit was rather peaceful and serene. If you're visiting Marrakech, this place is a "must see" in my opinion. The garden is laid out very well with both tropical plants and cacti from all over the world. The electric cobalt blue paint they used throughout the garden was magical.

exquisite. Great place. Interesting history owned by yves saint laurent and his late partner. Interesting how they over look his their sexuality. We went at 11:00 am very crowded lots of tour buses. Our guide explained that if we had time it would have been better to come in the afternoon less people. This is a must see.

Amazing!. If you visit Marrakech you cannot miss the Jardin Majorelle. The garden is lovely and vibrant - full of flowers and color! I advise you to arrive very early if you want to enjoy the gardens before the busloads of tourists arrive - I went at 9.15 am and had about 15 minutes before it was flooded with people. Get there when the doors open for a peaceful experience and a chance to get some great photos!
Beautiful!. Lovely gardens- no need to do them on a tour: much cheaper just to walk from town or get a caleche. A good place to get your breath back after the souks!

Oasis.. A beautiful and peaceful garden with quite a history. The profusion of plants and the colour are magnificent. We had coffee before we walked around in a pleasant outdoor restaurant.We were shielded from the sun by the tall trees and plants. The cactus plants were very dramatic.

Colourful twist on Moroccan design. Very beautiful, stunning, interesting and incredibly calming. I had no idea there were so many varieties of cacti and palm trees from around the world. I particularly loved the use of bright colours in the garden. It was very inspirational.

Deeply touristic - strangely.... We hated the number of people - strangely given the fairly limited amount to see - and the poor labelling. On reflection, an audio guide might have improved matters, but one shouldn't need it. Stay away, we thought.

Gorgeous oasis. Beautiful and fascinating garden which was not only visually pleasing but incredibly peaceful despite its position within a crazy, busy and noisy city. The gardens are not particularly large but the array of plants is incredible and the impeccable presentation is to be congratulated.efinitely worth a visit especially if you enjoy gardens
An oasis in Marrakech. This garden is associated with Yves St. Laurent and has a memorial to him in its midst. Beautiful variety of plants and trees, and a lily pond..
Calming and beautiful. A must for those who love gardens and also for those who don't. The colours and the plant display will amaze.

Beautiful Rest-Bite, Recommended!. I visited Jardin Majorelle with my partner and found it to be wonderful..Yes, it is not very big and it certainly doesn't take long to walk around but for 50 dirhams (£4) it is very good value and very beautiful. We walked around once, taking in the picturesque views of the wildlife and plants within the garden before having some lunch in their outdoor cafe. The food was very good value again, considering it is the only place you can eat in there we expected it to be a little expensive but it wasn't. We then walked around for a second time to get some photographs. Previous reviews I have read said it got very busy but we didn't find it too bad when we went, it got busier the longer we stayed there but then again the weather was getting slightly better! It's just very relaxing and we got some great photos of the turtles swimming in the large pond and of the different plants etc

Pretty and affordable but not overly interesting. I visited le Jardin Majorelle with my mother who absolutely loved it. She did say "it's an age thing". To me, it was just a garden with a lot of tourists in it and not really worth the effort to go there. My mother couldn't disagree with me more though. She found it pretty and relaxing and advised anyone we met on holiday that too must visit.
Overrun by Tourists - Go Early or Late!. There were too many of us there! <Grin> A beautiful garden that could be so much more enjoyable with less people. Do relax and take it in.
Stunning peaceful gardens. The colours and the birdsong with the tranquil water made this a real haven in the city. One of the most memorable gardens i have ever seen

Don't miss the Berber Museum. This cool, green garden of striking bamboo, cacti and ferns is a lovely escape from the heat, Excellent paths ensure easy flat walking throughout. Although very busy it maintained its serene atmosphere. A highlight was the Berber Museum, the additional 25 dirham entrance fee is excellent value.

Overrated. Not much to see. Expected bigger area and more coloured plants, but only the pots were in different colours (than cactus/palm tree green). Entrance 50dhm overcharged, 20 is reasonable for what you see inside. Not a must see in my opinion
Not really worth. Scale is very small and not really worth a visit. Much over hyped and talked about. Some collections like cactus and choice of colours are nice. But overall not really worth

A quiet oasis with many visitors. Beautiful garden kept in immaculate condition. We were fortunate to arrive there just after opening time, before the rush commenced.You will be disappointed if you expect these gardens to be massive like some of the botanic gardens in other places.
a very special place. This is a lovely garden but the museum must not be missed. It is spell binding and one the best things in Marrakesh.

Just amazing. The colours of the buildings and pots are so vibrant,and the gardens were manicured within an inch of their lives. It was such a pleasant way to spend a few hours. The shop was a bit expensive but the cafe with its automated sprays of water was a welcome retreat
fantastic cactus garden. loved the yves saint laurent garden full of huge cacti. Amazing time watching the little turtles swimming in large lake and popping up their heads to look for food.
stunning. great bookshop as well restaurant a bit pricey even though it was tasty food. would recommend this garden.

Tranquil and beautiful. Away from the hustle of the main city, a visit to the house and gardens of Yves Saint Laurent is a must. Tranquil, shaded gardens where you can sit back and take in beautiful srroundings and vibrant coloured buildings.

Exquisite, Tranquil Gardens with Excellent Museum and Cafe. These stunning gardens full of birds, cobalt-blue features, a beautiful lily-covered pond with turtles and frogs, pools, and a monument to Yves St Laurent is not to be missed. The excellent museum is a gem, full of historical items chartering the history of the Berbers. The outdoor cafe within the shade of trees and plants is a wonderful place to relax and drink mint tea after your trip. Definitely worth a visit.
very peaceful. go into the berber museum it is really good. Lots of info and fabulous costumes also yves san Laurent museum with his art work

Too busy. This would have been lovely if you could be there alone (!) or if they limited entry numbers but as it was, the crowds spoilt the peace and we were forever tripping over people taking photographs!

Ok. Ok. It's definitely a quieter place in Marrakech, but still with a crowd of tourists. Expensive if you compare to other touristic attractions in Marrakech. The garden is nice, but nothing different, don't go expecting something like monet's garden or exquisitely unique. Other weak points are, if you are staying in the Medina, it's far (specially if it's hot).If you don't see gardens that often maybe you want to go. I didn't regret it. As i said, was ok.

Green Yves. Lush park of cacti and other tropical/desert plants. Inundated with tourists, probably mostly due to it bing owned by Yves Saint Laurent. Gift shop, tiny Love gallery, cafe. Worth leaving the Medina for? No.

Colourful and interesting garden. One of the main attractions in Marrakech, and rightly so. The garden is delightful, and the colours work very well and are a contrast to the plants (mostly Cacti).We were there in what I imagine is not peak season (April), but it was very busy. The museum costs extra but is worth it - interesting and informative - not about the gardens so much, but about the local area and people.The garden is very well managed and maintained and has a great collection of cacti, and the water features are well laid out.Needless to say, there is Majorelle Blue everywhere, and it looks wonderful.Don't miss it if you're in Marrakech, it makes a change from the palaces and Madrassa etc.

Peaceful and cool. A little pool of European chic in the joyful mayhem of Marrakech. Real toilets and calm. Not as big as thought would be. Visited as part of half day tour - only 60-90 minutes but that was about enough. Would need longer if see the (small) museum or use the café.
Jardin Majorelle. Not to be missed. Stunning gardens with the most intense colors! I can understand how Yves Saint Laurent was inspired by its beauty.

Oasis of serenity. Away from the maddening crowd! This is a much needed area of relaxation within a frenetic city. We spent a lovely time here and saw many locals sitting reading their books within these gardens. The museum within the gardens is really interesting showing artefacts, costumes and jewellery of the various Berber people. YSL memorial area is beautiful.

beautiful. Tucked behind a wall you will discover an oasis of magic, colour and calm. The vibrancy of the blue architecture and the sculptural planting is beautiful. The water lilly pond looks like it is unreal it is so perfect. I loved the tranquility of the garden and found myself taking so many photos as it was stunning. I am sure many people who have gardens will be inspired by the design and planting at Jardin Majorelle. The garden is a work of art :)

Beautiful. These gardens are an absolute MUST go and see! really beautiful and tranquil. if you like art then you will love this place, its also got a Yves Saint Laurent museum of his works! and to top it off such a quant little cafe hidden beneath an arch and under ivy and trees looks truly magical- overpriced tho which is a shame!

Not sure what the fuss is about. Utter waste of time and I am not sure why anyone would spend 5 euros to enter a garden which has nothing unique to offer. In a city steeped in history you are much better off in exploring some old monuments rather than paying to enter a place which really is nothing more than a collection of plants from around the world
nice berber museum. too many tourists which creates crowdy bottlenecks / very nice museum / the garden is rich and nice /
beautiful oasis. A gorgeous spot with beautiful plantings, garden containers filled with greenery and color. A great cafe and shop on the premises.

Majorelle visit. A beautiful tropical feel to this garden, which is like an oasis in the middle of the town, but you do need to allow an hour to appreciate it. We found half an hour was not enough, as that was all the time allowed by the tour operator.

yves garden. although the gardens are stunning to look at with bamboo reaching 30ft high and every shaped cactus imaginable,it really doesnt take long to go around even when we stopped to admire the art gallery and library,we were done in little over 20 minutes including stopping by yves saint laurents grave.we went as part of a tour but even then there is a museum within the gardens that you have to pay extra to enter.overall the gardens really are worth a look but dont expect to find hours worth of sights,its not as big as expected.
Beautiful but busy. Beautiful gardens - but not large. We went late morning and very very busy. Would recommend going very early or late in the day. Small museum was interesting.
Worth a visit. Very nice place to spend some time & take some pics. But it was very busy when we were there, mid - late afternoon.

Gorgeous. What a haven of peace and tranquility in this busy and chaotic city! Even with lots of tourists it seemed quiet and serene. Beautiful collection of cacti, pleasant walkways a lovely cafe and a charming, though pricey, boutique. Not to be missed and very cheap and 25 Dh.

Nice but overrated. Fairly expensive entrance fee (50 dh) for a small bamboo garden.
You are not allowed to visit the house of Yves Saint Laurent
Lovely. Well worth a visit. Reasonable entrance fee. Beautiful and peaceful. Plenty of places to sit and reflect and great photo opportunities. Expensive gift shop..
Beautiful oasis. We enjoyed the peaceful tranquillity of the garden. The perfect antidote to the madness of Marrakech.

beautiful, cool and calm. I loved the gardens, tropical and lovely. Can get crowded and it was a little smaller than I expected. The cafe was very expensive and no picnics allowed so make sure you bring a bottle of water before getting there and eat before arriving if you are on a budget. the shops in this area are around double the price as the medina area for everything included water.

Small but very beautifully formed. Marrakech doesn't have too many 'must see' sights but assuming you like gardens, this is one of them. It's also worth getting a ticket for the adjoining museum. Together they take about an hour to have a look around and we got some lovely photos of the gardens
peaceful. lovely gardens not far from hustle and bustle, nice cafe with different seating areas. Best first thing though mostly in shade. Taxi cost 50 Dhm back into marrakesh

Yves garden. I really liked the cactus collection and the garden should have been tranquil but unfortunately it's too popular. I wasn't particularly taken with the museum although I'm not into jewelery.

Worth a look. This house designed by Yves St Laurent is well worth a look, but it is quite pricey for what you get. It's best to go mid-afternoon when it's super sunny to really be able to appreciate the contrast between the blues and yellows.

Beautiful Gardens. If formal gardens are your thing, this is a beautiful place to visit. The colours and planting are amazing and the staff are very hardworking, pots were being painted and leaves swept the whole time we were there. We took the horse drawn carriage from the main square and our driver took us on a lovely trip around the city lasting around 40 minutes, he even crossed us across the busy road when we arrived at the Gardens. Worth a visit if you like this sort of thing. The Berber Museum within is a separate cost, buy both at gate if you want to visit both. Toilets are clean, attendant (needed to be tipped as most places in Marrakech). We enjoyed a cup of tea in the cafe within the grounds, the misted water sprayed into the air helped to cool us in the midday sun.
cobalt blue. enough blue for a lifetime. lovely gardens. worth visiting. peaceful memorial to ysl. the shop had some lovely things - unfortuntely over my budget.

Inspirational. I have seen glimpses of the garden on numerous TV shows and also seen its influence on gardens at the Chelsea Flower Show (UK). There can be little doubt that the garden was an inspiration to the previous owner of my house. My garden all makes sense now. Well, as expected, this place is amazing. Beautiful colours, stunning planting and extremely well kept and presented. Some fabulous places to take some photos and also to stop to take a rest.Would love to go back and see it all again. I just know a second or third visit would give me the chance to see things I know i must have missed this time around. If gardens are your thing or if you want some down time from the souks this place is a must-see.

Beautiful, well worth a visit. We read all the reviews and took on the advice and arrived early.We arrived at 8.30am and there was only us and one other couple in the gardens at that point allowing us great photo opportunities without crowds in every shot!The gardens were absolutely beautiful, i thought i would be a little bored as I'm not that much into gardens but they were so different from anything else i have ever seen that i was in awe of them. It is only a small place and cost 50DH to enter with an additional 25DH to visit the berber museum once inside which was certainly worth a visit.The museum was really interesting BUT all the signs were in French and arabic, by the time the place started to fill up there was many english around so it was a little disappointing they could not have translated some of the information into english too, still i enjoyed looking at all the magnificent berber clothing and jewellery.Watch out for the taxi drivers when you leave that want to take you to see other places like spice markets or carpet shops, we had to be firm and insist they take us where we wanted to go or we would not pay
Buy the ticket to the Berber Museum.. Pretty place. Not overwhelming but it's worth it for the visit to the Berber museum. It's worth a visit if you're in Marrakech.
gem of a garden. beautiful kept garden just outside the city with a wonderful array of plants collected from around the world. Nice shady place to spend a couple of hours

An outstanding Oasis !!!. A beautiful place to visit that extends the incredible experience of visiting Marrakech. The colours and selected plants gathered from all around the world (including from New Zealand!!) was amazing and presented so artistically appealing. well worth the visit!!! It was also a refreshing haven from the incredible heat out on the streets ( 53 degrees C)

Different!. We went here as we had just arrived and there was a gale blowing and thought this would be a good place to visit as it is a walled (sheltered) garden. Small but interesting particularly if you like Palms, Bamboo, cactii and succulent.as it has some magnificent specimens. The garden, owned by Yves St Laurent is landscaped with bright blue tiles, pottery, brickwork and sculptures giving it an 'arty' look, It won't take long to walk round unless like myself you are an exotic plant lover and might walk around it a couple of times possibly because being small it can get very crowded and you might miss things the first time!Café food looked expensive so we went to the one across the road which was more reasonable.
Well worth the visit even after a 2 hour walk!. Beautiful oasis if you have the time then definitely visit just be careful where you sit as there's a lot of bird perching in those trees!!!

So colourful!. We love the colours (mainly bright blue and yellow) of the pots, paths, etc. The gardens are very peaceful, although a bit crowded, and beautifully kept. The cacti were amazing! Definitely worth a visit.
AKA Berber Museum. Delightful gardens and Museum on History of the ancient Berbers which is definetly worthwhile small enough to enjoy with gardens in an afternoon or morning
Beautiful and tranquil. A great escape from the madness of the Medina. The garden is not huge so take your time walking around.
Lovely gardens. Lovely gardens, worth a visit, we went about 3pm and it wasn't too busy. Lots of massive Cactus plants

Stunning Jardin Marjorelle Bleu. A tiny oasis in the middle of the busy new part of Marrakech. Quiet, serene, and beautifully maintained. Originally owned by artist Jacques Marjorelle, later owned by Yves Sant Laurent and Pierre Berge, now passed with his memorial and ashes in the garden. Bamboo groves, cacti gardens, other exotics, a pleasant cafe, a bookstore and a lovely Berber museum all within it's premises. But, the best thing is the stunning, eye popping intense 'marjorelle' blue theme of the garden. Reminiscent of Berber cloaks, Moroccan tiles and Matisse paintings. A tiny fee to get in, a short bus #15 ride from Jemma el Fna square.

Hell is other people. Jardin Majorelle is a very popular destination in Marrakech, so much so that the sense of peace and sanctuary that its creator must have once achieved is long gone and replaced by a stream of slowly shuffling snapshotters.Entrance fee, including the Berber museum is modest at around £6. The garden pathway meanders through palm trees, exotic cactii and potted plants and the place teems with bird life. To be fair if you are patient it is possible to sit and feel a fleeting sense of what a haven it must have been for its owner.There are fountains and ponds with fish, benches under trees and very photogenic views at every turn.The museum is very interesting but sadly there is only one painting by Majorelle on show.However, if you must go try to be early to truly appreciate the beauty of the place,  .
Yves St Laurent's gargens. Go early but the most quiet and magical place. Not large but just special ... and the cactus' are pretty cool!

Cobalt Blue and green. We were given two very divergent views of these gardens before going, so decided to go and make up our own minds.They are stunning, certainly highly photogenic with species of desert plants from all continents that have desert-type weather. The cobalt blue house that is the museum stands as a fantastic backdrop to the foliage in the beds of very obviously planned arrangements. We didn't pay to enter the museum but from what we gathered, it was well worth it, with excellent displays of Berber costumes amongst other things.We thought the café was overpriced. But it is an oasis on a hot day. Avoid getting in a taxi outside the museum; walk to the main road a minute or two away and there are plenty there to flag down.

a sea of blue in a red city. The gardens are beautiful, but the best part for me was the respite from the endless terra cotta pink that surrounds you in this desert city. The pink becomes quite intense after a while and it is nice to be surrounded by this gorgeous cobalt blue for a few hours. The contrast of this blue with the stunning plantlife makes this a very popular spot for photo ops.

Beautiful and Tranquil oasis in Marrakech.... A visit to the private Marjorelle Gardens will certainly help take you away from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech which can be overwhelming. A Camera is essential if you do decide to visit. Make sure you take time to relax whilst in the garden and take in the colours of the flowers and the blue pottery and walls as they really do catch the eye. Not sure what the gardens are like at any other time of the year but springtime is probably best. Also visit the memorial to YSL, even though his ashes are in another private garden adjacent to Marjorelle. In the gardens you'll also find a museum on Berber artefacts and life and there is also a gift shop and cafe available. Great way to chill out and relax for an hour or two.

It was pretty. I don't know that I would spend much time here, although it was pretty and interesting. Flora and Fauna are not my thing, but it was interesting to see all the different kinds of cactus.

Nice haven in a busy city. We went on foot from the old city (medina) and got a bit of a feel for what the new city is like. Garden is nice although a bit small and a bit pricey. A worthwhile side trip if you have a couple of hours to kill

Soothing spot. Lovely atmosphere in this very stylish garden. I was surprised YSL did not put his own stamp on the artist Majorelle's garden by adding some scented flowers somewhere! Cafe good but overpriced. Shop is missing a trick - no prints, no postcards, no cheaper smaller items.We bargained hard with the taxi drivers outside who had first quoted twice the price it had cost us to get there.
Don't miss it. Beautiful and calm, a brilliant way to spend a hot afternoon under the giant bamboos - the museum is well worth a look too

Worth a Visit. We visited this garden on our second full day in Marrakech and really enjoyed our time there. It is a little expensive compared to other attraction prices (50 dirhams to enter plus 25 dirhams if you want to visit the Berber Museum), but it is such a nice break from the dust, heat, hustle and bustle of the medina. There are a ton of different plants, ponds, and also turtles and fish to look at. There is also a nice cafe (again expensive compared to the food prices you can find in the medina) with very nice staff and good refreshments. I definitely recommend a visit to this garden to see a different side of Marrakech!

Very special. Yes, lots of tourists...not surprising as it is a very special place. The cafe is lovely and the food good, make time to stop there and enjoy it. We took a caleche from Djemma Al Fna, insisting on one way only. Don't let them pressure you into a return fare - there are lots and lots of taxis and caleches for your return waiting at the exit.
Pretty and Colorful. A nice break during a hot day in Marrakesh. Crowded, so go early. One of the best places to people watch that I can remember.

A Must. The Majorelle is a strange and beautiful garden, magical really. It is all bamboo and palms, little ponds and fountains, and quite corners for reflection. Fabulous gift shop with all kinds of Yves St. Laurent mementos.
beautiful garden. it is a nice place to see the nature. I found it a little bit expensive to see a garden. But it is ok!
A must see beautiful gardens. This tranquil gardens with the stunning Marjorelle blue named after the painter. Peace and stunningly arranged gardens. A must see, you will be amazed.

A Definate Must Do...... These gardens, a gift from Yves st Lauren are simply beautiful, so colourful and well laid out, a vast array of plants and cactus, coloured pots and pagoda's make it a very pleasant, relaxing break from the hustle and bustle of the souks, a nice place to unwind for a few hours, probably not if it is packed with people, but it wasnt to bad when we went which was late afternoon.
Lovely oasis in the city. Arrived early mornig and spent several hours wondering through the lovely gardens. Cafe served excellent fresh juices.
Beautiful !. We was here in May 2013.Was so beautiful and paceful ! It's a paradise place .Some day we'll return here.!

Worth a short visit. Lovely garden, well worth the trip to a shady oasis away from the busy souk. If you take a cab make sure you check with your hotel how much you should pay so you will be not be over charged.Some of it looks a bit tired and numers of visitors can make it very crowded.
gorgeous gardens. Lush garden escape jam packed with color, beauty and tranquility. Impressive variety of plants& flowers and outdoor vignettes. An intimate and lovely stroll for an hour or so.

WOW!!. What a beautiful place, we took a picnic and spent a fabulous couple of hours enjoying the tranquillity :)
It made a lovely contrast to the hustle and bustle of the city.
It was well worth the small entrance fee.

The Garden a surprise.. Marrakech was our last city to visit on a 15 day tour. We arrived at the garden towards the end of the day and it was deserted. We would have liked to have stayed longer but it was closing. It may be small but it packed a wallop with colors and varieties from all over the world. The saguaro cactus is limited to the Sonoran desert of the USA southwest but they had some. The use of the color, Moroccan blue, enhanced the overall design and the beauty of the blossoms.
An oasis. Make sure your camera battry is charged. A lovely little restaurant close to the entrance serving the best Tjeen. Forget the name but they also do Pizzas

Peace and tranquility. What a wonderful escape from the hustle and bustle of the busy medina. It is a true oasis in the middle of Marakech. The garden is beautifully maintained and definitely worth a visit!
garden trip. an oasis in the desert. Well worth a vist and good value for money. The colours are fantastic as are the variety of plants

Awesome. Loved the Bamboos...unusual types. Looked through Bill Willis's decorative flair for the discerning...what I wouldn't give to spend just one day in one of the homes that he made so exquisite!!
Peaceful oasis. We loved this. Go early or late to avoid crowds but in any case it is beautiful and good for the spirit.
Worth a visit. This Garden is an array of wonderful Plants and Colours. There is a small Cafe and a Museum a good way to while away an hour or two

Great visit. Get there early as it can get very busy when coaches arrive.
We travelled there by horse and cart was just amazing
Beautiful. Stunning and tranquil, a desert like oasis enlivened by the bright blue and yellow. Try lunch in the courtyard.

Not worth the price. They charge 50MAD for admission, and the garden is tiny. You probably able to finish a straight walking tour of the garden in 10 min? However, since people paid 50MAD for the entrance fee, they do tend to stayed longer than what they should have.

An Absolute Must. Located in the new city, this lovely garden will provide an hour or two of respite from the intensity of Marrakech. Take the time to visit the museum. It is small, but offers incredible insight into Berber life.

A little oasis.. If you want to see the gardens on your own and take pictures without crowds in them, go here at 8am! You will find that within 30mins the crowds start coming in. I went on the sunday afternoon first and the queue was halfway down the road. Also I missed a (very large) sign and after another 100 yards the common 'i will help you, police knows about us and we are approved' guide came out from a shelter. It is quite easy to find really as there is a big sign and there are loads of horse drawn carriages on the main road where you turn left. The garden itself is beautiful but not very large. I went around 3 times to take pictures and was out within the hour. There is a cafe there as well but as a mint tea was 5 dirham more than the entrance fee to the gardens, I decided to get that somewhere else. Definitely worth a visit and overall a great experience.

Pretty gardens. Very pretty gardens, nice to keep you entertained for an hour or so. There's also a lovely vegetarian juice and salad bar at the top of the road, which is a welcome treat after eating tagines for days on end

Make the effort to go!. I'm not sure why but I thought this was where Yves St. Laurent's Moroccan home. Turns out his was the enormous mansion next door, but he and his partner Pierre Berge bought the property and skillfully restored the amazing gardens of Jardin Majorelle. The incredible blue Moorish villa was built for the french painter Jacques Majorelle and is now an interesting museum with a delightful cafe attached. The gardens are a stunning mix of cacti, succulents, bougainvillea, bamboo, laurel, hibiscus, papyrus, water lilies and cypresses interspersed with enormous multi coloured pots, ponds, fountains and irrigation channels. If you have even the slightest interest in gardens then this is the one to see!

A breath of calm in crazy Marrakech. If you find yourself feeling a little overwhelmed by the medina, do yourself a favor and spend a peaceful morning wandering the beautiful, quiet Jardin Majorelle. I'm not particularly keen on gardens, but this one was very enjoyable and a lovely respite in our trip.
Tranquility!. Beautiful gardens, well maintained, peace and calm away from the madness of the city! A worthwhile experience, nice food in the restaraunt.
A little jewel. The garden is very well kept of course you have to pay for the entrance 5 dirham. Also the public gardens in Marrakech are very well kept. Lots of interesting plants.

Museum and garden. We were the first visitors of the day by accident, not planning. But the peace and beauty of the gardens were worth the effort. The Berber Museum was worth the trip by itself. The displays were informative and interestingly displayed. The experience is very different from other Marrakech attractions.

Designer garden. A peaceful haven in busy Marrakech. A feast to the eyes as the sun chases shadows, and lights up the colourful walls, pots, pergolas, doors, windows, zellige fountains.... Exotic plants abound so there is a feast for the senses all over the place. This is worthy of Yves St Laurent's reputation as a great designer, even if his "thing" was not gardens! Visiting is more expensive than other Marrakesh monuments, and it has become a little touristy. Can be too many people visiting at once so try for the "down" times.

Peaceful. This was not as big as I expected but it was still worth a visit. Very pretty gardens with big bold colours and cacti. You probably only need to put aside a couple of hours.It only costs a fiver to get in, and it's a nice change to the hustle and bustle of the souks. As it's outside of the town chances are you'll have to get a taxi back into the center. Beware the taxi rank right outside! Agree a price with the taxi driver before you get in and be sure not to get ripped off - we were quoted 50dirhams for a trip we know should cost only 20. Walk to the main road and hail a taxi there - be prepared to walk away or haggle if they quote silly prices.
A cool garden to escape the heat. Garden layout of palms and bamboo owned by Yves St Laurent. Interesting show of Berber jewellery, costume and photographs. Cafe a little on the expensive side.
An oasis in the city. Beautifully maintained gardens trusted to the city by Yves St Laurent. The place is so tranquil and relaxing after the hubbub of the city and well worth a visit
Nice gardens. Very clean and well kept a good variety of plants and a berber museum we had a lovely cup of tea in the garden cafe.
Worth a look. This is a historic and pretty but small garden in the new town section of Marrakech. It's worth around 45 minutes of your time, but it's pretty crowded with tour groups.
Worth a visit. Beautiful gardens and a nice break from the hectic markets. we also enjoyed a very nice avocado shake at the cafe, with the mist spray.

Nice garden, but no visit to Yves Saint Laurent house. An attractive Mediterranean / dessert garden, lots to look at, and relaxing. There is a courtyard cafe, gift shop, small art gallery, and a museum on local history. We had thought there was also access to the adjacent house of Yves Saint Laurent, but this is not the case. It is walkable from the city centre, but a taxi ride from the hotel district.
Stunning color. Beautiful cooling plants, vivid colors. A little oasis in the heat of the day. It can be crowded, but it is quite nice!

A place to relax from the city heat. Colorful, interesting, shady and not too big. It's as simple as it gets, well preserved and calm, it's a get away from all the noise of Marrakech, don't expect too much though and it maybe one of the most expensive entrances.

A beautiful oasis. A formal garden developed as a work of art by french painter Majorelle and then rescued after his death by Yves St Laurent. There are a vast variety of plants and cactii from all corners of the world and the pools and fountains, often populated with carp, frogs and terrapins, provide a lovely cooling place to rest. Tip 1: arrive early monring or late afternoon to enjoy the garden quietly without the tourist buses.Tip 2: Turn right out of the garden and stop at the 2nd cafe on the left for a delicious tagine and great service.
Hour of peace. Bit expensive but nice hour or so of peace and good walk, though Marrakech has plenty of nice gardens you can visit for free.
Great quiet escape from town. Beautiful gardens, the contrast of the cobalt blue and the plants is amazing. Great little retreat from the busy souks of Marrakech.

Not that impressed. We were told these garden were beautiful and a must to see. Coming from England, we were not that impressed. Mainly bamboo, cacti and palm trees. This place is a memorial to Ives st Laurent, who used the visit here. It does have a pretty pond with fish, turtles and frog swimming around and a ice little tea room. It is a quiet tranquil place away from the busy roads, but very busy with tourists. At around £8 entrance fee, it was OK, worth a look but not all that impressive.
Nice gardens, a bit pricey. It's quite calm away from the crowds, but thought it was a bit expensive at 200 dh for four. It makes a refreshing break from the busy square with all its hustlers though.
beautiful garden. beuatiful garden with amazing colors.You will feel refreshed and at peace after walking in the Medina :)many many cactus types, very ncie.

Most expensive and least interesting garden in Marrakech. This garden is about 250 square meters, and you can see it all in in a very leisurely, slow-moving 5 minute walk. There are a ton of people, so you're constantly sliding by overweight Westerners snapping photos, and admission is 5 euro/person, which is extremely expensive for Morocco. I would recommend other, larger gardens. If you do come here, though, there is a Western grocery store right around the corner that offers cheap cold beer and wine, though! Stop by this place and by some drinks to enjoy back at your hotel :) The grocery store reeks of horse urine, as there are many horse chariots parked outside, but the prices and selection make it worth the pain of the stench :)
Wow.. This was a beautiful garden and museum really worth a visit. They are well maintained, although many tourists you could still enjoy the amazing plants.
rehabbed and lovely. It is a gentle journey one should take, especially through the lovely Berber museum as well. Stay a while and go around the areas where everyone else isn't congregating

nice cacti garden. This garden is not a typical flower garden. It is a cacti garden with a variety of species - suitable for Marrakech climate. It is pleasant and quiet, a place to escape the harassment of shops and others. The cafe inside the garden is reasonably priced - a nice place to rest and enjoyed some local food.

Bamboo, cactus and blue paint. The vibrant blue of this house is a pleasant change from the uniform pink of Marrakech. The garden is small but interesting with its mixture of cacti, bamboo and more typical greenery. It is a French artist's house restored by Yves Saint-Laurent, and also house a museum of Berber culture with a collection of traditional outfits.If you are visiting you might enjoy a stop at the Kaowa cafe opposite and the 33 Rue Majorelle designer boutique

Pretty, I guess?. I think the estimated 1-2 hr time frame for this garden is a bit of a stretch. It's much smaller than I expected but a very pretty, serene setting in the otherwise controlled madness of Marrakech. I think if you happen to be in the area (it is a short cab ride from the Medina) or just want a change of pace - its great to check it out but I don't think it is worthy of considering a "primary" attraction. The shade does keep the area somewhat cooler which I am sure will only become more welcome as the city becomes sweltering come June/July. The cafe is expensive but appeared to be serving crepes being enjoyed by more than a few.Wouldn't make it a set stop but would fit it in somewhere in the itinerary. I would save it as a "tag along" attraction - maybe save it for a quick stop on the day of your flight out of Marrakech like our group did - a nice finish to the trip and something a little more relaxing than the streetfight mentality of the souks...

Worth a visit.. Enjoyed the greeneries of various bamboo and cacti. Be noteful at certain times in the afternoon, this garden closes. many tourists visit the garden. A souvenir shop is located at its entrance ticket booth for minor shopping.

Not worth the journey from medina. We visited this and a few of the free parks and the free ones were more interesting by far. If you have time on your hands and don't mind the 50d charge then might be worth it but I'd not make a special effort to see it.

Well worth a visit. A photographer's dream, especially if you go when the light is soft. The shop and museum didn't appeal. Very glad we went and I would suggest a visit to Marrakesh is not complete without a visit.

Quite Beautiful Gardens. Just north of the old town, this is well worth a visit even at 50 DH each. After the hussle and bussle of the main town it is an oasis of tranquility. Designed by Yves Saint Laurent it is a real touch of class.
Jardin Majorelle. the place is very peaceful and if you like gardens, this is one place you have to visit while in Marrakech

Relaxing few hours with plenty of shade and plants / architechure to look at. Some awesome plants / trees / ponds in the middle of Marrakech. Well worth spending a few hours here and only 50 dns to get in per adult. There is a pretty looking cafe inside but we didn't eat there. Nice to escape the hustle and bustle of Marrakech for a bit of midday peace! Take your camera!

Beautiful serene gardens. This garden is well worth a visit. It is beautiful and serene- with amazing flowers. The café is nice ( didn't like the milk with dates and orange blossom - but the mint tea was good.

Overrated. Was a nice garden but doesn't seem any different to the many other bigger nicer gardens. The YSL link is probably the only attraction.
25MAD to enter.....if you are near it - it's worth a visit.

beautiful shady retreat. The gardens were lovely after a busy couple of days in The Medina.On this particular day it was very hot and the gardens are quite shady so it was ideal. A lot of people just chilled on the benches-we didn't eat in the restaurant as we found it to be a bit on the pricey side

Dont't miss it. A oasis in a very busi and noisy city.
Amazing Cacti and Bamboo!
Fantastic colors, especially the Yves Saint Laurent Indigo Blue

A calm oasis amongst the madness. Beautiful,peaceful and colourful. Try to arrive early in the morning prior to the tour buses. The courtyard cafe is lovely and shady, however quite expensive and the waiters are rude.

An oasis in the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. After a hectic first day in the souks, the Majorelle gardens were a haven of peace and quiet. Great interest for garderners and non-gardeners alike. Great fun for kids to explore without annoying fellow visitors. Very pleasent cafe.

Be sure to see the Berber Museum when you are at the jardin. The Jardin Majorelle is a nice oasis in hectic Marrakech. Be sure to visit the Berber Museum when you are there. The museum is a small treasure and not to be missed. Stunning displays, gorgeous photography, and very informative---a real highlight of our trip! Even though the service is slow, the restaurant at the Jardin Majorelle is a lovely spot for lunch.

Not very large but well maintained. We took a taxi from the old town for 50 Dirhams as it is about 2.5 miles from the old town. The taxi driver said it would only take 20 minutes to walk round but we spent a very relaxing 2 hours there and took alot of photographs. We also visited the museum within the grounds which was interesting as they had written guides in English unlike many other Marrakech attractions. It cost 60 Dirhams entry including the museum which was on the high side for Marrakech. The small gift shop was very expensive as was the cafe. We crossed the road outside the gardens and had and excellent lunch at a reasonable price. The day we vised was exceptionally hot so we really appreciated the shade but if you are expecting lots of colourful plants you may be disappointed. We had spare time to visit but I would not put it near the top of my list to visit.We walked back past all the caleche and taxi drivers and it took just over an hour,

Very beautiful but not over overwhelming. A very beautiful place & very well looked after but we couldn't see how you can spend longer than an hour there, it was very hot the day we visited (36 Deg's in April) so we enjoyed the peace & coolness of the place. It was very busy & quite crowded & not as big as we expected however it was somewhere we have now ticked off the to do box.

Gorgeous. A must see for anyone interested in art, gardens, or beauty! Indescribably gorgeous. Highly recommend the Berber Museum, which has a wonderful collection of jewelry, artifacts, and costumes.
Tranquil Gardens. Definitely worth a visit to these lovely gardens, with cafe, museum and little shops on site. A bit of tranquillity away from the hustle and bustle of Marrakesh!

Beautiful gardens. We came to Jardin Majorelle on our third day in Marrakech and it was a beautiful place to visit. We wandered the gardens peacefully and stopped in the cafe for a much needed cold drink and some lovely ice-cream. A must see for anyone visiting Marrakech.

Charming gardens, but not excellent. Place is very charming, you may stay there at least 2-3 hours, if is not so hot. Better to visit between October - April, in off season, because in summer months it may be not pleasant. It is the best garden in Marrakesh, full of colours, carefully designed and maintained, plent of birds, etc. The sky has a wonderful blue colours, perfeclty matching with Majorelle garden's colour.

Relaxing place!. Quite far from the city centre (about 1 hour walking).If you want to find a beautiful garden to relax after a busy day (good idea if you know about people and traffic in the city centre)....this is your place...beautiful colours...and relaxing atmosphere!

Nice place to while away a couple of hours. I like the fact it was beautiful and peaceful but found it was quite crowded. It also wasnt as big as i expected. Wheelchair facilities were good though. Children and OAPs get free entry.

Small paradise in a noisy city ;-) . We start our day from the Jardin. A very peaceful and beautiful garden with a lot of big cactus that will impress you ! Must have a mint tea, coffee or lunch in the coffee near to exit. Beautiful yard and nice staff.
disappointed. don't bother going to this garden,, a disappointing place, dirty water, no flowers, very busy.. we went on a sunday when it seemed the whole of Marrakech were there too...
Sublime beauty. This is so worth going to and will stay with you long after. The museum here is also wonderful and should not be missed. Would go again.
Wonderful!. Amazing garden with spendid plants and vibrant colours! Unfortuantely relatively far from the other main attractions but definitely worth the hassle.

YSL memoir . The garden was immaculate and a great insight into part of Yves Saint Laurent's life as he bought the place & this is where he's ashes were scattered. Its a good escape from the maybem in the Medina. However it is expensive 50dihrams & the place is small but its wonderful place for photography enthusiasts
Garden. Neat looking place but not a must see. If you have the time and are around, then hit hit but there are better things to hit in the city.
Beautiful - Colourful. It does really worth a visit. Go early morning and take a meal or a tea in the country-ward restaurant. A really relaxing experience!

Bright, Beautiful Garden. This was an unusual and beautiful garden in Marrakech. We didn't stay long and the admission fee is a little high, but worth it. In the craziness of this city, it felt like an oasis of calm.

Lovely escape from the city. My husband and I really enjoyed the gardens. It was quite small but we didn't think the price was too much at all. We loved seeing all the weird and wonderful cactuses. We didn't go to the museum. We walked from the medina - it was hot but we didn't find it too far at all and it was easy to find. It was also easy to get a taxi on the way out when we were finished. Would definitely recommend.
Wow, Wow. Very intresting gardens, don't miss when you are in Marrakech. you can go to Majorel Gardens by "Calehc" horse or Take small tax from Your hotel or from The big suare jamaa lafna.

Amazing collection of plants. A quiet place filled with tranquility and beauty. The assortment of cacti was amazing. Do not miss out.And, inside there is a small cafe. We had not had any lunch and saw this serene Parisian style cafe so we stopped and then we sat and reviewed out photos and had some crepes. YUM

Inspiring. I found this place totally inspiring. A collaboration of creativity from the berber museum to majorelle and Yves Saint-Laurent, each contribution is fantastic and the gardens manage to retain a serene feel despite the hoardes of tourists descending on it. Well worth the entry fees.
Tranquil. Peaceful delightful gardens with fantastic cacti. Cafe charming with great coffee and mint tea. It was a real break from the bustle and noise of the souks.

Just Lovely. The Jardin Majorelle were approximately a 10 minute walk from our Riad in the Medina. However while on our way there a friendly man, claiming to be from our riad, advised us that the gardens where closed. We didn't recognise him so carried on walking and of course the gardens where open. We spent a very pleasant and hassle free couple of hours walking around these beautiful gardens and museum, make sure you take a camera to capture all the vibrant colours. We thought the cafe in the gardens was reasonably priced. When you come out of the gardens there is a row of nice shops you can browse and buy without haggling.

A fabulous garden. There is something very special about this garden. Even with crowds of tourists it retains an atmosphere of amazing tranquility and elegance, almost akin to a zen garden. The planting and maintenance are immaculate. The use of colour in the pots and hard landscaping seems at first somewhat eccentric and garish, but grows on you and ends up feeling quite in harmony with the unusual nature of the garden. The garden cafe is a delight, serving a wide range of delicious food. No alcohol. The Berber Museum is a must. It is by far the best small museum on Berber culture and artefacts in the city. Beautiful examples of the items presented, perfectly displayed and lit.It's a pity about the poor, smelly, tourist horse-carts outside the garden gate - not to mention the outrageous level of rip off taxis awaiting the unwary (if you walk to the main road and hail a taxi you will get a much better price).
A slice of peace in busy Morocco... Beautiful place. Well maintained, really lovely. A little out of the way but a safe nice walk from the Madina.

Very pretty oasis and check out the Berber museum too. Beautiful for an hour or two, and very walkable from the Old Medina (although make sure you have directions, as the way is not marked until you get close). Buy the combo ticket for the garden and the museum, which is small but a great introduction to the Berber culture. Skip the cafe however, which is overpriced.
Relaxing garden. This is a nice little place, good for taking photos in an otherwise busy noisy city, only £6 for two people and a nice Moroccan breakfast available inside for a good price.

Highlight of Marrakech. We went to the Jardin Majorelle as it is such an iconic place within Marrakech and was not disappointed. The gardens are a wonderful calm and beautiful oasis in a chaotic city. We wandered around the gardens and then has a lovely lunch in the cafe. It was not cheap but lovely food and drinks and worth the cost. Lovely way to spend a couple of hours in Marrakech.

Calm oasis in the middle of Marrakech. The Majorelle garden is in my opinion one of the highlights of Marrakech and should be on everyone's must-see list. The garden is situated in Marrakech's new town. There is an entry fee of 50 DRH which is totally worth paying it. The Majorelle garden is a mixture of a botanic garden and an Art project. It was founded by the French Artist Jacques Majorelle and was later bought by the famous Yves Saint-Laurent. The gardens are a bit of a calm oasis in the middle of the busy city. It is a place where you can reflect on all of the impressions you have made in crazy Marrakech. Dive deep into this small paradise and take in the spirit of this place. We definitely were able to relax for a while and enjoyed the beautiful nature. The strong colours (bright blue, orange and yellow flower pots) and exotic plants (and cactuses) made this trip very interesting for photography.

Amazing garden oasis with a museum and cafe. An oasis of sheltered calm full of unusual plants set around the blue villa of Majorelle the artist. Saved by Yves Saint Laurence the villa contains a superb collection of Barber artifacts which I believe makes it the best museum in Marrakech.
Amazing Oasis. Just simply has to be visited and experienced. It oozes style and is extremely tranquil. It's also a nice shade from the intense heat.

Beautiful garden!. Such a lovely space and well worth the visit to Gueliz . . . some very tempting boutique shops locally too as well as the best rug vendor in Marrakech a short walk away (Ben Rahal - Rue de la Liberte) and a lovely lunch spot - Grande Café de la Poste

A joy for eyes and mind. Those of you loving gardens and vegetation will enjoy the nice collection of tropical and desertic species from all over the world . Those of you with art in mind will feel like inside a drawing, with windy pathways among vegetation and colourful pots and buildings . Those of you looking for ancient cultures will be surprised by the small but beautifully arranged Berber museum. In one word: excellent, don't miss it if you are in Marrakech or round there

The most beautiful blue in a garden. We did visit the garden Majorelle and we did not expect too much of it. However when you are inside you will be asthonised by the beauty of the garden and the architecture of the house. Especially the blue color is very intense and in contrast with the green color of the garden.
