My advice: take some beautiful pictures of your love here, because you will find the most beautiful backgrounds here.
Well worth a visit. Stunning gardens and a great break from the madness of the medina. Be sure to explore the surrounding area as well, as there are some stunning stores.

Slice of paradise. But a tiny slice. The walk to this place showed us the poorer side of the city. And once you've got there (if you can find the entrance) its a real gem of a garden. Its a little on the small side, so dont get your hopes up. The entrance fee is relitvely steep for the city, and for what you get there. All in all it was a little dissapointing, as its supposed to be one of the cities major attractions. Dont get me wrong, its gorgeous. Just don't expect too much, it will only take up about 40mins of your day.

Stunning. Gorgeous gargens - a quiet oasis in the city. There are also some great shops in the block leading up to the gardens. Definitely worth a stop if you are looking for higher end, ceramics and art.
ok but not great. there are much nicer (and cheaper) gardens without the YSL gift shop - selection of plants was nice, tons of cactus

This is the garden to visit in Marrakech. These gardens are magnificent, if a little small. They are also very busy with dozens of tourists on the excursion trail. Having said that, its majesty and artistry makes up for it, and it really is well worth the visit. You could walk around in 15 minutes, but we were given 45 minutes, and that felt too short.
Beautiful and serene. Calm and tranquil setting, a nice break from the heat. Beautiful colours. We have been on our last trip too, worth visiting the shops on the same road too.

Beautiful gardens, worth a visit. A garden owned by YSL foundation, beautifully conserved and just a short walk (20 mins) from the centre of Marrakech. Maybe a little bit pricey the entrance (50 dirhams) however overall I believe it's worthy a visit while in Marrakech, to escape the chaos of Medina, an oasis of peace and green where finding a refuge for 1hr or more.

Respite from crazy Marrakech!. Beautiful gardens... Stunning colours and a lovely sense of relaxation about it.. That is despite the number of people there... How wonderful it must be when empty! Nice shop though a little expensive. We didn't make it to the museum as we had had a walking tour all morning and were somewhat exhausted! Worth a trip
An oasis. Yves St. Laurent was right to preserve this sanctuary in the middle of Marrakesh. The garden is heavenly, a true oasis.

Beautiful!. Lovely plants and museum although no photos allowed inside. Quite small so therefore felt that admission could have been cheaper. Cafes outside the garden are more expensive than the main city.

Worth a quick visit.. It is worth spending approx an hour here. There wasn't a huge amount of variety in terms of flowers / trees but it was very peaceful and was a nice contrast to the bustling squares and streets of Marrakech. Worth having some mint tea and a bite to eat in the cafe.
Must See - A beauty of a garden!. Beautiful garden - def a must see! we took so many beautiful pictures here, the museum was also worth to see and was very interesting.

Jardin Majorelle is a cultural Oasis in Marrakech. Marrakech is a wild and exciting city. However there is not that much to see or do other than shop. Morocco and it's tourist trade seem oblivious to the fact that this city is experience-lite when it comes to entertaining the culturally curious tourist and after visiting the Medina and souks it soon loses it's appeal. The Jardin Majorelle is a brief glimpse of what could be offered by a visit to Marrakech if the authorities appreciated how fortunate they are to be getting this number of visitors. The aesthetics mimic a Japanese garden and the shocking contrast with Yves Saint Laurents cobalt blue used on all the buildings makes it a visual feast. A visit would be a sublime experience if not for the shear number of visitors pushing and jostling in what is quite a small area. A botanical garden is always a beautiful diversion in a city and Marrakech's climate would make it a natural choice.Try to pick a time when the level of tourists visiting Marrakech is low; the jardin Majorelle could be the perfect place to spend a quiet afternoon reading a good book and enjoying the calming effect of water features and lush vegetation.

must-see the Berber museum. The gardens are beautiful, but I found it to be over-rated. It is a nice respite from walking around the souk though. But the Berber Museum, which you have to pay to get into, was amazing. I really learned a lot and the jewelry displays were amazing. It made the Majorelle Gardens worthwhile for me actually :)

Worth the visit. The gardens are very well maintained, the variety of cactusses is amazing. We arrived at closing time of the museum but thankfully were still allowed to visit the museum. It was fantastic! Not too big but the collection was so beautiful! The little shop was also nice to buy some souvenirs. Outside the gardens are a few shops that sell very nice clothing and houseware.
Good way to spend a few hours. Lovely gardens, very colourful and lots of opportunities for pictures! Would definitely recommended as a place to visit whilst in Marrakech.

Beautiful if a little too busy. Perfect on a sunny day, amazing colours, great shade, shame about all the fellow travellers.Cafe onsite was expensive by local standards, but very tasty and pretty location.

Great, but too many other people there.. A wonderful garden with clever use of painted surfaces to give a unity of design. However, it was really busy even at ten in the morning, making it difficult to take any decent photos. It would maybe be worth getting there as soon as it opens to avoid the crowds.
Bellisimo. a beautiful jardin, very nice plants, flowers, nice decoration, very peaceful, there is also a Yves Saint Laureant gallery

Small gem. A short visit to a cool, calm oasis - combined well with a Kaleche tour from near Koutoubia. It did not take long to walk round. We avoided the expensive (by Morrocan standards) cafe and having arrived by Kaleche returned by taxi to eat lunch overlooking the square. You have to haggle with the taxi drivers. We paid 40dh for the trip back.
Beautiful gardens. Go early before the crowds arrive however still possible to take photos without people in the shots. Very quiet and calm place.

elegant & tranquil oasis. This garden, designed by Majorelle and owned by Yves Saint Laurent, provides a wonderful contrast to the hurly burly of Marrakech - well worth spending an hour or two listening to the birdsong whilst admiring the stunning garden design.

A nice contrast to the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. Wandering around the gardens is a brilliant away to spend a morning, it is so calm and peaceful and much welcome as a contrast to the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. The gardens are quite small, but you can walk around as many times as you like and there are lots of cactuses and other plants to look at (it's all very well laid out). There is also a museum which you can look around and there is a cafe where you can stop off for a drink or something to eat (but this is very expensive compared to the prices that Marrkech has to offer). The entrance to just the gardens is 50 dirham, or it's 75 dirham for both the gardens and the museum.

Quite beautiful!. Jardin Majorelle can feel like a real tourist trap at first, with lots of visitors around. But when the crowds disappear (as fast as they appear) and you take your time to look at the richness of details of the gardens, with their stark colour contrasts, Jardin Majorelle becomes a beautiful oasis of colours and green monotones. The cafe' is very pleasant (although service is not the best) and the Yves Saint Laurent room at the back is exquisite. Definitely worth a visit!
Good but choose your time carefully.. Lovely well tended gardens with YSL connections however it is small and very popular so is unpleasantly crowded in the middle of the day. Go early.
Blissful and Beautiful. You must spend some time walking around the gardens, it feels like a million miles away from the madness of Marrakech.

Very pretty. This garden is a bit out from the Medina but it is a lovely place to go for a change from the rest of the scene. It is a overpriced and is not that big. However, it is very well kept. Most of the plants here are cacti.

A must in Marrakesh. The sense of calmness is palpable as soon as you enter the Jardin Majorelle. Outside there are drivers of caleches and taxis who hassle you but you leave all that behind once inside. Although this is a small garden there is a lot to see and learn if you are a keen gardener, especially about cactuses and palms. Everything Is laid out beautifully, as if the garden were a piece of art.On our visit, and contrary to all our guide books, the Islamic Museum is now a Berber Museum. This was very well curated and the quality of the items on display were of a very high standard.Lunch at the cafe is also a very calm affair with enough choices to suit most people, and there is a large selection of interesting drinks.This is a gem and should be on every visitor's 'to do' list in Marrakesh, especially if you done the souks and old palaces. The cost is 75 dirham for both the garden and museum, and is worth it.

Lovely. Gorgeous gardens, smaller than I expected but the vibrant colours and tranquility make it a great way to spend a relaxing hour or so. Taxis from outside can be expensive so make sure you know what you should expect to pay and be prepared to negotiate.

A painter's gardens. "Jardin Majorelle" is a "must" for all visitors to Marrakech - nt onyl has it a wonderful display of plants from all five continents of the world, arranged together to provide a livign work of art in addition to which there is the "Musee Berber" which gives a hint of life within the most ancient tribes of North Africa; don't miss either.

Overpriced and Underwhelming. I didn't consider myself a garden connoisseur but after seeing this place I guess I have higher standards. Maybe if you were coming from Siberia this place would be fantastic but I am coming from southern CA so we have this kind of thing (and more) everywhere. It was completely packed with tourists around 1pm for either go earlier or later than mid-day. Also there about 10 different types of plants on a relatively small plot of land so that's why my review is so low. If you like gardens maybe go to one of the big hotels and walk the grounds. Probably better experience and its FREE! ;)

Berber Museum was fascinating. The garden itself is OK. For me the highlight is the Berber Museum which was fascinating. The collection is very good, especially the jewellery room. Its 50 dirhams for entry to the museum and garden. A great spot for lunch is at the cafe called Kaowa across the road from the garden. Recommend the Oriental (Moroccan) burger.
Beauty in Nature. The garden was absolutely beautiful. The colors, the atmosphere, the peaceful pool - the entire experience was well worth it. I took so many wonderful pictures.
Jardin Marjorelle. Quiet beautiful garden containing the unexpected. Stunning colours amongst the greenery. Small turtles in the ponds and birds in the trees. Well worth a visit.

Gorgeous!. Beautiful gardens with an impressive collection of huge cacti and other plants. I recommend going first thing in the morning before it gets crowded. Well worth the trip. Even my 10 and 11 year old boys liked it!
Quiet Haven. Well tended, almost manicured flora. Expensive (DHS 50) entrance. Fairly tiny. Restauraunt very expensive.

Blue,yellow and green magic. Every corner had a vista,colour was stunning and the way it is designed is wonderful.I loved all of it.Even the cafe is pretty and a lovely place to sit.It is all a photo oportunity

Small but perfectly formed oasis of calm. This is a lovely little garden. As you walk round pools, bridges and vistas reveal themselves. And at the end there is a cafe giving you time to contemplate the garden.

beautiful!. The gardens are absolutely beautiful, and a lovely place to wander around. They are a little further away from the centre, and smaller than expected but definitely worth a visit. And the food at the cafe is wonderful too!

A riot of colour. Loved this experience. So unexpected and felt small and intimate and very personal. There was an interesting exhibition which was unexpected and educational. Nice gift shop with quality items, bit above the going rate but a nice atmosphere to shop in. Take plenty of time to stop and sit a while. Every turn there is a pretty view and a quiet spot to sit and rest from the usual noise and hustle and bustle of Marrakech.

Beautiful Gardens in the middle of madness!. This place is beautiful and you simply must go - totally stunning and well kept gardens. A really nice hour spent here, in the relaxed gardens. The cafe is worth a visit but very pricey compared to most cafes in the medina.

Very busy gardens. The gardens are worth a visit, but were very busy, so not easy to get round and see everything, as people were posing for photos everywhere...including on the actual planting area.Entrance cost was 50 dirhams, so not extortionate. Expect a bit of hassle on leaving, from the numerous taxi drivers, and the horse and carriage drivers, who line the road leading to/from the gardens.
Lovely Oasis in Marrakesh. Beautiful Gardens. A lovely place especially if you are interested in photography. Only drawback was the day we went which was a weekday was really crowded.
Jardin Majorelle. This Garden is spectacular even when it is crowded. If you can visit on a sunny day then I think you will appreciate the Majerelle Blue of the building better.

An oasis!. Hidden from the madness of Marrakech, this garden is absolutely beautiful. The colours and plants were a delight to see. The only disappointment was the monument to Yves Saint Laurent. An old broken pilar which looked as if it had been shipped in from Egypt but snapped on the way! Well worth a visit.

Small, inviting, great cafe, hit early am when no bus tourists. Beautiful garden hidden in the city. There is a fee to get in, and an additional fee for th Museum, but do pay the extra as ita well worth the educational experience. Bought by YSL, and there is a memorial there. Lovely garden paths with plants, mostly cacti from all over the world. Take an hour to tour, including the Berber Museum. Great photo ops abound. Very small, probably 500 x 500 meters. Would not take small kids who are noisy and like to run. There are escorts to keep things quiet and zen like, and most plants have needles.But be sure to hit the cafe for an early lucious lunch. The Kafta was excellent.The Botique has some interesting gifts, but pricey. Be sure to go when the buses aren't there. It was crowded when we arrived, but then a short rain chased everyone off. Check online for hours open, it varies and they close early as they are not lighted.

A lovely, calm break from a very tiring city. The majorelle gardens are simply lovely. they are a great break from the rest of Marrakesh, which it, though brilliant, extremely tiring. the park open early so probably come early to avoid crowds, which is not what the park deserves.The park has a wide variety of cacti, bamboo, and fish and terrapins, and is extremely nice for a calm walk.

I expected a lot better. We visited in April and I was not impressed. The garden are very small and I had expected a lot more beauty and harmony. The YSL-monument was not very impressive nor did it reflect the impact he had on the gardens, beauty, feminism.Interesting was the Berber museum, showing traditional Berber clothing and jewellery, musical instruments, history. That is worth a visit.My suggestion: 1. If you go, make sure you include the Berber museum in your ticket (I think it was an extra 25dh).2. Leaving the museum, there is a smoothie bar on the opposite side of the street. Delicious smoothies and well priced.

Lovely spot. After spending time in the Medina it was great to get out and see this newer spot with a different spin on the jardins of Marrakech. Amazing design, and in a more modern area with funky shops and high design.

Lovely garden and great little museum. This is a stunning small garden which is well worth a visit. Defintely check out the museum of Berber culture which is in the garden too. It's small but beautifully put together and informative. A great way to spend an hour or so. The cafe opposite the entrance to the gardens is very nice too and has a stylish, modern vibe.
Oasis of Green calm. Well designed gardens with calming effect. The gardens-plants, buildings, fountains- give a sense of harmony. Charming tea rooms,

Cactus and palm trees..... If you are into cactus, palm trees and similar plants, then you might like this place. Otherwise, don't bother. Like the rest of Marrakech, it was a huge disappointment! It just a small garden, with a variety of plants from various region around the world which will cost you DHS 50 per person and won't take more than 30 minutes to see everything!!

Stunning. I have visited many gardens in different locations, this one is very unique in its style. The brightly coloured pots and bold decoration add a special touch to a beautiful selection of flowers, trees, cactus, fish and tortoises! Highly recommend this Garden to visit. We only had 3 days in Marrakech and Im glad we chose this as one of our places to visit.

Something to remember. The garden is really unique with everything from giant bamboo to palms and cactus with ponds filled with lotus plants. The color throughout is called " Majorelle Blue" . We've never seen a blue like it anywhere.
Beautiful Gardens. The gardens are an oasis of calm in Marrakech. Especially good place if you enjoy succulents and cacti although there is much more. Also a very interesting small museum.

Don't bother. Really, do not bother going there. The staff at our Riad told us not to bother going and they were right. It has absolutely nothing to do with Marrakech or anything Moroccan at all. It's just a pretty average, pointless, dull collection of plants with tourists taking pictures of them. That's it. That is all there is to it.You shuffle along with all the people who've been bussed in or dropped off by a calesh driver fancying a break, you stand and wait as tourists take pictures of themselves in front of a cactus, then you shuffle along until the next photo opportunity (of a person in front of a cactus).Total waste of half an hour and 20 dhiram. Walk up the road and go into the medina and see something real instead.

Stunning. Every trip to Marrakech needs a detour to see this wonderful place, a peaceful garden that serves as a monument to Yves St Laurent who lived nearby and made improvements here. Beautiful plants from all around the world, and shade from tall bamboo and palm trees make this a nice break from the bustle of Marrakech and the medina.

Expensive, small & rude staff. This garden is very small. You're round it in 15 minutes and it's expensive to get in. It's also crawling with people, so there's no atmosphere. I don't understand how people describe it as peaceful when all you can hear is traffic from the main road outside. The worst thing was a member of staff who got very rude and aggressive with me after I took a photo of some plants and a path. There was a possibility he might be in the photo (from a big distance) and this seemed to upset him hugely. He stood over me manhandling my camera (and me) and kept shouting until I deleted the photo! Very strange and unacceptable behaviour in a public place packed with people taking photos! Do yourselves a favour, and give this place a miss.
Stunning Gardens. Great photo ops, lovely gardens and amazing exhibition about Berber tribe and costumes! Should be more places like this in the country!
Superb!!. A quiet oasis, a big contrast to the hectic city. There was an indescribable calm and peaceful atmosphere in the garden. I took lots of pictures!
Garden visit in Marrakech.. Very well maintained garden, very pretty flowers and plants. Not very large, easy to visit in an hour.

A beautiful oasis plus neat museum. The Jardins Majorelle are lovely, tranquil gardens where you can escape the fast pace of Marrakesh. The plants are lovely, the art is bright and fun, and the museum is really cool, especially the room with the costumes. We really loved it and so did everyone else we talked to.

Beautiful. Colors, contrasts, greenery makes this place a treat for eyes. A beautiful garden and a relaxing place where you can easily spend few hours. Enjoy the beauty, relax and the cafe in the garden serves good food as well.

Gorgeous garden, wild colors. Try to time visit to avoid crowds. Fantastic garden, flamboyant and imaginative use of strong colors and water features. Amazing cactus and succulents, very well-maintained, set off very effectively in raked gravel. Could have benefited from better plant identification. The tour buses arrived around 10 am and the place was jam-packed with people not too interested in gardening or Berber culture - too bad since they took up a lot of space. Perhaps best to visit first thing in the a.m. or later in the afternoon.The museum of Berber culture is well worth the extra admission - extremely well-presented, good audiovisuals, very good examples of their art and daily use tools, clothing, etc. Just enough to give a good feel for them, without overwhelming you with hundreds of similar examples.

Oasis. This is a must, amongst the traffic is this Oasis, colours and plants are beautiful. Although it does get busy so go early. It is amazing respite to the hectic traffic and street life.Sit by the memorial to Yves St Laurent and ponder your thoughts.
loved the colours. Especially loved the electric blue colour present all over the garden (pots, Berber museum walls etc)

Definitely worth a visit. Really peaceful, lovely palms and cactis and water features. Worth the money. Cafe is very expensive. Look out for the turtles and fish. Feels very lush and green with beautiful flowers.
Disappointment. We saw nice cactus and some flowers. The garden is fairly small with no major attraction. Disappointed for the time and high relative entry fee for a small memorial garden to Eve...
Wow. Most impressive Gardens . Stylish as it `s owner was .The Colours of the pots and building in the mids of the greens of the exotic garden phh a feast for your eyes ....

lots of bamboo. we visited the Jardin Majorelle on a sunny March afternoon. We decided to walk all the way there from our riad in the Kasbah area of Marrakesh, quite a trek and not all that pleasant all the way. As it was out of season the queues were not too long and we could see the garden with ease. I was a bit disappointed with the limited variety of plants and the size of the place that could be walked in half an hour max, my son took lots of photos so our tour took a bit longer than that.I would not recommend the visit in the height of tourist season or temperature.
Meh. It is an attractive garden but not that large and was very busy when we visited. Would have been a bit disappointing had we not paid the extra to visit the Berber museum.

very nice. nice little park, amazing colours, beautiful imported cactus and trees. IF you like photography, this park is great for some interesting images and angles. get there early in the am. we arrived at 10:30 and the park was already full with people and school groups. As was leaving around noon, there was a long line to get in. Do I need to see this park? Well, it is one of the main attractions of Marrakech, so for the small entrance fee, yes, tick it off your list. You won't be back so do it now, is how I think about it.
Very beautiful and unusual. Well worth a visit! Such a range of unusual plants and designs. Very good cafe. We were a group of 13 friends and they made room for us inside.
Not our cup of tea. I'm sure people love this place, but I have to say we were sorely disappointed. If you love plants and cacti, then you'll enjoy this, but we were in and out within 30 minutes.
Very peaceful. Lovely and peaceful - a nice change from the hustle and bustle of the medina! Definitely worth a visit!
An oasis of calm and beauty. Very beautiful gardens and also a fascinating museum. Get a taxi there or a horse and carriage. We tried to walk (from the medina) and its a bit of a trek!
Beautiful but overpriced. The garden and the architecture in it is lovely. The price (50 dirham) is however slightly too high for what it offers.
beautiful. very nice garden. we enjoyed the colors and all plants. it was very interesting for us and our kids. They liked the fish and turtels and trees and the colorful enormous pots.

Everything you would expect. Lovely gardens still bearing the stamp of YSL and prior owners. Immaculately kept and worth going twice at different times of the day to capture the differing qualities of light.In-house cafe was nice ... but at YSL prices ... as was the giftshop !
A must to visit in Marrakech. Lovely and exquisite gardens and most interesting museum. I love visiting the place and I go back every time I am in Marrakesh.
Okay. Very nice, very pleasant tranquil gardens but quite small. It only takes around 15 minutes to walk round. Food is very nice but very expensive for a cafe.
A must do. One of the highlights of our trip, wonderfully relaxing & cool gardens & very original. Also great cafe & interesting museum.
We expected more. Very small. would not recommend at all. the museum was ok, but the gardens weren't much. We were bummed we wasted time going.

Beautiful setting and 1st rate gallery. Beyond the beautiful garden the place is worth visiting for the Berber Museum alone - the items on display are well curated and you can see the YSL eye for excellence in the selection of items.
Must see in Marrakech. smaller than I've expected but absolutely brilliant and beautiful place. Make sure you take your camera with you. Nice rest from dirt, crowd and dust of old Medina.

Oasis in the madness!!. Beautiful, tranquil place right in the heart of all the chaos that is Marrakech. Not big but lovely to spend an hour there. Did not eat there, restaurant looked lovely but little expensive and lots of people sat with no food in front of them. instead we walked back towards town and had amazing fresh kebabs cooked on a charcoal grill in front of us, with rice, fries, salad and sauce and drink for £3 each!!

beautiful jardin majorelle. beautiful gardens well kept a lovely tranquil place to visit and relax with blue and yellow pots and walkways and water features.they also have a lovely courtyard cafe worth a visit.
Nice place to get away from the hustle bustle. Great place to visit but very popular with western touirists - can be a little crowded but still worth a visit.
a piece of tranquility in the hectic town. A tranquil garden, but very small. S brisk walk would get you around in 15 min. The Berber museum however is worth a visit
A haven of peace. When you are tired of the bussle of the Medina find peace in this tranquil garden that Yves St Lauren created. And the cafe food is excellent
Just Ok. If you need a little break from the hustle and bustle of the Medina.. This is the place. But short on time while in Marrakech, give it a pass

Peace and tranquillity amongst the mayhem!. We visited here with my Husband's parents on the last day of their holiday (we had an extra day), as it was recommended by our Riad. It is a great place if you want somewhere quiet and cool to wander for a while. It is not as some quidebooks let you believe worthy of more than an hour or 2 (that included lunch for us). The Cafe set in a courtyard around a small fountain is lovely and the food was simple but good. We opted for salads and club sandwiches and were not disappointed.

Beautiful garden, definitely worth a visit. Quite a small garden, but beautiful non the less and we spent a good hour there. It cost 50DH to get into the garden with an extra 25DH for entry into the Berber Museum. We were confused by the signage and thought it was 25DH for one bit or 50DH for the both, so we only saw the garden part. The museum is housed in the old studio of the painter who established the garden. It was later renovated by Yves St Laurent and there is a memorial to him there as well as a display of the annual 'Love' cards he sent to his friends and colleagues each Christmas.The cafe was a pretty, relaxed courtyard where we enjoyed an ice cream.The straw chips looked amazing! There are plenty of taxis outside, although we walked back to our hotel in the new town.
Beautiful pace,well worth a visit. Cafe good,would ave liked to buy a book of the garden but non available.colours of pots etc fantastic.
Underwhelming. After all the high reviews I xpect something more inspiring. Didn't rock my boat. Mildly creative annd distinctly average. stop kidding yourselves folks.
Enjoyable Morning. We enjoyed wandering around the garden, it was a relaxing morning, and we had a lovely smoothie in the cafe before we left. However the garden was a lot smaller than we imagined.

Jardin Majorelle. Lovely gardens, and well worth paying to go into the cleverly laid out Berber museum too. Nice cafe, a little bit more pricey than we had paid hithertoo.Fabulous art deco style house in the gardens.

Tipped off to go here on a bright sunny day!. We were advised to head here on our first day by Christophe at riad L'Harmattan as the weather was glorious. After wandering the gardens in awe and basking in the sun we grabbed a bite at the in house eatery. Funny, attentive, welcoming staff greeted us and helped us make our choices. All were good but the chicken lemon and olive tagine and the kofta tagine were top of my list.

Nice but not compelling.. The gardens were smaller than we had expected and the memorial very understated. There were some nice plants and water features, good photo opportunities and a courtyard cafe that although pricey, did serve good quality food and drinks. Overall it was only £6 each to get in which is inexpensive but to be honest we certainly wouldn't pay more than that. If you want a peaceful hour away from the Medina then this would do although we would suggest getting there early because it gets busy.
beautiful. So beautiful! i love taking photos and I got to take lots and lots of pictures here.. i couldn't believe how beautiful it all was! great experience visiting Jardin Majorelle

Blue, Bold and full of Birdsong!. If you're not familiar with the art works of Jaques Majorelle, look him up before you go. The garden is stunning, although it gets very crowded as it is smaller than I was expecting, but really lovely place to visit and within easy walking distance of the medina.

Quite a distance from the main square but worth the detour.. Bamboos, cacti, palms and bourgainvillia are interspersed with brightly painted pots, the signature blue painted pavilions and water features. It's bright, bold and brave and in this setting it works! The cafe provides a tranquil and cool oasis.

Beautiful!! Although rather small... Absolutely beautiful! Costs under a fiver to go in to see the gardens, plus another £2 to go into the museum. Wonderful garden but it is small and we were done in about 20 minutes!

An oasis of calm. A real retreat from a caotic city. A beautiful place to spend a few hours and recharge your batteries.
Some peace and quite and fresh air was also welcome.
A nice spot to visit. The gardens are very lovely but I don't think they are a must-see in Marrakech if you're only there for a short time.
Tranquil Gardens by Yves San Laurent. Alovely place to Visit, Also go to the Berber Museum in the Gardens , Fascinating with fabulous photographic images.

Worth the visit. One visit to Les Jardin Majorelle and it will be clear to you while Yves St. Laurent fell in love with Marrakech. Lush gardens and heavenly scents, it feels like a nice escape from the hustle and bustle of the medina. This spot is heavy with tourists, so it may be difficult to get good photos, but you will enjoy it nevertheless. In the gift shop, pick up one of the YSL Love postcards for 10 dhs.

Completely special place. Don't miss!. Once you enter the garden, you feel something very special. It is a completely different attraction, comparing to the rest you see in the interesting city of Marrakesh. Special, original, beautiful, don't miss the chance to visit this fantastic garden.

Spontaneous visit thoroughly enjoyed.. we visited on a beautiful sunny day and thoroughly enjoyed our walk around. The garden is so beautifully maintained, and is a very welcome peaceful retreat during your visit to Marrakesh. We visited the gardens as part of a two hour Caleche Tour; and spent approximately 35 minutes walking around. It is a very good place for keen photographers. I would recommend this venue to be included Into your itinerary when visiting the City, as it is a complete contrast to everything else you will see.

Antidote to the hustle. As we went in March when the weather was a touch changeable, we were advised to wait for a nice clear sky before going to Jardin Marjorelle and it made all the difference. The blue was a perfect backdrop for all the colours, which admittedly were mostly cactus green (could be a different story in summer), but wonderful nonetheless. I imagine in summer it’s nice and cool too. Look out for the terrapins by the pond.There is a very nice, if a bit expensive café in the garden which is a serene place for some icecream.
Haven of tranquillity. A lovely garden to chill and relax in away from the noise and heat of the city outside. Amazing plants and lots of benches to sit in the shade
Yeh, not bad.... The gardens are pretty, with some impressive specimens but small and were a little crowded when we visited. Worth a look but don't expect too much.

A beautiful Tranquil Place. The garden is the home of some really incredible succulents. Their are cactus here that are rare as well as beautiful. The garden is peaceful and beautifully maintained. Make sure to leave time for at least a 2 hour visit.
not for everybody. very pretty enjoyed the berber museum , reasonably priced but think you would have to really enjoy plants more than i do

Spring for the museum. Please keep in mind that my three star rating for this attraction probably stems mostly from the fact that I visited in March and it was raining. I imagine that in summer the gardens would be much more beautiful. That being said, I originally felt that the ticket for the museum was overpriced, but it turned out to be totally worth it.

Majorelle Blue to the Fore!. We liked everything about it! Wonderfully peaceful- once we'd found it! A long street to reach it. The plants mostly cacti, bamboo and palm trees in excellent order. Obvoiusly very well looked after. Cafe, handy but looked rather expensive compared to the rest of Marrakech so we didn't have coffee there. Tranquil!

Ideal for photographers. Very pricey for a Marrakech attraction, but worth the money - fascinating design and endless photography opportunities. The museum provides some good context and info about Berber culutre that doesn't seem to be available elsewhere

Haven. Went here on our first coach tour in decades. Every kind of cactus imagineable and the bamboo and trees give constant shade.One tip - if y0u are going on to Menara gardens (not worth it in our view) use toilet at Marjorelle as none at Menara!Go early in morning or late afternoon as quite small gardens and if lots of coach trips can be quite crowded.
a pleasant garden. Restful after a morning of sightseeing and souks. Lovely setting, Astonishing variety of plants. We wanted to stop for tea, but the prices looked a bit steep.

Good for a quick 30 min tour. My guide went to have a coffee while I went thru this garden. It was small but well organized and the gift shop had some very nice items to offer. It was very crowded when I went but I felt like I had enough time to see everything.

Simply stunning. Beautiful gardens combined with very few visitors and clear blue skies, made this visit very enjoyable. Not massive but if you enjoy cactus plants this is your place. I would imagine it would be unbearable with too many visitors so best get in early.
not much there - when you have to pay to get in?. it took max 15 mins to walk round the whole thing?....a few memorabilia from Yves St Laurent and very expensive gift shop !.....waste of money !

Beautiful gardens. A lovely place to visit in the sunshine. Yves Saint Laurent sure did have good taste. The colours, the plants, the walk ways. Fabulous photo opportuntiies. Well worth an hour or so of your time.
Must see. This is a must see and the Berber Museum is excellent - it's an easy walk from the Medina. Earlier the better as it can get pretty busy by 11am

Difficult to find. Worth a visit but at 50dh (£4) one of the most expensive places to visit considering how small it is.
It was also very hard to find but in future I would suggest negotiating a carriage as it is a fair way!

Jardin. While I found the jarding to be beautiful, it was not very exciting and if you do miss out on seeing it, u will have missed nothing. I liked the flora and all that but if you travel throughout Morocco as we did, you will see many examples of Moroccan trees and plants et cetera anyway. It was peaceful and beautiful but Morocco has many free parks where you can just sit and enjoy nature, the birds and flora. I would overall give this a miss unless you are short on time.
beautiful gardens. lovely gardens for a quiet stroll - loved the bright pots and hot weather planting. Worth a trip but perhaps not a "must-see" for non gardeners

Be warned: these colours may not sit too happily in a damp English garden.... Even if cacti aren't your thing, don't miss the chance to visit this gem of a garden in the New Town. Rescued from dereliction by the French fashion designer Yves St-Laurent, the vivid colours used throughout just 'work', even though they have no right to. Startlingly bright yellow pots and the omnipresent 'Majorelle blue' provide brilliant visual punctuation marks amongst a fabulous collection of cacti, succulents and countless other dry climate plants and trees. It does get very crowded, so try to visit early in the day before most of the tour groups arrive.

Quiet change of pace. If you've spent a couple of days in Marrakech, this garden is a short walk outside the Medina into the "new city", and worth the visit for only a few durham. Cactus from many parts of Mexico and Central and South American and exhibits of craft over the centuries.
A peaceful location in the heart of the city. Although smaller than I imagined, it is a haven in this city with colour and interesting plants. The Berber museum is well worth seeing.

PEACE. I was in desperate need to find a peaceful place after all the "harrassments" at the Souk and in the other touristic places. Colors are amazing and the exposition on the BERBER museum is extremely well done. Very interesting for those who adore jewellery and traditional clothes.

Really beautiful. This is one of the busiest tourist sites but in spite of that was extremely tranquil. The colours are beautiful at any time of year but it is primarily a cactus garden and quite different from anything seen outdoors at home!

Haven of peace! Beautifully curated. A beautiful place to let the mind wander after the hussle and bussle of the city. Very well curated garden where walkways and pots are constantly being painted to bring out the vibrant colors protected by the shade of the trees and bamboos. I can imagine that this is heaven in the summer when it gets really hot...to find some shade and just breath.
Very pretty. Really nice and relaxing. The cafe had gorgeous teas, and we loved wandering taking photos for an couple of hours.
Very nice place. I enjoyed very much this little piece of garden in marakech. It feels fresh and relaxing. I would recommand to anyone
pretty. Nice retreat from hustle and bustle but not entirely spectacular. Glad I went though. Nice cafe on site

Best gardens in Marrakech. Just a short walk outside the Medina walls, Jardin Majorelle, named for its founder, the late French painter – Jacques Majorelle, is the best gardens in Marrakech. We had a picnic lunch and explored grounds including the extensive cacti collection. Be sure to check out the Yves Saint Laurent poster artworks – he was ofcourse the saviour and then owner of the gardens from 1980 until his death in 2008 – his ashes are now scattered in the grounds and there is also a memorial. Entry 50 Dirhams and 25 Dirhams for the museum

pretty, small garden. this is a very pretty, however very small garden , i dont think its worth £5 admission as it only takes about twenty minutes to get around, some nice photo opportunities though... a very expensive gift shop and restaurant... pretty, but not good value and certainly not a day- trip!!

The little Berber museum a wonderful surprise. While we enjoyed the gardens the highlights were the very good Moroccan food in the garden cafe and the wonderfully curated collection of Berber artefacts in the little museum. Worth a visit.

Lovely peaceful gardens. Visited these gardens and they are gorgeous. Well worth a visit and I'm not passionate about gardening! There are cacti from all over the world with information regarding where they all come from. It is clean and tidy. Yves Saint Laurent's ashes are buried there as he loved the place so much. Well worth a visit.

A lovely garden - awesome cacti. A lovely garden to wander through. Allow about an hour to see the lovely gardens and soak up the atmosphere. Clean toilets, water on sale but no food. I did not really appreciate the beauty of Cacti before my visit here.
small but perfectly formed. this was a lovely peaceful garden full of beautiful blues. The cafe was very good too. Definately worth a visit - the only one that is in my opinion

Blue is the colour. Fabulous oasis of cacti and cobalt blue pots. Small and despite the crowds quite peaceful.
Cafe is a welcome stopping place.
The Berber museum is also worth seeing

Gorgeous garden. Small but beautiful garden. The greens of the palms and plants contrast with the vivid Majorelle blue buildings. Great variety of plants which are are well labelled. Less crowded in the early opening hours or late afternoon. The Berber museum is well worth seeing: small but has wonderful displays of Berber life and culture. Has a cafe, bookshop and Yves Saint Laurent shop.Taxis back to the centre of Marrakesh are organised by a steward. Agree the price before you get in a taxi: we were asked for 60 Dirhams by the first driver, but got another for 20 dirhams, which seems to be the standard (tourist) price for a taxi anywhere in the central area of Marrakesh.

Colourful. This garden is carefully laid out with excelleny=t use of colour on the pathways and plant pots. There are some lovely vistas which make for good photography Within this landscape there is a wonderful, small Berber Museum with beautiful photographs, and objects of Berber life from cooking pots to exquisite jewellery and clothing.
Great small garden and interesting Berber Museum. The colours and planting in the garden are delightful and the small, manageable Berber Museum made a great visit on a rather wet day.
Beautiful Garden. A lovely garden, not huge but very beautiful. Amazing cacti and palms and just lovely to sit and take in the uniqueness of this little oasis. Well worth a visit.
YSL knew how to live!. Don't know much about fashion but YSL certainly made a beautiful haven of peace and tranquility here! Interesting and delightful place to spend a couple of hours in . Charming
Very shady oasis. Lovely garden full of all sorts of cactii and similar trees, and blue museum and garden features, takes around 30mins to wander, but can linger longer

A photographer's paradise. Wow - colours and plants combine in these peaceful and beautiful gardens to provide wonderful vistas wherever you look. a must see if you have time in Marrakesh to give you a complete contrast from the frenetic, the scruffy and the chaotic. The cafe setting is lovely but the food quite ridiculously priced for what it is - but that's the only criticism.
Beautiful Garden. Beautiful smallish garden and good exhibition. Arrive early to beat the crowds. Pleasant cafe if a little expensive.
Amazing. Heaven on earth. So calm and peacful, worth a visit. Very small so it could get easily crowded, but definately worth to visit.

Wonderful experience. We only had 20 minutes in the gardens as we were on a tour. However we loved every second. They are such unusual gardens and a great photographic opportunity. There is so much to see and the contrasting colours are so eye catching. It's wonderful to find such a clean calm spit in this noisy, dirty city! Definitely worth a visit.

Peacefull!!!. Amazing cacti! Love all the blue, greens, yellow and orange. Lovely to sit on the benches and just chill! We went when it wasn't very busy! Not sure if it was busy we would have enjoyed so much.
always a pleasure. Go first thing in the morning or later in the afternoon to avoid the coach tours and experience the calm and serenity of this beautifull garden.
A peaceful place. A quiet oasis of calm in a busy city. The gardens were well kept and even though there weren't lots of flowers out it was made colourful by the use of painted ceramic pots.

Stunning gardens. The colours, the cactus collection, the pond with the little turtle family, the tranquility in the mad hustle and bustle that is Marrakech - an absolute must see... go around 10am before the crowds. Gorgeous cafe and the berber museum really fascinating too. Loads of taxis outside.

not worth it. The gardens were much smaller than I expected. May be worth it if you have a particular interest in seeing different species of plants but otherwise it is dull and overpriced. You don't even feel inclined to stay and while away some time in the gardens as they are so small and limited seating areas.
Interesting with mature plants. A pleasant small quite expensive garden, cafe and shop expensive..but still a little oasis on a hot day
lots of green!. nice park for a walk when you tired of the city; very refreshing with cool breeze. The peacefullness of this place and fresh hair, might make it for a long day walking the city center
Immaculate tranquil haven.. Beautiful well laid out borders of palms, succulents and cacti. There is an excellent cafe/restaurant (a bit slow), shop (pricey) and Berber Museum. Well worth a visit.

Well-tended cactus garden. Beautifully cared for array of cacti you can walk through on cement paths, filled with splashes of bright blue here and there. Really, really nice display of Berber jewelry in a star-studded mirrored room in the small Berber Museum. Former home of Yves St Laurent is outside the back wall, and there's an odd monument memorial to this designer in the park.

What an amazing Garden!. This is such a fantastic oasis in the middle of Nouvelle Ville, and the house is stunning! We didn't go in to the house (now a Berber museum) but instead just wandered about in the cool garden and then went for drinks at the cafe. The mint tea we ordered was terrible, so that's why the gardens only get 4 stars from me!

Take the number 15 bus from the square. From djemma el fna take the number 15 bus (4dh each, one way), takes about 6mins, then 3 mins walk from stop. Gardens were a bit over priced but nice (50dh each, berber museum 25dh) museum was only ok.Afterwards we had pizza at Red Garden (exit gardens, on main st turn left, 1-2min walk) pizza was good and cheap, free wifi too. To get back to el fna square exit red garden turn left, walk 1min, across the road take no. 11 bus. Avoid peak time on the bus, very crowded!
Stunning. I went in there not expecting much from a garden in the middle of Marrakech and was in turn extremely surprised at the design, beauty and serenity of Jardin Majorelle. Not to be missed.

Majorelle gardens. 50 dirhams entrance fee ... Allow yourself a good couple of hours to enjoy the atmosphere, view the museum, have something to eat/drink. Beautiful - I could very happily live there.
Gorgeous Gardens / Great Cafe. Spent 3 1/2 hours wandering the grounds, viewing the Berber museum and lunching at the cafe. Time well spent!
Gorgeous, tranquil & an must-see place. So beautiful. A really unexpected immaculate colourful oasis in the middle of the madness that is Marrakech.

Wonderful...shades of blue.. Loved the Jardin Majorelle. A peaceful haven in the new city. Renovated by Yves St Laurent and brought back to its former glory it's a must visit. We spent the complete day to chill and relax. We took our Kindles and relaxed...a perfect day since Marrakesh is a busy & bustling city. A lovely cafe / restaurant and the Berber Museum. All worth a visit and worth the entry cost.

Very pleasant, worth the visit.. Excellent little trip to pass an hour or so. Try and avoid hotel excursions as it's only 50dirums enter. Try and eat at the little cafe within, few plesant with the sun shining on the court-yard, not to expensive either.

An urban oasis. This beautiful garden with bright flower pots in yellow, blue and orange is a bit of an escape from the hectic inner city life in Marrakech. On a sunny day you can stroll along the park, sit under a palm tree, have a drink of gunpowder tea in the cafe or visit the art museum. Great place to take pictures. Really enjoyed it.

A breathtaking wonder. These gardens were a complete surprise; I came expecting much less than this world-class collection of cactus and other dry-terrain plants in such a beautifully created space, intersected with smooth red paths punctuated with urns in yellow and the almost iridescent Majorelle blue. The dry-terrain plants themselves (mostly cactus) are absolutely stunning; each one of them in perfect condition and some of them bearing their invariably curious and often rare flowers. Only some skilful photographs would do these gardens justice.Almost as fine in its own way is the Berber Museum with its perfect collection of atrefacts, beautifully arranged and lit.

A haven of calm. A lovely place to visit anytime but particularly in the warmer months in Marrakech as it offers such a haven of calm and coolness. The garden itself, although small, is ideal for a 30-45min wander, more if you are a photographer, followed up by a delicious meal of smoothie in the on site restaurant. Last visit I tried the Avocado, date and Almond smoothie, absolutely delicious. Well worth visiting within the gardens is the fantastic Berber museum, good exhibits and interpretation and fabulous jewellery and costume displays. Again not huge but these three elements - garden, museum and restaurant - make an ideal afternoon excursion and one with a real feeling of calm (unless you go high season when its packed!).

Worth a Visit!. A pleasant stroll around a garden full of a variety of cactus. I reckon it takes an hour at most, there is a little cafe, but we never had anything. The garden is kept clean and there are little ponds dotted around the garden. Its not massive, but a nice change of pace in Marrakesh.

Different and somewhat exotic. Nice place to sit down and daydream. It has an impressive collection of cactai, and a tiny but very well prepared Berber museum, where I enjoyed the presentation of jewels the most. The café there is a bit overpriced and so it the little store they have, but the place itself is very enjoyable.

Not worth the price and trouble. I really don't know why people rave about this small garden. If you are a botanist specialized in cactii, it would probably be worthwhile, but otherwise it is just a small garden, well maintained, but nothing special. Would not recommend. There are very beautiful gardens all over Morocco which are free to enter.50 dirhams for a 10 minutes walk in garden, in Morocco, is not small money. Don't waste your time.

Amazing. My visit to Jardin Majorelle was pleasant, but the gardens were certainly not world-class. The abundance of cacti was the highlight. The plants were quite impressive especially the cactus. It is something different in Marrakech especially when your hotel is located in the loud medina.We have reached the garden with the horse carriage and it was not expensive.

A bit over rated. A bit over rated in my opinion. Lots of cactae, bamboo and palms kept immaculately in a small area with lots of brightly coloured pots scattered around. Certainly different but not my cup of tea
Unforgettable. Magic, unique, unexpected beautiful, its not only about plants and that deep indigo color. Its somethng in the air. I Do understand ISLaurent, its place where you can leave your heart.
waste of money. just a garden full of cacti and other greenery, oh and a pond. even the museum was extra to pay. so dispappointing as no flowers etc..

Stunning calming gardens. Walked here from our Riad and after reading some reviews about how small it was was bit worried would be waste of money, however it is amazing, such beautiful gardens, with an amazing calming atmosphere. We spent a good couple hours here, just enjoying the views and wandering about. Also went into the Berber Museum which is worth a visit to look at the clothes and jewellery they wear, and a relaxing drink in the cafe there. Glad went and would definitely visit again.

Tranquility!. After the frantic bustle of the streets this escape was like paradise. The conception is beautiful and the rustle of the tall bamboos and palms very relaxing. In such a dusty country the vibrancy of the Majorelle Blue was fantastic. Lunch at the café was both really good and good value. Highly recommended to make the most of the environment.

Superb!. Loved this garden. The colours and layout were beautiful. So bright and colourful. Could just walk around and spend the whole day here. Absolutely loved it ... a must must visit for all travellers to Marrakech.

Enchanting respite from the Medina. Well worth the trip out of the Medina -- particularly on a hot day as most of the gardens nestle beneath the shade of bamboo and palm. Loved the tea in the cafe too. A must.

Tranquil Gardens. We enjoyed an hour wandering around this lovely botanical garden. It isn't very big but there are some nice areas to sit and take in the garden/plants. It is spotlessly clean and beautifully kept. Unfortunately the museum/house was closed as we arrived fairly late.
Gem. Brilliant tourist attraction where you can chill out from busy marrakech. Great cafe and museum for a small fee.

Tranquility. Although this is not a very big garden it was peaceful and tranquil and my husband who is a gardener really liked it. However, if you are expecting lots of plants, shrubs and trees these are not found here. The area is covered with Cacti and Bamboo trees and pots painted in bright yellow and blues which I loved. There are also various water themes which gave the gardens the feeling of tranquility it has. There is a Berber museum here which is well worth a visit. The cafe was very good and reasonably priced. Would definitely recommend this takes about hour and half to go round and I think the entrance was £4.00 approx. A fitting place for a memorial to Yves St Laurent.

Just Huge Cacti. Huge cacti. Architectural size plants giving some excellent black and white photos, very textural. Don't touch!Free disable entry.Good disabled access except to the shop and book room. Access loo at back of cafe.Nice cafe.Blue is the colour.

Pleasant, but not Essential. My visit to Jardin Majorelle was pleasant, but the gardens were certainly not world-class. The abundance of cacti was the highlight. The Berber history museum was interesting, but again, not really essential. For 75 dirham (about 7 euro), I was a bit disappointed. About a third of the garden was blocked off during my visit, which made it even less worth it. If you're in Marrakech for a few days, it's worth a visit, but don't feel bad if you can't make it.

A peaceful sojourn.. The gardens restored by Yves saint Laurent & Pierre Berge are a haven of peace and tranquility away from the frenetic hive of activity in the city. One tip is to arrive early before the coach parties when you are most likely to have the place almost to yourself. The gardens consist of mostly a large variety of fascinating cacti, bamboos, succulents and climbing plants. There is a small museum within the gardens, a souvenir shop and a small cafe.
Stunning. If you are in need to a little calm and tranquility this is the perfect place, the fauna is stunning.
Beautiful. Great garden, museum and cafe. Fell in love with Majorelle withs beautiful layout, plants, shade and bright pots.
Fabulous defo worth a visit.. Very beautiful. Peace and quiet and a contrast to the Madina. The museum inside is also worth a visit. Gardens 50 durum £4 museum 25 duram £2

my private Eden. I visited Jardin Majorelle in early March 2013. I especially liked the variety of palm trees and cacti. What made it so special to me is that it is a quite oasis in the middle of vibrant Marrakech, within walking distance from the Medina.

Disappointed. While the whole place is well looked after the only plants are cacti. A big forest of assorted sizes & colours. If like me you like roses, tulips, etc you will be disappointed.The tea-room is a rip off. A tea & a coffee cost 75D. In Marrakech the same was 33D

Tranquil contrast to the crazy medina. Yves Saint Laurent's blue house and gardens are a refreshing contrast to the chaos of the souks or main square.Great value and the Berber museum within the house is well worth adding to your ticket.Incredibly peaceful even though it was fairly busy. The space demands a respect for the silence and tranquility.It makes you wish you had been a French fashion designer so you could have built and lived in a place like this.

beautiful tranquil stop in the heart of a bustling city. we found this by accident whilst looking for a nearby museum, we were so glad we did. The garden was stunning and the little museum in the centre is a little gem of a find. A must visit if in Marrakech.

Underwhelmed. I think if it had been hot and sunny and later in the spring it may be better but on a rainy cold windy day this garden just looked tired. The size of the cacti and bamboos are impressive but there doesn't feel like any planting design - just plants dotted around. The memorial garden is a piece of broken column in a circle! Nothing else in the area

A tranquil place. Beautifully laid out gardens with vivid colours! My second visit and still as enchanting.. You must stop at the cafe for a juice, mint tea, coffee or snack. Look out for the terrapins!

Not to be Missed. This is such a lovely garden. So reminiscent of where I live - the Palm Springs area. The bright blue of the buildings is a sight to behold. Peaceful bliss in amongst chaotic Marrakech.The high point is the small museum that is within the garden. Historic recounting of the Berbers. Wonderful gift shop attached with sweet watercolor paintings and other Moroccan treasures.This is a "must see"!
Beautiful. We loved this place, the stark bright blue of the buildings coupled with the serenity and natural beauty was very refreshing in a busy dusty city. We expecially loved the bamboo.

Magical cactus garden and outstanding museum. Who would believe that giant bamboo and cacti of all sorts would co-exist in this magical spot. Many photo ops with the cobalt blue Berber Museum as a backdrop. Great restaurant for a cool lunch too.
Jardin Majorelle. This beautiful place is a must see destination on any trip to Marrakech. Go early in the morning or after 4.00.

Lovely oasis. lovely quiet relaxing little garden in the middle of the hustle and bustle of the new town. Entry fee of 50 DAM seemed reasonable. We opted onto to do the gardens, not the museum and on a showery day, it was perfect.
Relaxing compact gardens. A haven of tranquility to the north of the Medina. A nice place to unwind after the hectic pace elsewhere in town. Visit very early or late to avoid the crowds.

A very original garden. This garden is a must if you have some time, it's not what comes to your mind at first when you hear the word "garden", is more original. You enter for a very good price and the place is very enjoyable and peaceful, when you think that it's been enough plants for you, just close your eyes and relax because at any other corner of the city will be more difficult.
Amazing!. Do go and see this wonderful garden and learn a bit more about Majorelle and Yves St Laurent, also a lovely area to walk around, nice shops.
Marjorelle Gardens. This was okay but quite small so didn't take long to walk around. There were some great species of cactus and very tall bamboos and very bright pots!

A Beautiful Oasis. The tropical gardens are absolutely stunning and well worth a visit. Although they are extremely popular, so if you are planning to visit I would suggest going in the morning. There is an entrance fee (approximately £5). Personally I think it is a little expensive for what you get, although I enjoyed walking around the gardens. There is also a café although we didn't try this.

Lovely 'oasis' in the middle of a bustling city. This beautiful garden is an oasis in the middle of a bustling city. Made in the 1920s by French painter Jacques Majorelle, the gardens have marble pools, raised pathways, and a selection of beautiful plants such as banana trees, bamboos, palm trees, cacti and so on. There are also lots of lovely water features - channels, fountains and ponds. the trees provide shade and coolness, and the atmosphere is one of peace and quiet. After Majorelle's death, the garden was neglected for some year's until it was taken over and restored by Yves St Laurent. there is also a very interesting Berber Museum, opened in 2011, with a collection of photographs, films, music, etc from the world of the Berbers. Majorelle gardens is a must-see attraction in Marrakech, it is so different to anything else in the city - highly recommended.

a beautiful garden away from the crowds. This is a beautiful garden providing an oasis of peace away from the crowds in the medina. We spent an hour here admiring the many unusual plants and trees and attractive landscaping. The cafe looked enticing although the gift shop was expensive. We were told the Berber musuem in the gardens was excellent but did not have time to visit. One warning - ensure you agree a fare with the taxi driver outside the gardens before you get in the car. They quoted us a fare which was double the fare we paid when we came to the gardens!
Peaceful, colourful, tasteful. Haven in the middle of bustling Marrakesh with stunning cacti, trees,bamboo and exhibitions - small but well worth seeing and breathing a little tranquility.
vivid green in a dusty pink neighbourhood. and the intense blue architecture of the excellent Berber museum, all with a fascinating story involving Yves St Laurent
Cool Gardens. Was busy in paarticular around yves memorial, but plenty space elsewhere. Nice and cool place to relax

Try and avoid the coaches when visiting. Used to be a wonderful retreat away from the maddening crowds, unfortunately it is now one of the main stops for coaches and tourists, so can get very crowded. If you manage to go when it is quiet, the light, plants and colours inspired by Yves Saint Laurent are lovely. The cafe is excellent but pricey. Book shop is very good.

Just normal place to visit. The place is just ok.Colorfull, clean and beatyfull for take some pictures, but if you think the place in relation with the price, is too expensive: 50 dh for a garden where you can spend not more than one hour... And if you want to go into the museum, you have to pay 25 dh more.
Beauty in a garden. The final resting place for Yves St Laurant, and a testimony to his love of design and colour. It was worth the trip JUST to see this.
Mind Blowing Beautiful Blue Building.. Dazzling colours amonst the cactus and a lovely garden cafe. A welcome escape from the crazy chaos of the Medina.

Beautiful Oasis. Absolutely worth any admission fee (also check out the museum inside). It was tranquil as there were not too many people before 1pm, so you could really take your time and stroll around the garden, take lovely photos, and sit at a bench and reflect or people watch. I really enjoyed the different types of plants in the garden as well while my fiancee liked the colors and architecture.The cafe is also very nice with excellent food (try the Berber Tajine!) and while some guidebooks may say it is expensive, I did not find this to be the case.
Excellent!. Really interesting and beautiful garden! Well worth a visit, to see something you've never seen before!
Beautiful. A small but absolutely stunning garden. The stylised planting couple with the primary colours of the planters and buildings gives great beauty and serenity - well worth a visit.
A little peaceful corner. We took a caleche ride here from the main square, a lovely start. The gardens are compact and bijoux but worth a visit

Small but perfectly formed. Nice relaxing gardens away from the madness of the roads in Marrakech. Arrived early at 9am and had the place to myself so it was handy to get the photographs sorted without bumping into throngs of tourists.Entrance fee is £4 (expensive for Marrakech but gardens were very well maintained). They have other small museums and shops inside plus an attractive courtyard cafe which is worth having a look in or grabbing a bite and a drink maybe later in the day.
Cactus. if you like the prickly plants then this is worth seeing. It is however a rather odd garden and cramped garden and hardly worth a visit.

A bit of an anti-climax but with a good museum. Good for cactus fanciers but a relatively small garden compared to the average UK garden visit. Cafe prices are twice the hotel rate.The small Berber museum is very good though, with a positively superb collection of Berber tribal jewellery.

Enchanting!. So glad we visited this beautiful garden. Unbelievable that it is in the middle of such a busy city. The wonderful colours are perfect and reflect Yves Saint Laurents' couture history. Perfectly cared for. The museum in the grounds is worth visiting, very small but informative, the room that houses the jewellery has the most incredible ceiling!.

Nice but small gardens with an entrance fee. These gardens are well maintained but relatively small and have a £5 entrance fee per person. They were quite full when I visited reasonably early in the morning in February, so I suspect they are crowded in high season.OK for a quick look around, especially if you have someone in the party keen on gardening and plants, but not a must see attraction in my book, a view seemingly shared by the many teenagers looking bored as they followed their parents around...
Beautiful!. The garden looks so beautiful in the sun! The smell of blooming flowers is extraordinary! A must for every Marrakech visitor!

Unleash Your Inner Hippie Here. When you first enter this walled garden the color scheme sort of jumps out at you - IKEA blue and yellow prevail. After a few minutes it grows on you. The arrangements of desert cactii and succulents mixed with water features and palm trees is very creative and pleasant. The place feels like a cross between art deco and a Peter Max poster.The cafe is great. Stop in for a drink or try the argan oil and almond ice cream. You probably won't find this anywhere else.

astonishing. this blu is a reference and is unique !
whoaw , if travelling in Marrakesh les jardins majorelle is a must see ,

relaxing stop in Marrakech. We visited Jardin Majorelle as part of a museum tour during our vacation in Marrakech. The garden was beautiful and full of vibrant colors. We enjoyed walking around this peaceful place and took time to sit on a bench and take in the lush surroundings. It was a nice break from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Wonderful and serene. Had a lovely couple of hours at the Jardin Majorelle. One of the easier things to find in Marrakech, just a short walk outside the Medina walls. There is a beautiful (but expensive) YSL gift shop inside as well as a gallery. The Berber Museum inside the gardens is also well worth a visit.If you want to combine the gardens with a horse drawn carriage ride, its ideal as there are plenty just at the end of the street.

Lovely peaceful gardens. These gardens are really fun, with glimpses of bold splashes of colour, lovely water features and lots of bamboo and cacti. We paid to go in the small Berber museum as well which was quite interesting but I wouldn't call it a must see.
Top of your list. I loved the Berber Museum, wandering the grounds, and drinking hot chocolate in the cafe. It was one of my favorite attractions in Marrakesh. Try to go when it isn't so crowded.

Well worth the trip. Really enjoyed our walk around these gardens. Didnt go inside the house so cant say about that but the gardens are lovely. When we finally buy our villa this is how its going to look!!

Beautiful and peaceful designer garden. Amazing display of shades and shapes of green dotted with brightly coloured pots and arches. Surprising worldwide plant selection make a peaceful heaven in the busy and noicy new Marrakech. YSL shop nicely out of the way at the back of the garden i.e. Commerciality didn't interfere with enjoyment if the garden.

Tranquil and pretty. Loved all the colours and calm feeling. The small exhibition of 'love' posters was great. Entrance fee was good value and the gardens were a very different Moroccan vibe. Didn't eat in the cafe but it looked lovely.

sensory calm. liked everything about the garden.....take time to sit down and take it all in there are a lot of rare african birds that nest there and just to sit down and listen to them is a free sound download of a lifetime. Dot forget to visit the small pond tucked way in the back of the garden. Do also visit the memorial.
good place to go. well worth a visit - would recommend. great collection of plants, cactus etc. Very peaceful. Nothing to dislike.

Beautiful gardens. We visited this in October 2012. It took about half an hour to walk round the gardens (but you can spend longer). There are lots of tropical plants to see with lots of different cacti and bamboo. It didn't cost alot to get in. I can't remember exactly how much but around £4.50 per person. There is a very small museum in the gardens. We didn't pay the extra to see it as we were off to the Atlas mountains and did not have time. There is also a small cafe but again we didn't go in. There are limited toilets available, with attendants waiting for you to cross their palm with a few pence on the way in/out. They were very clean and tidy though. WhenYves Saint Laurent died in 2006 his ashes were scattered in what is now known as The memorial garden. Well worth a visit
an oasis of peace and quiet. Lovely gardens. More cactus than flowers. Interesting to see if you have a spare 45 minutes.probably nicer if the sun was out and you could sit a while!
Peaceful and beautiful. These gardens are an amazing and quiet oasis within Marrackech, and a great way to begin or end your day of sightseeing. Inexpensive, as well.

Not worth lingering. I disagree this is a place to linger - nothing lush or exotic. All we saw was a few tacky blue buildings and a selection of cactus plants. Alsoat the entrance you will be pestered by taxi drivers and hawkers. If you want to see a nice garden, visit La Mamounia Hotel where the gardens are beautifully landscaped and full of flowers even when we visited at the end of February.

A cool respite from the hustle and bustle. A lovely, and well maintained garden in the North of the city. Unfortunately, when I visited, maintenance was being carried out in parts of the garden, meaning that several paths were out of bounds, which had an effect on the flow of visitors; it seemed really busy. Interesting cactuses and lots of shady places to sit. The Berber museum is definitely worth a visit - it's really well laid out, and there are information cards in English about all the exhibits. Small, but the best of the museums I visited in Marrakech. Nice, but pricy outdoor cafe, and good clean toilets. I've got a strange urge to paint everything yellow and Marjorelle Blue now. Caleche stand outside, but it's an easy walk from Gueliz and the Northern Medina riads.
Spoilt by crowd. This would be a delightful place if you could visit when there are few other visitors. It would then be a haven of peace in a bustling city.

Loved it!. A beautiful garden filled with a limited colour palette. Look around and there is water, listen to the birdsong, look up and see the tops of palm scraping the sky. Look the other way see that vibrant blue through the shapes the plants make. A lovely retreat in the endless hustle and bustle of Marrakech. Take time to visit this garden it really is worth it.We enjoyed lunch in the restaurant and would recomend it for something light.
Soothing respite. This garden was left to the city of Marrakech, and is beautiful for a half hour or so wander around.

Peace, tranquil, beautiful colours and shadowws.. Although more expensive to visit than other sites in Marrakech it is probably worth it for the marvelous colours , plants, lay out and detail. try and avoid coach party time as it is not a huge area so can get crowded.

Oasis.. A small but great oasis of tranquility in the middle of crazy busy Marrakech. Very nice place to spend a couple of hours chatting and leisurely walking around with its great collection of cactus & towering bamboos.

beautiful little oasis inside marrakech. We stopped by this garden as it was much talked about by our guide as something the moroccans were quite proud of. It is a short walking garden (maybe 30 minutes) and there is a cafe onsite as well (we did not eat there).
Don't miss this on your first visit. This place should be amongst the top 5 five places to visit in Marrakech. Although outside the medina, is is simply a wonderful place to linger for 1-2 hours.
Nice place. Nice place to relax from the crowdy and busy city. A wonderful garden and pituresque villa. For Marrakesh an expensive entrance fee, but it is worth.

Nice but little. As a photographer i expected more variety at this tranquil garden.
There where to many visitors .
The blue colours from the potterys are eyecatchers and the water
lilies in the little lake are so beautiful.
But thats it - 45 Minutes and i was done.

An enchanting garden. A wonderfully different garden experience, more like a sculpture park, with the weed-free plant beds showing each variety in its own space. And all is enhanced by the vibrant colours of the pots and the built environment.
Lovely little blue oasis!. Small but really interesting garden just outside the Medina. Lovely cafe and beautiful gift shop. The blue paint is very atmospheric, and the plants are most unusual.

Interesting Gardens. Interesting gardens, which used to belong to Yves St Laurent-his tomb is in one of the areas of the garden. The gardens are well looked after and have stunning cacti and water features. The cafe is very nice too :) Well worth a visit-and a quiet place to wander around.

Inspiring garden. The garden was fantastic and just a short taxi ride from the centre of town. The museum to Yves was a highpoint as were the cactus outside the main building. How the garden manages to be so varied in such a small space is a marvel. Downside too many visitors so get there early or late so you are not battling to get photos.

Tranquil. Great to soak up the sun listening to birdsong. The gardens were a bit busy and I can imagine them being crowded later in the year. The museum was worth a visit but the garden is the main attraction. Loved the variety of cacti and the terrapins.

Pretty but pricy. This beautiful little garden and house used to belong to Yves St Laurent and his tomb is in the gardens. In the noise of Marrakech it is an oasis of calm with beautiful plants and stunning colours. It is a bit out of the way but I would recommend visiting even though I think the 50dirham entrance fee is a bit over the top as you would be pushing it to spend more than half an hour here - even if you move very slowly.

Charming garden and blue building..... The house is one of the few things worth visiting in a city full of nothing to see. It is, however, the sort of attraction one visits, takes a photo and then leaves after no more than a half an hour spent in the delightful small garden.

The colour is inspirational. A lovely hour in this special garden. The forms of the plants were exciting and linked with the limited pallet it was a treat for the senses. I would recommend a visit if you are in the area although it is not even a half day visit.

Small but exquisite. It took us a while to reach this garden, and we had walked round it in about twenty minutes. That said, it is stunningly beautiful and worth a visit - as long as you don't expect to pass the whole day there.

A lovely peaceful setting. The gardens were peaceful and a pleasure to walk through. You are able to sit and enjoy and the staff are welcoming. Not as large as i expected, however, and there appeared to be some essential and perhaps unavoidable maintenance going on which was a bit of ashame although it did not interfere with my overall enjoyment.

Blue and green haven. Amazing gardens and fascinating berber museum with lovely cafe. A stunning oasis of calm - and vibrant colours in the garden with an amazing historical and hitech exhibition about berber life.

Berber history and haute couture. As well as the beautiful gardens, the Berber museum is well thought out and interesting. The influence of Yves Saint Laurent ( buried here and his Foundation supports the gardens financially) is very visible in the gift shop - exquisite items at high prices. The pretty cafe is worth a visit.
Beautiful!. Well worth a visit. Stunning gardens and water features, a real oasis in all the bustle of Marrakech. Very interesting small museum and history. A real must-see.

Escape from the Medina. A nice way to escape the hustle and bustle of the medina, but the gardens are pretty small. The flowers were pretty and unusual but its not exactly Kew. I do appreciate this is the desert though and it was a nice escape. Also rate the cafe which had a lovely laid back feel. We spent ages havin a coffee and lunch - overpriced, but a nice way to spend the afternoon. Come here after a few days spent in the souks and the square for a spot of light relief!

Lovely Garden. Very pleasant and cool garden to visit within easy walking distance from the centre of Marrakech. (if you don't want to walk, take a horse drawn carriage or a taxi, not expensive!). Go yourself and not on the trips organised by your hotel.

Beautiful Gardens. These gardens are like discovering hidden treasure in a desert. Located unobtrusively off a busy, dusty street, from the moment you enter you are in another world. The colours, the water, the plantings, everything about it is calming and a feast for the senses. I'm sure I must have used the equivalent of a roll of film on my digital camera because I wanted to capture everything I saw. It's a must see site for anyone visiting Marrakech.
Serene Beauty. Actually one of our favourite parts of Marrakech - so serence, but go early, as it's not big and crowds can overwhelm.
