A beautiful labor of love. This was one of the prettiest sights we saw in Morocco. My two pre-teens really enjoyed it. Very interesting
beautiful. It's a nice way to get a break from the dirty busy streets of the medina. While you're there go enjoy some of the restaurants in the nouvelle ville!

Francine. What a gem!!! Fabulous gardens and museum as well as really charming restaurant. Not the biggest garden you can visit but although fairly pricey to get in you can dtay all day!!! And we did....enjoyed sketching in the garden and sitting in the sun. It was crowded but a real pleasure to go to and the bookshop was excellent. Also there are some lovely shops and galleries in the area around it which are wellWorth the visit.

Peaceful and shady. The gardens are a little way out of the rest of the touristy areas of the city and make a nice, peaceful break from the chaos that characterises some parts!Spend an hour or so wandering around some beautiful gardens and water features - there's a cafe to sit and have a drink if you like. It's a tranquil oasis and an escape from the hordes!
small but nice. a small garden but nice for. short visit.will not take u longer than 20mins togo around the garden and take some pictures
Calm formal garden.. A little out from the main sightseeing area, but interesting and beautiful.It is worth buying a ticket to include the museum as the Berber jewellery displayed inside is stunning

A beautiful, peaceful space. I would highly recommend a trip to Jardin Majorelle to anyone who visits Marrakech.It's a very calming, well kept space with a great variety of plants and Berber blue buildings. You can catch a horse and cart there from the main square - which I think is well worth doing, but be prepared to haggle!

Beautiful but go early. The gardens were lovely and beautiful. I think that going early in the morning is the way to do it. When we went at 9:00, there were not many other people. The path is not huge and so I imagine it can get crowded or congested and difficult to take pictures with lots of other people around.

Beautiful. Lovely gardens, so glad we decided to visit it on our last day. The gardens has a large variety of plants from different continents which are nice to look at. We got lucky because the weather was just beautiful on the day we visited. We paid 50dirhams (about a fiver) to enter the gardens but I think it was worth it. The garden is quite a small area but there is lots to look at once your inside.Must visit if you are in marrakech.
peaceful!. Amazing variety of cacti and plants set in beautifully kept gardens. Museum very interesting giving an idea how people in Morroco have lived for hundreds of years
Lovely cacti!. Lovely garden but very busy even though we were there in February. Go early in the day to avoid the crowds.

gorgeous colourfull garden. we loved it because it was very pleasing relaxing. the colourfull
pots were fantastic and the majorelle blue everywhere so uplifting

Ok - if you know what to expect. For a family of 4 I would say it is only average value. We went in the morning so the garden wasn't too busy which was just as well as the garden is quite small - and some paths were closed for maintenance.The garden is neat with some nice colour and photo opportunities.The memorial to Yves St Lauren is a little odd - but decide if you agree fir yourself.The small museum is interesting, unfortunately our visit coincided with a tour from Spain which made it hard to see everything. The cafe is in a lovely setting - but is overpriced - taking advantage of the captive tourists.We walked back to the new ville, had lunch, and then strolled back to our hotel in the Medina - a nice day out.

Small, but pretty. You'll only need about 30 minutes to take a quick walk around this garden. It cost 50 dirham to enter, just under €5. We stayed in the medina, so I'm not sure we would've made it here without our trusty tour guide. The potted plants and painted walls offer a nice contrast to the greenery.
nice break from the hassle of the city. nice garden that will inspire you - walking distance from the square but expect to get lost at least once.

A nice garden. Entrance was 50 Dirham/adult. The garden was crowded with tourists, and though it was fun to walk in Louis Vuittons footsteps, it was not worth the money. Better to visit the park in Gueliz - bigger, better and free of charge

Magical Garden. A beautifull garden in a magical setting! Well worth a visit a very peacefull place full of tranquility. There are gift shops and a very nice cafe/restaurant in the grounds. We visited this as part of our horse drawn carriage ride around the city and definately worth the stop. With a few boutique shops close by.

Beautiful Garden, bad restaurant. The garden was so pretty, with range of different flowers and plants that are put together to create a breath taking place. The blue buildings were odd, but somehow fit in perfectly to the surroundings. There was plenty of great photo opportunities. There was even a dedicated area to Yves Saint Laurent, that was lovely as there were lots of pictures hanging up that he had designed.The problem we encountered that let the gardens down was the restaurant. we ordered drinks and ice creams, as it was fairly hot out and we had been walking a day. The restaurant was full and the guy took our order. We found that in Marrakech they take their time to serve food, but other people were coming in and ordering food and drinks, time passed the other people received their drinks and food. Still we waited.......and waited, until another waited asked and we said we were waiting on food, he disappeared and carried on serving people. 40 minutes went pass and still NOTHING!!!!.So, we left. Outside the gardens was a excellent drink place where we settled to have a drink. This experience with the restaurant let the garden down and I understand that they were busy, but to serve others who came in after us. Even if I just had the drink then I would have been happy. Other than that it was a great day out with my family, (Dad, Mum and Sister)

Pretty but expensive for its size. We had allowed a couple of hours to visit this garden but completed the tour in a very short time. Without doubt it is pretty, but the cost of entry is disproportionate to its size.

Is overrated must-to. Every body insisted that we should visit this jardin. We did but it is not a must! It is expensive, very small and nothing attractive to see. Almost every pec or botanic garden is more interesting.

Blue, yellow and orange pots. This is a must visit whilst you're in Marrakech! A unique garden last owned by Yves Saint Laurent with his memorial and new year's day art on show. The plants are beautiful and amazing. We took time out from the busy city to explore the garden and museum and to write postcards in a sunny spot.
Beautiful colors, great for pictures. Its a beautiful garden, great colors and lots of different varieties of cactus and plants but its not very big andits full of tourist. Worth the visit.

Oasis!. Such a quiet, peaceful garden, located outside the Medina. Many different plants and tree to admire. Beautiful landscaping. Lovely Koi pond as well as a beautiful tribute to Yves Saint Laurent. The cafe has very good crepes and is quite a nice outdoor place to enjoy the tranquil surroundings. Many benches along the gardens to sit and relax.
So peaceful. Brilliant Oasis in a buzzing city. The grounds are kept immaculate and the Berber Museum, within the grounds, is well worth a visit

Marrakech March 2012. Before going to Morocco I already had my heart set on going here, all the pictures I saw were wonderful and as a keen photographer I was eager to check it out.We went in March and the temperature in the city was higher than we're used to, but as soon as we entered the Jardin Majorelle it was cool and shady, a complete contrast to the hot and hectic city outside. A lovely place to stroll and admire the wonderful collection of plants and odd cacti. There are numerous water features which add to the beauty. Also a rather bizarre collection of bamboo canes which have been carved and scratched with visitors' graffiti, which is rather unique if a bit untidy. There is a café within the gardens which is very pretty but also rather over priced which was a shame as it put us off buying anything. This and the fact that it was smaller than I was hoping are the only bad points. I would defiantly recommend for those who enjoy gardens and having a bit of quiet time, make sure to also visit the museum tucked away in the gardens!

Expensive and small. The garden was very crowded when we visited and much smaller than we had expected. We paid to visit the museum too but it was tiny. The garden IS lovely, but I wouldn't go back again of I were in Marrakech.
Nice Place. These gardens are a nice traquil place to visit, My partner and i went one morning to have a stroll around, probably don't need more than an hour to get around.

I wish I owned this place!. Being a landscape designer, I thought it'd be a great thing for me to see. And it was. Most of the plants here are identified (which is good to see), and there is a great sense of harmony with all the colour in the garden. the house is a spectacular blue and you definitely need a photo in front of it!The museum is worth going into - there is a lot on Berbers which is very interesting (particularly their dress and jewelry). I'd give the gift shop a miss inside...it's a bit overrated for my liking BUT outside the gardens there is a fantastic little shop that sells some nice post cards if you want them.

Nice cafe and a break from the dust of the city. This is attraction is outside the Medina, on the north edge of the city. Should cost about 50DHR by taxi to get there and the entrance fee is 50DHR too. The gardens are very pleasant, mostly cactii but also palms and succulents and a couple of nice water features. There was a dead pigeon in the pool being nibbled by terrapins but generally the garden is clean and well maintained.There is also a nice cafe there, the first on site cafe we have seen in the whole city!The gardens do get crowded and they are quite small so I'd advise getting there before 9AM.

Magical, serene, relaxing and beautiful. My husband and I visited with a guide and 2 other couples and we were enchanted by the beauty and peaceful of it. The buildings, cacti all outstanding and there is a bench to sit and contemplate the sheer beauty. Yves St. Laurent and his designer team, made a wonderful restoration of Marjorelles` Gardens, very spiritual place.

peaceful. visit when quiet - and you will get the full experience. Amazing plants the shapes and textures really are stunning.
The blue of the villa against the gardens and the sky on a sunny day will stay with you forever.

colourful place.. Our visit to the gardens was on a particularly beautiful day and we were bowled over by the colours, plants and design of the whole place. We had some mint tea in the lovely cafe there....very tranquil

Unique Garden.. We were told to go immediately after lunch to avoid the crowds. About 2pm is the perfect time to go to have the garden almopst to yourself. Never quite seen anything like it. A serene monument to Majorelle. And there is a small monument to Yves St Laurent whose house joined the garden.
Essential visiting. Relaxing garden and a welcome break from the madness of the town. Peaceful, immaculate, with a great little cafe and a fabulous museum. Make a point of going

Leaves a very distinctive memory. We walked to these gardens from the centre of Marrackech and it was rather further than expected and not the most attractive walk either. The gardens are small but the combination of plants and the vivid Majorelle Blue of the buildings and masonry leave a vivid impression.
Ok. Nice place to see to kill an hour ot two, but not amazing. Would like to see some benches, particularly around the ponds, to catch the rays!
magic. very nice place to visit. fresh atmosphere and nice walk. they have good ice cream in the bar in front of the entrance!

if there's one tourist attraction you really have to visit.... There's a touch of magic in the air of Majorelle - perhaps it's the vivid Moroccan pigments used to colour the buildings and plant pots, or the vivid "Majorelle Blue" of the Art Deco buildings that are a perfect setting for the silvery green succulents and cacti at the heart of this horticultural treasure trove - in a word "stunning"!

Beautiful peace and quiet in a loud city. Whenever you are tired of the city and don't feel like leaving it, do leave it while staying within city limits. These gardens are beautiful and worth a visit.

Beautiful Garden in a bustling part of the city. I love the vibrate colours which set of the plants beautiful making the garden very relaxing. Depending on the time of year it can get very busy here. So best to visit early morning. The museum is delightful. A wonderful place to meet friends and have a light lunch too.

beautiful garden in the new town. Beautiful garden, with lots of shade and greenery. Stunning bright blue paintwork. Was very busy when we went which was a shame - would be really relaxing if less touristy.

Visually stunning. Not far from old Marrakech, this garden is vivid and tranquil. The Tuareg blue pots and house against the green vegetation is very striking. And the little Berber museum is small, but well put together. Worth the extra cost.
Beautiful quiet garden. We loved this garden. Absolutely beautiful and quite unexpected. The Berber Museum was interesting too and well worth a visit.

OK, but not incredible. Quite nice gardens but maybe not worth a special trip. Small and doesn't take that long to get around. It is fine as one of the places to visit in Marrakech, but not that amazing.

Unexpected Treat. I was on tour with Gate 1 and after a full day I was not looking forward to yet 1 more stop at what I thought was yet another garden and museum. Was I in for a pleasant surprise. It was another garden but one filled with various cactus. It was simply beautiful. The Berber museum was very interesting while small really gave a sense of the Berber culture. Don't hesitate to go, it's a delightful quick stop and was well worth seeing.

Beautiful garden but nothing too amazing. Quite, relaxing but no colours I.e flowers ( but maybe due to the time of year we visited). We were slightly disappointed especially that it was quite a way out from the city square. It's good but don't expect anything grand!
Serene place to relax. These gardens are a nice break from the chaos of the city. Lots of cacti and a nice tribute to yves saint laurent. Peaceful place to relax.

Nice to wander around; museum was quite interesting. We read some mixed reviews on the gardens and decided to give it a try, given that we were in Marrakech for two and a bit days and there isn't all that much more to do in the way of sightseeing. THe gardens are nice to wander around, but nothing very special. The monument to YSL, which we saw on described as a must see by some reviewers, is nothing more than a broken pillar... we didn't really get it. We quite enjoyed the Berber museum though. It is small, but has some interesting examples and explanations of the different clothing worn by different groups of people throughout Morocco.

Beautiful gardens in Marrakech's new town.. The gardens themselves are beautiful and architecture lovely. Gorgeous colours and cacti. The museum inside Berber museum is also very interesting. The cost is very cheap to enter, but the cafe and gift shop is very expensive. Worth a visits and the section regarding Yves San Laurent was particularly interesting. Poorly signposted though. Look for the line of horse and carriages and follow the small road.
Oasis. Don't miss this total gem of a place. Calm, peace and quiet, with zinging colours and well kept gardens. Excellent Berber museum and great little restaurant. Walkable from the city.

Peace in marrakech. The Majorelle garden is haven in busy Marrakech. You can see everything in 30 minutes or enjoy a slow wander through the beautifully planted largely shrub, tree, succulent and cactus planting along with quiet pools full of goldfish. The bright orange, blue and yellow pots are eye catching. A visit to the Berber Museum is well worth it to see the craftmanship in the pottery, jewellery and weaving and learn a little of the Berber history. After that enjoy a drink, snack, meal at the pretty Cafe.
Jardin Majorelle. Very peaceful and beautiful. Lots of different areas of plants and trees, with several water features, a very nice garden café and a lovely little shop

Refresh Your Eyes at Marjorie Gardens. A must visit. My wife and I found the site inviting, peaceful, extremely well maintained, and a wonderful assortment of plants. Walk the grounds and enjoy the plants as you are transported to a place of tranquility. There is a restaurant on site but we did not eat there.

Really nice. I liked this place. It is walking distance from the Medina, and quite an interesting display of plant life. The Berber exhibition inside is a truly excellent montage. I highly recommend going in. Only thing I despise is the inability to take photos inside the museum.

beautiful garden. The Jardin Majorelle is an oasis in the middle of Marrakesh with flowers, trees, and artwork . It's a tourist hotspot where you might find friends and acquaintances from your travels elsewhere.
Needs a taxi. Quite busy, even in February but well worth seeing. Amazing cacti, beautifully kept and lovely use of colour. There is a nice tea room too which is very welcome
Lush Gardens!. Beautiful way to spend an hour! Loads of photo opportunities and a great way to enjoy the outdoors! Definitely recommend for a hot day as the gardens keep you a bit sheltered and cool.

Just a garden. Was okay but I think most of the hype is that is was YSL who purchased the gardens. If you are someone who loves to go to botanical gardens in any city you visit then go, but if you haven't been to the botanical garden in your home town, then I would skip it if you have a limited time in Marrakech.
An oasis. The shadowy coolnes, the colors, the quiet and the very interesting small museum of berber culture makes this worth the trip.

Nice place to take a break. It was really nice to take a break from the heat at this place.
Lots of trees and a nice pond in the middle to take a breather. Have a tea or cold drink and cafe and listen to the peacefulness away from teh main square well worrth teh entry price of 50 DHS

Peaceful, pretty and amazing cactuses!. Not the biggest of gardens to get lost in so doesn't take long to go round but we really enjoyed it. It was a glorious day, the sun shining through the trees. Pretty colours and just a pleasant, relaxing stroll through. The cactuses are absolutely amazing!
Wonderful. Delightful gardens , vibrant but very peaceful. Cafe set in pretty courtyard. Berber musuem wll worth a visit

Colourful and wonderful vistas. A wonderful oasis - a beautiully designed and maintained garden with colour and wonderful vistas. Even though there were quite a few visitors - it was still possible to find quiet places to reflect and enjoy.
Tranquil haven. A lovely quiet garden, full of shadey spots to sit and ponder, beautiful colourful paths and a nice shop and cafe. Would definitely visit again.

Majorelle gardens. Lovely gardens quite surreal place in the middle of the town surrounded by houses and shops! You'd never know it was there from the outside. Yves St Laurent has his ashes here and a memorial to him is a must see.

Incredibly over priced for what it was. I found myself in a confined space with lots of very unfriendly people and actually paid money for this experience.
After 6 trips to Morocco this is not an experience i enjoyed.
Out of this world. Words cannot explain how beautiful these gardens are, you feel like you are in a different world once you go through the gate away from the hustle and bustle of the medina outside

Jardin Majorelle. If you like Cacti you will love this garden, it is an oasis of calm on the edge of the town. My husband is not a cacti lover but even he thought they were amazing, I have never seens such a fabulous display
Wonderful collection of cacti. Brilliant museum and love seeing YSL's posters, the coffee shop in the courtyard was a lovely place to relax for a while.

Tranquil and different. If you love ecclectic gardens and Yves Saint Laurent, then this is a haven of tranquility for fashion and art lovers ....a garden and fashion fusion! This is very different so dont expect anything like an English country garden. Entrance is about 50 dirham and the museum dirham extra. An hour will be enough.

Peaceful even while full of visitors. Cactuses like we had never seen before; 'house-plants' growing outdoors; terrapins in the pond with the goldfish; unknown birds to identify; brilliant blue and yellow pottery.
Also WC available.

Peace and tranquility!. Beautifully peaceful, the Jardin Marjorelle is ideal for a quiet afternoon away from the chaos of the city centre. You can walk around and look at the extremely well-kept gravel gardens and cacti, or find a shady spot to settle down in and enjoy the view over the fish ponds and bright blue and yellow museum. Here you'll also find a memorial to Yves Saint-Laurent, who owned the gardens; a Berber museum which easily has one of the best collections in the city; and a couple of art galleries to take a look at. We ended up spending half the day here - well worth the £2!

Little oasis. So glad we visited this whilst in Marrakesh. 50 dh about £4 entrance. From entering the busy road outside you are suddenly submerged into a haven of tranquility and beautiful greys of the many different cacti and trees and azure blue and canary yellow paintwork. We had a coffee in the cafe and not cheap but an experience to sit and have a drink in a beautiful setting. Highly recommended.

Tranquility from the bustle. We went early to avoid the crowds and tried walking there - map was hopeless but speaking French helped and we found it - get a taxi or a carriage. Gardens themselves - beautiful, relaxing, places to sit, listen and just relax. Cafe great too. Don't miss it

Disappointing. It was overpriced and nothing special. The whole garden took less than 20 minutes to explore. However in the mid summer heat I can imagine it would be a welcome shade from the sun. There are plenty of lovely garden's in Marraheck to see for free so save your money.

A bright, pleasant oasis. Jardin Majorelle is very pleasant place to spend some time. The bright yellows, blues and oranges of the plant pots are a lovely contrast to the greenery. It's very quiet, so a nice place to take some time out from the hustle and bustle of Morocco. There is a very pleasant looking cafe and although it's a little expensive looks like a lovely place to enjoy a coffee or some lunch if you have the time. Well worth a detour.
Lovely way to spend an afternoon. Enjoy the afternoon sun, stroll leisurely along the meandering paths amongst the plants and flowers, and sit and relax by the water features.

quiet paradise. This was a quiet paradise in the hustle and bustle of Marrakech.Would recommend getting a petite taxi there as we found it difflcult to walk therewe got the musuem ticket also which was good valueNice little cafe for light snacks and drinks.A little tip, when you come out there is someone there asking if you want taxidont go with them as he takes you to taxi driver who is in queue and then you endup paying double usual fare because driver says he has to pay the bloke who took youto taxi, just turn right and approx 100 metres taxis there.

Jardin Majorelle. Spent a wonderful afternoon here, a little piece of paradise away from the hussle (or is that hassle) and bussle of Marrakech! I am sure that in the heat of the summer this is an absolute must. The little cafe was well worth the money and some fantastic photo opportunity. Make sure you get the Berber Museum ticket as well. Highly recommend a trip here.

Don't miss The museum!. A beautiful tranquil garden,if you visit it early in the morning or untill garden closing time. We were there about 4.30(it is closed at 5.30),it wasn't crowded.I also like the museum.It was small,but well organized.It is good to get information about berberian life.
an amazing variety of Cacti. Fun to look at all the different cacti, took lovely pictures. Visit the shop it has lovely quality items. Little museum is sweet.
Beautiful. A little oasis in the citty. Definitely recommend visiting while in Marrakech. And the cafe is pretty good as well.

Nice but busy. The gardens are lovely but they are a real tourist trap! It was hard to see he garden without being in a tourist photo op, worth a visit but it maybe good to go out of 'peak times' it was nearly lunch when we got there!
The cafe was very nice for a cold juice in the beautiful surroundings!

Designer garden in every way. If you want to see something truly different, visit this garden. It is not large and you could manage it within a couple of hours. The restaurant is also worth a rest in!

Fabulous colours. The Jardin Majorelle is much smaller than I'd expected and features a more limited array of plants with much emphasis on Mexican and South American species. But the use of colour is fabulous.

Relaxing place for morning/ afternoon visit. I do love this place. It is an oasis of tranquility. And even so popular place with tourists, you can find quite place and sit down and listen bird's songs. The garden is not very big. There is a restaurant, souvenir shop and gallery plus the Berber Museum (I did not visit this museum).It is open:October 1 - April 30 - 8am - 5:30pmMay 1 - September 30 - 8am - 6pmThe month of Ramadan - 9am - 5pmEntrance fee: 50 dirhams garden, 25 dirhams museum.

Don't miss these beautiful gardens. One of the highlights of Marrakesh. Lots of interesting plants and a cool oasis in the bustling city. Beatufil Art Deco house which now has a small museum on the Berber culture. You have to brave some scary traffic crossing roads to get to the gardens, but it's worth it. There's also a very pleasant cafe inside where the service is attentive, but relaxed, and they seem happy to let you spend a hour over coffee.

A haven from Marrakech madness. This was one of my highlights on our holiday to Morocco. Marrakech was brilliant but got a bit much at times, so I was so relieved to get into the gardens and relax. Though our 3 year old drank from the fountains and ran on the gravel (until we suggested there may be crocodiles hiding there) it was an amazingly chilled out experience. I love modernist design and architecture so this was a real treat.

Delightful gardens - tranquil yet interesting. On a recent return visit to Marrakech we had to pay a return to Jardin Majorelle. It's specialist place that majors on palms and cacti but you do not need to be a gardener to enjoy this lovely oasis in Northern Marrakech - an easy cab rid from the city centre. . Good value too - well worth a visit.
beautiful!. A little oasis of calm in an otherwise frantic city. Beautiful and shaded on a hot day. Take a picnic as the cafe is very expensive.

Quite pleasant. Not a great attraction, but very relaxing. Cafe very expensive, have a drink outside. It is a little oasis away from the chaos of the town. Local people can sometimes lead you astray if you can`t find it. About £

A must see in Marrakech. I absolutely loved the Marjorelle Gardens. They are stunning. The colours are beautiful and it is such a tranquil and serene place to visit. We took a horse and carriage from Jemaa el Fna (100DH) and we walked back down to the south of the Medina. We had some tea in the garden (which is pricey compared to other places - but very nice) and we loved the Yves Saint Laurent Gallery. The Museum, although small, is also really well curated - so it is worth buying a ticket for both. I loved it here and would visit again if I went back to Marrakech.

Beautiful but Expensive!. A wonderful garden. Well kept and a tranquil place to visit. We got some lovely photographs and enjoyed a lazy stroll. However the charge to get in for what it is, seems unreasonable and the cost of Drinks in the cafe is also very high.

Beauty. This place made by Majorelle a French painter is just a beauty. All plants come from all around the world and the quietness of this garden is just trouble by the tourist. The blue Majorelle used to decorated the painter's building is gorgeous.

Colourful, Peaceful Gardens. We took a horse and carriage ride and one of it's stops was Jardin Majorelle. I was very interested to visit these gardens as had read plenty of reviews - Yves Saint Laurent once owned these gardens and now it marks his memorial place. It does not take that long to walk around the gardens so the 30 minutes we had been given by our horse and carridage drivers was plenty long enough. However, for those who wanted to stay longer there is a cafe within the gardens and also a further museum which we did not pay the extra to visit.The entrance price was quite expensive for the size of the gardens (around £16 each). But I guess this pays for the upkeep of the gardens and the people to work there - and you would ordinarily pay this in London, UK to visit a place of interest.Well worth a visit !
Majorelle Gardens. Stunning 'oasis' on the outskirts of Marrakech - a wonderful place to relax, and soak in the atmosphere. Don't miss the Berber Museum
Small garden. We walked to several parks and this was the only one we had to pay to get in and took the least time to go round.It was striking but small

Amazing and calm amidst the Chaos of marrakech. I came here right as they were opening, and I had the entire gardens to myself. It was very, very peaceful, and I am so glad I came in the morning- you saw them watering flowers, etc. The bright colors fit in with Marrakech, but it is a very nice place just to sit and relax. I would definitely come here again.
Cacti section a must. Go via trip and you'll spend too long in the garden or walk around it twice. YSL shop is expensive. Garden made up of plants/trees you see in other places abroad.

Very colourful and peaceful. The Majorelle gardens are so peaceful inside, it feels like you are no longer in Marrakech.
There are so many different variety of plants in the garden, it is a testament to all those who make it such a beautiful place to visit.
There was an entrance fee but it was worth paying.
Beautiful, unusual gardens. I loved the bright blue of the buildings, fountains and pots, interspersed with cacti, succulents and greenery. Take your camera!

Very interesting, but... The beauty of this interesting garden, with colourful buildings, cannot be disputed. However it was smaller than we had expected and the entrance fee seemed a bit on the steep side.

Place for excellent photos. The gardens are small but give excellent photo ops. the vivid colours in such a peaceful place are pleasurable to the eye and calming to the senses.Taxi drivers will try to charge 100 + DH from the Medina but we insisted on only paying 20 DH which was our Riad staff told us we should be paying, and the taxi driver eventually agreed.

great if you like plants. I cant say anything bad about Majorelle garden, its very pretty with some really interesting plants, but I kind of expected more from it for some reason, all the hype about the garden and when I got there it was not wowing me at all, i think if you are into plants and gardening which Im not really! then you will love it and appreciate it more, its a lovely place for old people to : )
We enjoyed Jardin Majorelle immensely. The Jardin Majorelle provided an excellent visit for 2-3 hours - a total conreast to Marrakech outside the walls of the gardens. Layout and colours were superb

Brilliant legacy. This place is a must visit. It has historic value, with beautiful plants in a lovely setting. If one wants a botanical snapshot of Morocco this is the place to go. There is an overpriced cafe and a crafts museum to see the best products available in Mororcco!

Kind of boring. It's a car ride away from the square and once you get there, it's really just a bunch of cactus type trees. It's not very large. We walked through it and were done in about 20 minutes.
overhyped. hyped as the most beautiful gardens in Marrakech, they are tiny and uninteresting takes about 15 minutes to go round at a stroll
Beautifull. these gardens are so beautifull and peacfull. It's difficult to imagine that they are so close to the main road.A must see when you are in Marrakech.

Beautiful Gardens but so over priced. These gardens were a tranquil retreat from the hustle and bustle of the city and tucked away in quite a run down area. However it was almost £5 each to enter and only takes about 10 to 15 minutes to walk around! The tea rooms inside were also well over priced and you had to pay again to enter the museum inside! Though the cacti on show were amaing to look at, they all seemed to have originated from Mexico or America - none appeared to be native to Morrocco or Africa. Most admission charges for attractions in Marrakech were a lot cheaper and offered a lot more.

Classic garden with a fine museum. The soaring bamboos at the entrance to this compact garden, restored in the 1980s by Yves Saint Laurent and his partner Pierre Berge, draw one into a walk around plants from around the world. There is a memorial to the French fashion designer and a fascinating Berber museum in the garden's cobalt blue pavillion. This only opened recently replacing the Islamic Arts museum which was there before. There is a courtyard restaurant offering a calm place to relax in an already peaceful part of this busy city. The garden's name comes from its original designer, Jacques Majorelle, a French painter.

A Unique Bit Of History. Jacques Majorelle created a garden like no other. It mixes bamboo with cactus amidst pools filled with lotus. But what is really unique is the color blue which seems to exist nowhere else. You have to see it.
Oasis of calm. Beautiful gardens, tranquil even though there were plenty of other people around. We ate in the restaurant, which was very good, excellent lemonade.

Jardin. Marginale... If you like blue.. maybe. Or cactusses. Or have a special taste wise deviation like YSL. In all other cases you'll be probably somewhat surprised by the mediocre and just sad atmosphere and sorry 'garden design'. Best of the walk down there, the visit and the way back, was the fresh orange juice we had on the lunch café just opposite the entrance.Jardin. Marginale. I would say..

A magical place, quite unique. I visited this a couple of years ago, only because it was linked to the name YSL and I was intrigued. It took some finding as it was next to a building site, but as you step through the gate, you enter a small haven of tranquility. The use of colour is quite unique. It's sort of like an art museum with plant life and garden paraphernalia instead of pictures. The cafe is also very tasteful (but expensive), and the shop has some really unusual and beautiful things on sale (good for presents for people)I will return one day, as well as the leatherworks on the edge of the city. Stinky but fascinating.

A must for lovers of nature and art!. An easy 15-20 minute walk from the Medina (or 5 minute taxi), this garden by Majorelle and house by Yves Saint Laurent is a must see. There is a beautiful museum exhibit of Moroccan culture, art, clothing and jewelry within the big blue house, and walking the grounds amongst the global selection of plants is extremely relaxing.

Disappointing but peaceful. We visited the garden in August as a break from the hustle and bustle of Marrakesh and because we were interested in its link with Yves St Laurent who owned it at one time (I think his ashes are there). Unfortunately, although there are some attractive plants and trees, the planting is unimaginative (it looks like they've just gone round sticking things in where there was a space) and the garden does not have a natural feel. It is quite small and you may well have had enough inside an hour. The link with YSL drew us in but was not made enough of in the garden itself. OK if you like cacti etc or you just want to sit peacefully outside in the shade but otherwise not worth the visit.

Pretty and quite unusual gardens. Visited this attraction which was on the hop off /on bus route.The cool colours of the setting were nice and the giant cactus were unusual but unless you are a real plant or YSL fan half an hour or so will be as long as you would want to spend here. There are other more exciting things to see and do in Marrakech.

A waste of time and money. This was a cactus garden with lots of primary colours on the walls, bridges, etc. It wasn't amazing, exciting or even unusual. I was disapointed as I knew this was ranked 3rd of Trip Advisor - but spent at most 20 minutes walking around.It would have been interesting if it were free but otherwise, it wasn't worth the taxi ride out there - let alone the entry fee.
Oasis. A beautiful oasis and welcome escape from the heat and bustle of the streets, little cafe is slightly more expensive than a normal restaurant but good service and good food.
Chilly!. Very pretty but not as big as I expected, and expensive too. I'm sure it's delightful to get out of the heat in summer, but visiting in January I was freezing!

A far cry from the desert. Previously I had only seen small cactii in pots at home, large ones in movies, or in a hothouse in the UK, so to see them so cleverly arranged in groups with contrasting shapes and sizes was an unexpected pleasure. These grounds have been thoughtfully laid out and every 20 metres there is a different "picture postcard", gorgeous view. Well worth the 50 MAD entrance fee. I think if I lived there I would want to have a season ticket. One word of caution: you expect to pay a bit over the odds in any cafe where you are a captive audience but the one in Jardin Majorelle pushes it to the limit. The cafe opposite the entrance is much more reasonable.

Magical. I visited Jardin Majorelle last month and was amazed at the beauty and tranquility. It was truly magical. I particularly loved the Berber jewellery exhibition in the museum - breathtaking! Definitely not to be missed.

Lovely little garden. Don't expect a riot of colour from flowers, this is mainly a green garden with colour coming from the painted tubs and tiled walkways. It's lovely nevertheless and a nice place to be on a hot day as it's quite shaded.

Over-rated & trading on the YSL legacy. We walked for miles in squalor, dust and heat to reach this supposedly not to be missed garden and couldn't believe what the fuss is all about! The entrance fee of 75DH was ridiculous for visiting a garden full of bamboo and cactus and a small museum with nothing to write home about. The environment is serene and peaceful, and is very well kept with lovely primary coloured walls and paths, but the YSL monument is underwhelming and there is really nothing of great interest to draw people. I think the lack of strong landmarks in Marrakech makes this an over-rated draw for European visitors.One bright spot is the nice if expensive cafe in its own walled garden with friendly staff and good food.

an oasis. Initial impression of a bamboo plantation gave way to an amazing collection of cacti in a beautifully maintained setting. Restaurant pricey but prolongs experience of escaping from hussle of the city

Home of Yves St Laurent. Beautiful tranquil gardens planed with exotic palms and succulents from Africa, South America and Asia all arranged around peaceful water features and culminating in the enchanting villa and museum to Yves St Laurent..
Simply Wonderful. I just loved this place....serene and lovely colours... dont misss, one of the few place in marrakech, were no one to sell you anything .
AMAZING. It's breathtaking. Unfortunately a lot of to-see things in Morocco are not very well taken care of but this does not go for this garden as it is owned by the French. Very beautifull to see.
Little jewel. Don't miss the Jardin Majorelle. Restored by Yves St Laurent a wonderful oasis of peace and tranquility. Magnificent shaded garden of cacti and succulents.
Nice green space in Marrakesh. A peaceful place to take in various plants from around the world. If you're into cacti this place has the widest variety of cacti I seen in addition to other plants.
Nice gardens, but not incredible. It was cool and relaxing - a nice escape from the bus streets. However it was small and fairly uninspiring.
Lovely Gardens. Nice quiet oasis in the busy city. Took a Calleche from the Square - haggled the price to 60 dm (£4.60) for a one way trip. Beautiful palms and cactus.
B A U tiful. Really beautiful gardens one of the best I have seen.Tranquil,clean and well maintained.Loved the Museum

a must. it's not that expensive, 50 Dirhmams.
you'll need to grab a cab to go there, 15 dirham MAX from city center. It's a very pleasant garden, full of cactus and other exotic trees. Becarefull, can be very crowded, the only negative point. Nice shops by the garden.

I dont get it. We went there - expecting a magical mysterious garden - and we just did not see it. Saw lots of blue painted pots and things - but really not worth going. La Mamounia's gardens were prettier - recommend going there for a lunch or tea and wandering there/
chilled out sunday morning after!. Peacefull, tranquil, lovely colour contrasts and amazing structural cacti, restaurant food very good but a little overpriced

Blue Blue Blue & Greenery. Fantastic gardens set around a blue blue blue villa. One of the best ice creams I have had in years, a vanilla ice cream with espresso coffee. My wife enjoyed the plants, that's her thing.
Beautiful!. Beautiful place, a bit small but worth visiting. I would recommend to go by carriage as you can see the new city and take great pictures.

A peaceful haven. Beautiful gardens and surroundings. You do get badgered a little from staff wanting to take photo's of you for a tip (of course). Also lots of men outside the gardens wanting your business from taxi to hot air balloon trips.
little oasis. delightful gardens, away from the noise. tranquil and very well kept. Berber exhibition is excellent and informative

The Must do. Folks let's be clear "the must do" cause you have this amazing garden with those beautiful colours every where BUT DON'T expect to much, it's nice but quickly done and some how you will be a bit disappointed, Honestly the garden is small, it doesn't change the Fact that our Beloved Yves Saint Laurent created it and that's why it's so famous ... Sam
Jardin. Lovely spot to spend an hour or tour surrounded by lush green plants and bright bright colours. Check out the berber museum inside!

Pleasant enough but I don't see what all the fuss is about. If these gardens were not associated with Yves St Laurent I doubt they would be anywhere near as famous as they are. I like to visit botanical gardens and parks in any new city I visit and I was underwhelmed with these gardens. They are not objectionable, just not notable in anyway; the gardens are quite small, not very well stocked (mostly cacti and bamboo; a few ponds and sculptures to break things up a bit) and too busy. Sorry Marrakech - we had a great time in the City, but not because of these gardens.
Interesting but not great. Very well tended garden, with lots of different cactus and basins. It's a peacefull place, goof to take a break from all the noise of the Medina.
A peaceful retreat.. A great place to go to get away from the hustle and bustle of the Medina. Beautiful grounds. It wasn't very crowded when we were there and it was very peaceful.

Something different and peaceful. Marrakech is generally hectic and the Jardin Majorelle is therefore a perfect antidote. Although it does have a cost (50 Dirhams + 25 Dirhams for the Berber Museum in January 2013) it was worth it. There are a variety of interesting plants and the decorations are stylish. The cafe is expensive but you can plan ahead and eat before/after to avoid the need.

An oasis of tranquility.. it is perfect as the last place to visit before leaving. It will refresh your senses. If there is a photograph of your holiday that you think good enough to hang on the wall, it will be from here. The colours, plants and majesty all within a relatively small garden is captivating. It is obvious that the gardeners are skilful and proud. There is also a Berbere museum within the garden, that is well worth a visit. It is small but informative with an insight into their culture and history. There is a cafe inside and plenty of restaurants outside. We loved it..

What a lovely oasis near bustling Marrakesh centre. Just go there! Small but very, very special. It's like stepping into tropic jungle and Australian Bush at the same time, combined with Yves saint Laurant and designer Majorelle's creativeness
Serene and beautiful. a small oasis - the colours and the plants are stunning - the "Majorelle Bleu" is captivating. definitely worth a visit
Nice and quiet. Very special garden with a history. But a bit expensive - when you think of all the free public gardens in the city.
An ocean of relaxation in a bustling city. It was colourful and peaceful and the cafe is highly recommended. A perfect place to take time out and rest your weary feet.
Peaceful and tranquil gardens. Want to get away from the hustle and bustle of the Medina and Souks? head for the Majorelel gardens. Beautiful and peaceful. Well worth a visit
a walk in the garden. I liked the quietness and atmosphere but thought 50 Dhms to enter was a bit too much.Very well laid out and planted and the memorial to ysl was a nice touch
Breathtaking, calm and colourful. It was breathtaking. Wonderful serenity in the midst of hustle and bustle, well worth a visit, the cactus garden was eye watering.

An oasis. For a time out from the hecticness of Marrakech - GO to Jardin Majorelle. Lovely and calming. It rained while we were there but you can stay dry under the trees. It is worth going into the exhibit inside (I think you have to pay extra for it but I remember it being a very cool exhibition).

a lost of time. we heard a lot about these jardins and rresulted in a lost of time, it is an attraction offered to be done with a carriage travel till there. do not spend senseless your money. DO NOT GO.

Comentary. Interesting, beautiful, well maintained and shows Moroccan culture.
is worth including in your script.

Nice Outing. Cactus Garden very impressive, as was YSL's paintings of Love.
Best to go early in the morning and avoid the ehat and cues.
Colorful. Quite a walk from the main square but colorful and worth 5€ entrance. Restaurant is worth a stop for mint tea.

Gasp of fresh air. Jardin Majorelle - green oasis within dusty and sandy Marrackech. A nice collection of plants all over the world. The big amusement was a banch of bamboo straws with carved hearts and names on it. Despite of low season, the garden was overcrowded.
Lovely. No words for this, if you are in Marrakech you simply must see this… The most beautiful place I've ever seen

Stunning!. The collection in the garden is so well tended that each plant looks like a work of art. The cacti are especially striking. The cool shady paths are inviting, and the informative plaques scattered here and there satisfy the curiosity. The Berber Museum attached to the garden is wonderfully presented and full of surprises--by far the best museum we went to.

Beautiful (and nice break from the Medina). We went there with 3 children (10, 10 and 12 year old) who are normally reluctant to go to "cultural" places and they were literally bowled over. All three of them metamorphosed into happy-snappers, using MP3s and an old camera to document their adventure. It was magical to see them capture images of blue flower pots, tortoises in the ponds, cats among the bamboos, and to see them marvel at the various species of cacti.They even liked the Berber museum, specially the dark room with the sparkling ceiling where jewellery is displayed.Definitely a hit with our family.(We did not try the restaurant though, which looked way overpriced. Instead we found a local café a couple of blocks away where we had delicious tajine and pastilla at a fraction of the price).

Wow!. I don't think I've ever been to a garden quite like this. The entry is a cool passage under towering bamboo, and paths take you past stunning displays of palms, cacti and other succulents from around the world. The garden is punctuated by vases, walls and pools painted either yellow or a bright cobalt blue. It was a pleasure to walk around in!
A little secret. A beautiful tranquil garden in the middle of the city. Well worth a visit. Fantastic colours, good gallery and a gift for photographers.
Delightful surroundings. We enjoyed a snack in this lovely garden environment. The service was good and the food was tasty. The staff were well trained and multi lingual.

A Jewel of Marrakech; the Serene Garden Majorelle. The Majorelle was restored by Yves St. Laurent and his life partner Pierre Berge. An Oasis of desert species, the garden is full of surprises and very old (and large) Cacti as well as palms and bamboo species rare and both ancient and newly planted. The canopy of leaves above you dapples the ground around you and creates the sensation of being somewhere you've never been except in a dream. Water features and fountains cool in the shadows and obscure the sounds of the surrounding city. There are two structures painted a startling dense blue, one a viewing pavillion and the other an exotic little building housing a Berber Museum showing St.Laurent's extraordinary collection of Berber Jewellry and Tribal Costumes. There is an excellent bookshop and photographic prints at reasonable prices. Around the back of the Museum is a courtyard cafe with excellent food and refreshments. We spent about 3 hours or more in this garden adding lunch in our reluctance to leave the place.St. Laurent was born in Africa and built his getaway home adjacent to the garden. You can glimpse it with it's fanciful turrets and terraces through the greenery. It is not open to the public. The garden requires a modest charge to visit. An absolute must.
Small but beautiful.. Beautifully presented. Well tended and not a leaf out of place. It could be a little larger as it gets quite crowded during the day.
garden. this was a lovely little haven with peace and quiet. A lovely little cafe where we enjoyed a good coffee, it also sells food.

worth a visit. Really lovely and worth a visit- fantastic shop and gallery- didn't try cafe - looked nice tho- not too dear to enter 50 dirams - very peaceful and great for photos. Quite a few tourists - but marrakech is a busy place so this seems tranquil!
Not to be missed. So beautiful and so well maintained. An oasis even if it's one of the most visited attraction. The colors, the plants will blow you away. Merci monsieur St Laurent.

nice but crowded and very small. the garden is very nice to look at but it was very crowded, even in low season. after 15 minutes we finished our round and there were not so many paces to sit and rest. the plants and the colours are amazing though

a sanctuary in busy Marrakech. Enjoyed the walk to Jardin Majorelle and wasn't sure what to expect. the memorial to Yves St Laurent was a little disappointing but the surroundings and IKEA colouring of the hard landscaping made an interreting contrast

gardens are OK, but museum is great. People in Marrakech are very proud of this garden, and it is a lovely oasis in the dusty city. But as gardens go, it's just OK. The best part of this visit was the Berber museum inside in gardens (an additional 2.50 euro). It contains several rooms of Berber artifacts that show off their culture and artistic sensibility.
YSL.... ... Have to go. Even if it's just to see the cat's trying to fish out the coy carp from the pools while the turtles sun themselves nearby!
Inspirational. Love the Berber Museum and the colours- light is spectacular for pics and all gree, blue, yellow - love it.

Cobalt Blue Oasis in Gueliz. Nice cafe, amazing cacti, cool in daytime heat. Its in the new town, but is well worth the trip from the medina. It is an oasis of calm, with carefully chosen dry-loving plants well tended amongst cobalt blue buildings, watercourses and containers. The cafe serves superb food at reasonable prices in an outdoor courtyard, or inside. The boutique is expensive. You have to pay extra for the museum of islamic art. Dont get a taxi from right outside, the drivers really ramp the price up, walk to the main road and get one there.
Lovely, quiet gardens. Good to look round, they don't take long but you can spent a couple of hours in the peace and quiet.
Not worth the trek out of the medina unless you love Cacti. Not enough variety of flowers in the actual gardens. They are also quite small so was a waste of the taxi drive from the centre of town

A garden in blue. This is a must visit! Yves Saint Laurent and his partner, Paul Berger, purchased Le Jardin Majorelle right before it was planned for an apartment development. Really a wonderful and visually exciting place! Their Berber museum is a must as well!

just boring. anti climatic... and dull.. id rather be in Hyde Park! it's just a blue building in the middle of gardens which are pretty but nothing amazing, and the blue is pretty see it from anywhere.

Stunning!. Another oasis in this otherwise frenetic city. It's a bit of a treck from the main square but well worth it. It's all vivid blues, cool greens and trickling water. Good on Yves St Laurent for taking on and preserving it! A must see

Worthwhile visit. Recommended by my trek guide. We decided to visit on the spur of the moment early in the morning and was glad as it was much quieter and serene. Maybe more picturesque in the afternoon though. 50DH for entry and another 50 for museum. Well-run and well-kept garden.The cafe has free WiFi. Delicious food at tourist prices. Nice way to enjoy the garden view/setting at end of our tour.Took a taxi to Majorelle and from Djemaa el fna Square for 25-30DH each way. 15-20 mins ride depending on traffic.
Lovely garden stroll. A slow meandering stroll through the garden takes less than an hour. Very well designed, lots of water features. We especially loved the wide variety of cactus.

Haven in mayhem!. This was delightful. We went in Jan when hardly anything was flowering, but it was still well worth a visit. Not very big so won't take too long. The museum is well worth paying the extra to go in to, very interesting
peaceful. Away from the dusty hustle and bustle of the city. yves saint laurent ashes are buried here. the small burbba museum is worth paying to go in. the small shop is rather expensive.

Photogenic garden. Yves Saint Laurent knew how to plan a garden. The blue and yellow details in the garden can be used for great photos. The red fish in the ponds also add some more color.Do not miss the berber museum, very nice.

Don't miss this amazing garden. This is a unique peaceful garden, incredible plants and bright blue buildings. Cost 50 dirham entry (about £3.50). Don't miss the posters that Yves St Laurent created each year and buy some of the postcards of them. It's outside the centre so we had to get a taxi. You need to barter or you'll be overcharged - especially by the taxis waiting outside. I ended up paying half the amount they originally asked for.

Spectacular Colors!. We stopped in after traveling back from over the otherside of the Atlas Mountains, and toured the Jardin Majorelle for about 45 minutes on Christmas Eve 2012. It was cloudy and windy, probably not the best day to visit and kind of late in the afternoon. But it was still stunning the blue is amazing! Its impecable and tranquel even with tourist all over. The wind was fun to listen too as it went through the Timber Bamboo and Palm Trees. I would make just a bit of time at the very least to see this amazing place!

Lovely oasis!. A great place to go to get away from the bustle of the old town and a nice walk into the newer parts of town (takes the best part of an hour from the minuret near the main square). Beautiful way to spend a few hours, very well maintained and a good mix of gardens and art with pieces from YSL's own collection and works as well as the tribal museum.Cafe was nice if a little expensive.

One of the most beautiful gardens I've seen. The Jardin itself is 50 DH per person to go in, which in my opinion is worth it. When you pay to go into the Jardin it is worth paying the extra 25 DH per person to go into the museum as well.The Jardin is a mass of beautiful scenery with the fountains, ponds with fishes, trees, various different cacti etc. with plenty of photo opportunities.Even my little two year old was enjoying the scenery.There is plenty of seating to sit and enjoy the views and relax in the sunshine. There is also a cafe to have a bite to eat and/or a drink, though we didn't use this.There is a little free gallery of so of Yves Saint Laurent's work in the Jardin which has some nice pieces in it. There is a shop where you can get copies of these works and some Berber themed posters, books etc.The museum contains a lot of Berber history and was very interesting. It has arrays of Berber clothing and jewellery etc. The museum is not recommended for those with small children as they do not allow pushchairs so we had to carry him.There is a Berber themed shop, though this was expensive.
Nice garden. Nice gardens, nice walk for about 30 minutes... you can grab a coffee or fresh juice in the cafes outside...
Good Museum. The Gardens are not very big but nice to visit on a clear day. Te Museum is clean and quite interesting

An excellent garden and oasis of calm. An absolutely wonderful array of cacti and succulents are the highlight but the garden contains many other excellent plants and is beautifully maintained. The little cafe/restaurant is also a good spot for lunch or tea/coffee with good food and very good service. Well worth the entrance money and a must for plant lovers.

Great pictures!. It is a pretty botanical garden made by Yves Saint Laurent. You can admire various plant types and it is a beautiful place to take nice pictures - of the place and of your friends/ family, if you like to photograph :)

Perfect blue. If there is an perfect blue, this is it. I've chosen the afternoon hours for visiting the garden, cause the light is wonderful to take photos. In January I enjoiied the silence and lonelienes 'cause of less visitors. Amazing just to sit in the garden, watch the birds and listen to this quiet place in the middle of marrakech. In the end of the garden you'll find the Memorial of Yves Saint Laurent. Café inside is also recommentable. Have lso a look inside the Peace Gallery, Library and the Boutique.
Peace and tranquility. A haven of peace in a bustling city. It could perhaps get a little crowded in the high season. We used the city bus tour to get there.
Yves St Laurent Gardens / Jardin Majorelle. tranquil, beautiful, great art gallery and a fabulous gift shop if you want very stylish gifts to take home
overvalued. The garden was nice, but I think there much fuss about nothing. It's not very special and when we where ther it was very busy

Very pretty. It's full of palm trees and other desert plants - None of the attractions take look to go around and this one is no exception. It is undoubtedly beautiful and worth a visit but not worth queuing for.

Finding Serenity in Marrakech. Jardin Majorelle is serene, unique, and beautiful. So wonderful that Yves Saint Laurent's garden and where he used to live is open to the public. You could easily spend a few hours here, just contemplating the cactus and surrounding foliage, or slowly ambling along the many pathways.

Yves St Laurent - Gardens. The gardens were very nice however I just felt they were a little over hyped. My view was also more than likely impacted by the walk up as not for the first time during our stay we witnessed diabolical brutality toward horses, mules and donkeys which although we are seasoned travellers and have seen many upsetting things really shocked and appalled us such was its severity. Morocco/Marrakesh & tour operators really need to work on this aspect as it leaves an awful lot to be desired. In addition we witnessed our 3rd out of 5 accidents during that day - pedestrians are really not considered that important it would seem. Therefore by the time we reached the gardens we were probably not in the right frame of mind to fully appreciate the gardens.
Colourful. Worth a visit but can't help thinking that without the colourful pots it would be boring. The museum within the garden on the other hand had some truly amazing displays.

Very beautiful . If you're near, you should visit. The little pathways take you round the whole garden which is brightly colored and well looked after. There is also a memorial for yves saint Lauren, and a small museum which costs an extra 25 dh each. Worth going to take photos and have a sit down in the pretty little restaurant inside !
Another aspect of Marrakech. The beautiful gardens make a startling contrast to the rest of the city. The Berber museum is a must, informative and a very imaginative layout

Wonderful garden for visit. Wonderful garden which remind us on Yves Saint-Laurent who was owner until died in 2008. Exotic trees, interesting cactuses, a lot of blue color , We enjoyed in our stay there, walking arround the garden and rest in small caffe. There is also fancy shop where you can buy some souvenirs for reasonable price. We entered with group, so fee was cheaper for 50% than you are allone.

wonderful place for some peace and a cup of tea. Even with tourists wandering around, this garden was tranquil. The Berber museum was interesting and well worth the price of entry. Cafe was busy but the cup of tea was the best we had in Marrakech
Not much to see. We were keen to see the gardens but were somewhat disappointed as they didn't live up to our expectations. Very nice though and worth a visit.
Lovely. A sight to behold. It's a nice place but they shouldn't have too many security guards - It makesit less of a garden.

Relaxing Oasis. After endless negotiations with two petit taxis to the garden we felt we deserved a few minutes of relaxation by the pond. Garden is mandatory attraction if you are in Marrakech. Beautiful place and a start contrast with the outside world. Taxi stand outside the garden.

An oasis in the middle of the city. To my taste a bit too expensive entrance fee for what you can actually visit there inside; but at least they do take good care of the place, which is in top condition, unlike many of the surrounding buildings or parks nearby.

I could have lived without it. An attraction due to the museum but for 50 dirham i could have gone without a selection of cacti and palm trees. Located outside of the Medina its a nice place to take a breath of fresh air.

Beautiful Garden. After dirty and quite aggressive Marrakesh Medina, this was really the one place I really enjoyed in this town! Nice amazing plants! Go there in the morning, when there are not so many tourists!

A bit of heaven in the madness of Marrakech. Tis garden was absolutely beautiful, amazing, lots of love and care seemed to have gone into these gardens.
Will spend longer there on my return, the restaurant looked lovely.
Just go there!. A must if you are in Marrakech. Try to go there early in the moning before it+s get crowded. Bring your camera! take your time!
Oasis of tranquility. What an amazing place, so calm so beautifull. Toatl contrast to the rest of Maraketch which is fast and furiuos.
Make sure you also visit the Berber museum. The gardens are good but the Berber museum on the grounds is fantastic. A great peek into their culture and instruments. A tad on the expensive side.
Interesting but not that great. I found these immaculately kept gardens a little over hyped. Some interesting cactus but not much else really. Not worth the visit.

Pretty, but.... The garden was pretty with vivid blue accents from the surrounding cafe, but it was smaller, quite crowded and not as amazing as I had expected (I guess I had in mind a grand botanical garden...). For the price of a cab there and the entry fee, I would have rather done something else in Marrakech. To be fair, I was there in the winter, so it's possible that the plants are more stunning in the spring or summer.

Yves Saint laurent. I was expected to visit a different kind of place : compared to European gardens , this one , little, is not special at all...but it was Saint Laurent's garden and this is enough ! You can't miss it !
Majorelle Gardens. So peaceful, and cool. The colours were fantastic, and the design so inspiring. The Boutique is worth a visit too
MUST SEE. Amazing....... so many beautiful colours and a nice getaway from the hectic busyness of the city. We spent about an hour there walking around and taking it in. It really is a must see

Nicely landscaped but largely repetitive display of cacti. We liked it most because it took us into the new city.. The adjacent restaurants and shops offered an immediate sense of what daily life must be like for people who soon become oblivious to the contrast of activity on both sides of the wall.

Yes it's good but only OK really. What these gardens are, in a relatively small space of around 10,000 sq m or 2 acres, are a bunch of cacti, palm trees and bamboo nicely mature and well tended. Around the gardens are shocking yellow, blue and ochre pots against blue walls, I thought they were horrible plastic until I examined them and found they were painted terracotta. The visitor is restricted to the pathways, these are inevitably crowded and often quite noisy which destroys the atmosphere a little (and makes taking photos a bit difficult). There are some water features and a couple of block-built pavilions, an expensive café and a museum which I didn't see. The taxi from the old town to here, waiting for the 30 minutes we were inside and returning us to the town centre cost Dh100 which was the cost of the entry to the gardens. This is €5 each which is not expensive by Western standards but is quite expensive in Morocco. Yes it was worth it but I'm not sure you would bother in an environment less boring that Marrakech.The best bit, turn right out of the exit, walk 30m until you hit the main road, turn left and 10m on your left is a brand new alcohol supermarket with very keen prices. Not easy to find beer in Marrakech so worth the trip for this alone!

Manicured gardens with colour. Once a former holiday home of Yves St Laurent, these gardens are a wonderful splash of colour with coloured terracotta pots scattered everywhere and the painted brickwork of the little waterways, contrasted by the myriad of cacti and palms in the immaculate manicured planting areas. Round a corner and you have a totally different perspective of the same view with the vivid blue of the main house and adjacent museum peeking at you from a distance. Mornings are probably the best time to wander quietly around these lovely gardens, prior to the avalanche of bus loads of tourists who seem to descend here around lunctime onwards. There is a lovely little courtyard cafe within two minutes of the main house where you can sit in the sun and have your refreshment served to you by the bustling waiters. These gardens are a must do item on your list of things to see and do in Marrakech. PS the museum is at an extra cost and is not included in your 50 Dirham entrance fee.
Little gem. Really enjoyed these gardens and was so peaceful and beautiful, although doesn't take long to walk around.

Calm in the middle of chaos!!. Jardin Majorelle is in a central location but so serine! A very pretty garden with water features, beautiful plants and lots of colour. My fiance to be honest was pretty bored but he doesn't appreciate things like I do! The house is beautiful which is now a museum, we didn't get a chance to go in as we strolled rather slowly around. Glad we went but wouldn't need to go again.
Lovely gardens. A good place to relax and enjoy all species of flora characteristics of that part of the globe. Nice coffe shop and many shadows
Worth to see. The garden is gorgeous! You could find a lot of interesting tropical plants there. You could also visit the Memorial of Yves Saint Laurent which is inside the garden.

A new town must see. If you visit the new town you must check out this garden. You can while away a couple of hours in this tranquil haven and you are not too far away from the shops and restaurants of Gueliz.
The striking rive gauche blue makes the whole garden jump out at you - a delight to the senses.
Unexpectedly bowled over. Amazing place - cacti, colours, café food, degree of care and overall experience. I am not a big garden lover but this one will stay with me for ever.

oh my god. oh my god, I thought Id died and gone to heaven, a most beautiful garden and the the most attractive cafe I have ever visited, couldnt decide whether to sit outside in the walled garden or sit inside on big fat cushiony sofas by one of several fragrant woodburning stoves- absolute heaven, service was exellant too
Perfect. Full of colours! You can't stop looking at it! You'll love the view. the plants, the cafe, the shop. Excellent
Oasis. An oasis of peace and calm and exceptionally beautiful. Not to be missed. Amazing colours and plants.

Lovely, but fairly simple garden. This garden isn't especially big, so if you've got a spare hour then you can whiz around no problem. Compared to other attractions in Marrakech I think it's fairly pricey - 50 DH.

ok if your a bit bored. Take a look if you like as there isnt much else to do and its only about a fiver to get in and it will only take about half n hour for a good look round , dont know what all the fuss is about, it didnt do anything for me, just a load of cactus and trees

Good chill time. Great garden to relax, stroll and sit down if you're tired of the hustle bustle of the souks. Fairly small, but we visited early which means it was quite and relaxing. Nice cafe to have some mint tea and a small bite to eat.

Wonderful !. It's a must in Marrakech ! It really worth the visit! It is very clean ,perfect, a lot of plants from all the world ! The blue, yellow of walls are string and green of plants make the so beautiful and peaceful place! And stop at cafe for a relaxing moment!
Peaceful, calm with beautiful colours. A lovely MUST place to visit, not very busy on January. A nice cafe (but expensive) to have a snack or drink mint tea.

go early or late to avoid the crowds. Very pleasant small famous garden, but you'll need to go either early or late to avoid the hoards who turn up around 11 am. Ni It's really worth paying the extra to go into the small but perfectly formed Museum of Berber life, which has intelligent and informative captioning ( English translations available) and good design. The 'starlight infinity room' displaying jewellery made sense for us as we has just been on a tour of the Berber Villages in the landscapes of the Atlas Mountains, and you could see how they were trying to express some sense of the almost spiritual power of the space of those landscapes. Gift shops also quite smart and high end, good cafe.

Berber Museum within the Gardens - a must visit. This is a beautiful oasis in the heart of a very busy and bustling city. Created by French designer, whathisface, and then donated to the city it is a lovely refuge. One can imagine how peaceful it must have been for the owners, a place of refuge from the sun and of amazing colour. It does get crowded so try to get their early. The best museum of Berber culture is within the gardens and is truly a must see if you visit this part of Africa. The museum has great costumes and displays explaining the lifestyles and culture of the Berber people. Please go and experience.
Cactus and palmtrees for wheelchaired people. Small garden. Good for wheelchairs. Cactus and palm trees on sand/gravel. A garden easy to keep. Nice colors of urns. Otherwise a bit boring.
A peaceful haven. I have been here a couple of times- the colours are breathtaking and the garden is well cared for. The cafe serves delicious food.

A stunning hidden garden. A must on your itinerary, the Majorelle is beautiful, original and memorable. The combination of colour, architecture and planting amount to a superb setting and be sure to relax in the attractive courtyard cafe after your visit.

And my cactus is in a pot on the window ledge. Totally amazing. We went on a tour of Marrakesh which cost a fortune - Don't do it! and the guide dropped us off at Majorelle Garden's and said '20 mins, 30 max I'll be outside' and so we whizzed round and took some photo's and left. BUT it was so beautiful we went back in our own time and spent 3 hours there enjoying the gardens, the museum and then enjoyed a light lunch which was excellent. Go early to get some really good photo's, take you time and enjoy!
lovely!. well worth a visit. a wonderful escape from the excitement of Marrakech and colors that can't be beat.

An absolute must. This small but exquisite garden once owned by Yves Saint Laurent is an absolute must. The house is painted in an eye watering blue, in contrast to the flowers and trees. There is also a small museum on Berber costume and jewellery and a pleasant cafe.

What a wonderful garden, a complete oasis is a bustling city!. The variety of plants was amazing with quiet corners for reflecting.There were many tourists from all around the world. In some ways it also seemed like a wonderful tribute to Yves St. Laurent! Nearby are a number of quaint shops and restaurants, many serving French or arabic food.
busy. very busy and over priced queued to move around felt very pressured!!! called in cafe for a drink very very expensive felt ripped off

A most magnificicent location - well worth a visit!. Mr Khalid Abou El Allam from Badrane tours brought us here on our last day (just as an added extra) and we were so thrilled that we had the opportuity to visit it. A most wonderful garden and beuatifully maintained and presented. Don't miss it !
nothing special. the garden itself is a bit disapointing for a paying entrance., the garden of our hotel was as beautiful and free. The museum inside is worse the visit (added cost).
a little bit of peace..... Jardin is beautiful, well worth the visit, a welcome break from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech..

Hope you like Cacti.... Small and not a lot of time needed to visit these gardens - and relatively expensive to enter. Restaurant inside is good but pricey.
The Yves Saint-Laurent memorial is, frankly, odd!
Would be a nightmare if it was busy.

A small garden outside the city walls.. This was a small garden, mainly of cactus and some water features. It featured a memorial to Yves st. Laurent, and had a rather expensive souvenier shop and a small courtyard cafe.
Majorelle. A little bit pricey but beautiful gardens. Would be cool in summer. Buy a ticket for the museum too. Travel to it by Calleche

Disappointing place. Nice garden, to touristic for me,,, al the painted pots and paviljons is not my style, there is nothing wrong with it but Marrakech has more beautiful gardens in the city, even free entrance
A haven of tranquility. An opportunity to escape the hustle and bustle of old town Marrakech. Beautifully designed gardens and well explained. The cafe is also a delight.

Too crowded the day we visited. On previous visits the Jardin was almost empty and was a serene delight. Unfortunately on the December 29th this was far from the case. However despite the teeming crowds it was still lovely - the blue of the garden buildings is like Klein blue. The cacti are fantastic. But go on a quiet day
Designer Gardens. This is one of the most beautiful and immaculate Gardens we have ever visited. Well worth spending an hour or so.

Lovely and peaceful. What a find a little peace of tranquillity in such a bustling City,
So vibrant with all its coloured pots. What a joy to sit by the water and just watch the fogs on the lilypads and the turtles sunning themselves.

Not really worth the visit. Depending of course on where you are staying, these gardens are a real trek out on foot especially in the heat. They are expensive to get into, and are just a small garden with mainly south american plants that people have damaged by carving their names in them. Marracesh is a beautiful little city and has much better places to go if time is of the essence. Quite and tranquil but not worth the money or time it takes to get there.

SAME AS HOME (Southern California). If you are from California, would avoid this place (in the Winter) as a) there were quite a few people here (too crowed to find a set anywhere, wait in line to take a picture in a certain place, find a quite relaxing area by ones self), b) the food was WAY overpriced (3 - 4 X what you pay in the medina), and c) same botanical plans as one has at home in Southern California (desert plants and water ponds and bamboo - with lots of people's names carved in them). Disappointed with what one go for the high price (50 DAR each, vs 10 DAR each for other attractions). Look, this is a memorial to YSL and yet they have YOU pay to visit here .. .

Nice garden, but overpriced. The garden is a peaceful oasis containing exotic plants. For people who haven't traveled much, it might be nice to see cactuses, philodendrons, and water lilies all in the same place. But if you've seen them all in their native habitats, the garden doesn't really offer a unique experience. It is rather pricy (5 euros) for a 15 minute walk-through.

A brief respite amongst the heat and bustle. It is a bit of a walk out of the old town to reach the gardens but not unmanageable. Those less keen on walking could consider taking a taxi or one of the many horse drawn carriages. Having faced the endless onslaught of speedy motorcycles, the bust station and the mayhem of an African city, the gardens are both tranquil and restorative. We spent a happy couple of hours there and I particularly enjoyed seeing some of Yves San Laurent's annual card designs.

The no 1 must-see of Marrakech. We visited Jardin Majorelle just after Christmas, and although this is the winter season the garden was so beautiful. The colors and the design of the place are magnificent, and the spot allows a wonderful respite from the busy street life of Marrakech. The exposition with YSL posters is great, as is the (exclusive) gift shop and the great book shop. Extra plus for a top lunch restaurant; we had soup and pastilla and enjoyed every bite. The tea menu is extensive as well.

Jaunt along the Jardin!. The Jardin Marjorelle was enjoyable to wander round but was a little pricey for what you got. The garden itself was very pretty but too much of the same stuff. i.e. muchos cacti! Worth a visit but better attractions if you have limited time. Extra for the museum within...cheeky! Plenty of horse and carriages outside though if you fancy a casual saunter home!
Wonderful Gardens. The Gardens are beautifully landscaped, the water features and the colors of the containers and buildings are vibrant blue and yellows. Truly a feast for the eyes.
