Interesting but not a must see. This walled garden is worth a visit because of its 'design' and of course history. There is a museum on the site but entrance fee is not included in the entrance fee for the park itself.

December visit. A lovely garden, but a little way out, we took a caleche from the medina. The garden is quite small and I imagine could get very crowded so I would advise getting there early. Amazing colours. We didn't go to the museum, but I wished we had after having a little peak in. There is a well organised taxi rank outside if you need to go on elsewhere.

Mini kew garden. this is a small garden of well kept plants, a small kew gardens which is nice and peaceful. outside it is a rank of horse carriages which makes it a location of 2 things to do. entering the park costs 50dhirims each which is about £4.50p

Small but beautiful garden. Full of tourists, but really pretty garden. No monkeys that we saw - may have been wrong to expect that - but a really nice gift shop, book store, and art gallery showcasing the garden's history.
Great garden. A must see garden, very peaceful with a wide range of different plants. The restaurant is a bit expensive but very good and makes a relaxing break from the rush of the city center.
Very pretty. It is a very well kept Garden and well worth taking a look at. Not expensive to get in and value for money
a peak at excellence. beautifully laid out garden with open spaces, wide variety of cacti, cool shaded walks - breath takingly beautiful

Small elegant garden with interesting Berber museum. Arrive early before the mass of tourists and wander around this small garden and wonder at the collection of palms, cactus and flowering plants (e.g. plumbago, jasmine etc ). Then visit the Berber museum to see a really interesting collection of everyday things from Berber life; from clothes to utensils
Photogenic. Beautiful, tranquil place. Full of colour and photo opportunities. A must see in Marrakech.The afternoon is a good time to catch the best light for pictures.

Just beautiful.. The jardin majorelle is a beautiful oasis in the centre of marrakech. It has wonderful plants and fantastic brightly coloured and ornately carved buildings. The mint tea in the tea room there is fantastic also and the service is great. Well worth a visit and a walk around, somehow seemed peaceful even with all the visitors.
Outstanding garden. The diversity and beauty of this garden is breath taking. A true Moroccan delight. (Thanks to the late Yves St. Laurent and his partner, Peter Borje)
Beautiful. This is a really pretty place worth checking out. The gardens are serene with lots of interesting spots. There is a cute little gift shop too.
A nice escape!. Not to be missed! This is the prettiest garden I have ever been to, because of the good balance and harmony.
quiet clean air and beautiful museum. enjoyed the serenity and fresh air amidst the very bad pollution of the city. the berber museum is also very informative and pleasant to visit.

A nice hour spent without too much hassle. A calm oasis in a very busy environment and free from the constant hassling by people wanting to sell you something or drive you somewhere. The gardens have been beautifully restored and many plants were identified and their country of origin shown.There is an extra fee to be paid to see the museum. While it is small it is very interesting. The gift shops were beautiful, but horrifically overpriced! This is a small place, and the visit shouldn't take more than an hour overall.

Touristy but still nice.... You can't really come to Marrakech without visiting the Jardin Majorelle. Touristy though it is (visit early in the morning or late before closing to avoid the tour bus crowds, or go in the low season), the gardens are lovely, and great for a breather from the hectic fun of the souk and the Medina. There's an excellent new museum of Berber artefacts which has just opened. Also the shop has much more products from local craftsmen and women than before. The cafe garden is lovely, and is sprayed with fine jets of water in the hot season.
My favourite visit in Marrakech. Beautiful, peaceful and extremely photogenic gardens - but why oh why can't they put labels on the amazing trees!
Small but in Style. Not a big garden so if you expect anything like the Kew Garden scale, you will be disappionted. But it was still a lovely place full of colour and style,which worth visiting!

Well designed and colourful garden. Marrakesh has a lot of gardens, but Jardin Majorelle was a nice surprise. The garden is filled with cacti, palm trees and bamboo. It is nice to walk around, take a look at the Yves Saint Laurent memorial, relax, and watch the fish and turtles swim in the little pond.

Stunning gardens. We visited several of the public gardens in Marrakech and although you have to pay for this one it is well worth it. In such a chaotic city this is a haven of tranquility and order. Go visit.
Tranquil and Calm. The Gardens are well worth a visit but are not very big, we had lunch there which was excellent and not too expensive
Breathtaking. A veritable oasis. A must see for only a small entrance fee. Bold bright colors along with cool waters. Wow

small & boring. overpriced, went round the whole thing in around 10minutes,
its pretty.... but should be free, maybe nicer in summer,
Beautiful. Amazing gardens. A real gem hidden away in the centre of this bustling city. A visit to the Berber museum is a must, along with lunch in the cafe there.

A place to relax. A calm oasis in a very busy environment and free from the constant hassling by people wanting to guide you somewhere. The gardens have been beautifully restored and many plants were identified and their country of origin shown

interesting... but.... the garden is nice and has lots of different cactus's everywhere and desert plants etcits a bit of a rip off and you also have to pay more to see the museum. id reccommend going to see it thoughHOWEVER, it lies outside the medina so you have to take a bus/ taxi.... or walk (dont as it will take a long time/effort)

Small garden - a mix of art and plants. We enjoyed the garden as part of a garden tour. Designed by French artist Majorelle. There is a little extra to pay for a small museum and gallery which we thought was worth it.
Nice, but smaller than expected. The Jardins are really unique, really a nice place to visit. But you'll be done within an hour (unless you are truly interested in all the plants on display)

Very nice escape, beautiful. We hesitated to pay 50dh to enter as its not that big, and seems a bit pricey by Moroccan standards, but were pleasantly surprised. The gardens are intriguing, calming, peaceful and packed with exotic plants, colourful pots and shady pools. If you are a photographer you'll love the colours. It wasn't too busy when we went so this no doubt added to the ambience; it may be a bit hectic in the height of season. Easy walk from all areas of the medina. Tip, avoid the touristy restaurants outside, there are plenty of better choices nearby.

Tranquil respite ("Golden Castle"). Very well maintained for Marrakech - the grounds were clean, the plants beautiful, especially the cacti. Could hear birds and breathe relatively clean air - a nice break from from the moped exhause, noise and pestering by the merchants of Medina Marrakech. It sort of makes you feel sorry for the people of Morroco that it seems the most beautiful diversions from the native culture were created as walled off mansions built by the French. Nice to have these jems, but it does emphasize the divide between the haves and have-nots. My children feel very, very fortunate to be born in a country with so many conveniences unheard of in the rest of the world. The walk from Medina Marrakech to this garden emphasizes this...
Worth a visit.. It's a really beautiful and tranquil garden, perfect for a short getaway from the busy and dusty streets of Marrakech.
Brilliant colors. Very nice exotic garden with wonderful colors. An interesting museum about Moroccan life is included.
Beautiful gardens. A tranquil area of gardens, a good time to visit in December as not so many visitors in the busy season suggest go early.
Bliss. If you want a little peace before your trip to the chaos of the souks, or to chill out afterwards, this is the perfect place to go.
A little heaven. Definitely one of the highlights of my trip to Marrakesh. Beautiful, elegant and peaceful. When you can't take the chaos of the crazy Moroccan streets anymore, it is an ideal escape.
Sweet. Cactus city or what? Excellent exhibition in the Berber museum in the grounds....must see! Yves san Laurent influence obvious and colourful...shop items a little too pricy
Peaceful hide away. Lovely garden but soemtimes a bit full of tourists. Away from the hustle and bustle. Imagine nice and cool in the hot summer

Peaceful and cool oasis in the heat. The colourful pots took my fancy. The plant collections beautiful. Many cactus blossoms to photograph. LOVELY to visit a garden in the middle of a hot desert like Marrakech. Much better than the Menara gardens.

Nice enough gardens. It was pretty but don't expect too much . The gardens are not that big - we had expected more given the hype. Very pretty but not as great as we had expected. The berber museum was the highlight for us.
So nice we went round three times. Very peaceful, very well tended and one of the nicest gardens we've visited. We were recommended by a friend of ours and thoroughly enjoyed it.

Serenity in Marrakech. Beautful gardens, was concerned as all the guide books said it was expensive so nearly didnt go - took a taxi from hotel and it cost 50 dr to enter just over £3 so was not expensive. The gardens were beautiful however many security staff lurked around each and every corner not sure what they were expecting. You couldnt spend too much time here - no more than an hour as it isnt big, but it is not too far from the square if you dont have time to do one of the other half or full day tours - was well worth the visit.
Mind boggling. These gardens are out of this world much better than we expected. There is a memorial to Yves st Laurent which must be seen.

It's okay but worth a visit. Former art studio, then belonged to Yves Saint Laurent, then turned over to Morocco and made into a "place to visit". Colorful, cost to get in (I thought it was free), some cool things in the museum...might as well pay for garden and museum. Some of the available for purchase seemed way overpriced.
A necessary break. In the pollution of Marrakech, the Jardin Majorelle is a literally a breath of fresh air. For those that will stay more than two days, it is worth a visit.
To avoid with a bus of 100 persons.... Nice place, we thought it would be quiet, but when the bus stopped with about 100 persons following their guide, next time perhaps...

Beautiful even in Winter. We spent a very pleasant morning here recently after walking from the Medina. On the way we were advised by a "helpful" local that the gardens were closed. Thankfully we are aware of this ploy and ignored him completely. It cost 150 dirhams for two of us to visit the gardens and the museum.A very peaceful and enjoyable experience and I am sure that in the height of the summer heat it will be an oasis of cool.Good cafe in teh grounds as well.
Beautiful Gardens!!. Amazing gardens. Also visit the Berber museum, which has the history of the Berbers, the native Moroccan people.

Enchanting. These gardens were truly beautiful. Although in December not a vast amount of colour from the plants, the ambience within the garden was magical! A very restful, relaxing place. Exquisite!
This is a Marrakech Must.. The garden was created by Jacques Majorelle with plants that you rarely see in Marrakech. Everything is painted a special blue that is now associated with the artist.

Best garden in Marrakech. Amazing and very tranquil. You have a choice to visit either garden or garden and Berber museum. We went only for garden. Don't think I have seen a place like that before.Would love to return again. Place kept very well. Please be aware in summer months this will be extremely packed so go early in the day.

average. it is definitely beautiful once you are in! however it is kinda remote if you decide to walk, especially if it`s +38 degrees in a shade! nothing special though if you are not a plant lover. some staff member were quite rude as well! not worth the entrance fee!
Wonderful Oasis. Put this on the list of places to visit--the gardens were beautiful and the museum on of the best curated in Morocco.
Very pretty. Not a huge garden, but very exotic and pretty none the less, nice hiding place from all the hustle and bustle of the city.

Yves Saint-Laurent garden... Absolutely beautiful garden. Had all morning before flying back to London so I took a horsecart ride to this rather stunning looking Jardin Majorelle (north of the old town). Splendid collection of cactus, Japanese bamboo trees, and plenty of strong blue, yellow, orange and other colours everywhere... The house is stunning with strong blue colour, and you will find the YSL design of "Love" in a back of the house... Definitely a worth spending few hours here... Strongly recommended.
YSL - Jardon Majorelle. The gardens were amazing and contained plants from all over the world. The water features were so beautiful that we are considering their design for our home.

Oasis in the Gueliz area. We walked her from the Medina area, got lost, were redirected by a local. Beautiful, peaceful gardens, employs locals to keep it up (great!); has a terrific little restaurant. Berber museum in the grounds so-so. Nice little gift shop.

A peaceful haven. An amazing respite from the hussle and bustleof the Medina, beautiful cactus gardens, an excellent but expensive restaurant, the berber museum is very well worth the visit most instructive and interesting

A beautiful Oasis in Marrakesh. During our stay in Marrakesh we visited Majorelle Garden which is one of the beautiful oasis in Marrakesh.The garden has been open to the public since 1947.Accoring to our guide it hosts more than 15 bird species that are endemic to North Africa. It has many fountains, and a notable collection of cacti.

A nice break from the souks. This garden is sublime and beautiful, and the way they've painted the buildings to contrast with the plants is very eye-catching. The Berber museum is well worth taking in, to gain an appreciation of this unique culture.

worth the detour. A little chilly in the shade in november,must be wonderful in the summer,wished I had a camera as the colours were amazing.Know nothing about plants but still enjoyed it.Gift shop expensive

Jardin Majorelle Yves St Laurent. An interesting garden but probably not big enough to wander about in for long. There were many tropical plants set in behind brilliant blue planter boxes. A nice achievement but nothing startling.

Disappointed. I've wanted to visit the Majorelle Gardens for years - since I first read about them, and fell in love with the idea. Perhaps my expectations were too high, but this was the most average of all the gardens we saw in Morocco. The entry fee was expensive, the gift shops uninspired (they were selling prints of Persian tilework in the Berber museum shop - this seemed patronising, and quite absurd), the pond seemed cloudy, and nothing was quite well cared for enough. Possibly it's also a taste thing - the famous Majorelle blue didn't thrill me as I'd thought it would; it seemed to wash out the sky (how do you make the Moroccan sky look BAD?), and it greyed the skin of everyone I photographed against it. The Berber museum is small but well displayed. We liked the little alcove with YSL's yearly 'love' posters. Otherwise it sort of felt like we'd wandered into an 80's primary colour fashion shoot, but not in a good way. All in all, not the fabulous we were expecting.
Wonderfull. Beautiful garden, superb layout and plant collection. Museum is interesting.Well worth the visit - take your camera
Jardin Majorelle. This was a lovely place to visit. Perfect for photographers and worth a visit. Lots of blue and yellow everywhere amongst the palms and plants, making it look really peaceful.

A colorful oasis in the city. This is a beautiful, colorful garden with water features and a Berber museum. Stop a spend time at the pond and look for the turtles. They were fascinating to watch. The museum was the coolest museum I've been in. Its small but very effective. I really enjoyed the room where the jewelry was displayed.

Tranquil oasis in the middle of Marrakech. This is an expensive 30-60 minute activity. 50 Dirhams per person, plus 25 more if you want to see the Berber Museum. It's the most expensive tourist attraction in the city.The gardens themselves are small. Very beautiful, but you don't need more than 30 minutes to see the whole thing. The Berber Museum is absolutely tiny, and entirely in the French language, except for a handful of panels written in English. Don't bother with the Museum. It's a total waste of money.There is a small café inside the gardens. It is a pleasant environment for some relaxation. However, the prices are horrendously expensive for what you get. And the food is not very nice. They have a captive tourist audience and they take full advantage knowing that they will never see these customers ever again so why bother with decent food?There is a Yves Saint Laurent Memorial inside the gardens. It's just a 3 foot concrete column on a plinth. Totally underwhelming. There is also something called the 'Galerie Love' inside the garden, dedicated to YSL's art. Again, underwhelming.There is also a gift shop next to the 'Galerie Love'. This is perhaps the biggest rip-off of them all. Even something as simple as a candle can cost 30 Euros! Disgraceful gouging.And outside the gardens you will be harassed VERY aggressively by taxi drivers and people selling counterfeit wrist watches. You have to be quite rude to get them to leave you alone as they will persistently follow you down the street even if you totally ignore them!Overall - Definitely not worth visiting this place unless you want to tick it off your list. Don't bother with the Berber Museum and you should probably avoid buying any desserts from the café as they are awful and expensive.

Pretty, but not special.. It's a very small area in the middle of Marrakech. There are beautiful cacti and the Yves Saint Laurnet memorial is there, but aside from that it wasn't really worth the 50dh to get in.
peace and tranquility. an oasis in the middle of the hustle and bustle of marrakesh well worth a couple of hours 150 dirhams each for garden and museum

Over hyped and quite pricey for a small place. Not as big as I imagined or saw in the pictures! Could miss it if you're not on your way. Mostly lovely catus plants in all shapes. Didn't visit the museum so I have not comments.

Peaceful retreat in Marrakech. beautiful garden is a pleasant retreat from the busy Marrakech medina. Quite peaceful and relaxing spot. The museum isn't really worth it, so spend some extra time enjoying the garden beauty.

Time out of the madness. Make sure and make time when in marrakech, to visit these gardens. A delightful oasis of calm and colour. You'll be bowled over by the blues and yellos surrounding you . The cafe there too is lovely , not cheap (400dhs for a pot of tea) but worth it for the sake of your feet! The gardens aren't big so it won't take you long to get around it. The Berber museum is interesting also. Plenty of aces to stop and have a wee rest in the way around. Gardens are beautifully tended .

Great way to spend an hour. Lovely tranquil gardens, very pretty and well kept - nice photo opportunity, entrance fee 50 dirham per person so don't be conned into an organised trip for 250 dirham (unless of course you want a guide)
a bit of peace from the hustle and bustle. Beautiful gardens and memorial to Yves Saint Laurent. Short taxi ride from the main square. Well worth a visit for only 50 dirhams entry per person.
Beautiful & peaceful. These gardens are beautiful and a must do if you are in Marrakech. However do not expect to spend longer than 1 hour as there isn't too much to see.

Tranquillity in Marrakech. We went in October, and its well worth a visit, very realaxing away from the madness of the city take a taxi there, dont ask them to come back for you, as there are loads waiting outside the gardens. Sweet little cafe within the grounds, perfect for a spot of mint tea - very good souvenir shop, and the Berber museum is unmissable.
Heaven in a busy city!. This is THE place to find some rest and peace of mind in a city which is very noisy and crowed!!!Everything here is amazing, from the colours to the flora!

A haven of peace...a "must see" !. Les jardins Majorelles are located in Bab Doukkala ,between the old Medina (old city) & the more recent buildings, right near the old walls. An incredible haven of peace & freshness , with exotic trees , bamboo , flowers & even a museum , The combination of the Majorelles blue colour & the green plants & trees is a pure joy & adds to that zen feeling ..Absolutely recommended to take a break from the hustle & bustle of the city ..

Overpriced entrance fee. While the gardens were lovely; we felt the entrance cost was high, given the fact that little museum inside on Berber culture was not included and was extra cost. Gardens are quite small.
A Peaceful Garden. A unique garden, fascinating collection of Cacti, bamboo and palms from around the world - a very peaceful surroundings, Nice food in the restaurant. Well worth a visit.
Barely worth it :-(. Nice garden but very small. Mostly limited to cacti and bamboo. Very poor coffee shop, miserable waiting staff. Wouldn't recommend.
Oasis in the middle of hectic Marrakech. Stunning gardens in the middle of Marrakech, it wont take long to walk around them but its def worth a viist!!

Jardin Majorelle. Fantastic place to visit - absolutely beautiful and serene. The Berber museum was also fantastic with some lovely exhibits although there is a small fee (around eight pound for four people). A must do visit if staying in the vicinity of marrakech.

Very pretty & quiet but don't plan more than 45 minutes here. The gardens are lovely, and of course, it is a breath of fresh air, stepping into the quiet from the busy Marrakech street. However, it is small. Very small. We planned a half day for the gardens and we were through in under and hour.

Fantastic and well worth it!. This was such a beautiful and tranquil visit, a real break from the hussle and bustle of the city. The place is kept in great condition and there are plenty of plants to look at. The real highlight is the strong blue and vibrant yellows, that fill this garden. Pleased we visited and would strongly recommend!

Best garden in Marakesh. Delightful haven of peace and tranquility - a definate lynot to be missed, a must do. In area, not large but the layout ,cleverly using coloured archtectural structures and water creates a very special atmosphere.

Beautiful, but.... This garden and the accompanying museum were so beautiful and well-kept that I was compelled to rate this destination as excellent. Be prepared, however, for large tourist crowds, pushy staff, and a garden full of plants from abroad.

A beautiful place to spend an afternoon. Beautifully maintained gardens which are well worth a visit as an escape from all the madness!
The Berber Museum is also worth the small admission fee (d25) but shouldn't take more than 20 minutes to get around.

lil bit expensive , but worth to visit. a garden where you can enjoy taking pictures with deffirent kind of plants , everything went great , the only bad thing was the entrance fee , 30 moroccan dirhams is awful.
Anyway , worth to be there .

Splendid Garden. It worths to spend one or two hours in walking around this splendid garden. The walls, stairs, doors and columns are painted in blue and yellow which looks gorgeous. The garden is maintaining well. You can find various types of cactus and plants all around. The Berber museum is informative.

so pretty. amazing place to spend some time with your friends who love greenery, colors and art. If you are into photography you will love the variations of shapes, colors and plants. Loved it. Very soothing place. A Treat for your eyes and soul.

Nice break but nothing to blow your mind. probably the best thing to do in Marrekesh of an evening. There are no picnic or green rest areas in these gardens - mainly walk through. Can complete in a leisurely hour. Overall 6/10 rating even though I haave an interest in gardens. Do it if you have an idle morning or afternoon - but not if you don't.

Stunning Gardens. A quick trip outside of the Medina brings you to the Majorelle Gardens. Designed by the late Yves Saint Laurent, the garden is not big, but what it lacks in size it certainly more than makes up for in 'wow' factor. Whilst the planting comprises for the most part bamboo (rustling gently in the warm breeze) and a myriad of cacti and succulents, you are not left wanting for colour. The pots and buildings are painted in the richest of hues: yellow, terraccoto, mauve and of course the stunning Majorelle blue itself. I defy you not to want to bring something home in that colour alone after having visited the gardens. Take light refreshments at the restaurant or visit the Berber museum. We took a caleche (horse-drawn carriage) to the gardens but walked back to the souks after.

Don't miss the Musée Berbère. Enjoy the Jardin Majorelle, but don't miss the Musée Berbère if you have any interest in the arts and crafts of Morocco's original inhabitants. It's a beautifully presented display of artefacts from the many tribes who live on and around the Atlas mountains, clearly described in French, English and Arabic. It also gives you a good idea of what's real and what's not if you go shopping later in the Souks. There's a good little illustrated guide you can buy on your way out - no need for it in the museum as it repeats what you're told in the captions.Well worth the extra 25 dirham on the admission price to the Jardin Majorelle.

Le jardin extraordinaire. After having entered to the garden, we have an impression to be in a rainforest (I've never been) Very green and very nice bamboos and exotoc trees, flowers everywhere. Very well kept. Incredibely nice and colored potsherds. Even the light is missiong sometimes, you defintiely need to have a good camera to take nice pictures, even for my iphone it was sometimes too dark. In the garden you have the Berber Museum where you can find out how people lived couple os centuries ago. The shops in the Garden are highly priced, the caffe of the museum is not the cheapest neither, but the it has a small teracce garden, very cosy and symphatic. When finished, just take a "caleche" you can find them next to the garden. If you go to the MEdina, eg. Jemaa el Fna, don't pay more then 120 dirhams. We paied 150, but asked the driver to take a small tour of the medina walls and it was like if you would hired a professional guide. Our driver knew everything about the town, and was able to looking at the map, while horses ran alone....you have to try it!!
Tranquil. A lovely peaceful and tranquil place to sit and enjoy the plants, cacti etc. There was a memorial stone to Yves St Laurent who had a lot to do do with the garden

Beautiful Gardens. Majorelle gardens are beautiful but very small, Its has interesting history and the Berber museum and coffee shop are good too, we spent an hour here as we spotted afew bollywood stars, you don't need to come with a guide, then you can leave early / late at your own leisure.

If you never saw a cactus in your life.... Having been to Mexico, well... I was expecting more diversity. 80% of the plants come from Mexico. Still, there is a very nice harmony to this place and we took beautiful pictures.
A little bit of peace. A stunning garden and a wonderful cafe, gives just a moments peace from the hectic hustle and bustle.

Must see for garden lovers. Despite the crowds it attracts, these gardens somehow manage to retain an air of tranquillity and charm. The vivid colours of the pots and water features attract most attention but plant lovers will also find plenty to interest them in the collections of cacti, succulents and palms which are beautifully presented amid immaculate brushed gravel beds. If you are in Marrakech and have any interests in gardens you must go!

Very nice gardens indeed!. Our taxi driver was like, shall I wait for you? because you will be out in 15-20 minutes maximum! He does not know what he's talking about :)If you enjoy photography this is a little haven, should we say. Walking around the very calm gardens and looking for the details. We were there for a good couple of hours at least. After we completed our visit we then also continued to have a mint tea in the cafe within the gardens as well. Certainly recommend.

Tranquility amongst the madness. This garden is the perfect place to find peace and quiet within the madness that is Marrakech. It is so beautiful with the overflowing vines and flowers and the Yves Saint Laurent memorial. There are so many little twists and turns with something to see at every curve (my favourite led to the small cafe that served the most delicious Orange Blossom ice cream).
exotic and blue. slightly off the beaten track - this is a small but exquisite garden - worth seeing for the bright blue motif everywhere!

Hidden garden. I would defiantly go and visit this amazing garden. The colours and plants are amazing.
The small museum is also worth a visit.
Have a quick lunch at the cafe and watch the food go by.

calm amid chaos. This place is an oasis of calm in the midst of the madness which is Marrakech. The colours of yellow, blue and green are fabulous. The gardens are immaculate and the cacti are just fantastic. A superb restaurant/cafe and with a log fire in the swalon in case it's chilly. This is a place you MUST visit.

A great oasis of calm. A lovely way to spend an hour or two away from the hustle and bustle of the main square. Very photographic gardens, good quality lunches (although a little pricey) and informative small museum

Beautiful. I loved walking around the garden and taking pictures. There are a lot of scenic views and it is very relaxing. There are also a lot of exotic plants so I would recommend that you take a couple of hours.
Beautiful garden in Marrakech. This is a nice garden in Marrakech with many different and exotic flowers. I also enjoyed the little islamic museum. very interesting.

Beautiful oasis. What a magical colourful little place in the far corner of a mad city! definitely worth a visit. there's also a cafe and little shop - we didn't try them but they look quite up market and nice but set in this amazing bright blue art deco building nestling in the cacti and walkways. look out for the turtles in the main pond!
A peaceful oasis.. I liked the visual mix of plants and design plus the new Berber museum. I didn't like the manner of the staff.
Beautiful Garden. This was a beautifil garden in Marrekech. There was also a decent little shop with soaps, scarves, etc.There is a memorial stone for Yves St. Laurent
was very charming. nothing not to dislike about this garden.You could walk round at your pleasure .Toilet clean and they sold a nice cup pf coffee and they did not rush you

Lovely but small. If you have time, go. If not, you are not missing too much. Yes it is very beautiful & well maintained. The deep blue seen everywhere added to the peacefulness & was comforting. The gardens, cactus etc...just lovely. However, it seemed small to me & doesn't take long to explore. And by Marrakech standards, entry was expensive (50 dirhams plus an extra 25 if you want to visit the museum). Go if you can but don't worry at all if not. Also, do not dine at the cafe there. I had been forewarned that it was pricey and not worth it. I didn't dine but glanced at a menu as i walked past. Pricey, yes. And after the delicious bargains to be found in the medina i just couldn't bring myself to eat there. Touristy eateries usually serve mediocre food.

Beautiful Garden. A nice little oasis, a bit far out but worth a visit, and there is an amazing shop just opposite on 33 Majorelle with great, properly handmade gifts. The Garden shows succulents at their best.

Lovely but try to avoid peak hours. My visit to this beautiful garden was slightly marred by the pure number of tourists there, which, apart from anything else, made it very difficult to take photographs. I would recommend going early to avoid the crowds.
Oasis of peace and quite. the colours and greenery are fantastic. there is peace and quiet even though outside the walls are busy roads.a must see if you are in Marrakech
Cactus heaven. Plants from around the world in a peaceful setting with wonderful colours and the light from the sun pearing through the leaves of the overhead plants.
not to be missed. The gardens are beautifully maintained. Everything is lovely, variety of plants from all continents. A must during your visit to Marakech!

Peaceful retreat... From the mad rush and noise that is Marrakech. Relatively small so can get quite full of tourists. You will remember the "majorelle Blue" colour for the rest of your stay.Expensive boutique inside and small book shop.

Top attraction of Marrakech!. My boyfriend and I went to the Majorelle Garden on our first day in Marrakech. It was one of our best experiences in Marrakech. The garden is not very big, but lovely. The blue and yellow colors of the buildings, bridge etc. made it a magical experience, typically Moroccan. I wore an orange dress and the contrast of the colors led to wonderful photos. Also, the Museum of Islamic Art is absolutely worth the visit. What I find strange is that it's not really a muslim museum. It should be called ''the Berber Museum'', because it focuses completely on the Berber culture. Nevertheless, the museum was great! There is one room with Berber jewellery and when you stand inside it's like you see millions of stars in a black sky. Very impressive!

Tranquility - Luxury - not to be missed. The gardens are just a joy, with every view considered, we saw turtles, frogs, water lilies, so many textures of planting. But the greatest surprise was the Berber Museum, made of sandalwood walls, air conditioned - again just fabulous
Great afternoon visit. We spent a couple of hours here and was impressed with how smart, clean and welcoming these gardens are. Nice little oasis in a mad city.
Well worth a visit. Really unusual garden and a real calm oasis in a busy town. It is very shady and one of the best green spaces around.
The most perfect garden.. Garden is amazing, not like anything I have seen before. Really calm and serene place despite being quite busy. Great little cafe, good coffee. Food good too!

great colours for photos. The gardens seemed a bit 'tired', but it was nice they had signs that showed where the plants originally came from. But the contrasting blues ans yellows made for great photos against the greens of the plants.

Felt disappointed. We read a lot of things about this garden and felt disappointed. 2 buses arrived at the same moment, we stayed only 30 minutes there, ticket is really expensive, we saw a lot of other "free" gardens more exciting like Koutoubia or Cyber park.
charming garden. charming garden iside of the hectic Marrakech. Nice to do soemthing completely difefrent and calming
Musée Berbère - very well done. Do not miss the little museum while in the Jardin Majorelle, this is very interesting exhibit of artifacts that explains the mountain tribes...
Beautiful. Small gardens but very well maintained and a pleasent change from the hustle and bustle of the Medina.

Must see. This garden is magical. Yves St. Laurent garden near his Palace.
Take a mini taxi from the Medina for 20dh and spend at least an hour!
Lovely place. We didn't stay long but what we did see of the gardens were very nice a very tranquil place to visit
Beautiful. Not a traditional Morrocan garden but well worth a visit. Large quantities of cactii and succulents from around the world and some great photo opportunities.

interesting place. lots of cactus and beautiful blue garden by YSL, it's in the new town so you also get to see the difference compared to the medina side. it's not super large so you can finish within an hour

Overrated. Compared to the rest of the sights in Marrakech, the entry fee is expensive, and it isn't worth it. The gardens are small and average but well kept. Nothing special. The cafe is overpriced too, as is the gift shop. The museum is okay, you have to pay extra, but you may as well pay as it is the most interesting part of this place.

Exotic Garden and Fabulous Museum. The garden is lush and beautiful, with quirky features like a memorial to Yves Saint Laurent, who donated it to the foundation which maintains it for public use. The surprising gem of the garden, however, is the tiny but gorgeous Musée Berbère, which has an exquisitely presented collection of Berber crafts, clothing and (especially!) jewelry.
Nice tropical garden. It's nice, it's tropical, it's rather expensive, It's very crouded (even 15' after opening ) ... Maybe an alternative if you're looking to escape from the real Marrakech ....

Nice Gardin. The 50 Dirham entrance fee is quite steep, compared to the genenral price level in Marrakech as you can buy a decent dinner for that kind of money, but that being said, the garden is very nice. Even if you don't know all the trees by name or are interested in the names, the design is very nice. The Yves st Laurent Blue gives you an opportunity to calibrate your camera!

A bit disappointing. Lovely gardens in immaculate order and a welcome break away from the madness of Marrakech. Interesting artefacts in the museum. You can pay for just the gardens with the extrs cost option for the museum.A little expensive for what you get & not sure i would bother with the museum bit again.
Wow!. What a wonderful oasis of tranquility in the bustle of Marrakesh. Stunning collection of plants in an amazing setting - a must to visit,

Interesting Gardens. We enjoyed our visit to the gardens, loved the Cacti section. Its a nice way to fill in a half day. A pretty walk to the gates, and through the garden. The garden was created originally by Majorelle and after his passing his family then sold the property to Yves St Laurent, who along with his partner kept it going, then after his passing have left it so that all can come and see it. Make your trip around lunchtime as there is a wonderful cafe/restaurant, with great food.
Marrakech trip. Nice cactus garden, but the rest of the jardin was average but pleasant. Prices in the cafe and storeslem where steep

Worth a visit!. We were really glad that we took the time to visit. We were also pleasantly surprised with the cafe - really good food and drinks. We also liked the museum. I think it cost a little extra and was worthwhile. My wife really loved Yves Saint Laurent's annual holiday card artwork.

Surprisingly peaceful spot in a frenetic city. If you have a couple of days in Marrakech this is worth a visit, even as a contrast to other sites. It is compact but very well designed and maintained. Predominantly palms and cacti so lots of interesting structures. Yes there are waves of coach parties (even in November) some more appreciative than others, but if you let them pass there are moment of calm. Our guide advised visiting early (they open at 8am) to avoid the crowds. We didn't have time for the museum but other friends said it was worthwhile if you have an interest in the culture of course.

Beautiful garden in Marrakesh's new town.. The garden was very well maintained and had some beautiful focal points, although I was somewhat disappointed by its size, expecting a garden of greater grandeur. It is however a tranquil garden, which is always a welcome rest from the mayhem of the Medina!

Quite Pretty but heaving with tourists. Not really Moroccan but would have been wonderfully contemplative if it weren't for the hundreds of tourists there. Of we were two of them helping to spoil it. Yves St Laurent has a bollard erected in an overcrowded corner to commemorate his services to road safety.

Worth a visit. Peaceful and beautifully designed. Not very big and even in November, quite busy. Doesn`t take long to wander round, about an hour. The Berber museum inside - although extra money - is worth a look.

Peaceful and colourful. We visited the gardens and had a pleasant walk around. Its a very peaceful and tranquil place to visit after the madness of the Medina and Souks! Lots of varieties of plants and colourful buildings. A room of Love too!

Green and Colorful. The famous Yves Saint Laurant garden is like an oasis in a hectic city. The bright colors of pottery and huge variety of trees and plants is joy to experience. The garden is not too big and will take 30 to 60 minutes do discover.

Peace and quiet but a bit pricey. The Majorelle Gardens are well worth a visit if you're happy to shell out the admissions fee. The gigantic bamboos, cacti and other succulents collected from around the world seemed out of place here but then again they didn't. The hussle, bustle and hassle were left behind at the entrance. Also smiles were left at the door by the staff once they had your dirhams. It was a peaceful 1-2 hours wandering around les Jardins and we decided not to enter the Berber museum ( better to see the real thing in the souks or a trip to the Atlas Mts). You need a taxi or caleche to get to les Jardins unless you fancy a long walk from the Medina square.The cafe was ok but we just had a coffee

Restive Retreat. This is one of the main tourist stops in Marrakech and it's easy to see why. Serene and stunning, the world behind these garden walls draws you in with a lush embrace. Plan to spend an hour or more and take the time to explore the plantings from different visual angles. There are views that boldly barrage your eyes while others find their mystique in more subtle fashion.The Berbere Museum is worth the extra cost of admission and should not be overlooked. Its not what you’d consider an extensive collection, but the variety and display hold your attention throughout the exhibit. We stopped at the café for soup and salad on our way out and it was nicely done. The mint soda drink made the stop more than worth it. Come for the color, stay for the spritzer.
A must for any garden lovers. The garden is absolutely unique, it is an absolute must for any person who likes let alone loves gardens.

Worth A Visit. The Yves St Laurent memorial was good and the gardens were well laid out with some amazing Cactii. A bit on the small size but as it was part of a half day excursion it didn't matter too much.
An oasis. A real little paradise of a garden with amazing cactuses and pools. The cafe was also a lovely place to sit and relax.

The colours!. Made me want to go home and paint my whole house blue and yellow and green! An absolute Oasis in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Marrakesh. Also within walking distance of lots of nice places to grab a drink and food and boutiques etc.
Tranquil oasis in the middle of Marrakesh. Lovely gardens with the buildings painted striking colours. A nice calm space in a quite overwhelming city.

Nice Gardens but avoid the Cafe!. If you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of Marrakesh this garden is a nice option. However its quite small--- smaller than I had imagined. I deliberately went there about 3.45pm in the afternoon to avoid the crowds! The gardens close at 5.30 pm in November and I had plenty of time. Basically this is a very well manicured garden of Palms, bamboo, cacti etc but few flowers as such. I liked the bold blue and yellow colours on the Berber museum and surrounding structures. BUT AVOID the cafe/tea room--- so expensive for Marrakesh-- 3 Euro 50 (35 Dirhams) for a milky coffee. There is a high enough charge for the garden (50 Dirhams) and museum (25 Dirhams)! Plenty of uniformed staff around but not very friendly--- a smile would have been nice!

A Lot of Hype for A Lot of Money. They have apparently raised the ticket prices here in the last year or so, making a moderately expensive trip into one that is just not worth it. While the gardens are decent, they are just gardens at the end of the day. They are not very large at all and the variety of plants is relatively low. The staff is unfriendly as well. The location is a long way from the Medina and can be difficult to find on foot, though all cabs know how to get there. I can't think of any good reason to go here unless you have some major time to kill in Marrakesh.

A break from the city and the heat. This nice exotic garden was designed by the painter Majorelle and then bought by the French fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent. The garden is an enjoyable break from the city and the heat.
nice for a moment of tranquility. a lovely peaceful garden just outside the madness of the medina. you can see why yve st laurent fell in love with it!

Underwhelming Gardens, Super Cool Berber Museum, Lousy Cafe. The Gardens are underwhelming - they have a shabby feel (peeling paint, dirty surfaces, graffiti into the bamboo plants) and are not particularly elegant or nuanced. Lots of bold colors. I had been to La Mamounia the day before and felt like these gardens were kinda ghetto in comparison. BUT - the Berber museum is cool and has one room that is spectacular, the room with all the women's jewelry has a ceiling that is made to look like the night sky with constellations and nighttime sound effects) and the jewelry collection itelf is gorgeous - the entire experience of that room and its contents is spectacular and worth the visit. The cafe is also quite shabby and I had a really terrible cappuccino. Better off having a coffee or tea outside.
Expensive but worth it!. Basically a very beautiful garden with a small museum. We spent quite a while here as it was a gorgeous sunny day (even in November) and we took many pictures. Worth a visit.

Beautiful and colourful garden - well worth visiting. This is one of my favourite tourist sites in Marrakech. Visually, its stunning with loads of cacti and exotic plants surrounding the striking blue, yellow and turquoise hues of the main building. Although it was fairly busy, it was still very calm and a relaxing place to visit if you fancy a trip away from the medina (there's a nice cafe inside too).

Jardin Majorelle. even though it was raining we were fascinated by the beautiful cacti and vibrant colours of the gardens themselves . The museum was amazing, very informative about Berber culture and dress.
Beautiful!. Brilliant" Beautiful gardens with bright blue and yellow surroundings-very cheap and worth a visit.lots of different plants and a pond with the birds cheaping all around-its lovely:)

Charismatic Garden. Immediately you enter this garden you feel you have come to a special place, the calm atmosphere seems to affect everyone, there are gigantic bamboos, palms of every description and sunny areas where cactus thrive, but there are very few flowers. There is a memorial for Yves Saint Laurent who restored the garden, but not one for Majorelle who created it.

Beautiful tranquil gardens and Berber Musuem. A haven of peace in tranquillity just outside the bustling medina. The small (4 room) Berber museum was really well done and helped us learn a lot that we might otherwise have missed.

an oasis in busy Marrakech. We walked out from the medina to the garden, and it was well worth the 20 minute trek. The garden seems popular - there were quite a lot of people there; nonetheless, it still was a relief to get away from the busy streets of Marrakech. The museum was worth the extra 25 dirhams to see some of the Berber history. Recommended for a few hours of colourful cactus filled escape!

" Majorelle Blue"- You can be in seventh heaven.... It is amazing that in crowded Marrakesh I found quit place for my romantic soul... I was in Majorelle Gardens in February 2012. I was enchanted by garden art. I love exotic plant that why this place it is heaven on earth for me. I am sure that worth seeing it and resting here...
Gardens. If you like cactus plants then this is the place for you. Lots of different cactus plants and talk bamboo trees.

Wondeful garden in Marrakech "new" town. This is one of the most beautiful of Marrakech's many lovely places. We first visited in 2009 and though it never seems to alter; it has a lay-out dictated by the pathways and water feature laid out several dacades ago, It is a place that draws you back again and again.  It is such a calming place - helped by its dominant colour -blue There is the emphatic cobalt blue of the painrted woodwork of the pergolas and painted panels on the buildings; but best of all is the glaucus blue of so many cacti that ccome in all shapes and sizes. But then there are contrasts. The almost black stems of some gigantic bamboos. The yellow and terra cotta of plant pots that contain palms and plantains. The pure white of a species of bougainvilla near the cafe. And the pale bricks of the paths. Magical !!
Go There. A bit expensive to go in. but delightful once in. It an be reached from the Palmeries tourist bus route.
Beautiful place. The striking cactus plants and the cobalt blue - superb photographic subjects in this peaceful and quiet part of Marrakech.

Worth a look. GreaT for some pretty pictures and a bit of a rest from the craziness of Marrakech.
Our guide book said 30Dh entry but I think the price has gone up to 50dh.

Lovely Surprise. I have to say that I was expecting to see flowers and was very surprised that there weren't really any there. But I was far from disappointed. It is so luck and beautiful. Even with ll the people visiting it still gives a sense of calmness. I would highly recommend that you set an hour aside and visit these lush gardens!
very beautiful. a very beautiful place where you can have a zen and relaxing moment in Marrakech....a must see place bring your camera with you any nice places to keep in your portfolio like souvenir

Beautiful garden of trees. It's really beautiful but dont go there to see flowers.. There are no flowers.. Its cactus, bamboo, palm trees, etc.. It takes about 20 min to do the tour.. Its small but wow, its really beautiful.. Find an hour in your schedule to go!
Well worth a visit. After the busy streets, this is a welcome relief with a lovely, tranquil atmosphere and the museum within the gardens is worth a visit too.

A must see oasis!. The most beautiful garden: try to visit early to get people-free pictures. Yves Saint Laurent's boutique is beautiful but expensive.The mint-tea however tastes great and helps you enjoy the great surrounding.

Only of specialists interest. If you have an interest in botany, Yves St Laurent or Majorelle then you'll enjoy this. Otherwise it's nothing spectacular in my opinion. I enjoyed it because I got there early before the hordes but I can imagine its not to everyone tastes
relaxing place. It's a must to see it. Green garden and blue majorelle are amazing!You can walk and relax in the garden all day.Berber museum is also great.Do not miss.
Overcrowded. We expected a large, peaceful garden but it was small and swamped with other visitors. It was difficult to enjoy the scenery when jostled by others.
Lovely. The gardens are beautifully kept and designed to make the whole place seem a lot bigger than it actually is. I could have sat in there all day its very serene.

beautiful. ............... - but crowded!! and it rained!!
we queued to get into the gardens, queued to get a table in the cafe, and queued to pay at the shop!! Not the garden's fault.... but but never the less, very very busy
Paradise. The cafe is what I hope heaven is like. Avocado milkshakes, constantly being misted, sparrows flying up to your table. Loved it.
Stunning. Stunning gardens, striking, well worth a visit and well worth the small 5e charge. Not to be missed.
immaculate gardens. yves saint laurent gardens were excellent. immaculate in appearance and unusual plants.well worth a visit and very cheap to go into .
Lovely garden - relaxing to walk around!. Had a lovely time here - the colour of the house against all the cacti was beautiful. Definately worth a visit.

An oasis in the city. This is a must visit attraction. A short taxi ride away from the medina we visited early morning as we were informed it gets very busy. I'm glad we paid attention because as we were leaving at around mid day it was getting to be quite packed. The gardens are well kept, with an abundance of Mediterranean plants and flowers. It's worth it also to pay a little extra to visit the museum. There is a lovely coffee shop but very few quiet spots to just sit quietly.

Good cafe, boring garden. Bizarrely you have to pay 50Dhm to enter, seems completely OTT given the price of entry to other places in Marrakech, but it isn't much I guess. The cafe inside is worth eating and drinking in, but if you're not hungry or thirsty I wouldn't bother going in.
Bamboo and crowds. Sadly missed the museum which, I gather, is a must. The gardens are lovely but difficult to enjoy when so very crowded.
Jardin Majorelle. Loved the plants and trees and especially loved the small indoor museum, but was unable to take pictures inside museum. Easy access to the Jardin via taxi or Marrakech tour bus.
The most relaxing place in Marrakech. Unusual, peaceful and beautiful. Not very big, though, but still the prettiest place in Marrakech.Don't waste your money on the museum, though.
Great to get away from the fumes. It's a nice garden with a lot of cacti in it. But the best thing about the place that there are no vendors hassling you. and no scooters running you over.
A wonderful green space. Beautiful tranquil garden setting...with the new excellent cafe and gift shop also it is much nicer than before. Great shops across the street as well.
A colourful haven. Loved the succulent and cactus garden. Beautiful selection and also the use of blue and yellow throughout. Berber museum very interesting also
Beautiful!. It's not very big, but it was beautifully done! And the Berber museum onsite is one of the best small museums I've been to in my life.
Oasis of flora in a desert of buildings. Never knew there were so many varieties of cacti, well laid out although not large gardens they were beautiful

A Must See. This garden was everything i'd expected from reviews and what i'd been told. It was beautiful. It was fairly hot when we went so I was worried about sun stroke but there's plenty of shade and benches to sit down and take it all in. The colours and different features were fantastic, I only wish my garden looked like that! At a couple of pounds to visit was a bargain.

Pretty, but Bamboo Heavy. Pretty in the sunshine, but maybe a little disappointing for the entry fee. The garden is largely boring bamboo until you reach the villa. However, given the bustle outside this is a nice diversion.
Boring garden - awesome museum. The gardens themselves are over crowded and boring but there is a Berber museum in the gardens that is a MUST.
Magical Garden. This is a garden from another era. Hard to describe but it is a mixture of palms,cactus and bamboo. It was owned by Yves St. Laurent and there is now a little monumen to him.

architectural garden design at its best. We had heard and read lots of things about Les jardins de Majorelle and we weren't disappointed. So much to see, so many different cacti, palms and plants from all over the world. The gardens are manicured and we spent a wonderful hour there.
A must when in Marrakech !. A great place to visit. Great flowers, colors & peace. A must to understand how YSL lived when in Marrakech and how he was such a visionary person.

A cool oasis. This is a rather small garden, so it got quite crowded with people. It was a nice place to cool off, as it was quite a hot day. Go here if you have some time to kill, but you are not missing everything if you don´t go. Mostly green plants, didn´t see any flowers, though it could be due to the season. Beautiful, big cactuses.We had cold drinks and ice-cream in the restaurant. Many people also had their lunch there. There is a small gift shop and a berber museum, we did not visit the museum.Entrance is 50 MAD for the garden and extra for the museum. Go visit if in the neighborhood, but don´t go out of the way to see it.
Tranquil Beauty. A wonderful sanctuary from the hustle of the world. Immaculately maintained with an excellent coffee house to sit and relax whilst admiring the gardens.
Very elegant and peaceful. A garden befitting the designer owner Yves St Laurent. A bit expensive compared to other Marrakech attractions. Spend some time here and get a peaceful break.

I don't normally 'do' gardens. As per the title of my review I don't normally do gardens, however I felt the Jardin Majorelle deserved at least a try and I found myself pleasantly surprised. The gardens are not large and there are not rows and rows of regimentally placed flowers, however I loved the bright vivid colours with the 'majorelle blue' bright yellow and green together - it's more of an escape from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech than a 'British Country Garden' type place (so don't go expecting that). The Berber Museum is well worth paying the extra 25LE for, beautifull exhibited items of clothing and jewellery - unfortunately no photography permitted and rucksacks are asked to be worn on your 'front' as to not bang or rub against any of the exhibits. Entrance is 50 Dirham and the Berber Museum costs an additional 25DH
Beautiful. A most see in Marrakesh.. Vibrant green space in the middle of the city. A work of art, on a very large scale..They don't let you out of the country if you do not see the garden...lol

a safe haven from the hustle and bustle. The hustle and bustle, the bartering and the banter, plus swerving out of the way of approaching scooters, bikes and donkeys are all part of the attraction of Marrakech, but sometimes you just want a bit of peace and quiet where no-one will try to sell you something, tempt you into their restaurant, offer to be your guide or run you over. Jardin Majorelle is the very place. I have been to the Jardin Majorelle before and find it inspirational. I am drawn to the contrast between the colours: the bright tropical foliage and the magenta bougainvillea; the yellow, orange and powder blue plant pots along terracotta paths and around murky pools. And, of course, the bright cobalt bleu majorellebuildings against the blindingly bright cloudless sky. The other big attractions are the tranquillity – interrupted only by the whispers of visitors and the tinkling of the fountains – and the shade. There is also a brand new museum of Berber culture, which we didn’t visit on this occasion, preferring to laze in the shadows of the palms. The café – in a small courtyard – is also excellent, although the prices are far higher than the world outside the walls!
well worth a visit. lovely gardens, great for photographs, visit the cafe for a nice drink and good food in a lovely setting

There Are Better Gardens - For Free!!. Thre is a charge of 50 Dhirams per head for entrance to these gardens. If you need to get out of the sun and find somewhere cool and shady, this might be right for you. However, the vegetation is extremely closely packed so there are virtually no open spaces, and not too many places to sit either.We much preferred the Jardin du Harti (free entrance) with plenty of open spaces, and plenty of places to sit and relax, and watch the wildlife. The Arset Moulay Abdessalam was also free, but did not have as many places to sit and enjoy the views.

Hmmm. Dont want to be a grump, but we hoped for so much more. Dont know what disappointed. Was it the wall to wall crowds. Or the conveyor belt feeling of the roped off path. Or just the lack of floral drama. Ok now I am sounding grumpy. Ok in its own right but dial down your expectations...
not THE highlight!. I expected more of the garden, it's nice - lots of plants but also a lot are just the same... not that extraordinary I expected it to be.

colourful garden. Very beautiful colourful garden, it was very nice to enjoy some of the shadow it offers after a morning in the hot sun. The bar acroos the street offers some delicious food and smoothies

Wonderful garden away from the chaos. The Garden is beautiful YSL's little oasis in Marrakech. it was such a wonderful suprise to find this place, the amazing painted pots and beautiful blue painted walls combines with Yves collection of Moroccan clothing and jewelry.

Don't miss this small museum in Marrakech. When in Marrakech and exhausted by the madness of the medina, the shopping in the souks and the wildness of Jemma El Fna....take yourself off for a gentle ride in a caleche (horse and carriage) to the magnificent and peaceful Jardin Majorelle. The green, green, green is restful on the eyes, the lush and exotic plantings good for your soul and the strategic seating invites weary feet. And while you are there, don't miss the small museum devoted to the artisanal work of the Berbers of Morocco. This is by far the best museum I have ever experienced in Morocco.....especially the unforgettable, octagonal, starry desert sky room housing traditional jewellery. Listen for the sounds of a desert tribe somewhere in the distance and transport yourself to another era. For me, one of the finest and well curated displays I have ever seen.
Smaller than expected. Nice place to visit but smaller than i imagined and not as fantastic as some reviews suggest. Not much else in immediate area.
an serene oasis. very calm. well kept. very different to the hustle and hustle elsewhere I the city. well worth a stop!

Don't miss this wonderful garden. The garden is not particularly big, but so well laid out that you always seem to find yet another path or hidden corner. The collection of trees and plants is abundant and impressive, not least the numerous and very different species of cacti.The buildings and the amany vast vases are painted in very bright colour. This may sound awful, but wait till you see it. It looks great! Especially the blue colour is likely to impress you.

A Cultural Surprise. The garden was a lovely respite in the hot daytime hours in Marrakech. But the museum is the reason I am recommending this site. Yves Saint Laurent collected traditional Moroccan clothing and jewelry. I know of no other museum that displays this side of the Moroccan culture yet everyone comes to Morocco to see the Berber and buy the local trinkets. We were rewarded with a wonderful history lesson as well as a great opportunity to bird watch.
Jardin Marjorelle. Loved the garden. Excellent photo oppotunities...well kept garden and the colours of the pots and buildings are fantastic

Have seen better private back gardens. I honestly don't understand what all the rave is about. Yes it's peaceful and quiet, and yes it's clean, but other than that you're better off spending your time elsewhere in Marrakech or on a daytrip in the mountains.Nothing special, more an overrated tourist trap.
Vibrant Gardens in Hectic Marrakech. Riot of colour with blues, green and red. Palms and cacti. Wonderful haven just outside Marrakech media. Must stop for photographs.

Nice for a quiet break but not amazing. Good to spend a pleasant hour or so away from the heat and crowds, and probably better during a flowering season, but quite a small place and not too much to see.

A quiet spot in the centre of town, amazing. Plenty of shade to escape the heat and you can barely believe you are in the middle of town. Kept beautifully and Icould have spent a couple of hours here easily just sitting and looking at the plants and taking it all in. Good value for money.

Peaceful and lovely. A beautiful place to visit and escape the city, especially on a really hot day as the trees keep it cool You can while away the hours in there without feeling like you've outstayed your welcome. It can be a bit hard to find on foot, but you'll know you're nearby when you see lots of horses and carriages and a row of really modern shops which are nice to look round as well. The cares nearby are good for a quick snack.
Gardens. We found this to be the best place to visit in Marrakesh. So peaceful after the noise and noise of Marrakesh.

Small, but beautiful and worth an hour's exploration. If you've been in Marrakech for even a day, you'll come to see the vibrant reds, yellows and oranges as the color palette of the city, making the distinct blues and greens of the gardens all the more enchanting.Although it's a small property, Yves Saint Laurent went all-out in crafting a beautiful space with towering palms, trickling koi ponds and brightly painted pots and woodwork. The blue-raftered bridge is especially colorful in the afternoon sun, and offers the best view of the gardens as a whole.

Glad I went, but wasn't great.. Me and my partner walked there on our second day and were stopped and told by 2 different people that it was closed, but just told them we weren't going there and were just out for a walk. Once there, the first thing that struck me was the peace and tranquility, compared to what was on the other side of the walls. We didn't pay to go in the museum, and just walked around the garden and the shops. I have to say I'm not really one to appreciate gardens so, although I thought it was nice, I wasn't really overwhelmed by it. My partner is however, and she loved it, so that was good enough for me. The one thing that we did both comment on was that there wasn't many flowers - but this could have just been down the time of year. There is a cafe on site, but we found it quite expensive, so went to one of the little ones outside before having a carriage ride back to the hotel, which was pretty good value and a nice way to travel back (being taken through some off the beaten track areas, so seeing a slightly different side of Marrakech) and completed a very pleasant morning.
Expensive and small. Beautiful but quite a lot when your travelling in a party of 6. Tickets 50drh each and the gardens quite small
Amazing. amazing blue walls, beautiful collection of cactus plants, large bamboo, very nice to wander around.

Beautiful gardens to escape to. We unfortunately only had half an hour here as we took a caleche (horse & trap) and he waited for us outside. The gardens are beautiful, really well maintained and clean, lovely cool shade after the heat and no-one trying to sell you anything or asking for money when you get your camera out!

Jardin Majorelle. Very beautiful gardens with colours to amaze. Even in the mid day heat a place of calm and shade to look at flowers and listen to birdsong. Easy to but a bottle of water at the water kiosk in the garden but we found that the restaurants outside the gardens were more reasonanle for teas and coffees.

Not so tranquil!. A very interesting garden & well worth a visit. It would be wonderful if one could visit alone!! There are winding paths (shared with dozens of other people) with fascinating plants, including cacti from around the world.

peaceful gardens. the gardens are located outside of the medina and we used a taxi to get there. The gardens are not large but they were a relaxing and beautiful place to come at the end of a busy day tour of Marrakech

Mediocre site in Marrakech. I would like to give this site higher marks, but I have to be honest...it is rather mediocre. Yes, it was owned by Yves Saint Laurent. I get that, but it has to be more going for it than that. It is a green oasis amongst a rather dry, arid area. I did enjoy the oversaturated bursts of color in the buildings and pottery against the greenery. That is unique, but the overall design seemed a little tired and haphazard. As a photographer, I was looking for some great shots to showcase this site, but I was hard-pressed to find any. The main house is probably the most striking due to color, but getting a photo from any vantage point was very difficult. It can make a pleasant stroll if time is no problem, but I would not overlook other sights to fit this into a jam-packed itinerary. If you are going to enjoy the Berber Musuem located in the main house, then this sight does warrant a little more attention. Be aware that the sight is outside of the Medina tucked off a major street among very modern, non-descript housing blocks. This is not a charming neighborhood by any measure. Walking there from the Medina is not that much fun. Most people seem to take a cab or use a tour operator. Do your homework and make sure you have the time and inclination to spend time at this attraction.

Lovely gardens. Majorelle gardens are very beautiful and a peaceful retreat from the hectic atmosphere of the Medina and even the traffic of the new town. Well worth a visit but it is located quite far out from the medina, possibly a good 40 min walk.

A peaceful retreat. We loved our visit here - definitely worth a morning away from the hustle and bustle, to enjoy its calm and beauty. Also worth checking out the Berber museum inside for a few extra dirham, and visiting the cafe - we paid more for the usual Moroccan fare but were enjoying the atmosphere so much it was a great excuse to stay longer!

Lovely Garden, Great Museum and Cafe.. Very interesing and beautiful place, cafe has great food and staff, the Berber museum is well worth seeing and the gift shop has many nice gifts, the perfume is especially nice. Visit early morning or late aftrnoon as it can be very busy. Couple of good shops and a cafe across the road from the gardens as well.

Paradise in Marrakech. Worth a visit to reclaim your sense of cam and well being while in Marrakech. The bamboos an the cacti make for a lovely stroll. Well worth a visit! Not to be missed while in town

Exquisite and memorable. If you like cactus, palms and bamboo, this is heaven. Beautifully landscaped and presented. The small museum is not to be missed, even if you have seen other Berber museums. Take a telephoto lens and grab some good close up/macro shots. And sunscreen.
Beautiful gardens. Quiet gardens, and a very well thought-out museum. A good month to visit, not too busy, and still some colour

Nothing special at all. Was really the last thing in our list of places ti visit.
Very disappointing ... Nothing special, a very simple garden you can better appreciate with a video reportage than going spending you time and money.

The restaurant is a gem!. We went there for the garden and discovered the wonderful restaurant. Somehow the menu fitted the location perfectly and it was busy without feeling crowded. The mist system also kept it cool and refreshing, which was wonderful on a 40ºC+ day.
Disappointing.... This is a simple, tidy garden but nothing truly special. Certainly not worth going out of your way for.
Palace gardens. Very pleasurable and quiet. Take a guide with you, just outside the walls on mohamed 2 Beautiful forna and easy to find.
Tranquility in the City. Lovely gardens with fantastic cacti. There is also an excellent Berber exhibition (extra cost but well worth seeing).

Beautiful garden, museum worth the additional cost. The garden is beautiful and very well kept. The Berber museum costs extra but it is very well laid out with explanations in French (and in English on additional cards) and the clothes, jewellery and artefacts inside are fascinating
Fantastic garden.. This is a wonderful cool retreat from the hot busy streets outside. Well worth a visit is you like well laid out and artistic gardens.

Nice to wander around and get out of the city for a bit. Not much to see there, but it's nice to take an hour out and wander round the gardens. I absolutely loved it the first time I went there a few years back, this time it seemed maybe a bit more sparse but it's definitely worth a visit if you have time.
Wonderful gardens. A must if you are in Marrakech - quite small so not a long visit. An amazing legacy of Yves St Laurent.
A must to visit. Even if you don't have time, this is certainly the one place to visit absolutely, refreshing, creative and simply exquisite.
Haven of relative peace. Amazing array of plants (and the odd turtle) and the vibrant blue has to be seen. Also a pleasant cafe an shop. A good place to slow down and relax.

Top marks for this unique garden.. This place was a really pleasant surprise. My husband is not keen on visiting gardens - I have bored him to death with these over 45 years, but this was something quite different - well worth a visit and in my view one of Marrakesh' top attractions.

Overpriced and rather small. Nice gardens, but if you are from a country with beautiful forests and gardens like i am you wont be impressed. The blue all around is nice but its more a tourist grabber than anything else in my opinion.
A memorable green encounter. Central, simple and a work of living art, whilst in Marrakesh make the time for this tranquile haven.

Absolutely breathtaking!. My travel companion hadn't done any research, but I dragged her there and she absolutely loved it! Pay the extra for the Museum. It is well worth it. The grounds were stunning, and the palm trees were swaying. The museum/house were eye popping and made for great photographs.
beautiful gardens in Marrakech. It was very small but as it was so well laid out it was still well worth the small entrance fee. Full of wonderful cactus, fountains and many other plants

Yve Saint Laurent's garden(pity you cant visit the house). Bit of trek to find from the centre of the souk but exceptional when you get there. We arrived at 10.00 which was a good job as we left at 12.00 it was getting very crowded.
part was cut off as they were having maintenance but still very worth the visit

Average. we got the free entrance from our hotel, so decided to go have a look. nice size garden with bamboos and tropical plants. nothing special, but if you visit in a hot day, worth to hide there for a nice rest.

Blue on red. A tranquil spot in a busy city... A great and interesting collection of cacti, and of berber culture (museum). Garden staff on patrol could appear more friendly and welcoming: many appeared more like prison wardens... Likewise, with the nearby stand of horse-driven caleches, city-municipality might like to consider means of keeping streets cleaner and flies/ smells at bay.

Majorelle. Visiting a garden that Yves St Laurent had dedicated to preserving peaked my interest, so I set out on a warm September day. In terms of gardens it is beautiful but fairly average. I did take many happy snaps of succulents and cacti in close up and observed painters with their watercolours reliving what the painters of the past would have done. I particularly liked the display of St Laurent's LOVE Christmas Collages and purchased a few in the gift shop. The museum of Berber artefacts was well curated and installed.

Beautiful and tranquil. the gardens were not entirely what I expected....some bursts of colour, but it's the cacti that are truly spectacular. I particularly enjoyed the museum exhibiting artefacts of the Berber culture.
Simply Beautiful. The number one must see sight in Marrakech for me - tranquil and beautiful gardens, nice cafe too. Loved it

Busy but beautiful.. Gorgeously laid out gardens, we went round and around again. Stunning use of colour, lovely water features and lots of very unusual looking and interesting plants to look at. It was busy but this didn't detract from our enjoyment at all, it was a highlight of our stay.
Not really worth the visit.. Not really what one would expect in morocco. Strange mix of buildings, cactus and primary colour. Maybe this place will appeal to some.

Peace, tranquility and blue.. A fabulous, calming place to spend an hour or three (and cool, in both senses), away from the grime, noise and busy-ness that is Marrakech. The cafe is fine (bottled water is available by the entrance). Read about the garden's creation and development before you visit - well worth it. The tourist big red tourist bus stops outside (the oasis route) so you can pick it up again an hour, or two hours etc later in the afternoon. The cost of entry at 50 dirham (October 2012) was quite dear, given that the state palaces, the tombs etc were just 10, and our 2012 guide book quoted 30! But 50dh is only £4, well worth it in our view.
Great little museum and gardens. Really liked the museum as it is a wonderful collection of Moroccan history.The gardens are pleasant and tranquil.
Colourful. Very interesting and garden, plenty of colour, great variety of trees, specially exotic cactus.Relaxing atmosphere.Must see the Memorial Yves Saint Laurent and also the Museum.
Wonderful flowers. Very nice garden of Yven Saint Lorene. Enter is about 70DH. Taxi from Medina is about 50DH. Visit take about 1.5hour.

Beautiful garden!. I love a beautiful garden and this one did not disappoint! It was the best of everything - palm trees, cacti, water features and gorgeous Moroccan colours, making this garden well worth a visit if only for beautiful pictures and a bit of shade!
Jardin Majorelle. Absolutely beautiful garden - the light and shade were amazing. Very good cafe too. Would love to visit again at a different tiome of day.
Yves St Laurent's famous gardens. We last visited the gardens 6 years ago and found this time it was very crowded in the afternoon - go early!
Stunning. A beautifully designed garden, using colour and form as well as plants to create an artistic paradise. Lunch at the cafe was delicious, staff friendly. A must see.

Tranquil Oasis in bustling city. Beautifully laid out formal garden with dazzling use of colour and perspective. The museum is not only interesting but has a spectacular optical illusion to display some of the artefacts.
Enjoyed refreshing drink in courtyard cafe, this would be ideal visit after some of the shops in the adjacent area.
Too busy. Had seen a programme about this garden on tv so was really looking forward to going. Unfortunately it was so busy that we didn't really get a chance to see the garden at all.

Gorgeous garden. Best garden in Marrakech anyday. It is 50 dirhams to get in plus 25 dirhams for the Berber Museum. You can get around this in 1 hour maximum - love the tall palm trees and all the cactuses here - it has a pond with fishes in them. There is a outdoor cafe here as well. This place is worth a visit.
Impressive garden. Fascinating to find such peaceful garden in the middle of a chaotic town.Worth visiting although the Berber museum is a bit over the top.Never seen a greater variety of cactus.

Oasis in the New Town. Lovely peaceful garden with stunning colours and plants. There were quite a few visitors when we went but it did not feel too crowded. Our guidebook said the garden was free but it actually costs 50dirhams (about £5) per person. However, I'd say it was definitely worth it

A lovely place but not worth the money!. Annoyed. A Lovely place to visit but not worth the entrance fee! We got the Red Bus [Bus Pass...Get on and Get off for a day.....anywhere!] However, had a great Lunch along the way! The Restaurant, that puffs 'Spray' over you....you cannot miss it!
