Beautiful and Peaceful. This is a very peaceful place to get away from the Marrakesh rush. We took a taxi there for 25dh from the souks. The colours in the Garden are calming and its great to sit for an hour to enjoy the peace and serenity that this place holds.
Beautiful. An amazing garden that both tranquil and cool. A real must and a great retreat from the hubbub of the city. Some fascinating things to learn too - if you are interested in Berber history
Lovely place. very peacefull after the chaos of the Medina, the Berber exhibt was very interesting, a bit shy of english explanation notes.

Beautiful amazing garden!. Beautiful colors, amazing big cactus 'trees'. And cool! So if you're hot go there to cool down and relax. Nice place to have drink.
Will take you only 30-45 minutes to walk around, but worth going there.

Oasis in the chaos of the city. The gardens aren't too expensive, 50 dirham, and it's worth the taxi ride out of the medina to visit. It's beautiful, but small, so it doesn't take more than an hour or so to visit. Go to the museum if you can as well. It was a piece of calm in the chaos of the souks, and the organic cafe across the street has the best date/almond/banana smoothie I have ever tasted!
Fantastic place. Probably the nicest place in Marrakesh the only place i enjoyed is a haven in a sand box so if your there make the effort to go here and even take a book and sit in here for a while,
An oasis.. A really peaceful calm attractive garden with a wonderful cafe/restaurant and a brilliant museum display.

Utterly peaceful. This is an absolute must-see while in Marrakesh. The peace, calm and serenity hits you the minute you walk through the gate. I was surprised by the relatively small size of the garden - for some reason, I was expecting it to be bigger - but you can still lose most of the tourists and find a quiet spot to sit and contemplate. I understand it is also fully wheelchair accessible.There is a memorial to Yves St Laurent in one corner which made us giggle. It was rather phallic, but perhaps that's just our dirty minds! He bought and restored the gardens after Majorelle's death in the 60s.The workmen wear uniforms of the same cobalt blue which is the keynote colour of the gardens and apparently that blue was originally inspired by the colour of French workmen's uniforms. So that's very appropriate.This garden is located a little out of the way so a taxi may be a good idea, but on no account should it be missed. It was a highlight of our trip. There are a few cafes and souvenir shopson the road outside and also a rather nice bookshop on the road opposite the entrance.

Lovely. Totally unexpected; a real place of beauty. A bit expensive to enter, but once in the setting was lovely, and very photogenic. Worth a visit and very different to anything else you will find in Marrakech.

A sensual feast --. Did you know that THAT blue was called Marjorelle Blue? I didn't until i toured the garden and its structures. Paths of mature cacti, shaded areas, glistening pools and the berber headress collection inside yves san laurent's former resthouse.
Wonderful. A most stunning garden with exquisite design. Amazing that with so many people there one could still fully enjoy the splendour of the garden. Beautifully maintained. A must.
Peace in Marrakech. A beautiful and peaceful place in an otherwise hectic city. Excellent gardens, amazing small Berber museum, and great cafe/restaurant.

what I expected. There was a wonderful exhibition of nomadic berbere tools, clothing & jewelry. But very dissapointed that there were no Jacque Marjorelle paintings on display. The house is closed to visitors.

Small but Beautiful Garden. Don't Miss the Museum!. Majorelle Garden is absolutely an oasis in Marrakesh. It is beautiful garden with tropical colours everywhere. Not only the famoue "Majorelle Blue", but also many pots are painted in vivid yellow, orange, etc, which creates beautiful contrast with natural green colour from trees and plants.There is a small museum, which displays different clothes, Jewelleries from different part of Morocco. I personally found the displayed objects were more interesting than Dar Si Said (Dar Si Said has fabulous interior decolation, of course) and nicely presented.The boutique and book shop were also clean, beautiful and everything was nicely presented.If you compare with other places to visit in Marrakesh, the entry fees are much more expensive, but I personally found it is pity not to visit this garden.
Stunning. Second visit to this stunning place. Beautiful gardens and a very peaceful atmosphere in such a bustling city. New museum opened last year and is a great addition to the place.
Tranquill Gardens. A pleasant place to wander around and to chill and relax away from the square. One of the few places I would recommend. The monument to Yves st Laurent was a bit disappointing.

Wonderful gardens.. The gardens were restored in 1980 by Yves Saint Laurent and are a peaceful, beautiful oasis in the middle of the city. Inspired planting, great variety plus a small musem and bookshop too. Well worth a visit.
A GO for Sure!. Be sure to go!! Berber Museum is Excellent. Gardens are beautiful. Colors are completely different than what you find in the rest of Morocco.

please don't miss it. i have been to many gardens around the world but this is way up in the top five, and even overcame my dislike of cacti. don't miss the artistry and serenity of the place, (and eat in the cafe as well).

Calm. Utterly beautiful and peaceful, A bit too peaceful, it's a bit like you are worshipping rather than enjoying, everyone talking in hushed voices. A more relaxed - and free - garden is the Technology Park on Avenue Mohammad V (Check out the old phone museum!) or the Jardin Harti off Marrakech Plaza. Can be busy, and is a bit of a circuit you follow rather than wander at will, but you can linger at any point and just chill. You can end up queueing behind others to get good photos. The cafe is great, can recommend the paninis, but can be difficult to get a table and you feel a bit awkward standing waiting. You do get 'misted' with water though, nice and cooling. The museum bit is good if you don't really like museums as it's small, but does have a few interesting things so you can say you've seen ancient daggers & carved doors & stuff. No good if you really are a history buff. Beware the taxi's outside, they charge a mint and won't come down in price as it's such a prime location. Walk a couple of blocks and get one on the street for half the fare. I'd say don't miss it but it is just a garden, and quite cultured rather than buzzy.
Good to go. It is a well organized small park. It does not have variety of plants that you could see similar parks. However I did like bamboos.

A calming oasis amid the bustle of Marrakech.. Date of visit 3/10/2012First, you need to dispel any ideas you have of gardens in the English sense - this is a garden designed for it's location and terrain using sculptural plantings of predominantly cacti and palms. It also has been designed to make the most of the limited colour palette - the predominantly green of the plants, the 'Moroccan' blues of the house and pots, interspersed by sunshine yellow - and the natural light and shade. Thadows and reflections can be as important as the physical plant.It is a calming oasis amidst the heat and bustle of Mararakch and a perfect retreat to contemplate. There are some seating areas dotted around and it is worth taking advantage of them and just sitting for a while and absorbing what it in front of your eyes.Various carp, frogs/toads (?) and turtles can be spotted at the ponds. Birds can be clearly heard singing although they were harder to spot.The garden opens at 8 am and closes, relatively early, at about 6pm. (Please confirm these times if you are going to visit as I may not be accurate. It is a shame it is not open in an evening too as it would be a magical place to walk around with appropriate lighting. I visited at about 10-30 am and although busy, you could still walk around and not feel that the garden was over crowded.Within the garden is a Berber Museum (sperate ticket). Although small, I thought it one of the best folk lore museums I have been to. It is worth taking time to watch the video displays of the old photo's (although a seat would have enhanced my experience). The jewellery display is particularly well done - you can find replica's of many of the items in the souks (although you may well be told they are antique too!).The cafe in the garden, although a pleasant location, is not cheap (think in terms of equivalent to UK tourist sites eg National Trust). I have to say I found this place the worst for service and attitude in all the places I stopped for a drink. My order did not come complete but they failed to tell me there was a problem. When I brought it to their attention all I got was a shrug of the shoulders and a gruff 'We've run out'. As stopping to take refreshement there was a treat for me this did rather take the edge off it for me.Toilets in the garden and at the cafe were clean.Ticket price: Garden 50 dh Berber Museum 25 dh - both bought at the entrance gate. N.B. People with mobility problems/disabilities - this is an ideal site to visit (assuming you like gardens) as it is flat and the paths are fairly wide in most parts. There is a bridge across a pond at one point that has some steps but there is an alternative route possible around the edge.I would love to visit this garden again someday as I am sure at different times of year the light conditions will give it other dimensions of appeal.Beware if you want to get a taxi when you leave here. My first impression was good because there was a marshall who seemed to be calling cars in order. My next impression was not so good as the driver wanted to charge me 90 dh for a relatively short journey that should cost 20 - 30 dh max. Needless to say I walked away from him but he called me back supposedly agreeing to my price but as I was about to get in he uttered another price which was still too much. To save all that hassle it is worth walking on and around the corner and picking up a car on the street - still being careful about price though.

Not really sure what all the fuss is about?. After reading the reviews of Jardin Majorelle, my partner and I decided to take a stroll through the medina to outside of the walls to see the gardens. However after spending nearly £10 to get in we had completed the repetitive walk round and seen the extremely boring memorial to YSL in about 15 minutes and that included a little sit down.I have been around the world and have seen some beautiful gardens which have been inspired but this a small garden with cacti and blue walls, there are much better things to see in Marrakech that are free. Save your money for better things.
Very average. I found this disappointing and some of the free gardens were more pleasant. It was very busy when we went and found it difficult to spend even 1/2 hour at the garden.
Lovely. Beautiful. A great escape from the chaos of Marrakesh. It was quite busy though even early in the morning, but it was mostly elderly European tourists so they went about slowly.

Worth a visit!. Was part of bus tour and everyone kept saying to go and see it. Approx. £5 entry BUT it is pretty cool, especially the variety of Cacti and the waterlilly pond with the turtles. Also, the Yves Saint-Laurent exhibition was really smart
Lovely Shaded Gardens. Very pretty cool shaded gardens - myself & 3 friends enjoyed a break from the busy square wandering round the gardens & sitting in the shade - Well worth a visit.

Lovely quiet place.. Unlike most of Marrakech's public places, the Jardin Majorelle is an oasis of tranquility. The collection of plants isn't as dramatic as the setting amongst the red paths, the bright blue buildings, and the yellow planters. The Berber museum is definitely worth a look, as you won't see inside many Berber houses.

A quiet hiding place for Europeans. It's just a garden. It looks alright, but it's not very big and it wouldn't stand up against gardens in other major cities across the world. It's probably not even the best garden in Marrakech.I didn't feel it was unique or embraced Morocco in any notable way. Just a garden for Europeans with blue buildings in it

Nice cafe. Entry is overpriced, and I've been to much more beautiful gardens. I'm a fan of YSL but I don't think he had such significant input into the design of the gardens - this is subjective but I just personally didn't find the aesthetics particularly breathtaking. I loved a lot of the art & photography in the gallery, and there were some cute though expensive things in the gift shop. The cafe is quite pretty and a nice place to hang out - I'd definitely urge you to have a break there.

Blue and cool.. An attractive and cool place, it would be good to see when more things are in flower (we were there in September). Pools with turtles and carp. The cafe is relatively expensive but you get Kaab el Ghzal with your mint tea.

Don't miss the Museum. The gardens are great and well described by others below but recently a small museum has been added. You have to pay extra for this but it's fantastic value. The YSL and Berger collection of Berbère jewelry is simply fantastic. Nowhere in the world will you find it's equivalent.

Blue Gardens. I enjoyed strolling around these gardens. There were many tourists so you need to get there early. I think they may open at 8am but check up on that. I liked the display of YSLs yearly cards and the museum was okay, but it was all in French. The little courtyard cafe was a lovely spot to have a cuppa. The garden is very well maintained and consists of a lot of cacti, palms and and flowering vines. I walked back to Jemaa-el-Fna square via Mohammed V ave. and stopped off at Les Jardins de Gueliz, which provides a fantastic lunch menu. I also stopped in at Cyber Park and the Handicaft Centre. It was a great way to spend the day.
Lovely with a little history .... Great way to spend the day, a Moroccan Kew Gardens with a designers touch! Advise to go earlier in the day and avoid the afternoon sun.

Beautifully cool spot. The gardens are beautifully maintained and have their own cool mini-climate. It's well worth visiting the Berber Museum in the garden. There is a WOW room in there showing the range of berber jewellery.

beautiful,cool and well worth a visit.. lovely colours of Morocco.Plenty areas to seat and enjoy the trees etc. Cctus and bamboos amazing, An absolute must and not very far in taxi(roughly 10 mins from Main square) ..Some fantastic photo opportunities.Highly recommended.

Worth a visit. The gardens are quite small but very attractive. The entrance is a tunnel of bamboo offering welcome shade. Yves Saint Lauent bought the gardens and restored the property which now houses a Berber Museum. All the paint work is a vivid blue which is the attraction of this garden along with the massive collection of large collection of cacti.

Fantastic, a world apart. I got there by taxi, and outside there is a more modern Marrakech, but as you get in you go to a world apart where time slows down, and you just walk into the different areas, and then the camera comes out... amazing photo opportunity.
Beautiful gardens. Nice to visit, but only need about 30minutes. Is very peaceful and beautiful to view. It's on Yves St Laurent street, so added bonus for people who liked him.
Beautiful, fragrant & tranquil. Ornate setting, pleasant to meander around..but be advised-it's small! A full walk-around takes less than 20 minutes

A very plesant break from the hussle and bussle of the city. a cool and calm walk that let me recharge my batteries. After experiencing the madness of the medina where you constantly dodge motor cyclests this stroll round the gardens proved to be very good for the soul.
YSL love... we loved this garden, its so stylish and secluded - not so large but beautifully maintained. Shop unbelievably expensive but beautiful items.
A beautiful oasis in a busy city. Well worth a visit as so tranquil and wonderfully designed. A lovely cafe for your mint tea or coffee with Moroccan pastries.
Magnificent!. If there is only thing you do when you go to Marrakech, this is it. I went twice and I was just baffled.

Relaxation. I needed to chill out from the craziness of Marrakech's medina and this was the perfect place. We stayed here happily for hours, sitting on a different bench every quarter of an hour or so. The gardens are very pretty, but the real beauty of this garden is that it is like being instantly transported from the hustle and bustle of this city. Maybe not a must-do for those on a tight schedule, but for those with time to spare then worth a visit.While no picnics are allowed, there is a restaurant. It was slightly outside of our (quite modest) budget but it did look very nice.
colourful oasis. A colourful oasis of peace and calm. Lovely little cafe and a great museum of Berber history, highly recommend getting the ticket for both the garden and the museum.

Lovely gardens. These gardens a definatley worth a visit if you have time. Lots of different varieties of plans and a lovely cafe inside which is a bit pricey so if yu want a coffee it is better to get one from the cafes outside the gardens.
calm and tranqullity in bustling city. stunning design, excellent if small museum and really a good cafe. Museum is extra but worth a visit.

Beautiful oasis in the centre of Marrakech!. Majorelle is like a small paradise set in the heart of a chaotic Marrakech! Abandoned after the death of it's owner the artist Majorelle, it was beautifully restored by Ives Saint-Laurent and is now famous all over the world. A visit to this enchanting and peaceful place is a must in my opinion if you are visiting Marrakech. Sit in the cafe, relax and enjoy the flowers and palm trees that provide the atmosphere that surrounds you. The only reservation is that you must visit reasonably early in the morning as it gets very busy towards late morning and lunchtime and later throughout the day.
Delightful on a very hot day. Just a little beautifully tended sculptured garden - not a weed or dead leaf in sight - highly recommended if you like shapes and coolness

Morrocan Blue. beautiful garden and very natural, nothing superficial. Very calming and relaxing! The Morrocan architecture was evident throughout and is so lovely. The orange and blue looks absolutely gorgeous in the Morrocan sunlight!

Stunning and historic! You have to go!. This is such a gem in a busy old part of Marrakech. It is so peaceful and interesting - only a 20 min walk from the Medina and you can have some tranquility!! The cacti are amazing and who knew that Yves Saint Laurent has a memorial there!!

Great if you never seen cactus..... In the new ville, which was also a let down. We paid 80 dh for taxi (back & forth), 100 dh for entrance into the gardens. There is a pillar in the garden in honor of YSL....didn't get it? Save your dh for the souks
Jardin Majorelle. We visited the garden and found it to be quite interesting, although there was not a lot to see, apart from Yves St Laurent's memorial area.
Magical collors. very nice very well maintained garden with magical colors, one regret and turns very quickly. So a visit to predict another go rounds.

An oasis in the midst of a very hectic city. Beautiful and tranquil garden in the middle of the new town. Very well kept with an interesting museum on Berber culture and history. A fantastic Yves Saint Laurent poster exhibition also!
Not as colourful as we thought. Not as much to see as we thought for the money unless you like cactus and palms. There was a souvenir shop which was very expensive. The museum was quite interesting

hmm, its okay.... I guess I was just expecting more...it;s a pretty garden....but I think I'd rather spend more time soaking up local cultural treats....wasn't very taken with the YSL tribute stautu either....

A unique garden with a soul. There was no way we could visit Marrakesh without visiting the well known Yves St Laurent's Majorelle Garden. As soon as you come in, you understand its wonderful reputation. This is an heaven for the soul and the eyes. The garden is so exotic and filled with Mediterranean colors that enhanced its beauty. It is very creatively done and we stayed a good couple of hours. We also visited the small and beautiful done Berber Museum inside the garden. They also offer a lovely cafe where you can rest, dine in a very pretty surrounding. We highly recommend the visit. Do not miss the Love Gallery at the end of the garden.
A Dream. A must visit for the beauty that Jacques Majorelle created. There's a little monument to Yves St. Laurent in a quiet corner.
Worth a visit if you have time. It was really nice, the garden is small, special in its way, but I wouldn't say AMAZING or a MUST SEE, it's just nice.

time to relax. A nice little place to chillout and escape from the hectic city.Best time to go is in the morning as there are less people there, but regardless of the time you can find a bench to sit down on and relax in the gardens.

the bluregarden. liked - the cool environment. This was enhanced by the blue/ grey colour of so many of the plants. I did expect to see more colout there apart from the yellow flowers on some of the cacti.

Interesting. Whilst we liked the pleasant stroll around this lovely garden, it was much smaller than we had thought and only took an hour. We had a carriage ride to and from the garden which was good as we had pre-booked so got really nice ones.

Nice break of the hustle and bustle. Good photography opportunity with vibrant colours and the most important thing: an oasis out of the hustle and bustle of the Medina.
It is pricey and small but worthy if you need a bit of peace and relaxation.

expensive marmalade. The gardens were smaller that I expected, but a lovely escape from the hustle and bustle of the town. The museum gave you a great insight into the various villages and their clothes etc. The small shop was very expensive!! I thought I would be nice and buy my husband a pot of Marmalade but it wasnt until I paid I reaslised it was 180 Dhrs which I later worked out to be approx £14 for a jar. At least my husband had a laugh.
A Beautifull Garden. Cost approx 3 euros, allow 1 hour. Excellent garden and a nice tearoom. Smaller then i imagined but did not distract the value. A relief on a hot day.

Very possibly my favourite place in the world.. There is nowhere more tranquil. It's so beautiful and cool, the perfect way to cool off during the hottest part of the day.The museum of Berber artefacts in the gardens is well worth visiting as well.We went back to the gardens 3 times during our 10 day stay.It is off a side street and can be missed if you ,re not looking carefully.
Garden with Panache. Tranquil & immaculate gardens set out in vivid shades of blue and yellow paints and pots. You can tell a designer was involved as the landscaping was a joy to behold.

Pretty Place. Loving the Cactus plants here! You'll need no more than an hour here to see the gardens only. Watch out for slippery walkways when wet after heavy rain - they do remove the surface water but watch your footing if you don't have decent treads on your footwear.

A lovely peaceful oasis. The gardens are quite shaded, and in temperatures of 41C this made it very comfortable to walk around. There are plenty of seats dotted by the sides of the paths. Mainly it is a green garden, lots of palms, trees etc with the odd flowering tree, with the colour being given by the brightly coloured pots and tiles.We really enjoyed the museum in the grounds, which contains a lovely selection of silver tribal jewellery amongst other things. There is a memorial to Y S Laurent in the grounds, which is appropriate since he was the person who rescued the neglected gardens years ago, and organised the planting.Well worth a visit. The tourist bus actually stops outside the gates.

small but very good. lovely museum very well set out easy to get to by taxi... colorful and interesting, can be very very crowed at times although we didnt go in there is a small coffee shop, a very nice but sparse gift shop, all staff seemed very nice well worth going to
Well worth a visit. Just a delight and don't miss out on the Berber Museum which is there too. Go early to avoid the crowds

Majorelle Garden. These gardens took you back in time and it reminded you of a secret garden. The ambiance of the gardens was lovely, you could sit on benches in awe of the splendour of the bamboo, cactus and the various species of plants. The garden has mystical qualities.

A little oasis of calm. These gardens are small and compact but very pleasant. Originally belonging to the French artist Majorelle, they fell into disrepair when he died. Yves Saint Lauren then purchased them and restored them to their current glory. On his death, a memorial was placed in the gardens. Well worth a visit if you like gardens.

Totally serene. Loved this place. So calm and peaceful after the medina. The landscaping is superb. The Berber museum was in a contemporary setting, the handy information cards in English were a great idea (suggest Maderesa Ben Youssef & Musee of Marrakech could do same).
Fantastic and a must see. if you don't manage to visit anything else in Marrakech this is the place to go-absolutely fabulous. Tranquil and spiritual and so cool in the 40c heat

Very pretty. Lovely, you only need 1.5 hours to see them all which includes a drink in the cafe. It was a quiet retreat from the city and offered some shade on a very hot day. No problem getting a Taxi back to the hotel afterwards as there is a queue at the door.

intensely blue. overall first impression, lots of shade and very high densly planted. about 1 acre, slow walking with a bit of sitting and a bit of clicking took us about 40 minutes. 50 dhs to get in. the villa sits in the middle, its cobalt blue cube shaped with a beautiful large balcony framed with rich yellow drapes bordering on the ochre. brick and terracotta painted concrete paths, with interspersed water features and painted blue and yellow terracotta pots along the way. no lawns at all, smoothly arranged gravel in between cacti, incredibly tall bamboo, succulents like aloe vera and one of the biggest rubber plants i have ever seen.worth a visit if you'r a fan of ives saunt laurent, like blue a lot, but a quiet walk it is not.

A tranquil oasis away from the madness of Marrakech. Expensive to get in for Marrakech (50 dirhams for the gardens, plus 25 for the museum per person) and small in terms of size for gardens however very beautiful with the contrast of the colours ( cobalt blue) the plants ( succulents, cacti & bamboo) & water features. Delightful to photograph & plenty of seats to relax and take it all in .The museum was modern, exhibits beautifully displayed with info in English as well as French.Well worth a visit as lots of sites in Marrakech it's the architecture you view rather than artefacts - here there were exhibits of Berber clothes, jewellery, rugs which were artistically displayed.We ate outdoors in the courtyard cafe , ( tagine royal 100 dirhams) & whilst slightly expensive by Marrakech standards the ambience, food & service were very good .We spent 3 hours there in total were pleased to have made the effort to visit -it was a very welcome respite after a morning of historical site and souk visiting.

Another little haven. It is so good to find the quiet and peaceful areas of Marrakech and this is one! Such a calming atmosphere. The gardens are beautiful and the colours used for the pots are great to enjoy. Also a good place to enjoy lunch at the cafe.
Beautiful. Very pretty but very popular so be prepared for crowds! A 'must visit' whilst in Marrakesh - the hop on/off bus stops here so definitely get off!

Lovely Garden. We took a trip out to the garden. It was quiet and refreshing. We also enjoyed the cafe within it. It was nice to get to a cool garden in the middle of a hot afternoon. We walked from the old city, wouldn't do that again. Take a taxi, it is so cheap and not swelteringly hot.

Nice, but not really worth visiting. Whilst it is a pleasant garden, it is quite small. Unless you are a keen horticulturalist or particularly interested in Yves Saint Laurent, it is not really worth the visit.
Also known as Yves St Laurent Garden. It was very quiet and calm and a nice place to visit on a hot day as it is very shady but not sure I would put it high on the list of priorities.

Don't miss it. I run a tour to Morocco and one of the most exceptional things to see is often missed. This place will astound you. The gardens are beautiful and a wonderful respite from the hustle of the tourist areas. The museum is one of the finest small museums I have ever seen. It is laid out beautifully and you will learn more in an hour about Moroccan culture then you can possibly learn anywhere else.
Beautiful, well worth a visit!. A little expensive for Marrakech but it's a must for any tourist! Lots to see and the museum is really interested. An explosion of colour YSL would be proud of.

Worth a visit, for the museum alone.. To be honest, this wasn't really for me. It's not that the gardens weren't beautiful, peaceful and inspiring (they were), just that it was all a bit monotonous after 10 or 15 minutes. Lots of trees, cacti and plants. Not sure what I was expecting really, lushious meadows and wildflowers perhaps.Several sections were closed off when we visited (I looked through the hordings though, no meadows behind there) which was a shame. Also, not the most relaxing layout.. you sort of go in at the start and walk around in a circle until you pop out at the end, kinda felt like visiting IKEA but without the furniture.There is a Berber museum on site which you have to pay extra for but which is well worth the money. Plenty of exhibits and a really enjoyable insight into life in the Atlas mountains. There is also a lovely cafe which is a nice place to chill out before heading back to the medina.All in all, worth a visit if gardens are your thing, but be sure to pay the extra for the museum.
peace and calm in a hectic city. A nice oasis of tranquility. Lots of beautiful palms, cacti and bamboo. It could use more flowers for some more colour...
Good short break. Easy to find by taxi, good hop on and hop off...Not very big, nice to use a hour too walk around. The bar annex cafe is way overpriced.

"happy we made the visit, but a little overpriced". We spent a couple of hours in the gardens, which were well cultivated and a pleasure to wander round. The gardens are a great place to take photos. The Berber Museum which is in the grounds of the Jardin Majorelle is worth visitng - well laid out, with some great exhibits. Information on all the exhibits in the museum were in English. There is a gift shop selling some lovely items - bags, scarves, jewellery and pottery, but at a price!! The entrance cost per person for the gardens and museum is 75dh.If you are walking to the museum take care as there were no crossings nearby and the roads were very busy and difficult to cross.
Very peacefull. Very quiet and lovely garden. A bit rushed when on one of the tours but do not be afraid to get a taxi and do it yourself.

Vibrant gardens. This was our first stop and it was a welcomed surprise. Beautiful coloured plant pots and stunning blue house greet you in this little oasis. Disliked the price of i think 50 Dirams (5 euros each) for a little garden, but if you bring a book then you can make the most of it! Enjoy!
Not a must see. The gardens are very nice and well kept. It was different than what I had expected but would say that it is not a must see.

If you wish to see Yves' memorial; look around you. Jardin Majorelle was not created by Yves St Laurent, but he revived it after it had fallen into disrepair. It is not really 'walkable' from Djemma al Fnaa; if you take a 'petit taxi', make sure you negotiate a reasonable return fare IN ADVANCE. The taxi drivers always wait outside the gardens for you. Some will try to tell you that they will only wait 30 minutes or an hour- take no notice, they are just trying to bully you.Yves' personal contribution to the garden reflected his own talents; it was colour- but what colour...A special blue now known as 'bleu majorelle' as a background colour , then pots all painted in pale citrus colours. The plants are all ones that would flourish in a desert & some of them make the most extraordinary shapes.Although the garden is in a side street off one of Marrakech's main roads, it always feels peaceful inside and there are plenty of benches where one can just sit & meditate.Yves St Laurent's personal memorial is very simple but none the less, touching.There is a building in the centre of the garden which usually has on an exhibition of some sort related to clothing. A while back, I was lucky enough to be there when an exhibition of some of his original designs was running. More usually, there is an exhibition of Berber costumes, which are interesting.There is a cafe, where it is lovely to sit outside, or inside by a small waterfall. The food & drinks are not cheap, but all is high quality and beautifully presented.There is also a shop which I find very expensive.Like many visitors, I go back every time I visit Marrakech. It is genuinely unique and happily Yves left enough money in his will for the gardens to be maintained in perpetuity.The 'Majorelle' district is now one of the most expensive addresses in the city. There are some nice 'designer 'shops opposite which certainly contain some lovely things - but at sky high prices.

Beautiful gardens, overpriced cafe!. The Majorelle gardens are extremely beautiful and are a welcome oasis in the bustling city of Marrakech. The gardens are really well laid out and include a fabulous collection of plants from around the world. The main building is really beautiful and is such a lovely splash of contrasting colour in the gardens. The museum is also very good and very informative. However, I would recommend not going to the cafe as it is very overpriced for food that can be described as average at best.

BEAUTIFUL. It is certainly a site not to miss when visiting Marrakech, this garden is a gorgeous combination of cactus, trees and colours, along with a very interesting and well put together Berbere Museum. Take your camera!

nice garden shame about the visitors. I don't know why but the gardens seem to be awash with french people (perhaps now that YSL has his memorial there?) who have little regard for the paths/walls/gardeners/peaceful atmosphere. I may of course have just been at a bad moment I expect it's less crowded later in the day. The colours are gorgeous and despite being a small garden you can cross it multiple times in different directions and make it last at least an hour.
Beautiful. Very calming. The gardens are set up to represent the various Continents of the world, some are clearer than others.
Mini oasis just outside the medina. Well worth a walk from the Medina. Lots of interesting plants and very colourful buildings and pots.

A true oasis. Lovely chill-out spot to get away from madness of the Medina. Well worth going in the morning although Sunday mornings are very popular with locals. We spent about half an hour there and it was worth the small entrance fee.
A must with YSL house now a wonderful Berbere museum. Not far and well worth a visit, go by carriage a well worth trip. Negotiate price ( no more than 15 euros both ways!)

Second time around. This place is beautiful however a bit over-rated as it is a relatively small garden. You tour it fast. I compared the pictures I took 10 years ago and noticed a lot of the vegetation has been cut out.
beautiful gardens. this is a very well kept garden of peace & tranquility, also has a rather beautiful open air restaurant.

An Amazing Garden ...... Really Unexpected Beauty. This amazing garden is full with nice and unusual colour and garden design. The strong blue colour theme of the garden gives it an unique identity. The bamboo garden and the cactus garden are the main attractions of Jardin Majorelle. The garden also houses the Islamic Art Museum of Marrakech, whose collection includes North African textiles from Saint-Laurent's personal collection as well as ceramics, jewelry, and paintings by Majorelle. I strongly recommend a visit to this place, a must see site at Marrakesh.

One of the great magical events of the city. A world class garden with enough space to allow groups to come and go while you spend time with the succulents and cactii and surreal bright colors. This time I found a terrific cafe to have coffee in betwixt, and a superb show of Berber artifacts in the museum. The canopy of plant life provides a cool temperate climate in contrast ot the hot pavement of Marrakech.

Captivating Cacti. A great spot to escape the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. We arrived early to avoid the hordes of tourists and the high temperatures. Most people here at this time were serious photographers rather than sightseers. We came from the medina and travelled by calèche (we negotiated a price from the main square to the gardens and back again, the driver waited for us whilst we visited and we paid him upon return to the square – it was a great way to travel and we didn’t feel rushed or ripped off). It’s a bit out of town so it’s not recommended to walk it from the medina, there are plenty of taxis available but we thought going by calèche hit two birds with one stone, making the journey there an experience as well as the gardens themselves. There is a prescribed route around the gardens, it’s a tranquil place and home to plenty of birdlife and turtles. The colours are vibrant and beautiful. The size and variety of cacti are very impressive as well. It’s not a long walk to take everything in, plenty of benches to stop and admire the plants and so on, so those who are less mobile or those with younger children shouldn’t find them too much of a challenge. There is a rather overpriced gift shop as well – focusing more on the previous designer owner than the impressive contents of the garden itself.
Tranquil garden, good museum. This is an extremely peaceful and well-designed garden that contains, among other things, an interesting museum about Berber culture. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful Blue! Cactus Variety!. Lovely vision in green and blue. Doesn't take too long to walk around but then there was a museum we just didn't go into that so couldn't possibly make a comment on the museum. Really happy with our guide.

Colourful Marrakech garden. Nice place to visit to delight your eyes with the vivid colours of the cactus pots spread across the garden.While being there you can see the Yves Saint Laurent monument (he lived the end of his life in Marrakech) and small museum plus Berber Culture small Museum exhibiting artefacts, Customs and Traditional Clothing and Jewellery. Worth visiting for 30 mins or so.Best part is to take some time to walk around the garden, take pictures (the place offers unlimited background scenes) and sit on a bench and admire the various cactus species.
It was nice. Nothing much to see but you go to say you've done it lots of plants including cactus and bamboo and the memorial of Yves st Laurent

Beautiful. The range of exotic plants and trees, at 1 point I thought I was in Jurassic Park. It's very peaceful with lovely water features with vivid blue colours. A must for your camera. Begruge having to pay over the odds for mint tea and small lunch. best time before 10am, before the crowds come.
The best garden yet. Beautifully constructed and maintained with loving care An oasis of tranquillity in the middle of a busy city

Small garden - mainly cactus. Majorelle Blue is a beautiful colour and looks great on the buildings inside the garden, but it's very small (can walk around in about 5 mins) and unless you're really into cactus, not much else to see...
Garden oasis in the city. Beautiful building and gardens, just wish they had some of the paintings by Majorelle in the studio.

Beautiful escape. We spent around 30mins here whilst on a horse and carriage ride. They are stunning gardens with the vibrant blue paint makes it a quiet oasis of calm. There are benches scattered along the pathways where you could easily while away some time. There is a cafe there although we didn't use this although the courtyard looked lovely. Recommend a visit.

Fantastic gardens, awful cafe. If you're interested in botany or just in visual splendour the Jardin Majorelle is a must. I would also recommend the Berber museum inside, which is very professionally and informatively laid out. We could easily have spent more than the few hours we did in the gardens. Although slightly pricey for Marrakech, the entrance fee is worth paying.The one downside to our visit was the terrible cafe, which we ended up having to use for a light lunch. The prices are phenomenally high, literally ten times what you might pay nearby. The food was also not particularly good and the service indifferent. Avoid if at all possible!

A liitle piece of heaven. Created in the 1920s by a French painter and restored by Yves Saint Laurent, this large tropical garden in the north of the city is definitely a must-see. Once inside all noise of the city is gone and sounds of birds accompany you on your winding walk under palms and trees and tall exotic plants. The deep colour of Egyptian blue is everywhere and each view is a photo opportunity. You won't want to leave!
Nothing interesting. Yes the gardens are well kept, but besides cactus plants, there isn't much else to see especially as the entrance fee was so much more than other places, I wouldn't recommend.
Ok snack. Ok snack Free water with a Dame Blanche, Crepes not up to scratchNice to sit and relax, with water mist cool you down
Majorelle bleu. A disappointingly quick tour (booked through Thomas Cook prior to going) of a lovely garden which I would have liked to have spent more time in.

Not as big as we envisaged. Not clearly signposted - we had to ask our caleche driver where the entrance was!A little bit disappointed. Sorry Good cacti collection. We didn't visit the museum. Get there early to avoid the coach loads!!!
Relaxation. Very nice garden with a museum about Berber history. Definitely worth a stop. There are benches where you can relax and a small coffee shop as well.

small nice garden. not a very big garden to visit but lovely,work are done at the moment so could not visit it all. They have a berber museum inside but you need to pay extra to visit it not so great.

Expensive for what it is (compared to other attractions). We decided to walk to this attraction from our Riad in the old town which may have been a mistake. We like to walk but the blistering heat meant by the time we arrived we weren't as enthusiastic as we might have been. For 50dihram (about£5) it was the most expensive attraction but not the best. If you've got time to spare then take a look but not the best Marrakech has to offer.
Lovely cafeteria within Majorelle Gardens. More a cafeteria than a restaurant but the environment is really nice : beautiful settings and colours. Food is quite good but not cheap.

Definitely worth a visit. This is a beautifully kept small garden with a lovely area to get refreshments and food. Would recommend that you take a taxi or horse and carriage as its a bit of a trek in the heat and nothing of interest en route.

Wonderful site for the eyes.. This oasis in one of the suburbs of Marrakech offers lots of photo opportunities and houses the Berber museum. In my personal opinion, one of the best little museums I've ever been to! Lot's of information about this ancient culture and lots of items on display. There are many interpretive signs but you have to be able to read either Arabic or French. Signs in English would have been nice.
beautiful Gardens. Once you walk inside the ambience is stunning, in your own oasis. Stunning bamboo and cacti everywhere, with a tree canopy to keep out the hot morocco sun.
Saint - Laurent's legend. Perfectly well kept. Very good small museum. and of course a beautiful shop rather expensive but I would have bought it all

Lovely peaceful gardens. Very tranquil with a lovely cafe we had a very nice breakfast which we thought was good value for the amount we got.The gift shop was very expensive and sales assistants snooty.We went quite early in the day before it got to busy as it is not huge so could get quite crowded

Peaceful but pricey. Pleasant enough gardens but nothing that special (compared for example with La Mamounia Hotel). Very pleasant, cool and relaxing teashop. Prices high for Marrakesh and boutique prices quite ridiculous.
That's what a "haute couture" garden looks like. The gardens are beautiful, tranquil, it feels as if you are in a different world... highly recommend you take a break in their cafe.

Not bad, not the greatest. Went here today and spent just under an hour in the garden. It is a nice change from the busy city but I was expecting it to be bigger and better. Certain areas of the garden were also closed for repair today.It costs 50 Dirhams to get in and another 25 for the museum if you choose to visit it, I didn't so can't say anything about it.

Beautiful and easy to enjoy. My travelling companion wanted to see the gardens and I dutilfully tagged along. Very glad I did! The bamboo forest was impressive - we took loads of pictures - and our fellow visitors were very nice. Everyone was offering to help each other take group photos, taking turns at the busy locations without getting grumpy, and generally showing howing being in nature can be restful and relaxing. The museum was small (maybe even tiny) but informative, and there were other shops and galleries to browse. We stopped for lunch in the open air cafe, and generally had a lovely afternoon. Well worth a visit.

Pleasant but nothing to write home about. The Majorelle Gardens, though pleasant enough to wander around, were nothing particularly exciting or interesting. It seemed like a bit of a waste of money to me to walk around a garden filled with cacti, probably because I have had the good fortune of growing up somewhere where beautiful gardens are abundant. So for me it was nothing special and probably a bit of an overpriced excursion. I was interested to enter the Islamic art museum there but it was an extra expense that as a budget traveler I couldn't afford at that time.
Peacefull and beautifull gardens. Well maintained with bamboo and cactus trees. Very quiet and opportunities for great photos.The museum is small but worth it!50drh entrance gardens, 25drh museum

aka YSL gardens. I expected a lot more considering we saw very pretty public gardens. Mainly cacti, there was a memorial, small bookshop. To be honest, it was very hot that day and so I wasn't as impressed.
Beautiful. A very out of this world place, totally unexpected from the outside. The colours were beautiful and is A MUST DO WHILE IN MARRAKECH!
yves st laurent memorial garden. a little overpriced but very beautiful and peaceful is an otherwise chaotic city, nice to escape the crowds and find some shade!!!
garden. like the tranquility and lay out - very good and peaceful. it is not at a very good position as you have to walk to the back of the street for the entrance.
Lovely Haven in busy Marrakech.. We visited the gardens on Valentines Day, They are lovely and it was so relaxing to wander around away from the hustle and bustle of the city

Well worth a visit. A miniature Kew.
Go there!
There is still work to be done.
It will be fantastic when it's all done- if that's possible.

Great gardens.. These gardens are well worth a visit. It's like a miniature Kew Gardens.
There is a lot of work still to be done but it's a really interesting place to visit.
Oasis in Marrakech. Nice and small, cool with a lot of shadow, interesting to see YSL's house and garden. Quite touristic so go early! Great bamboo and other trees.

Busy but beautiful. In the new part of Marrakech (avoid the taxis near the entrance-easily walkable from the medina). Lots of visitors but still retained an air of calm and peace. Lovely cafe making teas and juices with a hialrious waiter who thought my husband should have had the spicy ginger and mint juice due to its 'aphrodisiac' qualities. Fabulous colours and the sound of the breeze in the bamboo was fantastic.

Equisite Museum. Majorelle Gardens are just beautiful to walk around and to experience some peace and quiet after the 'madness' of Marrakech! The museum is totally exquisite - don't miss it - simply sensational Berber jewellery/clothing collection. I also enjoyed my meal at the outdoor cafe. Would definitely return to Majorelle Gardens for another visit.Suzanne - Tasmania - Australia

Beautiful. Gorgeous gardens, reasonable admission and the perfect place to visit on a hot, summers day. Lives up to the (high) expectations set by every guide book and then, as you turn a corner, blows them away. Leaves mortals like you and I with a (marginally) deeper understanding of what it must be like to be a world-class designer if this is what you do in your spare time between redefining world fashion!

STYLE. This is a place Yves St Laurent made famous,him and his closest friend,M Bergé.They saved the home and garden of the famous French painter Majorelle from destruction,planted hundreds of delicious plants,mostly cactus,had all the pots painted in the color blue Majorelle invented and made a tourist attraction out of this small park,as important to Marrakech as the Eiffeltower for Paris

Average!! To say the least. Very disappointing. I have been to many gardens around the world and this really does not compare. It was very small, the cafe within is super over priced. All it seemed to have is lots and lots of bamboo and cactuses - very green not no other colours!!
beautiful gardens. wow this was fantastic - would never have expected the tranquility of the place.Go early in the morning as as the day gets hotter more people arrive & it can get

Well looked after garden. The garden is amazingly looked after, the people who work there do a very good job. I'd say it's a little over priced at 50 dirhams entry and the café (although it looked very nice) was very over priced. It's a nice break from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech.

A beautiful oasis. Have wanted to visit this place for years and it was my primary reason for visiting Marrakech. Only about £4 to enter it is a welcome oasis of shade in the intense heat of August. There are photo opportunities everywhere and the garden is very well maintained. The cafe is worth a visit, their teas and ice creams very good and you can escape the heat indoors. Museum worth a visit too.

Relaxing & peaceful hang out. Arrived in the morning and it was very busy, however by midday it was quiet and we sat on a bench in the shade reading. Really peaceful place. The Berber museum in the grounds was a real highlight. The food in the cafe is great as well. The gift shop is generally expensive but there are some cheap little gifts to be found.

Moderately interesting but nothing special.. I don't understand the raving reviews. The garden is calm, pleasant and very shaded but it's nothing special. Having paid about 50 mad (roughly 5 euros) we were given small leaflet style maps with a few paragraphs abou the history of the garden. We walked along the route (can be done in about 10 minutes at a slow pace) and ended up in a highly overpriced caffe/restaurant which is a part of the garden. 50 mad for a bottle of sparkling water - expensive even by European standards. The garden itself is nice but thats all it really is. I definitely wouldn't go again as it just isnt all that interesting / picturesque. Maybe worth a quick visit for anyone on holiday in Marrakech but try ad have a low expectation so you aren't disappointed at the end.

To die for. This was my favourite place in Marrakesh. Cool even on the hottest of days amongst the vast mostly shaded collection of palms and cacti. The art deco building within is stunning and there was water available at a reasonable price. Don't accept the initial price of the taxi's afterwards on the stand outside. It looks like the sorting it out for you, just do some good old fashioned haggling and it should drop by 1/3
nice colors. beautiful blue en yellow colors, nice to have a walk and a visit! cool bamboo trees and beautiful flowers. nice picture spot!

Lovely and peaceful. Great cafe and really pretty gardens. A real treat but a bit smaller than I thought it would be. A fair price for admission but you will need a taxi to get there or a horse drawn carriage ride as it's a bit far out of the main square.

Overpriced!. Ok, so it's nice to explore some of the gardens in Marrakesh to escape the hussle and bussle of the medina, but I couldn't help but feel that people only pay the 50 Dirhams each to get in because of the YSL memorial. We thought other gardens in Marrakesh, such as the Cyber Park, were far nicer, and also free to walk around. Also, this is not the kind of gardens you can truly sit in quietly to enjoy, as there are so many tourists taking pictures!!!
Yves Saint Laurent.. Beautiful garden outside the Medina. Cost 50dirhams to get in but its really worth it. Pay your tribute to YSL here.
Beautiful Relaxing Place. Great place to chill-out, away from the hectic city centre.Nice restaurant, but a bit on the expensive side.
Nice for a walk. We did love walking there and see how beautifull the garden iswe loved the musem and the moroccan clothes
Delightful use of 1.5 hours. Calm and peaceful with an interesting collection of cacti and trees. Great for photos and having a very leisurely stroll.

So worth it. Stunning and so much to see - one of the many musts of a trip to Marrakech. We went on a guided trip and this made it more informative - would recommend this. It's something different after the main square, soukhs etc
Peaceful. This is such a beautiful and peaceful garden, I would definitely recommend a visit. although it was very busy it was so quiet and tranquil like a little slot of heaven hidden away x

A good place for chilling out. The Majorelle Gardens is a must see while in Marrakesh. Allow more than 2 hours in order to get there using a buggy horse carriage and you will be more than happy to pay the 50 dhs or so for admission. It is one of the best places in the dry hot city of Morocco. We also recommend going there late in the afternoon for a better chill out.
nice location. very comfortable appearing. we did not stay there so cannot comment on the rooms. the site forcing me to write more and I do not have anything else to say.

Favourite Part of My Holiday. Really loved our trip here. The plants were beautiful and it was really cool against the 46 degreess in the sun! The bright colours of the pots and the house were beautiful. The museum of the Berbers was ok but not everything was transalated into English. The whole place isn't huge and doesn't take up much of your day - perhaps we would have stayed a bit longer if we didn't have a taxi driver waiting outside. Was really lovely and clean and there were lots of gardeners about tending to the plants. A must visit, really glad we went!

breathtaking. The vibrant colours and the cafe there is delightful......go early morning to avoid the crowds. There is a shop and the prices are high but there are lots of seating areas to sit and enjoy the gorgeous plants and trees.
Amazing !. In the heat of Marrakech, it is always a pleasure to walk in the Majorelle Garden. There is always an interesting exhibition to see in the museum and the café is very also very nice.

go late afternoon. this place is beautiful oasis in a dry, dusty city. However, there is not that much space on the walkways and I imagine it gets annoyingly overcrowded in the mornings, when I understand bus loads of tourists turn up. it's not that big, so if you give yourself and hour to an hour and a half, and turn up mid/late afternoon, you will have a much more leisurely and enjoyable time.

50 MAD???. Small garden very full of people and quite expensive for the possibilities. Botanicals are not well identified and most are just cactus that seem randomly placed around. Museum must be payed apart. Visit can be made in 10 minutes, the hordes of tourists taking the typical places won't let you enjoy anything of this suffocating closed garden. There are gardens around the city much better than this one and are free and with tons more of space, air and refreshing shadows.

cool and shady and beautiful. we visited in August and in such heat this was a wonderful cool oasis. Lots of bamboo, palms and cactus varieties. A lovely tranquil, peaceful place to spend an hour. There is also a cafe though I didn't try it.
well worth it. this is just wonderful a little gem in the madness of marrekesh as a lovely cafe in the middle of it very clean and reasonably priced well worth a visit
A must see. Interesting style and colours, exotic plants, nice atmosphere, but boy was it hot, 46°C, as we were there during an unusually hot period for May.
An oasis in the chaos. Really peaceful, stylish and colourful, good cafe and quite quiet. However small and fairly expensive so consider which of Marrakech's jardins you want to visit.

Nice enough but overpriced. The gardens themselves are nice and very well kept but the whole place is not that big and it costs 50dirhams (about 5 euros) to get in. I felt it was really overpriced for what there was to see. I also paid another 25dirhams to go into the berber museum which was interesting but small. There is a cafe there but it is 40dirhams (4euros) for a tea so I went to one across the road.

Relaxing gardens. Near to our hotel (Moroccan House Hotel). Very cool, shady areas with lots of seating. Unusual cactus displays and memorial to Yves Saint Laurent. Lovely use of colour, vivid blue and golden yellow.
One of our Highlights of Marrakech. This place is a must, I'm not a big garden fan but this has to be seen?! The blue villa, the big bamboo plants the massive cactus beautiful fountains

Pleasant experience. Interesting garden, particularly if you like bamboo and cactus, and brightly colored hardscape. The Berber museum inside the villa is also an interesting collection of objects. By and large, worth the trip.

Very nice and refreshing. The Majorelle garden created by the painter Jacques Majorelle then redeem by Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Berger is a beautiful garden in Marrakech with a great diversity of plants and flowers.
Beautiful. An oasis of calm and tranquility in the busy hubbub of Marrakech. Perfect for coling you down on a hot afternoon.
An oasis in the middle of the hustle and bustle. Lots of different plants and colourful buildings ideal for taking photos. A lot of shade to hide from the blazing sun.

Magical Garden!!. What a magical garden in the middle of Marrakech! A lovely escape from the sweltering heat of the city. We loved viewing the various flowers and plants in this peaceful oasis. Also loved that Yves St. Laurent acquired and restored this property. Great way to get away from the hustle and bustle of the medina.

Over-rated: 20 minutes is plenty of time. All the guide books recommend this garden as a highlight (of morocco and not just Marrakech). It is a lovely peaceful place but completely over rated and not really worth the taxi ride unless you love cacti. Disappointing.
beautiful. a really calm and beautiful gardens, colourful, lot of trees and plants, a galerie with paintings of Yves saint laurent. worth it.
Nice oasis. Beautiful and fresh. The colors are incredible, and also the variety of plants. It is full of tourists despite the price, though.

Beautiful gardens makes you feel you are in 1920s Marrakech. The diversity of the plants is stunning, as is the design of the water ways and the main house. The contrasting colours of the walls, flower pots and park benches work wonderfully with the greens of the cacti and blue of the sky. There is a little cafe, which is a little expensive for what it is, but it is in a beautiful little courtyard, where they vapourise water to cool the temperature down.

A beautiful site. Beautiful surroundings, fab berber museum with costumes. Distinct lack of Yves Sant Laurent considering its links with the designer. A gallery of his artwork is there, but would be nice to see some clothes,and pictures of him at the gardens- which I noticed in a book in the shop.

Lovely gardens. Compact but very attractive formal gardens, including the former painting studios of artist Jacques Majorelle, now a museum. A little courtyard cafe there serves cooling drinks - very welcome in the heat of the day.

Nice.. But nothing exciting... It's a well laid out and beautiful cacti garden. Can get vey busy with lots of visitors as its not a huge place and when groups of people are standing around on the narrow pathways it can be difficult to navigate (especially if you're pushing a pram). It has some lovely water features and a little cafe where you can cool off and have a drink. Worth a visit if your there outside of peak holiday season when its not so busy and you can enjoy the garden a little more. Don't expect too much and you won't be disappointed..

Not what I expected. Not sure what I expected to find at the Majorelle Gardens but it certainly exceeded anything I had thought it might be! lovely and calm, beautiful colours and a fantastic variety of plants and areas divided up into unique sections with a lovely little cafe for refreshments! Couple of great shops just outside too!

Colourful gardens. We really enjoyed visiting here, the colours used are amazing and the gardens are really interesting and tranquil; nice staff standing around offered to take our photos and then expected tipping so take small coins otherwise that can get a bit expensive; certainly worth visiting for a few hours.

Cool place. Love the different kinds of greenery, the contrast with the colorful vases and the water fountains, we didn't go into the museum. August is very hot so if you would like a place to sit down and admire the beauty, this is it. Give it a try.
Pretty and peaceful. I was hoping for a guide to tell me more about it. The museum was closed at the time we visited. There are no names on the plants but gardens are very well kept.

Lovely Garden if you like cacti love the Majorelle Blue colour. Visited here as part of a guided tour, this was one of the better bits as the guide left us alone and let us visit this 'romantic' garden. The guide told us to take our time as its a special and romantic place, my take on the place is that its a load of Cacti and a nice little pond. The pond was interesting as it had little terrapins in it that we loved but think this should be a free public area and if you want to see it no need for a 'guided tour' which we found terrible and overpriced but just get a taxi here (it costs next to nothing to get in)Nice but perhaps a bit overrated, we spent 10-15 mins here and was a bit under-whelmed especially as the guide had spent 10 minutes previously building it up.
An Oasis. It is only a small setting, but you can spend an hour walking through, checking the museums and having a little sit or drink. Very relaxing and a welcome break from the summer heat.
Nice respite. A lovely spot from which to escape the heat of a Marrakech summer day! Just a stroll from the central square.
beautiful colours!!. great to see, but small garden and done in about 30minsThe house is a seperate charge which is a little frustrating.
Expected more?. It was okay. Known of the garden for at least 20 years. Pleased I went, but expected more. Okay for quiet and packed lunch!!
Our visit to the garden. This is a wonderful place to visit during any stop in Marrakech - don't miss it. We had a wonderful time exploring the gardens.

Pretty,expensive and full of people. Packed full of tourists and not enough space to enjoy it.overrated as really its a cactus garden with a few water features. The museum was closed as well. If there was space to enjoy it i think i would have rated it atad higher.

A nice place to realx and refresh your body.... We spent good time at these botanical gardens of Majorelle. It is recommend to visit them after lunch and have a drink in its cafe restaurant.
The gardens have also a nice Berber Musueum.
We love it.

A peaceful respite from the bustle of Marrakech. This is a beautiful and somewhat unusual garden. Instantly cooler than the surrounding city, and despite being fairly busy the day we were there, it was quiet, with most visitors taking it in quietly. A nice place to pause.I also strongly suggest paying the extra charge to visit the museum. It provides an interesting overview of traditional Berber life, with many everday artifacts. There is a display of clothing for various activities/occasions with those for the weddings being particularly ornate. There is a very impressive display of berber jewellery. Museum is also air conditioned, so provides a chance to cool off on the toastier days! We were there for a heatwave that included 40C days, so this was very welcome!!
Overated. Pretty overated. Plenty of cacti but little to see and hardly worth the entry fee. Spent about 15mins there!
Okay. I know people love these gardens but I only found then ok. Quiet, cool and pretty but I would not go out of my way to visit again.
Paradise in Marrakech. Amazing place in Marrakech. Walk in to this garden and you instantly feel like in another world. A perfect place to hang out for a while.
Absolutely Stunning!. Lovely...well worth going to. Very cool and serene..A must go for fashionistas, massive YSL influence.

Yves Saint Laurent Blue. This gem of a city garden and artist studio with Berber clothing exposition is not to be missed, especially if you have any interest in YSL. Once you've been there you'll know why he chose bright blue for his signature designs...

Beautiful "oasis" in the centre of Marrakech. The beautiful gardens were created by the French artist, Jacques Majorelle. They are absolutely stunning with the bamboo groves,cacti and palms, and the pools with water lilies. There is a small gallery showing some of Majorelle's work along with some Islamic Art.
Not To Be Missed. We learned what the term "Majorelle Blue" meant. It is unique. I've never seen a blue quite like that.
A bit overhyped. Pretty gardens, but very small, and overpriced. The Marakech people are very proud of it though, so I dont want to sound too harsh. Allow no more than 2 hours
Very nice, But noisy !. Aftet three days in Marrakech , we visitd this garden ,it was one of the amazing places in Marrakech , but noisyyy....full of people

Peaceful reprieve. Visit these gardens when the bustle of the medina becomes a bit much. The gardens are lovely, and a small cafe attached serves excellent soup and fruit juices (try the banana avocado). The blue paint is striking (the color is patented!), and the Berber museum holds an impressive collection of artifacts and cultural objects.

beautiful garden. This is a beatufil place to go if you want some peace an quiet after walking around in Marrakech. The garden is a well of colour and smell.
The garden is very vell maintained, and the restaurant serves delicious food and refreshing drinks.

A beautiful garden and experience. We walked from the Le Meridien, so it was a bit of a trek, but we kept to the shade and saw parts of the city we had not seen before. I mention it only because of the horror stories of using cab and getting fleeced. We only used a cab to get from the airport to the hotel, otherwise we walked everywhere.Quiet, cool and very serene, we enjoyed every minute we were there. We had lunch at the cafe and while expensive, it was nice to sit outside. The Berber museum was small, but worth the seperate fee. My wife bought a very nice leather bag that she now uses all the time. I got some very nice pictures and the history is interesting too.
Lovely.. A lovely garden, full of bright colours and smells. You would not know Marrakech is right outside the walls.

A stunning oasis, rescued from decay. The Jardin Majorelle is an absolute must-do. This stunning exotic garden features a variety of succulents, palms and other greenery, contrasted with Lapis Lazuli blue, and is a true oasis of calm and tranquility amidst the hustle and bustle of the Medina. The tiny Berber museum offers a thoughtfully presented and engaging insight into Berber craft and culture. Our visit was an absolute highlight of our trip. Thank you to the late Yves Saint Laurent for preserving this wonderful slice of paradise for generations to enjoy.

A blissful escape from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. These gardens are not huge but what they lack in size they make up in serenity, colour and style. My gardening hating husband who has no appreciation for plants even enjoyed the visit. There are palms, bamboo, fountains, Koi goldfish, cactus garden and a Yves Saint Laurent memorial. A few have said you can be in and out within 15 mins and I suppose you could if you just follow the paths from entrance to exit without stopping to take in the beautiful surroundings. We were there 2 hrs or so, just chilling in the remarkable peace and quiet despite being just off a main road. We also had mint tea and pastries under an orange tree in the courtyard cafe which isn't overpriced and has efficient staff. The place was one of the highlights of our trip and in my opinion well worth the £3.80 each or so to get in.
Fashion & Relaxing. If you like fashion and give value to the greatest creators you mut go to this place where Yves Saint Laurent got some of his incredible inspirations.
Lovely. A short trip to fill an hour. Just outside the city centre or on the hop on hop off bus route. The gardens are a peaceful place to sit and have a drink.

more space. large open space full of olive groves as far as the eye can see at the end a large pool /lake full of large carp..take some bread with you the water erupts when you throw it in brilliant !
Gardens. Very relaxing atmosphere, you would not know you were in the middle of abustling city..make it a must visit
Stunning garden!. Beautifully cool under the palm trees, exciting cactus-filled landscapes, a lily-pond, and lots of little paths to explore!
A breeze in July. Small garden, but shades and nice to go if you are in Marrakech in the hot, hot summer. Not sure what Yves Saint Lorent have done there...?

Small tasteful oasis within the city. I was wondering about the "guaduas"which are a very very thick type of bamboo that needs lots of water.How can they maintain them?
There is a beautiful pond.
The colors of the house are amazingly beautiful, specially the cobalt blue.
I also liked the Berber Museum

Lovely way to spend a morning. We arrived at the gardens for them opening at 9am which was perfect as it wasn't too busy. We paid 75 Dirham each for entry into the museum and gardens. The gardens are beautiful with many places to stop and take photos and benches to sit for a few minutes. There are a few ponds with fish and terrapins inside which were lovely to watch. We stopped for a fancy juice in the cafe courtyard (fresh pineapple juice, ginger and mint) which was very different to the drinks we get at home and although expensive (about £5 each) they were worth it. The Berber museum is definitely worth a look - it probably only takes 15 minutes but it is only a few pound extra and the jewellery exhibition in particular was very beautiful.

A shady retreat- bliss. The gardens came as a welcome retreat from the heat of the afternoon, and are beautiful. Great colour (the blue), and lots of shade and places to sit. There is a cafe on site, but it was closing early (we visited during Ramadan), but we still walked all the way round, and visited the museum, very interesting Berber costumes and jewellery). Water is also very cheap there at 5d. A very pleasant way to spend a couple of hours.

Lovely Garden but not very big. Memorial is weird. The garden is a great place to go when it is hot as it has deep shade and even in the cafe there are water sprays to keep you cool. There is an amazing collection of cacti from all over the world. However, it is not a big garden and you will certainly get round it is an hour or so even if you loiter. The memorial to Yves St Laurent is a bit weird - a simple column, and was a disappointment to me. In the garden is a Berber museum which was quite interesting but again not large. The best bit if the cafe where the posh fruit juices and salads are delicious

Doesn't match the hype. Smaller than we expected; nicely laid out and an interesting mix of trees and some rare and attractive plants, but you can see it all in 20 minutes and if you don't manage to catch it then you needn't feel you have missed anything too spectacular. We didn't visit the Berber museum or cafe, which some say are excellent, so cannot pass comment on those. The YSL connection seems overplayed to attract the tourists.
Superb. I loved the plants, the colours, the serenity and knowing YSL himself had been there! Everything about Majorelle is wonderful

Green sanctuary amidst the hot dry red city. Escape the bustling city by taking a break and amble thru the beautiful gardens. Landscaping is not a priority in much of Morrocco, so it was interesting to see what kind of plants could grow there.

A photographer's paradise. The garden is full of colour and a real treat for photographers, you can take photos until your heart is content without having to ask permission like you do with many other things in the city. Many parts of the garden act a great shade from the scorching summer sun.
Beautiful gardens owned by Yves Saint Laurent. Worth the money and time spent here - beautiful and relaxing. Recommended.

Beautiful, peaceful. After the hustle and bustle of people and donkeys and cars and scooters on the streets of Marrakech, these gardens were a delightful retreat. Unusual plants set in a soothing setting of lazy winding paths. Gorgeous flowers-and not one rose! (Thank goodness-I'm allergic to roses.) Lovely afternoon break.

Worth a visit.... A calm & blissful place to visit. Wonderful gardens...
I would return again.

Stunning Gardens. Yes the gardens are not big but this place is well worth a visit. An oasis in the middle of Marrakech. Colorful, peaceful and well maintained. YSL memorial in the gardens. Great visit

A must see.. Amazing garden to look around and admire, especially enjoyable due to the shade and running water giving you some relief from the heat. I would recommend this site to any friends or family visiting.

A historical treat. Thanks to Saint Laurent and Pierre Berge, a tribute to this painter and his garden
the most visited spot and since many of us bought YSL perfumes, ties or clothes. We all felt like sponsors !

Disappointing!. We visited the YSL garden and were rather disappointed.
I think we were expecting something a little more stylish having heard that YSL was involved with the gardens. We managed to view the whole garden in about 20 minuets. The garden did however off us 20 minuets out of the Marrakesh sun.

very nice garden. Very beautiful colors in this super well maintained garden.
Very relaxing it really worth it.

No indigenous plants. Apparently all the plants here (and it is almost all plants, very flew flowers) were brought here from other countries. It's a very quick visit while you walk around the circular path. Very cool on a sultry day but not much to see.
Tranquil haven. Do not expect a large place, this was St Laurent's personal garden and is very pretty altho not the best I have visited, but still worth a view.
Nice little walk & expensive cafe/resto. Pretty garden, nothing amazing in the way of vegetation, but very becoming of YSL. The resident cafe served good food, but at a hefty price.
beautiful gardens. the colours are vibrant and interesting, the cacti have to be among the best i have seen, well worth the visit.
Enjoyable Visit to Majorelle Gardens. The variety of plants and trees was amazing, the Moroccan museum was interesting and the cafe provided a nice respite for a cold drink.
Worth a visit. Worth a visit, gardens are impressive and only takes about half an hour out of your day. Quite a cool place as well

Amazing gardens, a cool oasis in a unique setting in Marrakech. Not to be missed! Marrakech's wonderfully unique and exotic botanical garden. The icing on the cake is the excellent perfectly formed and really interesting Berber Arts Museum. Try to visit early in the morning, lunch time or late afternoon. to avoid the crowds and the groups.

Nice little stop if you have time, or if you don't have much time. This isn't anything you absolutely have to see while in Marrakech, but it's nice if you have the time, or even if you don't have much time, b/c it doesn't take too long. Even though there were many other tourists and school groups, it's a calming escape from the hustle and bustle of the medina. My husband and I decided to stop here on the way to the Atlas mountains for a hike. In addition to the more tropical plants like vibrant bougainvilleas, there are water and cactus gardens. You can get some great pictures with the incredibly vivid blue used on the property. See what I mean with a google image search.
stunning!. Go in the morning while it is quiet- its very quiet and peaceful. A beautiful place.

Peaceful and worth seeing. For what is basically £3 you experience a very cool and pleasant trip around these gardens, which I feel are well worth seeing. After the square and souks you will need a slower pace. I recommend going earlier in the morning to miss the tours - around 10/11am. There is a restaurant which is nicely laid out for a drink/snack - prices looked quite high but we didn't go in.My other piece of advice is, if taking a taxi here, ask for them to use the meter (this applies to anywhere around the city), because tourist traps such as these attract ridiculous fares [many drivers quoted us 50/60MAD and we got there for 8 in the end...]) - I would also recommend walking up to the taxi rank 100m up the road, rather than paying inflated prices as you leave.

A Great Escape in Marrakech. A really worth while place to visit.The gardens are small, well maintained and are really beautiful.There is a great little museum and gift shop in the gardens and the shops that are situated around the entrance are really worth a look.
Beautiful. Lovely colorful gardens located 10 min walk from the medina. Touristy, but still worth it. Try to go there early to avoid the crowds.....

Colourful and exotic. The vibrant colours (blues, greens, yellows) of the planters, the walls and the pools make this garden truly colourful. Then there are the plants! A must see in Marrakech and don't overlook the Museum.

Beautiful garden, YSL tribute!. Beautiful garden, gives a sense of peace and relaxation to your trip. It also sows the tribute to YSL and has the Berber museum which shows the history and beauty of these people. A must see!
better things to do. we would not rush back but its okay if you like looking at cactus and the cafe is very expensive!
Colorful. Lovely garden, small but very 'zen'. Avoid from 10an to 4pm. Better at 5pm !
peaceful haven. Definately worth a visit. Emmaculately kept and very interesting.
