Beautiful gardens. Gorgeous landscaping, an amazing cactus garden, and an incredible use of color (bright lemon yellow and cobalt blue) ... after shopping in the souks, spend an afternoon here. There is a wonderful little cafe with homemade sorbet and gelato katacorner from the entrance ... I had blood orange and lemon -- very refreshing and very nice and helpful staff.
Worth seeing. The gardens were very crowded when we were there but well worth the visit. Since I was planning a Moroccan themed garden at home it was quite inspirational.
a beautiful surprise. The only un-missable site in the Ville Nouvelle of Marrakech, as my Rough Guide rightly says. Very beautiful and refreshing.
Fantastic Cactus. Beautiful but small garden and very well maintained

Tranquil space in the rush of the city. A beautiful little gem in the busy city, fantastic planting schemes and use of colour. A lovely place to visit for a couple of hours, a photographers haven with typical Moroccan tiling and hues of blues
Food and drink more expensive, so take your own
Beautiful and tranquil. So quiet in such a vibrant city. Colours were stunning.

My Best place in Marrakech. Majourelle Garden, is my favourite place i try to recommend for my friends, family, and anyone visiting Morocco, Marrakech it's really worth a visit, even you have one day in Marrakech, it has what we can call Magic of nature, really enjoyed the plants, and the breathtaking colours, in addition to the hidden ART it has. Really magnifecient, i highly recommending Majourelle Garden for a short visit, you'll not regret or lose anything if you visit it.

A Santuary amid the noise of Marrakesh. A spendy lunch but worth it for the peace and beauty of the place. The food was nice, the service is good. Worth the visit but the gift shop is very expensive!!

resonable interesting... great for photos but crowded. The garden was pleasant and peaceful contrast to the hustle and bustle of the souks... and more importantly clean and well kept!! lots of nice colours but also relatively small and fairly crowded. Good for an hour or so unless you are an botanic. Visually i have seen more impressive gardens, nothing exiting but we did enjoy our visit. Great photo opportunities if you have patience or enjoy sceneries with random strangers in them.
AN Oasis. So tranquil and lovely to walk around. It is not huge but a lovely place just to chill for a bit, the museum inside is excellent even though it is small!

Morocco much better than Jordan. Casablanca's Hassan II Mosque (world's third largest) is an architectural marvel. Worth making a journey just for this. Marrakech's Jardin Majorelle is superlative - almost sanctuary-like if you go early. Reminds me of Monet's house/garden in Giverny, France! Morocco is leagues ahead of Jordan. Morocco is much more colourful and showcases the Arab and Islamic culture in a more sensitive and representative tone. Also, the Berber and other tribal art and culture are alive. Most of all, the warmth of Moroccans - whether in big cities like Marrakech, Casablanca or in tiny villages along hiking trails - is most welcoming. Even though they are poor, they have genuine smiles - unlike the Jordanians who are mostly surly and $$$-minded.Make time to do oasis walks and savour the stunning vistas of various kasbahs (forts), whether small or big. Lawrence of Arabia and Gladiator are shot in Morocco for a good reason! Our guide, Aziz, is trained in law but free-lancing as a tour guide due to Morocco's economic hardship. Aziz went the extra mile to shar the nuances and inside track during our trip. I still keep in touch with Aziz via e-mail as he is a young man worthy of tour referrals for FITs and small tour groups.
The Oasis. We have traveled to botanical gardens worldwide and this one stands out as a gem. Very small but quaint and very well maintained. I strongly recommend the gift shop for quality goods.

Pleasant and reasonably interesting. It was a pleasant and relaxing way to spend half an hour. Nothing Exciting though. It was just nice to get away from the medina madness for a bit. The entrance fee was 40 MAD and entry to the museum was 25 MAD. The museum was more interesting than the garden itself, which was a bit of a let down. I did enjoy relaxing in the cafe. The food was good and I would recommend having lunch there. You can find a nice warm spot in the sun or they have 2 room with sofas where you can loung for a bit with a coffee and a good book.

Vibrant colors in a tranquil garden. The vivid colors juxtaposed amidst collection of cacti are somehow very pleasing to the eyes. The garden gives one a sense of calm and serves as a quiet retreat from the noise and medlam of the medina.The cafe serves wonderful food as well in a quiet courtyard.Take your time to enjoy the greenery and assimilate the art of Majorelle and YSL.
Oasis in the smoke filled New City. Beautiful, peaceful and exotic garden well worth the visit.

Worthwhile visit. Beautiful gardens & great food.. The cafe in here is wicked. Food superb! Try the vegetable couscous - yum yum. The grounds are great and it was very interesting to see Yves Saint Laurent's posters and learn a bit about his life.
A cool place. Beautiful plants, interesting small Berber museum and great coffee house. The link to Yves St Laurent adds to the fascination.

peaceful oasis. great for shade from the heat and a calming oasis in the bustle of town. Definitely worth the trip out of the markets to sample the tranquility!
Great for photographers too.

A Must-See!. This is a great way to spend an hour or two. A tranquil sanctuary that feels like a million miles away from the hustle and bustle of the souk and the kasbah. A beautiful mixture of palm trees, bamboo, exotic plants, every species of cactus, lily ponds, fountains, coloured pathways with huge plant pots and that wonderful shade of Majorelle blue. You don't have to be a botanist to enjoy it and I guarantee you will want to take hundreds of photos. It also has a nice courtyard cafe and clean restrooms. It's one of the major attractions in Marrakech, in a good central location and doesn't take up too much of your time.
great!. gorgeous. didn't mind that it was touristy, you can go at your own pace and avoid the crowds.

Most beautiful garden ever. You have to plan this must-see during your tour of marrakech. The garden is planted with so many different kinds of cactus, the colors are amazing and it offers a nice retreat from the maze of the medina.

Pleasant enough. Pretty garden, pleasant way to get away from the bustle for a while but not a 'must see'. Most lasting impression was of the appalling silent atmosphere in the gift shop, guarded by supercilious assistants who made no attempt to move out of the way if you wanted to look at something. The perfect antidote to the souks I guess!Good cafe too - with open fire which was needed unfortunately.

Great place to take pictures. Nice colorful tiles, very YSL style garden. There are some rare plants and a lot of cactus. It's nice. However don't plan more than 1 hour for it, 45 min is enough. Unless you want to eat or drink at the Majorelle cafe..
yves st laurent. i found it hard to fault this garden. it was fantastic. very quiet and sedate among the normal madness of the city. and the info on yves st laurent was a revelation to me
beautiful oasis in Marrakech. This is a beautiful place to visit for some quite time apart from the chaos of the medina. I truly recommend the visit!

Restful garden. Worth a visit if you are nearby. Beautiful green gardens with a thoughtful layout, set off by the blue paintwork of the buildings. A good place for a time of peace and quiet in the exotic madness of Marrakech. Sit and rest or walk around and explore the trees, foliage and cacti. There is a museum and gift shops, as well as a cafe and toilets. Enjoy your mint tea in the traquility of the cafe courtyard, but be aware the food seems a little pricey.
YSL. Truly inspiring what fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent did there.
Worth a Detour. Very nice garden with a museum and buildings, A nice memory of Majorelle
WOW so beautiful. La Majorelle is a really beautiful garden with a memorial by Yves Saint Laurent. There are many beautiful plants and beautiful arabic windows/doors :P It's really romantic also!
Must visit. Gorgeous gardens, a must for Marrakesh.The museum was closed when we were there - but the gardens are amazing. Busy though.

A dream of garden. You can see a lot of bothanical garden in the world but the atmosphere and the colours of this garden with the touch of Yves Saint Laurent are at the top.You cannot miss it in Marrakech
So clean!. Although in the New City this Garden is so pretty and in the centre of things that you really dont feel like you're in Marrakech at all! It's a great place to wind down and relax.

Beautiful gardens not to be missed. The Majorelle Gardens are definitely worth a visit. Although it is quite small, there is a wide variety of different water features and plants to see. The vibrant blue colour is lovely to look at amongst the contrasting bright colours. There are plenty of scenic photo spots in the Majorelle Garden, the layout is beautiful and it is lovely to walk through. It was warm when we visited, which made the gardens look even better. It is very relaxing and gives you a refreshing break from chaotic, but wonderful Marrakech!
Beautiful. Go early in the morning and take a good camera, expect a garden that is definately of the region but with such class

Beautiful and peaceful amongst the voltage of Marrakech. The gardens are beautiful and peaceful. The area where the gardens are situated is quite nice. The walk there from the Medina was fine for us although I would not recommend to the faint hearted. a definite must for any visit to Marrakech
Beautiful. The garden was good and the museum was fabulous!!!!!
Tranquillity in Marrakesh, who knew!!. Lovely quiet oasis in the middle of the crazy city, well until you venture back outside to be accosted by taxi drivers and horse & carts :-)

Peaceful. The gardens were a peaceful place amidst the bustle of the city, with beautiful colors (mostly in the building structures) and much appreciated shade. I have been to more impressive gardens, but it was nice, green.

If you're in the neibourhood - check it out. we liked the garden as it was nice and small - so we didn't get bored seeing cacti upon cacti. I love the cobalt blue colour with the contrasting colours.Worth going if you're in the neighbourhood, if you don't get a chance to see it, then you're not missing out on much.A good tip- there is a supermarket (Achi) across the road, we stocked up on snacks and water before flagging down a cab back to the main square.

magic, and an excellent renovated museum. No trip to Marrakesh is complete without visiting these beautifully maintained gardens. The marjorelle blue paint is all it is made out to be, and the gardens provide a wonderful retreat from the bustle of the city. Thanks to the Yves St Laurent funds, the Berber museum has been renovated and is now one of the most detailed and well laid out museums in the city.
Beautiful, don't miss the Berber Museum. A beautiful, relaxing spot, don't miss the Berber Museum on site, it's really worthwhile.
Cool garden. 50 MAD from old town. Well worth a visit for an hour, lots of shade and water on a hot day. Fantastic coffee shop outside the main entrance, centre of the block.
Awsome!. Don't miss it. it's beyond words. The idea someone might have of paradise.
Stunning garden in relaxing setting. This is a complete contrast to the chaos of Marrakech - its very beautiful and relaxing and colourful. Highly recommend.

Pretty garden for a relaxing walk. The garden is a nice, quiet little oasis in the middle of the chaos of the city. It's quite pretty and a nice place to have a walk, but very small and a bit expensive for what it is. In the summer heat it might get bonus points for providing some much needed shade.
What agarden!!!. This is a must for anyone who visits Marrakech! Beautiful!!!!

Blue Heaven. This was a real highlight of our few days in Marrakech. Yves St.Lauren and Pierre Bergé rescued this garden from dereliction and saved a great plant collection, stunning buildings and features. The plants are amazing, tall and well-cared for, bamboos, palms, trees, aquatic plants; the building and infrastructure colours are strong and startling, the air is full of birdsong and splashing water yet the overall feel is relaxed and peaceful. The garden was created in the twenties by painter Jacques Majorelle and it is a real delight and despite plenty of visitors didn't feel crowded. It's a must-see for any serious traveller to Marrakech. It's a pity the plants aren't labelled as many were unusual or rare, but we discovered later that there is a guide book which could be worth using as a guide
worth a visit,. These beautiful gardens that were resurrected from decay by Yves St Laurent are well were a visits, and Oasis of calm in a manic city.
cacti. Stunning garden, well worth a visit. Cacti of all shapes and sizes forming an architectural wonderland.
Worth a visit.. Well laid out.Worth a visit. If you like bamboo trees and cacti.

a gem. a tranquil oasis from the chaos. Had seen pics and read about but they fell short of the reality, amazing. The museum is fascinating and not to be missed. Displays of tribal jewellery, costume and historic artefacts.
very pretty garden. This isn't very big, but it was nice to wander around for an hour or so, from memory it was 40 dirhams per person, more for the museum inside.
an oasis in the heat of the day. We found it easily enough from the medina and it was full of bamboo and cacti with lots of water and seating area.
Blue Majorelle. Place to Relax and to discover a rich botanical world
Majorelle Gardens. Nice place to visit, but quite small, so you can get round in a short time. Nice museum on site though and good cafe.
Beautiful gardens. Beautiful and understandably very popular place to visit

Overated. As both a gardener and an artist, I was a little disappointed with the garden. Some design aspects show flashes of brilliance (the cafe courtyard for example) but not on the whole. The house has no redeeming features apart from being bright blue. The planting is often simply large plants which crowd in and cut out light. However, in an area where there is not much else, it is an oasis.

Lovely and calm. Lovely grounds, though perhaps a bit dry considering the little rain. We took fantastic photos near the intense blue painted buildings (which we found later is a shade called Majorelle blue).

Best site in Marakesh. The gardens are fun, but do pay the extra and go in the Berber Museum. This is really good quality stuff collected by Yves St Laurent, it has good English explanation boards for each room, and some videos explaining how things are made. It's air conditioned, well laid out and really worth the trip

A little peace of almost calm in Marrakech. It is truly beautiful and there are so many photo opportunities - however it was full of people so occassionally you have to wait to have a photo taken as there is someone else there. We timed our trip well, we stopped for an early lunch and then had a look around, almost everyone else went for lunch at the same time so we got to see everything. It's smaller than you think so won't take long to wander round.My word of warning is lunch - it is fiendishly expensive and not that great (for your money). the juices are awesome - the one with the mint, pineapple and something was epic but it is expensive!
Tranquility. Such a beautiful place, well organized for tourists and very peaceful. Good loos !

A must see !. Fabulous garden ; one of the must sees in Marrakech ! A good idea is to take a carriage on the main square to get to the garden; it takes about half an hour and it is utterly romantic !! Cost is about 80 MAD (5GBP).
An Oasis!. Once in the gardens it felt like a calm and peaceful retreat from the city. The jewel room in the museum is breathtaking. The cafe is pleasant to enjoy a relaxing half an hour.

peacefull. go early in the morning around 10 am as it gets busy taxi from the squre returne came to 80 dhm was for us 3 ladies in total£8. the driver waited for us we paid on return get a price before you get in BARTER its between 20-30. which is about£2-£3. one way.

nice garden, but walk over was the interesting part. We visited the garden after it was recommended to us, and we walked there from the center of the Medina. The walk there was by far the most interesting part, and although the garden is very nice, just not sure it was worth the price.

Tranquil and peaceful. YSL memorial and lush garden! A beautiful and peaceful place in the middle of the city. A great place to wind down, especially after visiting the medina! DH40 to enter. Was not crowded when I was there.

a botanist's view. Partly because its history (created by landscape painter Jacques Majorelle in 1924 and then subsequently purchased and gifted to Marrakech by Yves Saint Laurent) and partly because of guidebook hype these gardens generate some controversy. However, as a professional botanist (accompanied by my aunt and cousin, both keen gardeners) we were all impressed that in such a small area the five continents of flora were represented. From cacti and other succulents, the grove of asiatic bamboos (perhaps sadly disfigured by teenage carvings - but hey (pun intended!) bamboo is a grass after all - to the lilies in the water features, the Norfolk pines (neither from Norfork nor are conifers, but I nitpick here) and the tradescantias and zebrinas The overall impression that we came away with was pleasurable.

Peacful and clean. In the middle of a hot and dusty city, this is a lovely place to come and relaxed amid plantlife and relative quite. It was fairly busy in some areas of the gardens but everyone was relaxed and calm so it was not a problem. We did not visit the museum on this occassion. The cafe was a little pricey but I guess that is location. There were some cute cates sleeping in the gardens as well. Overall, very nice

Try to visit at a quiet time. I've been to the Majorelle Gardens three times and will always return on any visit. The contrast of the bright blue painted buildings with the greens of the cactuses and trees never fails to impress. The gardens are beautifully laid out, extraordinarily well maintained and there's plenty to see at any time of year.The only thing that winds me up about this place is just how busy it gets. After a few days of Morocco I start to bristle at the site of coach parties full of scantily clad tourists flashing their flesh in totally inappropriate clothing and I long for them all to disappear and give me space for some good photos. Best time to visit is during Ramadan when tourist numbers are low but if you can't manage that, try to go first thing in the morning when it has just opened or last thing before it closes to avoid the crowds
It was interesting but little here that really suggests innovation. So much more to see in Marrakech opt for something more culturally representative
Very Special. Absolutely beautiful. Go immediately after lunch about 2:30 before the crowds arrive. You'll have the place almost to yourself.
Dull. I do like my flora as well as my fauna, but this just wasn't that special.
Very pretty garden. A little escape for an hour from the hustle and bustle and to gain some fresh air!
beautiful garden. the garden owned by YSL is really amazing. very nicely done, good place to stay and relax for a while.

Striking and Picturesque, Worth a Visit. It was a really pretty place, with striking, colorful backdrops that make for great photographs. Just know it is a major tourist attraction and the prices in the boutique are not for the meek...

A tourist trap. Nice garden but small and congested. 40 Dhm entry and beware the cafe, they do not offer a menu and you'll get a surprise when you receive the check. 60 dhm for an orange juice.
Marracash the people are obsessed with gouging tourists.

Bit disappointing. I expected these gardens to be really stunning and was a little bit disappointed. They are nice but nothing special. They were much smaller than I expected and consisted of biggish beds planted with similar plants e.g bamboo, cacti, grasses etc. I believe they are meant to represent the 5 continents but I had difficulty working this out. The lilly pool was the prettiest part for us; there were some small turtles sunning themselves on the edge.The cafe was pleasant but a little expensive, the shop was outrageously expensive!There is a Berber museum within the grounds which is an extra 25 dirhams to visit, if you are even remotely interested in this culture it is well worth the extra as it has some fascinating artifacts inclusing some stunning jewellery.

Boring but peaceful. Was not too impressed with this place, its a nice place to walk around within such a manic city but i would have rathered been in the riad reading my book, as there were so many people walking around taking photos it kind of took away from the serenity that is implied (I visited in Nov so not peak season) plus it wasn't free (only 40 dh though). On a positive note the YSL shop was nice and the toilets decent. but i wouldn't go again as its a tazi ride there for 100 dhs each way (£15 total)

A welcome break from the hubbub of Marrahech. Well worth visiting. It is an easy taxi ride from the medina. Very pretty and interesting design( I took away lots of ideas for my garden at home). Nice little cafe, lovely to sit in. Gift shop was expensive. Worth a visit
Cacti extraviganzer. I never knew I liked cacti but this changed my mind.
One of a kind. It is a unique place, next time I would take my book with me. it is a place to relax and have one the best coffees in town.
Very nice. Loved this garden, worth the trip. costs 40 Dirhams, lovely
georgous gardens. Absolutely beautiful, peaceful & tranquil,only a short taxi ride away from the medina. A 'must see' for anyone visiting Marrakech
Oasis of Yves Saint Laurent. Wonderful garden with special atmosphere. Beautiful colors, lively flora. Ideal for romantic walk and escape from the hectic center.

Tranquil cool garden. This is interesting to walk around. The plants, trees and birds make it very worthwhile. As a tribute to YSL it probably falls short but what would not. The cafe is pleasant but a little expensive. The gift shop is quite over priced and had little of interest

A Secluded Gem!. I'm no horticultural expert but this garden (funding by Yves Saint Lauren), but it's certainly a surprisingly quiet and peaceful garden, about 20 minutes walk from our hotel at La Renaissance. The garden is gorgeous, plenty of bright, moroccan colours, mixed in with the birds tweating, turtles bathing in the sun, plants and loads of Cactus!There was a small queue when we arrived but nothing excessive and there were plenty of people wandering around in the garden, but still very peaceful and quiet. There are some great shots to be taken in this garden if you're an amateur photographer!
A Memorial to Y.S.L.. Beautifull gardens, don't miss.The local tours do not allow enough time.
Beautiful. This is a stunning picturesque and calm place amongst the noise and hustle bustle of Marrakech
Not all that. Lovely gardens but not as great as I had been led to believe. Worth the trip if you have time however.
Les Jardins Majorelle. Smaller than anticipated, but very pleasant. Very good neighbouring gift shops!
Stunning. This was our favourite place to visit in Marrakech, beautiful gardens and gorgeous vibrant colours. A quiet gat away in the centre of the city!
Amazing colours. Amazing colours. Well worth a visit. Perhaps smaller that I thought it would be, but worthwhile nevertheless
YSL Garden Heaven. Love love love this garden - No. 1 thing to visit in Marrakesh for me

Incredible colour. Smaller than anticipated and blunted a little by heavy drizzle, apparently unusual in October! The layout very interesting and colourful pots and accessories to the plants. A fascinating connected history with Yves Saint Laurent.

Beautiful. This is a gorgeous garden which is a complete contrast to the rest of Marrakech and full of the most amazing cactus I've ever seen. Lovely, if a little expensive, cafe - somewhere to relax away from the hubub.
Wonderfull gardens. This is not a big place but a small garden with an athmosphere. Do not miss the small café where the orange salad is fantastic.
truly exellent. well worth a visit,lovely lunch at resturaunt, a real oasis of calm in a pretty bonkers city

A Beautiful Respite from the Craziness of the Medina. This is a beautiful, peaceful garden dedicated to Yves St. Laurent. Amazing cactuses, birds, ponds. We didn't go into the gallery because it was closed. But, if you need some peace and serenity while in Morocco, this is the place to go.

Majorelle Gardens.. a nice garden which was owned by the french artist , it contains a big collection of cactus trees collected from all over the world.in side of it the mesuem of the islamic art, and where you can have a snack.
Beautiful garden. This is lovely to see, there are lots of exotic plants and although the garden is actually quite small, you feel as if you could get lost in it.

Ideal morning activity-Jardin Majorelle & Museé Berbere. The Berber Museum within Majorelle Garden is a must see to gain an insight to the Berber people,language, history & culture. The gardens are also pretty and there is a restaurant to grab some lunch. A great morning activity away from the crowded medina.
beautiful. Go early to avoid all the coach trips. A very peaceful and beautiful garden. Best attraction in Marakech. Pools, cacti, bamboo, trees...excellent cafe/restaurant. A treat.

FANTASTIC. Both my Wife and I were overwhelmed by the Gardens and the serenity one felt the moment you entered through the main entrance. I am not a great lover of visiting gardens but with the Majorelle this was different in that I could have spent hours there because it was so peaceful and serene, although there were lots of Tourist like myself the Gardens seemed to have a magic affect on everyone even children who did not run around etc. This is a place that one has to visit again if visiting Marrakech.
Very pretty. Worth a visit. Tiny garden and you could rush round in an hour or stay and read books in the shade. Lot of people chilling. Very calm and atmospheric

A little gem for photographers and garden lovers. We visited the Majorelle Garden when it opened at 8a.m. as we wanted to savour this artistic oasis before busloads of tourists descended upon it. At that hour it was so tranquil, numerous birds were singing in the palm trees, and the shady walkways and various water features helped keep it cool.Don’t expect to find a lot of colourful flowers here as the essence of the garden seems to be more about juxtapositions of texture, shape and foliage, enhanced by the vivid deep cobalt blue paint which Majorelle borrowed from Berber house decoration and made the signature feature of his garden, using it here on pots, tilework, walls and buildings.  The plant collection is extraordinary, with a mini forest of whispering bamboo, cacti - some of which have attained amazing girth and startling height, palm trees, succulents growing in painted blue, lemon or ochre pots, and aquatic plants including lovely water lilies. Unlike Monet’s free form water lily pond at Giverny, Majorelle’s pond has strict geometric lines, and the stunning reflections in the water include the tops of palm trees, lending it a fantastically exotic aspect. The use of terracotta gravel to surround plants in the garden beds and reddish paint on the cement paths adds yet more colour to the garden.This small garden in Marrakech is a photographer’s dream, and a must-see for anyone interested in gardening and landscaping. A café, gift-shop, free toilets, and museum are located inside the garden. It opens daily at 8a.m. (9a.m. during Ramadan) and admission is 40dh (garden only) additional 20dh for museum admission.

Over Hyped and Over Priced. We love gardens and found some marvellous ones whilst in Morocco. But this was not one. First the price was about four times the average charge for garden. Secondly, it is a design which smacks of pastiche and derivativeness (e.g. the use of Chefchaouen type blue) with no eye for perspective or proportion. It is interesting to walk round but of limited creativity. Try instead the gardens in the Bahia Palace in Marrakech (10 DH), or Jardin Jnan Sbil gardens in Fes or the Moulay Ali Cherif Mausoleum in Rissani south east Morocco

A symphony of colour and shape. We liked everything about it - the tall green plantings with highlights of blue and yellow pots along the paths, the pond with its water lilies, the restrained use of bougainvillea, the impressive cobalt pavilion.

Peaceful gardens in the a chaotic city. The gardens are so peaceful, it is worth going there to get away from all of the noise. You cannnot believe you are in the middle of Marrakech when you are in the gardens, it is so peaceful in there. There was a small entrance fee but it was worth it as we got lots of good photographs in there. Definetly worth a visit.

One of THE sites to visit in Marrakesh. Really wonderful gardens once owned by Yves St Laurent.Not overly large so easily walked around and with seats to sit on. Informative small museum and nice cafe attached.
shady oasis. beautiful spot but very busy. Cafe charming lovely bazzar shop close to gardens- very nice quality at a price. Taxis close to exit. Go early or late to avoid overcrowding.
Not to be missed. A lovely environment. I would recommend bringing a book & staying a few hours.
A beautiful garden. This is an exquisite garden in the property owned by Yves Saint Laurent

An oasis of peace. These gardens are simply beautiful and well worth a visit. We also had coffee and ice cream in the little cafe, which was lovely, but expensive. Then again, Marrakech is very expensive everywhere.
Peaceful paradise. A quiet oasis. Well maintained. Beautiful colours.
Ok. The horse and carriage was the highlight of this trip but I did feel for the horses as it was very hot
Disappointingly small. Not much too it but what there is is pretty. I didn't feel it was worth the taxi fares to get there and the entrance fee.
Beautiful. Beautiful calm gardens - well worth a visit - can use the 'hop on hop off tourist bus to get there
Yves St Laurance. The fashion designer had an eye for colour that's for sure. Impressive cacti and bamboo but the garden wasn't as big as I expected. 40 dirham each to get in and the loos are free
Gorgeous gardens .... ...With a great history. The Museum GIft shop has some precious books, too.
A true Oasis. The biggest bamboo I have ever seen - and that includes the bamboo I've seen in bamboo. Very, very calm and quiet. Well worth the trip out of the main part of Marrakesh.
so colourful. a very pleasant way to spend an hour or so and the museum is a nice surprise

An oasis of calm.. This garden, once owned by Yves Saint Laurent, is an oasis of calm, away from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech.I've been twice and both times I have heard British people complaining about the lack of flowers.This isn't Kew Gardens, there are no bright flowers, but there is some fabulous cactus and brightly painted pots and buildings. And due to all the palm trees there is a welcome covering of shade.If you look carefully into the pool, you will see Terrapins among the water lillies.The cafe is a little pricey, but very nice. If you want a cheaper lunch, head out of the gardens and there are a couple of cafes down the road with a pizza for 30dh - £2.40.You can spend a good couple of hours here, so plan for half a day trip. It costs 40dh - £3.20 to get in and another 25dh if you want to see the museum (worth it I think)
Lovely and peaceful. This place is amazing peaceful considering where it is. There are some fantastic plants here and it's a nice place to come to get out of the hustle and bustle!
Magical. perfect, beautiful, the pasion of YSL lives on!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Oasis. Not huge but very beautiful in a structural rather than floral way. Recommended to keen gardeners. Very cool in the heat. Cafe very expensive.

Amazing gardens. Amazing gardens...but very popular and crowded.
The shop staff need to learn some manners...very miserable rude!

Beautifully relaxing, a great escape. Just a short petit taxi ride from Jemaa Fna, the Jardin Majorelle was a beautiful escape. On such a hot day, the shade was a relief, and the gardens are very impressive. The shops are also lovely to visit. We spent a couple of hours enjoying all aspects - dont forget your camera! We enjoyed a calache (horse and cart ride) back to the Koutoubia - slightly scary, but a fun, must-do experience. A great trip.
A little oasis. Beautiful gardens in the hart of Marrakech. It is amazing how cool the garden feels once you enter through the entrance door. the prices in the shop are ridiculous!
Colourful, cool and quirky. Loved it but it was a hot walk there so should have taken a taxi.

Small but lovely. We found the gardens and seemed very busy however on entering the crowd disappeared in the paths and we were leave to enjoy a tranquil place. 40 dirham to enter. Lovely turtles lurking in the lily pads. We enjoyed it.

A Beautiful oasis in Marrekech. Be sure to take a few hours out of your day to visit Jardin Majorelle when you are in Marrekech it is a very special treat. It is a beautiful oasis and such an extreme difference from the other sites in the city - beautifully restored; the garden with capture, mesmerize and enrapture you. The garden contains a memorial of Yves Saint Laurent - the genius that ensured that this garden that started in 1924 would continue to remain to be viewed by the public.Enjoy!

Fantastic Haven. The miracle starts as soon as you enter the garden, as the micro climate is very different from what you experience outside. The air is very moist and fresh. The plants and ponds are well kept, I have never so many types of cacti in one place. Good place to have a romantic, relaxing walk and to clean your lungs.

Fantastic - if you like Gardens. This garden largely consists of cactus and tall bamboo with a number of walkways and formal water features. It has an excellent cafe at the centre. For me it is Morocco meets design. It is busy but it is also calming. Well worth a visit. The staff are very friendly and helpful.

Unexpectedly beautiful and unique gardens in Marrakech. The Jardin Majorelle are beautiful gardens restored to their current state by Yves Saint Laurent and we really didn't expect them to be as uniquely beautiful as they are. It's a really nice walk through the garden and you don't feel at all that you are in Marrakech!The gardens close at 6pm so make sure you factor this into your plans.

Breathtaking. In a busy dusty city, these are truly stunning. Compact and charming, they are easy to get to (by taxi) a little outside of the main city. The colours are beautiful, and the trees provide lots of shelter. Not really a place for little'uns as there isn't really anything for them there other than the view, and cacti are spikey fellows to play with. A few turtles, fish, and visiting birds provide wildlife. Nice for a peaceful stroll, and to pass an hour away with a book.You can easily view the garden within 30 mins, but worth taking a little longer and relaxing. Unsure of museum, as it was sadly closed when I visited. Inexpensive entrance fee. Bags are searched upon entry. Could just about manage a wheelchair and buggie, but definitely an adult attraction. Try to visit early morning or late afternoon when less people around, as this is definitely a place to lose yourself in tranquility.

Simply wonderful, an oasis of calm in the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. Everything good you read about the gardens is true. We loved it, a beautiful garden and a fascinating little museum of Islamic art (at a small extra charge, maybe 20 dirham?).It's a reasonable way out of the centre - we took the opportunity to take one of the horse-drawn carriages to get there.

One of the prettiest gardens I've ever seen. Everyone in our group really enjoyed spending time here. It's not that big, but the way it's laid out you don't feel crowded even when there are many people nearby. Different sections have different types of foliage, and the color scheme is gorgeous throughout. The vibe was calm and happy and it's beautifully maintained.

Yves Saint Laurent must be dissapointed if he can see!!. Dedicated to Yves Saint Laurent. I feel sorry for the talented guy. I was expecting sheer paradise, beauty. Despite it's location it was a peaceful oasis. But not beautiful. Not very many flowers and not pretty or beautiful at all except the entrance and the cafe area! Very disappointing!!
De-stress here!. Get out of the sun and the hussle of Marrakech with a trip to these gardens. The signature 'blue' in contrast to the dull yellow of central Marrakech is refreshing.A must.

Pretty but boring. Much smaller than seems to be advertised.Great if you like cacti and bamboo.Overpriced cafe.Overpriced Versace giftshop.Its main pluspoint is to keep the locals out and provides a respite from being hassled for a while.Hassling and haggling starts immediately outside with the taxi drivers.
Beautiful place. It is a must go in you are in Marrakech, it is so beautiful. Has a gifts shop and cafe/restaurant inside.

Beautiful little oasis but watch the staff!. I think we paid 40dhms each to get in. It's very beautiful and we spent probably 2-3 hours here. There is a quaint little French cafe inside that sells absolutely faultless food, I had a cheese omelette and it was the best omelette I've ever tasted. We spent a while in the cafe as it was much cooler than the garden which was like a sauna! There is a museum you can pay extra to visit, there is a gift shop and a room with some pictures in.. Not entirely sure what the point was but it was something to do with Yves Saint Laurent. I was too hot to care at that time. On our way out, one of the staff in the blue tshirts offered to take our picture, so we let him, but he required a tip for this. We didn't expect that but we probably should have! All-in-all a good trip but you only need to see it once so I'd not go back again.
Beautiful. We found the gardens beautiful, an oasis worth visiting! These garden's are an example that art is not just what is found on a canvas. Find it ... and enjoy!

Superb oasis!. The garden is amazing and only about 20 minutes walk from the new part of the city. It is also easy to find and well sign posted. Once you arrive it is a feast of colour and a variety of plants, that means you can walk through it enjoying the tranqulity. it has a stylish feel with the colours, layout and beautiful coulourful planters. the store is also a feast for the eyes and the house is beautifully decorated. the cafe is also worth sitting in though expensive for the venue. There are some lovely shops just outside the garden which are worth stopping at, since they are filled with Moroccian themed garments and goods. worth the visit.

Small but definitely worth visiting. It was a rainy day in Marrakech so we asked our guide to take us somewhere where there is hardly any rain or no rain at all. He told us we should visit the Jardin Majorelle. Because of the dense vegetation there was hardly any rain.They have a very large collection of plants and cactuses from around the world. The garden is very well kept. What I think was very sad is how so many people just had to engrave their names in the plants and bamboo. Besides that and the garden being very small this place is definitely worth visiting. We payed 40 dirham per person and we spent about 90 minutes in the garden. Which should be more then enough unless you would also like to sit and relax at the terrace.

Oasis in the chaos. It was a rainy cloudy day in marrakech so we decided to hop on a horse and carriage and visit the Majorelle Garden. The rain stopped the moment we got there which I knew was a good sign. The garden itself is tranquil, exotic and beautifully kept, there are an array of plants, ponds with various fish and even terrapins and plenty of places to sit and relax. After a few days of Marrakech madness, busy roads, haggling and a fast pace it was lovely to take it down a notch and relax for an hour in a relaxed haven in the city. If you don't want some quiet time then this isn't the place for you!

An escape within Marrakech. We took a small taxi over to the Jardin Majorelle to make sure we didnt get lost, and then spent about an hour or to jut enjoying the sound and relaxing nature of the gardens. The brightly coloured walls and pots complemented the fountains and flowers, and there was always somewhere to sit to enjoy to tranquil nature of the surrounding. The musuem of Yves St Laurent's famous outfits wasn't a highlight to myself but plenty of other peole enjoyed it and was something extra within the gardens. On the way back to the medina, the walk took a little over 30mins, and was a nice to see another section of Marrakech

Disappointed. Frankly don't see why everyone told us this was a must-do thing in Marrakech. Lots of cacti surrounded by gravel and bamboo. I was expecting a much larger garden. There were way too many people when we went mid-afternoon, maybe at other times of the day it's better. My wife liked it because of the Saint Laurent connection.

a must-see in marrakech. This is such a perfect spot to spend the afternoon! It is so serene and beautiful inside which makes it the perfect spot to escape the heat and chaos of marrakech. The ice-creams and sorbets there are amazing with their unique, traditional Moroccan flavours. The vibrant blue really complements the green of the plants and makes beautiful photographs.

Peaceful oasis (although shared with a lot of other tourists!). Don't miss it! It's well worth the 40dh entry fee (steep compared to entry at other sights, but still only a few £s).We walked from Djemaa El Fna and it took about 30-40 minutes at an easy pace and it was so lovely to sit and relax in the pretty surroundings. I spent a good while taking a lot of photos - all the bright coloured pots and pillars, and fresh green plants are beautiful. There are free toilets you may use and a cafe although we didn't buy anything from there.We went around midday and didn't have to queue to buy our ticket but when we leave an hour or so later there was a long line to get in so perhaps best to go in the morning.
Beautiful gardens, interesting museum.. The gardens are stunning and the museum has some interesting fashion designs by Yves Saint Lauren. A great place to sit and relax away from all the madness.

Overpriced and underwhelmed. We vistied the Majorelle Gardens in the middle of February.We had high expectations and came away thoroughly disappointed.The gardens were nice but very small and not worth the 40dhms entry fee.Not only that they are a good 1 hours walk from the square.The cyber gardens were much better and were FREE and are closer.If you like cactii then it might be worth a visit however if not dont bother.

The very definition of over-rated.. My sister and I expected some form of botanical gardens. What we received was a bunch of cacti and brightly coloured pots. Sure the vivid, lush blue was mesmerising to me as it is my favourite country, however the gardens were a rip-off and the restaurant was over-priced, and it's supposedly not allowed to eat in the gardens/to have a picnic, however to mine and my sister's luck the kind security guard allowed us to eat the cheaper, delicious wraps that we purchased from across the road. If you're in Marrakech don't waste your time here - it's only famous because it is affiliated with YSL and non-adventurous tourists - go and immerse yourself in the culture of Morocco and the souks.

Overpriced and underwhelmed.. Everyone said this was a must see when in Marrakech.Well it's 40DH to get in which is expensive for Marrakech. So the walls are painted a vibrant blue, and? Big deal guys! We had far more pleasure and relaxation In all the other city parks-the cyber parc is immaculate and peaceful and free.It's also tiny and can be walked round in about 3 minutes, if you have a limp!Really, save your money for chez yassine then chill in all the other gardens.To my mind it's another classic example of labelling, in this case YSL, for the designer crowd who have more money than sense. We won't be going back there.

A tourist attraction masquerading as a garden. By all means wander around there for an hour, because you shouldn't need much longer, but don't expect anything amazing. The colourful plant pots and buildings contrast with the greenery, and the pond in the centre is interesting to watch the frogs and turtles moving around the lily pads, but that's about the sum of the visit.The most disappointing thing for me was that this garden plays on the way that YSL 'gifted it' in perpetuity to the city and people of Marrakech. Except of course that 95% of visitors to the garden are tourists and the cost of entry pretty much rules out the great majority of the people of Marrakech from being able to see the gardens.I found the Cyber Parc to be just as interesting to walk around and because it was open to anyone it felt actually like a part of the city rather than some artificial 'westerners' hiding place.In summary, it was a nice garden and quite peaceful, but the cost and exclusory nature of it annoyed me.

Average...just a walk in a small park really. There is nothing wrong with the park but neither is it amazing. It's a collection of bamboo, palms and cacti in a small area that you have to pay to get into. There are plenty of palms and cacti in the Atlas mountains which make for a far more impressive trip. The cafe is nice if slightly more expensive than elsewhere. Also, rather oddly, the monument to YSL is very underwhelming given who it is there to commemorate...very austere and uninspiring. As I said, it's all ok but not, in my opinion, worth breaking your neck to get to see. Also, the taxis were lined up outside waiting to pounce on you and would not budge unless we would pay 15x what we paid to get there an hour earlier! Needless to say, we walked it!

Marrakech - beaty and peace in a great location. The Majorelle Garden is one of the most mysterious gardens... WonderfullYves Saint Laurent have given it to one fondation to ensure its continuing existence !!!If you are at Marrakech, idon't miss it, It is a great location and has a good cafeteria and a lot of peace !!!!Wonderfull place to go ... !!!!!!!!

Something SO special... I'm not sure if I can explain why I loved this place SO much, but the fact is that after visiting it I absolutely understood why was monsieur Laurent SO inspired by this garden :-)In a way, it was the most beautiful place I've been to in this flamboyant city :-) It's literally magical - even though there might be quite a lot of people around you, you can still get really calm here, meditate and relax. The nature here is a true, living organism that kindly welcomes you by a hug with all of its colours and scents. Please forgive me being a bit sentimental, but it's just the way this oasis made me feel :-)It's basically a kind of a botanical garden - lots of cacti, succulents and other exotic plants - but it's very special. The colours here are amazing (even on the toilets! :D), rich and very vivid, contrasts are almost eye-blinding in their expressiveness, and still at the same time, this place has the power to make you forget about everything and calm you down.Of course this is valid only for the type of people who LET it to do so and who enjoy these kind of things - nature, flowers, peace and a bit of philosophy maybe :-) If you're not into nature that much, it would probably be a waste of time for you. But if you'd like to just sit and admire the power of nature for a while, please don't hesitate :-)

Pleasant but disappointing. I can only agree with the previous reviewer.The gardens are pleasant if it is not crowded but they were much smaller than I expected and the cafe prices were astronomical compared to other cafes in the medina.

a nice garden, but nothing too special. I went to Majorelle Garden as it's described as the most beautiful and peaceful place in Marrakech. And I was disappointed. It is a nice garden, full of green plants with a lovely blue colour building where the ISL museum is, but it's nothing special, really. And as it is very small, it's very crowded. Also the cafe inside has the highest prices I have seen in Marrakech. Go there if you like, but you won't miss much if you don't. And if you fancy some peace and quiet time with no noisy people around, go to the Menara Garden. It's much bigger, with a lovely pond in the middle and if the weather is good, you will be able to see the Atlas Mountains above the city from there.

A breath of fresh air!. Majorelle Garden might be one of the most peaceful places in Marrakech. While impossible to avoid other people completely, it's a good place to find a moment of tranquility in this hectic city (and escape the smog!). Filled with plants and vibrant colors, it can be hard to imagine you're still in Marrakech inside these walls...highly recommend!

Don't waste your time and Money!. The garden is only seems relatively OK, as the rest of Marrakech is so bad. If you just want to get away from the people accosting you for an hour its OK. I'm no gardener, but half the garden is giant bamboo (All the same species) the other half is cacti, and a few succulents and datura's thrown in here and there in between. The memorial to YSL is a lump of "Greek" type column. It doesn't seem very fitting, or what he might have chosen! If you do go, have a peep over the walls into the neighbouring (Private) gardens they are better! We went in December 2010, and the price has gone up 25% to 40 dirams each. We found a "free" garden behind the Koutoubia Mosque, close to the "Big Square" Which is just as good, but still not worth the trip to Morroco.If your idea of a holiday is to stay somewhere like the slums of Slumdog millionaire, then you will love it, otherwise stay away.

Expected Florishing Colors...Just Cactus & Greens. Thought I'd be seeing some nice floral & exotic plants, but instead it was mostly cactus. Coming from Florida where it can be a tropical paradise, I was not impressed. Although it was a tranquil walk thru the gardens, I wouldn't do it again. The best part about it was the cafe' where we had some great Morrocan Mint Tea and coffee. The presentation is so impressive that I posted a quick video...http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=50QTOqaxcWA

A place to get some rest. A great place to spend an hour or two just hanging around, relaxing. Pleasantly green and calm, might get bit crowdy at times. If you're into taking photos (who isnt't ;) - a cool place do go - the colors are incredible.

Relaxation. We fitted the gardens in on our last day and to be honest we did expect much (dry desert gardens often look bare and boring) - how wrong we were
This is a colourful, vibrant and beautiful garden designed by a genious. Its extremely realxing and should be a priority on any Marrakech itinerary.

This was a really nice place to go and.... This was a really nice place to go and see we spent a lot of time just sitting around And taking in all the plants and just the atmosphere... It was a nice change to the very busy parts of Marrakech... Well worth the 30mad we paid to get in..

An oasis in Marrakech. The concierge at our hotel wisely recommended that we visit the Jardin Majorelle late in the day, in order to avoid the crowds. We went an hour before closing, which leaves plenty of time to visit the garden, small museum, and boutique. This is a very beautiful and tranquil place and is a real oasis away from the hussle and bustle and heat of Marrakech. The only downside for us was that we were expecting a larger garden, but small as it was it was well worth a visit. The boutique sells beautiful embroidered cushion covers, much nicer than anything we saw in the souks.

Tranquil spot.... Hard to believe it's only 10 mins from the sweltering heat of Jemma El Fna when you arrive here and would say you needn't have a great knowledge of plants to appreciate the tranquility and beauty.Have no problem recommending this to anyone who'd like a little peace and quiet. Dare I say it's quite spiritual too?!Entrance is only 30 MD but when inside, the prices both in the shop and cafe, are VERY high!Taxis and the little stall outside the entrance seem to see this as a bit of a tourist trap and inflate their prices accordingly. Having said that, prices not in the least expensive compared to UK and if you have the energy to haggle, I'm sure the prices would be reduced a bit! Great way to spend a couple of hours or so.

good if you are have a cactus fetish for 10 minutes. Writing this review to balance out all the 5 star recommendations. Couldn't understand the positive reviews from the photos I could see. Thought there must be more to it. Spent 10 minutes inside, and although relatively cheap (30 MD per person), you are very quickly bored. There are lots of cacti, but it's definitely not worth going out of your way to see.I can't imagine how some people say it's their favourite thing about Marrakech. Did they not go to the High Atlas mountains, through Ourika Valley? Play with the performers in Jemaa El Fna square at night? Go for a hammam and massage at a spa? Go on a cooking course with at a local Berber village?I've posted some photos, but they are nicer than the real thing. Perhaps we're spoilt, having been through the bamboo forests in Saga-Arashiyama (Japan) and Kew Gardens and the Eden Project (England), but I would give this a miss unless you REALLY needed a short break from the Souks.

Beautiful garden's, a wonderful haven.. Really lovely walking around the garden, it's not massive but meander round and enjoy the peace and quiet, bright colours and pretty plants.Got to see a man trimming off the palm trees with just a rope as his safety harness!Lovely place, highly recommended.

Lovely place. Lovely gardens. A short visit is more than enough. The cafe is not cheap but it is very picturesque, good French food (in case you want a break from all the Moroccan food) and efficient service. The cafe has misters to help with the heat. Nice store. Garden gets pretty crowded, not very meditative.

You haven't visited Marrakech if you don't visit these gardens.. Marjorelle Gardens was one of the attractions I wanted to visit on our recent trip to Marrakech as I'm interested in different garden styles. I certainly wasn't disappointed. There was a cooling and calming atmosphere to the place as we walked along the pathways through the various garden rooms. I was quite taken by the colours which dominated - yellow, blue and orange, and the plants blended so well with these. The cacti garden is quite superb and extensive and quite a photographer's paradise with the many varieties of cacti and the interesting ways they show themselves through their flowers and spikes. Even my husband said it was one of the best he'd walked through! A must on a visit to Marrakech.

Moroccan Paradise. This beauty of nature welcomed me to my trip to Morocco. This garden is a great place to go to in Morocco and I advise all tourists going to Morocco, This is a must with all its nature, fountains and beauty!

Pleasant enough on a hot day. We went on a hot morning in June 2010. Arrived and departed by Caleche, costing about 100 MDH for each trip. Quite a nice garden, made up of various palms, some shady spots, and a cactus garden. The courtyard cafe is pleasant with cooling mist jets and we had lunch there. It is rather expensive though, costing about £10 each for a panini with salad. The museum was closed when we were there.

Stunning garden sanctuary in the heart of the city. Land purchased by Frenchman and Artist, Jacques Majorelle, who planned the landscaping.. The garden has been open to the public since 1947.It a serene garden full of "architectural" type of cactii, bamboo,palms and plants native to Morocco. Exceptionally well kept - good walkways. A camera is an absolute must!! The house, which is a museum, was closed for renovation during our visit (April 2010). There is a cafe (did not try it) and also a "boutique" shop selling very expensive items!Since Majorelle's death in the 60's, Yves Saint Laurent (died 2008) and Pierre Berge bought and restored the property and subsequently established a trust to ensure the continued furure of the garden. Give at least two hours to vist and take in the beauty and calm of this lovely garden.

Like a Physchadelic Experience. It is one of the best places in the world. Mind easing and perception shifting. The colors make you feel in heaven. The smell and the sound of birds, fantastic. It is one of the places that you never want to leave. Makes you promise that you would build a garden like that as soon as possible. Do not ever miss that is the only attraction that worth it in Marrakesh.

Photographer's delight.. The Jardin Majorelle is a peaceful, cool & tranquil respite from the hot , bustling medina of Marrakech.A photographer's delight ,there are so many opportunuties to capture the perfect arty shot of the striking, spiky cactus against the cool backdrop of the 'Rive Gauche' blue artists studio.I strongly reccomend the beautiful courtyard cafe for lunch or a refreshing drink, we sampled the lovely, fresh salad Majorelle which was enough for 2. I also reccomend trying one of the many different teas on offer.All in all a definite must when visiting Marrakech.

Beautiful and atmospheric. I read that this garden was small and very nearly didn't make the effort to go. Small it may be - but it is a "must see". The birdsong alone was worth the visit (in March) to this garden of several sectors - notably the tall bamboo garden with many different sorts of bamboo and the cactus garden with all sorts of mature shaped cacti. Superb use of water enhances the garden and creates a great tranquil atmosphere - despite the large number of visitors. The courtyard tearooms are probably the most beautiful I have ever visited, if expensive by local standards.

Perfect Oasis. These beautiful gardens are a lovely respite from the crowds of the Medina. The tranquility of the gardens makes it hard to believe you are in the city centre. The staff was helpful and friendly, offering to take photos. Not too big, perfectly manageable!Thank you Yves Saint Laurent!

Well worth a look - but its art museum was closed. We spent about an hour or so there, getting there quite early before the crowds.Unfortunately we were disappointed to learn on arrival (March 2010) that the Museum of Islamic Art within the grounds was closed for renovation. There was nothing to indicate this on their website and no indication at the entrance for a reopening date. You don’t need a map, not that there is one, just wander along the paths. It is more of a plant garden than a flower one, but very nice. The cacti were impressive and set off nicely in gravel. Some of the large succulents and bamboo had graffiti on where people had scratched their names, unbelievable that people would do this.There were a couple of particularly good spots for taking photos, by the ponds, and some benches dotted around where you can sit.Wouldn’t think they do much business in the café as prices were exorbitant, but at least they have the menu with prices displayed outside.

beautifull. I went there at 12 o'clock. Outside the jardin majorelle it was about 40 degrees, but there it was so cool. The garden is really beautifull, al sorts of plants, flowers, fountains, Lots of colors. There is also a little restaurant where you can take lunch or drink something. Food is very good quality.
Calm earthly beauty with vibrant colors. Tranquil & serene beauty, with vibrant colors. A cool, shaded and calm atmosphere after a juggling day in Marrakech.

paradise on earth. The most beautiful place ever , very colorful and romantic ,went with my husband on our honey moon early December 2009 ,.Breath taking ,people were whispering in respect to the silence in there .Would definitely go again if i get the chance .Just 5$=30 Durhams .A must see in Marrakech

Dont miss it!!. it is a def. must sightseeing in marrakech. We spent like 2 hours here. i just loved the atmosphere. botanic garden, its cafe, galerie...it is the place where u can rest little bit...(after busy tiring tourist trap jemaa el Fena)
Small but beautiful!. A lovely garden to visit and take some beautiful photos. It was quite small but worth a look!

fantastic garden. Nothing can really prepare you for what a lovely oasis amonst all the mayhem of Marrakech this is.there must be thousands of photo opportunities here.The cafe if rather pricey is a lovely spot for a pot of mint tea.Try to arrive early to avoid the crowds.Will only take 1-1/2 hrs for a visit. Relax & enjoy the tranquility

Luxe, calme et volupte!. I visited the Majorelle Gardens (also known as the Yves St Laurent Gardens) twice during my visit to Marrakech. I was bowled over. The artist Majorelle designed these beautiful tranquil gardens then they were bought and brought back to life latterly by St Laurent. Cacti, fountains, beautiful tiled walkways and stunningly colouted pots and bamboos. All a haven of peace and style, with the crowning glory, teh stunning blue pavillion (the artist's former studio). Definitely a must see - then worth a revisit and a revisit.... DON'T GO TO MARRAKECH WITHOUT VISITING THIS!!!

Tranquil Oasis & Great for Portrait Photography. This tranquil cactus garden provides a very lovely space in which you can just relax ,and contemplate whatever it is that you need to think about come the time. It is immaculately maintained, a cool retreat from what can be a stinking hot city during May & June, and it's also an easily manageable size, so definitely well worth a visit. Bring your camera for pics of weirdly shaped cacti, and great portrait shots of your co-traveller. I don't know if we were just lucky on the 40 degree celcius day we were there, but the light was perfect for portrait photography. Picturesque backdrops in all directions - really fab.
Colourful garden. It's a great garden with a lot of contrasting coulours from the walls and vases.

Oasis of green tranquility. This is a great place to go to shake of the dust and heat of Marrakech. A 10dh taxi ride from the Place Djemma el Fna could be a million miles away. Entered from a slightly incongrous alley past some new building development you step through the gate into another world. Entry to gardens only was 30DH/person. The Museum of Islamic Art was closed for renovation when we visited but when it is open you can get a joint ticket for both attractions.It was quite busy with visitors when we went but it still remains calm and quiet. The high growth of much of the plants brings a lovely cool shade around much of the gardens. I'm no botanist and couldn't tell my bougainvilea from my jacaranda (and probably cant spell them either) but so many of the plants are spectacular. I loved the grouping of cacti for example.On a negative note, watch the charges in the cafe. It is a welcome chance to stop for a mint tea as you are not allowed to consume your own picnic. However, 2 juices, a mint tea and a small plate of pastries set us back 250DH, approx £21. A bit steep in my view.
Beautiful Garden. I loved the place. Was a nice little oasis amid the heat and hubbub of the city.Check out my photoshttp://www.shareapic.net/content.php?id=16930563&owner=arinum

Adorable sight. If you are tired of walking in the noisy streets, Majorelle gardens are very refreshing exprience. The atmosphere is amazingly peaceful and relaxing (expecially if you visit there straight on the morning). We loved the fountain and stylish colours everywhere. I think the Majorelle gardens are one of the best attractions in Marrakech.

Serene Beauty- Gorgeous morning light. Go right when it opens 9 am. It is so peaceful and beautiful. The gift store is pricey as is the cafe- but to be surrounded by such a well-maintained diverse garden- it is worth every dirham.
Pleasant surroundings..... We enjoyed our relaxing walk through the garden. Nice enough escape from the hustle and bustle although the garden is not big at all.

Crowded!. For my first three days in Marrakech in early March, it seemed like there were few tourists. But this place was very crowded with tourists. I'm sorry I didn't take the advice I read about going there first thing in the morning.

Little Jewel. This is a lovely garden and was probably my favourite site in Marrakech (other than the daily goings on at the Jemaa el Fna). It is quite small. I too expected it to be larger, but it was lovely and well worth it. The mere juxtaposition of palm trees and cactus gardens make it worth it as does the Majorelle blue. It's unreal. Go early to avoid the crowds. We arrived by 11am. I don't recommend arriving later. There was a massive queue by the time we left.

Beautiful and Pleasant. I would say take a few minutes before travelling and read up on the history of the garden and its relative recent restoration (its not boring , honest!)It is a pleasant getaway, as other reviewers have said. My wife and I did see plantation and beauty we had not previously encountered and did feel very relaxed and cool as we strolled around the garden. We did appreciate what the garden offered and did go into the museum of islamic arts and found it interesting (we are muslim by faith and so this is obviously ones own choice whether to pay the little extra and go in)Overall a very relaxing experience and recommended.

Nice escape from the city. Went to the Majorelle Gardens recently, very pleasant gardens with some very impressive plants and architecture. Great way to escape the city, its very peaceful inside and all the water and greenery makes you feel cooler & calmer. There is also a museum of islamic arts (we didnt go in as you had to pay extra), a small boutique and a cafe (not sure how another reviewer missed these?). The cafe makes really nice fruit drinks, although not cheap for Morocco standards.Only down sides were , slightly busy for its size . We seemed to arrive the same time as two coach loads of french tourists. The other is the taxi`s waiting outside asking exuberant prices, our Riad was only a 10 min walk away but due to a sandstorm we wanted a taxi. They were trying to charge us 60 dirham, instead of a normal 10-20 dirham. Managed to find one for 20 in the end.

Overrated. From reading our guidebook we thought this was going to be much larger and more beautiful than it is. You can walk around it in about ten minutes and as it's a bit of a hike out of the medina I don't think it's worth the effort. We did use getting there as an excuse to have a trip in a caleche and that was the best bit! It does have some good cacti but other than that it is just tiny lawns you're not allowed to walk on, and practically no flowers. There is nowhere to buy a drink or even any toilets so you can't linger for a few hours even if you wanted to. There were lots of people visiting so it obviously gets good reviews in all the guidebooks but personally, I thought it was disappointing.

Not the oasis I expected. I had heard a lot about these gardens and went there expecting an oasis of tranquility where I could sit in peace for a few hours and read my book. When I got there I found that it was very crowded, with tourists occupying every bench and people walking along every path. The blue building and colourful pots lining the paths were very beautiful but I ended up doing just one round of the place and leaving, as I thought I could find more peace in a cafe! Maybe I went at the wrong time of day (just after lunch) and things are different in the AM...

Perfect to escape the marrakech heat!. This garden had plants and flowers from all of over the world, which were pretty interesting to look at. However the best thing was that you could walk around in pleasant and cool surroundings unlike the medina in marrakech where its usually too hot!

Oasis of beauty in the middle of the madness. While I love hustly, bustly Marrakech, there are some times when you want a bit more tranquility and you'll find it here. The Jardin Majorelle is about a 25 min walk from the Djeema - I recommend getting a cab instead! The Jardin Majorelle was created by the artist Jacques Majorelle and has a huge cactus collection, as well as various other flowers. The blue villa is a gorgeous building. The shade of blue contrasts with the white doorways and yellow railings. There's also a lot of streams and ponds, complete with a huge turtle population. Nice way to spend a few hours
